                            Books by the Author

1. The Race of Grace—introductory book in which performance related
    themes (such as perseverance) are considered essential for rewards in
    heaven. Entrance into heaven, in contrast, is regarded as free. A strong
    defense of unconditional security derived from believers being given to
    Jesus is a particular strength of this book.
2. Is Heaven a Gift or a Reward?—while some assert that heaven is a
    reward in some sense, this book maintains that regarding heaven itself
    as a gift is best.
3. Breaking the Rocking Horse—introductory book regarding the
    distinction between having eternal life as a gift versus obtaining it as a
    reward. An overview of the outer darkness and an exegetical treatment
    of the parable of the soils are this book’s primary strengths.
4. Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity—a more comprehensive
    discussion regarding perseverance (and other performance related
    themes) as being needed for rewards in heaven rather than for entrance
    into heaven. This book provides both introductory material and
    advanced treatments.
5. Woolly Wolves and Woolless Sheep—a rejection of the notion that
    profession of salvation is proven genuine by the way a person lives. This
    book focuses on the parable of the sheep and the goats and shows the
    inadequacy of conditional security in interpreting this parable.
6. Sheep and Goats—an advanced discussion of the parable of the sheep
    and goats that evaluates four interpretations that are compatible with
    unconditional security.
7. Sealed and Secure—a thorough defense of a popular argument for
    unconditional security that also defends the premise of unconditional
    promises.
8. Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection—an advanced defense of
    unconditional security which affirms that believers can fall from grace
    but not fall from perfection.
9. Salvation—a study of how the verb save and the noun salvation are used
    in the NT. A comprehensive chart of NT usage is provided.
10. Believe—an aspectual defense of unconditional security that examines
    how the verb believe is used in the Gospel of John. A comprehensive
    chart of metaphors for believe in the Gospel of John is provided also.
11. Carnal Corinth—an affirmation of the categorical existence of carnal
    Christians within the Corinthian epistles.
12. The Outer Darkness—a magnum opus that ties together the author’s
    arguments for unconditional security and conditional rewards.

    See UnconditionalSecurity.org for the release status of these books.

                             Symbols
;    Not or apart from
⊂    Subset or virtually contained in
⊆    Subset or equal to (at least in extent)
⊄    Not subset or not virtually contained in
∩    Intersects
∩⁄   Does not intersect
z    Punctiliar instantaneous action
z  ▬ Punctiliar action with perfective state
z▬▬ Punctiliar action with permanent perfective state
£    Linear ongoing durative action
→    Sequence or descriptive aspect
⇒    If-then conditional statement so that A ⇒ B means: If A then B.
⇐    Inverse conditional statement so that A ⇐ B means: If B then A.
⇔    If-and-only-if so that A ⇔ B means: If A then B and if B then A.
⇔xxx If-and-only-if condition that is linearly and contingently punctuated.
∴    Therefore
=    Equal
≠    Not equal
 Cyclic mutualistic codependency
{¨   Externally punctiliar aspect with internal linear aspect
{    Externally  punctiliar aspect with internal non-stated aspect
{…   Externally punctiliar aspect with internal customary aspect
~    Externally punctiliar aspect with internal punctiliar aspect
 Externally linear aspect with internal non-stated aspect
 Externally linear aspect with internal distributive punctiliar aspect
 Externally linear aspect with internal distributive punctiliar aspect
{ ⋮  Externally punctiliar aspect with internal distributive aspect
{⋱   Externally punctiliar aspect with internal distributive aspect

                        Technical Terms
        Antinomian is derived from anti+nomos (anti-law) and refers to
those who are against the law. They are also known as libertines—those
liberated from the law. Legalists love to charge non-legalists with being
antinomians (i.e. teachers of lawlessness). Since Paul was a non-legalist, he
was reported slanderously as saying, “Let us do evil that good may come”
(Rom 3:8). This defamatory trend still survives today. Some so-called
Lordship Salvationists calumniously say that those who teach free grace are
teaching that the way a person lives does not matter. This would be true only
if rewards do not matter. Perhaps this is the background for some of the
criticism. So-called Lordship Salvationists can appeal to the popular
sentiment that rewards do not matter. For many, the only thing that matters
is heaven versus hell. So if you stress that the doctrine of heavenly rewards
provides a compelling reason to live a good life, then you have said (from
their perspective) that the way you live does not matter. Nevertheless,
biblical Christianity will remain a balance between legalistic and libertarian
extremists.

       Arminianism is a branch of conditional security which teaches that
God contingently predetermines that those who persevere will be chosen
(elected) for heaven.* Human perseverance is the condition for divine
election. The free will of the believer is emphasized. In Arminianism,
reaching heaven is conditioned on the believer’s perseverance. (Arminians
may be defined broadly at the popular level as those who believe that
regeneration actually might be lost.) The Arminian order of conditional
results is: perseverance, then predestination, then heaven. Arminianism is
summarized by the acronym PEARS:



*
  Technically, some Arminians affirm the unconditional corporate election of
those in Christ but make perseverance in faith the condition for remaining in
Christ. Those particular individuals who persevere in faith are conditionally
predestined for heaven. Hence, this approach simultaneously affirms conditional
particular predestination. Other Arminians affirm the election of individual
believers. Being elected is conditioned on being a believer. This latter Arminian
approach is less convoluted. Either way, the bottom line remains the same: In
Arminian theology, only those who persevere are elected for heaven.
Consequently, Arminians may be described as teaching conditional election (in
regard to the individual).
Page xiv                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

•   Prevenient Grace—means God’s preparatory grace by which He takes
    the prerequisite step of providing mankind with the pragmatic ability to
    search for Him and find Him in saving faith.
•   Election on Condition—means that God conditionally has elected all
    mankind to salvation. However, God has only predestined that those
    who of their own free will respond in faith to this offer of salvation and
    persevere in this faith will be saved. Predestination is thus conditioned
    on persevering faith.
•   Atonement for All—means that the atonement is available sufficiently
    for all mankind, and its efficaciousness is limited only by their response.
•   Resistible Grace—means that God’s prevenient grace may be resisted
    so that it does not result in salvation.
•   Salvation through Perseverance—means that God’s grace is not only
    resistible; it is also reversible. Believers may fall irremediably from the
    state of saving grace if they fail to persevere. Those who persevere are
    elected to salvation from eternal damnation as a result of persevering.
    Believers must persevere in order to be saved in the end. This doctrine
    also is popularly known as NOSAS, which stands for not once saved
    always saved. This form of NOSAS affirms that one actually may lose
    one’s regeneration and cease to be saved if one does not persevere.

       Bema is a transliteration of the Greek word used in 2Cor 5:10 to refer
to the Judgment Seat of Christ, and will be used repeatedly in the present
book as an abbreviated reference to the Judgment Seat of Christ. Christians
are judged at this judgment seat after the rapture. Unbelievers are judged
1,000 years later at the Great White Throne Judgment—the thronos of
Rev 20:11.

       Calminianism = Calvinism + Arminianism. The term Calminianism
was popularized by Norman Geisler in his endeavor to adopt a mediating
position between Calvinism (TULIP)* and Arminianism (PEARS).† His
Calminian approach basically takes the point of agreement between the two
systems regarding the soteriological‡ necessity of perseverance and replaces
the Arminian S of PEARS with a synthesis of the Calvinistic P from
TULIP.§ The end result is an abbreviated PS Calminian acronym.1

*
  See Calvinism, xv.
†
  See Arminianism, xiii.
‡
  See Soteriology, xxv.
§
  In S those who persevere are predestined, while in P those who are predestined
persevere. Geisler attempts to reject any logical order between perseverance and
predestination. Other Calminians do not necessarily reject a logical order.
Technical Terms                                                        Page xv
       Regardless of the preferred full acronym for Calminianism, final
salvation from hell comes through perseverance in all forms of
Calminianism (as well as in Calvinism and Arminianism). By definition,
then, Calminianism is a mediation between Calvinism and Arminianism
that, like its two predecessors, makes perseverance necessary for
salvation from eternal damnation. Since the present book does not make
perseverance necessary for salvation from eternal damnation, it should be
categorized separately from Calminianism. Contrary to Calminian claims
otherwise, in making perseverance descriptively necessary, Calminianism
also necessarily makes perseverance prescriptively necessary: both
exegetically and logically. The present book rejects any and all Calminian
attempts at harmonization in favor of a Marrowistic mediation which teaches
that perseverance is necessary for rewards in heaven rather than for entrance
into heaven itself.

        Calvinism is a branch of conditional security which teaches that God
sovereignly determines (i.e., elects) who will persevere and thus will make it
to heaven. Divine election is the basis for human perseverance. The
sovereignty of God is emphasized. The elect persevere because they are
unconditionally predetermined by God to persevere so that they might reach
heaven. Calvinists sometimes like to present themselves as advocates of
unconditional security, but actually Calvinism is a failed attempt to enjoin
unconditional security with conditional security. The Calvinist might assert
that the believer is unconditionally assured of reaching heaven, but what a
Calvinist actually means with such an articulation is that the believer is
unconditionally assured of persevering, thereby reaching heaven. In
Calvinism, reaching heaven is conditioned on the believer’s perseverance.
The Calvinistic order of conditions and result is: election, then perseverance,
then heaven. Calvinism is summarized by the acronym TULIP:
• Total Depravity—means total inability. Man is totally unable to believe
     the gospel unless God acts upon him with irresistible grace in
     regeneration. Regeneration, at least in its incipient form, must precede
     belief. God regenerates man so that man may believe in accordance with
     his new nature.
• Unconditional Election—means that God unconditionally elects who
     will believe and be saved. Man is not elected because he believes.
     Rather, he believes because he is elected. God predetermines who will
     believe and be saved. It was never God’s intention to save the nonelect.
     Election is selection. God pre-selects who will believe and causes them
     to believe. No one else genuinely can believe the gospel. No one else
     will persevere in saving faith. No one else can be saved.
• Limited Atonement—means that the benefits of the atonement are
     extended only to the elect. In summary, Christ died only for the elect,
     not for the nonelect. God limited the available benefits of Christ’s death
Page xvi                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
    to the elect. God never had any true intention of making salvation
    possible for everyone.
•   Irresistible Grace—means that God irresistibly causes the elect to
    become regenerate so that the elect will believe. Regeneration,
    therefore, precedes faith. Faith is a gift from God that the elect do not
    have the power to refuse.
•   Perseverance of the Saints—means that saints who persevere are
    preserved and thus saved, in the end, as a result of their perseverance.
    Only those who persevere are preserved. Preservation does not apply to
    those who do not persevere. Thus, perseverance of the saints is not to be
    confused with eternal security of the saints. Only the elect persevere,
    and they persevere because they are predestined to persevere. Yet they
    must persevere in order to reach heaven. From the perspective of
    unconditional election, this model teaches OSAS (once saved always
    saved). However, from the perspective of conditionality, this model
    teaches NOSAS (not once saved always saved). This form of NOSAS
    affirms that one hypothetically may lose one’s regeneration and cease
    to be saved if one does not persevere.

      Common Grace is the universal enablement of God that enables
human beings to exercise good will toward one another and perform socially
good works. Its positive influence restrains evil and upholds civil justice.
This universal level of grace is insufficient so as to enable the lost sinner to
respond savingly toward God, much less to seek God or have stirring of
good will toward God.

        Common-Prevenient Grace* is a universal call to fallen humanity
that begins as the individual’s first stirring of good toward God in response
to an internal, effective, general, supernatural call from God. This initiatory
draw uses general revelation (i.e., nature, history, and conscience) as its
instrument and enables the lost to respond positively toward God. This
general call, however, is insufficient for salvation. If one responds to the
initiatory stages of this prevenient grace so as to begin seeking God through
enabling grace, one may advance to the point where God will give special
revelation with the explicit message of salvation that is sufficient for
salvation.

*
 Common-Prevenient Grace is a coined term used herein to fill the gap created
between common grace and prevenient grace by those libertarians (such as
myself) who restrict prevenient grace to special revelation. Additionally, my
belief that one may harden one’s heart by rejecting God’s drawing to the point
where the possibility of responding in saving faith is effectively withdrawn, also
necessitates the proposal of common-prevenient grace as an intermediate state.
Technical Terms                                                     Page xvii
       Alternately, upon final rejection of this universal prevenient draw,
one potentially might reach a hardened state in which one could only grope
for God in the sphere of common-prevenient grace without hope of finding
Him—that is, without being able to ever enter (or re-enter) the sphere of
prevenient grace proper. This later state, prevenient grace proper, is the
necessary sphere for saving faith to occur. Therefore, even though one may
search for God through the pages of Scripture (while in the sphere of
common-prevenient grace), doing so is insufficient to qualify for prevenient
grace proper if common-prevenient grace is not sufficiently accompanied by
the Spirit’s inward draw to advance to prevenient grace proper. The general
external draw effected by the explicit word of God is insufficient apart from
the internal, cooperative, effective drawing of the Holy Spirit. One must
have both in order to savingly believe the gospel.
                  Illustration 1. Common-Prevenient Grace




       Compatibilism is an affirmation of divine determinism that believes
that hard determinism is compatible with human freedom since
compatibilism defines freedom as the ability to act in accordance with
one’s prevailing internal desires rather than being forced to take a
particular course of actions by external control. This viewpoint, also known
as soft determinism, actuality is no less deterministic than hard determinism.
In the soft view, our internal desires are causally determined by the external
factors leading up to those desires so that we could not desire to do
otherwise. Secondly, we cannot do otherwise than what we desire to do.
Stated jointly, we cannot do otherwise than what we do because we cannot
do otherwise than what our external factors have compelled us to want to do.
In other words, God made a complex array of dominos to control our desires
Page xviii                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
and thereby control our actions. By knocking over (or pulling the rug out
from under) the first domino, God has set in motion a sequence of events
that causally determines our internal desires to the point of making us
irresistibly respond in the manner in which we (desire to) do. God has
remotely controlled our actions by putting in motion a chain of events that
make it impossible for us to do otherwise than what we do. God controls
our internal desires, and our internal desires control us. In short, God
controls us by controlling our internal desires. God controls our
character, and our character controls us.

       Condign merit is performance that incurs reward because Christ won
these rewards for us and contingently obligated Himself to us by promising
these rewards to us on the basis of our derivative moral merit. Although the
opportunity to earn the reward is not merited, the reward is merited. In short,
condign merit points to the obligatory nature of the reward.
Quantitatively, every reward is merited. Solely on the basis of God’s
gracious initiative, He makes it possible for us to earn rewards through His
enabling grace: grace-grace
                       merit -reward.


       Conditional security is the conviction that once a person believes in
Christ for eternal life, that person is conditionally secure in Christ and
conditionally assured of reaching heaven. According to conditional
securitists, a believer must persevere in order to reach heaven. (Both
proveitism and forfeitism advocate conditional security.)

       Conditionalist refers to an advocate of conditional security—the
conviction that once a person believes in Christ for eternal life, that person is
conditionally secure in Christ and must persevere in order to reach heaven.

      Congruent merit is performance that results in rewards that
graciously, yet proportionally, outweigh any effort that we may have put into
our character development or any improvement actually made in our
character as a result of that effort. In short, congruent merit points to the
excessiveness of the reward. Qualitatively, the scope of the reward far
exceeds what we deserve. As an expression of God’s grace, although all
rewards are based on merit, God rewards our works with greater benefits
than we deserve so that Marrowistic congruent merit is: merit-gracious
                                                                  works
                                                                       reward.


     Divine Essentialism asserts that God wills something because it is
good and right, because it is in accordance with the essence of His
immutable good nature.

       Divine Voluntarism in the Calvinistic camp means that something is
right and good just because God wills it.
Technical Terms                                                        Page xix

     Elect refers to those chosen by God to reach heaven in both
Arminianism and Calvinism. Biblically, the term may be used much more
comprehensively than what is suggested by these two schools of thought,
however.

       Forfeitist refers to an advocate of conditional security who believes
that those who do not persevere forfeit (i.e., lose) the gift of eternal life.

       Free Grace Salvationists are those who insist that the biblical
requirement for salvation from eternal damnation is that one simply believes
in the Lord Jesus for eternal life. This understanding is exemplified by the
Grace Evangelical Society (GES) motto: Faith Alone in Christ Alone. From
their perspective, unconditional security is guaranteed upon the recognition
that the free gift of eternal life is offered freely to one who simply believes
in Jesus Christ for eternal life.

       Free will (from the libertarian/incompatibilistic point of view) is the
is God-given ability for free agency exercised by the freed agents that allows
them to do otherwise than what their desires dictate, within God’s
parameters and time frames. Free will (from the soft-
deterministic/compatibilistic point of view) is the ability to act in accordance
with one’s prevailing internal desires which, in turn, are predetermined by
external factors. Free will is outright denied in hard determinism.

       GRAPE—see Marrowism, xxi.

       Incompatibilism is the denial that free will is compatible with soft
determinism (i.e., compatibilism) or with hard determinism. In short, it is the
affirmation that one is freed (by the grace of God) not to act in accordance
with one’s prevailing desires.

        Initial justification is the justification granted when a person first
becomes a believer. Final justification is the justification necessary for a
believer to reach heaven at the end of his or her life. According to
conditional security, initial justification may be by faith alone but final
justification necessarily includes perseverance in faith and faithfulness.

       Insecuritist refers to an advocate of conditional security.
Perseverance (in faith and/or faithfulness) is the postconversional condition
for reaching heaven according to insecuritists.

       Libertarianism is the true affirmation of human freedom in which
prior factors are not seen as sufficient conditions to explain all of our
Page xx                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
choices. This does not mean that our actions are uncaused, of course. Rather,
they are self-caused. A person’s actions do not cause themselves; the person
himself causes his own action. This viewpoint is synonymous with self-
determinism. From the libertarian perspective, a person must be free to do
otherwise than what his or her internal and external factors dictate in order to
be morally responsible for his or her actions. Free agents must be free to
determine their own actions. This is not to say that their actions occur in a
vacuum, but free agents sometimes act contrary to their desires, and, in
doing so, they can have a dynamic effect upon our desires. Libertarian
freedom is therefore the ability to act contrary to external and internal
impulses.
       When the Scripture commands us to “let your character be free from
the love of money” (Heb 13:5), it thereby indicates that we have some
control over our character. Not only does our character mold us, but we
mold it (Rom 5:4). When the Bible says, “You shall not desire your
neighbor’s house” (Dt 5:21), it is taking libertarian freedom for granted in
telling us that we have culpable control over what we desire. When Paul
exhorts believers to “earnestly desire the greater gifts” (1Cor 12:31), he
assumes that they are free to determine their own desires (cp. 1Cor 14:1). In
fact, Paul gives believers a course of action which they may follow so that
they will not have to carry out the desires of the flesh (Gal 5:16). They have
a choice as to which desires they will obey: those of the flesh versus those of
the Spirit. We choose what desires we will obey. Believers are not slavishly
obedient to their strongest desires. Obviously, Paul is not a compatibilist,
much less a hardcore determinist. It is possible, on occasion, to base our
actions on our convictions and principles rather than simply on what we
want to do.

       Lordship Salvationists are those who maintain that some form or
degree of surrender to Christ as Lord of one’s life is biblically necessary for
salvation from eternal damnation. Actually, from an exclusively logical and
biblical standpoint, those (such as myself) who are opposed to today’s so-
called Lordship Salvation affirm that the only way to be saved from hell is to
submit to the Lordship of Christ in terms of believing in Christ for eternal
life. The Lord has commanded that we believe in Him for eternal life.
Therefore, to believe in the Lord Jesus for eternal life is to submit to the His
lordship in terms of what is necessary for eternal life. Genuine Lordship
Salvationists correctly insist that one must submit to the Lord’s will as it
pertains to having eternal life by believing in Jesus (rather than one’s
performance) for eternal life.
       As a theological term, however, the designation Lordship Salvation
has come to be associated with those who condition salvation from eternal
damnation on one’s performance (or at least on one’s intent to change one’s
performance). They frequently will be referred to as pseudo Lordship
Technical Terms                                                       Page xxi
Salvationists in this book because they refuse to submit to what the Lord
actually demands for this type of salvation—simple faith. Because of the
popular association of the term Lordship Salvationists with these false
advocates of Lordship Salvation, however, unless noted otherwise, the
popular association will be adopted by default so that the unqualified term
Lordship Salvation will be understood herein in the popular (rather than
biblical sense) as denoting performance-based salvation.

       Linear faith (£ ) is ongoing faith that takes place over a period of
time. Although linear aspect is represented frequently by a line (—) in Greek
grammars, herein it is represented as an arrow so that a line can be used to
represent a state in contradistinction to an ongoing action.

        Marrowism is the present author’s coined term for describing his
mediating non-Calvinistic Free Grace theology, which is positioned between
Arminianism (PEARS) and Calvinism (TULIP) and summarized herein by
the author’s acronym GRAPE. Historically, this movement was expressed in
seminal form by the Marrow Controversy. In a number of key areas, the
present author may be considered a modern-day Marrowist. The present
book is an introduction to Marrowism as the present author has come to
refine and define it. The author’s fuller explanation will be detailed in his
book, The Outer Darkness. As used by the author, Marrowism refers to a
defense of unconditional security consisting of soteriological and
misthological consistency. Marrowism is summarized by the acronym
GRAPE:
• Gift is Free—means that the gift of eternal life is offered as a free gift
     and must be passively received as such.
• Rewards are Earned—means that the distinction between unmerited
     gifts and merited rewards must not be blurred.
• Absolute Assurance—means that personal assurance of one’s salvation
     from eternal damnation is the essence of saving faith.
• Passive Persuasion—means that faith is a passive persuasion, not an
     active commitment.
• Eternal Security—means that the person who trusts in Christ alone for
     eternal life immediately and eternally thereafter has eternal life and
     cannot experience eternal damnation. This doctrine of eternal security is
     known popularly as OSAS (once saved always saved) and is
     consistently and emphatically affirmed by GRAPE, in contrast to the
     conditional denunciation this doctrine receives in TULIP and PEARS.
     The affirmation of eternal security (E) is placed strategically at the end
     of the GRAPE acronym in order to contrast the most distinctive aspect
     of Marrowistic theology from the other two acronyms. Unlike
     Arminianism and Calvinism, Marrowism emphatically does not
Page xxii                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
    condition salvation from hell on the believer’s perseverance. GRAPE
    affirms true eternal security, not some Arminian or Calvinistic imitation
    of security. Marrowistic eternal security is unconditional security.

       Mistholic is an abbreviation for misthological (that has been
shortened syllabically to match its counterpart soteric, which, in turn, is the
abbreviation for soteriological).

       Misthologist: refers to an advocate of unconditional soteriological
security who has a sufficient degree of misthological competency so as to
recognize that the biblical teaching regarding the outer darkness pertains to
misthological themes so that salvation from the outer darkness depicts
conditional misthological security.

       Misthology is a coined term derived from the Greek word misthos
(reward) and logos (teaching) and refers to the doctrine of temporal and
eternal rewards but is used primarily in reference to eternal rewards.

        Monergism means to work alone and refers to the sovereign work of
God in which He is the necessary and sufficient cause in regenerating the
elect without dependency on their freewill synergistic cooperation. Although
broader than Calvinism, this view is associated typically with Calvinism.
Since synergism also affirms that regeneration is the work of God alone, the
crux of the dispute between monergism and synergism narrows down to the
fact that Calvinistic monergism places regeneration before faith so that it can
attribute initial faith exclusively to God’s work apart from freewill
synergistic cooperation. In terms of salvation apart from works, however,
this Calvinistic emphasis on saving faith being produced monergistically by
God is largely beside the point. Since Calvinism conditions final salvation
on the believer’s synergistic perseverance in faith, Calvinists are synergists
in relation to final salvation. Because Calvinism simultaneously teaches that
the elect are unconditionally elected to final salvation apart from their
cooperation, Calvinists have an irreconcilable tension created by their
making perseverance conditioned on their cooperation. As a result, some
Calvinists will even try to make perseverance a monergistic result.

        Nomian is a coined expression from the Greek word nomos (law) and
refers to legalists who believe that soteriological salvation is conditioned on
performance.

        NOSAS is the popular acronym for Not Once Saved Always Saved
(i.e., conditional security). Popularly, OSAS is not the same thing as
unconditional security in that many proveitists believe in OSAS yet insist
Technical Terms                                                       Page xxiii
that one must persevere in order to reach heaven. This hybrid by the
proveitist camp is not considered a valid form of OSAS in the present book.

       OSAS is the popular acronym for Once Saved Always Saved (i.e.,
unconditional security). Technically, OSAS is not the same thing as
unconditional security in that many proveitists believe in OSAS and yet
insist that one must persevere in order to reach heaven. Thus, reaching
heaven is conditioned by the proveitist camp on perseverance. This
proveitist hybrid is not a valid form of OSAS. The only form of OSAS
considered legitimate herein is the unconditional affirmation of OSAS even
if one does not persevere.

        Outer Darkness is a picturesque term used three times in the Bible
(Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30). The author’s book The Outer Darkness defends the
thesis that this term, when used in the Bible, refers to the loss of rewards in
heaven. For example, Charles Stanley’s popular book Eternal Security takes
much the same position. Exploring what such a loss would entail is beyond
the scope of the present work. Such matters have been explored in the
author’s major work on that subject. Suffice it to say here that since rewards
are eternal, loss of rewards is also eternal.

       Ordo salutis is a Latin term meaning order of salvation. In
theological discussions it pertains to the logical sequence of events that take
place regarding conversion.

       Overcomer is a coined expression used to refer to those believers who
overcome. Although the word overcome is used as a statement in Scripture
to refer to the positional victory already achieved by all believers in the past,
it sometimes is used in Scripture as an exhortation, urging believers to
progress on to achieve experiential victory in the present. Finally, it is used
futuristically as a promise of rewards to those relatively few believers who
will be victorious in faithfulness until the end, thus urging experiential
victory in the present. Its chief usage herein is as an exhortation and promise
for believers to become what they are so that they may rule as such.

       PEARS—see Arminianism, xiii.

       Pelagianism is a heterodox view of human monergism that asserts the
natural and moral human ability to initiate and consummate salvation by
exercising good will toward God apart from the grace of God.

       Performatist refers to someone who believes that good performance
on the believer’s part is necessary for entrance into heaven.
Page xxiv                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Prevenient Grace (proper) is the orthodox view of divine-human
synergism in which God initiates a pre-regenerative enablement that makes
it possible for a lost person to respond cooperatively in saving faith to the
gospel and thereby experience regeneration (in the form of impartation of
eternal life to one’s spirit). This form of grace, therefore, logically precedes
the regeneration of one’s spirit in sequence, efficiently restores the lost
person’s ability to respond positively to God by breaking the initial and
normative bondage of the enslaved human will to sin so that one no longer
has to respond negatively to God, supernaturally prevents one’s fallen will
from making a positive free response to God impossible, sufficiently arouses
the lost soul at the hearing of the gospel so that one can either resist the
gospel call and stay asleep in unbelief or allow oneself to become fully
awakened by the call to believe, partially opens one’s eyes to the truth of the
gospel so that one may either close one’s eyes in disbelief or allow one’s
eyes to be opened in saving faith, directly restores free agency so that the
constitutional free agent who is practically bound by sin pragmatically now
becomes the freed agent who may respond freely, instrumentally exerts
resistible persuasional force upon the intellect through the explicit gospel
that will be successful unless resisted, and internally creates a desire and
ability in one’s soul to respond positively to the gospel.

       Proveitists is a coined abbreviation for prove-it-tists: advocates of
prove-it theology. Many proveitists will object to being calling Calvinists.
Perhaps they are Calminians or closet Calvinists. In any event, the term
proveitists is used broadly to denote those who (like Calvinists) maintain
that the way a person lives proves whether that person is a genuine believer.
Proveitism asserts that fruit in the form of perseverance is necessary proof of
salvation: If you do not have this fruit, then you were never saved initially.
Perseverance is necessary to prove that you are saved and to enter heaven.
Calvinists, closet Calvinists, and Calminians would thus be included under
the proveitistic umbrella.

        Punctiliar faith (z) is a response of faith that takes place at a point in
time.

       Regeneration is the theological term used to describe the impartation
of eternal life as a free gift (to one’s spirit) which occurs when a person
believes in Christ for eternal life. Such a person is said to be born again (i.e.,
given spiritual life in the form of eternal life as a free gift).

       Saving faith is a theological term used to refer to the faith which
results in salvation from hell. For an unconditional securitist, such faith is
regarded as punctiliar (z). For the conditional securitist, such faith is
regarded as linear (£). In other words, securitists believe that initial faith is
Technical Terms                                                        Page xxv
sufficient for salvation from eternal damnation. Insecuritists, in contrast,
teach that initial faith is insufficient since it must be followed by
perseverance in faith in order to qualify for heaven.

      Securitist refers to an advocate of unconditional security—the
conviction that once a person believes in Christ for eternal life, that person is
unconditionally secure in Christ and is assured of unconditionally reaching
heaven.

       Semi-Pelagianism is a heterodox view of human-divine synergism
that asserts the sufficiency of natural and moral human ability to initiate
(rather than consummate) salvation by exercising good will toward God
apart from the grace of God. (Consummation of salvation requires the grace
of God.)

       Soteriology is based on two biblical Greek words, soteria (salvation)
and logos (teaching) and correspondingly refers to biblical teaching about
salvation. Although the biblical concept of salvation includes many
dimensions other than deliverance from hell, it is this aspect of salvation to
which writers refer frequently when they use the word soteriology. Thus,
salvation from hell (or more specifically, from eternal damnation in the Lake
of Fire) will be referred to as soteriological salvation or eternal salvation. A
soteriological interpretation of a passage thus would treat the passage as
dealing with eternal salvation from the Lake of Fire (Rev 20:14-15).

       Strict merit refers to an equitable exchange between works and their
attendant reward. Basically, the reward is the agreed-upon, fair-payment
value for the service performed. The reward is fully merited. No appeal to
grace occurs in this view: merit-reward.

       Synergism is derived from the Greek verb sunergeo and means to
work together cooperatively with someone else to produce something that is
a result of mutual work. God works synergistically with the cooperative
individual to bring the individual to the point of saving faith. The saving
faith produced by this joint enterprise is the result of mutual work.
Therefore, saving faith qualifies, by definition, as a synergistic response—a
response produced by mutually cooperative work. Although saving faith is
the result of work, saving faith itself, however, is not a work. Consequently,
regeneration is not a synergistic result. Regeneration is produced exclusively
by God, not jointly by God and cooperative human beings. (We do not give
birth to ourselves.) The cooperative human being is regenerated by God on
the condition of faith alone—apart from any human works. Because
regeneration is not the result of mutual work, it is not a synergistic result.
Regeneration is exclusively a work of God and therefore a monergistic
Page xxvi                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
result. The only thing contributed by the cooperative human being at the
point of regeneration is the passive response of faith which is not a work.

       TULIP—see Calminianism, xiv.

       Unconditional security is the conviction that once a person believes
in Christ for eternal life, that person is unconditionally secure in Christ and
assured of unconditionally reaching heaven. Technically, this articulation is
superior to saying that a believer is unconditionally assured of reaching
heaven. A Calvinist might affirm the latter but could not affirm the former.

       Unconditional securitist: someone who believes that perseverance is
not necessary to enter heaven.

       Works-righteousness is a derogatory label applied to the teaching
which asserts that we are saved from hell on the basis of “works of
righteousness which we have done.” Such a teaching rejects the clear
biblical summation which teaches that we are not saved from hell on the
basis of “works of righteousness which we have done” (Tit 3:5). Biblically,
by faith we must rest our soteriological justification solely on the
imputational/legal righteousness of Christ apart from any of our works
(Rom 3:28; 4:6). Those trusting in impartational/practical righteousness to
get to heaven are trusting wrongly in works-righteousness for a benefit it
was never intended to bestow.

        Special thanks is owed to my wife and children who are not only

but who are also willing to live through any local fallout that may come as a
result of this writing. Over the years my wife has come to view us as
traveling theological gypsies. Granted, my attempts to find a church where
the freeness of the gospel is presented consistently has resulted in a nomadic
existence.
        At one Southern Baptist church we briefly attended a few years ago in
this community, I wrote to the pastor of that church, asking if, in the Berean
spirit described in Acts 17:10-11, I might have an opportunity to privately
discuss some questions I had with him. He responded that I did not have a
right to ask him any questions and that if I asked him any further questions,
he would have the deacons bar me from the church.
        Obviously, trying to discuss theology with the pastor of the church
one is attending is not as easy as many might think. I did not seek to cause
trouble for that pastor by complaining to his church membership of his
reaction. Still, as one might anticipate, the experience was unpleasant for
my wife and children, and we quietly left that church to seek a church that
did not condition the free gift of eternal life on performance. By and large,
after having failed so many times to find such a fair haven, I have given up
on such a quest, resigning myself to having to attend churches that teach
performance-based salvation from hell.
        At times it is difficult to maintain a balancing act between the biblical
injunctions not to be disruptive yet to be corrective. I have found open ears
(much less sustained interest in discussing theology) to be exceedingly rare
among pastors. Nevertheless, on this occasion, rather than write a letter, I
have written a book. At least some pastors will read a book. Whether this
book will result in discussion, repulsion, or expulsion, I do not know. Our
Page xxviii                          Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
current pastor has a pleasant personality. So perhaps some remote possibility
exists that dialogue will result.
        Regardless of the potential fallout from others, I am thankful to the
Lord for a wife who has endured my passion for consistency and for sons
who are becoming discerning regarding sermonic inconsistencies they must
endure.

       Inquiring Friends
       During the summer of 2008, I attended a Sunday School class that
was working its way through Mere Christianity by C. S. Lewis. During that
same time period, two of my secular co-workers asserted that the only thing
that really matters in terms of morality is that a person not hurt anyone else.
Lewis addresses this very mentality from a philosophical perspective in the
opening section of his book. Therefore, part of the inspiration for the present
book has been to interact with this popular one-dimensional approach to
morality. The first section of this book accordingly will adduce its biblical
conclusions by means of philosophical reasoning. May my secular co-
workers find this book informative.
       When Mere Christianity moves beyond philosophy into religion, it
presents its conclusion in support of Lewis’ famous trilemma, which
stipulates that Jesus Christ must either be regarded as Lord, Lunatic, or Liar.
Even among my conservative friends, who certainly would affirm the
Lordship/Deity of Christ, a dilemma exists as to what should be done in the
evangelistic arena with this trilemma. Must one recognize the Deity of
Christ in order to be saved? During the course of that summer, friends on
both sides of this dispute requested that I express my opinion on this matter.
The defense herein of Lewis’ trilemma naturally provides the opportunity in
which to do so. May my fellow theological conservatives on both sides of
the Deity issue find some room for common ground in the present work.
       Lewis’ Mere Christianity embodies the popular sentiment shared by
Catholicism, Arminianism, and Calvinism in surmising that Christianity
teaches that the final attainment of salvation from eternal damnation is
conditioned on perseverance in faith.* While working on a response to this

*
  Arminianism is a branch of conditional security which teaches that God
contingently predetermines that those who persevere will be chosen (elected) for
heaven. Human perseverance is the condition for divine election. The free will
of the believer is emphasized. In Arminianism, reaching heaven is conditioned
on the believer’s perseverance. The Arminian order of conditional results is:
perseverance, then predestination, then heaven. Arminianism is summarized by
the acronym PEARS. (For definition of PEARS, see Arminianism in Technical
Terms, xiii.)
       Calvinism is a branch of conditional security which teaches that God
sovereignly determines (i.e., elects) who will persevere and thus make it to
heaven. Divine election is the basis for human perseverance. The sovereignty of
God is emphasized. The elect persevere because they are unconditionally
Page 2                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
argument as expressed by Lewis, I received an email from a friend asking
me to explain why unconditional security* would be preferred as an
expression of authentic Christianity over conditional security, particularly
regarding perseverance in faith. Mere Christianity, with its affirmation of
moral virtue in the Christian faith, supplies a springboard by which to
interact with this question regarding the believer’s security in a direct
manner consistent with the more thorough investigation forthcoming in my
major book, The Outer Darkness. May my friend who repeatedly emailed
me during summer of 2008 asking for a defense of unconditional security
find in the present book a helpful expression of the much more exhaustive
defense of unconditional security yet to come in The Outer Darkness and
related works.

         Lewis, Edwards, and Aquinas
       The defense for unconditional security in the present work is
purposefully limited, to a considerable degree, to the contribution made by
Lewis in acknowledging that perseverance in faith is a virtue. In order to
deal with this topic of virtuous faith with anything approaching adequacy, it
was necessary to interact with Jonathan Edwards’ classic Justification by
Faith Alone. Consequently, the second chapter of the present work is
devoted to that Edwardian classic. Naturally, research along these lines
requires that one at least mention the parallelism found (since the days of
Thomas Aquinas) in Catholicism. May those seeking a biblical affirmation
of unconditional security with responses to Edwardseanism and Catholicism
find encouragement in the current discussion.

reading a book by John MacArthur. This member expressed an uncritical
praise of MacArthur’s writings. For the sake of MacArthurian fans, the third

        According to the Bible, those who know the truth are responsible to

      Life Events
        When the Sunday School class that initially prompted me to write this

regarding ordo salutis, the need for the present discussion provided herein
became even more acute. Life events kept unfolding during the course of
editing and proofreading this book that spurred me on in my efforts to finish
it. Sharing some of these events in this expanded prologue will give a keener
sense of my motivation and provide practical application for the material to
be covered in the ensuing chapters and appendixes.

         Repentance Tract
       During that same September, another adult and I became co-sponsors
of the Bible study that started in our local high school. This co-sponsor
asked my son, Jonathan (who was to teach the Bible study), personally to
pass out some of her tracts to his friends at school during the upcoming
week. The problem was that her tract defined repentance as a turning from
sin and made repentance a condition for salvation from hell. Jonathan
handed the tract to me for evaluation. I handed it back to my co-sponsor and
explained that Jonathan would not be able to pass out the tract because we
do not believe in a performance-based salvation from hell. The co-sponsor
was quite upset with this response and had the committee person who asked
us to do the Bible study contact me that night to challenge my reply. This
committee person who called me said that every person on the committee
would agree with the lady co-sponsor.

         Committee Representative
       Knowing that this committee representative who challenged my
response claims to be an advocate of eternal security, I explained the
incompatibility of claiming to believe in unconditional security while
simultaneously believing in performance-based security. By the conclusion
of the telephone call, the committee person was dissuaded from making
repentance a theological necessity for salvation and instead came to agree
with me that repentance becomes an issue for a Christian after salvation.
Repentance, insofar as it pertains (as a theological necessity) to becoming or
being a Christian, is not the condition for becoming a Christian or for
remaining a Christian. Rather, repentance (as a theological requisite
pertaining to conversion) is a postconversional response that becomes
requisite after one has become a child of God. Postconversional repentance
is necessary to avoid God’s woodshed in this life and in the afterlife.* In
other words, Christians need to turn from their sins after becoming saved
from hell because God will discipline them as disobedient children
otherwise. The issue regarding repentance, as it relates to Christians, is not
whether or not disobedient Christians are children of God or remain children
of God. The Christian’s relationship with God is permanent. God is not

       Ordo Salutis
       As Hodges documents, Martin Luther, citing Jonah 3:5, insists that
repentance is a work of saving faith* (i.e., a fruit of saving faith).
Repentance becomes an issue after one is saved, not before. Luther
stringently warns, “Beware then, of putting your trust in your own contrition
and of ascribing the forgiveness of sins to your own remorse.”2 Amen!
Placing repentance before saving faith puts one in the precarious position of
making repentance the object of one’s faith. Emphatically, however, one
cannot be saved by trusting in one’s repentance/performance! Tracing out
the development of Calvinism, Kendall correctly notes that one of the main
concerns is “whether faith precedes repentance in the ordo salutis† (or vice
versa).”3 Calvin, as Kendall demonstrates, believes that “faith must precede
repentance in the ordo salutis.”4 Calvin’s successor, Beza, on the other hand,
tended to invert the order and placed repentance before faith and thereby
made repentance a condition for salvation. And so it is today that Calvinists
tend to abandon Calvin and make repentance a soteriological‡ condition for
saving faith. Defining repentance as a turning from sin and then making it

*
  Saving faith is a theological term used to refer to the faith which results in
salvation from hell. For an unconditional securitist, such faith is regarded as
punctiliar (z). For the conditional securitist, such faith is regarded as linear (£).
In other words, securitists believe that initial faith is sufficient for salvation from
eternal damnation. Insecuritists, in contrast, teach that initial faith is insufficient
since it must be followed by perseverance in faith in order to qualify for heaven.
†
   Ordo salutis is a Latin term meaning order of salvation. In theological
discussions it pertains to the logical sequence of events that take place regarding
conversion.
‡
  The reader is already familiar with the word theology, which is based on a
combination of two biblical Greek words: theos (God) and logos (teaching).
Thus, theology refers to biblical teaching about God. In similar fashion,
soteriology is based on two biblical Greek words, soteria (salvation) and logos
(teaching) and correspondingly refers to biblical teaching about salvation.
Although the biblical concept of salvation includes many dimensions other than
deliverance from hell, it is this aspect of salvation to which writers refer
frequently when they use the word soteriology. Thus, salvation from hell (or
more specifically, from eternal damnation in the Lake of Fire) will be referred to
as soteriological salvation or eternal salvation. A soteriological interpretation
of a passage thus would treat the passage as dealing with eternal salvation from
the Lake of Fire (Rev 20:14-15).
Page 6                                  Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
the vehicle by which one receives or retains soteriological salvation is a
popular yet lethal combination. Nevertheless, this departure from Calvin’s
order shows up all too frequently in pop-evangelism.

         FCA and Cahill
       This encounter at the Bible club was not the only event that occurred
during September 2008 that accentuated the need for this book. My sons and
I had attended an FCA (Fellowship of Christian Athletes) breakfast earlier
that month. Unfortunately, one of the books on the table being promoted by
the FCA was Mark Cahill’s One Heartbeat Away. This book, likewise,
makes repentance (in the form of turning from one’s sins) a requirement to
escape the fires of hell. Cahill quotes Spurgeon to the effect that one must
turn from sins in order to escape hell but at the same time claims that if the
reason one is turning from sins is in order to escape hell, then one will go to
hell.5 I know that sounds weird, but that is what Cahill and Spurgeon
believe. And they are not alone in that assessment.6
       One encounters a similar mentality from those evangelists who say
that you must believe in Jesus in order to go to heaven but then
simultaneously stipulate that if you believe in Jesus in order to go to heaven,
you will go to hell. For such psychotic evangelists, the basic thrust of their
argument is that salvation must be more than fire insurance. In stark
contrast, the Bible teaches that believing in Jesus for eternal life so that one
will not go to hell is a sufficient reason for believing in Jesus for eternal life.
This is the motivation provided in Jn 3:16, for example. The sole motivation
given for believing in Jesus for eternal life in this verse is so that one will
not perish (in hell). Jesus is offering fire insurance—freely. But very few
evangelists believe this verse. You have to keep quoting it to them. We need
to evangelize our evangelists.

         Pastor
       With the beginning of September, the Sunday School class my wife
and I were attending moved on to a different curriculum in which our pastor
began a series entitled Essentials of New Life in Christ. The first point on
our pastor’s list was: “What is a Christian?” (Emphasis his.) His answer on
the handout was: “A Christian is someone who has repented of his sins
and placed his faith in Jesus Christ alone for salvation. John 3:16; Hebrews
11:6.” Our pastor has departed from Luther and Calvin in making
repentance a condition for what is supposed to be the free gift of eternal life.
Since I am neither a Lutheran nor a Calvinist, my pastor’s defection from
Luther’s position, much less from Calvinism, is of little concern to me, but
Prologue                                                                  Page 7

on this particular matter Luther and Calvin are correct.* Repentance cannot
be made a condition for becoming a Christian without doing violence to the
gospel message of salvation by faith alone. Far more important than our
pastor’s departure from these two Reformers, however, is the fact that our
pastor has departed from the Scripture in his ordo salutis. Apparently, he is
blinded, by his theological presuppositions, to the shortcomings of his own
citations. For example, neither verse cited by our pastor even mentions the
word repentance! Just to focus on Jn 3:16 for a moment, since so many seem
to have forgotten what this verse actually says, perhaps a reminder is in
order: “For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that
whoever believes in Him should not perish, but have eternal life.” The sole
condition in this verse for having eternal life is to believe in Jesus for eternal
life. The verse does not say, “For God so loved the world, that He gave His
only begotten Son, that whoever repents of his sins and believes in Him
should not perish, but have eternal life.” Does our pastor not believe John? If
he does believe John, then why has our pastor added repentance as a
soteriological necessity?
        Our pastor has put words into John’s mouth that John purposefully
has omitted. It is no accident that John refuses to use the words repent or
repentance anywhere in his entire gospel, nor is it any accident that our
pastor added repentance as part of his personal evangelistic appeal and
falsely attributed this repentance to Jn 3:16. Our pastor frequently focuses
his evangelistic invitations on a person’s willingness to change his or her
performance, saying that if you are willing to commit your life to Christ (and
thus serve Him for the rest of your life), you can believe in Christ for eternal
life. Or, after preaching a sermon in which he claims to believe that salvation
is by faith alone in Christ alone apart from works, our pastor will conclude
that what one needs give his or her life to Christ in order to come into
possession of eternal life. Doing so demonstrates that our pastor does not
believe his own sermon, even though he surely thinks that he does. To
condition the possession of eternal life on giving one’s life to Christ is to
condition the possession of eternal life on the life one lives for Christ.
According to such pastors, if you give Christ your life, then He will give you
eternal life. Such invitations logically present eternal life as a barter rather

than a gift. Although such prater turns eternal life into a barter, Jn 3:16

         Southern Baptists
       Our pastor is doing nothing uncommon in conditioning the
supposedly free gift of eternal life on performance and good behavior. His
repent-and-commit gospel unquestionably reflects the majority opinion
heard in pulpits and over Christian radio stations. I suppose one should not
be shocked when one’s Southern Baptist pastor conditions salvation on
repentance and faith since this is the perspective adopted by the Southern
Baptist Convention in the Baptist Faith & Message. Not surprisingly, our
pastor implicitly affirmed his agreement with the Lordship Salvation*
expressed in the Baptist Faith & Message.7 Therefore, it is natural that his
theology leads to conditioning salvation from hell on one’s performance. But
such Baptistic conditioning of the free gift of eternal life on the believer’s
intention to perform better leads to the conclusion that believers are saved by
virtue of their performance. This Baptistic soteriology is no better than the
form of Arminian theology that makes final justification a reward.†

*
  Lordship Salvationists are those who maintain that some form or degree of
surrender to Christ as Lord of one’s life is biblically necessary for salvation
from eternal damnation. Actually, from an exclusively logical and biblical
standpoint, those (such as myself) who are opposed to today’s so-called
Lordship Salvation affirm that the only way to be saved from hell is to submit to
the Lordship of Christ in terms of believing in Christ for eternal life. The Lord
has commanded that we believe in Him for eternal life. Therefore, to believe in
the Lord Jesus for eternal life is to submit to the His lordship in terms of what is
necessary for having eternal life. Genuine Lordship Salvationists correctly insist
that one must submit to the Lord’s will as it pertains to having eternal life by
believing in Jesus (rather than in one’s performance) for eternal life.
          As a theological term, however, the designation Lordship Salvation has
come to be associated with those who condition salvation from eternal
damnation on one’s performance (or at least on one’s intent to change one’s
performance). They frequently will be referred to as pseudo Lordship
Salvationists in this book because they refuse to submit to what the Lord
actually demands for this type of salvation—simple faith. Because of the
popular association of the term Lordship Salvationists with these false advocates
of Lordship Salvation, however, unless noted otherwise, the popular association
will be adopted by default so that the unqualified term Lordship Salvation will
be understood herein in the popular (rather than biblical sense) as denoting
performance-based salvation.
†
  Initial justification is the justification granted when a person first becomes a
believer. Final justification (as used above) is the justification necessary for a
believer to reach heaven at the end of his or her life. According to conditional
Prologue                                                                   Page 9

       Arrington’s Arminian argument, for example, is saturated with
references to final salvation from eternal damnation, and he regards this
final form of salvation a reward: “To do good works and receive final
salvation means believers must remain faithful.”8 “Victorious Christians are
promised salvation as their reward in the world to come.”9 Whereas initial
salvation might have been a gift, final salvation is a reward in this Arminian
perspective. Blomberg, the Matthean commentator for the Southern Baptist
Convention, likewise regards heaven to be a reward: “The blessing for
endurance is ‘the kingdom of heaven.’ The ‘great reward’ of v. 12 [Mt 5:12]
must therefore refer to the kingdom itself rather than some special status
within it” (emphasis his.)10 Rather than acknowledge degrees of rewards in
heaven, Blomberg makes a reward of heaven. Granted, many Baptists are
not so blatant in making heaven a reward. Nevertheless, the majority of
Baptists seem to follow Jonathan Edwards’ example in considering heaven a
reward, while simultaneously acknowledging that there will be degrees of
rewards in heaven.*
       Contrary to the Catholic-Calvinistic-Baptistic perspective shared by
our pastor and many Arminians (which treats heaven as a reward, whether or
not they admit it), the present study asserts that the only thing we must do to
receive and keep the free gift of eternal life is to trust in what Christ has
done for us. This free gift is not conditioned on what we do for Christ, but
what He has done for us. As for those passages that describe a future
realization of eternal life based on performance, they are focusing on another
aspect of eternal life.

        •   Quantitatively, eternal life is free.
        •   Qualitatively, eternal life is a reward.

Eternal life encompasses both soteriology and misthology.† The degree to
which believers experience the fullness of this life is a reward, but the basic
possession of this life and entrance into the kingdom are a gift. The free gift
is free both in its initial reception and final realization. This unconditional
quantitative aspect is the focus of Jn 3:16. The person who possesses eternal
life presently (as a result of simply believing in Jesus) will not perish
eschatologically. The believer will never thirst, die, or perish soteriologically

security, initial justification may be by faith alone but final justification
necessarily includes perseverance in faith and faithfulness.

         Need for Repentance
        I stressed Jn 3:16 in responding to my co-sponsor for the Bible study
and to the committee person who called me to challenge my response. They
both were shocked that I did not believe in their turn-or-burn gospel. I used
to believe the turn-or-burn gospel—when I was a kid. But the more I studied
the Bible, the more I became convinced that the turn-or-burn message I had
been presented all my life was a misrepresentation of the Bible. The absence
of any form of the word repent from the Gospel of John became an absence
too hard to ignore. It is conspicuous by its absence. When I mentioned the
fact that the Gospel of John purposefully avoids any mention of repentance
to my co-sponsor, she did not even seem to be aware of this omission. In any
event, her remark that repentance is found in the other gospels did not
demonstrate any concern on her part as to why repentance was omitted from
this evangelistic gospel.
        Perhaps one partially could understand this lack of concern by the
laity, but the situation does not necessarily get any better when one consults
MacArthur. Astoundingly, he repeatedly claims: “No one who neglects to
call sinners to repentance is preaching the gospel according to Jesus.”11 “No
message that eliminates repentance can properly be called the gospel.”12
Despite the well known fact in theological circles that John omits any
reference to repentance, MacArthur insists that anyone who omits calling
sinners to repentance is not presenting the gospel (i.e., saving message)
according to Jesus. MacArthur gives us a clear choice with such wild
accusations. One may either reject the gospel according to MacArthur or the
gospel according to John (as being an accurate representation of the gospel
according to Jesus).* In short, since the Gospel of John is Scripture, the only
reasonable conclusion that can be drawn is that MacArthur’s gospel is anti-
Scripture, a false gospel. MacArthur needs to repent of his statements
regarding repentance.13
        One need not be in the dark concerning the absence of the word
repentance in the Gospel of John. Simply, the other gospels were written
primarily for the purpose of disciplining those who were already believers.
Sensibly, these Synoptic Gospels contain Jesus’ stress on repentance.
Christians are subject to God’s temporal wrath and misthological wrath—
God’s woodshed so to speak—and they need to be warned of the need to
repent. John himself quite emphatically warns carnal Christians to repent in
Rev 2-3. But in his gospel, John omits the call to repentance because he is
focusing primarily on telling people how to have eternal life rather than

perish in hell (Jn 20:30-31). Heaven is conditioned on believing in Jesus for
eternal life. Unbelievers need to believe in order to become believers. There
is no need for John to discuss repentance in his gospel since he is presenting
what is necessary to have eternal life in terms of going to heaven.
       Do unbelievers need to repent? Of course unbelievers need to repent.
God’s wrath is not limited to Christians! But changing one’s behavior is not
the means by which one freely gets eternal life and escapes the hell of God’s
soteriological wrath. To avoid perishing in hell, one simply must believe in
Jesus for eternal life. That is John’s point in Jn 3:16. One becomes a believer
by believing, not by changing one’s behavior. Those who maintain the if-
you-believe-then-you-will-change-your-behavior perspective of the gospel
already have effectively conceded that this change of behavior comes after
you change what you believe. In other words, they practically have admitted
that the natural order for repentance is after faith. On the other hand,
although repentance comes naturally, it does not come automatically. For
example, we all believe we should exercise, yet many of us do not. Believers
are not necessarily exercisers. Even though exercise is the natural result of
believing that exercise is good for us, many of us fail to exercise.

       Carnal Christians
       Similarly, carnal Christians are believers who are not exercising their
faith. Their faith is not living and active. Their faith is a couch potato.
Nonetheless, this does not mean that they are unbelievers. Living out their
faith would be the natural thing to do, but doing so is not automatic and
certainly not inevitable. Just as in the case of physical exercise, our beliefs
do not necessarily determine our actions—we do. Our beliefs influence our
actions, to be sure, but ultimately we determine whether we are going to take
the appropriate action. We ought to exercise, but this does not mean that we
will exercise: ought to ≠ will. As Lewis demonstrates, the fact that we ought
to do something does not necessarily mean that we will do it. We are not
rocks but creatures with free will. Our actions are not mechanically
determined by what we believe. In theological circles, this is an affirmation
of libertarianism.*
*
  Libertarianism is the true affirmation of human freedom in which prior factors
are not seen as sufficient conditions to explain all of our choices. This does not
mean that our actions are uncaused, of course. Rather, they are self-caused. A
person’s actions do not cause themselves; the person himself causes his own
action. This viewpoint is synonymous with self-determinism. From the
libertarian perspective, a person must be free to do otherwise than what his or
her internal and external factors dictate in order to be morally responsible for his
or her actions. Free agents must be free to determine their own actions. This is
not to say that our actions occur in a vacuum, but we sometimes act contrary to
Page 12                                 Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

       Turn-or-Burn
       The major problem with the popular turn-or-burn approach to heaven
is not found in its attempt to turn us into robots, however, but in its
conditioning salvation from hell on performance. The turn-or-burn
performance mentality is easily deduced:

     1. To repent is to turn from your sins.
     2. To turn from your sins is to change your performance.
     3. To condition your salvation on your repentance is to condition your
        salvation on your changing your performance.

       FCA Concert
       The turn-or-burn invitation to heaven is an invitation to performance-
based religion, not to Christianity. Yet, at a supposedly Christian concert,
which the FCA also sponsored during September 2008, the evangelist who
spoke at that concert conditioned getting to heaven on turning from sin,
making Jesus boss of one’s life, and getting up out of one’s seat and
publically professing Christ. In other words, his invitation was one of
performance, performance, performance. To be sure, as the evangelist noted,
Jesus warns us that if we deny Him, He will deny us. In connection with a
believer earning rewards in heaven, Paul says the same thing: “If we endure,
we shall also reign with Him. If we deny Him, He also will deny us”
(2Tim 2:12). Reigning with Christ in heaven is conditioned on confessing
Christ on earth. Since the reward of ruling with Christ in heaven is based on

our desires, and, in doing so, we can have a dynamic effect upon our desires.
Libertarian freedom is therefore the ability to act contrary to external and
internal impulses.
        When the Scripture commands us to “let your character be free from the
love of money” (Heb 13:5), it thereby indicates that we have some control over
our character. Not only does our character mold us, but we mold it (Rom 5:4).
When the Bible says, “You shall not desire your neighbor’s house” (Dt 5:21), it
is taking libertarian freedom for granted in telling us that we have culpable
control over what we desire. When Paul exhorts believers to “earnestly desire
the greater gifts” (1Cor 12:31), he assumes that they are free to determine their
own desires (cp. 1Cor 14:1). In fact, Paul gives believers a course of action
which they may follow so that they will not have to carry out the desires of the
flesh (Gal 5:16). They have a choice as to which desires they will obey: those of
the flesh versus those of the Spirit. We choose what desires we will obey.
Believers are not slavishly obedient to their strongest desires. Obviously, Paul is
not a compatibilist, much less a hardcore determinist. It is possible, on occasion,
to base our actions on our convictions and principles (i.e., on what we believe to
be right) rather than simply on what we want to do.

works, confessing Christ is a performance-based issue that pertains to
rewards or lack thereof. Being denied by Christ as a result of not confessing
Christ likewise would pertain to rewards in heaven, not to entrance into
heaven. Perhaps the evangelist should have reflected a little more carefully
on the passage which he quoted from Jesus:

      Everyone therefore who shall confess Me before men, I will
      also confess him before My Father who is in heaven. But
      whoever shall deny Me before men, I will also deny him
      before My Father who is in heaven. (Mt 10:32-33)

        In this passage, where is Christ denied? Before men. Where? On
earth. Where are those who confess Christ confessed by Christ? Before His
Father. Where? In heaven. The most natural deduction is that Jesus is
referring to the judgment of believers in heaven. The question is not, “Will
they be in heaven?” Of course they will be in heaven. They already are there
being judged. Duh! When this judgment takes place, those being judged are
standing before God in the kingdom of heaven. This judgment accordingly
takes place in the kingdom of heaven.14 One need not fail to see the obvious.
Jesus is not talking about entering heaven.* The Lord implicitly is indicating
that those who already have entered the kingdom of heaven (as a result of
believing in Him) subsequently will be judged in the kingdom before His
Father.15 This judgment in Mt 10:32-33 deals with those who already can
legitimately refer to God as their Father who is in heaven (cp. Mt 6:9) and
pertains to the importance of believers having rewards in heaven. Jesus
already had stressed the importance of rewards in heaven earlier (Mt 5:12;
6:20). Confessing Christ in Matthew’s context is dealing with rewards. For
an evangelist (such as the one who spoke at the FCA concert) to base his
invitation on this confessional text from Matthew is to make heaven a
reward rather than a gift. Apparently, this evangelist did not realize that
Matthew (in general) and this passage (in particular) are not focusing on
evangelistic motifs.
        Many at the FCA concert responded to this misconstrued evangelistic
invitation, thinking that they were responding to an invitation to heaven, not
knowing that they really were responding to an invitation to hell instead.
Any performance-based religion leads to hell, not to heaven. As I remarked
to my son, Jonathan, as we were leaving the concert, “Satan won a major
victory tonight.” The many who had responded to the supposedly
evangelistic invitation to heaven at that FCA concert (and walked down the
