         Way of the Master
        When proofreading this book at the end of 2008, I decided to add
another appendix: the one dealing with preconditions. So my work on this
book spilled over into the first quarter of 2009, at which time our church
started a new Sunday School class in which our previous Sunday School
teacher (who taught Mere Christianity) would now teach an evangelistic
program entitled The Way of the Master (www.wayofthemaster.com). As it
turns out, this evangelistic method focuses on using the law as described in
Gal 3:24, which is a topic I had just finished covering in that additional
appendix. The basic premise of this evangelistic presentation is that we must
use the law to bring the lost to the point of repentance. By conditioning the
potential convert’s salvation from hell on the convert’s moral performance
via repentance, this evangelistic technique hopes to bar heaven’s doors to
backsliders so that converts will persevere in their moral transformation in
order to reach heaven. By means of such legalistic performance (in
threatening backsliders with hell), Way of the Master hopes to stem the tide
of backsliding.
        The purpose of the law, however, is to show the futility of trying to be
justified by performance. Therefore, it makes no sense for Way of the Master
to use the law to claim that we are justified by changing our performance via
repentance. The law condemns Way of the Master as being a futile means of
justification. The clear implication of Gal 3:24 is that “the Law has become
our tutor to lead us to Christ, that we may be justified by faith”—not by
repentance, not by changing our performance! Way of the Master uses the
law unlawfully to claim that we are justified by changing our performance,
by promising to do a better job of keeping the commands via repentance.
The purpose of the Law, however, is to show that we cannot be justified by
our performance, so Way of the Master is being illogical in its attempt to use
the Law to get us to change our performance as a means to justification.
        Unlike Cahill,* Way of the Master correctly stresses that the proper
motive for evangelistic repentance is fire insurance (i.e., the desire to be
saved from hell). This emphasis on salvation from hell fire is indeed
appreciated by the present writer. As Way of the Master correctly deduces,
many potential converts have been told to trust in Jesus for a wonderful life

*
    See FCA and Cahill, 6.
Prologue                                                                Page 15

only to become disillusioned when they backslide and then conclude that the
Christian life is not necessarily all that wonderful from a worldly
perspective. Being a Christian can bring persecution, for example. As Way
of the Master correctly notes, we should lead people to trust in Christ for
eternal life. Trusting in Christ for a wonderful life is no substitute for
trusting in Christ for eternal life, and many who have trusted in Christ for a
wonderful life have never received eternal life. Nonetheless, the major
weakness with the Way of the Master’s approach is that the free gift of
eternal life ceases to be free.
        From the onset, the potential convert is told by Way of the Master that
he or she must repent (i.e., perform a once-for-all-turn from his or her sin*)
in order to be saved from hell. Those of us participating in this evangelistic
class were requested to share prayer requests for friends who we would like
to see come into a saving relationship with Christ. I shared prayer requests
for a couple I know who were living together outside of wedlock. According
to the Way of the Master, I would have to tell this couple that they have to
repent (and thus stop this behavior) in order to receive the free gift of eternal
life. I would be required to make a sham out of the biblical offer of eternal
life as a free gift (Rom 5:15-16; 6:23). It is a shame that most people in
church have been conditioned to ignore the sham they are making out of the
gospel.
        The fornicatory conduct of the woman at the well was made clear by
Jesus when He pointed out that she was living with a man that was not her
husband (Jn 4:18). She already had struck out more than three times at trying
to have successful relationships with men, and according to the popular
mentality of that day and time, she was doomed to burn in hell. She needed
something other than performance-based religion. Jesus offered her eternal
life as a free gift and made it clear, by bringing up her checkered past, that
she had no moral claims to such life. She would have to receive it by faith in
Jesus rather than by faith in any moral virtue that she might try to conjure
up.
        Without doubt, the Bible is clear that fornicators will not inherit the
kingdom (1Cor 6:9-10). Like other advocates of conditional security, Way of
the Master assumes that inheriting the kingdom and entering the kingdom
are referring to the same thing. From this premise, it would be reasoned that
such a woman would have to change her behavior in order to reach heaven.
However, the Scripture is equally clear that inheriting the kingdom is an
issue pertaining to rewards (Col 3:23-25). Yet in its FAQ dealing with

OSAS (once saved always saved), Way of the Master just as clearly rejects
this association of inheriting the kingdom with rewards and complains
(regarding OSAS) that the author of one book, when facing someone
involved in adultery, “instead of challenging the man as to the validity of his
faith,† and therefore warning him that ‘adulterers will not inherit the
kingdom of God,’ he spoke of the man’s ‘loss of rewards.’”16 In other
words, Way of the Master thumbs its nose at treating the inheritance of the
kingdom as a reward issue and criticizes those who warn that adulterous
behavior disqualifies one from inheriting the kingdom because Way of the
Master wants to condition entrance into the kingdom on changing one’s
behavior.
        Since The Outer Darkness provides a rigorous defense for the
mistholic‡ interpretation of the inheritance motif, it suffices here to use
common sense. To make giving up a fornicatory relationship a necessary
requirement for entering heaven and to ignore the biblical distinction
between gift and reward makes heaven a reward. Therefore, Way of the
Master turns the free gift offered to the fornicatory woman into a reward that
she is supposed to gain by changing her performance. Way of the Master
misconstrues Jesus as pointing out the woman’s sin so that she would
perform better and get eternal life as a free gift from Jesus in return. A better
evangelistic method is to follow Jesus’ actual example in offering the free
gift of eternal life (and its attendant entrance into heaven) as a free gift to
those who will take it freely. Jesus did not condition the woman’s reception
of the gift on her willingness to abandon her fornicatory relationship. He was
showing her the hopelessness of her situation and of any performance-based
solution. He implicitly was using the law lawfully.
        By following Jesus’ example, I will not be caught in the illogical and
unbiblical predicament of having to explain to a couple living together in
fornication why they must change their performance in order to get a gift
that is supposedly free. Instead, I can point out that their performance
condemns them, so they cannot trust in performance-based solutions. They
need eternal life as a free gift.

*
  OSAS is the acronym for Once Saved Always Saved. NOSAS is the acronym

†
  Calvinists insist that converts validate the genuineness of their faith via their

sometimes nicknamed prove-it theology. Arminianism is dubbed lose-it

since the way you keep yourself regenerate in both systems is by proving that
you are still a believer via your performance: perform or die.
‡
   Mistholic is an abbreviation for misthological (that has been shortened

        The woman at the well was condemned already by the Law. Sleeping
with that guy she was living with one more night or not sleeping with him
that night after talking to Jesus was not going to change that fact one
smidgeon. Her moral record already was smudged hopelessly. Jesus did not
tell her that she better find somewhere else to sleep that night or He would
withhold the free gift of eternal life from her. Nor did Jesus indicate that the
free gift of eternal life that He was offering her would dry up and die if she
did not find somewhere else to sleep that night. He was not making the free
gift of eternal life conditioned on her performance but showing that He was
offering it to her despite her performance and thereby underscoring the dual
truths that He had presented to her. Namely, the life He was offering was
free, and it was eternal. The fact that He was offering it to her as such
despite her performance underscores the truth and consistency of His
message.
        Jesus made her reception of eternal life conditioned on her reception
of this life, not on her changing her life: “Jesus answered and said to her, “If
you knew the gift of God, and who it is who says to you, ‘Give Me a drink,’
you would have asked Him, and He would have given you living water”
(Jn 4:10). Imagine the thoughts that would have been running through her
mind if Jesus had proceeded with His gospel presentation without bringing
up her past: “Yea, right! You say that you will give me eternal life, but if
you really knew what I had done, you wouldn’t say that!” Or perhaps she
may have thought, “Ok, I’ll try to live better so that I can have this living
water.” Or maybe she would have thought, “All right, I’ll stop sleeping
around so that I can keep that living water.” If she had been listening to a
Way of the Master seminar, she might, indeed, have had some such thoughts.
Instead, the true Master brings up her past and does not back down on His
offer of eternal life as a gift. He does not flinch. He does not start attaching
strings. In doing so, He proves to her that His offer of eternal life as a gift is
genuine. He truly is offering her eternal life as a gift despite her
performance.
        The reason for those engaging in extramarital sex to change their
performance is to get the reward of the inheritance and thus to escape the
outer darkness. But they first must receive the free gift of eternal life before
such matters logically become considerations. To make the natural response
of turning from fornication a necessary response to escape hell (as is done
by pseudo forms of evangelism) is to turn the grace of our God into
legalism. Reinforcing this natural response to turn from one’s sins (when
trusting in Christ to forgive one’s sin) with the doctrine of rewards, however,
is biblical and does not involve the logical absurdity of claiming that the free
gift of eternal life is a free gift that costs you everything. Salvation from hell
is free!
        To be sure, many caught in immorality will reject the gift of eternal
life even though it is free, because embracing such a message naturally
Page 18                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
entails acknowledging the fact that one should turn from one’s immoral
practices and admitting that one must follow through on this natural
inclination to submit to God’s will regarding one’s performance in order to
escape misthological consequences. In other words, many still will refuse to
become a child of God (even though He offers them eternal life with Him in
heaven as a free gift) because they will not want to have to relate to God as a
Father who will discipline their behavior here on earth. Many fornicators
will refuse to trust in what the Bible says about their being able to have
eternal life as a free gift because doing so naturally would lead them to
believe what the Bible says about fornication being wrong and punishable.
Be that as it may, whosoever will may take the water of life freely
(Rev 22:17). If they will, they may.
        In this same FAQ on OSAS, Way of the Master continues: “We do
believe in eternal security for a true convert. He puts his hand to the plow
and doesn’t look back, because he is ‘fit’ for the kingdom (Luke 9:62).”
Such a statement is generally a coded affirmation of the conditional
security of the Calvinistic variety.* According to such conditionalists, if you
look back, you will go to hell because you are unfit for heaven. Calvinists
end up conditioning reaching heaven on your not looking back. The
Calvinist will say, of course, that if you are elect,† then you will persevere
(i.e., you will not look back). The flipside of that Calvinistic claim is that
Calvinists also stipulate that you must persevere or God will consider you
unfit for heaven and will throw you into hell. Being fit misthologically
versus being fit soteriologically is not given any serious consideration in
such a system because such Calvinistic theology already has scoffed at the
biblical doctrine of rewards.

*
   Some Calvinists like to present themselves as advocates of eternal security
(i.e., preservation of the saints). As many Calvinists would admit, Calvinists are
more accurately described as affirming the perseverance of the saints.
Calvinistically speaking, God preservers saints through their perseverance. Even
if a Calvinist were to assert that the believer is unconditionally assured of
reaching heaven, what such a Calvinist actually would mean is that the believer
is unconditionally assured of persevering and thereby reaching heaven.
Accordingly to Calvinists, if the saints were not to persevere, then they would
go to hell. In Calvinism salvation is conditioned on perseverance and thus on
performance. Calvinistic eternal security is really conditional security. Let the
reader beware of Calvinists who say that they believe in eternal security. Just as
one must carefully examine terms when cultists come to the door and claim to
believe that Jesus is the Son of God or God/god, one likewise must critically
examine Calvinists who claim to believe in eternal security.
†
  Elect refers to those chosen by God to reach heaven in both Arminianism and
Calvinism. Biblically, the term may be used much more comprehensively than
what is suggested by these two schools of thought, however.
Prologue                                                                 Page 19

      The Way of the Master cites material from The Evidence Bible at
www.livingwaters.com in defense of its performance-based entrance into
heaven:

           If belief is all that is necessary for salvation, then the
     logical conclusion is that one need never repent. However, the
     Bible tells us that a false convert “believes” and yet is not saved
     (Luke 8:13); he remains a “worker of iniquity.” Look at the
     warning of Scripture: “If we say that we have fellowship with
     him, and walk in darkness, we lie, and do not the truth” (1 John
     1:6). The Scriptures also say, “He that covers his sins shall not
     prosper, but whoso confesses and forsakes them [i.e., repents]
     shall have mercy” (Proverbs 28:13).17

        First, Way of the Master is rejecting the biblical claim that salvation is
by faith alone with its counterclaim that belief is not all that is necessary.
Second, Way of the Master wrongly assumes that if salvation from hell is by
faith alone, then “one need never repent.” To the contrary, repentance is still
required for temporal salvation and for salvation from the outer darkness.
Third, Way of the Master mistakenly assumes that the converts in the
Lk 8:13 are false converts because such converts only believe. Biblically, the
only requirement for salvation from hell is that one believes in Jesus for
eternal life. These converts pictured in Lk 8:13 believe and are therefore
saved from hell. The problem is that they only believe for a little while.
Naturally, conditionalists will insist upon perseverance as a necessity to
reach heaven and thereby deny that simple faith is all that is necessary to
reach heaven. Way of the Master does just that and rejects the idea that such
a convert is saved, because Way of the Master does not believe that faith is
all that is necessary to reach heaven, much less that the Bible teaches
unconditional security. Additionally, Way of the Master has not considered
carefully the full implications of this parable pertaining to evangelism, as is
evidenced by Way of the Master’s statement that Jesus always prepares the
soil first and never casts the gospel seed on bad soil. Contrary to Way of the
Master, in this parable Jesus acknowledges that He does the very thing being
denied by Way of the Master. He casts the good seed on all four types of
soil, not just the good soil. Fourth, soteric salvation is not conditioned on our
works or on our ceasing to be workers of iniquity. Fifth, although our
fellowship with God is conditioned on our moral walk, our relationship with
God is not conditioned on the way we walk. Way of the Master demonstrates
contextual insensitivity toward different types of forgiveness, failing to note
that the type of forgiveness that is conditioned on the way we walk/live
cannot be equated with type of forgiveness that is granted independently of
the way we live. Sixth, misthological mercy is not to be equated with
soteriological mercy. The mercy we earn by changing our performance is
Page 20                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
not to be confused with the free mercy offered to us in the free pardon of our
sins. But further digression into such considerations is beyond the scope of
the current book.
         Nevertheless, in passing, I will point out that another major problem
with the Way of the Master is that, in such an approach, eternal life logically
ceases to be eternal. The convert is to hold on to Jesus as he or she would
hold on to a parachute that will save his or her life when it comes time to
jump from the plane. The Way of the Master hopes to cause the convert to
hold onto Jesus in an effort to escape hell. However, if the reason we are to
hold onto Jesus is so that we will not go to hell, as Way of the Master
suggests with its parachute illustration, then there is no soteriological reason
to hold onto Jesus once we receive eternal life if our possession of eternal
life is really eternal. According to such a premise, there would be no need to
continue to hold onto Jesus for eternal life if the eternal life we already have
received from Jesus unconditionally guarantees that we will unconditionally
reach heaven.
         Once the convert has jumped through the first performance hoop laid
out by Way of the Master (via a once-for-all soteric repentance), there would
be no reason for the convert to continue to hold onto Jesus in order to reach
heaven since the convert would have already come into possession of eternal
life—unless eternal life were forfeitable in such a soteriology. Therefore, it
is necessary for Way of the Master to condition the convert’s retention of
eternal life on the convert’s continuous hold on to Jesus, as pictured by the
convert holding on to Jesus like a parachute (via Calvinism or
Arminianism), in order to ensure that the convert produces the Christian
morality deemed soteriologically necessary by Way of the Master to reach
heaven. Lifelong Christian morality now becomes the means to Christian
immortality in such theology. Accordingly, in this conditionalism, neither
the reception nor the retention of eternal life is free. Believers are saved by
their hold on Jesus, not simply by Jesus’ hold on them.
         Way of the Master justifiably is concerned about disillusionment
resulting from wonderful-life approaches to evangelism. By the same token
however, I am concerned that in Way of the Master temporal disillusionment
is traded in for eschatological disillusionment. Jesus describes this type of
disillusionment in Mt 7:15-23, where those who are trying to get into heaven
on the basis of their Christian performance are sent to hell because their
performance is not good enough. Those attempting to get into heaven by
means of the performance laid out in Way of the Master similarly will be in
for a great disappointment.

       Hell’s Best Kept Secret
      Contrary to Way of the Master, hell’s best kept secret is not merely
that an evangelistic program which stresses that a convert can have a
wonderful life via repentance and faith is a false gospel, but that an
Prologue                                                                Page 21

evangelistic approach such as that presented in the Way of the Master also
leads to hell. Hell’s best kept secret is that both methods of evangelism lead
to hell.
        The Four Spiritual Laws, by Campus Crusade for Christ, is probably
the most popular, wonderful-life presentation of the gospel in the world. It is
the evangelistic message that I believed during my youth and which I was
trained to share with others. The Four Spiritual Laws basically starts off
with the premise that Jesus offers us both eternal life and abundant life
(Jn 3:16; 10:10). This premise is biblical. In its fourth law, Four Spiritual
Laws states that we must repent and believe in order to have these twin
benefits. To a limited degree, such an approach is defensible in that the Bible
does condition the believer’s temporal and misthological experience of the
abundant life on the believer’s repentance. Also to its credit, Campus
Crusade for Christ has a follow-up tract that does, to a limited degree,
clarify that experiencing the abundant Spirit-filled life is the dimension that
is conditioned on the believer’s performance. One potentially could deduce
from this joint presentation that the gift of eternal life is free but that the
experience of the wonderful Spirit-filled life is the dimension conditioned on
the believer’s performance. Thus, from this potentially joint perspective, the
Four Spiritual Laws is superior to Way of the Master in a crucial aspect. One
eventually might stumble upon a correct understanding of the gospel via the
combined presentation by Campus Crusade for Christ. But Way of the
Master seeks to close the door on even an accidental discovery of the truth
that eternal life is a free gift by conditioning emphatically the supposedly
free gift of eternal life on repentance regarding one’s moral performance.
Whereas the Four Spiritual Laws makes it very difficult to conclude
logically that eternal life is a free gift, Way of the Master makes it
deductively impossible.

       Insult upon Injury
       Yet to be fair to Way of the Master, tracts following the evangelistic
method expressed by the Four Spiritual Laws do tend to add insult upon
injury. Whereas Way of the Master conditions the reception of the free gift
of eternal life upon changing one’s performance via repentance (and thereby
insults Jesus by presenting Him as offering a free gift that is not really free),
these other tracts add further injury to the gospel of grace by saying that you
must additionally give Jesus control of your life in order to get the free gift
that Jesus is offering. Turning from negative performance is combined with
positive commitment in strong affirmations of Lordship Salvation. Softer
forms of Lordship Salvation, such as that found in Way of the Master, only
require turning from negative performance. Whether soft or strong, a false
gospel of performance-based security is being presented by both forms of
Lordship Salvation.
Page 22                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Sometimes false presentations can be used with a positive result,
however. For example, I handed a young lady a tract from Way of the
Master that looks like a $1,000,000 bill. This tract is a nice eye catcher and
conversation opener. I explained that it was a gospel tract and then asked her
if it would make sense to her if I were to offer her a free gift but condition it
on her changing her performance.* She responded negatively. I affirmed that
her negative response was accurate. Conditioning a free gift on changing
one’s performance is fallacious. So I then pointed out the obvious deduction
to her. Since this tract by Way of the Master conditions the gift of eternal life
on repenting (i.e., turning from one’s sins†), this tract is making a false
presentation that conditions the free gift of eternal life on her changing her
performance. Therefore, this tract is not only a counterfeit bill but represents
a counterfeit gospel. To conclude the conversation, I handed her my own
tract and suggested that she read it as an example of a genuinely consistent
gospel message that offers the free gift of eternal life as a free gift.‡
        One can use the insult-upon-injury tracts similarly. More Than
Winning by FCA and Do you Know? by Evangelism Explosion provide
examples of tracts that present the false condition of giving Jesus control of
one’s life in order to get the free gift of eternal life. While having breakfast
with a pastor in our community, I was discussing with him the Sunday
School material that his church currently is using. He was very pleased with
it. So I asked what did the material present as necessary for the reception of
eternal life. Repentance and surrendering your life to Christ was his
response. I took a dollar out of my wallet and laid it on the table and told
him that I would give him that dollar as a free gift if he would just surrender
control of his life to me. To put a little levity to the mood, I mentioned that I
needed someone to cut my grass, so I really would appreciate if he would
take my free dollar!§ He declined. Too bad, I really would have liked to see

Sunday after Sunday, representing Jesus as offering eternal life as a free gift
if we will just surrender our lives to Jesus. In such an exchange, eternal life
costs us our lives. By no means is it really free! The next time your pastor
tries to offer you eternal life as a free gift if you just surrender control of
your life to Christ, ask him if he would accept a dollar as a free gift. If he
asks if there are any strings attached, you can ask him if there are any strings
attached to his offer of eternal life—making it really not free. Then offer him
this dollar as a free gift if he will just surrender control of his life to you or
commit his life to you. See if he believes his own invitation—that the offer
of a free gift that is conditioned on the surrender of one’s life is really a free
gift. You will find that he does not. A gift that is conditioned on the
surrender or commitment of one’s life is not truly a gift. It is a barter.
        The Bible says that those who do not believe God’s message
regarding His offer of eternal life make God out to be a liar (1Jn 5:10). Can a
person get eternal life by making Jesus out to be liar when He offers them
eternal life as a free gift? Hardly! Nevertheless, those who believe that they
must surrender control of their lives to Jesus in order to get into heaven are,
in effect, trying to get into heaven by making Jesus out to be liar. Since Jesus
offers the free gift of eternal life as a free gift and demands that it be
received as such, those trying to obtain it some other way are making the
Lord out to be a liar. The argument of this book is that the Lord is going to

by pouring more water on its back. If even such an elementary observation as
that offered above rolled off this pastor’s back and thereby revealed him to be a
duck that ducks out from seriously considering the ramifications of his own
theology, then there was little reason to proceed with the explanation that the
Calvinistic God does not keep us apart from our perseverance. Still, had this
pastor reached out to take my dollar, I would have added the clarification that he
had to return my free gift if I was not satisfied with his performance. After all,
that is how pseudo Lordship Salvation really works.

be more than a little bit displeased with those trying to get into His heaven

         Fireproof
        The soteriology that Kirk Cameron expresses in Fireproof is far
superior to the soteriology he expresses in Way of the Master. Without a
doubt, Fireproof is a great movie that depicts the evangelism one typically
would find in wonderful-life presentations of the gospel. In such
presentations, and in Fireproof, a felt temporal need leads the convert to
trust in Christ, not only for eternal life but also for the abundant life. Such a
presentation can be done with biblical accuracy as long as the convert is
trusting in Christ for eternal life as a free gift that is not conditioned on his
or her performance. If, at the same time, the convert wishes to submit his or
her life to Christ in terms of his or her performance so that the convert can
experience His divine aid in dealing with some immediate felt temporal
need, then the convert has made a doubly wise response that not only results
in the immediate appropriation of eternal life but which also places the
convert on the path to abundant life.
        Way of the Master, on the other hand, paints a false picture of typical
wonderful-life presentations of the gospel by acting as though such
presentations normally do not include a discussion of sin and repentance. In
actuality, wonderful-life presentations of the gospel often express a
soteriology very similar to Way of the Master in that repentance is made a
condition for full salvation. I have no objection to this requirement, of
course, in that repentance is, in fact, a condition for salvation from the outer
darkness. Full salvation encompasses salvation from the hellish penalty of
sin (justification), from the tyranny of sin (sanctification), and from the
misthological consequences of sin (the outer darkness). Certainly,
repentance is required for full salvation since full salvation reaches out
beyond the gift of justification to include the performance-based themes of
sanctification and co-glorification.
        The frequent problem with such wonderful-life presentations,
however, and the unquestionable problem with Way of the Master is that
they make repentance in terms of one’s moral performance a condition for
basic salvation. In such presentations, salvation from hell logically ceases to
be a free gift. Instead, salvation from hell is conditioned on the convert’s
change in moral performance. In short, evangelistic appeals such as Way of
the Master teach salvation by works—a false gospel that leads to hell. Such
evangelistic messages are nothing other than the cries of wolves in sheep’s
clothing.*

*
    See http://misthology.org/pdf/tracts/Cry_of_the_Wolf.pdf.
Prologue                                                               Page 25

       Unconditional Love and Security
        Obviously, as an advocate of unconditional security, I have some
theological objections to the conditional security inherent in Way of the
Master. In addition to such theological objections, there are some pragmatic
remonstrations. After reading my brief online article Moral and Theological
Apostasy (which has been covered much more thoroughly in the present
book), an inquirer began a series of correspondences with me in February
2009 in which he expressed concern over his moral apostasy. Earlier in his
life he had experienced a wonderful spiritual, moral, and emotional change
when he became a convert by responding to the repent-and-commit form of
the gospel espoused by pseudo Lordship Salvation. Eventually, however, he
became entangled in a moral state that he describes as moral apostasy. Now,
he even struggles with feeling hostility toward God.
        Thus, one pragmatic problem I have with repent-and-commit forms of
the gospel is that such evangelistic programs do not necessarily produce the
results in their converts that these methods are supposed to produce. Such
programs do not necessarily live up to their claims, in other words. This
false gospel is guilty of false advertisement. This convert, for example,
already had given the response demanded by the repent-and-commit form of
the gospel, but his commitment had fizzled out. So what will a repent-and-
commit advocate tell him now? Do it again? This is easier said than done,
especially when the person who has been converted by the turn-or-burn
approach to heaven already is trying to do it again and failing. Moreover, if
the repent-and-commit response did not provide a permanent solution the
first time, why think that it will do so the second time?
        To be sure, Way of the Master has a scapegoat by which to explain
the failures within its program. If the repentant convert becomes
disillusioned with the Way of the Master, we are supposed to get the convert
to question whether or not he or she was ever saved in the first place rather
than question whether or not Way of the Master was ever biblical in the first
place—a typical Calvinistic maneuver. But why should converts have to
keep doing this supposedly once-for-all repentance?* This Calvinistic cover-
up is hardly persuasive to those who repeatedly have jumped through that
Calvinistic performance hoop.
        During the course of these correspondences, this person questioned
my insistence that God could love him unconditionally. This individual’s
*
  Way of the Master assumes a Calvinistic premise that if you fail to persevere,
then you never were really saved to start with—a copout which fails to
acknowledge that those making a repentant decision to follow Christ eventually
may cease to follow Him. For theological as well as practical considerations, it
would have been wiser for Way of the Master to follow Calvin’s ordo salutis
which insists that repentance is not a condition for regeneration.
Page 26                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
inability to grasp God’s unconditional love is logical for someone who has
been told that being loved as a child of God is conditioned on repentance
and commitment (and thus on moral performance). This inquirer questioned
the idea that God could love him unconditionally by saying that he had been
told that unconditional love sees the need but does not count the cost, does
not see if the person is worth it, and does not stop giving. I responded along
the following lines:

           As to unconditional love, it is found in the drops of blood in
     Jn 3:16 and in the drops of rain in Mt 5:44-46. It is found in God
     demonstrating His love for the lost despite the cost (2Cor 5:19)
     even while they are enemies (Rom 5:8), despite their not being
     worthy of it, and in such a way as to offer them the gift of eternal
     life—a gift that keeps on giving life regardless of performance. It
     is found in the last verse of Jonah, where God’s love for a
     wicked people in sending them Jonah was not conditioned on
     their condition. It is found in 1Jn 4:19 where God loves us even
     before we love Him. It is found in Rom 8:39 for those who have
     embraced God’s unconditional love. So I take it that you have
     never experienced God’s unconditional love?
            It must be hard for you to love a God that only loves you
     if you love Him. It probably would be hard not to feel hostility
     toward a God who conditions every drop of His love for you on
     your performance for Him. I guess my boys would be inclined to
     hate me if I told them that the only way I would love them as my
     boys is if and as they obey me. But my boys know that I love
     them unconditionally as my boys. If they disobey me, they may
     not like the manner in which that love is expressed, but they
     know that I will keep on loving them regardless of the cost,
     regardless as to whether or not they are worth it, and that my
     love for them will never give out. There is security in that kind
     of love. As to that kind of love, it exists in my heart. God placed
     it there from His heart. I am committed to loving my boys no
     matter what. I learned that kind of love from my Father.

       Unconditional love and unconditional security go hand in hand.
Those who teach that God’s love for us as His children is conditioned on our
moral performance have denied both God’s unconditional love for us as His
children and our unconditional security as His children. How can those who
teach that we have to repent of our behavior in order to become a child of
God ever hope to present a picture of God loving us unconditionally as His
children when, in their theology, God would not even accept us as His
children until we first promised that we would clean up our act? Moreover,
Arminianism and Calvinism reject the notion that God will keep us if we fail
Prologue                                                              Page 27

to persevere. Therefore, the affirmation of God’s unconditional love for His
children logically is limited to those who have rejected the performance-
based security found in Arminianism and Calvinism and have refused the
performance-based evangelism represented by the Four Spiritual Laws and
the Way of the Master.

       Adoption
       My sons are mine by birth. Similarly, we become children of God by
spiritual birth—by having eternal life imparted to us in what the Bible
describes as new birth. The Bible also pictures what legally takes place at
the time of new birth as adoption. Some people evidently limit their
perspective of God adopting us to that of adopting a little orphan Annie, as
represented in the musical. A better illustration, in many regards, would be
to visualize an adoption in which an abused, rebellious adolescent is adopted
from a foreign land by a father who knows her history and background and
chooses to adopt her anyway. This child did not try to clean up her act in
order to be adopted. Nor was she required to do so. She is not being adopted
because of her behavior but in spite her behavior. Her adopting father wants
to make it clear to her, and to everyone else, that the reason he is adopting
her is because he loves her, not because he loves her behavior. Although He
makes his adoption (covenant) with no strings attached to her behavior, no
one questions his disapproval of her behavior. He wants to rescue her from
the state she is in, but there are no behavioral prerequisites to the adoption.
Nullifying the adoption afterward would be unthinkable because it would
demonstrate that his adopting love was conditioned on her behavior after all.
But he was determined to love her as his child regardless of her behavior.
Naturally, she is not familiar with the family code of conduct before the
adoption and displays the expected resistance to complying with it after the
adoption. Nevertheless, her adoption is unconditionally secure, even when
she resists her father’s parental discipline.

       Unconditional Love
        Granted, not all dimensions of God’s love are unconditional. The
Bible is very clear on that matter. God’s love for us as His obedient children
is conditioned on our obedience. My love for my sons as obedient sons, for
example, is conditioned on their obedience. Howbeit, that does not mean
that all dimensions or expressions of my love for my sons are conditioned on
their obedience. Not by a long shot! Similarly, if we are God’s children, then
God unconditionally loves us as His children—regardless of our moral
performance. Even so, if we want to be loved as obedient children of God,
then we must be obedient children of God. Not all dimensions of theology
need to be complex in order to be profound.
Page 28                                   Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

       Pseudo Lordship
        Our pastor, like any typical pseudo Lordship Salvationist pastor, is
fond of conditioning salvation from hell on believing in Jesus as one’s Lord
and Savior. The thought typically conveyed by such an evangelistic appeal
is that one must submit one’s moral performance to the Lordship of Christ in
order to become a true convert to Christianity and thus to possess eternal
life. During the course of their sermons, such pastors may state time and
again that salvation is not gained through one’s works but only through faith
in Christ. However, they only show that they do not believe their own
sermons when they close their messages with a serpentine evangelistic
appeal in which they subtly slide in performance as the necessary means of
coming to Christ in saving faith. Such evangelistic appeals are very
pernicious in their denial that salvation is by faith apart from works.
Nevertheless, the bottom line of such invitations is very clear to those who
will think through what is really being offered in this theology: Make Jesus
Lord of your moral performance or go to hell. Logically, such evangelistic
appeals make saving faith impossible because they condition the convert’s
regeneration* on moral performance—a deadly mistake.

       Typical Southern Baptist Pastor
        To reiterate, I am not accusing our pastor of doing anything that the
typical Southern Baptist preacher would not do. Far to the contrary, I have
heard many Southern Baptist speakers over the years and have grown
accustomed to such inconsistencies. If a pastor is preaching that salvation is
a free gift, I can almost rest assured that within the course of the sermon he
will make at least one statement that shows that he does not believe what he
is saying. If the unexpected happens and he does not discount his belief in
the freeness of the offer during the course of the sermon, he almost certainly
will do so when he reaches the invitation, where he will be careful to speak
out of both sides of his mouth.18
        Calling for repentance and commitment are certainly biblical.
Nothing is wrong with doing so, when done in a biblical manner. The
problem occurs when pastors make such responses conditions for receiving
or keeping the free gift of eternal life. Out of one side of the mouth, they
stress that the free gift of eternal life is free, but from the other side of their
mouth they deny that it is truly free to the recipient.


*
  Regeneration is the theological term used to describe the impartation of eternal
life as a free gift (to one’s spirit) which occurs when a person believes in Christ
for eternal life. Such a person is said to be born again (i.e., given spiritual life in
the form of eternal life as a free gift).

            Illustration 2. Typical Pastor’s Offer of the Free Gift




        Calling for (1) repentance from sin, (2) commitment of life, and
(3) perseverance in such commitments are performance issues that certainly
are appropriate in the context of discipleship. Making such performance
motifs necessary to enter heaven though, even while simultaneously
preaching that heaven is free, necessarily smacks of multiple inconsistencies
in which heaven ends up being conditioned on triadic performance.
        Such inconsistencies are not slips of the tongue but examples of
pastors speaking with a forked tongue since such contradictions are by-and-
large predictable retractions of the free offer of saving grace. Perhaps such
pastors technically are not lying because they truly may believe that they are
telling the truth (while being blinded to the truth). Nevertheless, since they
are presenting a lie, the charge of speaking with a forked tongue sticks.
Certainly, many such pastors are preaching the gospel with all sincerity.
Still, sincerity is no substitute for accuracy. As the old adage goes, one can
be sincere yet be sincerely wrong.
        As well-intentioned as they may be, pastors who teach a
performance-based salvation from hell actually are teaching a poisoned
gospel that leads to hell. Pseudo Lordship Salvationists may give lip service
to proper theology, even to the point of affirming the popular Free Grace
motto: Salvation is by faith alone in Christ alone. Normally, one does not
have to wait long, however, before these pseudo preachers attach their fine
print to their correct statements. These resulting inconsistencies condition
salvation on performance and thus teach conditional security. Naturally,
conditioning salvation on turning from sins is to condition salvation on
performance in regard to negative works. Likewise, conditioning salvation
on commitment of life is to condition salvation on positive performance in
regard to one’s works. The real meaning of such appeals comes through
crystal clear when those conditions are expressed in terms of their logical
implications:
Page 30                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
    •   Commit your performance to Christ.
    •   Surrender your performance to Christ.
    •   Give your performance to Christ.
    •   Trusting Christ with your performance is the way you trust Christ for

        Needless to say, eternal life is clearly seen not to be a free gift when
presented with the full ramifications of such invitations. In the above
illustration, I am using a fictional picture of the typical pastor to represent
these offsetting appeals. Over the years, I could have placed many faces in
that circle. I have no reason to think that such inconsistencies are limited to
Southern Baptists. During the course of this book, I will fill in that circle
with writers who have committed their inconstancies to published works.
Documentation of their inconsistencies will suffice for present purposes and
show that such inconsistencies are typical of pseudo Lordship Salvationists
across the board and not just from those of the Southern Baptist
denomination. Perhaps, regardless of your denominational background, you
may recognize the face of your pastor belonging in this circle as well. If you
are a pastor reading this book, perhaps your own face belongs within it.
Perhaps not. There are genuine exceptions, even Southern Baptist
exceptions. Charles Stanley is such an exception—a remarkable one in fact.
His book, Eternal Security, is a terrific writing that at one time gave me
hope that our fellow Southern Baptists might indeed stop talking out of both
sides of their mouths.19 Stanley correctly affirms that the outer darkness is a
picture of loss of rewards in heaven for those Christians who do not submit
their lives to the Lordship of Christ on earth. As a result, he does not need to
speak out of both sides of his mouth in order to stress the importance of
submitting one’s life to the Lordship of Christ. Salvation from hell is free.
Period! Salvation from the outer darkness (i.e., from loss of rewards in
heaven) is another topic altogether and is conditioned on the believer’s
performance. Getting to heaven is free for the believer; being rewarded in
heaven is not free. Doubletalk is unnecessary for Stanley. The elegancy of
such simplicity speaks for itself.
        Stanley’s book came out in 1990. The years have come and gone
since then, and Southern Baptists still are trying to work their way to heaven.
Times have not changed. In the years following the release of Stanley’s
book, I have been working on my book on the outer darkness that will
defend unconditional security by means of an integrated misthology that I
herald under the name of Marrowism.* That writing project is taking many

      Better Way
       A better approach to acknowledging the Lordship of Christ is to
acknowledge that Jesus is Lord whether we make Him Lord or not. One day
everyone, lost and saved alike, will have to acknowledge the fact that Jesus
is Lord (Phil 2:11). Everyone will have to give an account to Lord Jesus for
the way that they have lived because He is their Lord and Judge. The
question is not whether Jesus is our Lord but whether we are living in
harmony with that truth. Before we were saved, Jesus was our Lord simply
by virtue of being our Creator and Judge. After we are saved, Jesus also
becomes our Lord by the additional virtue of being our Savior. He bought
us; we belong to Him (1Cor 6:19-20). For this reason, the Bible calls us
slaves of Christ (1Cor 7:22-23). Christians need to wake up and smell the
Lordship. But a perversion of the gospel by pseudo evangelists is not the
biblical way to wake up Christians to the Lordship of Christ.
       Being accountable as slaves of Christ is not an option. When we
believe in the Lord Jesus as our Savior, the Lord Jesus automatically
becomes our Savior. He was already our Lord (in a variety of ways).
Converts do not need to be told to believe in Jesus as their Lord and
Savior—as if to convey the false impression that it is necessary to make
Jesus Lord of their lives/performance in order for them to qualify for heaven.
Let them take the free gift freely. There is no escaping the Lordship that
goes with it. Jesus automatically becomes our Lord in a new way regarding a
new entrustment.
       When my children were born to me, they did not have any choice
about being accountable to me as their father for their moral behavior. When
converts are born into God’s family, they do not have any choice as to

refers to a defense of unconditional security consisting of soteriological and

whether they will be held accountable by their Father for their moral
behavior as His children either. Accountability comes with the territory. The
Lord will discipline His children for their moral performance. We should not
try to make moral performance the avenue by which coverts become God’s
children. Moral performance is not the birth canal leading to the new birth.
Becoming or being a child of God is not conditioned on moral performance.
        If one absolutely feels compelled to express the full spectrum to
potential converts (and there are occasions when it might be prudent), let
such converts be warned that God will discipline His children and that slaves
of Christ are thrown into the outer darkness if they do not live in harmony
with His moral expectations. At the same time, let potential converts be
assured that as slaves of Christ they will be saved from hell and that as
God’s children they will be loved unconditionally as such through all
eternity. Neither things present, nor things to come, nor Arminians, nor
Calvinists can separate believers from the unconditional love of God which
is in Christ. I have heard sermons about hell that would have led me to faith
in Christ if I were not already a believer. Yet it was the love of Christ that
captured my heart.
        Let us not diminish the love of Christ out of some compulsory need to
stress the outer darkness. I have spent many years writing a book on the
outer darkness, but my love for Christ is a greater motivator than my fear of
the outer darkness. The truth of the outer darkness is there for all to see. The
Lordship of Christ is there for all to read. But the love of Christ is there for
all to embrace. Believing in Christ in order to escape hell and serving Christ
in order to escape the outer darkness need not necessarily be the strongest
motivations in one’s heart to believe in Christ and serve Him. Love for Jesus
can be a stronger motivator than both of these motives put together. Why not
allow our converts to have the opportunity to believe in Jesus and serve
Jesus because they love Jesus? Is it so hard for today’s Lordship
Salvationists to understand that Free Grace Salvationists* might want to
believe in Jesus because He is the kind of Lord they would want to live with
eternally, and they want to serve Him because their love for Him compels
them to do so? Let believers in Christ and followers of Christ be lovers of
Christ. Let them know what unconditional love really is. It is hard not to
love a Savior who is committed to loving us in this manner no matter what.



*
  Free Grace Salvationists are those who insist that the biblical requirement for
salvation from eternal damnation is that one simply believes in the Lord Jesus
for eternal life. This understanding is exemplified by the Grace Evangelical
Society (GES) motto: Faith Alone in Christ Alone. From their perspective,
saving grace is conditioned on the recognition that the free gift of eternal life is
offered freely to those who simply believe in Jesus Christ for eternal life.
Prologue                                                              Page 33

         Root-Fruit Rhetoric
        While preaching through the book of Galatians, our pastor presented
a number of sermons in which he emphasized that eternal life is free, with
the typical implicit inconsistencies that one would expect from a Lordship
Salvationist. I anticipated that when he reached Gal 5:16-21, he would
change his tone, however, and preach a sermon explicitly nullifying his
acknowledgment that eternal life is free. As expected, his sermons on this
passage thoroughly repudiated his previous focus on the freeness of eternal
life.* His entire sermonic stress became that control of one’s life determines
if one will reach heaven. Committing one’s life to Christ so that He is in
charge was emphasized repeatedly as the way to avoid hell. Translated, this
means that Christ must be in charge of your performance in order for you to
reach heaven. The reason pseudo Lordship Salvationists stress that Christ
must be Lord of your performance in order for you to reach heaven is
because according to their theology reaching heaven logically is conditioned
on performance, even though they generally will refuse to admit it.
                      Illustration 3. Root-Fruit Canoe




       Not surprisingly, our pastor gave a closing comment in his first
sermon on this passage that was supposed to deflect any concern that he was
teaching salvation by works. He claimed that we are not saved because of
our good fruit; rather, we bear good fruit as proof that we are saved.

*
    See endnote 7.
Page 34                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
According to this proof retort, we bear good fruit because we are saved, not
in order to be saved. This evasive maneuver implements the common root-
fruit distinction appealed to time and again by such Lordship Salvationists.
        Our pastor illustrated his point by comparing producing the good fruit
to rowing upstream. Our church is located in the mountains, so we are
accustomed to whitewater rafting and canoeing. Merely getting in a canoe
and drifting downstream with the flow of the current could be likened to just
going with the flow of ungodly influences to produce the negative fruit
described by Paul in Gal 5:16-21. Christians need to paddle upstream against
the flow of the current. This analogy by our pastor is splendid insofar as it
goes. The problem is that he was using this analogy to maintain that we must
paddle upstream to be saved from hell. Whoa! Would that not be salvation
by works? Of course! Instead of acknowledging the logical outcome of his
sermon though, our pastor invoked the ploy often used by legalists to avoid
honestly facing up to the logical implications of such sermons. He indicated
that we are not saved by the fruit we bear but by the root that produces the
fruit.
        The most glaring problem with such a ridiculous conclusion in this
particular illustration is that the fruit is the paddle! In such theology the root
commitment* made in one’s heart to change one’s performance (by giving
control of one’s performance to Christ) means nothing if not accompanied
by fruitful performance. Even on the basis of his own analogy, our pastor
logically was conditioning getting upstream to heaven on paddling upstream.
Necessarily, one would have to reach heaven by works. His suggestion that
we are saved by paddling upstream but not saved by the paddling is
completely irrational. Obviously, salvation from going downstream is by


*
  My criticism of pseudo Lordship Salvation is still accurate even if the root is
correctly perceived as being regeneration. Regenerative fruit/performance would
still be necessary to reach heaven according to pseudo Lordship Salvation.
Additionally, Col 3:23-25 explicitly makes the inheritance a reward conditioned
on works. Therefore, to equate entrance with inheritance necessarily teaches
salvation by works. Yet the root argument, as used by our pastor as well as by
most other Lordship Salvationists, is susceptible to even further reproof in that
the root they demand from the convert is a commitment to changing
performance. The potential convert is told to commit his or her life/performance
to Christ in order to be saved from hell. Faith is redefined as commitment of
positive performance, and repentance regarding negative performance is added
to faith, thereby making the commitment to change one’s performance the root
of the issue. The root is composed dualistically of commitment regarding
positive and negative performance; the fruit is composed of the follow-through
of that performance related commitment—making the whole scheme a
performance-based soteriology.

means of the paddle—by means of the good fruit produced. Exegetically, the
same conclusion would be reached from the passage itself.
        Paul, writing to Christians, warns them, just as he already had
forewarned them: “I warn you, as I did before, that those who live like this
[like going downstream in carnal behavior] will not inherit the kingdom of
God” (Gal 5:21; NIV). Inheriting the kingdom is conditioned by Paul on the
way Christians live. Equating inheriting the kingdom with entering heaven,
as our pastor mistakenly did, unmistakably conditions entering heaven on
the way Christians live.20
        Our pastor was doing nothing out of the ordinary in making such an
association. Indeed, he was just presenting the standard assumption heard
over and over again from preachers and teachers across our land. Such
pastors naturally stress that you must commit your life (i.e., the way you
live) to Christ because these pastors and teachers believe that in the end the
way you live determines whether or not you will be saved. Amazingly, such
preachers stress that you are not saved by works (i.e., by the way you live).
Their disclaimer is true, to a point, in that according to their theology you
are not initially saved by works (i.e., by the way you live). Ultimately,
however, their theology makes final salvation conditioned on the way you
live. Consequently, when their theology is viewed in its entirety (as to what
is necessary to be saved from hell), their emphasis that their theology
teaches that one is not saved by works is completely fraudulent.
                 Illustration 4. Entrance Versus Inheritance




      This whole fruit-root assumption is exposed as a fiasco when Paul’s
promise in Col 3:23-25 is considered. Writing again to Christians, Paul
exhorts them to work for the inheritance so that they can receive it as a
reward for their work:
Page 36                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
      Whatever you do, do your work heartily, as for the Lord rather
      than for men; knowing that from the Lord you will receive the
      reward of the inheritance. It is the Lord Christ whom you
      serve. For he who does wrong will receive the consequences of
      the wrong which he has done, and that without partiality.
      (Col 3:23-25)

The inheritance is a reward based on works. Therefore, when Paul warns the
Galatian Christians that those who live in a godless manner will not inherit
the kingdom, he is dealing with a reward concept based on works. Paul
wants Christians to paddle upstream against the earthly current so that they
may receive the reward of the inheritance.
       Marrowists believe in paddling upstream. In fact, that is a picture of
me in the canoe paddling upstream in Illustration 3. Root-Fruit Canoe. But
Marrowists do not believe in paddling upstream in order to enter heaven.
Heaven is a gift! We are paddling our hearts out for heavenly rewards, not
for heaven itself. The difference is vast. Those pastors who equate entrance
into heaven with the inheritance of the kingdom logically turn heaven into a
reward based on works, even if such pastors do not acknowledge explicitly
the logical outcome of their insistence. Some pseudo-Christian writers and
preachers, on the other hand, acknowledge the logical outcome of their
arguments (to a considerable degree) and practically admit that heaven is a
reward. Others, in fact, do admit explicitly that they believe that heaven is a
reward. This book will interact with their arguments as well.

       Implicit is Still Deadly
       My experience over the years of sitting under the teaching of many
Lordship pastors is that they prefer to make heaven an implicit reward.
Otherwise, the people in the pew would more readily catch on to what they
are doing and object. As it is, their congregations are being poisoned without
realizing it. Unconsciously, such congregations are allowing their pastors to
plant the seed of works-righteousness* in their minds and permitting it to

*
  Works-righteousness is a derogatory label applied to the teaching which
asserts that we are saved from hell on the basis of “works of righteousness
which we have done.” Such a teaching rejects the clear biblical summation
which teaches that we are not saved from hell on the basis of “works of
righteousness which we have done” (Tit 3:5). Biblically, by faith, we must rest
our soteriological justification on the imputational/legal righteousness of Christ
apart from any of our works (Rom 3:28; 4:6). Those trusting in
impartational/practical righteousness instead in order to get to heaven are
trusting wrongly in works-righteousness for a benefit it was never intended to
bestow.
Prologue                                                                  Page 37

fester into a malignant brain cancer that makes it impossible for them
genuinely to believe the gospel.
       Congregations are led to believe that they must commit to changing
their performance (and follow through on that commitment) in order to reach
heaven. Consequently, even on those occasions when their pastors may
spend most of a sermon stressing that eternal life is a free gift, parishioners
will be hard pressed to respond savingly to the message they are hearing
from their pastors because churchgoers have had the notion planted in their
minds (almost subconsciously) that such a message stressing the freeness of
eternal life is compatible with their belief that they must commit to living a
good life (and follow through with that commitment) in order to have eternal
life.
                     Illustration 5. I believe—but not really




        Despite their profession (and belief) that they believe eternal life is a
free gift, they actually believe that they cannot have eternal life without
living a good life. In other words, they do not really believe that eternal life
is a free gift; they just think they do. The worst thing about it all is that they
really think that they believe that the gift is free, but they do not truly believe
that it is free. The works-righteousness planted in the back of their minds
makes it pragmatically impossible for them to respond in saving faith. By
the frequent and predictable association they have learned from their pastors
in connecting the possession of eternal life with a change in performance,
they have been inoculated satanically from being able to respond saving to
the message that eternal life is a free gift.
        Psychologists can train dogs to associate a tone with electrical shock
by simultaneously producing that tone and shocking the dogs every time
they feed the dogs. Eventually, the dogs unknowingly begin to associate that
tone with the shock, even when no food is present. The human ability to
make mental associations far exceeds that of dogs. In a similar, yet far more
sophisticated manner, Satan is using pseudo-Lordship pastors to condition
their congregations into unconsciously associating the free offer of eternal
Page 38                                 Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
life with changing their performance (as a soteric necessity) so that their
congregations will think that they must change their performance when they
are given the free offer of eternal life, even though no mention of changing
their behavior is present for vast stretches of many evangelistic sermons. By
rocking back and forth between saying that the free gift of eternal life is not
based on performance but requires a change in performance, Satan is able to
use such pastors to make congregations immune to the gospel, even on those
occasions when their pastors speak correctly about the gospel. The
congregation has been trained successfully, yet unknowingly of course (and
perhaps unwittingly by such pastors), to perceive an unstated association,
even on those occasions when the gospel is stated accurately, so that they
believe that heaven is nevertheless a reward based on their performance even
when they are told it is not. They have become accustomed to think of
heaven as free, yet not free. Unbeknownst to them, this means that heaven is
not truly free in their way of thinking.
       Satan demonstrated his penetrating insight into the human psyche in
the Garden of Eden, and he still manifests it in typical pulpits today. He
plays many pastors like a tone, using them to condition their congregations
into thinking that they believe that heaven is a free gift—while
unknowingly, yet simultaneously, they are led to believe that heaven is a
reward. The shock will come when those who have believed this false gospel
wind up in hell because they never truly believed that heaven is a free gift
with no performance strings attached. To be sure, they (and their pastors)
believe that they believe that eternal life is a free gift. The sad reality, on the
other hand, is that they do not really believe that eternal life is a free gift. I
know. I used to be a pastor. When I asked the people in my congregation
diagnostic questions* to determine what they really believed, even after
preaching at length about the freeness of eternal life, it became alarmingly
apparent that they did not truly believe that eternal life was a free gift. They
had been conditioned by previous pastors to perceive that good performance
is somehow necessary to enter heaven no matter how clearly I demonstrated
otherwise. So the deacons in my congregation insisted that I stop asking the
congregation such diagnostic questions! Silencing the few messengers that
actually sound a warning is an altogether too common response.

       Believing that you Believe
       I have talked with many people and read many writers who genuinely
believe that they believe that eternal life is a free gift. Regrettably, they do
not genuinely believe that eternal life is a free gift—they just believe that

they do. Logically, if churchgoers believe that they must perform up to a

                        Illustration 6. Mistaken Belief




        The tombstones of most Lordship Salvationists could read: “He
believed that he believed.” Jesus said that the majority within professing
Christendom would try to enter by the broad gate into heaven only to find
out that they have taken a path that leads to destruction (Mt 7:13-14). Trying
to take the broad path of good performance to heaven is like trying to paddle
up a waterfall! Most Lordship Salvationists will fall to their eternal death. I
used to be a pseudo Lordship Salvationist, so I know the mentality.
        I have also fallen down a waterfall—literally. Back in my younger
days, I was standing on the top of a waterfall, taking off my socks, thinking
that if I did so I could walk across the top of that waterfall. I was wrong.
Thankfully, when I fell, although I glanced my head against a rock on the
way down, I was still conscious enough to point my feet downward as I
bounced off the rocks, until I finally landed amidst the rocks in a less-than-
waist-deep pool at bottom. If that fall had killed me, I guess they could have
written on my tombstone: “Thought he could walk on water.”
Page 40                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        As it was, when I landed, and was slumped over in the shallow pool,
my brother, Phil, who had been standing at the bottom (some distance away
getting his camera ready to take a picture) was running toward me, through
the rocks and water, shouting: “Are you all right?” I looked up, eventually,
blood running down my face, and asked, “Did you get a picture?” He had
not. Too bad.
        People have died falling down our mountain waterfalls. I came close
to being one of them. After that experience, I have never tried to walk across
the top of a waterfall again. And I would caution anyone else against doing
so. In this book, I likewise supply a warning. Do not try to paddle your way
upstream to heaven, no matter what your pastor may tell you. Only one
person could paddle His way to heaven—and He could walk on water. I’m
not Him, and neither are you.
               Illustration 7. Don’t Paddle Yourself to Death!




       Jesus promises: “He who believes in Me has eternal life” (Jn 6:47;
TM). He does not promise: “He who believes that he believes in Me has
eternal life.” Fooling yourself into thinking that you believe in Christ for
Prologue                                                                Page 41

eternal life as a free gift when, in fact, you are trusting in Christ for eternal
life as a result of your performance does not qualify you as believing in
Christ for eternal life. Believing in one’s performance is not the same thing
as believing in Christ. Hell is the only thing promised to those who trust in
their performance for entrance into heaven.

       Danger
       I am confident that my sons have eternal life. Does this mean that I
can sit back and relax and not be concerned about their being exposed to
false teaching that exhorts them to paddle upstream in an effort to escape
from hell? Not at all. Escape from the outer darkness is still at stake.
Believers are to paddle upstream for the heavenly reward of hearing the
Lord say, “Well done, good and faithful slave; you were faithful with a few
things, I will put you in charge of many things” (Mt 25:21). Rulership comes
with a price tag. We must pay it with faithfulness, not only paddling
upstream, but paddling upstream for the right reasons. Entrance into heaven
is not conditioned on how well we perform but inheriting the kingdom
certainly is. If believers subsequently insult the Lord by trying to earn the
gift which He already has given them freely, then they fall from grace into
the outer darkness (which is exclusion from the realm of ruling service to
which they otherwise could have aspired).

       Control of your Life
        On the same Sunday in which our pastor preached his second
successive sermon on Gal 5:16-21, stressing that salvation from hell is all
about who is in control of your life, Jeremy, my oldest son, sent me an email
asking me why is it that some Christians whom he had admired previously
for following the “straight and narrow” seem not to care anymore about
living for the Lord?21 Since a large part of my motive for writing this book is
to help my sons, I will add a note here to address Jeremy’s question in the
context of our pastor’s sermon—a sermon which Jeremy also heard. Not
even a whisper of eternal life as being free was made in this particular
sermon in which control of performance was the complete focus.
        Many people have given Christ control of their lives earlier in their
lives, just as our pastor has called upon the congregation to do again in this
sermon, yet they have faltered on that earlier commitment and lost interest.
According to some teachers within our church, these carnal (worldly)
believers have lost their salvation. Carnal believers are no longer saved in
the opinion of these teachers. Given our pastor’s sermon, this certainly
would make sense. After all, if having eternal life is conditioned on having
Christ in control of one’s life, then if one ceases to have Christ in control of
one’s life, one loses salvation. Thus, believers who have turned away from
Page 42                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
the Lord have lost their salvation. Many Arminians within our congregation
would be satisfied by-and-large with this explanation.
       Given our pastor’s Calvinistic perspective, however, he probably
would prefer to hedge his statement by saying that such carnal believers
were never genuine believers. The problem, of course, with this cop-out is
that these believers did, at one time, make the very commitment regarding
their performance that our pastor was urging people in our worship service
to make—promising them that they would be saved if they made this
commitment. If our pastor’s promise means anything, then such a Calvinistic
explanation is worthless. These carnal believers had made such a
commitment. Either that commitment does not save (or his promise is false)
or the commitment does save (and salvation was lost). The promise and the
perspective are mutually exclusive. Logically, one must either reject the
promise or the Calvinistic perspective—or both. I reject both.

would win hands down in terms of logical consistency. Marrowism,
however, trumps Arminianism in terms of such logical consistency because
Marrowism does not confuse a gift with a reward and because Marrowism
teaches that eternal life is eternal life, not temporal life: A life that is eternal
cannot be lost, and a gift cannot be earned.
        So, Jeremy, one reason that many people whom you admired
previously as Christians will fizzle in their commitment to the Lord is
because they were never really saved in the beginning. They merely believed
that they believed. They were never genuine believers. From the onset, they
bought into the Calvinistic and Arminian lies that their salvation was a free
gift apart from works that was conditioned on their works. The mental strain
of this irrationalism takes its toll on the intellect, making it difficult for
logically consistent people to maintain. Perhaps some of those whom you
previously held in high regard just got tired of trying to earn heaven by their
performance while being told that heaven is a free gift. They simply may
have tired of the irrationalism inherent in the evangelistic messages they
have heard all their lives. Having heard nothing but such irrational
explanations, they may not realize that an alternative is possible. They have
had no one to turn to, because every Christian they had ever met held to the
irrationalism embedded in the typical Lordship evangelism.

within the Bible have been known to leave their first love for the Lord

This is why the biblical solution to carnality is, “Remember” (Rev 2:5).
        You will see Christians fall into a carnal lifestyle. I warned you that
this would happen before you left for college. Many of these friends were
never saved to start with because they thought that their salvation from hell
was contingent on their performance. They need to be shown that eternal life
is a free gift. They need to be awakened to the genuine freeness of God’s
saving grace by realizing that it is not conditioned on their performance,
despite the sermons they have heard to the contrary all their lives. In the
meantime, you yourself will be tempted by these licentious friends. You
yourself will need to remember what is at stake: salvation from the outer
darkness, from loss of rewards in heaven (not to mention painful experiences
on earth from the discipline of your Father). Do not let licentious friends
cause you to forget what is at stake. You are loved conditionally as a servant
of Christ and subject to the outer darkness if you fail in your service.

those whom you previously respected. The theme music from Mission
Impossible® would be appropriate here. Your mission, if you should choose

lives. Hell is not at stake. The outer darkness is. To confuse the two issues is
to teach a performance-based gospel that leads to hell. Do not make that
mistake!
