       Legalistic Friends
        Returning now to the general readership, a slogan on television says,
“Friends don’t let friends drive drunk.” This book is a word of concern to
my friends in the Bible study committee, in FCA, in our churches, and in our
pulpits. Friends don’t let friends teach a turn-or-burn evangelistic gospel. He
is no friend who shows no concern and keeps his mouth shut out of fear of
offending his friends. May God grant my friends the “repentance leading to
the knowledge of the truth” (2Tim 2:25).
        These people are my friends. I not only love these people; I like them.
My sons and I attend and support their Bible studies, FCA meetings, and
churches. There are many positive reasons for our doing so. These friends
teach that one should love Jesus and live for Jesus. I’m all for that! “If
anyone does not love the Lord, let him be [temporally and misthologically]
accursed” (1Cor 16:22). I love their love for the Lord, and I appreciate their
stance for morally sound Christian virtues. I am not going to throw out the
baby with the bathwater when it comes to participating in local Christian
ministries. FCA has a lot of great Christian literature and people. And
despite Ray Comfort’s involvement in Way of the Master, his Scientific
Facts in the Bible is a splendid little apologetic book. I gave my boys copies
of this book to read, despite the fact that it conditions salvation from hell on
turning from all sin and thus teaches a false gospel on the last page of the
book: only one bad page in the whole book.22 I simply pointed out the error
of this page to my sons. To speak colloquially, sometimes you simply have
to spit out the bones when you are eating a good fish.
        Likewise, sometimes the best one can do is keep one’s own garments
white (and hopefully those of one’s family white) by teaching one’s loved
ones to discern truth from error when interacting with friends in the church
who insist on soiling their own garments (Rev 3:4). When my friends in the
church start conditioning entering heaven on our love for Jesus and on our
living for Jesus, then to that degree they have stopped conditioning entering
heaven on Jesus’ love for us and His death for us. They are soiling their
garments (Is 64:6). And I am going to encourage them to change the
bathwater, or in this case, the linen water! We not only need moral purity but
doctrinal purity as well. But as it is, with their teaching of conditionalistic
salvation, my friends not only are soiling their own garments but
inadvertently are trying to lead my children astray into soiling their own
garments with works-righteousness as the means of entering heaven as well.
My friends are trying to cause my children to fall from grace (Gal 5:4). My
friends are trying to lead my boys astray into legalistic performance with the
result that my boys would be disqualified from being overcomers in white
garments and would be thrown into the outer darkness as the outcome. So
what is a father to do but take up his pen and write? I will not let my
children slip quietly into the night without a fight!
                            Introduction
       Clash of the Titans
        The propensity for pastors and theologians to speak out of both sides
of their mouths is aptly described by Gracely with the analogy of the rocking
horse.23 He has documented this phenomenon, as it applies to Calvinism,
also explaining how it is implemented psychologically. He links it
philosophically to the relativism of the Hegelian dialectic. Perhaps pastors
are implementing this technique unconsciously. In any event, Gracely’s
rocking-horse analogy serves as a suitable introduction to the present book
because he relates that discussion to Jonathan Edwards: “Jonathan Edwards,
the well-known 18th century Calvinist, believed that a man always willed his
choice in the direction of his greatest desire.”24 (Gracely challenges
Edward’s position exegetically and philosophically.) The present book will
provide a challenge to Edwardsean deterministic thinking from the pen of
yet another well-known Christian writer, C. S. Lewis, as an advocate of free
will, who argues philosophically that human beings are capable of deciding
to follow their weaker desire.
        For those not acquainted with the theological ramifications of this
face-off between Edwardsean determinism and Arminian libertarianism, it
amounts to answering this question: “Does God cause everything?” The
Calvinistic Westminster Confession of Faith addresses the issue this way:

             God, from all eternity, did, by the most wise and holy
      counsel of His own will freely, and unchangeably ordain
      whatsoever comes to pass: yet so, as thereby neither is God
      the author of sin, nor is violence offered to the will of the
      creatures; nor is the liberty or contingency of second causes
      taken away, but rather established. (WCF 3.1)

Gracely rightly criticizes this answer:

             This sentence is a contradiction because it involves two
      ideas in which each idea makes it impossible for the other idea
      to be true. Yet under the Westminster Confessions these two
      opposing propositions form a ‘system’ (or synthesis) that is
      nevertheless held to be true.25

If the confession is restated in Hegelian structure, without the masking of
synonymous vocabulary, the contradiction is more apparent:
Page 48                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
  •   Thesis: God sovereignly causes (i.e., ordains) everything.
  •   Antithesis: God does not sovereignly cause (i.e., ordain) sin.
  •   Synthesis: The thesis is relatively true as qualified by the antithesis.

        By changing the word from ordain in its thesis to author in its
antithesis, WCF is better able to mask its doublespeak. In actuality, the same
issue is under discussion in both statements and boils down to an attempt to
avoid a straightforward answer to the question: “Does God sovereignly
decree everything that will take place?” To decree sovereignly is to cause
irresistibly. On the one hand, WCF says that God does; on the other hand, it
says that He does not. The WCF thesis, by logical implication, makes God
the author of sin; the WCF antithesis denies the logical outcome of its own
thesis. Along the way, the human ability to do otherwise than perform the
sin that God sovereignly has decreed is both affirmed and denied. This
logical contradiction has left no room for mystery. Yet Calvinists appeal to
mystery as a means to continue the illusion of a successful synthesis.
                      Illustration 9. Prescriptive Thesis




       With its thesis, WCF makes sovereignty completely prescriptive. God
gives the directives for everything that happens. Some people do this
without thinking, it would seem. The evening that I wrote this note, while I
was walking out of the recreation department after a workout, the custodian
mentioned that it was raining—again. We are well over our quota for rain
this summer. He remarked, “Well, I guess the Good Lord thought we needed
Introduction                                                          Page 49

more rain. He knows what is best.” I responded, “I certainly believe in
sovereignty, but I think there is some room for free will and free rain.”
       Last summer, we had a drought. Did the Lord think we needed a
drought last summer and a super abundance of rain this summer? Does God
calculate how much rain we are to get everyday to the precise rain drop? A
humorous example perhaps, but when seemingly mindless tragedy strikes
and lives are lost in a flood, must one remark, “Well, I guess the Good Lord
thought we needed that rain and that those people needed to die”? I don’t
think so. One may read Gracely’s book for further discussion as to the
tension between sovereignty and the weather. For present purposes, I simply
point out that WCF has made God not only responsible for the weather but
for sin as well, when it says that God unchangeably ordains [orders,
decrees, prescribes, dictates] whatsoever comes to pass: be it rain or sin.
       Perceiving this to be the case, WCF swings immediately to the
opposite end of the spectrum and gives the illusion that sin is attributable to
the will of the creatures God has created. To affirm God’s permissive will,
however, and thereby make room for the free will of His created beings to
rebel against His sovereign will, completely nullifies the WCF thesis. How
can creatures freely sin against God’s sovereign will?
                    Illustration 10. Permissive Antithesis




       Back and forth the Calvinists goes, making completely contradictory
statements in affirmation of God’s prescriptive sovereignty to the
elimination of any other possibility and then rocking back in the opposite
direction with statements completely at odds with their previous statements.
Page 50                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
In the end, Calvinists who do not make genuine room for God’s permissive
will have nullified human free will and have made God responsible for
human sin. Making room for God’s permissive will by claiming that He
permits us to do what He already has sovereignly decreed that we will do is
nothing but a sham, one more rock of the saddle.
       Appealing to indirect causation is not any better. To be sure, the
Calvinistic God may or may not directly cause everything to take place—
depending on which Calvinist you ask. Nevertheless, the Calvinistic God is
logically the one ultimately responsible for everything that takes place and
the way it takes place, even though He may act through secondary causes.
For example, the statement, “The king ordained the execution,” only affirms
that the king ordered the execution by virtue of his superior authority. He
was not the one who carried the execution out. Still, he is responsible for the
execution. To the extent of his authority, he issued the decree to perform the
execution and would see to it that it was carried out. In the OT, a “king had
ordained to destroy the wise men of Babylon” (Dan 2:24; KJV). This earthly
king’s decree was circumvented by Daniel. The Calvinist, however, has
everything sovereignly ordained by God, so circumvention of anything is
impossible.
       In the Calvinistic system of thought, God cannot circumvent His
decree; otherwise, He would have to give a decree to circumvent Himself! A
second party could not act to circumvent God’s original decree unless this
second party was decreed by God to circumvent God’s original decree since
everything (including the circumvention by the second party) is decreed by
God. Because God unchangeably has decreed everything, everything is set
in stone. God cannot circumvent Himself, and no one can circumvent God.
Moreover, as the issuer of the original decree, God will do everything
necessary within the extent of His power to see to it that His decree is
carried out. Unlike an earthly king who may have the execution of his will
circumvented, God will not have His sovereign will circumvented. Even for
those Calvinists who try to circumvent making God the direct cause for sin,
there is no escape from making Him the ultimate cause for sin. If God
ordain/causes everything, then God ordains/causes sin.
       Within the Calvinistic system, those Calvinists who try to get God off
the hook for causing sin do so by asserting that so-called freewill actions are
caused by one’s strongest desires. This Edwardsean mentality only begs the
question: “Who ultimately determines our strongest desires according to
Calvinism?” God! Because God irresistibly determines our strongest desires,
He irresistibly determines what we will do, including what sins we will
commit. In this clash of the titans between Edwards and Lewis (representing
the clash between Calvinistic determinism and Arminian libertarianism,
respectively), the present book will be found in the Arminian corner,
championing free will. Otherwise, one makes God the devil, and the devil
God.
Introduction                                              Page 51

               Illustration 11. Who’s Controlling Whom?
Page 52                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        In determinism, God logically becomes the devil in that He
sovereignly causes sin by dictating the strongest desires of His freewill
creatures so that they must carry out their strongest desire (and thus His
sovereign desire) in sinning. With the same logical consistency, it may be
deduced that the devil effectively becomes God because God acknowledges
that the devil can incite Him to certain courses of action, even against His
faithful followers like Job (Job 2:3). Since according to Calvinists one’s
freewill actions are caused irresistibly by one’s strongest desires, Satan can
irresistibly control the Calvinistic God—by causing God to act in
accordance with the desires Satan causes God to have. After all, the
Edwardsean God could not do other than what His strongest desires dictate,
and that desire (in some cases at least) is determined by Satan. On this
occasion regarding Job, such a mindset logically would make God a helpless
pawn in Satan’s hands. As a result of the intense desire Satan evoked within
God, Satan sovereignly invoked the Edwardsean God to action by evoking a
strong desire within God to allow him to afflict Job. In short, Satan was
pulling God’s strings in much the same way that Calvinistic determinism has
God pulling our strings.
        Calvinistically, appealing to God’s preexisting sovereignty will not
help any. God would only sovereignly be predetermining to let Satan
sovereignly determine what God would do at that subsequent point when
Satan incited Him. God and Satan would be taking turns in pulling each
other’s strings. If one were to picture God and Satan standing in front of two
mirrors facing one another, Satan, in effect, would become God’s Calvinistic
mirror image in the never-ending mirror in a mirror.
        Picturing God as knowingly deciding to create something that would
uncontrollably induce Him to commit evil does not absolve God of evil.
Suppose Sam decided to create a still, even though he knew it would
undoubtedly cause him to do things he normally would not do and should
not do. While driving under the influence of the moonshine he created, Sam
unavoidably hits Job, who was just crossing the street minding his own
business. Does driving while under the influence of the alcohol Sam created
make Sam’s actions morally excusable as merely attributable to the
moonshine? Of course not! Neither is it excusable for Calvinists to present a
theology that logically would depict God as running over Job because God
was acting uncontrollably under the influence of the satanic being He
knowingly had created that irresistibly would incite Him to do otherwise
than what He would do normally. The Calvinistic domino effect makes God
dually responsible for the sin: (1) He pushed Satan who (2) pushed Him to
sin. The Calvinistic response that God voluntarily* has the right to make

*
  Divine Voluntarism—in the Calvinistic camp means that something is right
and good just because God wills it. Divine Essentialism—in contrast asserts that
Introduction                                                          Page 53

satanic moonshine and then drive uncontrollably (yet knowingly) under its
influence and damage His creatures in the process (just because He is God)
does not make for a morally-acceptable picture of God.26 Might does not
necessarily make right.
                   Illustration 12. Who’s Pushing Whom?




       The libertarian response does away with the chain of sufficient
causation that lays sin at God’s doorstep by acknowledging that one’s
strongest desire does not determine one’s course of action. Just because God
allowed Satan to afflict Job does not mean that God helplessly capitulated to
His strongest desire. Instead, God chose (of His own free will) to act in
accord with His strongest desire by permitting Satan to afflict Job in order to
show that Satan was wrong in his slanderous attack on God’s character and
on Job’s character. Doing so was God’s free choice and was in accordance
with His good nature. Nevertheless, God could have chosen to do otherwise.
       Calvinists will insist that God always acts in accordance with His
strongest desires. Such an assessment would be mistaken, however, not only
because it would have Satan sovereignly pulling God’s strings but because
God clearly chooses, at times, to act against His strongest desire, as Gracely
explains concerning

             Jesus’ statement to the Father in Gethsemane [Mt 26:39],
      “Not my desire, but thine be done?” (Gr. thelo, i.e., desire,
      (which, depending upon context, either means bare desire, or a
      will congruent with desire, or a will incongruent with desire).

God wills something because it is good and right, because it is in accordance
with the essence of His immutable good nature.
Page 54                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
      Christ (i.e., the Son) is clearly stating that His strongest desire
      is to avoid crucifixion, while the Father’s strongest desire is that
      He undergo crucifixion. Edwards’s response presumably would
      be that Christ ultimately had a greater desire to please His
      Father than He had desire to avoid the cross. But this argument
      renders Christ’s statement about His strongest desire
      meaningless.…Christ said “Not my will” (Gr. thelo,
      contextually here, desire). Thus Christ bent His will in a
      direction opposite of His desire and did not follow His strongest
      desire. Properly speaking, then, Christ willed the Father’s
      desire; He did not desire the Father’s desire. That is, He chose
      it. On this basis we may conclude Edwards’s argument false
      (i.e., that a man always chooses according to his strongest
      desire). Indeed, how else is the Christian to also understand
      Christ’s statement that the one who wishes to follow Christ
      must deny himself? That is, how can one follow Christ while
      denying himself? The conflict in Christ to will something other
      than His strongest desire is, in fact, the whole basis for Christ’s
      agony in Gethsemane. (Emphasis his.)27

       The reason libertarians champion free will is not because they have a
philosophical axe to grind or a love affair with the idea of free will. Rather,
because libertarians love God, they will not stand by idly while His character
is besmirched by the logical implications of Calvinistic determinism.
Libertarians insist that the blame for sin logically lies at the feet of the
freewill creation, not at the feet of the freewill Creator. Freewill agents
rebelled against the One who endowed them with free will, thereby incurring
their own guilt.
       Moreover, as an aside, I would mention that libertarians do not
believe that freewill agents control God by the strong desires they evoke
within God. Some libertarians set up a false dichotomy between sovereignty
and free will, as if you are limited to one or the other. Arminians, for
example, will assert that after one becomes a believer one may still lose
eternal life. According to such libertarians, you were saved by your own free
will, so you must be able to lose your salvation by your own free will. To
claim otherwise reputedly would be a violation of the believer’s free will.
       By way of rebuttal, I would remind fellow libertarians, who live on
the other side of the tracks in the Arminian camp, that our free will does not
control God. Libertarians defend free will because they defend the
character of God. This statement is true for Arminian libertarianism as well
as for Marrowian libertarianism. Because it is not a violation of God’s
character to suppose that He sovereignly (i.e., irresistibly and irrevocably)
saves His children, the supposition that He may sovereignly decree that
those who come to Christ will reach heaven unconditionally is not a
Introduction                                                          Page 55

violation of libertarianism. The believer’s free will does not dictate to God
what He can and cannot do. God’s character is the controlling factor. The
character of our Father is such that He sovereignly saves His children. Just
as I would defend God’s character against the thoroughgoing Calvinistic
sovereignty that makes God culpable for our sin, I will defend my Father’s
character from the thoroughgoing Arminian libertarianism that makes God
impotent to save His children. God is omnipotent, not impotent. My defense
of unconditional security is a defense of God’s character as Father. Child
abandonment is not in His character.

      Harmony of the Titans
        The major thesis of this present book, therefore, is not aimed at the
clash between Lewis and Edwards regarding free will. As important as that
discussion may be, defending God’s character against those who attack it
under the guise of upholding His sovereignty is not the only issue at stake.
Extreme libertarians also engage in character assassination from the opposite
direction. Surprisingly, those upholding God’s sovereignty are not immune
from attacking God’s character from this opposite direction either. Calvinists
join hands with Arminians in portraying God as making the salvation of His
children contingent upon their perseverance. Like deadly dragons, these
false theologies are dragging people to hell and defaming God’s character in
the process. This book is dedicated to fighting such monsters and defending
God’s character. Unlike the false gods in the OT who had children thrown
into fire, our God does not throw His children into the fire.
                         Illustration 13. Free Thesis
Page 56                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity


        Our people, the people in our churches, frequently are being given a
false picture of God and a false means of salvation. They are being seduced
into trying to ride a rocking horse to safety and being lulled into a false sense
of security, thinking that they successfully are fleeing from meritorious
dragons. This book is a call to get off the rocking horse and flee to Christ for
eternal life. One cannot flee to Christ by riding the Calvinistic-Arminian
rocking horse. Dismount the horse and run! Easier said than done, however.
The Arminian and Calvinistic titans vigorously press the Protestant believer
into the rocking-horse saddle screaming, “Rock faster!”
        Getting out of the saddle is difficult when those with pastoral
authority are shouting to stay in the saddle. Both Lewis and Edwards insist
that perseverance in riding that saddle is necessary to reach heaven.
According to them, if you rock hard enough and long enough, your horse,
supposedly, will eventually bring you to God’s green pastures. As in the
discussion of sovereignty, the illusion of mysterious harmony is created by
rocking back and forth between contradictory assertions. On the one hand,
Protestant pastors strongly affirm that salvation from hell is free. They may
even spend the bulk of their sermons defending this thesis, thus giving the
unsuspecting listener the false impression that they really believe such
salvation is actually free, as they talk out of the right side of their mouths.
                       Illustration 14. Costly Antithesis
Introduction                                                             Page 57


        As a rule, however, before the sermon is over, or at least at the
invitation, these pastors will rear back on their antithesis and qualify their
thesis with provisos. In effect, they are saying that heaven is free except in
the fact that it is not free. Naturally, they are not going to state the matter so
bluntly. Gracely’s discussion of the psychological subtlety with which
contradictions are made regarding sovereignty could also be read profitably
as applying to this aspect of soteriology.
        When my children were very young, my wife and I bought them a
blue rocking horse. They used to rock back and forth, pretending they were
riding a real horse, imaging that they were making real progress. Many
sermons are like that rocking horse, giving an illusion of progress, with what
the onlooker perceives to be exegetical movement in the pulpit. In reality,
the only thing achieved is logical inconsistency. Such pastors do not lead
their flocks to green pastures.
        Rocking horses eventually end up in the junk pile. They never eat the
green grass. The theological tragedy is that those who insist on staying on
the rocking horse provided by Lewis and Edwards eventually will end up in
the junk pile of hell. To say the least, this rocking horse is not a child’s play
thing. As will be shown in this present study, Lewis and Edwards concur
that one is saved from hell by virtue of one’s perseverance in faith.
According to these literary giants, riding one’s faith unto the end is
necessary to escape damnation in the end.
        The horror of it all is that Calvinistic and Arminian pastors adopting
such an approach could be likened to the parents of young children whose
house is burning down while the parents are screaming, “Rock harder!” Like
a dad and mom of a household, the Calvinistic and Arminian pastors will not
agree with one another on every detail, but they are agreed on the
fundamental safety of their children. Such pastors are doing their loving best
to save their loved ones from the fires burning around them by having their
flocks rock furiously in a frantic attempt to escape the fires of hell.
        Knowing that the roof eventually will cave in on such parents and
their children, who are trying to ride out of their burning house on their
rocking horses, the neighbors outside are crying out, “Get off the rocking
horse and run!” But the rocking pastors inside are shouting to their
congregational children, “Don’t listen to those heretics, listen to us!”
        The irony is that some of the children of their flock are my own
children. Since such sermonic inconsistency is such a widespread tendency,
it is not as if I can just tell my children that we will find a church that is
consistent. We have been there, tried that, and found that sermonic
consistency is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, to find. The time has
come where my sons are getting old enough that they can be taught how to
spot such sermonic inconsistencies for themselves and recognize a rocking
horse behind the pulpit for what it is—demonic deception.
Page 58                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

       Free and Costly
        Just as the present book defends both the sovereignty of God and the
free will of humanity without compromising either, it will also defend the
freeness of eternal life without diminishing its costly aspects. Regeneration
is that aspect of eternal life which pertains to our entering heaven and is
completely free in both its initial reception and continued possession. The
crown of life, in contrast, is an additional, superlative experience of eternal
life. Crowns in heaven are not free. They are rewards. Unlike the costly-free
dialectic which falsely regards soteric regeneration as being both costly and
free, the distinction being made herein does not revoke the law of non-
contradiction since the aspect of eternal life that is free is not confused (or
fused) with the aspect of eternal life that is not free.

       Inerrancy
         Of course, my sons (and others) need to be warned of liberals who
deny the inerrancy of Scripture theologically. Just as acutely, they need to be
wary of conservatives who deny the inerrancy of Scripture pragmatically by
portraying the Bible as full of logical (as opposed to supposedly factual)
contradictions, making it impossible to understand the Bible logically. For
reputed inerrantists to claim that the Bible is inerrant (as a thesis), then quip
that it is logically inconsistent (as an antithesis), and then claim that both are
mysteriously true (as a synthesis) is nothing more than rocking-horse
doubletalk. Sure, there are limits to what logic can do. Of course, Scripture
takes precedence over logic. Logic is a servant to Scripture. Even so, it is a
disservice to Scripture to dispense with the service performed by logic.

       Logic
       Among other things, being created in the image of God means that we
were created as rational beings because God is a rational being. Logic is
rooted in the nature of God and thus in our nature. At our deepest level, we
do not accept contradictions or doubletalk. We have an innate need for
truth—for logical consistency. Modernism mistakenly thought that logic was
the cure-all so that God was no longer necessary. To the contrary, logic,
without the light of Scripture, gropes along in darkness. Such logic stumbles
and falls. Without God as the foundation for logic, the tower of modernism
fell, collapsing into a despairing, atheistic, postmodernistic revulsion of
logic.
       When theologians cloak their irrationality by calling it mystery, they
are undermining the very foundation upon which theology is built. The word
theology is derived from combination of two biblical Greek words: theos
(God) and logos (logic). Biblical theology is logical teaching about God.
Geisler defines theology as “the logic of God. Theology is rational discourse
Introduction                                                            Page 59

about God.”28 Irrational pastors may object to having their irrational
statements subjected to logic, claiming that doing so subjects God to logic.
On the contrary, God is not on trial; irrational preachers are. Sermons that
are true to the nature of God will not violate God’s moral laws or His logical
laws. The axiomatic “law of non-contradiction (A is not non-A) [which]
says that no two contradictory statements can be true at the same time and in
the same sense” can be applied to their sermons because “God is the author
of all logic” (Geisler’s emphasis).29 Not even God can do what actually is
impossible logically, such as making a round square, because that would go
against His very nature. The truly mysterious goes beyond human reason,
not against it (emphasis his).30
        Or as Gracely would express it, the human inability to know God
comprehensively does not nullify the ability to know Him fundamentally
(emphasis his).31 Just as A cannot be non-A, just as light is not darkness, just
as sweet is not bitter, just as it is wrong to “call evil good, and good evil”
(Is 5:20), so it is wrong to call free costly! Lordship Salvationists are being
irrational when they talk of the free gift of eternal life as being costly to the
believer.
        And please, if by chance you are a pastor reading this book, do not
respond that the gift of eternal life is free to us but costly to God. Of course
it is! I am simply tired of pastors using this dialectic to mask their
contradiction when they claim the free gift of eternal life is costly to us.
More interesting dialectics (such as free to receive but costly to keep) will be
refuted as we proceed.* After all, the Bible says “to refute those who
contradict” sound doctrine (Tit 1:9).† But the dialectic that costly to God
means costly to us is just plain insulting to rational thought.
        The Bible tells us to be rational (logikos) in our worship of God in
Rom 12:1 (MRD). Most translations render the word in question as spiritual
or reasonable. Of course, if the requested worship is in accord with reason,
it is rational and reasonable. As to the rendering of spiritual, certainly this
type of worship feeds our spirit (the metaphysical as opposed to physical
dimension of our being), and the context is using logikos in relation to
dedicating our physical bodies spiritually to God. Still, the word in question
is logikos (logical), the adjective form of logos (logic). Why not simply
translate the verse as the CJB does, as referring to an act of worship that we
are to perform because it is logical?
        Christians are supposed to be logicians, at least to a reasonable
degree. They are expected to offer themselves as living sacrifices to God

Page 60                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
because doing so is logical, not mechanical or external. In the OT, no appeal

on the alter and be slain. It was given no choice. Lambs could not offer
themselves logically of their own free, intelligent, informed decision.32
Human beings, on the other hand, are given free choice and allowed to make
an informed decision. Therefore, an appeal to their intellect is within reason.
For good reason, Geisler entitles his book, Come Let us Reason. God gives
this invitation: “‘Come now, and let us reason together,’ says the Lord,
‘Though your sins are as scarlet, they will be as white as snow; though they
are red like crimson, they will be like wool’” (Is 1:18). God expects us to
reason with Him because He is reasonable.
        To be sure, God’s thoughts are higher than our thoughts (Is 55:8-9).
Calculus is a higher branch of mathematics than arithmetic. Yet this does not
mean that calculus is irrational or contradictory to arithmetic. In the same
way, this biblical text should not be used as proof text to assert that God is
unknowable or illogical, especially since the context suggests that God only
may be describing His moral supremacy to sinful humanity. Or, at the very
least, as Gracely notes: “this [text] means in degree, not in fundamental
nature, so that a proper logic would no longer be applicable” (emphasis
his).33 In any event, God clearly asserts that He may be found by those who
seek Him (Is 55:6-7).

       Harmony of Trio
        A three-headed dragon will be pictured within the pages of this book
as three forms of merit. Another three-headed dragon must be exposed here.
The titans of Calvinism and Arminianism have spawned a beautiful
offspring, a promising child, by the name of Calminianism,* a deterministic-
libertarian siren singing a seductive song that lures its siblings to destruction
by promising them sweet harmony between their clashing parents regarding
sovereignty and liberty, while at the same time singing in harmony with its
parents when it comes to calling for perseverance in faith as the costly
means of freely reaching heaven. “There’s no need to fear,” Calminianism
assures those concerned about the clash between sovereignty and liberty,
“As long as you keep rocking along, the fires of hell will not touch you.”
        With Calvinism, Arminianism, and Calminianism combining their
collective voices to make the virtuous strength of one’s commitment to

*
  Calminianism = Calvinism (TULIP) + Arminianism (PEARS). Calminianism
is a mediation between Calvinism and Arminianism that may be adequately

damnation. (For fuller definition, see Calminianism in Technical Terms, xiv.)
Introduction                                                           Page 61

persevere in the faith the condition for reaching heaven, most of those sitting
within the Protestant churches on Sunday morning, listening to Christian
radio during the week, and reading an occasional Christian book, find it easy
to be lulled into a false sense of security in their perseverance-based
soteriology, ignoring dissenting voices if perchance they hear any. Many
have never even heard a dissenting voice, calling for freedom from free-
costly inconsistencies. Most Protestants rock quietly along, back and forth,
impervious to the danger. I must protest. After all, I am a Protestant too.

       Four Schools of Thought
       Arminianism teaches that those who persevere are predestined to go
to heaven. If believers do not persevere, they actually lose their
regeneration. Ultimately, it is up to believers to avail themselves sufficiently
of God’s enabling grace so as to persevere and thus make it to heaven. In
summary, according to Arminianism, anyone can be saved, and those who
are saved actually can lose their salvation.
       Calvinism teaches that those who are predestined for heaven
persevere. Initially and ultimately, it is all up to God as to whether or not
you will persevere and make it to heaven. If you do not persevere, then you
were never sovereignly elected by the Calvinistic God to persevere, so that is
why you failed and went to hell. God’s will be done. You cannot do other
than what the Calvinistic God wills anyway. He is only going to save the
ones to whom He elected to give persevering grace, and He sovereignly will
cause them to persevere. Even so, elect believers hypothetically could lose
their regeneration. If they were not to persevere, they would lose their
regeneration. In summary, only the elect can be saved, and the elect
hypothetically could lose their salvation.
       Like Arminianism, Calminianism does not limit regeneration to a
Calvinistic select few who have no choice to the contrary in the matter. Like
Calvinism, on the other hand, Calminianism hypothetically affirms that if
believers were not to persevere, they would lose their regeneration.
Regenerate believers will persevere, and they will make it to heaven because
the Calminian God sovereignly has predetermined that they will persevere
(or because God has decided to withhold regeneration from those whom He
foreknew would not persevere—depending on which Calminian you ask).
Loss of regeneration hypothetically is possible. In summary, anyone can be
saved, and those who are saved hypothetically could lose their salvation.
       Like both Arminianism and Calvinism, Calminianism makes
perseverance necessary for salvation from eternal damnation. All three
schools of thought make retention of regeneration and final salvation
conditioned on perseverance. This commonality is what makes them a three-
headed dragon. In counter to these various forms of conditional security, the
present book affirms unconditional security, not some dialectic imitation that
Page 62                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
conditions unconditional security on perseverance—which is nothing but
doublespeak. A security that remains conditional after it has been granted is
not unconditional! Perseverance cannot be a condition for unconditional
security.
       The presentation in this present book, therefore, should not be
confused with Calminianism. Merely affirming that salvation is available for
all and that anyone who is saved will never lose that salvation is not enough
to qualify as a Marrowist. “What happens to believers who do not
persevere?” is a key question that distinguishes Marrowism from
Calminianism. The Calminian will insist that believers who do not persevere
go to hell, frequently stipulating that such believers were never genuine
believers to begin with. For the Calminian, perseverance is necessary to
reach heaven; for the Marrowist, it is not. Therein lies the major difference
between these two schools of thought.
       Naturally, Arminian and Calvinistic writings in general, and
Calminian writings in particular, can be read profitably when such writers
are speaking out of the right side of their mouths. For example, in this very
discussion, I have recommended Gracely’s Calminian writing. For the
discerning reader who has been given a heads-up on the inconsistency, I
would highly recommend other Calminian books as well.34
       Nevertheless, many readers and listeners fail to discern when a pastor,
writer, or teacher starts speaking out of the wrong side of his or her mouth
with logical and biblical inconsistency. Many victims too easily are led
astray by the inconsistency coming from the mouths and pens of those who
affirm inerrancy theologically while defending inconsistency pragmatically.
Therefore, writing a book such as this one is necessary. I do not wish my
sons, or those like them, to be caught unaware. At this stage in my sons’
development, they need to be given a heads-up. This book meets that need.

       Four Mascots
       My sons and I are used to attending sporting events and associating
schools with mascots. They and I both participated in high school sports. So
perhaps associating the school of thought advanced by Free Grace
Salvationists with a mascot will help my sons (and others) get a visual grip
on the issues at stake. The name I have chosen for this Free Grace school of
thought is Marrowism. The school mascot will be the meerkat.
       Hopefully, the addition of such illustrations will not be perceived as
being too whimsical or polemical for those who want a “serious” exchange
of ideas. I anticipate that those who read the body of this book will not find
it lacking in serious consideration of the primary issues under discussion.
For those, however, such as my sons, who are not accustomed to reading at
that depth, I have added these illustrations so that they might have a fighting
chance to grasp the concepts involved. My sons are a key part of my
intended audience, so I will attempt to bridge the gap between their reading
Introduction                                                        Page 63

level and mine with such illustrations. They are accustomed to seeing my
sermon handouts presented in terms of pictures and charts. So pardon me if I
combine my gift of teaching with my gift of knowledge (and a strong dose
of proclamation). Each of these gifts is biblical.
        I thoroughly appreciate Gracely’s description of the practical
ramifications of these gifts. He hit it right on the head.35 MacArthur’s
discussion of spiritual gifts is useful also.36 Unfortunately, the gift of
proclamatory warnings is frequently met with strong resistance by God’s
people, so much so that God’s people stoned the OT prophets sent to them.
The trend for God’s people to respond coldly to the warnings they receive
still survives today. Be that as it may, sounding the warning is necessary
both biblically and morally, even though those hearing it want to hit the
snooze on the alarm (and sometimes desire to hit the alarm clock itself).
                      Illustration 15. School Mascots
Page 64                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity


       Because of the poison in the tail ends of acronyms for the opposing
schools of thought, their mascots will be duped the scorpions, and disguised
from one another primarily by means of their stingers. The Calvinistic
scorpion naturally will have a P for its stinger due its acronym (TULIP). The
Arminian scorpion correspondingly will have an S because of its acronym
(PEARS). Calminianism will have a PS to represent the common
denominator it shares with the other two forms of conditionalism:
Perseverance of the Saints and Salvation through Perseverance.
       In contrast, to these competing schools of thought, the Marrowistic
meerkat will be associated with E in accordance with its acronym (GRAPE).
It must be remembered that for a Marrowist, eternal security is
unconditional security—a security not conditioned on the believer’s
perseverance. The other schools of thought sometimes will give mouth
service to eternal security. Nonetheless, when they do so, they are speaking
dialectically of an unconditional security that is conditioned on the
believer’s perseverance and therefore is not unconditional security for the
believer. In other words, they are speaking nonsense in the form of
doubletalk.
                   Illustration 16. Meerkats Eat Scorpions
Introduction                                                         Page 65

        When I told my youngest son, Jonathan, that I was going to use a
meerkat as an illustration in this book, he asked, “What is a meerkat?”
Thinking that I would be able to provide him with an example that he would
easily be able to identify, I mentioned that Timon in the Walt Disney
animation The Lion King™ was a meerkat. Living in the mountains of
Western North Carolina, Jonathan thought that it must be something like a
groundhog, which we see frequently in our area. A word of differentiation is
apparently in order. Meerkats live in the Kalahari Desert of South Africa and
are part of the mongoose family. Like the animated Timon, meerkats are
considered cute and adorable (by many) and feed on bugs and insects. Like a
mongoose, however, meerkats kill snakes. More importantly, for the sake of
my illustration, not only do meerkats eat snakes, they also eat scorpions. In
fact, meerkats are immune to the poison of the very potent scorpions that
live in the Kalahari Desert. As an interesting side note, in African folklore,
meerkats are considered sun angels who protect the villagers from moon
devils.
        Combining these images together for a composite of our school
mascot, Marrowistic meerkats are angelic in their protection of others, fierce
in devouring the venomous arguments of those who would do harm,
endowed (through sound doctrine) with an immunity to poisonous gospels,
and faithful servants of their Lion King—Lord Jesus. As for being cute and
adorable, well, I guess having a mascot that fits that bill will have to do.
                           Illustration 17. No Fear
Page 66                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Jeremy, my oldest son, has a motto that is appropriate for our mascot:
“No fear!” When understood within a biblical context, it is an appropriate
slogan. For example, “God has not given us a spirit of fear” (2Tim 1:7;
NKJ). On the other hand, even meerkats have guards on lookout duty for
danger. The Bible appropriately tells us to be on the lookout for Satan and
his false teachers. The Bible is not riding a rocking horse when, in certain
contexts, it rules out fear and in other contexts it urges caution. To the
contrary, some things we should fear, and other things we should not fear.
When one has been saved unconditionally from hell, there is no need to fear
hell. And there is no need to fear the teachings of those saying that you can
go to hell—if you are a believer and know how to unmask their
inconsistencies. The meerkat, living in a land infested with poisonous
creatures, does not run in fear from the scorpions or snakes. Instead, when
faced with such poisonous vermin, the meerkat exclaims, “Lunch!” This
book is intended to help train my young meerkat pups how to think
critically, logically, and biblically in devouring the sermonic scorpions that
they will be facing for the rest of their lives in this land infested by
theological doublespeak. Do not fear lunch! Even meerkat pups eat
scorpions. For my meerkat pups and other meerkats who may venture to
read this book, “Lunch is served!”
    Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity
       Introduction
        Mere Christianity, the classic work by C. S. Lewis,
is a popular introduction to Christian philosophy that seeks
to explain Christian morality. The purpose of this overview
will be to explore some of the strengths and weaknesses of
Mere Christianity in relation to the moral truths it presents
as foundational to Christianity.*
        One of the most intriguing values of Lewis’ book is
its ability to address, almost prophetically it would seem,
what many would call the postmodernistic climate of our
day.37 Yet Mere Christianity was first delivered as a series
of radio broadcasts during WW2. Obviously, incipient
postmodernism existed even during that war. One might




                                                                 Illustration 18. Vertical Morality
say, then, that Mere Christianity has laid the axe to the root
of the postmodern morality of our age.

       Philosophy
        Many in our postmodern generation simplify
morality with a reductionistic mentality to conclude: If it
does not hurt anyone else, then it is all right. Logically, of
course, this popular attitude is actually a philosophical
statement regarding morality that sets a yardstick by which
to measure what is right. The question, however, that
thinking people must ask themselves is rather quite simple:
Is this an acceptable standard? Even more succinctly, Is it
all right? Undoubtedly, the biblically-informed Christian
will respond repulsively with an almost impulsive
mentality that asserts that there is more to morality than
simply not hurting others. But the thinking person to whom
Mere Christianity is addressed is not expected to respond
with a religious knee-jerk reaction. Mere Christianity seeks
to explore the philosophical premise of this no-hurt
morality, and then, and only then, Mere Christianity opens
up the avenue to consider biblical amplification. Such a
quest seems reasonable. Philosophical statements should,
after all, be capable of withstanding philosophical analysis.
*
   Since various editions of Mere Christianity are enumerated differently,
citations to it herein will be by book, chapter, and page number.
Page 68                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Our inquiry, accordingly, will be to interact with the postmodern
reductionistic morality from a logically objective framework. In doing so, it
will become apparent that our society has slit its wrist with Occam’s razor in
trying to check its moral pulse in such a simplistic manner.

       Premature Verticality
       Beginning, then, with the no-hurt-no-harm yardstick, our natural
tendency is to ask ourselves, How well do we stack up when it comes to not
hurting others? Whether this tendency is expressed by a Christian or by a
postmodernist makes little difference. Either perspective makes multiple
philosophical mistakes with respect to its orientation in asking such a
question. On the one hand, if we ask this question as Christians, then we will
implicitly add God in our frame of reference and ask ourselves: How well do
we stack up to God when it comes to not hurting others? In doing so, we
assume a vertical orientation without proving that there is even an upright
dimension to morality. Quite frankly, philosophically speaking, we are
guilty of circular reasoning in that we have committed the logical fallacy of
begging the question by assuming what we are to prove as part of our
premise. Logically, we cannot assume there is a God. So our initial question
cannot be: How well do we stack up to God or to what God wants?
       Postmodernists make no theistic assumption, at least not explicitly.
Emphatically, much to the contrary, postmodernists purposefully have
leveled the moral playing field to a horizontal arena with their statement: If it
does not hurt anyone else, then it is all right. An action need not be upright
to be all right in postmodernism. No thought is given by the postmodernists
of today to the fact that their action might hurt God. There might not even be
a God up in heaven, and even if a God exists, who is to say that this divine
entity has any interest in what we puny specks are doing down here on
planet Earth? Just as someone driving down the road may run over two ants
who are fighting on the road and not even notice (much less care) that these
two ants are killing each other, it cannot be assumed that God (if one exists)
has done anything more than deistically throw a universe into motion in
which the ants, whatever their degree of evolution, are allowed to kill one
another without moral repercussion.
       So let us not get ahead of Mere Christianity or of contemporary
postmodernists in assuming that anything we do matters vertically. We will
not assume an upward dimension to morality as our premise. On the other
hand, postmodernists cannot be let off the hook either by assuming a faulty
standard as a premise. If the postmodernist is the one thinking to him or
herself, How well do I stack up when it comes to not hurting others? then he
or she certainly will supply a horizontal frame of reference: How well do I
stack up against others when it comes to not hurting others? In doing so, the
postmodernist presumes that it suffices to be better than others. But who is
to say that this is an acceptable standard? Does it suffice to be better than the
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 69

Joneses? Can the moral precept Love Thy Neighbor be reduced to Be Better
Than Thy Neighbor? How good is good enough? Does it suffice to be better
than the worst? Can one be content with being better than a Hitler or better
than a Stalin, or must one be better than the best—better than a Mother
Teresa or better than Jesus Christ? What if your neighbor is the best woman
in the community? Can you get by with being second best? Do you have to
be better than only some others or must you be better than most others?
Moreover, why do you have to be better than anyone else anyway? What
difference will it make in a hundred years?

       Horizontal Inadequacy
       The postmodernistic reductionist has a solution: Get rid of such
complex questions by taking them out of the equation. Again, the thesis
statement for postmodern morality popularly is expressed simply as: If it
does not hurt anyone else, then it is all right. There is no need to be better
than anyone else, just do not hurt anyone else. So let us lower our standard
and reduce our expectations (of ourselves and others) to a mere horizontal
dimension in which we are to do no harm to others. Is this a logically
satisfying solution?
                     Illustration 19. Horizontal Morality




        In his opening chapter of Mere Christianity, Lewis examines the
horizontal level of morality that frequently shows itself in everyday
arguments when people appeal to each other’s moral sense of right and
wrong. The human propensity to make such appeals demonstrates some
perceived common standard, whether it be called “some kind of Law or Rule
of fair play or decent behavior or morality or whatever you like to call it,
about which they really agreed” (1.1.4). In the old days, it was called the
Law of Human Nature. Lewis surmises that across cultures and across time it
has been “agreed that you ought not to put yourself first. Selfishness has
never been admired” (1.1.6). At first glance, it would appear that his
assessment falls short of reaching out futuristically to encompass the
postmodern attitude of our day which has tried to reduce morality to not
hurting others. Is it all right, in other words, to be selfish as long as you do
not hurt others? Has our contemporary society actually lowered the universal
standard, as Lewis perceives it, to a new low not yet reached in previous
civilizations so that selfishness is now morally acceptable? Perhaps. But if
so, then it is not immediately apparent that it is so. “Can one actually be
selfish and not hurt others?” is a question the new morality must address.
Page 70                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Has postmodern morality actually reached an all-time low in which Lewis’
examples fail to withstand scrutiny?
         Regarding his example of cowardice, for instance, do we really think
it is all right to be a coward today as long as one does not hurt someone else?
Looking out for number one—is this all that really counts, as long as one
does not hurt another in the process? No one enlisted in the armed forces
would be excused for desertion in the face of danger with such an excuse.
The postmodernist might complain that his do-not-hurt-others philosophy
requires that he be a pacifist and thus not give such an example from the
armed forces any further thought. But such an intellectual copout, if given,
would fail to note that in not helping others, one may be hurting others. If
one’s country is being attacked and one refuses to help when called upon,
one is in effect hurting his or her country. To move the example a little
closer to home, if a man’s home is attacked in the middle of the night and he
does not help his family but runs out the back door instead, will anyone
think that it is all right that he has simply looked out for number one?
Neither our society nor our conscience normally functions at that level of
decadency. Both our collective and individual consciences would condemn
such a coward for being selfish in only looking out for number one. But if
helping one’s family is deemed reasonable as indeed universally seems to be
the case, then it must be reasoned that we must help others (namely our
family in this case), even if it means hurting someone else (namely a
robber). Lewis’ assessment appears to be accurate. Selfishness is not morally
admirable.
         A doctor who drives by a car accident will not be acquitted if he fails
to stop and render assistance. Legally and morally, the doctor ought to stop
and help. It is not enough that he passes by without hurting the injured
driver. It will not suffice that the doctor tells the judge or his conscience,
“Well, at least I did not stop and shoot the poor chap and perform a mercy
killing.” A doctor, as someone in the position to help, is supposed to help,
not merely not hurt. Not even the postmodernist laying injured on the side of
the road would think otherwise and let the doctor passing by off the hook.
Even the postmodernist expects the doctor to help because it is the right
thing for the doctor to do. Consequently, it is not all right for the postmodern
morality to try to get by with the attitude: If it does not hurt anyone else,
then it is all right. This philosophy must be expanded to include helping
others. The do-not-hurt motto must be extended to include a do-help policy.
The do-not-hurt-others premise cannot be reduced to a look-out-for-number-
one premise. For sake of expediency, we will jump ahead of Lewis to the
golden rule: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you. It would
appear that this attitude is really the horizontal rule by which we ought to
live. And this rule is really just an expression of what Lewis would call
common decency.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                     Page 71

        The problem is that none of us really live up to this golden rule. We
all fall short of living up to this horizontal standard. We do not always do
what this internal impulse of right and wrong tells us we ought to do. Even if
postmodernists were allowed by society and by their own conscience to live
by this simplistic no-harm-no-foul motto, if postmodernists are honest with
themselves, they would have to admit that at times they have hurt someone
else, have said something hurtful behind someone else’s back, and have hurt
the feelings of others. Postmodernists stand convicted as guilty by their own
guilty conscience. They have broken their own internal moral law. Their
moral compass may not point true north, but it does point to a straighter path
than they have followed.
        Even if there is some God who does run over us like ants on the
highway with this universe He has created, we are found to be warring ants,
at times attacking one another with our backbiting. And yet even we ants
know that in doing so we are behaving in a way we ought not to behave.
Whether or not there is a God who splatters us under his cosmic tire, our
behavior is inexcusable even by our own standards. The Law of the Jungle
and the Survival of the Fittest give way to the Law of Human Nature in
which we sense that we should not hurt others at times even when we do
inflict such hurt. Therefore, not only has the Christian vertical yardstick been
found to fall short of logical consistency, even the postmodern horizontal
yardstick has been found defective in that both yardsticks only depict
positive numbers. If such measuring devices are to be a true measurement of
our behavior, however, they must unfortunately extend algebraically and
morally in the negative direction as well.
                 Illustration 20. Negative and Positive Morality




       The problem, as Lewis points out, is that we all have at least some
negative shortcomings in our lives. “None of us are really keeping the Law
of [Human] Nature….We have failed to practice ourselves the kind of
behavior we expect from other people” (1.1.7).* As proof, Lewis mentions
the fact that we are very anxious to make excuses for our behavior, thereby

*
  When Lewis refers to the singular Law of Nature, he does not mean the plural
laws of nature (1.3.16-17). Rather, he intends for Law of Nature to refer to the
Law of Human Nature (i.e., the Moral Law). For sake of abbreviation and
clarification, I will not simply rely on this singular versus plural differentiation
between the two laws but rather use the abbreviation LN for law(s) of nature in
contradistinction to LHN (Law of Human Nature).
Page 72                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
revealing that we do believe in some degree of moral decency, even trying to
shift responsibility for our actions to something or someone else. This
scapegoat mentality is as old as humanity itself and is engrained into our
nature. Our nature is to make excuses. We know that we deserve to be
whipped, but we want someone else to be our whipping boy, and so we pass
the buck. This shared common experience gives Lewis the grounds by which
to conclude with two points: “First, that human beings, all over the earth,
have this curious idea that they ought to behave in a certain way, and cannot
really get rid of it. Secondly, that they do not in fact behave in that way.
They know the Law of [Human] Nature; they break it” (1.1.8).

       Ought To
        So what? Why should we obey the Law of Human Nature (LHN)
anyway? Lewis answers this so-what question in his third chapter: “The
Reality of the Law.” This chapter could perhaps have been better named:
“Because We Ought To.” Like the marching cadence of a drum, Lewis
keeps a steady beat. We ought to obey this law because we ought to. Not a
very satisfying answer is it? Circular reasoning to be sure. Yet his chapter is
not a waste of good ink, in that Lewis is not satisfied with such an answer
either. And that is the point. The problem, as he demonstrates, is that those
who attempt to live by the do-not-hurt-others philosophy are being
shortsighted in attempting to live with such a circular philosophy. Logically,
they are running around in a circle when they conclude that the reason they
should not hurt others is because they should not hurt others. But this
circular answer is the best answer that a horizontal mentality can provide as
it runs around in a horizontal circle, which concludes that the reason we
ought to refrain from hurting one another is simply because we ought to.
Such an answer, when offered by the postmodernists, is really not an answer.
        Many would respond, without thinking too deeply according to
Lewis, that the reason we should not hurt one another is because society
would fall apart otherwise. The common good dictates what we ought to do.
But Lewis has already given us reason to believe that the Moral Law is more
than “social convention” (1.2.12). When faced with this stock mentality of
social responsibility, one is inclined to ask oneself, at least internally, “Why
should I care about the common good? What good is it to me personally?”
Lewis surmises that our answer will have to be, “Because you ought to be
unselfish.” But why should we be unselfish? Because we ought to. And there
is the quandary. This societal answer is no answer at all but “simply brings
us back to where we started” (1.3.19). We are simply running around in a
logical circle on a horizontal track, which only affirms that we ought to
because we ought to.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                     Page 73

       LN Versus LHN
        Postmodernism is only spinning its wheels when it asserts that not
hurting others is the right thing to do because it is the right thing to do.
Questions must be answered. What makes it the right thing to do? How do
we transcend this circular logic and find something to which to anchor our
do-not-hurt-others philosophy? In answering such questions, Lewis suggests
that the Law of Human Nature (LHN) is not like the laws of nature (LN).
The latter only tells us what will happen. A rock will fall if you drop it; such
is the law of gravity. The laws of nature do not tell what the rock ought to
do, only what a rock will do under certain circumstances. Like the fabled
apple hitting Sir Isaac Newton on the head, resulting in his brilliant insight
regarding the law of universal attraction, so the illustration of a falling rock
strikes Lewis with an insightful deduction into LHN.
        Lewis reasons that the Law of Human Nature (LHN) is not like the
Law of Nature (LN). LN tells us what its objects will do. A rock will fall if
you drop it. LN does not tell us what ought to take place, only what will take
place under certain circumstances. In contrast, LHN does not tell us what we
will do but only what we ought to do. A rock does not have free will; a
human being does, and therein lies the difference between the LN and LHN.
The missing ingredient (the H in other words) that makes us morally
accountable human beings is free will. The Law of Human Nature appeals
to our moral conscience to do what we ought to do. It does not determine
what we will do, only what we ought to do. We ourselves are the ones who
determine what we will do.

       Incompatibilism
        The Moral Law (another name for LHN) will often tell us to follow
our weaker impulse. But we must decide whether or not we are going to
obey this weaker ought-to desire. If Lewis were using philosophical jargon,
his argument would be a clear affirmation of incompatibilism (i.e.,
libertarian freedom).* Incompatibilism teaches that determinism is not
compatible with libertarianism (i.e., with free will). Lewis’ deduction means
more than claiming that we are not a rock controlled by external factors.
More precisely, his appeal to our freedom to choose to obey the weaker
impulse means that we are not mechanically (or chemically) controlled by
our internal desires.


*
  Incompatibilism is the denial that free will is compatible with soft determinism
(i.e., compatibilism) or with hard determinism. In short, it is the affirmation that
one is freed (by the grace of God) not to act in accordance with one’s prevailing
desires.
Page 74                                 Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       The opposing view, compatibilism,* is a form of determinism which
believes that divine determinism is compatible with libertarianism. In other
words, God’s dictating everything we will do supposedly can be made
compatible with our free will. The way compatibilists try to pull off this feat
is by saying that God controls us by controlling our internal desires. We are
free to do what we want to do. God simply controls what we do by
controlling what we want to do. Lewis asserts otherwise. We control what
we are going to do by deciding which of our desires we will obey. We can
choose to obey the weaker desire, which will quite often be the ought-to
desire of the Moral Law.
       True free will, not some compatibilistic imitation, is crucial to Lewis’
argument. His entire contention collapses without it. In the absence of
incompatibilism, there would be no difference between ought to and will.
Our reactions would be controlled chemically, just as a rock’s actions are
controlled mechanically. The difference between LHN and LN would
disappear without free will—the power of contrary choice. Without it, the
Law of Human Nature (which internally prompts us with suggestions) would
control us. LHN would be an unmerciful dictator whose every desire we
would carry out to the letter if we did not have the power of contrary choice.
Lewis’ freewill argument therefore would be an affront to both materialistic
and theistic determinism. And it is a frontal assault to the soft determinism
of compatibilism. When faced with two competing impulses—one to help
others in danger versus the contending desire to help yourself by fleeing


*
  Compatibilism is an affirmation of divine determinism that believes that hard
determinism is compatible with human freedom since compatibilism defines
freedom as the ability to act in accordance with one’s prevailing internal
desires rather than being forced to take a particular course of actions by external
control. This viewpoint, also known as soft determinism, actuality is no less
deterministic than hard determinism. In the soft view, our internal desires are
causally determined by the external factors leading up to those desires so that we
could not desire to do otherwise. Secondly, we cannot do otherwise than what
we desire to do. Stated jointly, we cannot do otherwise than what we do because
we cannot do otherwise than what our external factors have compelled us to
want to do. In other words, God made a complex array of dominos to control our
desires and thereby control our actions. By knocking over (or pulling the rug out
from under) the first domino, God has set in motion a sequence of events that
causally determines our internal desires to the point of making us irresistibly
respond in the manner in which we (desire to) do. God has remotely controlled
our actions by putting in motion a chain of events that make it impossible for us
to do otherwise than what we do. God controls our internal desires, and our
internal desires control us. In short, God controls us by controlling our
internal desires. God controls our character, and our character controls us.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                  Page 75

from danger—Lewis finds support for libertarianism in the arbitration that
occurs between these opposing motivations:

               You will find inside you, in addition to these two
       impulses [to help and flee], a third thing which tells you that
       you ought to follow the impulse to help, and suppress the
       impulse to run away. Now this thing that judges between two
       instincts, that decides which should be encouraged, cannot
       itself be either of them….If two instincts are in conflict, and
       there is nothing in a creature’s mind except those two instincts,
       obviously the stronger of the two must win. (1.2.9-10)

        So what is this third thing that decides which impulse to obey and
sometimes chooses to obey the weaker impulse. The only conclusion left is
that it is you yourself (i.e., your self). Philosophically speaking, this is an
affirmation of self-determinism. We determine our own course of action.
This is not to say that we decide what we will do in the absence of desires.
Simply, our desires do not dictate which course of action we will take.
        Lewis will return to this argument again in the second section of his
book to affirm: “God created things which had free will….Some people
think they can imagine a creature which was free but had no possibility of
going wrong; I cannot. If a thing is free to be good [then] it is also free to be
bad. And free will is what has made evil possible” (2.3.47-48). What Lewis
is offering is the classic freewill explanation as to why there is evil in the
world. God created us with free will so that we could love Him voluntarily
rather than involuntarily as robots. I concur with this classic conclusion but
question its premise.
        Let two questions be asked of Lewis’ statement. First, can God sin? If
not, then how can it be said that God has free will? If God is not free to be
bad, then how can God be free to be good according to Lewis’ explanation?
Second, will people be able to sin in heaven? If they cannot sin in heaven,
does that mean that their free will is taken away in heaven and that they love
God involuntarily when they reach heaven?
        Answers to such questions would require a digression too far afield
from Lewis’ discussion. Such considerations are not even raised in Mere
Christianity. Philosophically, Lewis’ response is satisfactory, even if
elementary, and his freewill argument can be strengthened theologically by
considering the source of the first evil desire. Lewis, however, at this point
of his argument, is not considering theological arguments, and neither will I,
particularly since theological reinforcements for libertinism and answers to
such questions are provided in my treatment of incompatibilism in The
Outer Darkness and related works.
        To confine myself currently to the scope of Lewis’ presentation, I will
simply concur that as earthly creatures we choose which inner impulses we
Page 76                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
will obey. The problem is that sometimes we choose to obey the wrong
impulses. We must decide if we are going to do what we ought to do or cave
in to our stronger impulses instead. So we cannot pass the buck and blame
the Laws of Nature for the way we behave, nor can we excuse the way we
behave as an involuntary impulse. When we wrongly hurt someone else, we
are wrong because we could have done otherwise. No one can blame a rock
for falling down a hill and hurting someone. The rock has no choice in the
matter. But one can blame a human being for pushing the rock because the
human being has a choice.* With the ability to choose comes the culpability
for the choice made as to whether or not to hurt someone else.

       Horizontal Duality
         So the postmodernist has a free will that he or she exercises in both a
positive and negative direction in regards to hurting or helping others. The
exclusively negative focus of the postmodern premise has been found
inadequate. It is not enough to say, “If it does not hurt anyone else, then it is
all right.” Sometimes it is necessary to help others. One cannot always be
morally content with merely not hurting others. Does an expansion of the
postmodern morality to include helping others suffice for a functional
philosophy of morality? If so, what will the postmodernist say to the man
who is perched on the top of a building ready to jump and end it all because
he lost his job and family? Does the postmodernist respond, “If it does not
hurt anyone else, then it is all right”? What about the youth who is
experimenting with drugs or with so-called safe sex and who justifies her
action by claiming, “I am only hurting myself; I am not hurting anybody
else”? Does the postmodernistic mother respond, “If it does not hurt anyone
else, then it is all right”? What about the student who is cheating on exams
and is told by a friend that it will only hurt him later in life? In response, the
cheater retorts to his friend, “Well, in that case I am only hurting myself, so
it is all right.” Does his postmodernistic friend then agree, “If it does not hurt
anyone else, then it is all right”? Something is not right with the
postmodernistic philosophy that would logically deduce that such behavior
is all right.
         Accordingly, a weakness quickly surfaces in the postmodernistic one-
dimensional morality: It gives no thought to hurting oneself. Yet when
contemplating suicide (or some other destructive course of behavior) that
inner impulse of the Moral Law whispers in one’s ear, “You ought not to do
that.” In addition to the do-not-hurt-others policy expressed by the algebraic


*
  Lucifer’s fall would be attributable to God if Lucifer did not have the power of
contrary choice. But libertarians are able to assert that God did not push Lucifer
(like a rock) into sin because Lucifer acted on his own accord.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                    Page 77

line above in Illustration 20, we must add another dimension which affirms:
Do not hurt yourself.
                Illustration 21. Second Dimension of Morality




Is it selfish not to want to hurt yourself? Not necessarily. Selfishness is
defined by Lewis as “putting yourself first—wanting to be the centre—
wanting to be God” (2.3.49). But that is a far cry from simply defining
selfishness as seeking self-interests. More precisely, selfishness is seeking
self-interests in such a way that would hurt others or prohibit one from
helping others. The golden rule provided for the first rule of horizontal
behavior was: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you. An
alternate expression of this internal rule of moral conduct is: Love thy
Neighbor as thyself. As anyone can see at Wikipedia, the golden rule has
been expressed in various forms in multiple religions and cultures.38 This
Moral Law is but a part of the moral fabric of humanity that has expressed
itself time and again as a part of the moral code by which we live and that
we find within ourselves.
                   Illustration 22. Bi-Dimensional Morality




       Lewis makes the interesting observation that we can love ourselves
even when we dislike ourselves, so we should be able to love others as
ourselves even when we do not like them (2.7.116). The golden rule, as it
pertains to others, implicitly contains the second dimension of morality, as it
pertains to oneself. If we really are to treat others morally as we morally
would treat ourselves, then obviously we are to treat ourselves morally.
Therefore, the Law of Human Nature has been confirmed by humanity as
comprising a dual-dimensionality.
       The mono-dimensional morality that seeks to content itself with
saying, If it does not hurt anyone else, then it is all right, falls woefully short
of logical consistency and shows a considerable lack of continuity with the
Page 78                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
moral decency perceived throughout the history of humanity. Single-
dimensional morality will not hold up in the universal court of human
consciousness as being the true representation of the moral law we typically
find within ourselves. A two-dimensional horizontal morality is, therefore, a
philosophical necessity as the expression of the Moral Law we find
revealing itself within our hearts. The syllogistic argument for the first
dimension of morality is the same as for the second.
           Illustration 23. LHN is Syllogistically Dual-Dimensional
    1. The code we live by is that impressed upon us by LHN.
    2. LHN compels us not to hurt others.
    3. Therefore, the code we live by is that we should not hurt others.

    1. The code we live by is that impressed upon us by LHN.
    2. LHN compels us not to hurt ourselves.
    3. Therefore, the code we live by is that we should not hurt ourselves.
