       Logically, the second syllogism is just as valid as the first syllogism.
Both dimensions have been accepted time and again as being the universal
expression of the moral code humanity finds within itself throughout history.
But can we be content with a morality that only consists of two parts? Not
according to Lewis. To tell someone facing such moral choices regarding
hurting themselves or hurting others that they should behave properly
because otherwise their actions will ultimately hurt themselves or others
only begs the question once again: “What makes it wrong to hurt oneself or
someone else?” This question cannot be silenced with a simple ought-to
response. This question persists and amplifies itself in multiple forms:
“What makes this internal moral law right and one’s decision to hurt oneself
or someone else wrong? What makes LHN right? Just what is it that lies
behind the Law of Human Nature that makes it right? So what is wrong with
deciding to hurt ourselves or others? What is the so-what factor?”

       Vertical Necessity
       What Lies Behind the Law? is the subject matter of chapter four in
Mere Christianity. Philosophically, it is a very important question, because if
there is nothing behind LHN, then there is no right or wrong. If it is truly
wrong to hurt others, then there must be something that makes it truly wrong
to hurt others. But what? Society? Hardly! (1.2.12-15) Such an answer only
leaves one running around in circles. Lewis reaches the obvious deduction:
“Somebody or something wants me to behave in a certain way….Something
which is directing the universe, and which appears in me as a law urging me
to do right and making me feel responsible and uncomfortable when I do
wrong” (1.4.25). Running around in horizontal circles is no longer necessary
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 79

in this discussion. Philosophically speaking, if there is a law, then there must
be a Lawgiver.
        The term Lawgiver is permissible for obvious philosophical reasons.
For every effect, there must be a cause. If the Law of Human Nature is a law
(and undeniably it is a law since it functions in that capacity by prompting us
to do right and condemning us when we do wrong), then it must have a
corresponding cause. That cause could not be immoral or amoral; otherwise,
one would still have to explain from whence came the moral nature of that
law. In other words, the first cause for the moral effect must be moral. This
internal law, therefore, tells us something about the being who produced it.
The nature of this law tells us that it was produced by someone rather than
something. Amoral impersonal materialism could not have produced a moral
code. If there is a code, there must be a coder. More formally, since the
moral code is information, and since information requires an intelligent
cause, the source of the code must be intelligent since the cause must be
capable of producing the effect. Since information is non-material, it could
not have been produced by a material cause.39 This Lawgiver must
himself/herself be immaterial.
        Moreover, immorality does not create morality. From the law of
entropy, we might consider the possibility of immorality coming from a
breakdown in morality, but immorality would not build up to morality.
Order tends to go to disorder, not disorder to order. This Lawgiver must
himself/herself be moral. Tracing the evidence we find within ourselves
back to its source leads us to “conclude that the Being behind the universe is
intensely interested in right conduct—in fair play, unselfishness, courage,
good faith, honesty and truthfulness” (1.5.29-30). This Being behind the
Moral Law must be an intelligent Moral Being.
        For the sake of simplicity, we may refer to this entity, this Lawgiver,
as God. The ultimate source that philosophically may be deduced as being
behind these two horizontal rules of conduct must be some type of God. This
God must be both immaterial and moral. So a third and final line must be
added to our dimensions of morality. Since this third dimension of morality
relates to God, it will be drawn vertically. By a process of philosophical
deduction, the conclusion has been derived that the vertical ruler was right
all along, at least in the fact that there is a vertical dimension to morality.
Mathematically, the two horizontal dimensions to morality must be
combined with the vertical dimension to yield a composite three-
dimensional morality. Logically, one cannot leave theology out of the
picture when discussing morality. Just as one cannot fully consider the law
of the land without due consideration to the lawgiver and law enforcer, one
cannot afford to ignore God when considering the ramifications of living an
immoral life.
Page 80                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                  Illustration 24. Tri-Dimensional Morality




       As one might expect, each axis of this three-dimensional morality has
a positive and negative extension. Lewis devotes the first chapter of his third
section to “The Three Parts of Morality.” In this section, he clearly addresses
the popular mentality of our day which asserts: If it does not hurt anyone
else, then it is all right. Lewis refutes this claim by deriving the second
horizontal rule by means of vertical morality:

              Let us go back to the man who says that a thing
       cannot be wrong unless it hurts some other human being.
       He quite understands that he must not damage the other ships
       in the convoy, but he honestly thinks that what he does to his
       own ship is simply his own business. But does it not make a
       great difference whether his ship is his own property or not?
       (3.3.74)

       Not damaging the other ships is not good enough. If your ship does
not belong to you, then you cannot be excused for damaging your own ship.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                   Page 81

For a more contemporary illustration, in the movie Top Gun, an air force
pilot who goes by the name of Maverick is reprimanded by his commanding
officer, Stinger, for not considering these very implications: “Maverick, you
just did an incredibly brave thing. What you should have done was land your
plane! You don’t own that plane, the tax payers do! Son, your ego is writing
checks your body can’t cash.”
                     Illustration 25. Don’t Be a Maverick




        Maverick performed a rescue but, in the process, endangered his F-14
Tomcat. Stinger admits that what Maverick did was brave. Yet Stinger
criticizes Maverick for failing to consider the fact that it was not his plane. It
belonged to the tax payers of the United States! Therefore, Maverick was not
authorized to take whatever risks he wanted with the plane. Three
dimensions had to be considered: Maverick’s responsibilities for the planes
of his fellow pilots, for the plane he was piloting, and for the fact that he
could not do whatever he wanted with his own plane since it did not really
belong to him. Ultimately, it was not his plane. He was the pilot, not the
owner. Many people are being a maverick when it comes to God in that they
fail to take into account that since they belong to God, they are accountable
to God. He is their owner by virtue of being their Creator. They are writing
checks with their body that they cannot pay back to God.
Page 82                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       I have chosen a different path than Lewis by which to derive the
second horizontal law and show that we are morally responsible for what we
do with our own bodies in that I have shown that the logical principles
which lead to an affirmation of the first moral law (not to hurt others) also
lead to an acknowledgement of the second moral law (not to hurt ourselves).
I then deduced the vertical moral law (not to hurt God) from the two
horizontal moral laws. In doing so, I used a strictly philosophical argument
by which to derive all three laws. Lewis chooses instead to derive the
vertical moral law philosophically from the first moral law. Thus, having
established a vertical law that obviously would have corresponding
theological implications, Lewis proceeds theologically to derive the second
horizontal law. Both procedures are valid. Consequently, they are
complementary.
                        Illustration 26. 3D Morality




       You are not morally free to hurt yourself if you belong to the
Lawgiver. This conclusion is valid whether it is strictly-philosophically
derived (as I have done) or philosophically-theologically derived (as Lewis
has done). But so what? You have free will. In the terms of having the power
to assert that free will, you are free to hurt yourself and others. So what
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                               Page 83

makes it wrong for you to do so? Are we right back to running in a circle,
saying that you ought not to hurt yourself simply because you ought not to?
       Our answer to this question might be derived philosophically by
asking ourselves another question: “What can we determine about this
Lawgiver from the nature of the law we find placed within ourselves?” On
the basis of the ought-to deduction, it has been deduced that just because we
ought to obey the Lawgiver’s law does not necessarily mean that we will
obey it. We are not rocks or robots. Even if this Moral Law is hardwired or
programmed into us, we obviously have a choice as to whether or not we
will obey this internal prompting, and we frequently choose not to obey it. If
this Lawgiver were a programmer intent on programming our unflinching
obedience, then he or she certainly has written a very unstable program since
it often crashes against the programmer’s wishes—unless of course this
programmer has been able to do something that we, even in our
technologically-advanced society, still have not been able to do, which is to
program into one’s creation the ability to make freewill choices. The
Programmer’s programming code must include free will. So the first thing
we note is that this Lawgiver values free will and has programmed us with
the ability to choose contrary to his or her programming. The programming
subroutine that comprises the moral code can be overridden by the
remarkable higher order of programming—free will. Just as a higher law can
trump a lower law, so the higher programming routine trumps the
subroutine. For example, the law of aerodynamics can lift an airplane off the
ground despite the pull on the plane by the universal law of gravity. One law
suspends the other law. This Programmer prizes free will above robotic
control and obviously has given free will a higher order in the protocol.
       Free will poses a moral problem, however. It proves that we are not
ants who are free to kill each other as we deem fit or necessary. Instead, we
are morally free agents, who are free to make moral decisions which run
counter to what we know we ought to do. Someone has taken the trouble to
input a moral code within us and with it a sense of moral accountability. We
cannot be content to fight among ourselves and to kill ourselves with the
thought that it does not matter. Logically, we would reason wrongly to
assume that our killing one another does not matter. Logic would dictate that
we would be wrong to think that it does not really matter what we do.
Concluding that we can kill one another without moral repercussions
because we eventually will be splattered like ants under the cosmic tires of
the universe anyway is an invalid deduction. The Lawgiver cannot drive
along oblivious to our actions.
       Woven into the fabric of the human personality (and as a result
expressed in the laws of our society) is the belief that when laws are broken,
consequences should follow. A lawgiver is bound to enforce the laws he has
given. Those under the law ought to obey it, and the one who has given the
law ought to enforce it. Both the lawbreaker and the law enforcer are bound
Page 84                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
jointly by the same law. Accordingly, we may deduce that the cosmic
Lawgiver is bound morally to carry out the punishment decreed by His law.
Understandably, Lewis concludes:

      The Moral Law does not give us any grounds for thinking that
      God is “good” in the sense of being indulgent, or soft, or
      sympathetic.…It is as hard as nails. It tells you to do the
      straight thing and it does not seem to care how painful, or
      dangerous, or difficult it is to do. If God is like the Moral Law,
      then He is not soft” (1.5.30).

      The scary thing is that although we fail to do what we ought to do, we
have no grounds for thinking that the Lawgiver will fail to do what He ought
to do—punish us for our disobedience to the law. Consequently, as Lewis
deduces, “if there does exist an absolute goodness it must hate most of what
we do” (1.5.31). And if this Lawgiver is absolutely good, then He cannot
allow our lawlessness to go unpunished—none of it. A chilling thought
indeed!

      Religion
       This observation is as far as we will go in a strictly philosophical
defense of the morality found in Mere Christianity. Since a philosophical
examination of our moral makeup leads to condemnation, Lewis turns to
religion for consolation. But to which religion should we turn? Pantheism
already has been ruled out from realistic consideration. Not simply because
our analogy pictures God behind the wheel rather than as part of the wheel
but because our analysis has found God to be a Lawgiver and therefore a
Moral Being rather than impersonal force. The elimination of pantheism
leaves us with two alternatives: dualism and monotheism.

      Nature of Evil
        In dualism, two Gods (one good and the other evil) are believed to be
dueling it out. But the problem with this position is that in calling one of
these Gods good, we have admitted that there is a standard (a real right)
which makes one good and the other evil. The Supreme Being we call good
is the one who made the law (which we regard as right since it tells us what
we ought to do), and we regard the other being as evil because this evil
Supreme Being seeks to break the law that we know ought to be obeyed.
This Evil Supreme Being rebels against the Good Supreme Being. However,
we identify this Good Deity as the Lawgiver since He is the one who has
programmed us with the sense of a real right and wrong. Consequently, the
evil being must be a derivative being who is rebelling against what he ought
to do. Like us, the evil being must have been programmed with a code that
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 85

not only tells him what he should do but also with a higher routine (which
we call free will) that allows the evil being to rebel against his moral
programming. In short, the evil being must be the program, not the
Programmer. The evil being is dependent upon the Good Being for his
freewill ability to rebel against the Good Being’s program. Logically, the
Good Being must be the Lawgiver since the evil being is the dependent
being. The evil being is not co-equally supreme. Therefore, dualism is
rendered invalid since the evil being is nothing more than a moral agent who
has rebelled against the initial programming given to him by the
Programmer—by the higher Good Being.

       Problem of Evil
        Yet how can God be a Good Being if He allows evil to exist?
Evidently, there is something to the classic answer suggested by Lewis that
God allows evil because He believes free will is worth the price of allowing
evil to exist. Even to ask such a question, as to why a good God would allow
evil, is to admit that one has an internal sense of justice that expects a good
God to do something about evil. Our very sense of justice, from which we
voice our objection to God allowing evil to go unabated, reveals the fact that
we have been programmed by the Lawgiver to sense that justice demands
that He, as the Lawgiver, must be just and punish evil. If God is to be just,
He must render justice by punishing evil. Unfortunately, this observation
means He must punish our evil; otherwise, He would be unjust. So even the
internal sense of justice to which many atheists appeal in their attempt to
deny God’s existence boomerangs upon them and comes back to hit them
with the fact that they have been programmed with a sense of justice that
demands justice from God. Our very demand for justice reveals our internal
programming. And if there is a program, there must be a Programmer—a
Programmer who has told us something about ourselves and about Himself
by the way in which He has programmed us. Evil is a derivative response
that springs from the free will passed on by the Programmer to beings He
has programmed with free will. Therefore, there are not two equally
Supreme Beings dueling it out, but only a lesser programmed being rebelling
against its Programmer. Dualism is nullified, and monotheism is left as the
only true contender. So if we are going to find a logically satisfying basis for
our morality and an escape routine from the consequences of the evil choices
we make, we must look to the monotheism rather than dualism.
Philosophical considerations lead us to look to religion for moral moorings
and then to narrow our choice of religions to the monotheism of Christianity.
Lewis’ argument is sound in these aspects.
Page 86                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

       Trilemma
       My concurrence with Lewis’ thesis concerning the multi-
dimensionality of morality should not be misconstrued as an uncritical
embracement of his morality, however. There are flaws in Lewis’ argument
yet to be considered when he seeks to cross the chasm from philosophy into
theology. My appreciation for his philosophical contribution does not mean
that I am gullible in my perception. For example, his popular trilemma
(which asserts that since Jesus claims to be God, Jesus must either be Lord,
Lunatic, or Liar) is widely ignored in NT scholastic circles.40 The logical
soundness of this trilemma in particular and of his dilemmas in general has
received criticism as setting up false lemmas with straw men as the opposing
horns.41 And such criticisms are not without a measure of justification.
Indeed, I will express some of my own critiques in a critical response to
some of Lewis’ arguments. Nevertheless, before doing so, we would be
well-advised to pause and critically examine some of Lewis’ critics.

       Conservative Debate
       As to his Lord-Lunatic-Liar trilemma, the debate as to whether or not
Jesus explicitly claims to be God is hotly debated even among conservative
scholars. Conservatives will acknowledge that Jesus is God but may differ
among themselves as to whether Jesus explicitly claims to be God. Liberal
scholarship will assert that Deity is something that Jesus’ followers ascribe
to Him, not something that Jesus claims for Himself. Does this mean that
Lewis’ trilemma is necessarily falsified or neutralized by his critics? Not by
a long shot.

       Psychological Versus Theological Requirement
       First, as to the discussion within conservative circles, the debate is not
over whether or not Jesus is Lord (God); both sides agree that Jesus is God.
Rather, what is contested is whether Jesus clearly presents Himself as God.
And even if Jesus explicitly does claim to be God, does He do so in such a
way as to make recognition of His Deity a theological necessity for
salvation. The majority opinion among contemporary conservatives would
be to affirm that Jesus explicitly claims to be God in the gospel accounts and
makes believing this proposition a condition for salvation. The minority
conservative position is that Jesus only implicitly claims to be God and at
most makes believing in His Deity (in certain cases) a psychological rather
than theological necessity for salvation.
       To illustrate, in a debate with His enemies, Jesus warns them: “I said
therefore to you, that you shall die in your sins; for unless you believe that I
am He, you shall die in your sins” (Jn 8:24). But who is the He whom Jesus
is claiming to be? That is the very question his enemies ask: “And so they
were saying to Him, ‘Who are You?’” (Jn 8:25) Jesus does not come right
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 87

out and say, “I am God.” These monotheistic Jews would have stoned Jesus
on the spot if He had done so. Nevertheless, at the conclusion of the debate,
Jesus makes it very clear that He is in fact ascribing Deity to Himself, and
His Jewish enemies do in fact try to stone Him at that point in the narrative.
Yet Jesus shows enough finesse in the way in which He provides His answer
so that it requires those listening to Him to be able to put two and two
together and deduce that He is claiming to be God. Jesus is willing to leave
the matter at least a hairsbreadth short of being an explicit claim to Deity. To
some degree at least, the claim was left implicit. Still it was a claim.
Consequently, Lewis’ trilemma remains valid. At least implicitly, Jesus
claims to be God. Therefore, Jesus must either be Lord (God), Lunatic, or
Liar.42

       Subjective Versus Objective Lordship
       The related matter in conservative factions deals with the question:
Must one subjectively recognize the objective Lordship (Deity) of Christ in
order to be saved? The answer on this occasion (in Jn 8:24) appears to be
affirmative since Jesus quite clearly asserts, “Unless you believe that I am
He, you shall die in your sins.” To be saved from their sins, this particular
group of Jews apparently would have to believe that Jesus is God. The
question then becomes whether Jesus is presenting this as a psychological
requirement for this particular group of people or as a universal theological
requirement for everyone at all times. If the latter, then for anyone to be
saved he or she must believe that Jesus is God. If the former, then only those
people who would find it psychologically necessary to believe that Jesus is
God before they would believe in Jesus for eternal life would have to believe
that Jesus is God in order to have eternal life. In other words, there are some
people who would never believe in Jesus for redemption unless they first
came to believe that Jesus is God. For His enemies seeking to stone Jesus on
this particular historical occasion, it was a psychological necessity that they
believe in Jesus’ Deity because otherwise they would not believe in His
offer of eternal life. There was no way this particular group of Jews was
going to believe in Jesus for eternal life unless they first believed that He
was God.

       Theistic Forgiveness
        These Jewish listeners already had correctly deduced the logical
necessity of Jesus’ Deity from His claims on an earlier occasion. Previously,
Jesus had healed a paralytic and told him: “Your sins are forgiven.” In doing
so, Jesus implicitly had claimed to be God. Those who would later try to
stone Jesus realized that even at this early point in His ministry, Jesus was
claiming to be God by forgiving sins: “But there were some of the scribes
sitting there and reasoning in their hearts, ‘Why does this man speak that
Page 88                                  Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
way? He is blaspheming; who can forgive sins but God alone?’” (Mk 2:5-7)
That Jesus implicitly was making a claim to Deity was deduced logically by
His enemies, and rightly so.
        For example, if your neighbor down the street sins against you (i.e.,
hurts you) by stealing $100 from you, then can another neighbor up the
street forgive him for you? No. It was your $100 that was stolen, not that of
your neighbor up the street. You will have to be the one who does the
forgiving. Ultimately, the only one who can truly and fully forgive sin is the
one against whom the sin is committed. Therefore, when we hurt God (i.e.,
sin against God), He is the only one who can forgive us. Only the Lawgiver
can forgive the lawbreaker. Fellow lawbreakers cannot forgive one another
horizontally and then equate this horizontal forgiveness with vertical
forgiveness from the Lawgiver. To be sure, sometimes the Lawgiver
conditions His non-salvific vertical forgiveness on our horizontal
forgiveness of one another, but even then His vertical forgiveness is not to
be equated with our horizontal forgiveness. In other words, when Jesus
conditions God forgiving us on our forgiving others (e.g., Mt 6:14-15), He is
not teaching us how to get to heaven. Just as there are different dimensions
to morality, so there are different dimensions to forgiveness.*
        On the occasion in which Jesus healed the paralytic in Mk 2:5, He
conditioned the paralytic’s forgiveness simply on faith, not on the paralytic
forgiving others. The condition for forgiveness varies according to the type
and dimension of forgiveness being granted. The condition in Eph 1:7 and
Col 1:14 for our redemption (i.e., for the forgiveness of our sins as far as
going to heaven is concerned) is simply faith (i.e., trust in Christ for such
forgiveness). This soteriological forgiveness is foundational for
soteriological justification. But Jesus’ enemies had already correctly
perceived that for Jesus to be able to grant such forgiveness, He must be
God. Therefore, the only way they would come to faith in Jesus for such
forgiveness was first to believe that Jesus is God. In their case, believing in
Jesus’ Deity was a logical necessity because it was the only way,
psychologically speaking, that they would come to believe in Jesus for
eternal life.
        Does this mean that everyone everywhere must first conclude that
Jesus is God before they can be saved from their sin? Not necessarily. The
minority conservative position is that if a person can come to the place
where he or she believes in Jesus for the forgiveness necessary to reach
heaven (i.e., for salvific forgiveness), then such a person is forgiven even
without having full cognizance of the logical implications that this
redemption has in regard to Jesus’ Deity. It suffices that one believes in
Jesus for redemption without realizing all the mechanics necessary that Jesus

*
    See Illustration 48. Four Planes of Forgiveness, 151.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 89

had to go through in order to provide such redemption. As Lewis
acknowledges, “Theories about Christ’s death are not Christianity: they are
explanations about how it works.” “A man can accept what Christ has done
without knowing how it works” (2.4.54-55). Consequently, it would not be
necessary for a person to understand that God incarnated Himself to provide
redemption in order for that person to partake of the redeeming benefits of
Jesus’ incarnation. Taking medicine from a pharmaceutical company in
order to be cured, for example, does not necessarily entail understanding
everything that the pharmaceutical company had to go through in order to
provide the medicine. It suffices to trust the pharmaceutical company
sufficiently so as to take the medicine even though there is a considerable
deficiency in the patient’s comprehension of the operations behind the
medicine.

       Deductive Deity
        Even if it is deduced that Jesus leaves it up to others to deduce (from
His words and actions) the fact of His Deity for themselves, this does not
nullify the fact that He does indeed intend for them to derive this conclusion.
Consequently, Lewis’ trilemma still remains valid even if Jesus relies upon
His audience to use logical observations in deriving His claim to Deity. In
fact, if one carefully notes how Lewis words his trilemma, it certainly leaves
room for this very conclusion: Jesus’ claim to be God was deduced by Lewis
from “the sort of things Jesus said” (1.3.52). Lewis does not say that Jesus
explicitly claims to be God; instead, this claim to Deity must be deduced. By
leaving the question of Jesus’ affirmation of personal Deity up to theological
deduction, Lewis presents a trilemma which is very difficult, and perhaps
even impossible, to refute.
        The liberal attempt to evade Lewis’ trilemma is thus largely beside
the point. It will not suffice to say that Jesus does not explicitly claim to be
God. What must logically be demonstrated in order to invalidate the
trilemma is that Jesus does not even implicitly claim to be God and fails to
make this a logical deduction for Himself. For the sake of argument, let us
assume for the moment from the liberal perspective that Jesus’ followers
embellished the gospel accounts to some extent. Even so, it would still have
to be admitted that Jesus’ followers believed that embellished account—
which ascribes Deity to Jesus. They believed that Jesus is Lord (God) so
much so that they were willing to die torturous deaths for their belief.
        It takes more than a little stretch of the imagination to believe that
there was nothing about Jesus to convince His followers that He was indeed
God when they were willing to lay down their lives for that very conviction.
If their conviction led them to embellish what Jesus said to such an extent so
as to fictionally create His Deity, then what was it that created their
conviction? If what He said did not create their conviction, then what did?
Page 90                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Moreover, His disciples were monotheistic Jews who were willing to die for
their conviction that Jesus is God. It would have taken irrefutable evidence
to convince them of His Deity. His followers were willing to be burned at
the stake and torn in two by lions for claiming that Jesus was Lord rather
than a Lord. If they had just been willing to ascribe Lordship to both Caesar
and Jesus and acknowledge that Caesar was Lord also, they would have
saved their lives. But they refused to do so and reserved their affirmation of
Deity for Christ alone. The issue for which they were being killed was for
confirming the exclusivity of Jesus’ Deity.
        To claim that Jesus did nothing to give His followers the clear
affirmation of His Deity is itself an absurd claim. The basic two-fold thrust
of Jesus’ gospel is: (1) Believe in Me in order to go to Heaven, and
(2) Follow Me even to the point of sacrificing your life for Me if you want
rewards in Heaven. His whole message centers around Himself. Jesus’
ethics are egocentric. In discerning the impact of His claims to Deity, one
must factor in the entire thrust of Jesus’ gospel. His gospel focuses on
Himself, not merely as a lawyer but as the very Lawgiver: with His
thundering edicts, amazing promises, and unflinching demands.* Lewis is
correct in perceiving that such statements can only be the ravings of a mad
human being, the solicitations of the derivative evil being, or the
proclamation of the Good Being. Jesus is either the Lawmaker (the
Programmer so to speak), or the lawbreaker (the derivative evil program
who rebelled out of free will), or a lawbreaker (a human being who himself
falls short of the moral standard and who has even fallen into insanity for
thinking otherwise).
        The reaction of Jesus’ enemies confirms the authenticity of the basic
message recorded by His followers. One does not kill someone for simply
telling people to be nice to one another. Jesus’ claims to Deity (however
implicit they may have been) were obviously a large part of what got Him
and His followers killed. There must have been at least an element of truth to
the claims of His followers that justified the claims of His enemies that Jesus
was making Himself out to be God (Jn 10:33). Any extreme liberal
contention otherwise is completely unwise.




*
 As typical examples of such astonishing claims by Christ, note the edict: “You
have heard…but I say to you”; and the promise: “Truly, Truly, I say to you, he
who believes in Me has eternal life”; and the demand: “If anyone wishes to come
after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow Me. For
whoever wishes to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for My
sake, he is the one who will save it.”
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 91

       Level of Specificity
       To a considerable extent, the whole argument over Lewis’ trilemma is
a debate over the level of specificity of Jesus’ claims to Deity. Logical
consistency requires that one acknowledge the accuracy of the trilemma
unless one moves all the way down the scale to the most extreme liberal
position and thereby claims that Jesus did not even make one implicit claim
to Deity. Common sense dictates that a person need only indicate one time
that he believes himself to be God for the trilemma to apply.
                     Illustration 27. Scale of Explicitness
Conservative    Conservative       Liberal          Liberal         Liberal
  Explicit       Inexplicit       Inexplicit       Inexplicit         No
  Claims          Claims           Claims           Claims          Claims
    No              No              Some             Major          Complete
Embellishment   Embellishment    Embellishment    Embellishment   Embellishment


       Those who adopt the ultraliberal claim for complete embellishment
will, of course, still have to explain why his followers created such an
embellishment that cost them their lives. And such liberal ultraists also
would have to offer a suitable hypothesis by which to account for why Jesus’
enemies were so intent on taking His life. Presuming such hypotheses could
even reasonably be formulated, these conjectures would still be insufficient.
Additionally, one would have to be able to defend the thesis that Jesus did
not even think that He was God even though His theology required that He
be God.
       The necessity of Jesus’ Deity is evident. In order to make a sacrificial
atonement, Jesus had to be sinless. Moreover, His death had to have infinite
value to atone for sin. Accordingly, the only way it could have infinite value
was for Him to be an Infinite Being—God. A lawbreaker cannot forgive the
sins of his fellow lawbreakers. Only the Lawgiver can forgive the
lawbreakers’ sins. Jesus’ theology is satisfying philosophically if and only if
He is God. The most rank liberal position requires that we not only believe
that Jesus did not claim to be God but that He was not bright enough to
figure out the theological ramifications of His own teaching. It would be
more intellectually honest for liberals adopting such a position to just admit
that they consider Jesus a liar than to persist with such a preposterous thesis.
Lord, Lunatic, or Liar—these are realistically the only valid choices we have
for how we regard Christ.

       Soteriological Versus Theological Necessity
      Lest it be thought that the present discussion comes to this summation
in defense of Christ’s Deity out of theological desperation, let it be
acknowledged that the preference herein is for the minority conservative
Page 92                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
position mentioned above. Consequently, the defense of Lewis’ trilemma
taken herein does not regard the personal affirmation of Jesus’ Deity as a
theological requirement for soteriology. In other words, in terms of what one
must do to get to heaven, the rock-bottom requirement is not that a person
answers the trilemma with logical consistency or biblical accuracy. Simply,
all that is theologically necessary for one to have eternal life is that one
believes in Jesus Christ alone for eternal life. God does not require that we
fully understand the logical implications of what it means for Jesus to be
Christ in order to believe in Him for eternal life. It suffices that we
understand that Jesus is Christ in the sense of bestower of eternal life to
those who believe in Him for eternal life. The Lawgiver simply requires that
we believe in Jesus (and therefore in the Lawgiver Himself) for forgiveness.
If we believe in Jesus for eternal life, we have in fact believed in the
Lawgiver for eternal life. The Lawgiver does not make additional
requirements, such as demanding that we be able to put our theological
ducks in a row and figure out the full implications of how He made it
possible for us to receive such life or even for us to be able to figure out that
He is the Lawgiver. My affirmation of Lewis’ trilemma is thus not based on
a disposition to regard the trilemma as a soteriological necessity.
        Additionally, although the freewill position presented by Lewis is the
one held herein, shortcomings in his discussion of free will have been
admitted. So my concurrence with Lewis’ philosophical defense in general
and with his trilemma in particular is not due to an inclination to turn a blind
eye to weaknesses in his arguments. Consequently, the support herein for
Lewis’ trilemma should not be brushed aside as that of someone who would
blindly follow Lewis in his assessments, even when they are found
attractive. Rather, my support of Lewis comes from a desire to follow the
evidence. As further proof that my agreement with Lewis on the matter of
Jesus’ Deity is not because of insensitivity to Lewis’ propensity to overstate
his arguments, actual inaccuracies in his material (and grievous ones at that)
will now be demonstrated in Lewis’ endeavor to explain other aspects of the
Christian religion.

       Mistakes
        When defending the above trilemma, my two-fold summation of
Jesus’ gospel was that Jesus demands two primary responses: (1) Believe in
Me in order to go to Heaven, and (2) Follow Me even to the point of
sacrificing your life for Me if you want rewards in Heaven. Lewis blows the
first requirement badly and dismisses the second one offhandedly. Dealing
with his error regarding the second issue will not be necessary, since Lewis
himself speaks positively of rewards in other of his writings and thus offsets
some of his own weakness regarding this matter elsewhere. My focus will be
instead on his major mistakes, which are regarding what is necessary to get
to heaven.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                Page 93

       Frontloading
        Lewis’ first error is to commit what is known in theological circles as
frontloading the gospel, which refers to adding additional requirements for
what is necessary to become saved on the front end. That is, Lewis makes
additional requirements as to what is necessary to become a Christian in the
first place. He defines repentance with moral overtones in terms of changing
one’s behavior regarding submission to the Lawgiver. Apparently, Lewis
understands repentance to be a moral submission to the Lordship of Christ
regarding one’s performance. To be sure, such repentance can only be
accomplished with God’s help. But realistically, in Lewis’ soteriology, this
only means that God will help you get to heaven by energizing your
performance. Lewis reduces Christianity to a do-based religion: “We need
God’s help in order to do something which God, in His own nature, never
does at all—to surrender, to suffer, to submit, to die” (2.4.57-58).
Repentance is something we do, as Lewis admits. We do it with God’s help.
And since we must do it in order to reach heaven, it must be something, in
Lewis’ assessment, that God requires. Repentance is made a theological
requirement to reach heaven by Lewis.
        Yet Lewis says that the Lawgiver does not demand repentance. For
Lewis, “repentance…is not something God demands of you before He will
take you back and which He could let you off if He chose: it is simply a
description of what going back to Him is like” (2.4.57). But regarding
repentance as a mere description rather than a condition is a horrendous
misrepresentation of Jesus’ instruction. Using an imperatival command,
Jesus demands repentance: “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand”
(Mt 4:17). In the Greek language in which this command is recorded, Jesus
is clearly issuing a demand. Jesus furthermore calls “sinners to repentance”
(Lk 5:32). Jesus warns repeatedly, “Unless you repent, you will all likewise
perish” (Lk 13:3,5).* The Greek language in which Jesus’ warning is
expressed is a third class conditional sentence meaning: “If you do not
repent, you will perish.” The third condition leaves the outcome in the air so
to speak: You might repent; you might not. It is up to you. You have free
will. But regardless of what you decide to do, your not perishing is
conditioned by Jesus (with this conditional sentence) upon your repenting.
Lewis is dead wrong when he pictures repentance as a mere description
rather than condition. Jesus demands repentance as a condition. Repentance
is not merely a psychological necessity; it is a theological necessity. God
imperatively demands repentance. Jesus issues a repent-or-else-I-will-take-
action-against-you type of warning (Rev 2:5,16).

*
 The word perish can be used in different senses depending on the subject
matter. See Solution, 103.
Page 94                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       As established by Lewis’ trilemma, since Jesus is God and since Jesus
demands repentance, this logically means that God demands repentance.
Lewis completely misrepresents the nature of the case when he states that
God does not demand repentance. Moreover, Lewis practically refutes
himself in his next breath: “If you ask God to take you back without it
[repentance], you are really asking Him to let you back without going back.
It cannot happen” (2.4.57). The reason it cannot happen cannot be reduced to
psychological necessity. In many contexts, repentance is a theological
necessity.
       One reason that Lewis is struggling with such internal inconsistencies
in his treatment regarding repentance is because he is trying to walk a fine
line between prescriptive and descriptive statements in a completely
unsuccessful attempt to avoid a do-based religion. For example, the biblical
statement, “he who endures to the end will be saved” (Mt 24:13; Mk 13:13),
is taken by some to be descriptive. Purportedly, it merely describes what
someone who is saved will do. Others will say that this statement is
prescriptive. In other words, God demands that you endure in order to be
saved. This latter perspective is correct. Injunctions to repent and endure
cannot be reduced from their biblically prescriptive status to be merely
regarded as descriptive. Such statements do not describe what we will do;
rather, they prescribe what we must do. Lewis’ descriptive approach to
repentance is illegitimate and easily refuted by the biblical record.
Repentance is prescriptive. God demands that we repent.*
       Far worse, Lewis is apparently laboring under the common
misperception that the biblical summons to repent means that we must make
a moral transformation in order to reach heaven. Three problems
immediately arise from his opinion. First, Lewis conditions salvation from
eternal damnation on works expressed in the form of moral action. But the
Bible is unmistakably clear that salvation from eternal damnation must be
received by faith apart from works (Rom 3:28). In simple English, this
means that salvation from eternal damnation is not theologically conditioned
on the moral transformation found within repentance.
       Second, Lewis’ call to morality as a necessary means to immortality
puts the cart before the horse. Despite Lewis’ attempt at implementing the
descriptive argument, he still ends up putting transformation before
regeneration. At the very least, he makes retention of regeneration
conditioned on post-regenerational performance. Moral transformation
ultimately becomes the means of getting eternal life and the means of
keeping it in Lewis’ performance-based soteriology. Yet the Bible tells us to

*
 Statements in the Bible which legitimately may be considered descriptive are
dealt with in The Outer Darkness. However, the passages being considered
presently do not fall in that category.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 95

regard teachers who present such distorted views of the gospel as accursed
since they are teaching an accursed gospel (Gal 1:6-9). Biblically, we must
denounce those who teach a false gospel as accursed; to do otherwise would
be unbiblical. Regrettably but firmly, therefore, when it comes to appraising
Lewis’ gospel presentation, we must conclude that Lewis is accursed, at
least misthologically speaking because of his works-based soteriology.43
       Third, the only gospel written primarily for an evangelistic purpose is
the Gospel of John. The other three gospels, the Synoptic Gospels, were
written principally for discipleship and conclude with the Great Comission,
in contrast to the Gospel of John which ends with the Great Invitation. The
Gospel of John, the one and only explicitly evangelistic gospel, purposefully
avoids any mention of the word repentance in order to demonstrate that
repentance is not a theological requirement for the reception of eternal life.
Those who teach that you must believe in Jesus for eternal life plus do
something else (like repent) in order to get to heaven simply do not believe
what Jesus says is necessary to get to heaven. Jesus clearly and repeatedly
expresses and stresses the singularity of belief as the only requirement for
eternal life in the Gospel of John: “Truly, Truly, I say to you, he who
believes in Me has eternal life” (Jn 6:47; TM). To redefine believe as a
virtuous commitment to moral performance in a vain attempt to slip
repentance into the Gospel of John is to disbelieve Jesus. One is not saved
from hell on the basis of moral performance. As is so often done today,
those who define repentance as a moral turn and who then turn around and
make it the flipside of saving faith lock themselves out (on the front side)
from the reception of the eternal life, which is promised and limited to those
who simply believe in Jesus for eternal life. In other words, one cannot get
the free gift of eternal life by following Lewis’ procedure. One is not free to
redefine Jesus’ terms as to what is necessary to receive eternal life. He is the
authority on the subject.

       Backloading
       Lose Eternal Life
       Backloading the gospel refers to adding additional requirements to
stay saved once one is already saved. Lewis advertently backloads the
gospel.44 He purposefully equates the perishable nature of natural life with
eternal life:

       Your natural life is derived from your parents; that does not
       mean it will stay there if you do nothing about it. You can lose
       it by neglect, or you can drive it away by committing suicide.
       You have to feed it and look after it: but always remember you
       are not making it, you are only keeping up a life you got from
Page 96                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       someone else. In the same way a Christian can lose the
       Christ-life which has been put into him, and he has to
       make efforts to keep it. (2.5.62-63)

Certainly, one can lose physical life. But can the same be said of a life which
is not only eternal but also currently possessed? Like so many others, Lewis
poses a false continuity between physical life and eternal life when he states
that one can lose one’s current possession of eternal life just like one can
lose physical life. Yet Lewis himself will admit the discontinuity between
physical life and eternal life when he stresses a distinction between bios as
natural life and zoe as spiritual life (4.4.177). His subsequent argument for
the discontinuity between physical and eternal life offsets his claim that one
can be lost in the same way as the other. You cannot lose physical and
eternal life in the same way because they are not the same thing. Suggesting
that a life which is temporal can be lost in the same way as a life which is
eternal is absurd. Conditioning the retention of eternal life on one’s works
(“efforts”) to keep it is just as preposterous since the Bible teaches that
soteriological salvation is not conditioned on one’s works.
        On the one hand, Lewis asks, “Once a man is united to God, how
could he not live forever?” (4.4.176) Good question. This should be a
rhetorical question, acknowledging that the possessor of such life will live
forever because, as Lewis states, zoe is “the higher and different sort of life
that exists in God” (4.1.159). Though instead of acknowledging the obvious,
Lewis immediately goes on to ask, “Once a man is separated from God,
what can he do but wither and die?” (4.4.176) Lewis probably is alluding to
Jn 15:6, where Jesus warns that a believer who does not remain in Him will
wither and be cast away (and thus separated from Him). To be sure, even the
apostle Paul acknowledges the possibility that he could be a castaway—in
terms of rewards in heaven (1Cor 9:27; KJV). But with Lewis’ insensitivity
to such misthological possibilities, it is apparent that he intends to suggest,
with this follow-up question, that believers can wither and lose the
soteriological life they currently possess. Lewis thinks that believers can die
spiritually in the sense of losing regeneration. Such a position presents
problems.
        How can a believer become separated from God in terms of losing
eternal life when, as Lewis acknowledges, the believer has the same kind of
life that God has? Since God cannot die (i.e., cannot lose eternal life), how
can a person who possesses eternal life (i.e., God’s kind of life) die
spiritually and lose eternal life? When Jesus died on the cross, did He lose
eternal life? No. As man, Jesus could perish in the sense of losing physical
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 97

life.* As God, however, Jesus could not perish in the sense ceasing to be the
Son of God or of completely losing eternal life.45 Even so, if our sins could
not cause Jesus, who bore our sins, to completely lose eternal life, then how
can our sins cause us to completely lose eternal life or cease to be a child of
God? Lewis leaves many such questions unanswered.
        Logically, losing the eternal life one already possesses would be an
impossibility for those who acknowledge that eternal life includes durability.
Lewis appears to have forgotten that Jesus’ invitation to the woman at the
well was based on a discontinuity between what is necessary to sustain
natural life and eternal life: “Jesus answered and said to her, ‘Everyone who
drinks of this water shall thirst again; but whoever drinks of the water that I
shall give him shall never thirst; but the water that I shall give him shall
become in him a well of water springing up to eternal life’” (Jn 4:13-14).
Only a conditionalist would slither up to the woman and whisper in her ear,
“You have to keep drinking this living water, or you will become spiritually
thirsty and die.” Jesus contrasts being given eternal life with perishing;
moreover, He promises that those given the former will not experience the
latter: “Whoever believes in Him will not perish but have eternal life”
(Jn 3:16). “I give eternal life to them, and they will never perish” (Jn 10:28).
The one who has partaken of living water by believing in Jesus for eternal
life will never perish in the sense of lacking spiritual life.

       Effort
       As noted above,† Lewis conditions the retention of one’s regeneration
on one’s efforts to keep it, but his assertion that you have to make efforts to
keep eternal life boils down to salvation by effort and thus by works. It is a
works-righteousness attempt to earn heaven. Granted, Lewis evokes the
popular approach of asserting that we do not work for heaven as a reward. In
other words, Lewis acknowledges that we are neither saved nor kept saved
by our works: “You are trying to obey Him….Not doing these things in
order to be saved.…Not hoping to get to Heaven as a reward for your
actions” (3.12.147). Notwithstanding, Lewis immediately turns around and
refutes himself by insisting that we are kept saved by works after all. Only,
these works supposedly do not count as works because God is the one doing
them through us, even though we have to work out our own salvation.46 He
cites Phil 2:12 in support, which says: “Work out your salvation with fear
and trembling” (3.12.149).



*
  The word perish can be used in different senses depending on the subject
matter. See Solution, 103.
†
  See quote 2.5.62-63 from Lewis under Lose Eternal Life, 95.
Page 98                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
          Illustration 28. Lewis Speaks Rightly and Wrongly of Heaven




       To be sure, we are not to understand Lewis as saying that we are
saved by our independent effort. Nevertheless, it is no less our effort—even
though performed through God’s enabling (i.e., energizing) grace—that
finally enables us to enter heaven in Lewis’ opinion. Our derivative effort is
no less our effort. Lewis tries to set the stage for reaching this supposed
solution by passing it through the horns of a dilemma, evidently so that the
reader will not notice the dilemma into which Lewis places himself with his
contradictory assessments. Realistically, however, the horns of the dilemma
that Lewis poses in reaching his supposed solution are nothing more than a
strawman illusion. He does not even consider a third alternative, namely,
that the word salvation, when used of something we work for, is being used
in reference to something other than salvation from eternal damnation. If he
had made this elementary observation, it would have enabled him to escape
from his own dilemma. In Scripture, salvation frequently is conditioned on
our works, but such salvation is never salvation from eternal damnation.

      Works Alone
       In terms of net effect, Lewis sets up a false dilemma when he
surmises the options presented by different sets of Christians: “One set were
[sic] accused of saying, ‘Good actions are all that matters.” Lewis rightly
objects that this would wrongly mean that “Heaven can be bought,” which
would “not be good actions at all, but only commercial speculations”
(3.12.148). His objection is valid, but it is leveled at a strawman. Those
holding the standard type of position Lewis is refuting with his dilemma do
not normally say that good works are all that matter. To the contrary, those
within the body of Christendom adopting a soteriological emphasis on good
works normally will acknowledge that faith also matters but will assert that
in order to reach heaven one must have faith and works or faith that works.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                  Page 99

Either articulation amounts to the same affirmation. Lewis cuts through the
chatter by picturing the relationship between faith and works as a pair of
scissors:

       Christians have often disputed as to whether what leads to the
       Christian home is good actions or Faith in Christ. I have no
       right to speak on such a difficult question, but it does seem to
       me like asking which blade in a pair of scissors is most
       necessary. (3.12.148)
                    Illustration 29. Soteriological Scissors




       Those who follow Lewis in combining faith and works (like the twin
blades in a pair of scissors as being dualistically necessary to reach heaven)
are teaching a salvation from eternal damnation that is conditioned (to some
degree and in some fashion) on works. From the soteriological perspective
shown by Lewis in Mere Christianity, entrance by the believer into his
heavenly home is obtained by the believer’s works. To the contrary, the
stark reality is that this path biblically leads to hell rather than to heaven as
one’s eternal home. Tragically, it is the path that most within Christendom
Page 100                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
choose to follow—following the crowd in trying to earn their way into
heaven through the broad gate of human performance.47 According to the
Bible, those believers who, like Lewis, appeal to their works as their basis
for entrance into heaven will be condemned to hell by that very basis
(Mt 7:22-23). Whether it is as Arminians or as Calvinists that they make
their appeal to their works for soteric entrance will not make any difference;
no one can cut the chain of eternal damnation with a pair of scissors. Such
an approach just will not cut it.
                  Illustration 30. Faith-Works Are Necessary




       From Lewis’ perspective, for a Christian to reach his or her heavenly
home, it will take both faith and works or faith that works. It makes no real
difference how it is articulated; the end result is still the same. Both faith and
works are necessary to reach heaven according to Lewis. In both
Arminianism and Calvinism, faith-works are necessary for believers finally
to reach their home in heaven. Works must be added as a secondary, yet
necessary, co-condition to reach heaven in both systems of thought. One
cannot be saved by faith alone. One cannot be saved by works alone. Saving
faith must include works in the minds of most people.

       Perseverance is not a Gift
       Calvinists pretend that perseverance in faith is a gift from God. In this
make-believe world of Calvinism, God is seen as rewarding His own work
when He rewards our perseverance in faith. Thus, salvation from damnation
is said to be based on God’s works rather than ours. In this way, Calvinists
hope to condition a believer reaching heaven on the believer’s works without
acknowledging that these works are, in fact, the believer’s works.48
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                   Page 101

Thankfully, as an Arminian, Lewis does not sink into this moronic
monergism* but affirms scriptural synergism: “God and man working
together” (3.12.149).49 Biblically, they are our works which we produce
through God’s energy. Paul clearly affirms both his effort and God’s
enablement: “For God is the one who is internally energizing you both to
desire and to be energized according to His good pleasure” (Phil 2:13; TM).
“And for this purpose I also diligently labor, agonizingly striving according
to His energizing, which energizes me with power” (Col 1:29; TM). Without
delving into the Greek, summation suffices: God provides the energy, but we
supply the sweat. We provide the labor; God provides the means and motive
for the labor. God provides the energy, but we supply the effort. God is our

*
  Monergism means to work alone and refers to the sovereign work of God in
which He is the necessary and sufficient cause in regenerating the elect without
dependency on their freewill synergistic cooperation. Although broader than
Calvinism, this view is associated typically with Calvinism. Since synergism
also affirms that regeneration is the work of God alone, the crux of the dispute
between monergism and synergism narrows down to the fact that Calvinistic
monergism places regeneration before faith so that it can attribute initial faith
exclusively to God’s work apart from freewill synergistic cooperation. In terms
of salvation apart from works, however, this Calvinistic emphasis on saving
faith being produced monergistically by God is largely beside the point. Since
Calvinism conditions final salvation on the believer’s synergistic perseverance
in faith, Calvinists are synergists in relation to final salvation. Because
Calvinism simultaneously teaches that the elect are unconditionally elected to
final salvation apart from their cooperation, Calvinists have an irreconcilable
tension created by their making perseverance conditioned on their cooperation.
As a result, some Calvinists will even try to make perseverance a monergistic
result.
Synergism is derived from the Greek verb sunergeo and means to work together
cooperatively with someone else to produce something that is a result of mutual
work. God works synergistically with the cooperative individual to bring the
individual to the point of saving faith. The saving faith produced by this joint
enterprise is the result of mutual work. Therefore, saving faith qualifies, by
definition, as a synergistic response—a response produced by mutually
cooperative work. Although saving faith is the result of work, saving faith itself,
however, is not a work. Consequently, regeneration is not a synergistic result.
Regeneration is produced exclusively by God, not jointly by God and
cooperative human being. (We do not give birth to ourselves.) The cooperative
human being is regenerated by God on the condition of faith alone—apart from
any human works. Because regeneration is not the result of mutual work, it is
not a synergistic result. Regeneration is exclusively a work of God and therefore
a monergistic result. The only thing contributed by the cooperative human being
at the point of regeneration is the passive response of faith which is not a work.
Page 102                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Helper, but we are God’s laborers.50 By conditioning our entrance into
heaven on the works which God energizes us to perform, Calvinists still are
conditioning entrance into heaven on our performance. Regarding such
performance-based effort as monergistic is nothing less than oxymoronic, a
vain Calvinistic attempt to deny the obvious mistholic* nature of a
performance-based entrance.
       Lewis, on the other hand, erroneously seems to think that he can get
away with saying that heaven is not a reward because it is based on
synergistic activity. However, this would mean that heavenly rewards are
not based on synergistic activity. Contrary to Lewis, if you want rewards in
heaven, then you better capitalize on working through the enabling power
God provides. The fact that God is working through you does not mean that
what you are working for is not a reward and that what you are doing is not a
work. Far to the contrary, freewill synergistic work expressed by means of
God’s enabling grace is the way believers earn heavenly rewards!
Everything else will go up in smoke. As a freewill synergist, Lewis should
have deduced that what Christians are working to achieve is not the reward
of heaven but rewards in heaven. Regrettably, his interaction with
misthology is anemic in Mere Christianity.51

        Gift is not Reward
        In order to escape the charge of works-righteousness, those who teach
that we get to heaven by faith and works (which is equivalent to faith that
works) will often claim that getting into heaven is both a gift and a reward.
Still, even a child should be able to distinguish a gift from a reward. The
categories are mutually exclusive:
                          Illustration 31. Gift ≠ Reward
    1. Gifts are not based on works.
    2. Rewards are based on works.
    3. Therefore, a gift is not a reward.

Whether it be monergistic Calvinists or synergistic Arminians trying to earn
the gift of heaven as a reward, the futility of either approach should be
apparent. Heaven is a gift because it is not conditioned on our works.

       False Dilemma
       Lewis practically concedes that his dilemma between faith and works
is false when, on the next page, he admits: “Even those who insist more

*
  Mistholic is an abbreviation for misthological that has been shortened
syllabically to match its counterpart soteric, which in turn is the abbreviation for
soteriological.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 103

strongly on the importance of good actions tell you [that] you need Faith;
and even those who insist most strongly on Faith tell you to do good actions.
At any rate that is as far as I can go” (4.12.149).
       What a sad state in which to be left, not being able to go any further
than that! Lewis seems to be wandering around in the forest, completely lost
as to how to proceed. How can he be expected to set up a true dilemma
between faith and works when he does not even know what the true dilemma
is? As evidenced by (1) Lewis’ inability to explain effectively the
relationship between faith and works, (2) his mistakenly thinking that our
keeping eternal life is conditioned on our efforts in feeding our faith, (3) his
conditioning God’s free gift on our moral virtues, (4) his assuming that we
lose eternal life if we break the moral law which tells us not to kill ourselves,
and (5) his conditioning the retention of one’s regeneration on one’s moral
performance, Lewis is quite clueless, as he himself seems to perceive, as to
how to reconcile faith and works.

        Solution
        Such matters would have been resolved easily if Lewis had discerned
that although repentance and faith are both necessary for one not to perish,
the word perish can be used differently in different contexts. Perish can refer
to losing physical life rather than to losing spiritual life. If Lewis had not
falsely (and inconsistently) equated physical life with eternal life, perhaps he
would have been able to recognize the difference between repenting in order
not to perish physically and believing in order not to perish spiritually.
Likewise, if he had recognized that soteriological salvation is by faith but
misthological salvation is by works, then he would have had no problem
explaining salvation by faith apart from works, on the one hand, versus
working out one’s salvation, on the other hand.
        The word salvation, like the word perish, can have different meanings
in different contexts. For example, when the disciples were in fear of
drowning to death, they came to Jesus and pleaded: “Save us, Lord; we are
perishing!” (Mt 8:25) Neither the word save nor the word perish are being
used in connection with eternal damnation in this passage. This passage, as
pictured in the chart of Rembrandt’s The Storm on the Lake of Galilee, is
referring to physical salvation. Correspondingly, it cannot automatically be
assumed that when the Bible talks about salvation by works or not perishing
as a result of repenting that the Bible necessarily is using these terms in
relation to eternal damnation. When we say that our nose is running, or the
faucet is running, or the dryer is running, or the runner is running, we
obviously expect the verb running to be understood differently in each
context. No one pictures a nose wearing a pair of sneakers, for example.
        Such elementary observations are missing from Lewis’ discussion. Of
course, he is not alone in making such unwarranted assumptions. More than
one pastor has been guilty of jumping to the conclusion that just because the
Page 104                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
word perish is used in both Lk 13:3 and Jn 3:16, the same type of perishing
must be in view, thereby falsely concluding that salvation from perishing in
hell is conditioned on more than faith alone.
                     Illustration 32. Pie Chart of NT Salvation




       To provide a brief summation of the research already conducted and
charted elsewhere,* justification salvation (i.e., salvation from the penalty
of sin and its attendant eternal damnation) is not the manner in which the
word salvation is principally used in the NT. When the disciples frantically
cry for Jesus to save them from drowning, for example, they are seeking
physical salvation. When believers cry out for deliverance from the power
of sin, they are requesting sanctification salvation. They are not trying to
keep their justification salvation. When Paul tells believers to work out their
salvation (Phil 2:12), he does not mean that they need to give the salvation
they already have a workout! Rather, the Greek word translated work out
(katergazomai) means to achieve, accomplish, produce, and bring about.
Thus, Paul is saying, “Achieve your salvation; accomplish your salvation;
produce your salvation; bring about your salvation.” This misthological
salvation is to be understood in terms of co-glorification with Christ, which

*
    See Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                    Page 105

is vastly more than just reaching a heavenly home in glory. Other popular
texts falling into this category of co-glorification salvation include those
dealing with enduring to the end (Mt 10:22; 24:13; Mk 13:13) and salvation
by faith-works (Jam 2:14).

       Faith Alone
        In his dichotomy between the works-alone and faith-alone groups,
Lewis pictures the faith-alone group on the opposite side of his horns of
dilemma in an equally unrealistic manner: “The other set were [sic] accused
of saying, ‘Faith is all that matters. Consequently, if you have faith, it
doesn’t matter what you do. Sin away, my lad, and have a good time and
Christ will see [to it] that it makes no difference in the end” (3.12.148).
Granted, there are securitists* whose theology does appear to approach such
ridiculous licentiousness. But once again, this is not the standard position of
those holding the type of position Lewis is critiquing with his horns of
dilemma. Normally, those stressing the sufficiency of saving faith will stress
that good works are necessary to avoid severe discipline in this life and the
loss of rewards in the next. Misthological defenders of unconditional
security are especially emphatic about the latter. Such securitists simply
insist that in regard to believers reaching their heavenly home, they are
saved by faith alone.

*
  Securitist refers to an advocate of unconditional security—the conviction that
once a person believes in Christ for eternal life that person is unconditionally
secure in Christ and is assured of unconditionally reaching heaven.
     Insecuritist would conversely refer to an advocate of conditional security—
the conviction that once a person believes in Christ for eternal life that person is
conditionally secure in Christ and conditionally assured of reaching heaven.
Perseverance (in faith and/or faithfulness) is the postconversional condition for
reaching heaven according to insecuritists. Calvinists sometimes like to present
themselves as advocates of eternal security, but actually Calvinism is a failed
attempt to enjoin unconditional security with conditional security. The Calvinist
might even assert that the believer is unconditionally assured of reaching
heaven, but what a Calvinist actually means with such an articulation is that the
believer is unconditionally assured of persevering and thereby reaching heaven.
Reaching heaven is conditioned on perseverance in Calvinism. Genuine
unconditional security, in contrast, would assert that the believer is assured of
unconditionally reaching heaven rather than merely affirm that the believer is
unconditionally assured of reaching heaven. The latter word order suggests that
only the assurance of reaching heaven is unconditional for the person who has
believed in Christ. This inferior word order stops short of admitting that
reaching heaven is itself unconditionally assured for the person who has
believed in Christ.
Page 106                                 Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       Only a fool without any mature appreciation of the importance of
biblical rewards would slander a misthological defense of the faith-alone
position as teaching that it doesn’t matter what you do. Far to the contrary,
eternal punishment in the outer darkness* is not a matter to be taken lightly.
No Christian spending eternity in the outer darkness will ever think that
what he or she did on earth didn’t really matter. Nevertheless, there are
those who malign the faith-alone advocates as teaching that works do not
really matter. Such badmouthing naysayers do exist, and Lewis appears to
have met some of them. Regrettably, at least in Mere Christianity, Lewis
appears to be one of them.
       Lewis responds to the faith-alone group, which he falsely has
caricatured, with further misrepresentation: “If what you call your ‘faith’ in
Christ does not involve taking the slightest notice of what He says, then it is
not Faith at all—not faith or trust in Him, but only intellectual acceptance of
some theory about Him” (3.12.148). Lewis’ statement is false on multiple
grounds. First, contrary to Lewis, saving faith is, in fact, the intellectual
acceptance (i.e., the intellectual persuasion) that one has eternal life simply
as a result of believing in Christ for eternal life.† Second, the theory to which
Lewis negatively refers is popularly known as eternal security. More
precisely, it teaches the unconditional security of the person who has

*
  Outer Darkness is a picturesque term used three times in the Bible (Mt 8:12;
22:13; 25:30). The author’s book The Outer Darkness defends the thesis that
this term, when used in the Bible, refers to the loss of rewards in heaven. For
example, Charles Stanley’s popular book Eternal Security takes much the same
position. Exploring what such a loss would entail is beyond the scope of the
present work. Such matters have been explored in the author’s major work on
that subject. Suffice it to say here that since rewards are eternal, loss of rewards
is also eternal.
†
   In response to those who object that faith cannot be intellectual persuasion
because the demons have intellectual persuasion (Jam 2:19), let it be pointed out
that demons do not have the intellectual persuasion that they have eternal life in
Christ. To the contrary, demons believe (i.e., are intellectually persuaded) that
they will receive eternal damnation from Christ. The reason demons are not
saved is not because their faith is intellectual persuasion but because not all
intellectual persuasion is saving faith. Believing (i.e., being intellectually
persuaded) that one is damned is not the same thing as believing (i.e., being
intellectually persuaded) that one is saved! For that matter, believing (i.e., being
intellectually persuaded) that one has a baloney sandwich in the refrigerator is
not the same as believing (i.e., being intellectually persuaded) that one has
eternal life in Christ. In both cases, faith is intellectual persuasion. But trusting
(i.e., being intellectually persuaded) that one has a baloney sandwich in the
refrigerator cannot be equated with trusting (i.e., being intellectually persuaded)
that one has eternal life in Christ. No baloney.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 107

believed in Christ for eternal life. Contrary to Lewis, intelligible adoption of
this doctrine frequently is based upon extremely careful notice, especially by
misthologists, of what the Lord has promised. Third, even those among the
laity who adopt this doctrine of unconditional security without detailed
examination of the issues involved are nonetheless at least giving notice to
what the Lord has said when He repeatedly has promised eternal life to those
who believe in Him. To believe otherwise is to disbelieve Jesus. In all
reality, Lewis is adopting the works-alone position which he already has
criticized. He redefines saving faith in such a way as to make it a virtue, and
therefore a work, and then conditions believers reaching their heavenly
home on this work and on other works as well.

       Faith
       Since it is vitally important that faith be understood properly in a
religion such as Christianity, which stipulates that we are saved by faith, it is
reasonable that Lewis spends two back-to-back chapters dealing with this
crucial subject. Although his blunder in trying to incorporate works under
the banner of synergistic effort as a means of escaping hell already has been
demonstrated, going back and retracing the steps by which he came to this
faulty conclusion is advisable. Lewis is not doing anything that others have
not already done. Yet demonstrating his collaboration with other likeminded
conditionalists pales in comparison with the importance of observing that
part of his argument has considerable merit. Interaction with his positive
contribution to the discussion of the nature of faith will be beneficial.

        First Sense
        Lewis states that faith for Christians is taken in two senses: “In the
first sense it means simply Belief—accepting as true the doctrines of
Christianity” (3.11.138). If we may assume logical consistency on Lewis’
part with his next chapter on faith, this simple belief in his first chapter on
the subject would be what he criticizes in his second chapter as being mere
intellectual acceptance when he claims that intellectual acceptance “is not
faith at all,” that it is not “trust in Him [Jesus], but only intellectual
acceptance of some theory about Him” (3.12.148). In Lewis’ assessment,
faith needs more than just this doctrinal belief in order to qualify for faith in
the first sense.
        According to Lewis, faith in the first sense (i.e., as intellectual
persuasion) contains an element of virtue: “Christians regard faith in this
[first] sense as a virtue. I used to ask how on earth can it be a virtue—what
is there moral or immoral about believing or not believing a set of
statements?” (3.11.138) Lewis perceives, and correctly so, that persevering
faith is a moral virtue because you have to battle to keep “holding on” to it
“in spite of your changing moods.” This kind of faith “must be fed” to
Page 108                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
“remain alive.” His thought process at that earlier time was that the human
mind was ruled completely by evidence and reason. He subsequently came
to regard faith in the second sense as “the art of holding on to things your
reason has once accepted, in spite of your changing moods….This rebellion
of your moods against your real self is going to come anyway. That is why
Faith is such a necessary virtue….one must train the habit of Faith.” In
short, you have to teach your emotions where to get off (3.11.138-141).
        This deduction may very well be the best part of his book. You
yourself have to fight the good fight of faith to have a victorious faith, a
virtuous faith. The battle for a virtuous faith is real and requires our human
effort. Such faith is a virtue because you have to hold on to your faith by
