fighting and by training your moods and by diligently feeding your faith
in order to keep it alive. These are the same characteristics that led Lewis
to admit that such activity on our part definitely involves our effort:

       Your natural life is derived from your parents; that does not
       mean it will stay there if you do nothing about it. You can lose
       it by neglect, or you can drive it away by committing suicide.
       You have to feed it and look after it: but always remember you
       are not making it, you are only keeping up a life you got from
       someone else. In the same way a Christian can lose the Christ-
       life which has been put into him, and he has to make efforts
       to keep it. (2.5.62-63)

        The reason Lewis thinks that retention of regeneration is based on
human effort is because he believes that the effort we have to exert in order
to keep our faith alive is necessary to keep our eternal life alive. In Lewis’
way of thinking, eternal life will die if we do not take effort to keep our faith
alive because our possession of such life is dynamically dependent on our
perseverance in faith, and our perseverance in faith certainly requires our
effort.*
                    Illustration 33. Lewis’ Syllogistic Effort
       1. Our retention of eternal life requires our perseverance in faith.
       2. Our perseverance in faith requires our effort.
       3. Therefore, our retention of eternal life requires our effort.
*
  Had Lewis been referring to faith when he said that we must make efforts to
keep it, then he would have been correct. Indeed, he does accurately apply this
feed-it-or-lose-it argument subsequently to faith. And certainly such faith is
conditioned on the believer’s effort. Where Lewis errs is in thinking that the
feed-it-or-lose-it approach applies to regeneration also. Contrary to Lewis, our
retention of regeneration is not conditioned on our effort for the simple reason
that our retention of regeneration is not conditioned on our perseverance in faith.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                 Page 109


        Anyone who has tried to keep a campfire going knows that it takes
effort to keep such a fire going. You constantly have to gather wood and
place it in the fire, or it eventually will die and go out. The Bible likewise
teaches that faith without works is dead (Jam 2:17,26). It takes works to
keep faith alive, no doubt about it. One would think that such an observation
is merely common sense, but it is amazing how many Christians fail to make
this deduction. To his credit, Lewis admits the obvious. He does not labor
under the mistaken impression held by Calvinists who think that such a faith
is a gift, much less an Augustinian virtue freely given by God’s grace only to
the elect. Lewis is absolutely correct and astute at this juncture in discerning
that simple faith is an intellectual persuasion and that persevering in this
persuasion is a virtue. Persevering faith is virtuous. This perceptive
affirmation by Lewis opens up the door to a clear delineation: Simple faith is
the initial, (z) punctiliar, intellectual acceptance of the truth of a statement.
Virtuous faith, on the other hand, is the subsequent, tenacious, (£ ) linear
sustaining of that initial faith.
        The minor premise of Lewis’ deduction is correct. Our perseverance
in faith requires our effort and therefore incurs moral virtue. Alas, however,
Lewis makes a fatal error in his major premise when he bases our salvation
from eternal damnation on our perseverance in faith (and thus on our virtue).
Lewis is grievously teaching that we are saved from hell by a virtuous faith
rather than by simply taking Christ at His word. Lewis regards a simple
punctiliar faith to be insufficient to reach heaven. According to Lewis, one
must maintain a virtuous faith or one will go to hell. Thus, Lewis asserts that
you cannot be saved by being persuaded intellectually that Christ has told
you the truth in promising you eternal life (i.e., by trusting Him for eternal
life). Soteriological blasphemy! Lewis has denied the true essence of saving
faith.
        Lewis should have deduced that saving faith is composed exclusively
of our initial faith (i.e., intellectual acceptance), not our subsequent
persevering faith since our salvation from hell is not based on our virtue.
Nevertheless, Lewis does make a positive contribution to the discussion
when he explicitly deduces that perseverance in faith is a moral virtue.
We would be amiss to bypass the ramifications of such an affirmation and
miss out on its benefaction without tracing out its logical implication. Since
the days of the Reformation, those adopting the faith-that-works approach to
heaven have tried to camouflage their works-righteousness approach to
perseverance in faith with the erroneous statement: We are not saved by faith
and works but by faith that works. This soteriology is baloney as may be
demonstrated syllogistically:
Page 110                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                    Illustration 34. Perseverance is a Virtue
    1. God rewards Christian virtues.
    2. Perseverance in faith is a Christian virtue.
    3. Therefore, God rewards perseverance in faith.




What is received from God in response to perseverance in faith is a reward
(not a gift). Lewis acknowledges that heaven is not a reward (3.12.147). The
gift of eternal life is not a reward since it is a gift. Therefore, in order to be
logically consistent, it must be admitted that one does not get to heaven as a
result of perseverance in faith:
           Illustration 35. Heaven is not Derived from Perseverance
    1. Heaven is not a reward.
    2. God rewards perseverance in faith.
    3. Therefore, heaven is not a result of perseverance in faith.

Lewis’ major premise (that heaven is not a reward) destroys his conclusion
(that heaven is the result of perseverance in faith).

    1. Entrance into heaven is not based on our virtue.
    2. Perseverance in faith is a virtue.
    3. Therefore, entrance into heaven is not based on perseverance in
       faith.

By acknowledging that entrance into heaven is not a reward based on our
moral virtue, the securest comes empty-handed to the cross and in simple
faith appropriates the saving benefits procured by Christ. There is a song
which expresses this truth quite well when it says, “Nothing in my hand I
bring. Simply to Thy cross I cling.”52
                Illustration 36. Saving Faith is Empty Handed




                                     ⇒
                                                                  E te
                                                                       Gi
                                                                        ft
                                                                      r na
                                                                L
                                                                 I
                                                             f
                                                              e



                                                                      l
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                    Page 111


       A conditionalist like Lewis would object: “You have to cling to that
cross. If you stop clinging, you lose the benefits of that cross.” Though in
doing so, the conditionalist has refused to come empty handed to God in
order to receive the saving benefits of the cross as a free gift. The
insecuritist* offers God a virtuous faith in exchange for what was supposed
to be a free gift. Virtuous faith is indeed virtuous when one is trying to earn
rewards in heaven, but persevering faith is impetuous when it is used to try
to earn the free gift of eternal life (which already has been paid for by
Christ). Despite their claims to the contrary, conditionalists make heaven a
reward based on works. Attempts to enter into heaven in such a manner are
doomed to failure.
       The only way to cling to Jesus’ cross with an empty hand that
appropriates the soteriological benefits of that cross is to come with a faith
that does not equate eternal acquisition with ongoing appropriation. In terms
of the Greek aspect, one might call this present tense clinging to the
eternally saving benefits of the cross an eschatological perfective present.†
We cling to the free eternal benefits of the cross with an empty hand by not
clinging to our ongoing faith as a soteriological necessity. It is impossible to
rely solely upon the virtue of the cross if we simultaneously are relying upon
the virtue of our faith. By simple faith we must soteriologically let go of
virtuous faith in order to take hold of the soteriological virtuous exclusivity
of the cross. Once we have received this eternal benefit, we cannot lose it,
and in this way we cling to it. The free gift of eternal life is not only free and
eternal; it is eternally free. It clings to us in terms of the eternal benefit it
imparts, and in this way we cannot help but cling to it. Jesus promises
eternal life, not eternal faith, to the person who clings to Him in saving faith.
We cling to the cross by clinging to that promise.

        Second Sense
        Lewis’ perceptions are better than his conclusions. He correctly
perceives that faith, in the first sense, initially is composed of simple faith
(i.e., intellectual perception) which is devoid of any moral virtue and,
subsequently, composed of persevering faith which entails moral virtue. Had
he simply recognized that simple faith results in justification salvation but
virtuous faith subsequently results in co-glorification salvation, he would
have been right on target. But as it is, Lewis fails to make this deduction and


*
  Insecuritist refers to an advocate of conditional security. Perseverance (in faith
and/or faithfulness) is the postconversional condition for reaching heaven
according to insecuritists.
†
  See Illustration 44. Eschatological Perfective Present, 141.
Page 112                                   Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
erroneously adds even more virtue to saving faith in his second chapter on
faith.
        Interaction with his second chapter on faith has been provided in the
discussion of how he mistakenly thinks that heaven is not a reward and yet
conditions soteriological salvation on synergistic performance.* To the
trained eye, the approach he is taking is readily perceived as being an
extremely common one found among advocates of works-righteousness. If
one were to consult the Arminian classic by Howard Marshall Kept by the
Power of God, for example, one would find the same rationale:
“Perseverance in this life is the way of entry into the future kingdom.”
Marshall, in turn, cites Joachim Jeremias in defense of his supposition that
this is an “ethic of grace” rather than of works because it was based on
God’s “divine power working in the lives of the disciples to enable them to
obey the will of God.”53 Supposedly, this is not “a religion of works, for the
deeds are none other than obedience to God…which are the expression of a
living faith.”54 Such statements are nothing more than attempts to justify the
faith-works method of reaching heaven. Like Marshall, what Lewis has done
(in Lewis’ second chapter on faith) is simply to add works of faith as a
secondary but necessary component (and thus a necessary expression) of
saving faith and to stress that such works must be done through God’s
enabling grace: works ⊂ faith-works.
        To reiterate, the abbreviation faith-works stresses that the works are
secondary expressions of such faith. Those holding to the faith-works theory
of reaching heaven stress that such expressions of faith are necessary to keep
faith alive; otherwise, your faith will die, and you will die in the sense of
losing the free gift of eternal life that you already possess. A believer who
lapses into dead faith (cp. Jam 2:17,26) will lose eternal life according to this
perseverance-in-faith hypothesis. Obviously, in this perspective such works
are necessary for soteriological salvation. Thus, in stressing that such works
are a necessary component of such faith, the alternative works ⊂ faith-
works expression is just as valid a representation of the works-righteousness
position as the faith-works hyphenation in stressing that works are
secondary expressions of such faith. Works are made a part of such faith,
and this type of faith is considered to be soteric rather than mistholic. In
reality, conditionalists make this equation: (works ⊂ faith-works) = (saving
faith). Works, and therefore merit, are falsely made a part of soteric faith in
unconditional security.
        The fallacies of Marshall’s reasoning are self apparent. (1) Works of
the law are works done in obedience to God; nevertheless, God stresses
repeatedly that we cannot be saved by the works of the law: Rom 3:20,28;
Gal 2:16; 3:10; 5:4. Works of the law were done in obedience to God, yet

*
    See Perseverance is not a Gift, 100.
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                Page 113

they were rejected as a means to justification. Therefore, the supposition that
salvation by works is not a religion of works because such works are done in
obedience to God is gravely mistaken. Such a teaching is a religion which
cannot work; that is, it cannot save from hell. Obedient works are still
works. In rejecting works of the law as a basis for justification, God rejects
works done in obedience to Him as a means of justification. (2) That such
works are done by God’s enabling grace working in the lives of believers,
enabling them to obey God, does not mean that such works are not works.
On the contrary, rewards are expected to be earned by God’s gracious
enablement. Thus, those who teach that we reach heaven by means of works
produced through God’s enabling grace are transforming heaven from a gift
into a reward.* (3) Even faith itself is a work when it results in a reward, so
certainly works which are expressions of such faith would still be regarded
as works.

        Summation
        Lewis acknowledges that perseverance in faith is a Christian virtue.
What he should have acknowledged, then, is that we are not saved from hell
by virtue of our virtue. Salvation from hell must be limited to our initial
intellectual persuasion (which is non-virtuous) rather than incorporate
perseverance in that persuasion. Perseverance must be excluded
soteriologically because perseverance is necessarily virtuous. He fails to
make this deduction. However, Lewis’ approach to defining faith in dual
senses can be salvaged if the senses are defined properly. Faith, in the first
sense, is simply intellectual persuasion. Such faith is saving faith in that it
saves from hell. For such faith to result in positive rewards in heaven and to
save negatively from loss of rewards therein, it must persist on, in the first
sense, and embody works of faith. Such works are volitional expressions of
faith and therefore may be regarded as aspects of faith in a secondary
derivative sense.

    (1) First sense = (a) intellectual persuasion + (b) perseverance in faith.
    (2) Second sense = works of faith done by God’s enabling grace.
           • 1a + 1b + 2 ⇒ heaven (so Lewis)
           • 1a ⇒ heaven (so present author)

        Saving grace that saves us apart from works should not be confused
with enabling grace that enables us to work. Saving faith, which is limited to
our initial (1a) intellectual persuasion (which qualifies us for entrance into
heaven), should not be confused with our subsequent (1b) persevering faith
in that initial intellectual persuasion or with (2) works of faith. Entrance into
heaven is conditioned on (1a) the initial requirement; rewards in heaven are
conditioned on (1b and 2) the subsequent misthological requirements. Those
who confuse these concepts are taking what the Bible calls the broad gate to
destruction (Mt 7:13). The narrow gate must be narrowed down to (1a) our
initial intellectual persuasion. Those who try to broaden salvific faith to
include (1b) perseverance in faith and/or (2) perseverance in faithfulness
(faith-works) have taken a path that leads to destruction.
        Contrary to the expectations of Marshall and Lewis, God is not in the
business of helping us work our way to heaven. Those who experience a
measure of moral victory through God’s enabling grace cannot presume that
they are saved because of this alleged evidence of regeneration. To the
contrary, in the parable of the Pharisee and the Publican, Jesus makes it
clear that the Pharisee had achieved a much higher degree of moral virtue
than the sinful publican; yet, it is the publican (who was devoid of virtue)
who is justified by faith alone (Lk 18:9-14). Those who base their assurance
of salvation on their moral virtue are making a deadly mistake in assuming
that God is helping them work their way to heaven. God may be helping
them, but it is not for the purpose of helping them earn heaven. And those
who mistake enabling grace for saving grace will fail to experience saving
grace. Those who try to get to heaven by virtue of their virtue are not going
to make it. Just because one is experiencing a degree of moral victory as a
result of God’s enabling grace does not prove that one has experienced
God’s saving grace.
        According to the Bible, it is only in God that we, whether we are lost
or saved, “live and move and exist” (Acts 17:28). Surely, both believers and
unbelievers jointly owe their existence and corresponding abilities to the
grace of God. Such grace is common to all humanity and not reserved just
for believers. “Every good thing bestowed [on all humanity] and every
perfect gift [offered to all humanity] is from above, coming down from the
Father of lights, with whom there is no variation, or shifting shadow”
(Jam 1:17). God is the ultimate Author of everything that is good in our
human lives. Just as God, in common (i.e., universal) grace,* “causes His

grace is insufficient so as to enable the lost sinner to respond savingly toward
God, much less to seek God or have stirring of good will toward God.

unrighteous” (Mt 5:45), so He also graciously enables those who are evil “to
give good gifts” to their children (Mt 7:11).

        The morally good works that a lost person performs or the good gifts
that a lost father gives find their ultimate source in God who is the Author of
every good thing that any of us do. Through God’s enabling grace, He
enables and inspires both the lost and saved to produce good works.* Many

can earn heaven; therefore, such works are an insult when used in that capacity.
Still, relative to other fields of reference, works that a lost person does may be
considered good. See Theory of Misthological Relativity in The Outer Darkness.

will assume that they are saved because they produce good works through
God’s grace and exercise good will toward God at the prevenient level,* only
to find out that they never have experienced God’s saving grace. They will
have trusted in their works as proof that they were saved (Mt 7:22-23), only
to be condemned on that very basis—as having “trusted in themselves that
they were righteous” (Lk 18:9). Mistaking God’s enabling grace for saving
grace can be deadly.

       Conclusion
      Mere Christianity is a classic Arminian, philosophical introduction
with the typical soteriological strengths and weakness one would expect
from that theological tradition. On the positive side, its first section gives a
splendid philosophical treatment of the same premise Paul uses in Romans:
       14
         For when Gentiles who do not have the Law do instinctively
       the things of the Law, these, not having the Law, are a law to
       themselves, 15in that they show the work of the Law written in
       their hearts, their conscience bearing witness, and their
       thoughts alternately accusing or else defending them, 16on the

*
  Prevenient Grace (proper) is the orthodox view of divine-human synergism in
which God initiates a pre-regenerative enablement that makes it possible for a
lost person to respond cooperatively in saving faith to the gospel and thereby
experience regeneration (in the form of impartation of eternal life to one’s
spirit). This form of grace, therefore, logically precedes the regeneration of
one’s spirit in sequence, efficiently restores the lost person’s ability to respond
positively to God by breaking the initial and normative bondage of the enslaved
human will to sin so that one no longer has to respond negatively to God,
supernaturally prevents one’s fallen will from making a positive free response to
God impossible, sufficiently arouses the lost soul at the hearing of the gospel so
that one can either resist the gospel call and stay asleep in unbelief or allow
oneself to become fully awakened by the call to believe, partially opens one’s
eyes to the truth of the gospel so that one may either close one’s eyes in disbelief
or allow one’s eyes to be opened in saving faith, directly restores free agency so
that the constitutional free agent who is practically bound by sin pragmatically
now becomes the freed agent who may respond freely, instrumentally exerts
resistible persuasional force upon the intellect through the explicit gospel that
will be successful unless resisted, and internally creates a desire and ability in
one’s soul to respond positively to the gospel. For related definition of
Common-Prevenient Grace, see Technical Terms, xvi.) The present book
expressly rejects the heresies of Pelagianism (which teaches that man could
initiate and consummate salvation apart from God’s grace) and Semi-
Pelagianism (which teaches that man could initiate salvation apart from God’s
grace).

       day when, according to my gospel, God will judge the secrets
       of men through Christ Jesus. (Rom 2:14-16)

        Evidence of a law written in our hearts gives us grounds to conclude
that there must be a Lawgiver. If there is a writing, for example, naturally
there must be a writer. It also follows that this Lawgiver must be concerned
about our conduct and must judge and punish us accordingly. In Christianity,
the Lawgiver provides the solution by suffering the punishment Himself.
This is as it must be. Either we (the finite creature) must suffer infinitely, or
He (the infinite Creator) must suffer finitely. Mere Christianity also has a
commendable philosophical defense of free will and even attempts to defend
free will from the Eternal-Now perspective of time, which illustrates the
potential need to harmonize free will with one’s view of time.* Thus, the
spirit of Lewis’ attempt to get Christians thinking about such matters is to be
valued: “God is no fonder of intellectual slackers than of any other slackers.”
God wants you “brains and all” (3.2.78). Mature Christianity was never
intended for the intellectually lazy (Rom 12:1-2; 1Cor 14:20; 2Cor 10:5).
        On the negative side, Lewis’ treatment of rewards is weak in Mere
Christianity. On the positive side, as might be expected from an Arminian,
synergism is implicitly and rightly affirmed in Mere Christianity.
Nevertheless, the book suffers from its inability to link such cooperative
activity with rewards because it attempts to use this synergism as its basis
for entrance into heaven. This confusion stems from the typical Arminian
weaknesses inherit in advocating conditional security and therefore ends up
conditioning entrance into heaven on one’s synergistic performance. Lewis
flounders repeatedly and badly in trying to find a way to reconcile several
strains of conditional security: initial faith versus ongoing faith, dead faith
versus live faith, intellectual faith versus volitional faith, multifaceted
salvation versus monotonic salvation, morality versus immortality, and
eternal life versus physical life.
        When Lewis makes an invalid use of the distinction between
prescriptive and descriptive statements in claiming that God does not
demand repentance, Lewis is implementing a tactic that is popular in both
Calvinistic and Arminian circles. Understandably, he wants to deny that
preconversion repentance is a soteric necessity because making salvation
contingent on a change in one’s preconversion performance obviously
makes salvation conditioned on works. Yet since Lewis makes salvation
conditioned on works anyway, why struggle with this particular one?
Possibly, he does not want to make salvation conditioned on preconversional
works but only upon postconversional works. Regardless, neither avenue

*
  Not all libertarians find it necessary to adopt the Eternal-Now perspective of
time.
Page 118                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
will work because the Bible condemns works of any type as a theological
condition or co-condition for entrance into heaven.
        Perhaps it would have helped Lewis if he had gone back and reread
his introduction and followed it through to its logical conclusion: “When a
man who accepts the Christian doctrine lives unworthy of it, it is much
clearer to say he is a bad Christian than to say he is not a Christian” (xv).
The Bible would call such a person a carnal Christian (1Cor 3:1-4; KJV).
Why does Lewis rightly call the carnal Christian a bad Christian in his
introduction and then switch to regarding him as a spiritually dead Christian
who is no longer a Christian in the body of his book? Possibly, Lewis
acknowledges the existence of bad Christians (who, correspondingly, still
possess eternal life) because the Bible acknowledges the existence of such a
class of Christians as well. Carnal Christians exist.
        Since a bad Christian is still a Christian, how can Lewis indicate
elsewhere that a bad Christian is not a Christian? How bad does a person
have to be before he or she ceases to be a Christian? Can a believer be just
pretty bad but not very bad and still be a Christian? Lewis seems to have
some type of sliding scale when he says that many people are “slowly
ceasing to be Christians” (4.10.208). If that were not bad enough, he also
indicates that through other religions one can slowly become a Christian and
“thus belong to Christ without knowing it” (4.10.209). Soteriological
hogwash! Does Lewis hold to a progressive regeneration that simultaneously
is regressive? Unfortunately so. Does your freewill, moral response
determine how regenerate you are in Lewis’ theology? Regrettably so. As
Townsend concludes concerning Lewis’ theology: “Ironically, while he
believed some Christians could lose their salvation, he believed some non-
Christians could receive their final salvation.”55
        When the Sunday School class which the author was attending in the
study of Lewis’ book reached this particular passage, the present writer
objected that it appeared as if Lewis were saying that one can be 97%
regenerate today and 98% regenerate tomorrow and fall back to 97% the day
after. Presumably, a believer could relapse all the way to 0% and lose eternal
life completely in Lewis’ theology. To his credit, the teacher of the class
likewise felt uneasy with Lewis’ assessment, noting that it was tantamount
to the mentality that says one is just a little bit pregnant. Lewis’ mindset is
in error because one is either pregnant or one is not. Being pregnant is not a
matter of degrees. Similarly, one is either regenerate or one is not. One has
either been born of God or one has not been born of God. Lewis confuses
regeneration with sanctification when he fuses the two concepts together.
        Amidst other inconsistencies, while trying to explain the balance
between trying and trusting, Lewis says that you are “not doing these things
in order to be saved, but because He has begun to save you already”
(3.12.147). But how can this be a “less worried way,” as Lewis claims, when
his theology leads you to conclude that you are doing these things in order
Chapter 1. Mere and Moral Christianity                                  Page 119

to stay saved? Salvation and loss of salvation from hell are processes for
Lewis—processes that evidently do not need the message of Christianity. In
trying to reduce Christianity to its essence, he has disemboweled it of what
is essential.
        I will conclude by setting the record straight: A Christian, at the most
fundamental level, is someone who has believed in Christ for eternal life
(1Tim 1:16). One cannot believe in Christ for a moral transformation and
expect to get regeneration instead. One cannot believe in Christ for interval
life and expect to get eternal life as a result. Nor can one believe in Christ for
probation and hope to get salvation instead. Similarly, one cannot believe in
Christ for conditional security and receive unconditional security as the
consequence. Nor can one believe in salvation by works and expect to get
salvation apart from works as the outcome. Not even a great writer of
Christian literature such as C. S. Lewis can believe in Christ for
probationary life and biblically expect to get eternal life. Hopefully, there
was a point in his life, however brief it may have been, when the fog lifted
long enough for Lewis to believe in Christ alone for eternal life. But as it is,
Mere Christianity is engulfed in a fogbank of fuzzy thinking when it comes
to soteriology. Contrary to Mere Christianity, morality is not the means by
which Christians receive immortality or retain immortality.
        A Christian is merely someone who has believed in Christ for eternal
life as a free gift, not in something or someone else in addition to or in place
of Christ for anything less than a life that is eternal and therefore
unconditional. Such a person may be a bad Christian or a good Christian.
Possessing eternal life does not take away a Christian’s free will or
guarantee that he or she will be good here on earth. But it does mean that
once Christians reach heaven, they will want to have developed their
Christian character as much as possible while here on earth in order to
maximize the degree to which they experience that life in the hereafter. On
at least this matter, Lewis was right: character matters.

   These scissors will not work!
     Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith
       Introduction
       Atheists, of course, deny that faith is a virtue, but those Christians, on
the other hand, who (like C. S. Lewis) affirm that faith is a virtue, tend not to
know what to make of a virtuous faith. The theological virtues (faith, hope,
and love) are derived from the Pauline list: “But now abide faith, hope, love,
these three; but the greatest of these is love” (1Cor 13:13). Although love is
a greater Christian virtue than faith, an abiding Christian faith is still a great
virtue. Love is just a greater virtue. The virtuous nature of faith is affirmed
within Catholicism but frequently denied within Protestantism. A
straightforward reading of the text is sufficient to suggest that Protestants
have indeed erred when they deny that such faith is a virtue. The fact that
love > faith does not mean that faith = 0. When it comes to virtues, it would
be wrong to think that Christian faith counts for nothing.

       Catholic Merit
        Catholicism and Lewis are correct in their perception that there is a
virtuous element to Christian faith. Indeed, my book The Outer Darkness
and related works defend the reality of misthological faith (and thus of
virtuous faith). Nevertheless, many of the reasons supplied by those
attempting to defend the virtuous nature of such faith are unacceptable. For
example, Chilson, a Catholic, wrongly redefines faith as commitment while
rightly regarding faith as a virtue.56 But as has been expressed already
herein, faith is better defined as intellectual persuasion (not as a volitional
decision). Such volitional errors are by no means limited to Catholics. Also,
just as not all such errors are limited to Catholicism, so not everything found
in Catholicism must be brushed aside as error.
        Kwasniewski’s Catholic differentiation between objective and
subjective faith is all fine and good, for example. Moreover, his articulation
could be made equivalent to that of Lewis’ distinction with the clarification
provided by these parenthetical inserts: “Right away we should note that
‘faith’ has at least two different senses: [1] the [intellectual assent to the]
content of the creed or teachings we embrace as believers, and [2] the good
habit or virtue whereby we adhere to the truth of this content” (italics his,
bold mine). Such a statement is very much in accord with Lewis and is
accurate insofar as it goes. Yet when Kwasniewski gets around to discussing
the theological virtues, he needlessly wants to make virtuous faith a gift,
regardless of how much work such faith takes on our part: “However much
work we put into strengthening and purifying it, faith must be, first and last,
a gift from the merciful Lord.”57 On this particular matter, Lewis is superior;
nevertheless, Kwasniewski is expressing a sentiment popular in both
Page 122                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Arminian and Calvinistic circles. We cannot reject his statement just because
he is a Catholic. Integrity requires that if we dismiss his argument as being
unbiblical, we reject similar arguments used in the Protestant camp as well.

         Jonathan Edwards
       Kwasniewski’s understanding of faith in the second sense is the same
as the second part of Lewis’ understanding of faith in the first sense.* Both
Arminians and Catholics join hands in seeing faith in this sense (i.e.,
perseverance in faith) as a virtue because it is habitual. Turning now to
Jonathan Edwards, we find that he, perhaps to the chagrin of some within his
Reformed camp, also affirms the virtuous nature of habitual faith.58 For sake
of collaboration, Hunsinger’s analysis of Edwards’ position may be
consulted.59 Hunsinger traces the (largely unsuccessful) attempt of Jonathan
Edwards to explain the virtuous nature of persevering faith. Edwards
endeavors to make saving faith a virtuous faith that results in a somewhat
unmerited reward. The way Edwards tries to pull off this oxymoron is to
disassociate himself with congruent merit.

         Types of Merit
        To understand this reference to congruent merit, it will have to be
distinguished from other types of merit. (1) Strict merit refers to an equitable
exchange between works and their attendant reward. Basically, the reward is
the agreed-upon, fair-payment value for the service performed. If we do
good, we obligate God to reward us accordingly. If we do bad, we obligate
God to punish us accordingly. There is no appeal to grace in this view. We
may term this view as the exclusive-merit approach since it excludes grace.
For example, Christ merited our salvation by means of strict merit. God
did not fudge in allowing or accepting Christ’s sacrifice on our behalf.
The benefit of eternal life was strictly merited by Christ and is graciously
offered to us as a free gift independent of our merit. But the benefit that
Christ won for us as an expression of God’s grace toward us was not based
upon grace extended to Christ in allowing Him to earn something He did not
strictly deserve, if He was willing to pay the price necessary for our
forgiveness. We might symbolize the relationship between merit and reward
in this strict correspondence simply as merit-reward.
        (2) Condign merit refers to a graciously-promised reward. Some
would describe this as a full-merit approach. In this form of merit, God
graciously obligates Himself to reward us by virtue of His promise to do
so, so that it would be unjust for God not to reward us. We could do nothing
to obligate God to offer us a chance to earn positive rewards. Nevertheless,

*
    See Summation, 113. Kwasniewski’s 2 = Lewis 1b.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                      Page 123
the Lord has graciously chosen to make it possible for us to earn positive
rewards. Now that He has done so, He is obligated to reward us if we do our
part (through God’s enabling grace, of course) to earn the promised rewards.
The scope of the reward is equivalent to the merit of the effort, so that the
reward is fully deserved. We might picture this as offering someone a
chance to earn his dinner if he will cut our grass. This condign relationship
between merit and reward might be pictured as grace-grace      merit -reward to

accentuate the fact that the initiative to offer the opportunity to earn the
reward is exclusively based on God’s initial grace* and the merit itself can
only be achieved through God’s enabling grace.† Therefore, although the
reward is full of merit, the reward was made possible through grace.
        (3) Congruent merit might be described as a half-merit or partial-
merit. In this form of merit, our merit is combined with God’s generosity so
that God rewards us with more than we actually deserve. We might say
that the reward is disproportional to what we have actually done but
proportional to how much we have done. To illustrate the difference, picture
this type of merit as a father making a pact with his son in which the father
offers his son a chance to earn a million dollars if his son will cut the grass
in the front yard and a chance to earn two million dollars if he also will cut
the grass in the back yard. Such a reward obviously would be proportional
rather than equatable.60 The lavish nature of this gracious reward
simplistically might picture the congruent relationship between merit and
                   grace to stress the fact that the benefit bestowed in this
reward as merit-reward
reward of grace far exceeds our merit.‡
        According to some advocates of congruent merit, it would not be
unjust for God to refuse to reward us if He subsequently changed His mind
and chose not to do so because of the benevolent nature of such a reward in
the first place. Moreover, according to some advocates of this position, God
proportionately matches our virtue with a reward that is purportedly
independent of our virtue, because God does not give us the reward based on
our virtue. Such paradoxical attempts, however, to explain congruent merit
should be met with a considerable degree of skepticism. Arguments in favor
of congruent merit should not be incongruent to the nature of merit itself.

Page 124                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       Habitual Faith
       As to the distinctions between forms of merit, it is not clear how
Edwards is to be regarded as successfully disassociating himself with the
congruent merit found in Catholicism. Hunsinger identifies the problem by
noting that Edwards makes eternal life a reward given in response to the
human virtue of habitual faith: Edwards believes that “faith is that human
excellence or virtue which, in some sense, makes it fitting for God to
reward it with eternal life,” and this faith is “defined as a disposition, as a
‘habit’” (italics his).61 So the eternal life that grants us entrance into heaven
is a reward according to Edwards. But in what sense is the free gift of eternal
life a reward? In a fitting sense, whatever sense that is according to
Edwards.* Whatever else it may be, Edwards regards this faith as a virtue
because it is a habit. Lewis also regards this “habit of Faith” as a virtue
because of the work necessary on our part to maintain habitual faith
(3.11.141).† As partially quoted above, Kwasniewski (a Catholic) concurs:

              God alone gives the habit of supernatural faith….God
       alone, it should be stressed, is the author of these supernatural
       virtues. Neither by our own sincere efforts nor by receiving the
       instruction of others can man earn or obtain the theological
       virtues….However much work we put into strengthening
       and purifying it, faith must be, first and last, a gift from the
       merciful Lord.…If he asks you to do something beyond your
       strength, he must also give you the power to do it. How much
       more so with God, whose visitation we cannot command,
       whose grace we cannot merit!62 (Italics his; bold mine.)

       Supposedly, this habitual faith does not entail merit even though it
takes considerable effort because, as Kwasniewski states in a footnote,
God’s grace supplies the power to perform such faith—to persevere. In other
words, according to Kwasniewski, such work does not entail merit because it
finds its source in God’s enabling grace. So here we have Edwards (a
Calvinist), Lewis (an Arminian), and Kwasniewski (a Catholic) all in
agreement that we work our way to heaven by means of a habitual,
nonmeritorious, virtuous faith! If it were not such a tragedy, one might think
that this congruity were a comedy. But as it is, these representative writers
express a deadly soteriology that can readily be found in their respective


*
  Fitting sense evidently means natural rather than moral consequence, but there
may be a question as to Edwards’ consistency. See Problem of Congruency,
127.
†
  See First Sense, 107. Habitual faith = perseverance in faith.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                    Page 125
camps. Logically, they each make heaven a reward based on their work, and
thus on their merit, despite their attempts to claim otherwise.

       Hunsinger’s Criticism
       Edwards labors with all his considerable intellectual might to
disassociate himself with the salvation-by-faith-and-works found in
Catholicism and Arminianism by asserting that his view of faith has nothing
to do with “any moral congruity at all” because in his view faith derives its
inherent derivative merit only by virtue of being rooted in Christ. Even so,
his argument falls flat on its face, because any sophisticated Catholic would
affirm the same thing about congruent faith. Hunsinger acknowledges as
much:

              If the idea of congruent merit could be restricted only to
       the case of independent moral effort, Edwards would be
       correct. His idea that it is fitting, relatively and indirectly, that
       God should reward the virtue of faith with eternal life
       would indeed have nothing to do with the idea of congruous
       merit, for faith is not a matter of independent moral effort. But
       the Reformation had insisted that our justification depended
       entirely on Christ, and not in any sense on some virtue in
       ourselves—not before faith, but also not after faith; not
       absolutely, but also not relatively or indirectly. Justification
       did not rest on any such virtue qua virtue in us, even if that
       virtue were faith. Faith was simply not a virtue in that sense.
            Edwards knew about the Council of Trent, against whose
       view of justification he polemicized, but he apparently did not
       know about any more sophisticated forms of Thomism. He did
       not know of the proposal that virtues can be grounded entirely
       in grace and still be so pleasing to God that by sheer
       benevolence they merit the reward of eternal life, and that this
       reward need not necessarily be obligatory but only fitting or
       congruous. He did not know, apparently, that by defining faith
       as a meritorious virtue, regardless of how secondary and
       derivative, he had moved closer to Thomas than to the
       Reformation.63

        In Hunsinger’s correct assessment, by admitting that faith has virtue,
Edwards had attributed merit to faith and thus made the gift of eternal life a
merited reward. The Reformation had sought to head off such a theology at
the pass by denying that faith has any virtue. Still, in defense of Edwards,
Lewis, and Kwasniewski, it is certainly more straightforward to think that a
faith requiring that much effort to maintain surely would tend to be regarded
as a work. Logically, if faith is a work, it entails merit. Synonymously, if
Page 126                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
faith has merit, then it is a virtue. The virtue of the Lewis-Edward-
Kwasniewski argument that perseverance in faith is a virtue would appear to
be rather self-apparent.

       Digging Oneself into a Hole
         Edwards’ attempt to disassociate himself with his Arminian and
Catholic compatriots accomplishes nothing when Edwards seeks to
distinguish himself by stipulating that our works are meritorious only
because they are grounded in Christ.64 Any post-Thomanistic conditionalist
worth his Catholic salt would assert the same thing. Edwards unwittingly has
conceded the argument to those against whom he is arguing. After originally
denying that our faith results in such a reward, Edwards digs himself even
deeper into a hole when he goes on to admit that he believes that heaven
itself is a reward given in response to our derivative righteousness.

       Our Union is Not a Reward
        To retrace some of the statements that Edwards makes before he
descends into the abyss of works-righteousness, note that early in his
argument he asserts: “God does not give those that believe a union with or
an interest in the Savior as a reward for faith” (bold mine).65 Good. Our
salvific union with Christ, which gets us into heaven, is not a reward. Lewis
likewise acknowledges that we have no hope of “getting to Heaven as a
reward” (3.12.147). Such a statement is logically consistent and biblically
accurate. Both Edwards and Lewis correctly reject the notion that the union
with Christ as our Savior (which results in our going to heaven) is a reward
for our faith. Our soteriological union with Christ is not a reward. Both
writers should have concluded, then, that entrance into heaven is not based
on perseverance in faith. Alas, these writers (one an Arminian and one a
Calvinist) coalesce to teach that we are saved from hell by our virtuous
perseverance in faith! Logical consistency tragically is thrown out the
window. Documentation of this development in Edwards’ argument will be
more fully provided in the ensuing discussion. For now, it suffices to trace
his line of reasoning, basically in the order in which he presents it.
        Edwards accurately argues that this act of saving faith* is real since it
legally results in the bestowment of Christ’s merit to our account. The
*
 Even advocates of the intellectual view of faith (such as the present writer) will
sometimes use the term act of faith without indicating any concurrence with the
volitional view of faith. More germane to this present discussion, however,
securitists will insist (contrary to Lewis and Edwards) that saving faith is not
habitual. Therefore, for the intellectual securitist, the act of faith by which we
are saved is the initial punctiliar passive persuasion that we have eternal life in
Christ because we have believed in Christ for eternal life.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                   Page 127
justification that Christ gives to us in response to our faith is His reward and
our gift. Seen from this angle, one might overlook Edwards’ seemingly
inconsistent opening statement when he states the subject of his inquiry: “It
is evident that gospel grace consists in the reward being given without
works” (emphasis his).66 To the contrary, rewards are always based on
works. But if the gift of justification is regarded from the perspective of
what it cost Christ, then it is true that His reward is our gift. What was a
reward for Christ is offered as a gift to us. Christ earned eternal life for us so
that He could give it to us freely. Christ gave His life so that we could have
eternal life. In this sense, it may be said that what was rewarded to Christ on
the basis of His works is offered to us without works. In any case, the
statement herein is still true that what is given as a reward is always based
upon the works of the one who is receiving it as a reward. That which is
received as a gift, on the other hand, is not based upon the works of the one
who is receiving it as a gift.
        As will be seen, Edwards will indeed argue that Jesus’ merit (i.e.,
active obedience) is given to us as a gift. Splendid! If Edwards had just
stopped there, then all would be fine. But as will also be documented, when
Edwards gets to evangelical obedience, he commences his subtle departure
from the Jesus-paid-it-all approach and makes getting into heaven a co-pay
in which Jesus only made the down payment. A critical assessment of
Edwards’ overall approach will show that he really believes that heaven is
only offered on the installment plan in which our co-pay is composed of
derivative merit.

       Problem of Congruency
       Delaying our interaction with his discussion of evangelical obedience
for the moment, note that Edwards expresses the problem well enough:

             How this is said to be by faith alone, without any manner
       of virtue or goodness of our own. This may seem to some to be
       attended with two difficulties, viz. how this can be said to be
       by faith alone, without any virtue or goodness of ours, when
       faith itself is a virtue, and one part of our goodness….And if it
       be a part of our inherent goodness…that renders it
       a…congruous thing that we should have this benefit of Christ
       assigned to us, what is this less than what they mean who talk
       of a merit of congruity? (Italics his.)67

       Is this not an interesting dilemma? How can we be saved by faith
alone apart from merit, if faith itself is a virtue with inherent merit? Thus,
early in his discussion, Edwards turns our attention to the attendant problem
of congruent merit. His answer will be that faith does indeed entail merit, but
it is not independent merit. Rather, it is a relational merit that derives its
Page 128                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
worthiness from its union with the person of Christ. Whatever else may be
said about this relational association, it is at least a real, legal union in which
Christ’s merits now belong to the believer and are credited to the believer’s
account. To assist Edwards’ with his marriage analogy in terms of today’s
terminology, one might offer the example of a poor woman who marries a
rich man and now has a joint checking account. By joining herself to him in
marriage, she now has the merit of his account passed on to her by the bank.
The bank in this example would represent God the Father as the righteous
Judge who credits us with the righteousness of His Son.
       Edwards appears to be off to a good start as he implicitly denies “that
merit is a fit reward of faith,” opting instead to regard it as a natural, rather
than moral, fitness/consequence.* True. The faith which united us with
Christ in the soteric marriage analogy naturally results in our having the
Lord’s righteousness imputed to us. Soteriological justification is not a
reward but is a natural consequence of being united to Christ by faith so that
His merit legally is transferred to our account as a gift. And this transfer is
not based upon any moral fitness that we have inherent in ourselves. The
poor woman in our example was flat broke and had nothing in her bank
account by which to attract her perspective husband—truly a Cinderella
story.

       Villain
        Edwards introduces a villain in his plot, even at this early stage in his
explanation of the nature of justification by faith, and it is not the villain that
the unsuspecting reader would anticipate. As a masterful magician, Edwards
is setting the stage for when he will transform justification by faith into
justification by works.

       If this [i.e., justification by faith] part of our Christian holiness
       qualifies us, in the sight of God, for this benefit of Christ, and
       renders it a fit or meet thing, in his sight, that we should have
       it, why not other parts of holiness, and conformity to God,
       which are also very excellent, and have as much of the image
       of Christ in them, and are no less lovely in God’s eyes, qualify
       us as much, and have as much influence to render us meet, in
       God’s sight, for such a benefit as this? 68

       “If faith qualifies us for justification, then why can other parts of
holiness such as Christian works not qualify us just as much?” is the
question Edwards is asking. And as he closes his introduction on the

*
  Edwards will later cast aside his own rejection of moral fitness when he
discusses rewards and embraces derivative moral fitness.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                 Page 129
meaning of justification, he offers a hint as to the transformational trick he
will pull subsequently: “They [i.e., works of holiness] enter into the
constitution of justifying faith, and do belong to its nature.”69 To this extent
and in this manner, the camel of works will be imported by Edwards through
the eye of the needle that constitutes justifying faith.

       Alternate Villain
        Had Edwards launched immediately into his importation of works
through the needle of faith, it might have set off alarms. Consequently, it is
necessary that he pose himself as the hero fighting an alternate villain lest he
be perceived as the true villain. Those advocating for ceremonial morality
are dressed up as the alternate villain by Edwards with their objection to
justification by faith. They are posed as objecting, “It is by a persevering
obedience that they [the justified] are continued in a justified state, and
it is by this that they are finally justified.”70 So that we may attend
Edwards’ masquerade party, we will ignore, for the moment, that he believes
the same proposition that he masquerades as criticizing! Let us allow
Edwards to enter into the discussion, dressed as the hero he thinks he is,
riding in on his white horse to save the day, with his rebuttal of this
villainous perseverance-based soteriology:

       But this is the same thing as to say, that a man on his first
       embracing the gospel is conditionally justified and pardoned.
       …Therefore if a person is pardoned, or freed from this misery,
       on his first embracing the gospel, and yet not finally freed, but
       his actual freedom still depends on some condition yet to be
       performed, it is inconceivable how he can be pardoned
       otherwise than conditionally: that is, he is not properly
       actually pardoned, and freed from punishment, but only he
       has God’s promise that he shall be pardoned on future
       conditions. God promises him, that now, if he perseveres in
       obedience, he shall be finally pardoned or actually freed from
       hell, which is to make just nothing at all of the apostle’s great
       doctrine of justification by faith alone. Such a conditional
       pardon is no pardon or justification at all.71

        Splendid argument! Applause would be appropriate here. A
justification that is contingent upon a believer’s subsequent perseverance in
faith is not an actual pardon at all (but only a potential one) and therefore no
justification at all. Edwards makes a grand opening into the fray. The
applause dies quickly, however, as Edward continues:

       But not to dispute about this, we will suppose that there may
       be something or other at the sinner’s first embracing the
Page 130                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       gospel, that may properly be called justification or pardon, and
       yet that final justification, or real freedom from the
       punishment of sin, is still suspended on conditions hitherto
       unfulfilled.72

       The other proverbial shoe has hit the floor, but it hardly makes a
sound as it lands with only a soft thump because Edwards knows how to
deaden the reader’s sensitivity to the conditionality that he himself will seek
to import through the eye of the needle as he suspends final (and therefore
real) justification on the tread of the believer’s postconversional
performance. He launches a scapegoat defense against those villains who
would claim that we are justified by moral law rather than by ceremonial
law. Indeed, anyone who thinks that he can get to heaven by keeping the
internal moral law (as described by C. S. Lewis), would highly be
encouraged to read this eleven-point rebuttal by Edwards to show the fallacy
of such moral security. One cannot get to heaven by keeping the moral law
written on one’s heart or on the pages of Scripture. However, while such
erroneous ceremonial advocates may exist, Edwards appears to be doing
little more than using them as a ploy to detract from the fact that he
advocates moral security as well. The pot calling the kettle black does not
make the horse upon which Edwards is riding white.
                    Illustration 38. Forms of Soteric Merit




       The Edwardian attack against ceremonial morality is certainly
successful insofar as it goes, but it is hardly adequate for dealing with the
full monstrosity of soteric merit. Lewis, for example, acknowledges that the
moral law condemns us. If the moral law condemns us, then ceremonial law
has no chance of justifying us. Even Arminians may thus acknowledge that
ceremonial merit has no hope of surviving a critical examination. Therefore,
Edwards is not going to be able to kill the Arminian argument merely by
attacking ceremonial merit. Other forms of soteric merit are just as deadly
and far more prevalent. But Edwards will stop far short of killing the
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                    Page 131
meritorious dragon, choosing instead to give it a home and breeding grounds
in his writings after he dispatches with parts of it.
       After dispatching ceremonial merit, Edward embarks on yet another
holy quest in fighting the form of self-righteousness which asserts that we
can be “justified by our own sincere obedience, or any of our own virtue or
goodness.”73 And he hastens to add yet another round of arguments to those
who “suppose a man is justified by his own virtue.”74 Though as Hunsinger
has noted, Edwards only means to repudiate independent merit with such
seemingly strong words. Edwards has no intention of denying virtual virtue.
A fuller form of the pro-virtue argument that Edwards is up against might be
expressed syllogistically as:

       Major premise: Justification is not based on our virtue.
       Minor premise: Faith is a virtue.
       Conclusion: Therefore, justification is not by faith.

        How will Edwards dispense with this argument? He cannot
indiscriminately come riding in as a knight in shining armor and kill all the
dragons in this fight because he himself has a dragon in the fight as well. If
he obliterates the minor premise completely, as the Reformers would be
inclined to do, then he kills his own argument he is building in which he
wants to virtually import* virtue into saving faith. He takes a swing of his
sword at the Arminian dragon: “One would wonder what Arminians mean
by Christ’s merits. They talk of Christ’s merits as much as anybody, and yet
deny the imputation of Christ’s positive righteousness.”75 Even if this
criticism were true in Edwards’ day, it is not necessarily the case
subsequently. Lewis, for example, indicates that Christ’s positive merits are
imputed to the believer.† Yet doing so does not keep Lewis from assuming

*
  Virtually importing will be used herein to describe Edwards’ use of virtual
importation to consider a subsequent and dependent event or series of events as
being present in, embedded in, beheld in, or considered a part of the previous
event that gave rise to that subsequent and dependent event or series of events.
Specifically, Edwards believes that initial faith contains the subsequent faith and
faithfulness produced by that initial faith and that this subsequent faith and
faithfulness consequently are contained in the initial faith that gave rise to this
subsequent faith and faithfulness. The tree (of faith and works) that arises from
the seed (of saving faith) is contained virtually in the seed, so to speak, and is
dependent on that originating seed.
†
  In laymen terms, Lewis implicitly affirms the imputation of Christ’s active
obedience since he defines a believer as someone who “trusts that Christ will
somehow share with him the perfect human obedience which He carried out
from His birth to His crucifixion” (3.12.146). Yet Lewis does seem to fuse, and
perhaps confuse, this imputational righteousness (which is derived solely from
Page 132                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
mistakenly, from an Arminian premise, that believers can lose their salvation
if they fail to persevere in virtuous faith. Edwards appears simply to be
blowing smoke to conceal the fact that his Arminian opponents, by and
large, hold the same theology as he does when he tries to import virtue into
saving faith. For Edwards, Christ’s imputed righteousness is insufficient to
get the believer to heaven. The believer’s personal righteousness must also
be imported. Therefore, any meaningful difference between Edwards and
Lewis as to the composition of soteric righteousness is nullified. Both men
would deduce wrongly that imputed righteousness is not enough to
guarantee that its recipient will make it to heaven; imported righteousness
would also be added by both:

• Soteric righteousness = imputed righteousness + imported righteousness.
• Soteric righteousness = works-righteousness (so Lewis and Edwards).

       Imputational Righteousness
        In contrast to some of his works-righteous compatriots in
Catholicism, Edwards acknowledges correctly that Christ imputes His moral
righteousness to us. Christ’s active righteousness thus is credited to our
account. To use our marriage analogy, when Cinderella married Prince
Charming, all the money in his bank account became hers. Christ did more
for us than simply forgive our debts and bring us back to a point of Adamic
pre-fall innocence. If restoring us to a state of innocence so that we could
start with a clean slate as a result of having our sins forgiven was all there
was to the atonement, then we could fall again (and die again as Lewis
mistakenly thinks). In response, Edwards correctly refutes the theory that
Christ’s passive suffering on the cross to make atonement for us only brings
us to the place of innocence but fails to purchase eternal life for us. To speak
analogously, it would be like Prince Charming paying off Cinderella’s
creditors but not putting any money into a bank account for her. She could
easily go back into debt again. But what if he had opened up an
inexhaustible checking account for her? Her financial security would have
been settled permanently.
        According to the Calvinistic covenant of works, for Adam to have
been confirmed in an unalterable state of unconditional spiritual security and
receive eternal life as a resultant reward, Adam would have had to persevere
in a state of active obedience until such a reward was granted.* Christ, as the


Christ’s earthly life) with impartational righteousness (which Christ works out in
our earthly lives).
*
  Thus, perseverance is a human work from day one in Covenant Theology. This
covenant of works continues to function after the fall in the form of the Moral
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                 Page 133
second Adam, has kept this covenant of works for us. According to
Edwards, we have eternal life not only as a result of Christ’s passive death
but also because of His active righteousness which is imputed to us. By
virtue of His active obedience, Christ won the reward of eternal life which
He can now give to us as a free gift. His active obedience is reckoned to our
account just as if we had actually performed it ourselves. His perseverance is
reckoned to us as our perseverance. Half affirmations of the atonement will
not do according to Edwards:

       To suppose that all Christ does is only to make atonement for
       us by suffering, is to make him our Savior but in part. It is to
       rob him of half his glory as a Savior. For if so, all that he does
       is to deliver us from hell: he does not purchase heaven for us.
       The adverse scheme supposes that he purchases heaven for us,
       in that he satisfies for the imperfections of our obedience and
       so purchases that our sincere imperfect obedience might be
       accepted as the condition of eternal life, and so purchases an
       opportunity for us to obtain heaven by our own obedience. But
       to purchase heaven for us only in this sense, is to purchase it in
       no sense at all….But that is not purchasing heaven, merely to
       set us at liberty again, that we may go and get heaven by what
       we do ourselves. All that Christ does is only to pay a debt for
       us. There is no positive purchase of any good. We are taught in
       Scripture that heaven is purchased for us. It is called the
       purchased possession, Eph. 1:14. The gospel proposes the
       eternal inheritance, not to be acquired, as the first covenant
       did, but as already acquired and purchased. But he that pays a
       man’s debt for him, and so delivers him from slavery, cannot
       be said to purchase an estate for him, merely because he sets
       him at liberty, so that henceforward he has an opportunity to
       get an estate by his own hand labor. So that according to this
       scheme, the saints in heaven have no reason to thank Christ for
       purchasing heaven for them, or redeeming them to God, and
       making them kings and priests, as we have an account that
       they do, in Rev. 5:9, 10.76

       Active Obedience
       Advocates of unconditional security can appreciate Edwards’ stance
against soteric conditionalism and his strong affirmation of imputational
righteous. Yet to misthologists, and therefore to advocates of conditional

Law. Those who teach that you get to heaven by perseverance are teaching a
covenant of works, not a covenant of grace.
Page 134                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
misthological security, it is painfully obvious that Edwards’ argument has
proven too much and thereby indicated an internal flaw in his reasoning.
Even so, it appears to have dealt a death blow to the soteriological
conditionalism of Arminianism and Catholicism because it overstates rather
than misstates the scope of the procured benefit.
       The premise of Edwards’ argument is acceptable: By Christ’s passive
and active obedience, Christ purchased more for us than Adam lost.
Unconditional soteriological securitists acknowledge that the free gift of
eternal life has been freely and permanently given to the believer on the
basis of Christ’s active merit. When Christ purchased us as His possession
by His perfect obedience, He saved us from hell and guaranteed us a
heavenly home as our possession. Our soteriological security is
unconditionally assured by Christ’s perfect obedience. The typical Arminian
argument for unconditional security dies with this acknowledgement.
Unfortunately, Edwards goes beyond this deduction to suggest that our
misthological security is made unconditionally secure as well by also basing
our misthological security on Christ’s merit. But God does not give us free
rewards at Christ’s expense.
       On the contrary, Arminians are correct in noting that passages
pertaining to rewards are presenting conditions based upon our performance.
Consequently, rewards are based on the Christian’s merit. Still, it is not
independent merit. Christians are dependent upon Christ for both their new
nature from which this performance originates and for the energizing power
of the Christ’s Spirit. Christian service is made acceptable in the Son. In the
passage cited above by Edwards (Rev 5:9-10), believers praise the Lord
Jesus for redeeming them with His blood and for making them (naturally) fit
for heaven. As is demonstrable from a variety of NT passages, this
forgiveness is offered freely (and naturally to use Edwards’ term) to those
who simply believe in Jesus for the entrance necessary for heaven. The
passage from Revelation progresses beyond this gift concept, however, to
state that this particular group of believers is also able to praise God for
making this priestly group rulers of heaven. As also attested by multiple NT
passages, such rulership is conditioned on a believer’s perseverance.
       The proper conclusion would, therefore, be that Christ not only
purchased gifts for us with the merit of His active obedience but that Christ
also purchased rewards for us as well. The gifts are naturally given to us
with no strings attached when we become believers. The rewards, in
contrast, are offered conditionally to us now that we are believers. By His
own merit, Christ purchased both gifts and rewards to offer to those who
would trust and obey Him. Even so, Christ demands that His gifts be
received freely as the gifts that they are and that His rewards be earned as
the rewards that they are. The Lord will not give His gifts as rewards, nor
will He give His rewards as gifts. His conditions must be met on His terms.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                     Page 135
Those who try to come to Christ on their own terms and refuse to submit to
His Lordship will be in for a tragic end.
        Genuine Lordship Salvationists submit to the biblical teaching that
justification salvation is a gift which they can in no way earn, that the free
gift of eternal life is a free gift which cost Christ’s life but costs them
nothing, and that redemption was won for them by the blood of Christ and
not by the sweat of their perseverance. Unashamedly, they bend their knees
and their backs to the toil of perseverance since their Lord and Master has
conditioned their obtaining the rewards of co-glorification salvation, the tree
and crown of life, and misthological forgiveness on their derivative merit.
They must endure with Him if they are to reign with Him (2Tim 2:13). Co-
merit is necessary for co-rulership.77 Misthological merit is shamelessly
derivative. They can shout a bravo for Edwards’ defense of derivative merit.
Faith must be virtuous if it is to be misthologically victorious. Biblical
Lordship Salvationists can salute Lewis for not backing down when
affirming the virtuous nature of persevering faith, even when facing legions
of Reformers who would assert otherwise. Misthologists must lift their
shields of faith against the vast hordes of Reformed arrows, which at times
blot out the sun as they fall down in countless number, shot by pseudo
Lordship Salvationists who insist on making a gift a reward and a reward a
gift.*
                    Illustration 39. Edwards Speaks Correctly

                  is not a                        ar

                  reward.                     w                      7

                                         Ed
