    See http://misthology.org/pdf/articles/Genuine_Lordship_Salvation.pdf.
Page 136                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Edwards speaks out of the right side of his mouth when he correctly
concludes his discussion of imputation by saying: “Indeed, neither salvation
itself, nor Christ the Savior, are given as a reward of anything in man: They
are not given as a reward of faith, nor anything else of ours.”78 Heaven is not
given as a reward for faith. Edwards ends this section of his discussion on
this correct note. For this reason, discerning misthologists may profitably
read both the arguments by Edwards and Lewis, as long as they will keep
clear in their own minds at least that entrance into heaven is not a reward
based on our virtuous faith but a gift given in response to our initial faith.

       Evangelical Obedience
         After a series of many splendid arguments affirming justification by
faith alone, Edwards concludes his defense of justification by imputation
with a key affirmation that the salvation which gets us into heaven is not a
“reward of faith,” just as Lewis likewise had affirmed. Obviously, however,
neither of these two writers really believes what they write since they both
condition entrance into heaven on perseverance.* Edwards has set his reader
up for the kill, in leading the unsuspecting reader into thinking that he
actually believes in a justification and imputation that will assure the
believer of heaven on the basis of faith alone. He sets the stage for his
transformation of justification by faith into justification by works and is now
ready to destroy any hopes of getting to heaven simply on the basis of that
initial faith (which actually resulted in imputational righteousness). The
trick, according to Edwards, is to deny that initial faith is enough to actually
(i.e., really) be justified.

       Actual Versus Virtual Faith
        Edwards starts his downward spiral into the abyss of works-
righteousness as subtly as a serpent: “The acts of a Christian life cannot be
concerned in this affair [of justification by faith] any otherwise than as they
imply, and are the expressions of faith.”79 He should have stopped with the
first half of that sentence: “The acts of a Christian life cannot be concerned
in this affair [of justification by faith].” But as it is, he is swinging the door
wide open to justification by works-righteous (i.e., to acts of a Christian life)
as necessary expressions of faith, beginning with perseverance in faith:




*
  They may have psychologically fooled themselves into thinking that they
believe heaven is not a reward, but they do not really believe it with logical
consistency. Logically, given the fuller scope of their statements, they cannot
believe that heaven is not a reward.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                     Page 137
       And it seems manifest that justification is by the first act of
       faith, in some respects, in a peculiar manner, because a sinner
       is actually and finally justified as soon as he has performed
       one act of faith, and faith in its first act does, virtually at least,
       depend on God for perseverance, and entities to this among
       other benefits. But yet the perseverance of faith is not excluded
       in this affair.80

       Whereas Lewis only made an allusion to Jn 15:6-7, Edwards
explicitly mentions this passage in order to make the same point: Salvation
from damnation is conditioned on a believer’s ongoing faith and
faithfulness. Edwards criticizes the conditionalism of Arminianism only to
virtually take the same position himself:

       The consideration of the perseverance of faith cannot be
       excluded out of this congruity or fitness. For it is congruous
       that he that believes in Christ should have an interest in
       Christ’s righteousness, and so in the eternal benefits purchased
       by it, because faith is that by which the soul has union or
       oneness with Christ. There is a natural congruity in it, that
       they who are one with Christ should have a joint interest with
       him in his eternal benefits. But yet this congruity depends on
       its being an abiding union. As it is needful that the branch
       should abide in the vine, in order to its receiving the lasting
       benefits of the root, so it is necessary that the soul should
       abide in Christ, in order to its receiving those lasting benefits
       of God’s final acceptance and favor. John 15:6, 7.…If it should
       be begun without remaining, the beginning would be in vain.
       In order to the soul’s being now in a justified state, and now
       free from condemnation, it is necessary that it should now be
       in Christ, and not merely that it should once have been in
       him….it is necessary not only that they should once be in him,
       but that they should die in him.81

        Such conditionalism should come as no surprise since both
Arminianism and Calvinism concur: Entrance into heaven is conditioned (by
this necessity) on the believer’s persevering in the faith until the believer
dies. In both systems of thought, if a person were to believe but then die in a
state of unbelief, this former believer would die as an unbeliever and would
go to hell. Both groups would regard such a person to be nonelect.
Articulations differ between the two camps as to why this is the case, but the
bottom line remains the same: A believer’s security is conditioned on his or
her perseverance. Or as Edwards expresses it, the branch (i.e., the believer)
must (as a necessity) abide (i.e., remain) in Christ in order to receive eternal
Page 138                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
life as a lasting benefit that results in final justification at death. Advocates
from both camps frequently appeal to good works as necessary evidence of
faith. This evidence (i.e., this perseverance in good works) is necessary to
reach heaven. If a believer were to cease to abide via perseverance, then he
or she would lose eternal life. On this matter, Edwardseanism is in complete
agreement with Arminianism. Both systems teach conditional security.
Edwards merely attempts to justify his conditionalism by importing his
conditionalism virtually. Given his line of reasoning, it is not difficult to see
his rationale.

        Illustration 40. Edwardsean Rationale for Virtual Importation
        Major Premise: Initial justification is by faith apart from
                preconversion works and assures final justification.
        Minor Premise: Final justification necessarily is conditioned
                on postconversional works.
        Conclusion: Therefore, initial justification must include
                postconversional works.

        One who experiences initial justification is assured, in Reformed
thought, of obtaining final justification through God’s sovereign grace
causing him or her to persevere. According to Edwards, since this final
justification is conditioned on postconversional works in the form of
perseverance, these postconversional works must be embedded, by means of
virtual importation, into initial justification. The problem is not in the flow
of Edwards’ argument as I have expressed it syllogistically; rather, his error
lies in the minor premise of his rationale. Conditional security must prove
that final soteric justification is conditioned on perseverance. Without this
key piece of evidence, conditional security falls apart. Naturally,
unconditional securitists believe this missing link is fatal to the
conditionalistic argument. Without a doubt, mistholic justification is
conditioned on postconversional works. But a soteriological conditionalist,
such as Edwards, must demonstrate that more than rewards are at stake.
Conditionalists must prove that final soteric justification itself is in jeopardy.
However, securitists counter quite easily:
                  Illustration 41. Perseverance Entails Merit
       Major Premise: Perseverance in faith is a Christian virtue (so Lewis).
       Minor Premise: Christian virtues entail merit (so Edwards).
       Conclusion: Therefore, perseverance in faith entails merit.

       The counterargument is that soteriological conditionalism necessarily
conditions entrance into heaven on the believer’s virtue. Both Lewis and
Edwards virtually hand securitists their counterargument on a silver platter.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                      Page 139
Securitists can therefore be appreciative of the fact that Lewis practically
concedes the major premise of their counterargument by admitting that
perseverance in faith is a virtue. Moreover, if perseverance in faith is a
virtue, then perseverance in faith entails merit. Edwards acknowledges this
to be the case when he says that perseverance in faith has natural congruity
in that it depends on our abiding union with Christ. That is, the merit that is
naturally found in perseverance is derivative and dependent. Certainly, there
is no need to quarrel with Edwards’ assertion that a Christian’s positive
merit must be derivative and dependent.* Edwards, therefore, supplies
securitists with the minor premise of their syllogism.
        Laborious demonstration that virtuous faith is meritorious will not be
necessary in assessing Edwardseanism since Hunsinger already has
demonstrated the obvious: Edwards’ soteriology incorporates congruent
merit. Nevertheless, exploration of the route that Edwards takes to merit his
way to heaven will be advantageous because it eventually engulfs the
Reformers also. With a dichotomy between what is actual and virtual,
Edwards virtually will import everything, including the idiomatic kitchen
sink (so to speak), into saving faith:

               So that although the sinner is actually and finally justified
         on the first act of faith, yet the perseverance of faith, even then,
         comes into consideration, as one thing on which the fitness of
         acceptance to life depends. God in the act of justification,
         which is passed on a sinner’s first believing, has respect to
         perseverance, as being virtually contained in that first act of
         faith, and it is looked upon, and taken by him that justifies, as
         being as it were a property in that faith. God has respect to the
         believer’s continuance in faith, and he is justified by that, as
         though it already were, because by divine establishment it shall
         follow, and it being by divine constitution connected with that
         first faith, as much as if it were a property in it, it is then
         considered as such, and so justification is not suspended. But
         were it not for this, it would be needful that it should be
         suspended, till the sinner had actually persevered in faith.
               And that it is so, that God in the act of final justification
         which he passes at the sinner’s conversion, has respect to
         perseverance in faith, and future acts of faith, as being virtually
         implied in the first act, is further manifest by this, viz. That in
         a sinner’s justification, at his conversion there is virtually
         contained a forgiveness as to eternal and deserved punishment,
         not only of all past sins, but also of all future infirmities and

*
    See affirmation of synergistic merit in Perseverance is not a Gift, 100.
Page 140                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       acts of sin that they shall be guilty of, because that first
       justification is decisive and final.82

        Here, Edwards imagines that perseverance in faith is a property and
congruity that virtually is contained in initial faith so that one’s final
justification is conditioned on perseverance in faith in the end. By such a
congruity, Edwards’ makes heaven a gratuity. Hunsinger does not seem
quite sure what to do with Edwards’ appeal to virtual embedding, other than
to reject it. To be sure, securitists will reject it as well; nevertheless, this
rejection should not cause one to be insensitive to the potential geniuses in
Edwards’ argument.
        Those familiar with Greek grammar might picture Edwards’
argument in terms of external versus internal aoristic aspect. Saving faith is
claimed by insecuritists to be externally punctiliar but inwardly linear
(i.e., {
       ¨ ). In other words, conditional securitists claim that although saving

faith may look like it occurs in a moment of time when you look on saving
faith from the outside, if you truly get inside of saving faith and look at it in
terms of the Greek grammar, then it is really linear internally and
contingently runs throughout the entire course of the believer’s life. The
possible connection between Edwards’ conceptual argument and the
conditional aspectual argument should not escape the astute conditionalist.
                      Illustration 42. Virtual Embedding
      Ongoing Linear (£) Aspect                 Virtual Kitchen Sink

             ll y Pu
           a
                            nc
    te r n



                                tilia




                  OL
  x

       Viewed in this manner, Edwards’ claim is more comprehensible,
although certainly no more agreeable. His kitchen sink is a sinkhole into
which he wants to pour all sorts of postconversional performance into the
faith which initially and finally saved us the moment we came to saving
faith. Conditionalists claim that ongoing linear (OL) faith is embedded
internally in aoristic saving faith, even though saving faith appears to be
punctiliar to external examination. Edwards likewise is claiming that
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                    Page 141
ongoing faith and faithfulness virtually are embedded theologically in saving
faith, even though this faith certainly looks punctiliar, since the Bible
teaches that believers were justified fully and finally the moment they came
to saving faith.
       In my books, The Outer Darkness and Believe, I take an opposing
approach to conditionalists and naturally will do so here as well in
interacting with Edwards. But my opposition to Edwards does not prevent
me from appreciating his insight into virtual reality. As to the Greek aspect
pictured in Illustration 42. Virtual Embedding, I would argue for both
internal punctiliarity (~) and resulting linear state (▬).
              Illustration 43. Punctiliar Action Within Stative Result


                              x-▬
                          ~+▬=~ —
In conjunction with the interaction with Lewis in this present book and my
aspectual arguments elsewhere, my proposal is that the punctiliar action of
saving faith lives on (virtually speaking) in the stated result of having eternal
life into the eternal future. In other words, the soteriological promise of
eternal life could be pictured as: “He who believes (~) has (▬) eternal life.”
Since it is eternal life, one’s possession of that life must be eternal and must
logically extend eschatologically into the future.
                 Illustration 44. Eschatological Perfective Present




       Edwards conceives the condition as extending into the future; I
perceive the benefit as extending into the future. Therefore, speaking from
my perspective, in terms of the stated resulting benefit, a person would still
be a (virtual) believer even if that person were to cease to believe.* (This
conclusion is shared, although in a less technically-precise fashion, by my
Free Grace compatriots.) In terms of result, a believer is a possessor of
eternal life, and a possessor of eternal life is a believer. The benefit of being
regarded a believer extends into eternity future because one has eternal life.
After all, the Bible assures us that the eternal life which we receive the

*
    See Illustration 62. Causal Chain, 183.
Page 142                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
moment we come to saving faith is a free gift and that it is eternal. Naturally,
our having eternal life must be an eternal benefit. The description of a
person as a believer continues on into the present and even into the future in
terms of the eternal result. Even if a person ceases to believe, that individual
is still a believer in terms of the resulting benefit imparted. My thesis, then,
is simple: Heaven is a gift received in simple faith—not a reward earned
by virtuous faith. By making the benefit eternal and unconditional (in
calling it a free gift), the Bible virtually has encapsulated initial faith as a
fulfilled condition in the ongoing possession of eternal life.
         Edwards, on the other hand, argues for linear contingency rather than
for fulfilled contingency. One might very well turn to one of Edwards’ many
fine arguments when he talks out of the right side of his mouth to refute
Edwards when he switches to speak wrongly from the other side of his
mouth. To use, for example, Edwards’ imputational argument that Christ did
not make half of an atonement,* one well may ask, “Where is Edwards’
proof that when Jesus offered to become our Savior, He intended for us to
become co-saviors so that He is only a Half-Savior?” In the extended quote
provided above, Edwards makes two very feeble attempts to supply proof so
as to establish a linear condition as being virtually embedded within the
initial condition of punctiliar faith. Revisiting his proof that perseverance in
faith is embedded within initial faith is in order. His first proof stated in that
quote is:

               God has respect to the believer’s continuance in faith, and
         he is justified by that, as though it already were, because by
         divine establishment it shall follow, and it being by divine
         constitution connected with that first faith, as much as if it
         were a property in it, it is then considered as such, and so
         justification is not suspended. But were it not for this, it would
         be needful that it should be suspended, till the sinner had
         actually persevered in faith.83

        Edwards asserts that since God has divinely established that a
believer will persevere in faith, such perseverance must be constituted
divinely in that initial faith with the result that a believer is justified by that
continuation in faith. Otherwise, God would have had to suspend
justification until the believer actually had persevered in faith. The futility of
Edwards’ argument should be readily apparent to anyone not blinded by
Calvinism.
        First, his opening statement begs the question: “Did God
unconditionally decree that believers will persevere in faith?” Those outside

*
    See Imputational Righteousness, 132.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                 Page 143
of Calvinistic circles rightly would shake their heads, “No.” Secondly, if
God unconditionally so constituted believers that they would persevere in
the faith, then why did God conditionally warn them to persevere in the
faith? Lastly and most importantly, it is blatantly false for Edwards to assert
that if it were not for God establishing the believer’s perseverance in faith,
then God would have needed to suspend the believer’s final justification
until the believer persevered to the end. Hardly! God neither has demanded
that believers persevere in order to get into heaven or promised that
believers will persevere since they are going to heaven. To the contrary, God
could promise and has promised eternal life (not eternal faith) and final
justification (not co-glorification salvation) to believers. And they actually
receive the unconditional assurance of this final justification the very
moment they come to saving faith because this justification is not
conditioned on their perseverance.
                    Illustration 45. Picture of Importation




        For Edwards, the condition for final justification is made necessary
evidence of initial justification. Calvinists who claim that the evidence is not
conditional fail to see why it is necessary and virtually importable in
Edwardseanism. For Marrowists, in contrast, God is able to make such
unconditional promises because the fulfillment of these promises is free to
those who have met the stated condition, which in this case is punctiliar
faith. Since the fulfillment of the promise is unearned to the person who has
Page 144                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
believed and who has thereby received the free gift of eternal life, it was not
necessary that God suspend the declaration of the individual’s final
justification until he or she perseveres. These soteric promises are based
exclusively on Christ’s merit, not on an installment plan. Since when did
justification by faith apart from works become justification by faith which
embodies works? Edwards’ attempt to import work into faith without work
will not work.
        Nevertheless, just in case the relation of virtual importation with
respect to the Greek verbal aspect may be too foreign for those not trained in
Greek to grasp readily, the deduction used in Edwards’ argument may be
pictured from yet another vantage point that can be summarized
symbolically with the if-and-only-if (⇔) symbol:
               Illustration 46. Symbolical Syllogism of Importation
         1. Initial justification ⇔ final justification.
         2. Perseverance ⇔ final justification.
         3. Therefore, initial justification ⇔ perseverance.*

        As already indicated in Illustration 40. Edwardsean Rationale for
Virtual Importation, Edwards believes correctly that initial justification
always will result in final justification and that the outcome of final
justification is limited to those who experience initial justification.
Therefore, in Illustration 45 the first step is to use the if-and-only-if symbol
(⇔) to link initial justification with final justification. This is why both ends
of this elongated symbol are labeled as number one in Illustration 45. Initial
justification assures final justification. Taken at face value, this first step is
sufficient to affirm unconditional security for those who have experienced
initial justification. As a Calvinist, however, Edwards cannot afford to take
such promises in Scripture at face value. Calvinistic theology has been
summarized by the acronym TULIP, and the P in the Calvinistic TULIP
stands for perseverance. Calvinists soteriologically condition final
justification on perseverance.
        Therefore, as the second step, in order to accurately reflect Edwards’
soteriology, it was necessary to fill the elongated if-and-only-if symbol (⇔)
with dots (xxx) to denote daily, weekly, monthly, yearly acts of faith and
faithfulness (⇔ xxx ). In Edwardseanism, a believer will reach heaven if-and-
only-if the believer’s life is punctuated linearly and contingently with acts of
obedience. Since these postconversional works comprise the second step, the
dots are labeled with the number two in Illustration 45. Initial justification
and final justification are the bookends containing the believer’s works, and
these works qualify the believer’s faith as saving faith in Edwardseanism. So
*
    Edwardseanism: initial justification ⇔ perseverance ⇔ final justification.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                   Page 145
the second step in Edwards’ reasoning is to make these works of
righteousness a condition for final justification. Thus, the upper arching
arrow is drawn to represent his importation of these works contingently into
final justification. These dots are embedded as the intermediary connection
in Edwardseanism between initial and final justification and make a
condition for final justification.
        Finally, the third step in Edwards’ progression is virtually to import
this postconversional works-righteousness into initial faith. Thus, the
number three in the lower arching arrow of the illustration completes the
cycle by virtually importing all the dots (i.e., all our postconversion works of
righteousness and our perseverance in faith) back into initial faith. For
Edwards to say that these works of righteousness are imported virtually into
initial faith is simply to claim that they are embedded in, beheld in, and
considered a part of that initial faith.
        Virtual importation is a valid concept. But one must be careful as to
what one is importing. One cannot import a work construct into a non-work
concept. To illustrate why importing is important, however, a biblically
accurate example may be considered:
                     Illustration 47. Biblical Importation
       1. Redemption ⇔ justification.
       2. Justification ⇔ eternal life.
       3. Therefore, redemption ⇔ eternal life.

        In terms of logical soteric sequence (i.e., ordo salutis), redemption
provides the basis for justification. Temporally, everyone who has
experienced redemption also has received justification, and only those who
have received justification have come into a realization of redemption. The
first statement is rock solid. The same can be said of the second statement.
Justification provides the basis for the possession of the gift of eternal life so
that everyone who has the former also has the latter. And only those who
have the latter have the former. Therefore, it could be said that when God
redeemed us, He did so with a foreview as to the justification He would
grant to us as a result. One could expand this line of reasoning. This
justification was granted in anticipation of the regeneration that logically
would come afterwards. Regeneration, in turn, assures glorification.*
Granted, all Arminians (and most Calvinists) would challenge this last
statement. But without going into detail in the present work as to why this
glorification is assured just as much as the other items, let it suffice for now
to at least use this chain of thought as an example of potential importation

*
 See my book Ordo Salutis for more detailed consideration and for explanation
as to why I place justification before regeneration.
Page 146                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
and limit my defense of its biblical accuracy by offering a counter challenge
to Edwards’ faulty line of reasoning regarding conditional security.
       When one turns to Edwards’ next paragraph, in which he offers his
second proof for virtual importation, one finds that Edwards unwittingly
gives an affirmation of my premise:

            God in the act of final justification which he passes at the
       sinner’s conversion, has respect to perseverance in faith, and
       future acts of faith, as being virtually implied in the first act, is
       further manifest by this, viz. That in a sinner’s justification,
       at his conversion there is virtually contained a forgiveness
       as to eternal and deserved punishment, not only of all past
       sins, but also of all future infirmities and acts of sin that
       they shall be guilty of, because that first justification is
       decisive and final.84 (Italics his.)

All sins (past, present, and future) are forgiven when a believer comes to
saving faith. The benefit of having one’s sins forgiven soteriologically is
therefore eternal since this benefit encompasses all sins. Logically, one
could not commit a sin that would result in these sins ceasing to be forgiven
because even the sin that one hypothetically would have to commit in order
to do so already would be forgiven. With logical consistency and biblical
accuracy, it may be maintained that what is contained virtually in that initial
forgiveness is the unconditional soteriological forgiveness of all sins. This
importation by Edwards is biblically accurate. A person stands permanently
and perfectly forgiven as a result of having trusted in Christ to forgive all his
or her sins soteriologically because all those sins (even future ones) were
dealt with at that time. Heaven is the assured result. By the sheer nature of
the case, such a benefit can have absolutely nothing to do with the linear
condition of perseverance. Edwards has misfired and proven my point rather
than his own with this biblically accurate example of importation.

       David’s Justification
       Nevertheless, the scriptural basis that Edwards uses to justify his
linear view of justification (in which he seeks to make salvation from eternal
damnation dependent on ongoing repentance) must be examined critically.
His first argument comes from Rom 4:6-8 (cp. Ps 32:1-2):

            David, in the beginning of Psalm 32 speaks of the
       forgiveness of sins which were doubtless committed long after
       he was first godly, as being consequent on those sins, and on
       his repentance and faith with respect to them, and yet this
       forgiveness is spoken of by the apostle in the 4th of Romans,
       as an instance of justification by faith. Probably the sin David
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                   Page 147
       there speaks of is the same that he committed in the matter of
       Uriah, and so the pardon the same with that release from death
       or eternal punishment, which the prophet Nathan speaks of,
       2 Sam. 12:13, “The Lord also hath put away thy sin; thou shalt
       not die.” Not only does the manifestation of this pardon follow
       the sin in the order of time, but the pardon itself, in the order of
       nature, follows David’s repentance and faith with respect to
       this sin. For it is spoken of in Psalm 32 as depending on it.
             But inasmuch as a sinner, in his first justification, is
       forever justified and freed from all obligation to eternal
       punishment, it hence of necessity follows, that future faith
       and repentance are beheld, in that justification, as virtually
       contained in that first faith and repentance.

       Outline of Edwards’ Argument.
       Edwards thus appeals to the OT background of Paul’s statement for
the Edwardian importing of future faith and repentance into the initial faith
which justified us. So that the fallacy of Edwards’ argument may be made
more readily apparent, it will be helpful to restate his argument in a
syllogistic summary:

1.    David was initially justified by faith before he experienced the
      justification described in Rom 4:6-8 (Ps 32:1-2).
2.    David also was justified subsequently by faith when he repented and
      confessed his sin in Rom 4:6-8 (Ps 32:3-6).
3.    Therefore, initial justification by faith includes the subsequent faith
      and works which flow from that initial faith.

       Critical Response
        Multiple critical errors are apparent in Edwards’ recasting of the
sequence and in his equivalence of the biblical events. First, the conditional
contention expressed by both Arminians and Calvinists alike in claiming that
David was in danger of a soteriological death that would have resulted in his
eternal damnation in 2Sam 2:13 is contested by securitists. If temporal death
is all that is implied in this passage, then Edwards’ argument loses much, if
not all, of its force. If temporal forgiveness is indicated, then David is
conjoining soteriological and temporal forgiveness but not necessarily in a
manner conducive to Edwards’ argument, which stipulates that the
subsequent temporal forgiveness is contained in the previous soteriological
forgiveness. On the contrary, rather than assume that the initial justification
virtually includes the subsequent forgiveness, one may assert quite
reasonably an entirely different relationship: Initial justification makes
subsequent forgiveness possible. Taking Ps 32:1-2 as referring to that initial
Page 148                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
justification would harmonize completely with the Pauline text and do no
violence to the Davidic context by perceiving the initial justification as the
foundation for the temporal forgiveness that follows in Ps 32:3-6.
        According to Grossman, “David had committed sin for which there
was no sacrifice provided by the law, and he learned of the mercy of God
when he cast himself upon the Lord’s mercy to obtain forgiveness,
confessing his sin and admitting his own unworthiness.”85 To be sure,
Edwards could respond to such a statement by claiming that David was not
justified by works of the law but by faith-works (i.e., by works springing
from faith). One only need look at an Arminian like Guy Duty or a Calvinist
like John MacArthur to see that this is a popular means employed by
conditionalists in making salvation conditioned on postconversional
performance.
        Lopez penetrates further into the Davidic discussion when he implies
that the plural form makarioi (blessed) indicates more than one type of
blessing which encompasses the soteriological one-time-act of justification
in Rom 4:6-8 (= Ps 32:1-2) and the subsequent familial forgiveness
described in Ps 32:3-6.86 Therefore, although forgiveness is linear, the
soteriological dimension of that forgiveness is punctiliar. If this thesis is
correct, the justification of Rom 4:6-8 (= Ps 32:1-2) is foundational and
provides the fountain from which subsequent forgiveness flows.
Soteriological justification makes familial forgiveness possible. The
justification, which David had obtained earlier by faith apart from works,
made possible a continued forgiveness not available under the law. David
already had discovered and experienced an initial justification by faith apart
from works years before, and this discovery allows him to experience a
temporal justification by faith-works even when confronted by Nathan years
later.
        This subsequent justification by faith-works is not to be equated with
justification by faith apart from works (despite the inclination of Duty and
MacArthur to think otherwise).* If the not (;) symbol is used to signify
apart from, a refutation of the Duty-MacArthur equality would
correspondingly be: faith-works ≠ faith;works. In other words, justification
by faith-works is not the same thing as justification by faith apart from
works. As for a response to Edwards, this subsequent Davidic justification
by faith-works should not be perceived as being present virtually in
justification by faith apart from works. A negation of the subset symbol may
be used to express dissatisfaction with Edwards. The proper biblical




*
    See chapter three of the present work.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                 Page 149
                                                      *
equation would thus be: faith-works ⊄ faith;works. Justification by faith-
works is not virtually contained in justification by faith apart from
works! For that matter, when it comes to saving faith, this correct statement
can be abbreviated as: works ⊄ faith. Edwards is wrong in trying to import
postconversional works into saving faith. His soteriology could be
summarized as: works ⊂ faith.†
        Constable progresses yet one step further in biblical insight to assert:
“Paul not only proved that David believed in imputed rather than earned
righteousness with this quotation, but he also showed that when a believer
sins his sin does not cancel his justification.”87 Therefore, the Davidic
passage can be understood as supporting unconditional security per
Constable or as implying conditional security per Edwards. The balance is
decisively in Constable’s favor since Paul regards Ps 32:1-2 as a justification
by faith apart form works (faith;works) rather than a justification by faith
which includes works. Therefore, works ⊂ faith and faith-works are both
excluded soteriologically by Paul. All works are excluded—both legal and
virtual—from saving faith.
        Edwards inverts the flow of Paul’s thought when Edwards pictures
sanctification as flowing virtually back into justification. A river does not
flow back into its fountain head nor is a river contained virtually in its
fountain head; rather, the river flows from its fountain head and contains the
water from its fountain head.‡ Edwards is thinking in reverse when he
wrongly tries to incorporate our future works virtually into our past faith.
Justification by faith;works (in Ps 32:1-2) made it possible for David to
find justification by faith-works (in Ps 32:3-6). However, it is an error of the
highest magnitude to equate the two or to embed the two by making
postconversion confession and repentance part of faith;works.
        Edwards’ appeals to virtual incorporation, virtuous faith, and linear
justification are justifiable. Still, one must be careful when importing that
one does not import works into a realm were the Bible places a curse on
those who would make such an importation. Future sins may be described
accurately as virtually nailed to the cross. Initial faith certainly is to be
affirmed as being nonmeritorious, but perseverance in faith is properly

*
  Edwards believes faith-works ⊂ faith;works, that is, perseverance in faith and
in its corresponding works are embedded in the faith by which we were saved
apart from works. I am expressing my disagreement with the ⊄ symbol.
†
  For Edwards, works ⊂ faith means that works are a part of soteric faith. The
Bible rejects such a notion, however. My contention is that works ⊄ faith is the
biblically correct perspective. Works are not to be considered a part of,
embedded in, beheld in, or virtually imported into saving faith.
‡
  See Illustration 62. Causal Chain, 183.
Page 150                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
regarded as virtuous (meritorious). And as long as soteriological justification
is seen as the fountain head for misthological justification, and not vice
versa, the biblical directive and direction are maintained.

       Model Prayer
        Edwards’ Davidic argument above is thoughtful but sadly mistaken.
The same cannot be said for much of his subsequent arguments used to
support his importing of subsequent works into initial faith. For the most
part, his ensuing arguments are simply sadly mistaken:

             And besides, if no other act of faith could be concerned in
       justification but the first act, it will then follow that Christians
       ought never to seek justification by any other act of faith. For
       if justification is not to be obtained by after acts of faith, then
       surely it is not a duty to seek it by such acts. And so it can
       never be a duty for persons after they are once converted, by
       faith to seek God, or believingly to look to him for the
       remission of sin, or deliverance from the guilt of it, because
       deliverance from the guilt of sin, is part of what belongs to
       justification. And if it be not proper for converts by faith to
       look to God through Christ for it, then it will follow that it is
       not proper for them to pray for it. For Christian prayer to God
       for a blessing, is but an expression of faith in God for that
       blessing: prayer is only the voice of faith. But if these things
       are so, it will follow that the petition in the Lord’s prayer,
       forgive us our debts, is not proper to be put up by the disciples
       of Christ, or to be used in Christian assemblies.88

       Answering such arguments as these is nothing but child’s play and
leads one to suspect that Edwards is grasping at straws rather than engaging
in careful contemplation. First, it is true, not false, that Christians ought
never to seek [soteric] justification by any other act of faith but the first act.
The foundation of punctiliar justification by faith is apart from works. Our
subsequent works (acts) are not part of that foundation. We work to build
upon the foundation, not to add to the foundation. Second, it is blatantly
false for Edwards to assert that punctiliar justification rules out our duty as
Christians to seek to build upon the soteriological foundation with
misthological works. Edwards acts as if he has never read Paul’s statement
in 1Cor 3:11-15, which plainly asserts otherwise. Third, it is silly for
Edwards to give no thought to the fact that one type of forgiveness does not
necessarily rule out the necessity for another type of forgiveness. In the
model prayer, God’s children ask Him, as their Father, to forgive their sins.
And they are warned that if they do not forgive, they will not be forgiven—
as God’s children! We do not forgive in order to become God’s children but
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                               Page 151
because we are God’s children. Nor are we to forgive in order to remain
God’s children but in order to have fellowship with God as His children. A
child can understand, even if Edwards cannot, that for a father to forgive his
child or to withhold forgiveness from his child is not to be equated with the
type of forgiveness granted by a father in adopting his child.
        God foreknew all of our sins before He adopted us and forgave us of
all those sins in regard to adopting us when He accepted us into His family
and judicially forgave us. This once-and-for-all adopting forgiveness that
resulted in believers becoming a member of the family is not to be equated
with their subsequent daily family forgiveness that they need to remain in
fellowship with their Father. The fact that believers need ongoing familial
forgiveness to remain in fellowship within the family does not mean that
they need ongoing forgiveness to remain a member of the family. The
familial forgiveness of Mt 6:14-15 and 1Jn 1:9 is not to be equated with, or
embedded in, the judicial forgiveness that was granted to us when we were
justified by faith apart from works. The relational forgiveness that is
received in order to become a member of God’s family provides the basis for
the filial forgiveness that is experienced as members of that family. That
latter forgiveness is dependent upon the former, not vice versa.
                 Illustration 48. Four Planes of Forgiveness




      Since there are at least four types of forgiveness, it is no wonder that
Edwards’ soteriology collapses into justification by works when he
compresses all four types of forgiveness into one:
Page 152                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

            From what has been said, we may understand, not only
       how the forgiveness of sin granted in justification is
       indissolubly connected with a forgiving spirit in us, but how
       there may be many exercises of forgiving mercy granted in
       reward for our forgiving those who trespass against
       us….This forgiveness may be in reward for our
       forgiveness, without any prejudice to the doctrine that has
       been maintained, as well as other mercies and blessings
       consequent on justification.89

        To the present author’s amazement, when he pointed out to the
Sunday School class which was studying Lewis’ Mere Christianity that
since our forgiveness is conditioned on our forgiving others in certain texts
(e.g., Mt 6:14-15 and 18:32-34) such forgiveness must be meritorious, the
teacher of the class actually denied that such postconversion forgiveness is
meritorious, even though we have to jump through a number of performance
hoops in order to obtain it. To Edwards’ credit, he (in contrast to the teacher
of that class) correctly perceives that such postconversion forgiveness is a
reward for our forgiving others (and therefore meritorious). The problem is
that Edwards thinks that our initial justification (i.e., judicial) forgiveness “is
indissolubly connected with” our meritorious postconversion forgiveness of
others so that even our judicial forgiveness also may be considered a
reward! Such an allegation by Edwards is yet one more failed attempt on
his part to make heaven a reward and to deny that justification by faith alone
is a gift:

             Faith is the condition of justification, and in another
       sense, other qualifications and acts are conditions of salvation
       and justification too….But in this sense faith is not the only
       condition of salvation and justification. For there are many
       things that accompany and flow from faith, with which
       justification shall be, and without which, it will not be, and
       therefore are found to be put in Scripture in conditional
       propositions with justification and salvation, in multitudes of
       places. Such are love to God, and love to our brethren,
       forgiving men their trespasses, and many other good
       qualifications and acts. And there are many other things
       besides faith, which are directly proposed to us, to be pursued
       or performed by us, in order to [have] eternal life, which if
       they are done, or obtained, we shall have eternal life, and if not
       done, or not obtained, we shall surely perish.90
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                         Page 153
        To the contrary, the Bible is explicit that Edwardseanism is mistaken:
“Being justified as a gift by His grace through the redemption which is in
Christ Jesus” (Rom 3:24).* “In Him we have redemption through His blood,
the forgiveness of our trespasses, according to the riches of His grace”
(Eph 1:7). “If it is by grace, it is no longer on the basis of works, otherwise
grace is no longer grace” (Rom 11:6). This judicial forgiveness is not
contingent upon works. Other kinds of forgiveness, in contrast, are rewards
which must be obtained by jumping through a lot of hoops: confession,
repentance, baptism, prayer, and forgiving others. But judicial justification is
a gift, not a reward. This soteric forgiveness is obtained by merits of Christ’s
death, not by our works. Edwardseanism constructs a multitude of hoops and
conditions that one must jump through in order to have eternal life and avoid
perishing in hell. In the Bible, there is but one: “For God so loved the world,
that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him should
not perish, but have eternal life” (Jn 3:16).

       Assurance
       Edwards’ next argument plummets into the crash into which all his
inclusive arguments are heading.

            A Christian that is doubtful of his first act of faith cannot
       have [assurance] from that act, because, by the supposition, he
       is doubtful whether it be an act of faith, and so whether he did
       obtain pardon and peace by that act. The proper remedy, in
       such a case, is now by faith to look to God in Christ for these
       blessings, but he is cut off from this remedy, because he is
       uncertain whether he has warrant so to do….So he can never
       properly obtain the joy of faith, for there are acts of true faith
       that are very weak, and the first act may be so as well as
       others. It may be like the first motion of the infant in the
       womb: it may be so weak an act, that the Christian, by
       examining it, may never be able to determine whether it was a
       true act of faith or no….The proper way of deliverance, is to
       forsake their sin by repentance, and by faith now to come to
       Christ for deliverance from the deserved eternal punishment.
       But this it would not be, if deliverance from that punishment
       was not this way to be obtained.91



*
  The redemption, which makes justification possible and which comprises both
the first step of justification as well as the full scope of soteric justification, is by
grace apart from works.
Page 154                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Many (the present writer included) would attest readily that the path
Edwards is advocating leads to lack of assurance rather than to full
assurance. Many of us who believe in punctiliar justification indeed may
agree with Edwards that our initial faith may, in fact, have been very weak.
Still, contrary to Edwards’ supposition, we are not forced to forever look
back to that initial floundering faith for our present assurance. Instead, we
may rest quite contentedly on the fact that even now, at this very minute, we
(in contrast to those like Edwards) are trusting in Christ alone apart from
works for eternal life and therefore are completely assured of eternal life.
Edwards, on the other hand, does not come to Christ with an empty hand. He
seeks to cling to Christ with meritorious repentance and persevering faith,
and in doing so he is not clinging to Christ alone. Indeed, he believes that
salvation from eternal damnation is won by a daily forsaking of one’s sin.
This is the way that deliverance from eternal damnation is obtained
according to Edwards. But it is not Christ’s way.
        Not only does Edwardseanism lead us away from trusting in Christ
alone for eternal life, it also leads us away from complete assurance. How
can one completely be sure that one will turn completely from sin
tomorrow? If one cannot completely be sure (and if one is honest, one
cannot be), then one cannot completely be sure that one will be saved
tomorrow on Edwards’ terms. But for that matter, can one completely be
sure that one has forsaken sin completely even at this moment? If not, then
one cannot completely be sure (according to Edward’s premise) that one is
saved even at this very moment. Edwards’ doctrine of assurance is faulty
and deadly.

      Abraham’s Justification
        Edwards expends a few sentences to defend his thesis of linear
soteriological justification by pointing out that Abraham was justified by
faith (Gal 3:6) long after he had, by faith, left his home country (Heb 11:8).
Granted, this is a formidable argument. However, equally impressive
counterarguments have been proposed by others. The present writer adopts
the thesis advanced by Ross and accepted by Dillow, among others, that
Abraham was justified by faith years before. This justification by faith
preceded his justification by faith-works. Without going into the exegetical
details, since this has been done elsewhere, the same type of argument
advanced regarding David’s justification may be applied to Abraham.
Soteriological justification makes misthological justification possible, but
misthological justification is to be distinguished from, not embedded in,
soteriological justification.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                 Page 155

       Win Christ’s Resurrection
       If it were not for the fact that Paul’s discussion of Phil 3:8-11 already
has been explained well by so many others and addressed in detail in The
Outer Darkness, I might bother to refute Edwards on this passage. As it is, it
suffices herein to let Edwards hang himself in thinking that Paul is still
trying to win a soteriological participation in the resurrection. If one is not
willing to investigate alternate interpretations of this passage and seriously
consider the misthological ramifications of the out-resurrection in this
Philippians passage, one very may well shut oneself out from soteriological
participation in the resurrection by one’s own close-minded works-
righteousness. In such a case, what more need be said than what Jesus has
already said? Let the unrighteous still be unrighteous (Rev 22:11). Let those
who are close-minded to alternate interpretations or who are simply too
disinterested in investigating this Philippians passage continue to imagine
that they can win a free ticket into heaven with their laborious performance.
The only thing they will win with such attitudes is hell.

       Merit Your Salvation with Perseverance
       With a few more proof texts (e.g. Heb 3:6,14; 10:38-39;
Rom 11:20—which show nothing but misthological contingency), Edwards
now concludes his discussion of evangelical obedience by conditioning
entrance into heaven on the merit of the believer’s perseverance:

             Perseverance of faith is necessary, even to the
       congruity of justification….And that perseverance in faith
       is thus necessary to salvation….
             And that God in justification has respect, not only to the
       first act of faith, but also to future persevering acts….
             So that, as was before said of faith, so may it be said of a
       child-like believing obedience: it has no concern in
       justification by any virtue or excellency in it, but only as there
       is a reception of Christ in it. And this is no more contrary to
       the apostle’s frequent assertion of our being justified without
       the works of the law, than to say that we are justified by faith.
       For faith is as much a work, or act of Christian obedience, as
       the expressions of faith, in spiritual life and walk. And
       therefore, as we say that faith does not justify as a work, so we
       say of all these effective expressions of faith.92

        Edwards has documented his fall from grace (Gal 5:4) in his seeking
justification by works as his means of reaching heaven. Since these works
Page 156                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
are of a child-like believing obedience, they are supposedly not contrary to
Paul’s emphatic insistence that we are not justified by (moral) works.*
According to Edwards, since faith is as much an act of Christian obedience
as these postconversional Christian works, these Christian works are not
contrary to justification by faith alone. To summarize his argument:
       1.   Faith is an act of Christian obedience.
       2.   Good works are acts of Christian obedience.
       3.   Faith is not a work.
       4.   Therefore, good works arising from faith are not works.

Hopefully, one will sense that something is amiss for Edwards to conclude
that works are not works. In terms of logic, Edwards evidently is thinking
something along these lines:

       1.   A puppy is a four-legged animal.
       2.   A dog is a four-legged animal.
       3.   A puppy is not a winged creature.
       4.   Therefore, a dog is not a winged creature.

Superficially, such an argument seems to make sense. But the reality might
be better pictured as this:

       1.   A puppy is a four-legged animal.
       2.   A dog is a four-legged animal.
       3.   A puppy is not brown.
       4.   Therefore, a dog is not brown.

Something is wrong when one concludes that no dog is brown. Whereas,
Edwards’ first and second premises were correct. His third premise is faulty.
Some faith is work; likewise, some dogs are brown. Just as dogs can be
brown, so faith can be a work. In fact, Edwards and Lewis are correct in
considering perseverance in faith to be a virtuous faith. As such, it would
incur merit and thus be regarded as a work.
        One might object that this analogy does not formally hold true to this
representation of Edwards’ position: (1) A ⊂ C, (2) B ⊂ C, (3) A ≠ B, (4) B
≠ B. Granted, the dog illustration introduced a (D) fourth element into it,
namely brownness: (1) A ⊂ C, (2) B ⊂ C, (3) A ≠ D, (4) B ≠ D. Therefore,
the illustration may be revamped so that it will more formally concur with
Edwards’ logic:
*
 Edwards has already slit the throat of his own argument by showing that works
of the law include moral law. One cannot retreat to a distinction between works
of the law and moral law to defend Edwards’ position.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                Page 157


       1.   A puppy is a four-legged animal.
       2.   A dog is a four-legged animal.
       3.   A puppy is not a dog.
       4.   Therefore, a dog arising from a puppy is not a dog.
        Now, the deduction is getting formally closer to Edwards’ logic (or
lack of it as the case may be). Like Edwards, I now have proven successfully
(tongue-in-cheek) that a dog is not a dog, just as Edwards have proven that
work is not work. To speak analogously in terms of corresponding
statements in the comparisons, these affirmations may be paired: (1&2) just
as faith and good works are acts of Christian obedience, so puppies and dogs
are four-legged creatures; (3) just as faith is not a work, so a puppy is not a
dog; and (4) just as good works arising from faith are not works, so dogs
arising from puppies are not dogs. I now formally deduce that Edwards’
logic has gone to the dogs.93

       Rewards
       Contrary to Edwards, just because some acts of Christian obedience
are not works, this does not prove that no acts of Christian obedience are
works. Saving faith results in a gift; persevering faith-works result in a
reward. Therefore, the latter is regarded as a work in the Bible whereas the
former is not. Saving faith, then, is a response of Christian obedience, but it
is not a work. From the perspective of outcome, in terms of gift versus
reward, nothing we do that results in a gift is work (Eph 2:8-9). Conversely,
everything we do that results in a reward is a work (Rom 4:4).
                        Illustration 49. Faith ∩ Works

                                  wor k
                         ai t h
                    f




        Whereas Edwards argues that works ⊂ faith, I contend instead
that faith ∩ works. There is an intersection of our faith and postconversion
works. Since Christian works are subsequent expressions of saving faith and
grow out of persevering faith, such works are not a part of initial faith but
rather are added to postconversion faith. As a result, the affirmation is
Page 158                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
obvious: Works are a part of faith-works (i.e., works ⊂ faith-works).
Consequently, perseverance in faith has congruent merit so that one cannot
condition entrance into heaven on perseverance in faith without turning
heaven into a reward, thereby, falsifying one’s claim that heaven is not a
reward based upon our meritorious work.*

       Moral Fitness
       Misthologists should become keenly interested when Edwards starts
talking about rewards and should agree considerably with his prefacing
remark that all the value of our rewards are “secondary and derivative” since
the virtue of our actions are derived from “Christ’s righteousness and
worthiness.” Edwards even affirms misthological moral fitness: “Worthiness
does doubtless denote a moral fitness to the reward” in being worthy of
walking with Christ in white in Rev 3:4 and being worthy of the resurrection
Lk 20:35.94

             From the value God sets upon their persons, for the sake
       of Christ’s worthiness, he also sets a high value on their
       virtue and performances. Their meek and quiet spirit is of
       great price in his sight.…This preciousness or high
       valuableness of believers is a moral fitness to a reward. Yet
       this valuableness is all in the righteousness of Christ, that is the
       foundation of it. 95

       Believers are morally fit to receive a reward and have God set a high
value on their virtue because Christ is the foundation from which the value
of their works is derived. Such texts do, in fact, describe our derivative
moral fitness to participate in the reward. This aspect of Edwards’
misthology is quite good.

       Heaven is a Reward
       On the other hand, Edwards’ misthology is fraught with
soteriologically contamination resulting in damnation. One must be careful
to discern when Edwards switches to speaking wrongly out of the other side
of his mouth.

       According to Edwards, heaven itself is a reward in a secondary and
derivative sense, given to us by God in response for our good works: “Not
only higher degrees of glory in heaven, but heaven itself, is in some respect
given in reward for the holiness and good works of the saints, in this
secondary and derivative sense.”96 In this manner, Edwards attempts to turn
the gift of heaven into a reward for our good works. He is no better than the
Arminians whom he criticizes. Shank, a rank Arminian, asserts much the
same thing as Edwards:

         Just as the acceptance of the gift is costly…so is the retention
         of that gift, once received. There is therefore a sense in which
         eternal life, though God’s gracious gift to undeserving men,
         is yet a reward to those who faithfully endure as Christ’s
         overcomers.97

       Such feeble aberrations, which claim that the gift of eternal life is a
reward which costs us, must be considered a fatal distortion from the pit of
hell. Yet people have heard this lie so often and from so many sources that
they accept it today with unthinking alliance. Popular expressions of this
accursed theology can be heard on any given Sunday in churches across
America, making such contradictory statements as this one: “Heaven is free
but costs you everything.”* Television commercials saying, “Buy one get
one free,” have more intellectual integrity than many of our pastors who
claim that you are not saved by works but that you have to turn from your

    See Illustration 118. False Teachers in Mt 7:16-20, 299.
Page 160                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
sins in order to be saved. Truth in advertising would be appreciated. Truth
from pulpits should be demanded.
        In the secular arena, if you have to buy one to get the second one free,
then the second one was not really free. You simply are being offered a 50%
discount. In the same way, a turn-or-burn offer of eternal life is not a
genuine offer of eternal life as a free gift. Such an invitation bases your
reception of eternal life on you changing your performance. Such offers are
nothing less than performance-based invitations to works-righteousness.
Many pastors today tend to be no different than Edwards in his day. They
say you are saved by faith alone, but they do not really believe it, even
though they think they do. Not everyone who claims to be saved by faith
alone really believes that they are saved by faith alone. Finding pastors who
actually believe what they say can be like going on a treasure hunt. They are
hard to find. Just because a preacher like Edwards thinks that he believes in
justification by faith alone does not mean that he actually believes in
justification by faith alone. He nullifies his own profession of faith with his
necessitation of works.

        Edwards’ opening section provides a statement that would be
welcome in Free Grace theology: “Believing on God as a justifier, certainly
is a different thing from submitting to God as a lawgiver” (emphasis his).98
Unfortunately, Edwards will later denounce his own understanding of saving
faith when he makes moral submission to the lawgiver in the form of
repentance a theological necessity to reach heaven. According to Edwards’
subsequent statements, believing in Jesus as justifier necessarily includes
submitting to Jesus as lawgiver in terms of changing one’s performance.
        Edwards’ theological doubletalk is a highly accomplished art form
found in many theological circles in which a theologian or pastor refutes
himself by spouting contradictory statements out of both sides of his mouth
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                  Page 161
while those listening to him nod in hypnotic approval. Edwards is a highly

Edwards turning justifying faith into a virtue.

       Full Capacity
       Soteriological blindness is not the only thing plaguing our pastors.
Misthological blindness is just as prevalent. Only someone who is blinded to
the misthological import of numerous texts could subscribe to the popular
notion advocated by Edwards: “The saints are as so many vessels of
different sizes, cast into a sea of happiness, where every vessel is full.”99 Not
so. The popular saying still going around today that everyone will be
perfectly happy in heaven (like a cup filled to its capacity) is a lie from the
spawn of hell given to desensitize believers to the true importance of
Christian morality.100 The satanic strategy in spreading this lie is easy to spot
since such a lie has multiple demonic advantages.
       First, it desensitizes believers to the misthological importance of
living a good life, since such a teaching lowers the value that Scripture
places on rewards. Many believers will become lethargic, thinking that
rewards do not really matter. Second, as a result of this devalued perception
of rewards, some believers become very susceptible to trying to import, as
Edwards does, the misthological importance of living a good life into what
was supposed to be the exclusively soteriological arena of saving faith. This
Edwardsean importation results in a poisoned gospel. Those poisoned by this
importation then share this poisoned legalistic gospel with the lost, making it
difficult for the lost to respond savingly to the true gospel and making it easy
for Satan to sow tares in the church. Third, what proportionately few
genuine believers filter out enough poison actually to respond savingly to the
garbled gospel they hear are very susceptible to falling from grace into
legalism in trying to earn their way to heaven.

       Predetermined Capacity
       Dillow’s description of the Reformed notion of merit reveals Edwards
to be a hybrid:

             This Calvinistic reasoning is very complex, but it seems
       they are arguing like this: God in eternity past has purposed
       that some believers would have a greater reward than others.
       He therefore purposed that they would do more works in this
       life to “earn” them. He then enabled them to do the works
       which were consistent with the reward which He had already
       purposed. The reward was not based on works but on Christ’s
Page 162                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
         merit. God disposed these merits before anyone worked. They
         are therefore of grace.101

        Edwards tries to crawl back into his Reformed shell when discussing
the relationship between sovereign grace and the believer’s capacity. But his
affirmation of derivative moral fitness proves that he has based rewards on
derivative moral merit and, thereby, admitted the obvious connection
between reward and merit. Oh, to be sure, in accordance with his Reformed
perspective, Edwards believes that God has predestined who will believe and
has determined how much derivative moral merit each believer will accrue
and has sovereignly fixed it, in accordance with the predetermined capacities
for each believer, so that a believer cannot do otherwise. Yet despite being
linked ball-and-chain to such Reformed notions, to his credit Edwards does
believe that there is a connection between the believer’s reward and moral
fitness.
        Dare I describe this connection as merit? Yes! Even those
sympathetic to Edwards’ Reformed heritage (like Hunsinger and Logan)
acknowledge that Edwards advocates merit. Hunsinger criticizes him for it;
Logan uncritically praises him despite it.* With Dillow, I ascribe derivative
merit to our works and concur with Dillow that justification by faith-works
entails merit but justification by faith;works does not entail merit. It is
really that simple.

         Justification by Works
        The last objection Edwards mentions to his pretentious defense of
justification by faith alone deals with the double affirmation in James that
believers are justified by works: Abraham was justified by works, and Rahab
was justified by works (Jam 2:21,25). James expects us to “see then that a
man is justified by works and not only [monos] by faith” (Jam 2:24; TM).
Most people mistakenly think that James is denying justification by faith
alone or that James is talking about a different kind of faith than Paul, who
asserts: “A man is justified by faith apart from works” (Rom 3:28). Edwards
correctly affirms Paul’s statement and perceptively rejects the notion that
Paul is talking about a different kind of faith than James.

         First Base
      The basic options are to regard Paul and James as using either the
word faith or the word justify differently. Edwards rightly criticizes those
who take the former approach and who thus imagine Paul to “include all
saving Christian virtue and obedience” in faith.102 Granted, Edwards refutes

*
    See Logan’s Praise, 168.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                     Page 163
himself with this criticism in that he himself virtually imports virtue and
evangelical obedience into saving faith. Such self-condemnation aside for
the moment, Edwards is right to conclude that Paul and James are using the
word justify differently. With this discernment, Edwards makes it safely to
hermeneutical first base in interpreting this Jacobean passage.

       Second Base
        Many would think that Edwards even makes it successfully to second
base when he asserts that the distinction between the two aspects of
justification are to be found in regarding the Jacobean justification by works
as the evidence of the Pauline justification by faith. Some even within the
Free Grace camp would make such a distinction. They might even insist that
this justification only amounts to vindication before men.* So to be
charitable, for the moment Edwards will be allowed the benefit of the doubt
and pictured as sliding into second base by the skin of his hermeneutical
teeth and being ruled, by some fellow misthologists, as having reached
second base safely. Counter to intuition, the notion will be allowed, for the
sake of present discussion, to go unchallenged that James is conceiving of
justification by works as a declarative justification before men.

       Third Base
        As Edwards approaches third base, there are two ways to safely
proceed: Edwards can affirm that James is either talking about temporal
justification or about misthological justification in distinction to Paul’s
soteriological justification. But Edwards never rounds third base. Instead, he
pulls a hermeneutical hamstring as he tries to reach third base and is called
out easily by the third-base umpire. Even though some in the Reformed
camp, such as Logan, try to help Edwards limp along to third base with a
discussion of causation, the strain of his argument is apparent.

       Causation
        Admittedly, regarding Edwards’ discussion of the twofold nature of
justification, an examination of causation would seem fitting since according
to Edwards,

  For interaction with Free Grace writers adopting the before-men interpretation,
