        Logan correctly understands Edwards as making a distinction
between James’ manifestative justification and causal justification.
Argumentation, at present, with the second-base umpire as to whether or not
Edwards is correct in making this distinction, is unnecessary. Also, at the
moment, no quarrel with Logan about the potential differentiation between
cause and condition will be pursued when he says: “The fact that a certain
reality is not a cause does not mean, however, that it may not be a condition.
Very simply, all causes are conditions but not all conditions are causes.”104
Whether or not this distinction between cause and condition holds true in the
present case, weaknesses will be apparent in Logan’s defense of Edwards.
According to Logan, Edwards purposely avoids using the Aristotelian
delineation of causation so that he might limit causation solely to God.105
Consequently, Edwards is discontent with regarding faith as the instrumental
cause.106 More simply and sovereignly, according to Logan,

            Strictly speaking, even here the “cause” remains the
       sovereign grace of God. As Edwards points out in Freedom of
       Will and Religious Affections, man’s will acts in accord with its
       “disposition,” and a “gracious disposition” can come only from
       the operations of the Spirit. Thus, the Holy Spirit causes an
       individual’s evangelical obedience, but this does not diminish
                                                                    107
       the meritoriousness of that obedience one bit. (Italics his.)

       Such an affirmation of Calvinistic compatibilism comes as no
surprise since Edwards’ is historically perceived as attacking the freewill
Arminianism that was creeping into his parish. Still, it is refreshing to find
Logan practically admitting that this monergistic compatibilism introduces
synergistic merit so that a believer is saved from hell on the basis of his
merit. Naturally, the proposition by Logan and Edwards that one merits
heaven is rejected herein; nevertheless, it is refreshing when such opponents
of Free Grace theology openly admit what I have been endeavoring to prove:
that Edwards believes that one gets into heaven by virtue of his virtual merit.
As Logan surmises yet again: “Because of the nature of evangelical
obedience in the life of one who already stands in Christ, reward, merit, and
blessing all are appropriate and meet for that person.”108 Logan is making
explicit what Edwards made implicit: Evangelical obedience (and thus
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                               Page 165
saving faith) is a meritorious virtue in Edwardseanism, as has been noted
already by Hunsinger. To those who have eyes to see, it should be apparent
from such admissions by Logan that Edwards is trying to merit heaven and
can only earn hell in the process. Meritorious compatibilism is thus proposed
by Edwards in response to Arminianism.

       Arminians
        Logan expresses this dilemma in terms of causation: “In his sermons
on justification, Edwards seeks to answer both Arminianism and
antinomianism. To the former, he affirms that God’s grace alone causes
justification, that not even faith plays a causal role” (emphasis his).109 The
opposing view is pictured similarly:

            But causes are not the only conditions. Faith is the
       preeminent noncausal condition of justification, and, to the
       antinomians among his hearers, Edwards proclaims that there
       are other conditions also. Justification is conditioned upon
                         110
       obedience as well.

       Conditionalism (as found in both Arminianism and Calvinism)
teaches that faith-works are necessary to enter heaven. Edwards strains at a
gnat only to swallow a camel when he criticizes Arminians in his midst who
may affirm that believers are justified by merit. Edwards affirms the same
position; he only derives it differently. For Edwards, works are perceived as
“justifying as an evidence” (emphasis his). They are the “necessary
manifestation and evidence of faith.” Or to clarify Logan’s summation,
Edwards is advocating a necessary manifestative justification as opposed to
a causal justification. Using a courtroom analogy to illustrate, one might
express Edwards’ point of view this way: The evidence presented by your
defense attorney does not make (cause) you to be innocent, but it is
necessary to prove that you are innocent so that the judge will declare you to
be innocent. According to Edwards, God knows whether or not you are
innocent, but God will base His declaration on the evidence of that fact.
Edwards believes James is trying to refute an antinomian notion that would
claim that “good works were not necessary to salvation” from eternal
damnation.111 Edwards insists that good works are necessary to obtain final
salvation and escape eternal damnation:

            Man’s salvation is not only indissolubly connected with
       [evangelical] obedience, and damnation with the want of it, in
       those who have opportunity for it, but depends upon it
       [evangelical obedience] in many respects. It [evangelical
       obedience] is the way to salvation, and the necessary
       preparation for it. Eternal blessings are bestowed in reward for
Page 166                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       it [evangelical obedience], and our justification in our own
       consciences and at the day of judgment depends on it
       [evangelical obedience], as the proper evidence of our
       acceptable state; and that even in accepting of us as entitled to
       life in our justification, God has respect to this, as that on
       which the fitness of such an act of justification depends: so that
       our salvation does as truly depend upon it [evangelical
       obedience], as if we were justified for the moral excellency of
       it [evangelical obedience]. (Italics his.)112

        In Edwards’ final analysis, good works are necessary to reach heaven,
and entrance into heaven is a reward obtained by the derivative merit
embedded in our good works. Salvation and damnation hang in the balance,
and the outcome truly depends on the evidence derived from the believer’s
good works in the form of evangelical obedience. Pauline justification by
faith alone apart from works will not work in Edwardseanism because
justification by faith, apart from works, falls short of getting a believer to
heaven unless one imports virtually the believer’s works into saving faith.
Simply put, Edwards does not believe in final justification by faith alone
because (in his opinion) initial justification does not suffice for final
justification. In the final analysis, the Edwardsean justification which allows
a believer into heaven is by faith and works.

       Antinomians
       A word needs to be said regarding the historical backdrop as to what
constituted the libelous antinomianism that Edwards was seeking to refute.
As Logan points out, Anne Hutchinson had been excommunicated because
of her antinomianism which consisted of teaching that (1) the Holy Spirit
indwells justified believers, and (2) that “no sanctification can help us to
                                  113
evidence to us our justification.”    In other words, those accused of being
antinomians were those people who based their assurance on the presence of
the Holy Spirit within them rather than on their works. If that is what
constitutes antinomianism, then it is certainly superior to the legalism of
Arminianism and Calvinism, which conditions salvation and assurance on
works!
       If the works of one’s sanctification do not provide the believer with
the assurance of the Holy Spirit’s presence, then what does? How does one
know that the Holy Spirit dwells within him or her? L.E. Brown traces the
rudimentary elements of the Free Grace movement back to the Antinomian
Controversy that broke out in colonial America with the trials of Anne
Hutchinson. Citing Hall and Winship, Brown demonstrates (as has been
pointed out already by other Free Grace writers) that this controversy can be
called appropriately the Free Grace Controversy.114 Indeed, Makidon
surmises that the reason Hutchinson “was banished along with Roger
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                               Page 167
Williams from the Massachusetts Bay Colony [was] for antinomian
beliefs—believing that salvation is by faith alone in Christ alone.”115
Antinomianism is thus defined by Brown from the context of this historical
backdrop as “believing that salvation is by faith alone in Christ alone.” The
contemporary motto for Free Grace theology is faith alone in Christ alone.
Accordingly, Brown appropriately entitles his article: Colonial America’s
Rejection of Free Grace Theology.
        To introduce some of the key players in that controversy, John
Cotton abandoned his earlier views on assurance, in which he had based his
assurance on his works. Instead, he came to base his assurance on the
subjective witness of the Spirit. While it might seem intuitive to base one’s
assurance of having the Spirit on the direct (i.e., immediate) witness of the
Spirit to one’s heart, basing one’s assurance on one’s feelings may be
nothing more than emotional intuition and is certainly prone to erroneous
presumption. Still, Cotton’s subjective approach is better than basing one’s
assurance on one’s purportedly objective works. Faith is assurance. An
assurance of salvation based on works would be tantamount to faith in works
for salvation. The problem with works-based assurance is not limited to its
prevalent tendency to corrupt the gospel soteriologically. Additionally, since
no one knows exactly which works or how much work qualifies the believer
for absolute assurance, even basing assurance on supposedly objective
works is subjective. Anne Hutchinson followed Cotton’s transition away
from assurance based on works: “She realized that in searching for assurance
in her works she had turned away from grace” but even more importantly, as
Brown continues, “she determined that assurance rests solely upon God’s
promise.”116 More astutely than Cotton, Anne Hutchinson based the
assurance of the Spirit’s presence in our heart on the Spirit’s objective
witness to us in His written word. As Brown attests, John Wheelwright, a
pastor who was Anne’s brother-in-law, likewise “denounced those who
turned first to their own works rather than to Christ, or who seek comfort in
their fruits of their sanctification rather than in God’s promises.”117 The
nature of assurance was the issue at the heart of the Antinomian
Controversy.118
        Hutchinson and Wheelwright were expelled for their belief that God’s
word suffices for assurance. They were forced to leave because they
correctly deduced that since the condition for salvation is faith alone in
Christ’s promises of eternal life, believers could conclude that they have
eternal life and justification on the strength of those promises alone.
Historically, antinomianism is fundamentally the teaching that one’s
assurance of justification is to be found solely in the objective promises of
the Scripture, not in the subjective nature of one’s works or emotions. Since
justification is by faith alone, antinomians reasoned that those who believed
that they had been justified on the basis of faith alone could know for sure
that they were justified. This justification-by-faith-alone theology is what
Page 168                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
those like Edwards were seeking to refute. Let there be no mistake. What is
at stake is justification by faith alone, and Edwards does not believe in
justification by faith alone.

         Logan’s Praise
        Despite Edwards’ clear departure from the doctrine of justification by
faith alone, Logan rallies to Edwards’ defense with a full endorsement:

              Clearly, Edwards has correctly presented the fundamental
         biblical teaching on justification by faith alone. The crucial
         Edwardsean distinction between cause and condition is there in
         the sense of the biblical message even if the terms themselves
         are not used in exactly the way Edwards employs them.119

To the contrary, it is by no means clear that Edwards has correctly
elucidated the biblical teaching of justification by faith alone. Logan’s
implementation of smoke and mirrors between cause and condition does not
improve one’s perception that Edwards’ argumentation is the work of a
magician rather than a logician. According to historical accounts, the true
defenders of justification by faith alone had already left the building, having
been slanderously excommunicated as antinomians. Those left behind were
not the true defenders of the faith. Rather, they were Calvinists who had
denied justification by faith alone in a manner similar to that implemented
within Catholicism. These Calvinists were nothing more than fake
impersonators of the biblical doctrine of justification by faith alone. Even
Hunsinger notes that Edwardseanism smacks of the Thomism within
Catholicism. And Logan does not hesitate to affirm that Edwards’
“evangelical obedience might also be said to be a condition of
               120
justification.”    Logan quotes the statement that believers are created for
good works (Eph 2:10) as an example of proving that believers are saved by
good works and concludes: “Evangelical obedience is an absolute
                                                     121
necessity, a ‘condition’ in man’s justification.”         The fuller quote of
                                                  *
Logan’s summation has been provided above, in which he stated: “The
Holy Spirit causes an individual’s evangelical obedience, but this does not
                                                           122
diminish the meritoriousness of that obedience one bit.”
                          Illustration 52. Logan’s Summation
1.    Evangelical obedience is meritorious.
2.    Evangelical obedience is an absolute necessary condition for justification.
3.    Justification is conditioned on meritorious evangelical obedience.


*
    See Causation, 163.
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                  Page 169
So here we have it, directly from a Calvinist’s mouth: Good works (in the
form of meritorious evangelical obedience) are an absolute necessity for
man to reach heaven, and this summation means that good works are nothing
less than a condition for justification. In Calvinism, good works are not
merely descriptive of what a believer should do; good works are prescriptive
as to what a believer must do in order to reach heaven. Such a perspective
stance stands self-condemned to anyone who seriously contemplates the
context of that biblical statement: “For by grace you have been saved
through faith; and that not of yourselves, it is the gift of God; not as a result
of works, that no one should boast” (Eph 2:8-9). According to the Bible,
such salvation is not a result of good works. Consequently, good works are
not a condition for reaching heaven, contrary to Edwardseanism.
        As has been demonstrated, in the Reformed thought as represented by
Edwards and confirmed as representative of Reformed thought in general by
Logan, evangelical obedience (i.e., good works) is a condition for final
justification because this postconversional obedience is the necessary result
of initial justification:

            Edwards thus considers evangelical obedience a result
       (a “sign”) of the Spirit’s work and not at all a cause of that
       work. Along this line, he interprets James as describing
       “manifestative justification” and not “causal justification.”123

       Of course, postconversional works are not a cause of the Spirit’s
work. No one is claiming that postconversion work causes conversion. This
red herring defense by Logan is nothing but a ruse to throw us off the trail in
following the logical implications of the joint admission by Logan and
Edwards that in Reformed thought justification is conditioned on meritorious
evangelical obedience. The problem is that that Edwards has made
postconversional work (in the form of evangelical obedience) the necessary
result of initial justification and the condition for final justification. If one
simply combines Logan’s remarks above regarding the nature of evangelical
obedience in Edwardseanism syllogistically, the duality becomes apparent:
                     Illustration 53. Condition and Result
    1. Evangelical obedience is a condition for justification.
    2. Evangelical obedience is a result of justification.
    3. Therefore, evangelical obedience is both the condition for and the
       result of justification.

How can evangelical obedience (i.e., good works) be both the condition for
and result of justification? Hopefully, by now, the answer is apparent.
Because of the importance of the issue, however, making the answer to this
question unmistakable would be advisable. If one were to express the logical
Page 170                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
sequential relationship symbolically,* one might initially think that
Reformed thought is being so foolish as to suggest this simplistic sequence:
            Illustration 54. Mistaken Assessment of Reformed Thought
    Good works (as a condition) ⇒ justification ⇒ good works (as a result).

        Such a sequence obviously would be faulty both logically and
biblically in making good works both the condition for and result of
justification. It would be like claiming that a chicken can give birth to itself
in that good works are mistakenly thought to produce the justification which
produces the good works which produced it. Doing so would be tantamount
to trying to answer the proverbial question, Which came first, the chicken or
the egg? and claiming that the chicken came first, then the egg, then the
original chicken who laid that egg.
          Illustration 55. Mistaken Assessment of Chicken-Egg Sequence
                           Chicken ⇒ egg ⇒ Chicken

         Obviously, a chicken cannot lay an egg that hatches to give birth to
the same chicken that originally laid the egg. In all actuality, however, the
Reformed argument is not making such a blatantly false statement. First of
all, stated in terms of this chicken analogy, the Reformed camp is talking
about two different chickens. And, of course, the chicken riddle is answered
easily if one is talking about two different chickens. God created the first
generational chicken that created the first egg which in turn resulted in the
second generational chicken.
          Illustration 56. Correct Assessment of Chicken-Egg Sequence
                    First Chicken ⇒ egg ⇒ Second Chicken




*
    The symbol ⇒ represents a conditional statement: if A then B (A ⇒ B).
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                    Page 171


The first chicken lays the egg from which the second chicken hatches. The
first chicken results in the egg, and the egg results in the second chicken.
The second chicken necessarily results from the first chicken via the egg.
           Illustration 57. Actual Assessment of Reformed Thought
       Initial justification ⇒ good works ⇒ final justification.

        In Edwardseanism, good works are not the initial cause for
conversion; rather, they are a postconversional event. Or stated in terms of
the chicken analogy, good works are not the initial chicken; rather,
justification is the initial chicken so to speak. Initial justification necessarily
results in good works, and these good works are the necessary condition for
final justification. Final justification is thus conditioned on the manifestation
of good works flowing from our initial justification, and this initial
justification was by faith alone. So while it might be true that good works
are not the cause of our initial justification in Reformed theology, good
works certainly would be the cause for our final justification. Good works
are the golden egg from which one’s final justification springs in Reformed
thought. Therefore, the Edwardsean distinction between cause and condition
appears to be nothing more than a smokescreen to conceal the fact that in
Reformed thought good works are just as much a causal condition for final
justification as faith is a causal condition for initial justification.
        For Logan, Edwards, and Lewis, salvation from eternal damnation is
the result of good works. For Paul, it is not. Hodges destroys Logan’s
defense of Edwards in one fell swoop:

             In Reformed thought good works are a condition for
       salvation. A deft Reformed thinker, Samuel Logan, might add
       that good works are not a cause of salvation, while faith is both
       a cause and a condition for this. But the bottom line is that, for
       Reformed Theology, there are two conditions for final
       salvation—faith and works! (Emphasis his.)124

       Conclusion
        Some Reformed thinkers criticize Edwards; some Reformed thinkers
praise him. When it comes to the bottom line, criticism is just; praise is not.
But criticism of Edwards should not result automatically in praise for his
critics. Those within the Reformed camp who balk at Edwards do not
necessarily do any better than Edwards in explaining the relationship
between faith and works. As Hunsinger insinuated, as Dillow explicated, and
as Hodges annunciated, those in the Reformed camp who deny that merit is
involved in reaching heaven nevertheless condition reaching heaven upon
works. They simply deny (or ignore) the merit imbedded within such works.
Page 172                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Although I strongly disagree with Lewis and Edwards, since I reject
the notion that believers merit heaven by means of their virtuous faith, I do
appreciate the fact that these two writers acknowledge the virtuous nature of
the believer’s persevering faith. Lewis and Edwards deserve praise for doing
so. I cannot praise them for their bottom line—making heaven a reward—
but I can praise them for admitting that perseverance in faith is virtuous and
therefore meritorious. They stand a cut above many of their critics in that
both Lewis and Edwards are willing (to a considerable degree) to honestly
face up to the fact that they are conditioning their salvation on their virtuous
merit. Their mistake is simply in thinking that such salvation must be
soteriological. Such an error is deadly to be sure, but at least it does not
compound the problem by camouflaging works as being nonmeritorious. To
those who, like Lewis and Edwards, would ascribe merit to works, I say a
hearty, “Amen!”
        Edwards may be further commended for correctly concluding that
when James talks about justification by works, James is referring to a
different type of justification than when Paul is dealing with justification by
faith. Edwards is also correct in his assessment that this Jacobean
justification by works is secondary in terms of sequence. He is also on the
right track when he notes that this secondary justification is based upon the
works that are manifested as a result of our primary justification. And he
does well to admit the meritorious nature of this derivative justification. His
transition into error comes when he makes this secondary justification a
manifestative justification that determines whether one has experienced a
causal justification. Logically, if our works determine whether or not we are
saved, then our works will determine whether or not we will be saved.
Therefore, it comes as no surprise that Edwards reaches this conclusion
exegetically, since his mistaken protasis forms his premise. Contrary to
Edwards, I do not believe that James is talking about salvation from hell, and
thus I do not find James asserting that good works determine whether or not
believers are saved from hell or have experienced Pauline justification by
faith. Accordingly, this secondary justification is not a manifestation of
whether or not believers have experienced initial justification. While initial
justification makes secondary justification possible, initial justification by
faith in no way assures subsequent justification by works. Since this
secondary justification is by works, Edwards should have concluded that this
secondary justification is misthological rather than soteriological.
        Misthologists will limit the eschatological value of meritorious works
to rewards, even if they have to put up with slanderously being called
antinomians in the process. After all, nomians (whether they are found in
Arminianism, Catholicism, Edwardseanism, or Calvinism) insist on making
the way one lives a condition for reaching heaven. Whether or not nomians
have Edward’s candid intellectual honesty to admit the judicial nature of this
evidence or to acknowledge the conditional nature of this performance is
Chapter 2. Virtuous and Virtual Faith                                  Page 173
beside the point. By making works necessary for final justification, nomians
logically are conditioning entrance into heaven on postconversional works.
Nomians are conditional securitists, and conditional securitists are nomians.
They simply quibble among themselves as to which form of the law (ML,
OT, NT, Law of Christ, etc) and how much of the law one must keep in
order to be allowed into heaven. Naturally, nomians will libel unconditional
security as antinomianism since it is opposed to their nomianism.*
Frequently, being called an antinomian only means that the one being
labeled in this derogatory manner is simply an advocate of unconditional
security. Of course, unconditional securitists are not antinomians in any
theologically licentious sense of the word if they are simultaneously
misthologists because misthologists simultaneously affirm conditional
misthological security.†




       *
          Nomian is a coined expression from the Greek word nomos (law) and
refers to legalists who believe that soteriological salvation is conditioned on
performance. Antinomian is derived from anti+nomos (anti-law) and refers to
those who are against the law. They are also known as libertines—those
liberated from the law. Legalists love to charge non-legalists with being
antinomians (i.e. teachers of lawlessness). Since Paul was a non-legalist, he was
reported slanderously as saying, “Let us do evil that good may come” (Rom
3:8). This defamatory trend still survives today. Some so-called Lordship
Salvationists calumniously say that those who teach free grace are teaching that
the way a person lives does not matter. This would be true only if rewards do
not matter. Perhaps this is the background for some of the criticism. So-called
Lordship Salvationists can appeal to the popular sentiment that rewards do not
matter. For many, the only thing that matters is heaven versus hell. So if you
stress that the doctrine of heavenly rewards provides a compelling reason to live
a good life, then you have said (from their perspective) that the way you live
does not matter. Nevertheless, biblical Christianity will remain a balance
between legalistic and libertarian extremists.
†
  Free Grace writers would be better described historically as Marrowists or
doctrinally as Misthologists or rather than derogatorily as antinomians. Broadly
speaking, modern-day Marrowists will be presumed to be misthologists in the
present writing and thus holding to a strong view of rewards in general and to a
misthological view of the outer darkness in particular. Those Free Grace writers
not holding to a misthological view of the outer darkness may properly be
regarded as Free Grace soteriologists, but their misthology is too dysfunctional
to regard them as true modern-day Marrowists.
                                                           Page 174




It is not enough just to kill one form of soteric merit!
                                                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
              Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit
         Introduction
        Not all those in the Reformed camp have the moral virtue necessary
to admit that works are meritorious, much less that perseverance is virtuous.
As seen in the first two chapters, Lewis and Edwards are refreshing
exceptions to this rule. At least Lewis and Edwards realize, to a considerable
degree, that they are conditioning their entrance into heaven on their virtue.
That is a far more honest approach than that taken by Reformers who
condition their entrance on their virtue but who then turn around and deny
that this is, in fact, what they are doing.

         Summation
        Lewis evidently intends to limit merit to postconversional
performance with his descriptive treatment of repentance. Nevertheless, he
reads performance back into initial faith and thereby frontloads the gospel.
Like most Arminians, he fails to thoroughly distinguish between rewards in
heaven and the gift of heaven and ends up making heaven a reward despite
his attempt to do otherwise.
                           Illustration 58. Merit and Works
            Arminianism Catholicism        Marrowism       Edwardseanism      Calvinism
             Subsequent       Half              No           Derivative          No
 Merit
            Soteric Merit Soteric Merit    Soteric Merit    Soteric Merit       Merit
Frontload      Works         Works          No Works           Works            Works

Backload       Works         Works          No Works           Works            Works
Heaven       Meritorious   Meritorious    Nonmeritorious     Meritorious     Meritorious
Rewards      Meritorious   Meritorious     Meritorious       Meritorious    Nonmeritorious


        Catholics are correct to ascribe merit to rewards. Where they err is in
regarding this virtue as soteriological merit.125 Calvin and his cronies err in
denying merit altogether and in then conditioning entrance into heaven on
supposedly meritless works. Catholicism is criticized by Protestants as
teaching a meritorious entrance into heaven, thereby making a reward of
heaven. Granted, this Protestant criticism is justified, but, for the most part,
it is only an example of the pot calling the kettle black since those in the
Reformed camp are just as inclined to condition entrance into heaven on
moral reform. Edwardseanism is certainly no exception to this rule.
Page 176                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
              Illustration 59. Marrowism versus Antinomianism




        Biblical antinomianism (otherwise known as unconditional security)
would be better described in today’s theological climate as Marrowism since
this latter term is tied strongly herein to the complementary biblical
accentuation on the importance of good works as necessary for eternal
rewards. Although some substandard free grace advocates apparently are
antinomian in that they downplay the negative impact of an antinomian (i.e.,
lawless) lifestyle, Marrowism is opposed diametrically to licentious behavior
in that the present book stresses the three-dimensional importance of a moral
lifestyle. In order to avoid hurting oneself, others, and God, one must submit
to the moral will of God as expressed by the eternal will of God. Those
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                        Page 177
believers who succumb to immorality not only hurt themselves temporally,
they will also hurt themselves eschatologically. They will be repaid
misthologically, by God, for the wrong they have done (Col 3:25). Proper
Free Grace theology not only shares a historical continuity with its
forbearers in stressing that believers may have absolute assurance of their
soteriological security independent of their performance* but also evidences
a distinctive counterbalancing emphasis on the misthological necessity of
good works for heavenly rewards.
        Even though the present book falls within the sphere of denotative
antinomianism, as defined by Brown, in affirming that salvation from eternal
damnation is by faith alone in Christ alone apart from works, the present
book most certainly stands opposed to connotative antinomianism in that the
latter deemphasizes the misthological importance of living within the moral
will of God. Marrowism is opposed misthologically to connotative
antinomianism.
        As to the broader history of antinomianism, it is defined
connotatively by Linder with teaching “that it is not necessary for Christians
to preach and/or obey the moral law of the OT” (EDT). Two questions
should be posed immediately. First, are Christians still subject to the
underlying moral will of God? I would say so.† Therefore, Marrowism, as I
intend the term, is not to be confused with antinomianism. Second, what
kind of necessity is implied by EDT in order to avoid being called an
antinomian? Soteriological necessity? I hope not. If one makes good works
soteriologically necessary to enter heaven (as is done by many writers in
Calvinism, Arminianism, and Calminianism), then one is a nomian.
Marrowism is opposed to nomianism. If antinomianism is defined narrowly
as being opposed to nomianism, then the present work is, of course,
antinomian. Undoubtedly, many within Calvinism, Arminianism, and
Calminianism will lift their voices in unison in criticizing the present writing
as being antinomian, just as they do so in slanderously denouncing other
Free Grace writers who defend unconditional security. However, equally
apparent, antinomianism generally is associated with more than just denying
that good works are soteriologically necessary. Hence, the present book, in
particular, and proper Free Grace writings, in general, cannot be considered
antinomian in that they do not deny that obeying the moral will of God is
necessary either for practical sanctification or for misthological co-
glorification. Rewards count in Marrowism. Therefore, Marrowism cannot
be counted as antinomianism.

*
 See Antinomians, 166.

  See discussion of principlism in “Fulfilling the Law and the Prophets.”

         Marrowism is pictured in the chart as being inversely related to
Calvinism in the rows pertaining to heaven and rewards. Unconditional
security does not condition entrance into heaven on works, thereby
preserving a nonmeritorious soteriological entrance. In contrast, because
conditional security (even of the Calvinistic variety) conditions entrance into
heaven on the performance of perseverance, Calvinism (as well as other
forms of conditional security) must be marked as opposing unconditional
security, thus teaching a meritorious entrance into heaven.
         Without a doubt, many in the Reformed camp will try to elude such a
deduction. Dillow, as noted above, has already well summarized the typical
evasive maneuvers used by Reformed thinkers, but the momentum of their
argument easily pushes them through any guardrails they may erect seeking
to oppose such a conclusion. Nevertheless, the sound of their skidding tires
as they head toward the cliff of works-righteousness has not been ignored on
the chart. In accordance with Calvinistic claims, the chart acknowledges that
Calvinists do not believe rewards are based on merit and avow that there is
no merit in their system. Therefore, the corresponding row in the Calvinistic
column pertaining to heaven has been marked according to logical deduction
(i.e., as meritorious), but rewards have been marked according to Calvinistic
perception (i.e., as nonmeritorious), and their system as a whole has been
marked from their mistaken self-perception as not having merit in the first
row.

       MacArthur
       MacArthur may be used as a popular contemporary spokesperson for
the Reformed perspective to demonstrate how such a theology inevitably
makes heaven a meritorious reward even when its advocates deny that there
is any merit in rewards.

       Merit
        MacArthur criticizes Hodges for regarding “postsalvation works as
meritorious.”126 According to MacArthur’s Faith Works: “No one who
properly interprets Scripture would ever propose that human effort or
fleshly works can be meritorious—worthy of honor or reward from God”
(italics his).127 MacArthur’s objection to fleshly works is just a red herring
that he uses to detract from the fact that he is denying that human effort,
synergistically energized by the Holy Spirit, is honorable and rewardable.
Hodges is not saying that God is going to reward fleshly works with
heavenly rewards. Fleshly works are not the issue. As a misthologist,
Hodges believes that postconversion works wrought by the energizing power
of the Holy Spirit incur derivative merit. It suffices at this point to let Logan
and Edwards, MacArthur’s own fellow Reformers, debunk MacArthur’s
junk in their affirmation of merit in moral virtue.
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                       Page 179
        Of course, MacArthur wants to deny that there is merit in our
postconversional work so that he can condition entrance into heaven on
these works without being accused of teaching that heaven is merited as a
reward. Therefore, it is crucial to his argument that he deny that works entail
merit: “A crucial point must be made here. The works described in Hebrews
11 are faith works. These are not fleshly efforts to earn God’s favor. The
works described here are in no sense meritorious” (emphasis his).128
Contrary to MacArthur, faith-works certainly involve merit. Edwards
criticizes those who claim that such works do not include merit:

       It seems to be allowed by the divines in the Arminian scheme,
       in their interpretation of several of those texts where the
       apostle only mentions works, without any addition, that he
       means our own good works in general. But then, they say, he
       only means to exclude any proper merit in those works. But
       to say the apostle means one thing when he says, we are not
       justified by works, and another when he says, we are not
       justified by the works of the law, when we find the expressions
       mixed and used in the same discourse, and when the apostle is
       evidently upon the same argument, is very unreasonable. It is
       to dodge and fly from Scripture, rather than open and yield
       ourselves to its teachings.129

        Edwards is justified to criticize Arminians who claim that when Paul
insists that we are not justified by works, Paul really only means to exclude
merit rather than works. To be fair to Arminians, however, Edwards’
criticism should be applied with equal force to Edwards’ fellow Calvinists,
like MacArthur, who likewise try to claim that faith-works do not entail
merit. Constable hits the nail on the head when he rebukes MacArthur for
trying to make a false dichotomy between works and merit:

             Another answer that some who hold these views give is
       that what the Bible affirms is that man cannot merit eternal
       life. This is not the same, they say, as doing something
       necessary to obtain it such as submitting or remaining faithful.
       Yet the Bible uses the word ‘works,’ not just merit.”130

       The reason Paul excludes work is because work includes merit. One
might be able to take the caffeine out of coffee, but no one can take the merit
out of work—not even MacArthur. Works result in rewards because works
have inherent merit. Edwards and Logan recognize that moral virtue
necessarily involves merit. MacArthur refuses to acknowledge the obvious.
Rewards are based on our derivative moral merit. Such merit is inherent in
our works. Believers’ good works incur positive merit because of the union
Page 180                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
believers have with Christ and because of the internal power believers utilize
from the Holy Spirit (who dwells in them) flowing from their regenerate
nature in producing those good works so that they derive derivative merit.
Yes, antinomians (as Free Grace writers are slanderously called) believe that
the Holy Spirit actually dwells within them and has sealed them
unconditionally for and until the day of redemption* and thereby enables
them to earn heavenly rewards.

      Condition
        According to MacArthur’s Faith Works, on the other hand, “God
didn’t save us apart from faith, and He doesn’t keep us apart from
faith.”131 In other words, MacArthur teaches that the condition for our
retention of regeneration is our perseverance in faith: “God’s own holiness
thus requires that we persevere. ‘God’s grace insures our persevering—but
this does not make it any less our persevering’” (emphasis his).132
MacArthur is certainly correct to insist that it is our persevering, requiring
our full cooperation: “We are not passive in the process. The means by
which God maintains our faith involves our full participation.”133
MacArthur’s affirmation of our synergistic cooperation is appreciated, even
if granted unwittingly. The tragedy is that he bases our security on such
synergistic performance. MacArthur makes our performance the means
by which God keeps us saved from hell. According to MacArthur, God
requires our perseverance, and God will not keep us if we do not
persevere. Clearly, perseverance is a condition for reaching heaven in
MacArthurian theology. MacArthur is a conditional securitist. Hodges is
only pointing out the obvious when he calls MacArthur’s condition to our
attention.
        Yet MacArthur seeks to acquit himself of the accusation that his
soteriology teaches that faith-works are a condition to reach heaven’s glory:
“To say that works are a necessary result of faith is not the same thing as
making works a condition for justification. Would he [Hodges] accept the
charge that he is making glorification a condition for justification!”
(MacArthur’s emphasis).134 MacArthur’s attempt to conceal his condition is
futile.† Those within his own camp already have acknowledged that the
evangelical obedience which comes as a result of saving faith is a necessary
condition to reach heaven.‡ Still, one needs only to read MacArthur to refute

  The author’s online treatment of being sealed by the Spirit is available at

MacArthur. He himself acknowledges that God requires perseverance from
us or God will not keep us. Logically, this means that perseverance is a
MacArthurian condition which we must meet if we want God to keep us.
        Evidently, MacArthur wants to mix apples and oranges (initial
justification with final justification to use Edwards’ terms) in hopes that his
readers will gloss over his statements and unwittingly accept them at face
value. Naturally, perseverance is not a condition for initial justification!
Faith-works are postconversional works! The question is not, “Are
postconversional works a condition for initial justification?” Of course not!
Rather, the question that MacArthur skirts around is, “Are his MacArthurian
faith-works a necessary condition for a final justification in terms of
reaching a home in heavenly glory?” Certainly faith-works are such a
condition in his Faith Works. Is MacArthur playing dumb so that he can pull
the wool over the eyes of his readers?
                      Illustration 60. MacArthur’s Hatchling




        To restate the situation from the perspective of the chicken
illustration, MacArthur is, in effect, pointing out that the egg of good works
is not required for the first generational chicken in hopes that no one will
notice that he has made his egg of good works the condition for the second
generational chicken.* MacArthur has laid an egg of good works from which
he hopes to hatch his hopes of reaching final justification and its
corresponding entrance into heaven. But no one biblically can hope to get to
heaven by placing their hope in this rotten egg in which good works are
considered the necessary intermediate link between initial and final

*
    See Illustration 56. Correct Assessment of Chicken-Egg Sequence, 170.
Page 182                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
soteriological justification. This mutational form of final justification cannot
qualify anyone for heaven.
        Advocates of unconditional security see the matter quite differently
than MacArthur. Good works are the natural (not inevitable) result of initial
justification. However, these good works are not soteriologically necessary
for our final soteriological justification. To the contrary, initial justification
is final justification—soteriologically speaking. When we become believers,
God pronounces His irrevocable verdict on our soteric standing. This verdict
is both immediate and final. Our soteriological standing is not contingent on
our perseverance. Believers are declared innocent—now and forever—the
moment they first come to faith, independent of their future perseverance in
faith. The Reformed chicken-egg-chicken distinction between initial and
final soteriological justification is impossible.

       Glorification
        As to MacArthur’s quip about glorification, it only indicates that
postconversional works are no more a condition for the initial justification
(which made such works possible) than glorification is a condition for the
justification (which made such glorification possible). So what?
               Illustration 61. MacArthurian Apples and Oranges
M: Glorification is a result of initial justification rather than its condition. True.
M: Good works are a result of initial justification rather than its condition. True.
M: Good works are a result of final justification rather than its condition. False.
M: Glorification is a result of final justification rather than its condition. True.

        It is foolish for MacArthur to ask if Hodges would make glorification
a condition for justification. MacArthur is posing a misleading question. In
terms of logic, it is like the question, “Have you stopped beating your wife?”
Some questions are not to be answered with a simple yes or no, and the
answer to neither question justifies MacArthur’s conditionality. Glorification
is conditioned on justification. Justification is a condition for glorification
and comes before glorification. Postconversion works, on the other hand, are
not a condition for initial justification and come after such justification.
MacArthur’s appeal to glorification as a counter illustration is a
misrepresentation of the situation. As an unconditional securitist, Hodges
correctly would insist that initial justification unconditionally guarantees
final soteriological justification. Initial justification assures us of reaching
heaven and of soteriological glorification. MacArthur, on the other hand, as
a conditional securitist, requires our full participation in our successful
perseverance to the end of our lives in order for us to obtain final
justification. Otherwise, God will not keep us (according to MacArthur).
Viewed from the perspective of the end result, MacArthur is clearly an
insecuritist.
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                              Page 183
       My argument on Edwards’ behalf, in which I demonstrated the
possibility of legitimate importation, could be used to create a causal
connection for a chain of events.* Doing so provides an additional
opportunity to clarify the lack of logic in MacArthur’s question.
                 Illustration 62. Causal Chain for Glorification
redemption ⇒ initial justification ⇒ eternal life ⇒ final justification ⇒ glorification

        Given this ordo salutis, (1) redemption is the cause and condition for
initial justification. (2) Initial justification in turn is the cause and condition
for eternal life. (3) Having the free gift of eternal life is the resulting cause
and condition for final justification.† (4) Finally, final justification is the
cause and condition for glorification. Using a combination of
(A) Edwardseanism logic and (B) my explanation, one might say that
(A redemption virtually contains glorification (B) because the benefit of
redemption unconditionally flows like headwaters into a river of life
resulting in glorification.‡ Even if this inverted logic is temporally adopted
for sake of argument, it carefully must be noted that if there had been any
subsequent contingency involved, then I would not have been able to
embed the entire process in the initial event. But as it is, without any
intermediate contingency, an unbreakable chain reaction of unconditional
cause-and-effect sequences is unavoidable.

*
  See Illustration 47. Biblical Importation, 145.
†
  Final justification is being used soteriologically for the sake of this immediate
discussion.
‡
  I am, therefore, entertaining an implausible exception to my Critical Response
(p. 147) of Edwards and allowing the headwater to contain the river where there
are no subsequent contingencies flowing like tributaries into headwaters of the
river. In those cases where the river contains no subsequent contingencies, the
water found downstream in the river would be attributable solely to the
headwater. Still, the headwater does not actually contain the river; rather, the
river contains the headwater. In the same fashion, the initial event does not
actually engulf the subsequent events but rather insures them. Therefore, for
sake of logical consistency and self consistency, my above exception in which I
entertain the possibility that redemption virtually contains glorification may be
challenged successfully with this superior reverse articulation: Glorification
virtually contains redemption. Regardless, the reason remains the same: because
the benefit of redemption flows unconditionally like headwaters into a river of
life resulting in glorification. This reasoning is consistent with my argument for
unconditional security in which the benefit of having eternal life extends
eschatologically into the future so that one remains a believer in terms of the
imparted benefit, even if one ceases to believe. See Illustration 44.
Eschatological Perfective Present, 141.

      The differentiation that Logan suggests in defense of Edwards (in
which faith is regarded as both a cause and condition for salvation, but
works are regarded merely as a condition and not as a cause*) would seem to
come into question when viewed from this perspective:
                          Illustration 63. Dubious Chain
                            faith ⇒ works ⇒ salvation

       Granted, regarding faith as the instrumental cause is preferable.
Nevertheless, in light of the apparently legitimate importation in Illustration
62. Causal Chain (in which each link provides both the cause and condition
for the succeeding link), it seems rather dubious for Logan to base his
defense of a questionable importation on the notion that the same logic
would not apply to faith and works. One would tend to think that (1) faith is
the cause and condition for works, and (2) works are in turn the cause and
condition for salvation—if the same logic applies to both chains of thought.
Regardless of my conclusion regarding causation, the weakness of the
Edwardsean approach has been demonstrated already, in that it makes works
a condition for soteriological salvation and such salvation a result of works.
       The observation that works are a soteric condition for salvation in
Edwardseanism suffices for present purposes in demonstrating the fallacy of
MacArthurianism in asserting counter wise that works are not a soteric
condition for salvation in Reformed thought. Any straightforward
assessment of faith-works would assert that works are indeed a soteric
condition for final salvation in both Edwardseanism and MacArthurianism
(in addition to likewise being a soteric condition in both Arminianism and
Catholicism).

         Component
       According to MacArthur’s closing remark in this part of his section in
Faith Work: “Faith works are a consequence of faith, not a component of
faith” (emphasis his).135 Once again, MacArthur is trying to obscure the
logical implications of his own theology. As already demonstrated, the
works ⊂ faith-works abbreviation correctly expresses works as being a
necessary component of faith-works, and the faith-works abbreviation is
correct in stressing that those postconversion works are secondary
expressions of faith-works. Without a doubt, works ⊂ faith-works is
certainly a valid summation of faith-works theology.† Works are a part of
faith-works. Duh! Postconversional works are not only a consequence (as
denoted by the hyphen); they are also a component (as denoted by the subset

*
    See Logan’s Praise, 168.
†
    See Illustration 49. Faith ∩ Works, 157.
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                           Page 185
symbol). The problem comes when one tries to make saving faith equal to or
inclusive of faith-works. In MacArthurian pseudo Lordship Salvation,
saving faith necessarily includes faith-works. Biblical Lordship Salvation
asserts, to the contrary, that saving faith does not necessarily include works.
                  Illustration 64. Saving Faith ⊄ Faith-Works




       To address this matter from yet another angle with a more explicit
and exact illustration and explanation, (A) saving faith ⊄ (B-C) faith-works.*
This is not to deny that there is an overlapping intersection between faith and
works: faith ∩ works. Mistholic faith is the part of faith-works where that
overlap occurs, but soteric faith would logically not be a part of the semantic
domain pertaining to works since soteric faith lies outside of that overlap.
Saving faith is not a work. Therefore, the semantic range of faith falling
outside that overlap of faith and works is not a part of faith-work. If one will
simply be discerning as to what type or range of faith is being discussed, the
matter of constituency should not be confusing.

       (A) soteriological faith ⊄ faith-works.
       (B) misthological faith ⊂ faith-works.

       If MacArthur were thinking something along these lines when he said
that faith-works are a consequence rather than component of faith, then his

*
  More specifically, (A) saving faith ∩⁄ (B-C) faith-works. Saving faith does not
intersect (and therefore is not a part of) works. The part of faith that intersects
works is mistholic faith: A = soteric faith; B = mistholic faith. So A ∩⁄ B-C.
Page 186                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
claim would be comprehensible. If this distinction were his intention, then
MacArthur’s claim could be expressed as: faith-works ⊄ faith. This
statement is true if one is saying that misthological faith-works ⊄
soteriological faith (in other words, B-C ⊄ A), or more precisely, faith-
works ∩⁄ faith (i.e., B-C ∩⁄ A). Faith intersects works, but saving faith does
not intersect work; meaning, the component part of faith that intersects
works is not saving faith. Unfortunately, one gets the definite impression
from the MacArthurian faith-works argument that such elementary
observations are light years ahead of the MacArthurian equation. MacArthur
cannot be credited with indicating such a distinction between soteriological
faith and misthological faith when he is doing his best to equate them (or at
least combine soteriological faith with misthological faith) to form saving
faith. Therefore, his distinction between a consequence and a condition is
reprehensible rather than comprehensible and only allows one to conclude
that MacArthurian saving faith = A + B + C.
        For those not used to thinking in terms of logical consistency and who
may think that this whole matter is too technical to be comprehensible,
perhaps a children’s object lesson will help clarify the issue. One could print
off Illustration 64. Saving Faith ⊄ Faith-Works for the children in one’s
church and have them do a coloring exercise in which they color the
respective components as:

       (A) soteriological faith as yellow
       (B) misthological faith as green
       (C) misthological works as blue.

There are no soteriological works for them to color because there is no such
category. There is no such thing as soteriological works. Contrary to
MacArthur, there are no works that believers have to perform in order to get
to heaven. Heaven is conditioned on faith apart from works: Saving faith
=A. Using the if-then symbol (⇒) will allow a concise expression of the
coloring exercise. Children should be able to understand such matters even if
theologically color-blind preachers cannot.

       • yellow ⇒ heaven
       • green and blue ⇒ rewards in heaven

       Reading the illustration from right to left, one might conversely say
that (C) volitional works ⊄ (A-B) faith-works. This does not mean, however,
that there is no intersection between the two circles of works and faith. On
the contrary, as seen in the illustration, the circles overlap. (A) Yellow and
(C) blue combine to produce (B) green. Symbolically, this overlap between
works and faith is expressed as: works ∩ faith.
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                          Page 187
        The difference between soteriological faith and misthological faith is
not that one is intellectual and the other volitional. Faith is always
intellectual persuasion. Nevertheless, perseverance in that intellectual
persuasion requires meritorious effort and thus has a misthological impact
on our character. Therefore, perseverance in this persuasion is colored green.
The difference between (A) soteric faith and (B) mistholic faith is that the
latter entails merit and is accordingly considered a work and has the
potential to result in a reward. Likewise, the difference between
(B) mistholic faith and (C) mistholic work is not that one involves effort and
the other does not. Rather, the distinction is that the latter involves volitional
action whereas the former is simply intellectual persuasion. Faith-work
obviously has both components: faith and works. Consequently, it is
composed of two types of works: persuasional and volitional.

       Duty
       Like MacArthur, Duty (an Arminian) denies unconditional security
and simultaneously denies any notion of merit when he claims that there is
“no praise to man for anything. He cannot earn or merit anything from God,
not with all his obedience and faith” (emphasis his).136 Such drivel is not
biblical. According to the Bible, when believers stand before the Judgment
Seat of Christ to be judged misthologically for what they have done
(2Cor 5:10), some believers will be found worthy of praise from God, and
they will be praised by God: “Each man’s praise will come to him from
God” (1Cor 4:5). So much for Duty’s claim that there is no praise to man for
anything! The problem, in fact, is that many believers (Jn 12:42) will be
found to have “loved the praise of men more than the praise of God” (Jn
12:43; KJV). The Lord obviously indicates that some believers will earn
praise from God so that they can hear the words, “Well done, good and
faithful slave; you were faithful with a few things, I will put you in charge of
many things” (Mt 25:21). Those Christians who have done their duty will be
praised for having done so. This praise will show that they have merited
their reward. Naturally, Duty is correct to associate praise with what is
earned and merited: praise = merit. But he is not thinking straight when he
denies that believers earn praise and thus derivative merit. Consequently, his
whole argument against eternal security falls to the ground in a meritorious
heap of ruinous works-righteousness. He cannot condition our entrance into
heaven on our postconversional obedience and faith without conditioning
our entrance into heaven on our merit. Since heaven is not conditioned on
human merit, it cannot be conditioned on postconversional obedience and
faith.
Page 188                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       Faith and Works
        Duty may be credited, however, for being more refreshingly candid
than MacArthur. Although both these authors (one an Arminian and the
latter a Calvinist) reject unconditional security and condition the believer’s
security on his or her postconversional faith and works, Duty is much more
upfront with his claim: “James illustrated his faith-works doctrine with
Abraham….Faith alone or works alone would not have made Abraham
acceptable to God.”137 Duty rejects the Pauline notion that believers are
saved by faith-alone: “Do you dear reader, have the faith-works of a soul-
saving experience that can be seen, or a faith-alone experience that cannot
be seen and which cannot save you?” (Italics his.)138 Duty’s denies that you
can be saved by faith alone. Nevertheless, since he ties this denial in with a
question about the salvation of the soul, something meaningful may yet be
gleaned from his question. Misthologists concur completely that the
salvation of one’s soul is by faith-works not by faith-alone. Unfortunately,
Duty thinks that this Jacobean salvation of the soul is soteric justification
salvation and does not consider the alternative possibility: It might be
misthological salvation instead. And in doing so, he ends up denying Pauline
justification by faith-alone: “Faith alone cannot save—and works alone
cannot save….The Bible teaches that Abraham was justified by faith and
works….Rahab was also justified and saved by faith and works”
(Jam 2:21,25).139 There you have it, straight from an Arminian’s mouth:
faith-works = faith and works. Misthologists could not agree more.

       Faith and Perseverance
       For example, the writer of Hebrews urges believers to be “imitators of
those who through faith and patience inherit the promises” (Heb 6:12). This
inheritance is not conditioned on faith alone but on faith and patience. The
Greek word for patience in this verse is makrothumia. For those who may
wish to point out that Paul says that makrothumia is a fruit of the Spirit
(Gal 5:22) and then claim that it is produced inevitably by saving faith, a
misthologist simply could counter that in this very context (1) Paul is
warning believers that their inheritance of the kingdom is conditioned on the
fruit they produce. (2) Paul does not take for granted that believers
inevitably will bear this fruit since he exhorts them to walk by the Spirit
(Gal 5:25) so that they may bear this fruit and warns them that that if they do
not bear this fruit, then they will not inherit the kingdom (Gal 5:21).
       Most importantly, the inheritance is conditioned on the fruit
produced, not just on the root that gives rise to that fruit. The old root-fruit
myth that has been perpetuated widely by conditionalists which claims that
the inheritance is just based on the root and not on the fruit produced by that
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                       Page 189
root will not withstand scrutiny. In this myth, the fruit supposedly is nothing
more than the necessary evidence of the root.* To be sure, moral fruit is
necessary, but not for the reason supposed by insecuritists. They believe that
moral fruit is necessary to enter the kingdom. Paul, in contrast, believes that
it is necessary to inherit the kingdom. In fact, he explicitly teaches that the
inheritance is a reward based on works, not a gift. He exhorts believers: “Do
your work heartily, as for the Lord rather than for men; knowing that from
the Lord you will receive the reward of the inheritance (Col 3:23-24). This
inheritance is conditioned on the fruit of hard work. Such fruit is not
automatic or evitable, and it is certainly conditional for the inheritance.
        Unlike some conditionalists, biblical writers have no problem
affirming the conditional nature of our performance. The inheritance, for
example, is conditioned by Paul on the believer’s performance. Faith and
works are necessary to inherit the kingdom. One must be a believer (have
saving faith), and then one must work (add works to that faith) so that it will
incur misthological value, allowing one to inherit the kingdom.
        When doing algebraic word problems, one quickly learns that and
means add. When the writer of Hebrews says that faith and patience are
necessary to inherit the kingdom (Heb 6:12), he is providing an elementary
word problem: faith and works = faith & works = faith + works. The specific
form of work he has in mind is perseverance. (Makrothumia is also
translated as endurance, perseverance.) His expression through faith and
patience leaves no doubt as to the conditional nature of the relationship. For
example, in a well-known verse, Paul affirms that we are saved through faith
(Eph 2:8) and immediately goes on to clarify that this salvation is not a
result of works (Eph 2:9) because he is talking about a gift. The writer of
Hebrews, on the other hand, adds works because he is describing the reward
of the inheritance. Believers inherit through faith and works. Or
algebraically, one might express it as: faith + works = inheritance. Duty did
well to note that the works performed by believers in Jam 2:21 is tantamount
to faith and works (although the Jacobean focus is on the works).

       God-Enabled Works Are Still Works
       Where misthologists disagree with Duty is when he claims “that we
cannot earn or merit our salvation, no matter how many conditions we keep.
It is only by God’s undeserved grace that we are saved.”140 For one thing,
his own equation of praise with merit destroys his argument. Like so many
others before and after him, Duty mistakenly thinks that just because these
postconversional works are performed by God’s enabling grace that

*
  Preliminary introduction to this concept was provided in interaction with
Edwards. See Actual Versus Virtual Faith, 136. More thorough evaluation is yet
to come. See Root versus Fruit, 257.
Page 190                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
believers can trust in their performance as a condition for reaching heaven
and still make it to heaven by claiming that heaven is a free gift that they did
not merit. According to the Bible, however, those taking that meritorious
path to heaven will find that they have taken a path to hell instead, even if
they deny the logically-meritorious nature of the path they have chosen.
       What James is talking about is the possibility of Christians earning
misthological mercy so that they can experience salvation from a
misthologically merciless judgment at the Judgment Seat of Christ
(Jam 2:13). James goes on immediately to say that Christian teachers will
receive a stricter judgment (Jam 3:1). So it is extremely important that
Christian teachers do their Christian duty and rebuke Duty when he fails to
divide the word of truth rightly. He puts people on a wrong path to heaven, a
path that leads to hell instead. Even so, as Christian teachers, we are
encouraged to speak the truth in love (Eph 4:15) and can do so by focusing
our counterattacks on the logic of our opponent’s arguments rather than on
the character of his person. I have no interest in character assassination and
appreciate Duty’s positive influence when it comes to promoting Christian
morality through God’s enabling grace. Nevertheless, the Bible does say to
consider such teachers of works-righteousness as accursed. To do otherwise
would be unbiblical.

       Inherent Merit
       Many Arminians equate earning the crown of life with retaining
possession of the gift of eternal life. The gift of eternal life ends up being an
oxymoronic earned gift in such soteriology. Lewis certainly seems
susceptible to this typical Arminian weakness. Yet there is an underlying
subtle strength to Lewis’ argument (regarding the importance of producing a
virtuous Christian character) that should not be neglected, especially since it
makes a positive contribution to misthology, despite Lewis’ mistaken
opinion that it applies to soteriology.
       According to the biblical text (Jam 1:12; Rev 2:10), the crown
(stephanos) of life is a reward earned by perseverance (i.e., by being faithful
unto death). According to the Greek dictionary, this victor’s crown is an
“award or prize for exceptional service or conduct” whose “primary
significance as a symbol of exceptional merit” should not be overlooked
(BDAG). But upon whose exceptional service and merit is this victor’s
crown based? The believer’s merit, of course, is being lexically affirmed.
With Lewis, misthologists believe that a reward is not based merely on the
merit of the believer’s actions, conduct, or service, but also on the believer’s
godly character that the believer has further refined by performing godly
actions.
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                       Page 191

       Add Works
        To further illustrate the misthological concord with Lewis that godly
character counts, note that Peter stresses the virtue of developing a godly
character as the means by which to earn an abundant entrance into the
kingdom (2Pet 1:5-11). Duty is correct to equate faith-works with faith and
works. Peter is not describing merely faith that works; rather, he is picturing
faith plus works. The KJV and NKJV translate the key phrase in 2Pet 1:5 as
add to your faith virtue. The Greek word for add is epichoregeo. A number
of other translations also render it as add (GWN, MRD, NET, NIV, RWB,
and WEB). Supplement and supply are also popular translations.
               Illustration 65. Add/Supply Works to Your Faith




        Whether epichoregeo is translated as add or supply makes little
difference since Peter’s supplementation is addition. The important thing to
note is that faith comes first, and works are added to this faith. For this
reason, moving from left to right, faith is pictured as the flowerpot, and
works are pictured subsequently on the right as the water canister. Character
traits are to be added to this initial faith so that this saving faith may grow
into a virtuous faith. Many people mistakenly think that since works are
secondary, the faith-works expression necessarily means that works are
derived from faith or that these works are merely evidence of faith rather
than an addition to faith. Such limitations are false because Peter is talking
about expressions of mistholic works as necessary additions to soteric faith.
Page 192                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                        Illustration 66. Faith + Works




       In this Petrine equation, faith-works = faith + works. Saving faith
comes first; it is foundational. However, the works added to that initial faith
causes it to grow into a faith that God can reward. Adding works to faith141
(like supplying water to a plant) allows it to grow into a mature form.
Believers are to develop a character worthy of reward. Conditionalists who
insist that the faith-works expression means that works are strictly evidence
of saving faith completely invert what Peter is saying.
                 Illustration 67. Works as Evidence of Faith
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                           Page 193
       Works are not derived from faith in this passage. Rather, works are
added to faith. Petrine addition proves that a theology which must limit its
view of faith-works to viewing such postconversional works as mere
evidence of faith is false. Peter’s perspective makes sense. You have to have
faith first before you can add works to it, and you need to add works to it in
order to get the desired result. The faith-works perspective that insists that
works are only evidence of saving faith is nonsense. He is not talking about
faith that works but faith and works. Let Peter speak for himself:

       Now for this very reason also, do your very best to
       • add to your faith, moral virtue
       • and to your moral virtue, knowledge;
       • and to your knowledge, self-control,
       • and to your self-control, perseverance,
       • and to your perseverance, godliness;
       • and to your godliness, brotherly kindness,
       • and to your brotherly kindness, love (2Pet 1:5-7; TM).

Peter makes an addition column by which all these qualities are added by the
believers’ effort to their initial faith in order to qualify them for an abundant
entrance into the kingdom in v. 11. Believers are instructed to supply or add
something to their initial faith that this initial faith did not have originally.
Initial faith has zero misthological virtue. However, believers can add
misthological virtue to this initial faith and derive a virtuous faith as a result.
                       Illustration 68. Additions to Faith
                                 Faith
                                 Moral virtue
                                 Knowledge
                                 Self-control
                                 Perseverance
                                 Godliness
                                 Brotherly kindness
                               + Love
                               Abundant Entrance

                      Faith + works = abundant entrance

      According to Peter, if Christians practice (2Pet 1:10) adding all these
character qualities to their faith, they can have an abundant entrance into the
eternal kingdom: “For in this way the entrance into the eternal kingdom of
our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ will be abundantly supplied to you”
(2Pet 1:11). Peter makes a pun, using the same word epichoregeo for
supply/add in verse 11 that he did in verse 5. If Christians add these
Page 194                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
character qualities to their faith, God will add a rich entrance to them. If
Christians add misthological value to their faith, God will add misthological
riches to their entrance. If they do their addition, God will do His addition.
Believers already are qualified for soteriological entrance into the kingdom
by faith apart from works. But a faith that results in a rich entrance into the
kingdom requires these additions. The Greek word for abundantly is
plousios; it is also frequently translated as richly. This rich entrance into the
eternal kingdom is talking about believers meriting eternal rewards in
heaven because of their earthly performance in building a godly character on
earth. Rewards are eternal.
        By means of hard work, Peter enjoins believers to “do your best to
make your calling and election secure” (2Pet 1:10; TM). The Greek word
that Peter uses is spoudazo and conveys the idea of doing your best, working
hard, sparing no effort. Peter used the noun form (spoude) to introduce the
list in verse 5 when he said to do your best to add moral virtue to your faith.
This virtue is added by the believer’s hard work, by the believer’s effort. To
be sure, it is God-enabled effort. Nevertheless, it is the believer’s effort (i.e.,
the believer’s hard work) that goes into adding these virtues to the believer’s
faith. Rewards are based on the believer’s works.
        The Greek word for secure is bebaios; it means to guarantee.
Believers are to work hard to secure/guarantee their calling and election.
The realization of their misthological calling and election in achieving a rich
entrance into the kingdom is secured or guaranteed by their perseverance,
among other character traits. Perseverance is just part of this list. Yet
drawing attention to perseverance suffices to show a common fallacy. Those
who make perseverance a condition for final salvation from hell have
perverted the gospel and inverted the Petrine intent. Those who misconstrue
this passage into teaching how believers can be sure of reaching heaven have
perverted its faith-plus-works misthology into an accursed faith-plus-works
soteriology. Peter is not talking about how to guarantee that believers are
genuine believers but how to guarantee that they will be richly rewarded.
        Someone may ask, “What about those believers who lack
perseverance (and the other qualities on Peter’s list)?” Peter gives an answer:
“For he who lacks these qualities is blind or short-sighted, having forgotten
his purification from his former sins” (2Pet 1:9). That this person is a
believer is clear since his slate was wiped completely clean in regard to his
former sins. Therefore, two fundamental observations are self-apparent:
One, he was a genuine believer since his former sins were forgiven.* Two,


*
  If Peter had just been talking about provisional forgiveness available to
