Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                         Page 195
perseverance is really missing in the lives of some believers. Peter is not
dealing with a mere hypothetical possibility.
       Why does Peter only mention the purification of this believer’s former
sins? Why not all sins? After all, all a believer’s sins are forgiven
soteriologically. A reasonable proposal, in view of the context, is to suggest
that Peter is reminding his Christian readers that when they became
Christians and experienced the bath of regeneration (cf. Tit 3:5), this
forgiveness only wiped the slate clean misthologically for their former sins.
After that point in time, everything in a believer’s life counts toward whether
or not that believer will inherit the kingdom with a rich entrance.
       Oh, to be sure, soteriological cleansing results in the cleansing of all a
believer’s sins—soteriologically. Entrance into heaven is unconditionally
assured. However, stressing this aspect of soteriological forgiveness would
be counterproductive to the misthological theme Peter is developing. Peter is
not discussing assurance of entering heaven but assurance of richly entering
heaven. Soteriological assurance for those who have been cleansed
soteriologically is a given.* In contradistinction to this rudimentary
forgiveness, Peter is subtly reminding believers that soteriological
forgiveness only wipes the slate clean misthologically for those sins that
were committed up until the point in time they became believers. Peter is
encouraging believers not to rest on their soteriological laurels but to work
hard at adding virtue to their initial faith (which is without initial virtue) in
order that they may derive a virtuous faith and obtain a rich entrance into
heaven as a reward for their resulting conduct and character (2Pet 1:11). The
reason their Christian conduct is so important is because it improves their
Christian character and thereby qualifies them for rewards in heaven.
Heaven itself is a gift and is entered freely. Nevertheless, an abundant
entrance into heaven is a reward.

       Inherent Merit is Condign and Congruent
      Since these rewards are not just based on our conduct but also on the
character traits instilled into us by such conduct, these heavenly rewards
must be based at least in part on the inherent merit which resides in the
virtue of our Christian character. Our very character has been
misthologically enriched because of the merit that such character deserves.
      No doubt, such merit is derivative and secondary. This merit is
condign (in that the only reason our virtuous Christian character deserves
such rewards is because Christ won these rewards for us and contingently

improvement actually made in their character as a result of that effort as they
pursue such rewards).* Still, when all is said and done, to make such
statements misthologically correct, the bottom line still remains that rewards
are based on our derivative inherent merit. To express this truth in a pun, we
inherit the kingdom because of our inherent merit. Our inherent merit is our
inherit merit. As most misthologists realize, inheriting the kingdom is a
reward which surpasses the gift of merely entering the kingdom. According
to Paul, among others, such an inheritance is a reward (Col 3:24). The only
observation I am adding is that this inheritance is based on the inherent merit
of our character development.
       One reason I concur with Edwards and Lewis as to the inherent nature
of our virtue is because Peter has conditioned misthological entrance into the
kingdom on the virtue of one’s Christian character. The Bible also extols the
virtue of godly character by including an extended praise of the virtuous
woman, saying that “her worth is far above jewels” (Prov 31:10). God
assigns a great worth to her virtue. In the same fashion, Peter urges Christian
women to focus on developing their inner beauty by letting “it be the hidden
person of the heart, with the imperishable quality of a gentle and quiet spirit,
which is precious in the sight of God” (1Pet 3:4). The word precious
(poluteles) means “God appraises it at high value” (BDAG). This virtue has
great value or worth (L-N). In other words, such character has high inherent

clearly assert that it would be unjust for God not to reward us once He has

to Himself but to us. To be sure, God graciously chose to obligate Himself to us,
but this does not mean that He can fail to carry through on His promise to us
without being unfaithful to us. Additionally, I am affirming that rewards are

superior summarization of the relationship between merit and rewards is grace-

are fully merited quantitatively. Yet the magnitude of the rewards will far
exceed what we deserve and in that sense are only partially merited
qualitatively. Therefore, it is not a contradiction to say that rewards are both
fully and partially merited because the nature of reward is being viewed from
two different, yet complementary, perspectives.

merit in God’s eyes. Christians can add inherent merit to their inner

         Chocolate Milk Analogy
        Another children’s object lesson might be in order to illustrate how
merit can be added to something that is initially devoid of virtue. Let milk
represent regenerating faith (i.e., faith that results in regeneration), and let
chocolate represent virtue (i.e., character traits that result in reward). When
you add chocolate to milk, you get chocolate milk (representing a virtuous
faith that results in reward). To speak analogously, God graciously created
the chocolate and freely offers us a cup of milk, but He is not going to buy
the chocolate for us or put it in the milk for us. If we want chocolate milk,
we are going to have to buy the chocolate and add it ourselves.143

         Merit or Demerit
        Merit can be deadly, or it can be valuable. Those seeking to merit
heaven have no biblical right to expect that they will be successful. In
conditioning their initial reception or their continued possession of the free
gift of eternal life on their merit, they have barred themselves from heaven
and turned their merit into demerit. No amount of fame, not even Christian
fame, will get a person into heaven. Morality was never intended to be the
means by which fallen sinners were expected to obtain soteriological
immortality. Nor was Christian morality ever intended to be the means by
which Christians were to maintain their soteriological immortality.
        Nevertheless, merit is certainly the proper means by which to seek for
misthological immortality.* Unlike many Protestants, who find no virtue in
Christian virtue, Lewis and Edwards are to be commended for fully
affirming such virtue. The clarification added herein is that those Christians
who seek to add moral virtue to their lives and character will be well
rewarded for doing so as long as they do not try to merit heaven while doing
so. A proven character produces misthological hope of great reward (cp.
Rom 5:4).

         Virtue is not Its Own Reward
       The quote, “Virtue is its own reward,” comes from the playwright,
Sir John Vanbrugh. That quote continues by saying, “There’s a pleasure in
doing good which sufficiently pays itself.” So let us ask, “Did Jesus die a
virtuous death?” Certainly. But let us also ask a follow-up question, “Was
there sufficient pleasure in Jesus’ crucifixion to sufficiently justify His
*
    See “Misthological Death” in The Outer Darkness.
Page 198                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
excruciating death?” Of course not. Far to the contrary, as Don Francisco
has expressed in Christian lyrics: “Jesus didn’t die for us because it was
fun.” According to the Bible, it was “for the joy that was set before Him”
that Jesus “endured the cross” (Heb 12:2). That joy was future. Jesus
endured the cross; He did not enjoy it. Virtue is not its own reward, certainly
not on that most important and exemplary occasion. The reward that Jesus
would gain as a result of enduring the cross was the joyful anticipation of a
future benefit. This joyful anticipation provided the motivation for His
enduring the cross. His virtue was motivated by His desire for reward, and
His virtue resulted in His being crowned with the glory He so richly
deserved. By His life and death, He was seeking to earn gifts and rewards
that He could share and experience with others. Those in the Reformed camp
who appeal to Vanbrugh’s quote (in an attempt to rebuke the biblical
affirmation that virtue results in a merited reward) would do well to take
their eyes off of Vanbrugh and turn their eyes upon Jesus, who for the joy
set before Him in the future endured the cross in the present.
       If one were to trace Vanbrugh’s sentiment back to its source, as
Barnes has done, one would discover that it finds its roots in a misthology
which is antagonistic to Christianity:

             Plato rejects the Orphic doctrine of reward and
       punishment, using the term misthos more so in the sense of
       recognition and honor. For Plato, righteousness carried with it
       its own reward.
             Thus moral acts are to be done for their own sake, not
       with the motive of some reward. The denial of future reward is
       even more prominent in Aristotle and Stoicism.
             But as the river of time coursed its way beyond the
       Hellenistic era, the idea of future reward began to seep into
       religious thought….
             By the time you reach the Gospels, the Old Testament
       concept of rewards, both material and spiritual, present and
       future, is in full bloom.144

         Barnes appropriately concurs with Joe Wall that “Jesus will reward us
according to our persevering faith.”145 Wall derives this conclusion from the
promises made in Hebrews for persevering faith. Persevering in faith is a
rewards issue. To make heaven the result of perseverance in faith would be
to make heaven a reward rather than a gift. Since entrance into heaven is a
gift, it cannot be conditioned on perseverance in faith.

on the criticisms made by some Protestants), no one encountered in this

Calvinistic camp, on the other hand, attribute our works to God’s sovereign
grace in an equally futile attempt to deny that our works entail merit. This
approach gains little, if anything, since we still perform the work. Moreover,
this proposition creates additional problems in having to explain why our
culpability does not involve merit or demerit and also in having to explain
away free will. Therefore, Protestants (whether Arminian or Calvinistic) are

            Marrowism stands practically alone in teaching that entrance into
heaven is not conditioned on works. In Marrowism, entrance into heaven is
truly not merited in any sense of the word. Logical consistency requires that
this affirmation be limited to Marrowism. It is one thing for the other camps
to deny that heaven is merited (as most Protestants are quick to do), but it is
quite another matter to actually teach a soteriology which is consistent with
that denial and which is really devoid of any soteric merit. On this matter,
Marrowism is quite successful and quite simple:

        •   Only rewards are merited.†
        •   Heaven is not a reward.
        •   Therefore, heaven is not merited.

       In Marrowism, rewards in heaven are not confused with heaven itself
so as to make a reward of heaven. Heaven itself is not a reward. With logical

      Safety in Numbers
       Despite the arguments presented in the present book, most people will
seek to find safety in numbers and opt for the status quo. Since most
expositors and pastors throughout church history (and even in the present)
advocate some form of conditional security, most people ironically will seek
to find their security in the insecurity of conditional security. Most people
will go with the majority opinion. To be sure, that is the easy way to settle
the dispute: side with the majority. Politicians do it all the time.
       Understandably, believing in unconditional security is difficult since
unconditional security is the minority opinion and since unconditional
security goes against the natural kneejerk tendency that praises the human
work ethic as the means by which to get what you want. Yet there is a sober
warning in Scripture for those who seek the easy way out by siding with
majority opinion:

      Enter by the narrow gate; for the gate is wide, and the way is
      broad that leads to destruction, and many are those who enter
      by it. For the gate is small, and the way is narrow that leads to
      life, and few are those who find it. (Mt 7:13-14)

       The context of this passage is not talking about people outside of
Christendom being turned away from heaven. Given the exclusive claims of
Christ, it may be taken for granted that those who do not believe in Christ
for eternal life will not enter heaven (Jn 14:6; cp. Acts 4:12). However,
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                         Page 203
Christ is not addressing those who are trying to get to heaven apart from
Him in this Matthean context. To the contrary, the Lord is describing those
who are seeking entrance into heaven through Him, as proven by the three
times they implore Him not to turn them away from heaven because of all
the things they did in His name (Mt 7:22). Through the power of His name,
they were even able to cast out demons. If there were ever works that one
could perform that would prove that one was saved, surely one would
conclude that their casting out demons would constitute such a work (cf.
Mt 12:24-28). But even the performance of this work is not proof that one is
saved. The stark reality is that it is extremely dangerous to trust in the works
one performs through God’s enabling grace as the basis for one’s entering
heaven (or even for one’s assurance of entering heaven). Trusting in one’s
works is a path that leads straight to hell. Even so, it is the path that these
professing believers take in this eschatological context, begging Jesus to
regard them as genuine believers in His name because of all the “wonderful
works” (KJV) they have done in His name. The majority of professing
believers in Christendom are indeed trying to take this route to heaven, just
as Jesus anticipated.
       Most people in Christendom are trying to enter heaven by means of
their works and thus by means of conditional security. Comparatively
speaking, very few people truly find their solace in unconditional security.
Books truly defending unconditional security (and not some Calvinistic
imitation of security) will continue to represent the minority position in the
overall scheme of things. But hopefully, this book will be an encouragement
to those comparatively few in Christendom who find their security in Christ
alone rather than in the Protestant and Catholic masses. We should not base
our salvation from hell (or our assurance of salvation from hell) on the fruit
of our good works. Yet tragically, that is exactly what most people in our
churches are doing. And judging from Jesus’ warning in Mt 7:13-14, the
majority of the people in our churches are going to go to hell as a result. The
mass appeal of performance-based soteriology has a history of leading the
vast majority of professing Christians to hell. A Christian would be well
advised to find his or her security in Christ rather than in living or martyred
masses.

       Conclusion
       We have no hopes of getting to heaven on the basis of our merit. This
merit goes under various names, such as: works, virtue, perseverance, and
repentance. Those trusting in their merit to get to heaven, regardless of what
they call it, are going to be in for a bitter disappointment. Their merit will be
found to be a demerit because it was not founded on faith alone in Christ
alone for eternal life. Those who think that faith alone in Christ alone is
insufficient for reaching heaven have insulted Christ by failing to grasp the
saving sufficiency of Christ’s imputational righteousness. When it comes to
Page 204                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
soteriological sufficiency and punctiliar contingency, Christianity is a done
religion, not a do religion. It is based on what Christ has done, not on what
those who have already believed in Christ must yet do.
                 Illustration 70. Faith Alone in Christ Alone




        The reason the believer can rest in the saving sufficiency of Christ’s
earthly death is because God also imparts the saving sufficiency of Christ’s
earthly life to such a believer. Surely perseverance in faith (as well as every
other form of righteousness) is required of the believer in order for the
believer to reach heaven. However, this perseverance in faith (and every
other form of righteousness necessary to reach heaven) is immediately,
finally, and irreversibly imputed to the believer the moment he or she
believes in Christ alone for eternal life. Therefore, initial faith completely
and permanently cuts through the chain of eternal damnation (like steel bolt
cutters cutting through an iron chain) because one has all the merits of
Christ’s faith (as well as all His other forms of faithfulness) imputed to one’s
account the very moment one first believes in Christ for eternal life. Saving
faith in Christ results in the faith of Christ being imputed to the believer.
Therefore, one reason God can grant final salvation to the believer at the
moment of saving faith is because the righteousness of Christ’s faith is
imputed to the believer in that instant. The believer will thus enter heaven by
virtue of the virtue in Christ’s perseverance in faith, not by virtue of any
virtue in the believer’s own perseverance in faith. One cannot condition
entrance into heaven on one’s own personal perseverance in faith without
conditioning it on one’s own personal virtue and thereby incurring God’s
Chapter 3. The Virtue of Merit                                       Page 205
wrath for trampling underfoot the saving sufficiency of Christ’s death and
life.
       Naturally, this does not mean that one’s personal perseverance in
faith is unimportant, just that it is important for a different reason. The
derivative merit that a believer derives by means of God’s enabling grace in
persevering and developing a godly character after coming to saving faith is
indeed very valuable and precious in God’s sight. Such merit is fully
acceptable, because it springs from a regenerate nature in the heart of a
person who has first come into a saving union with Christ. In this
acknowledgement, the study by Edwards may be commended in finding
such merit fitting. And Lewis may be praised for likewise noting that
perseverance in faith is a virtue. As such, perseverance in faith necessarily
involves inherent (albeit derivative) merit. Biblical merit is the proper means
of earning rewards in heaven. Misthologically, the bottom line is simple:
Heaven is free; rewards in heaven are not free.

A demonic hatchling is not a proper soteric conclusion!
                                                          Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                  Appendix 1.
         Moral and Theological Apostasy
       Introduction
        Perseverance in faith has been found to be a moral issue, so that those
conditioning their salvation on this perseverance are in essence advocating
moral security: Morality is their means to immorality. In this conditionalistic
scheme of things, after believers come to faith, they must augment that faith
with subsequent good works in order to keep their faith alive so that this
persevering faith will, in turn, save them from hell at the end of their lives.
Nevertheless, some conditionalists try to condition this retention of salvation
on faith alone so that they can maintain their insistence that salvation is by
faith alone. In this way, the more astute conditionalist will claim that the
believer is saved by faith apart from works. Granted, works may be
necessary to come to faith and certainly are necessary to keep such faith
alive, but salvation is said (by such conditionalists) to be conditioned on
faith alone, not on the works necessary to come to faith or to maintain such
faith. The only way for conditionalism to condition the reception and
retention of regeneration on faith alone is to advocate a conditional
relationship that places faith as the sole immediate contingency for
regeneration. Faith is made the contingent buffer zone between
preconversion and postconversion works to acquit the conditionalist of any
charges of works-righteousness.
                        Illustration 71. Inverted Order
preconversion works ⇒ faith ⇒ regeneration ⇐ faith ⇐ postconversion works

         This Arminian view of regeneration turns regeneration into a linear
process. Postconversion faith is necessary to keep regeneration alive.
Therefore, to expound upon the above inverted order, I will focus upon the
relationship of preconversion versus postconversion faith in relation to
regeneration:
                      Illustration 72. Bidirectional Faith
        preconversion faith ⇒ regeneration ⇐ postconversion faith

          As noted by the direction of the conditional statement, regeneration
is initially conditioned on preconversion faith (⇒), but regeneration is
subsequently conditioned on postconversion faith (⇐). The direction of the
second conditional arrow is inverted in this Arminian perversion.
Nevertheless, this inversion does allow the conditionalist to condition the
Page 208                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
retention of regeneration on faith alone rather than on works per se, since
faith surrounds regeneration on both sides of the equation, preventing
regeneration from being conditioned directly on works.
                Illustration 73. Insulated Linear Regeneration




          One might picture this linear regeneration as the metal core running
through an insulated rubber wire which is enwrapped by a metal jacket.
Faith is necessary to protect regeneration from making direct contact with
works, which would ground out one’s regeneration by subverting it into
legalistic works-righteousness. Because regeneration is not directly
conditioned on works as such in this approach, conditionalists adopting this
outlook believe that they successfully have insulated themselves from being
accused of teaching an accursed gospel. Of course, they still have to contend
with the fact that perseverance in faith is a work, so they are still teaching
salvation by works. Even so, setting aside that weakness in their argument
for the moment, the logical order of their equation will be examined.
                        Illustration 74. Biblical Order
preconversion works → faith ⇒ regeneration → faith → postconversion works

          Making postconversional faith a condition for regeneration inverts
the biblical order by reversing the direction of the condition. My contention,
to the contrary, as pictured in Illustration 74, is that regeneration is the
necessary rather than sufficient instrumental cause for postconversional
faith. Or, stated in terms of conditionality, preconversional works are often a
precondition for saving faith, but saving faith is the sole condition for
regeneration. In turn, regeneration is a necessary condition for a mistholic
faith, although regeneration does not insure the presence or perseverance of
such postconversional faith. Most importantly, Marrowistic regeneration is
not a linear process, but a punctiliar event: a birth, not a pregnancy.
          As explained more fully in The Outer Darkness, by acknowledging
that works can play a preparatory role in a person coming to faith while
simultaneously insisting that such works cannot be made a co-condition with
faith, the punctiliar event of being born again is conditioned on faith alone.
A correctly articulated punctiliar conditionalism that avoids pseudo Lordship
Salvation on the front end does in fact successfully insulate being born again
from salvation by works on the front end. For example, although the
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                           Page 209
performance change (known as repentance) may be psychologically useful
to some people in coming to saving faith, regeneration would be conditioned
directly and exclusively on their response of faith, not on any change in their
performance that might have been useful in their coming to faith. In this
way, regeneration is insulated by saving faith from preconversional works.
The danger would come, of course, from a poorly-worded evangelistic
appeal that fails to properly insulate saving faith from works because it
conditions regeneration on repentance. Regeneration cannot be conditioned
on repentance (as a condition per se) without teaching an accursed gospel of
salvation by works. Repentance has its place as a potentially useful
preconversional and postconversional prerequisite, but it cannot be made a
theologically necessary conversional requisite.
         As to the distinction between sequential arrows (→) and the
conditional arrow (⇒) in Illustration 74. Biblical Order, the point being
conveyed by the sequential sign (→) is that preconversional works are
sometimes necessary for coming to faith but should not be considered a
theological condition for faith. Punctiliar faith, on the other hand, is
theologically necessary and conditionally sufficient for regeneration. Hence,
the conditional sign (⇒) is used for that relationship. Regeneration, in turn,
becomes the necessary (rather than sufficient) condition for postconversional
faith. So a return back to the sequential arrow (→) is used of that
relationship. The same is true of postconversion works. Postconversional
faith and postconversional works should be expected to flow from the
regenerate life of a believer as the natural (rather than necessary) results of
regeneration. But conditional security inverts the order and subverts the
relationship by wrongly making postconversional faith and works the
condition for regeneration:

                  regeneration ⇐ postconversion faith-works

         Laying aside, for the moment, my contention regarding the
sufficiency of punctiliar faith for an eternal benefit that already has been
granted, for the conditionalistic hypothesis to be correct, the ordo salutis
(order of salvation) in which a person comes to experience regeneration via
saving faith naturally would be expected to be inverted in the ordo apostasia
(order of apostasy) by which a person departs from saving faith.
             Illustration 75. Natural Ordo Salutis and Apostasia
Ordo Salutis:        preconversion work     →    faith   → regeneration
Ordo Apostasia:    postconversion work dies → faith dies → spiritual death

         This ordo apostasia in which conditionalism attempts to base
retention of regeneration on faith alone naturally places moral apostasy
(departure from Christian practice) as occurring before theological apostasy
Page 210                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
(departure from the Christian faith).* Realistically, as stated in my natural
ordo apostasia above, if a believer’s works die before spiritual death sets in,
then moral apostasy must occur before theological apostasy in order for the
conditionalist to have any hope of conditioning spiritual death on the loss of
faith alone.
            Illustration 76. Ordo of Satanic Attack on Faith Alone




         For the sake of readers who may be more visually oriented than
mathematically oriented in terms of their learning styles, the point being
made in the equation may be restated by means of the picture. In the normal
ordo, if conditionalists are to base our regeneration on faith alone, then they
must insist that before Satan can get to our regeneration and cut us off from
God in terms of having eternal life, Satan must first cut through the metal
jacket of our works; then he must cut through the soft rubber insulation of
our faith before he can cut through the metal core of our regeneration.
         Therefore, in addition to demonstrating that perseverance in faith is
not a work, in the normal ordo the conditionalist must also be able to prove
that a believer’s good works die before his faith dies and that his
regeneration dies as an exclusive result of the deadening of his faith.
Otherwise, the conditionalist obviously would be conditioning the believer’s
spiritual death on the believer’s works, which would be an immediate
example of works-righteousness. Consequently, if conditionalism wants to
give any semblance of teaching salvation by faith alone, it must avoid the
following ordo represented in Illustration 77 and Illustration 78 at all cost.


*
 See row 1 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
This ordo apostasia will be shown to be merely hypothetical.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                              Page 211
         Illustration 77. Synonymous Expressions of Ordo Apostasia
Ordo Apostasia: postconversion faith dies →   works die    → spiritual death
Ordo Apostasia:   theological apostasy    → moral apostasy → spiritual death

        In the above illustration, spiritual death is the direct result of moral
apostasy.* Without a doubt, salvation in this ordo is directly conditioned on
one’s performance and thus on one’s works rather than on one’s faith. As a
result, if conditionalism cannot limit moral apostasy to occurring before
theological apostasy, then the conditionalistic claim that regeneration is
conditioned on faith alone in their theology is immediately disproven.† My
objective, then, is simply to inquire from conditionalists as to whether or not
moral theology can occur before theological apostasy in their theology.
               Illustration 78. Inverted Ordo of Satanic Attack




       To restate the matter yet again pictorially, insecuritists must avoid the
ordo represented above if they wish to condition our (retention of)
regeneration on faith alone. Obviously, they cannot have Satan hacking
through our faith first in order to get to our works, only then to be able to
sever our regeneration. For in this case, they would be picturing a salvation
which is blatantly conditioned directly on our works. Faith would be
pictured as keeping our works alive, and our works as keeping our
regeneration alive, and our regeneration as keeping us alive. My goal,
accordingly, is to determine whether or not Satan has to hack away at our

*
  See row 3 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
This ordo apostasia will be shown to be merely hypothetical.
†
  This statement only holds true for the natural ordo, not for every ordo. See row

Page 212                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
works before he can hack away at our faith and thus kill us in
conditionalism. Is the ordo pictured in Illustration 76 the only way Satan can
kill us, or is the ordo pictured in Illustration 78 also a valid possibility?

       Believers are Worse
        The related questions that conditionalists must answer therefore are:
(1) Can theological apostasy occur before moral apostasy, as in Illustration
78?* That is, can Satan kill our faith before he kills our works? (2) Can
moral apostasy occur without first having committed theological apostasy,
as in Illustration 76?† Stated alternatively, can Satan hack through our works
without first hacking through our faith? (3) Even if moral apostasy occurs
without our first having committed theological apostasy, can moral apostasy
in and of itself result in the loss of eternal life? ‡ That is to say, even if Satan
can hack through our works without first hacking through our faith, can
Satan kill us simply by hacking through our works?
        The answers to such questions naturally will have a significant impact
upon one’s view of apostasy, so much so as to be completely detrimental to
the conditionalistic argument if these questions are answered in the
affirmative, given the conditionalistic premises. A natural focal point for
answering such questions is found in 1Tim 5:8 (within its context and with
its clearest cross-references). “But if anyone does not provide for his own,
and especially for those of his household, he has denied the faith and is
worse than an unbeliever” (1Tim 5:8). The moral apostasy described in
1Tim 5:8 implements the Greek word cheiron (worse) to describe morally
defective believers. No less than three times in the NT, this same word is
used to describe such believers as being:
                           Illustration 79. Worse Than
• Worse than unbelievers (1Tim 5:8).
• Subject to worse punishment than rebellious OT believers (Heb 10:29).
• In a worse state than at first (2Pet 2:20).

       Heb 10:29
       The passage in Hebrews deals with the case of believers who
subjectively defect from the faith by means of theological apostasy: “How
much worse punishment do you think he will deserve who has trampled
underfoot the Son of God, and has regarded as unclean the blood of the

*
  See row 3 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
†
  See row 4 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
‡
  See rows 3-4 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia,
227.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                                Page 213
covenant by which he was sanctified, and has insulted the Spirit of grace?”
(Heb 10:29; TM). This full-fledged form of apostasy marks the defector as
completely having departed from the faith. An Arminian will assert that such
a person is no longer a believer,146 loses eternal life, and will be worse off in
hell than his OT counterparts. For example, to Forlines’ credit, he attempts
to limit the loss of eternal life to theological apostasy so that he can affirm
that salvation is by faith alone.147 Yet in light of the other two passages cited
above, his attempt to maintain salvation by faith alone by restricting the
forfeiture of eternal life to the loss of faith alone is open to serious question.

         2Pet 2:20
       In the other two passages, believers defect from the faith in a practical
manner while still remaining in the faith in terms of theological profession.
These Christians still believe in Christ, but for all practical purposes they
deny Christ by the way they live. In 2Pet 2:20, for example, believers
become morally entangled after having morally escaped: “For if after they
have escaped the defilements of the world by the knowledge of the Lord and
Savior Jesus Christ, they are again entangled in them and are overcome, the
last state has become worse for them than the first.” The text does not
indicate that their moral failure necessarily had ensued from a complete
theological departure from the faith. Their practical apostasy does not appear
as thoroughgoing as the theological apostasy described in the book of
Hebrews. The observation that the moral apostasy described by Peter does
not necessarily mark subjective departure from the faith discredits Forlines’
attempt to limit the loss of regeneration to the lack of perseverance in faith.
       The majority opinion among Arminians, as expressed by Shank and
Marshall, co-conditions the retention of regeneration on perseverance in
both faith and faithfulness (Illustration 76 + Illustration 78).* This majority
perspective in the Arminian camp is exegetically superior to Forlines’
attempt to condition the retention of regeneration on perseverance in faith
alone.148 Of course, Forlines would agree with his Arminian counterparts
that moral apostates are dead spiritually, but where he evidently would part
company with many of his fellow conditionalists is in his placing moral
defection after theological departure. In other words, Forlines’ hypothesis
would seem to presume that the moral apostates already have defected from
the faith theologically and died spiritually before they succumbed to moral
apostasy. If so, he would invert the anticipated order apostasia.
                      Illustration 80. Inverted Ordo Apostasia
Ordo Apostasia: postconversion faith dies → spiritual death →   works die
Ordo Apostasia:   theological apostasy    → spiritual death → moral apostasy

*
    See row 1 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
Page 214                                Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

       By placing moral apostasy after theological apostasy, while
interjecting spiritual death as the intermediate result,* Forlines could
diminish the perception that he is teaching moral security—a security
conditioned on one’s morality. In doing so, he could attempt to condition
retention of regeneration on faith alone.† The moral lapse occurs after the
loss of the new nature in this proposal. But as may be seen in a comparison
with Illustration 75. Natural Ordo Salutis and Apostasia, an inverted ordo
apostasia, which places defection from Christian works after one ceases to
be a Christian, is not the order that one generally would anticipate from such
an Arminian argument.
                         Illustration 81. Forlines’ Inversion




        Pictorially, one may envision Forlines’ position as placing
regeneration as the buffer zone between faith and works. Faith keeps us
alive, and our regeneration keeps our works alive. In other words, these
works are living because they flow from a regenerate nature. Satan can kill
us by attacking our faith directly without having to saw through any
protective sleeve of works. However, if our regeneration keeps our works
alive, and our faith keeps our works alive, then what is left to keep our faith
alive? Presumably, we are to generate a shield of faith via our regenerate
nature by which to protect ourselves from such satanic onslaught. Perhaps
Forlines could consider Eph 6:16 as a case in point.


*
    See row 2 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
†
    Picirilli takes a perspective similar to Forlines. See Because versus Cause, 272.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                               Page 215
        Pragmatically, if it were possible to cease to be a Christian, then one
would expect it to come about because the Christian stopped reading his or
her Bible, stopped praying, stopped attending church, and stopped loving the
brethren. The believer’s faith could be expected to shrivel up and die in such
a case as a result of the believer ceasing to exercise his or her faith by means
of Christian works. According to the Arminian, this Christian would lose
eternal life as a result of this pragmatic defection. The natural sequence
would be: A believer would stop acting like a Christian, then stop believing
like a Christian, and then stop being a Christian.* One normally would not
anticipate an inverted order in which believers lose their faith, then lose
eternal life, and then stop reading their Bibles and praying.† The more
typical anticipation would be that a believer’s works would keep his or her
faith alive, not that a Christian would lose his or her faith out of the blue and
then stop performing Christian works.
        Even in the case of those Christians who have a tragedy strike
unexpectantly (such as a death of a loved one) and who lose their faith as a
result, it cannot be supposed that their faith was a helpless victim to their
circumstances. Biblically, it must be asserted that God would not allow a
tragedy to occur that was greater than the believer’s ability to endure
(1Cor 10:13). When tragedy comes, believers can overcome if they will
continue to avail themselves of God’s enabling strength through Bible
reading, prayer, and Christian fellowship. On the other hand, if believers
cease to do these things, then they may cease to believe. Cessation of
Christian works can be expected, at least as a rule of thumb, to precede
cessation of Christian faith. Moral apostasy can be expected, as a general
rule, to come before theological apostasy.‡ Such an observation is by no
means detrimental to Forlines’ overall argument, however.§ On the contrary,
as already expressed in Illustration 75, one would expect Forlines to place
loss of faith after loss of works or to express the expected order from that
illustration in terms of its synonymous expression:
                    Illustration 82. Natural Ordo Apostasia
Ordo Apostasia:    moral apostasy →      theological apostasy → spiritual death

  See row 1 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
†
  See row 2 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
‡
  An extremely important question at that point arises: If a Christian ceases
doing all these things, then is he or she still a Christian even if he or she still
believes? Given the Arminian premise, would not spiritual death ensue even
before his or her faith was completely lost? See row 3 in Illustration 89.
Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
§
  See row 1 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
Page 216                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Any counterargument that places theological apostasy before moral
apostasy as the ordo leading to loss of regeneration in 2Pet 2:20 is reading
an assumption into the text rather than from it. One just as easy could
maintain that the moral apostates in this passage simply followed the
example of the false teachers in turning the grace of God into licentiousness
and (if Arminianism is true) lost their regeneration as a result of their moral
defection (cp. Jude 1:4).*
        The postulation that these morally-entangled believers abandoned the
faith itself is without foundation, much less that they abandoned the faith
before becoming entangled in a moral web of lies.149 The more reasonable
supposition is that these believers simply were denying their Master morally
rather than theologically. To speak idiomatically, they wanted to have their
cake and eat it too. They simultaneously wanted the grace of God and the
pleasure of sin. As a result, they abandoned the faith morally, but they did
not abandon their faith theologically. They had not abandoned the doctrine
of salvation by grace through faith alone. On the contrary, they were
standing firm in the doctrine of salvation by grace through faith, but they
were abusing it. They thought it was quite all right if that faith was alone.
                   Illustration 83. Rudimentary Carnal Security
Ordo Apostasia:      moral apostasy →      theological retention →    spiritual life




       If one were to grant Forlines’ argument (that retention of eternal life
is granted on the condition of continuation in faith alone), then the most
natural conclusion is that these moral apostates still retained their faith in
Christ alone and, consequently, still possessed eternal life. Satan had cut
through their works, but he had not cut through their faith. If salvation is by
faith alone, then their salvation was still secure. Conditionalists would

*
    See row 4 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                                Page 217
criticize advocates of carnal security even at this rudimentary level, that is,
for wrongly providing security to morally-carnal believers when no such
security exists in the minds of the conditionalists.150 At the very least, those
in the conditionalistic camp insist that so-called carnal Christians cannot be
sure of their salvation because of their carnal behavior. Yet more often than
not, conditionalists further will insist that carnal security is false security,
that those believers living in a carnal lifestyle were either not saved initially
or lost their salvation subsequently. According to conditionalists, gross
immorality must be avoided by those believers who hope to make it to
heaven.
        Marrowists, in turn, would criticize conditionalists as trying to offset
carnal security with moral security. Soteriological postconversional
conditionalism is rejected in Marrowism as teaching salvation by works in
the guise of moral performance. Forlines endeavors to avoid this criticism by
limiting his conditionalism to perseverance in faith, where the only way one
can lose eternal life is by defecting from the faith. By means of this
argument, Forlines apparently intends to condition one’s security on faith
alone. Nonetheless, this order of apostasy has been found unnatural in the
cases of death by means of moral entanglement. Yet there are cases where
theological defection comes before moral defection.* A list of such passages
is provided in The Outer Darkness and is unnecessary in such a discussion
as the present one in which Arminians would agree that believers can
succumb to false doctrine and, in so doing, cease to believe the gospel. Since
such cases mutually are acknowledged to exist (in which Christians may
cease to believe in salvation by grace through faith but still may be
performing Christian works), I will concede that this ordo theoretically
would work for Forlines. Of course, he still would have to prove that
regeneration (rather than rewards) is lost.
        If, on the other hand, there are cases where the loss of eternal life
comes as a result of moral apostasy,† then Forlines’ thesis that eternal life is
conditioned on faith alone is disproven immediately. To demonstrate that
Arminianism cannot limit its ordo apostasia so that salvation is by faith
alone, one need only find one exception to Forlines’ rule that the loss of
eternal life is always conditioned on the loss of faith. If there is any case in
which Arminianism requires that the loss of eternal life be conditioned on
works, then his thesis that Arminianism can avoid teaching salvation by
works in its ordo apostasia has been disproven. The Judean example of
apostasy is a case in point in that these believers apparently were still
believers even though they were morally defective. If their retention of
eternal life is conditioned on faith alone, as Forlines’ theology would

*
    See row 2 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
†
    See row 3 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
Page 218                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
suggest, then they still possess eternal life, and my rebuttal of Forlines’
thesis is confirmed.

       1Tim 5:8
        Forlines’ sequence stumbles even worse, however, when it encounters
the third text: “But if anyone does not provide for his own, and especially for
those of his household, he has denied the faith and is worse than an
unbeliever” (1Tim 5:8). The crucial questions are: In what sense has this
apostate denied, repudiated, disowned (arneomai) the faith? Is the person in
question no longer considered a believer? The weight of the evidence is
decisively opposed to Forlines’ imposition upon the doctrine of moral
apostasy.
                                    The Faith
        Like Forlines, Lenski shares the Arminian perspective that apostates
lose eternal life. Nevertheless, Lenski concurs with my assessment that the
person in question in 1Tim 5:8 is a believer: “Paul does not say that he has
lost his faith” (italics his).151 What the moral apostate abandons is the faith
not his faith (i.e., this apostate departs from the objective faith not from his
subjective faith). Lenski bases this assessment in part upon the articular
construction of the term the faith. Granted, the articular construction was
used earlier in the epistle (1Tim 1:19) to refer to an objective apostasy that
entails subjective apostasy where some apostates suffered shipwreck of the
faith and, in so doing, lost their faith (NAS).* Their objective apostasy was
theologically subjective. However, the apostasy in 1Tim 5:8 is limited
explicitly by Paul to the moral arena. The moral apostate, on this occasion,
does not lose his faith—his faith remains theologically and subjectively
intact. This particular morally-dysfunctional believer is still a believer.
        Given a premise of eternal security, the securitist would presume that
even though this carnal believer acts worse than the unsaved, this carnal
believer remains saved. Thus, carnal security is not false security.
Nonetheless, Shank appeals to the context to object to Chafer's listing of
1Tim 5:8 as a proof text for eternal security. One certainly can understand
Shank’s consternation. Are securitists not begging the question by assuming
that the carnal believer still is saved when just two verses earlier had Paul
affirmed that the moral apostate is dead? According to Arminians such as
Lenski, Marshall, and Shank, the morally apostate believer in 1Tim 5:6 is
spiritually dead: “She who gives herself to wanton pleasure is dead even
while she lives.” So Shank would object that advocates of eternal security,
such as ourselves, are ignoring the obvious implication of the context, which
in his mind implies that the moral apostate in 1Tim 5:8 is spiritually dead.

*
  Lenski perceives correctly that row 4 is the proper Arminian option for this
text. See Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                             Page 219
        My objective, then, is to use the Arminian argument as advanced by
Lenski, Marshall, and Shank to limit the number of contenders on the
hermeneutical playing field. By momentarily adopting their premise of
conditional security, I will thoroughly dispense with Forlines’ hypothesis by
showing that the loss of regeneration can be the direct result of moral
defection in Arminianism. That is, it is my intention to demonstrate that the
most natural Arminian interpretation of this passage is that these believers
lose their eternal life because of their lapse in works, not because of their
lapse in faith. In so doing, I will prove that Arminianism conditions final
salvation on works.
                                   Worse Than
        Paul states explicitly that the moral apostate in 1Tim 5:8 is worse
than an unbeliever. Paul is not making a nonsensical statement to the effect
that the person is an unbeliever who is worse than an unbeliever. After all,
how could an unbeliever be worse than an unbeliever? Or as Hart aptly
expresses it: “One cannot be an unbeliever and be worse than an unbeliever
at the same time!”152 Paul’s contrastive use of cheiron (worse) demands that
this moral apostate be regarded as a believer. Marshall acknowledges that
the moral apostate is a nominal believer. Of course, for Marshall this means
that the person is now a believer in name only. This perspective might be
expressed by describing such a believer as being a shell of the person he was
before he committed moral apostasy. In Marshall’s eyes, the moral apostate
no longer has eternal life within him, so he is an empty shell. Even so, by
Marshall’s own admission, a moral apostate is still a nominal believer and
therefore still bears the name believer.153 Hence, such a person still believes
in Christ. Therefore, on the basis of Lenski’s articular observation and even
more so on the basis of Marshall’s nominal admission, it may be deduced
that the person in this text still is regarded implicitly by Paul as having faith
in Christ. But this observation drives a stake in the heart of Forlines’
proposal.
                        Illustration 84. Moral Apostasy
Ordo Apostasia:    moral apostasy → spiritual death →       theological apostasy

        If Arminianism is true, then this man died as a result of his
breakdown in moral performance, not as a result of his departure from the
faith. Since his loss of salvation was not based on faith alone, his salvation
was not based on faith alone. Arminianism is shown to teach salvation by
works. Forlines’ argument to the counter wise dies.
Page 220                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                         Illustration 85. Moral Security




        Specifically, in the case of 1Tim 5:6-8, this Arminian Satan is able to
hack through the believer’s works and cut into the believer’s regeneration
and kill the believer without severing the believer’s faith.154 According to
this Arminian perspective, a believer who subcomes to moral apostasy loses
eternal life, and according to Shank, such a believer quite possibly may lose
eternal life without even knowing it! The believer, and he is still a believer,
is spiritually dead because of his lack of good works, even though he thinks
he is still alive because he still has faith!*
                                 Arminian Death
        Marshall and Shank cite 1Tim 5:8 in conjunction with its contextual
equivalent in 1Tim 5:6 to indicate that a believer who becomes morally
worse than an unbeliever becomes spiritually dead (i.e., unregenerate).
Although moral apostasy is considered a practical (rather than a theological)
denial of the faith by advocates of this persuasion, moral apostasy is
nevertheless regarded as being just as lethal soteriologically as theological
apostasy. Such a believer still has faith, but it is no longer saving faith.


*
  Like Illustration 78. Inverted Ordo of Satanic Attack (p. 211), Illustration 85.
Moral Security is detrimental to Forlines’ thesis because as both illustrations are
read from the inside out to show the contingent relationships of the components,
regeneration is seen to be contingent on works. In the present illustration faith is
contingent on regeneration, and regeneration is contingent on works. In the
previous illustration regeneration is contingent on works, and works are
contingent on faith. Unlike the former illustration, however, the present
illustration represents the actual sequence of events necessitated by Arminian
exegesis, not a mere hypothetical possibility. If Arminianism were true, then it
truly would be found to condition retention of regeneration on works in these
types of passages.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                                Page 221
        Since saving faith generally is perceived by insecuritists as consisting
of perseverance in faith-works, moral defection from works is thought to be
just as deadly as theological defection from the faith. After all, faith without
works is dead (Jam 2:17). So according to Arminians, a person who has faith
but no longer has works is no longer saved. Thus, being dead is made
equivalent to being unsaved. This composite Arminian approach demolishes
Forlines’ argument that eternal security can be conditioned on perseverance
in faith alone within Arminianism.
                  Illustration 86. Composite Arminian Argument
       1. Theological believers can be moral apostates (1Tim 5:8).
       2. Moral apostates are spiritually dead (1Tim 5:6).
       3. Therefore, theological believers can be moral apostates and lose
          eternal life without losing their faith since they still are theological
          believers.

       Basically, by pitting Lenski, Marshall, and Shank against Forlines, I
have been able to use their triadic contestation to destroy Forlines’
contention that Arminian security can be conditioned on perseverance in
faith alone. Far to the contrary, when considered exegetically and if given
logical consistency, Arminian security necessarily conditions eternal
security on perseverance in both faith and works. Conditionalism teaches
moral security. The loss of eternal life cannot be limited to theological
apostasy. Moral apostasy may occur before theological apostasy. And if
moral apostasy occurs first, then, given the Arminian premise, the apostate
loses eternal life before losing his or her faith. Conditionalists cannot affirm
salvation by faith alone. They must avow salvation by faith-works.* One
cannot teach death-by-works and maintain salvation-by-faith-alone.
                                 Moral Denial
       Having established that Arminians must condition their salvation on
both faith and works (a point which readily is evident in mainstream
Arminianism), I will now deal with Marshall and Shank’s contestation that
the loss of eternal life is contextually in view. In equating the moral failure
of 1Tim 5:8 with the alleged spiritual death in 1Tim 5:6, both Marshall and
Shank fail to note the clash that they create with 2Thess 3:6-15. In 1Tim 5:8,
we encounter a believer who fails to provide for his own household. Paul
says that this believer has denied the faith. Thus, this sin of omission is
apostasy due to moral failure—it is moral apostasy. Marshall and Shank no
longer regard this moral apostate to be a genuine believer—a brother in
Christ. Certainly, James would concur that a believer who does not provide
for the needs of his own family has a dead faith (Jam 2:15-17). So here is a

*
    See row 4 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia, 227.
Page 222                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
believer who, because of moral apostasy, has a dead faith and is worse than
an unbeliever. Understandably, Arminians insist that this person has died
spiritually. Their whole argument for conditional security would collapse
otherwise. If this man is still a genuine believer and regarded as a brother
even though he has a dead faith, then obviously (1) carnal Christians are
saved from hell, (2) James must be talking about being saved from
something else other than hell, and (3) Paul is talking about being dead in
some other capacity than losing eternal life.* Arminians will no longer be
able to condition the retention of regeneration on moral performance in any
of these passages if it is admitted that the person in question is still a genuine
believer. What about Forlines? Would he be able to condition the retention
of eternal life on perseverance in faith independent of moral performance?
No. Even perseverance in faith cannot be maintained as a soteriological
condition because Arminians cannot allow a carnal believer to be saved by
perseverance in a dead faith. The stakes are high.
       When considering the related passage in 2Thess 3:6-15, one finds
examples of believers who Paul considers brethren, who are leading unruly
and undisciplined lives, doing no work at all, and eating the bread of others!
Basically, these non-working Christian brethren are eating the food provided
for them by their working Christian brethren. Instead of working to provide
for their own families and their fellow brethren, these non-working Christian
brethren are mooching off their fellow working brethren. Yet Paul says
explicitly not to regard these parasitic believers as enemies but admonish
them as brothers, even if these leeches refuse to heed Paul’s instruction to
work! Wow! Saved leeches! The non-providing believer in 1Tim 5:8 is
worse than an unbeliever to be sure, but these non-working brethren in
2Thess 3:6-15 are far worse than the non-providing believer.

        Unbeliever > non-providing believer > non-working brother

       Amazingly, Paul wants us to regard these busybody freeloaders as
brethren. Surely, James would preach them a sermon! After all, according to
Paul these loafers were doing no work at all, and James insists that faith
without works is dead. Obviously, James and Paul are talking about the same
kind of works. No doubt about it, these believers are dead. James and Paul
concur that such believers are dead in that Paul had just indicated as much in
1Tim 5:6. The sister in Christ in that verse, who had given herself over to
wanton pleasure, was dead. Does this mean that those believers with dead
faith had become lost, that they had lost eternal life? No!


*
 See discussion pertaining to Illustration 88. The Death of Eternal Life is
Contested (p. 227) for suggestive list of possibilities.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                                Page 223
        Paul says to keep aloof from every brother who acts in this manner
(2Thess 3:6), but in that same statement he shows that he still regards them
as Christian brethren and concludes by instructing us to admonish a believer
who acts like this (and who insists on continuing to act like this) as a
brother in Christ. We are to treat and regard such believers as brethren in
v. 15, just as Paul does in v. 6, regardless of their practice. Paul equates
being a believer with being a brother and a brother with being a believer (cp.
1Tim 6:2). So what gives Marshall and Shank the right to go against Paul
and claim that moral apostates are no longer really brethren or genuine
believers? Whatever else may be said about these moral apostates, several
observations are sufficient: (1) These moral apostates still believe in Jesus,
(2) the NT still regards them as our brothers in Christ, and (3) the NT does
not tone down the seriousness of their offense.
        Paul says that moral apostates have denied the faith, and he uses deny
(arneomai) again in Tit 1:16 in a related example regarding moral apostasy:
“They [morally apostate believers] profess to know God, but by their deeds
they deny Him.” From the perspective by such believers of themselves, they
were still professing faith in God; they had not disowned God. As far as they
are concerned, they still believe. Their deeds rather than their lips deny
Christ. A charge of moral denial rather than theological denial is clearly
intended by Paul. In view of 1Tim 5:8, the presumption should be granted
that Paul still regards these moral apostates in Tit 1:16 as believing in Christ
since he limits their denial to their works. As far as Paul is concerned, they
still believe even though in some sense they are dead. To use James’ related
term, their faith is dead, but it is still faith. The facts that their faith had died
and that they had died (in some undefined sense) do not give us the right to
regard them as anything less than believers—Christian brothers. Whatever
else may be said about this death, it does not involve one being regarded as
anything less than a Christian brother. These morally-dead brothers are still
brothers in Christ.
                                     By Works
        The Greek word for deeds is ergon, which is the typical Greek word
for works. The expression by works in Tit 1:16 is a dative of means, which
means that these works are the instrumental means by which the moral
apostate denies Christ in this verse. For example, when Paul says that “a
man is justified by faith apart from works” (Rom 3:28), he likewise uses the
dative of means to show that faith is the instrumental means by which we are
saved. In the same manner, since it is by works that the professing believer
denies Christ in Tit 1:16 and since it is by this same ergonic denial that the
moral apostate loses his or her salvation in Arminianism, the Arminian is
found to be teaching salvation by works. Arminianism twists itself into
many pitiful knots in trying to assert that we are saved by faith apart from
works but unsaved by works.155
Page 224                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Misthology, in contrast, does not have any problem with ergonic
salvation because it recognizes that a salvation by faith apart from works
cannot be equated with a salvation by faith and works. Salvation by works
(ergon) is ergonic; salvation by faith apart from works is not ergonic. More
theologians need to take a class in Ergonomics 101. But the reason that
Arminians struggle so much with simple ergonomics is that such
fundamental distinctions are not available to the Arminian. The only hope
Arminianism has in this discussion of moral apostasy by which to maintain
salvation by faith alone is that found in the minority opinion offered by
Forlines. However, the majority opinion among Arminians obliterates that
hope because the mainstream perception correctly deduces that moral
apostasy may, on certain exegetical occasions, predate theological apostasy.
The expression, “He was dead before he hit the floor,” may be applied aptly
to the moral apostate in such passages, “He was dead before his faith hit the
floor.”
             Illustration 87. Majority Arminian Ordo Apostasia
Ordo Apostasia:   moral apostasy → spiritual death →      theological apostasy

       As far as Paul is concerned in 1Tim 5:8 (and probably in Tit 1:16),
the believer who fails morally is still a believer theologically. According to
the Arminian, such a believer dies spiritually. Consequently, for the
Arminian, morality is the means to immortality. Moral steadfastness is the
means by which the believer keeps eternal life. The Arminian antidote to
carnal security is moral security. This statement holds true even for those
Arminians who may try to take Forlines’ approach. As has been
demonstrated deductively in my examination of 1Tim 5:8, Forlines’ attempt
to limit the Arminian retention of regeneration to perseverance in faith
cannot withstand scrutiny.
       Even if Forlines were successful in evading the assessment of his
fellow Arminians (who directly condition retention of regeneration on one’s
moral performance), he still would have to contend with the admission of
other Arminians that perseverance in faith is a moral virtue. In order to
prove that he does not condition salvation on moral virtue, he would have to
disprove the affirmation that perseverance in faith is a moral virtue. But
there again, I join hands with Forlines’ fellow Arminians in demonstrating
that perseverance in faith is indeed a moral virtue. Forlines cannot win for
losing. Even if Arminian security could be shown not to be conditioned on
moral apostasy, it still would be conditioned on perseverance in faith, which
is a moral virtue. Arminians trip all over one another in trying to avoid the
implications of their own theology. Morality is the means to immortality in
Arminianism. One simply cannot condition salvation on faith alone and
simultaneously condition salvation on perseverance in faith. Moral virtue,
merit, and works will slip in through the door of perseverance.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                           Page 225
                                  Profession
        A brief word will suffice in response to the Reformed camp regarding
moral apostasy. In their attempt to explain away the enigma that exists
between conditional security and morality, those in the Reformed camp seize
upon the word profess in Tit 1:16: “They profess to know God, but by their
works they deny Him” (TM). The Reformed quip will be, “Moral apostates
are professors not possessors of eternal life. By means of their works, moral
apostates necessarily nullify their profession and demonstrate their lack of
possession.” Bottom line, the Reformed tactic is to deny that those who
morally deny the faith were ever saved in the beginning. Perhaps such a
tactic might be plausible in Tit 1:16, but one would have to bury one’s head
in the sand to ignore the fact that the apostate was indeed a genuine believer
in the related cross-reference of 1Tim 5:8.
        While it is the moral apostate who professes to be a believer in
Tit 1:16, it is Paul who professes that the moral apostate is a believer in
1Tim 5:8. By acknowledging that the moral apostate is worse than an
unbeliever, Paul implicitly refuses to (necessarily) regard the moral apostate
as an unbeliever. Instead, Paul matter-of-factly regards the moral apostate as
a believer in this verse. Hendriksen is therefore in error when he asseverates:
“Lack of positive action, the sin of omission, gives the lie to his profession
of faith (subjective sense)” (emphasis his).156 To the contrary, Lenski is
correct to reject the notion that the passage can be limited to a subjective
apostasy which does not entail apostasy from the genuine objective faith. In
any event, the implicit profession of subjective faith on the part of the
apostate comes from the pen of Paul, not merely from the lips of the
apostate. To be sure, there is an incongruity between lips and life of the
moral apostate in Tit 1:16, but it is not a soteriological incongruity between
his profession and possession of eternal life. What Paul denies in that
passage is that the moral apostate knows God. Even if one were to define
eternal life as knowing God (Jn 17:3), one would still have to discuss the
potential difference between having eternal life and experiencing it. But
even apart from such considerations, Paul’s statement need not be construed
as meaning soteric knowledge. Carnal Christians do not know God in the
same way that Paul knows God for the simple reason that immature
believers do not have the same knowledge of God that mature believers
do.157 Even so, their lack of mature knowledge or experiential knowledge
cannot be equated with lack of saving knowledge.
                                  Silent Killer
        When 1Tim 5:8 and Tit 1:16 are viewed jointly, it becomes apparent
that moral apostasy may result from either sins of omission or from sins of
comission. The believer who has fallen into moral apostasy still may be
sincerely professing to know God and thereby reveal that he is not even
aware that he has committed apostasy. As Shank correctly notes: “He still
professes faith, and all seems well to him. He is quite unaware of his
Page 226                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
           158
apostasy.”     This Arminian argument by Shank refutes the Arminian
argument by Forlines that life-stealing apostasy is limited to willful,
presumptuous, high-handed sins. All forms of apostasy are deadly. The
believer who succumbs to moral apostasy is a living corpse even though she
(1Tim 5:6) or he (1Tim 5:8) still believes in Christ for eternal life.
       McCoy also suggests that moral apostasy is the subject matter in
another related passage: “Specifically in 2 Tim 2:12b the denial in view is
not a single act of denial of sinful selfishness but is rather descriptive of a
general failure or breakdown in discipleship.”159 Even those believers who
deny Christ simply by living a life that demonstrates a general failure in
discipleship will be denied by Christ. If a believer slowly retrogresses
morally, who is to say at what point along the way that such a believer loses
his or her spiritual vitality. Would it not be a slow, imperceptible death as
Shank maintains? Securitists cannot agree with Shank that such a death
would be soteriological, but they certainly can agree with him that it could
be imperceptible.160
                             Half-Hearted Security
       A half-hearted affirmation of conditional security, such as that offered
by Forlines, is hardly adequate to deal with the observations that come from
a careful study regarding the ramifications of moral apostasy. The full-
fledged conditional security provided by the advocates of the majority
opinion among Arminians is much truer to the texts dealing with such
apostasy. The death-dealing effects of apostasy cannot be limited to
theological apostasy or to high-handed sins. The arguments provided by
Lenski, Marshall, and Shank are also superior to the half-hearted attempt at
eternal security found in the Reformed camp. One cannot stand on the
Reformed sidelines and claim that the only people susceptible to moral
apostasy are those who falsely profess to have faith in Christ. If one is going
to actually enter into the arena and contend for the faith where the text
stands as referee, one must admit that Paul is the one legitimately professing
that genuine believers may give in to moral apostasy.
                          Heavyweight Contenders
       Lightweight contenders such as Forlines and Hendriksen already have
been disqualified from stepping into this heavyweight ring to engage
exegetically in battle regarding the impact of moral apostasy. Only two
heavyweight contenders are qualified exegetically to face off in this
hermeneutical matchup between NOSAS and OSAS. Full-fledged
conditional security stands in one corner, while full-fledged unconditional
security is chomping at the bit in the other corner.
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                                 Page 227
               Illustration 88. The Death of Eternal Life is Contested




       At the opening bell, Lenski immediately launches a NOSAS jab:
“The spiritual life in her died.”161 This comment, however, opens Lenski up
to an immediate counterpunch by OSAS: “How can eternal life die?” After
this almost devastating right cross, the sports announcer hurriedly informs
the fans: “This spiritual life is eternal life.” In the ensuing flurry of punches
from OSAS which follow, OSAS asks pounding questions: “Why must
being dead signify loss of regeneration in either 1Tim 5:6 or Jam 2:17? Why
could death not simply signify moral death, practical death, familial death,
soulical death, dynamic death, or misthological death?162 Why must denial
of Christ by works in 2Tim 2:12 result in a denial by Christ of faith?” At the
conclusion of the heavyweight fight, everyone agreed that it was well fought
and well worth attending.

         Summation
             Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian Ordo Apostasia*
1     NOSAS by faith:     works die    →      faith dies      →   spiritual death
2     NOSAS by faith:     faith dies   →    spiritual death   →     works die
3     NOSAS by works:     faith dies   →      works die       →   spiritual death
4     NOSAS by works:     works die    →    spiritual death   →     faith dies




*
    Row 1 = Illustration 76. Ordo of Satanic Attack on Faith Alone, 210.
    Row 2 = Illustration 81. Forlines’ Inversion, 214.
    Row 3 = Illustration 78. Inverted Ordo of Satanic Attack, 211.
    Row 4 = Illustration 85. Moral Security, 220.
Page 228                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                                   Rows 1-2
        Forlines’ noble attempt to counter the conclusion (that conditionalism
leads to salvation by works) by conditioning the retention of regeneration on
faith alone requires that the Arminian ordo apostasia be limited to the first
two NOSAS possibilities in Illustration 89. In row 1, the believer ceases
performing Christian works. His or her faith dies as a result, and spiritual
death ensues. Biblically, an Arminian might seek to implement Jam 2:14-26
as a proof text for this type of apostasy. Pragmatically, the conditionalist
might picture Christians who become cold and indifferent to the point that
they eventually cease to be biblical believers and lose eternal life as a result.
In row 2, the believer’s faith dies first; consequently, this person is no longer
a believer and loses eternal life as the outcome of losing his or her faith. As
in row 1, (loss of) salvation is conditioned on faith alone. Biblically, an
Arminian might consult Gal 5:4 for an example where infection of one’s
faith with legalism precedes a defection from the faith. Pragmatically, after
falling from the faith theologically, one would expect the behavior of such a
person to degrade into legalistic performance. Although the person in
question still may be going through the motions of being a Christian, his or
her good works are dead works since these works no longer flow from a
regenerate nature. Moral apostasy need not necessarily be limited to a
digression into immorality. A fall into legalism is just as lethal as a fall into
licentious behavior.
                                     Row 3
        In contrast to their predecessors, the remaining two rows picture
spiritual death coming as a direct result of a breakdown in one’s works.
Either one of these rows would be fatal to Forlines’ position. Fortunately for
him, row 3 has been included only for sake of theoretical completeness. The
supposition that spiritual death would wait until the death of one’s works
after one’s faith already had died is without reasonable foundation. Surely,
given the NOSAS premise, if one’s faith were to die, the loss of regeneration
would be immediate and not wait for the degradation of one’s works. As a
result, row 3 is removed from serious consideration and actually would
collapse into a row-2 sequence.
                                     Row 4
        Since row 3 reduces to row 2, row 4 is the crucial consideration
preventing Forlines’ thesis from making it out of the Arminian bullpen. For
this reason, the study in this present appendix has focused on the
significance regarding the case of moral apostasy in 1Tim 5:8 and its death-
dealing impact affirmed two verses earlier in 1Tim 5:6 to conclude that the
moral apostasy in 1Tim 5:8 results in the moral death described in 1Tim 5:6
so that Forlines cannot limit the deadly affects of apostasy to theological
apostasy. The deadly affects of apostasy ultimately must include moral
apostasy.163 Biblically, the moral defects described in the believer’s
character in 1Tim 5:6 and 1Tim 5:8 are sufficient grounds to pronounce the
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                              Page 229
believer dead even though she (v. 6) or he (v. 8) is still a believer in Christ.
Even though the person is still a believer, the faith of such a person is dead
according to Jam 2:14-26.
        Illustration 90. True Contenders for Arminian Ordo Apostasia
        1   NOSAS by faith:   works die    →     faith dies      →   spiritual death
        2   NOSAS by faith:   faith dies   →   spiritual death   →     works die
        3   NOSAS by works:   faith dies   →     works die       →   spiritual death
        4   NOSAS by works:   works die    →   spiritual death   →     faith dies

        Entertaining Jam 2:14-26 as a potential Arminian proof text for both
rows 1 and 4 is not by accident. Rather, this text reveals a very real problem
in the Arminian ordo. Whereas I, for my part, have admitted that row 3
collapses into the ordo presented in row 2, an evenhanded treatment of
row 1 by Forlines likewise would have to concede that row 1 gives way to
the ordo presented in row 4. The believer in question in Jam 2:14-26 is still a
believer and thus represents a row-4 ordo, where spiritual death comes as a
result of not working rather than of not believing. This believer’s faith has
