not yet deceased in the sense of ceased. Therefore, even though I have no
problem affirming the hypothetical possibility of a row-1 ordo, exegetically
one must reject this possibility if one is to interpret Jam 2:14-26 from an
Arminian premise. Logically, one would expect this to be the case since if
one simply looks at the chart, it will be apparent that rows 1 and 4 are
mutually exclusive as are rows 2 and 3.
        As for the pairing of rows 1 and 4, the questions to be answered are,
“In terms of biblical sequence from an Arminian premise, what happens first
after a believer’s works die? Does his faith die or does he die?” Spiritual
death does not wait around until its victim’s faith ceases in Jam 2:14-16. The
believer’s faith is dead long before it hits the floor in this context. Thus, as
already noted, the most natural supposition is that the people in question in
Jam 2:14-26, 1Tim 5:6,8, and 2Pet 2:20 still believe in Christ for eternal life.
Consequently, they are still believers in the NT sense of the word.
Consequently, row 1 is mentioned only as a theoretical possibility. Row 1
actually collapses into the ordo expressed in row 4. In addition to 1Tim 5:6,8
and 2Pet 2:20, a host of other texts (e.g., Acts 5:3-5; Rom 8:13; Gal 6:8;
1Jn 5:16) join their voices to affirm that row 4, rather than row 1, is the
proper representation of the Arminian position.164 If such texts are
describing spiritual death in terms of loss of regeneration as a result of moral
failure, as Arminianism supposes, then these texts are conditioning that
death directly on one’s works, not on one’s faith. The Arminian
interpretation of such texts must, out of logical necessity, reduce to a
religion of salvation by works. Salvation by faith alone is a myth in their
theology. A robust ordo apostasia proves far too much for Arminian
soteriology.
Page 230                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Now, to be sure, the Arminian will seek to redefine saving faith as a
commitment to moral performance in an attempt to deny that such a person
described in the above texts still has saving faith, but such a definition of
faith makes faith a work and is therefore not being honest with the subject
matter. The only way for the Arminian to avoid this conclusion is to beg the
question (as to whether or not a person can be an unregenerate believer) by
redefining faith so as to import works into saving faith in order to make
works inseparable from saving faith. But in doing so, conditionalists
necessarily deny justification by faith apart from works. Their theology puts
them in quite a quandary. The only way that Arminians can affirm that a loss
of salvation is conditioned on faith alone in such passages is to deny that
salvation is conditioned on faith alone by redefining faith!
        As for the pairing of rows 2 and 3, row 3 was only a theoretical
possibility mentioned for logical completeness. Row 2 is obviously correct.
Thus, rows 2 and 4 are the only true options for an Arminian ordo apostasia.
Arminian apostasy cannot be limited to either row but rather must
incorporate both possibilities to accurately depict the type of apostasy
occurring in various contexts. In Arminianism, spiritual death occurs as a
direct result of a breakdown in either the believer’s faith or in the believer’s
works. Both are valid possibilities within Arminian theology.
                                  Dead Works
        The explanation that was offered herein to explain, from an Arminian
perspective, how good works in row 2 could be considered dead works after
the loss of regeneration cannot be used to explain the nature of dead faith in
row 4. Unlike good works, saving faith does not come initially from a
regenerate nature in Arminianism. Rather, saving faith is the condition for
regeneration. Good works are not the condition for regeneration; faith is.
Faith comes before regeneration, and works come afterwards. Dead faith
cannot be equated with dead works as a potential postregenerational
phenomenon. If faith were to reoccur after the loss of regeneration, then
such faith would result in yet another occurrence of regeneration.
Accordingly, if faith still exists after the purported loss of regeneration, then
regeneration could not be lost because the faith upon which regeneration is
solely conditioned and which contingently sustains regeneration is still
intact.
        If Arminianism acknowledges the true nature of saving faith to be
trust in Christ alone for salvation, then it has no reasonable recourse by
which to explain the passages represented by row-4 apostasia. In such
passages, faith is presumed to still be existent but insufficient. Such faith is
presumed to be insufficient because it lacks moral performance. But if such
faith fails to save because it lacks moral performance, then salvation by faith
apart from works logically is denied. Even under the best of circumstances,
Arminianism still reduces to salvation by works in row 4 because (1) it
perceives spiritual death coming as a direct result of failure in one’s works,
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                             Page 231
(2) it denies that a soterically postmortem faith is sufficient for salvation,
and (3) it redefines saving faith so as to make works a necessary component
of such faith. Forlines’ half-hearted attempt at conditional security still
results in an immortality that is conditioned on the believer’s morality.
                           Half-Hearted Attempts
       Half-hearted attempts at conditional security by the Arminian camp
and at unconditional security by the Reformed camp are too seriously flawed
to be allowed serious contention. They are not serious contenders for a
biblical ordo apostasia. Realistically, full-fledged conditional security
versus full-fledged unconditional security are the only valid exegetical
alternatives. Either the believer’s security is conditioned on the believer’s
works, or the believer’s security is unconditional. No half-hearted
affirmation exists which can successfully condition the believer’s security on
postconversional faith apart from works. Full-fledged conditional advocates
include Lenski, Marshall, and Shank. Full-fledged unconditional
representatives include Hart, Hodges, McCoy, and the present author. The
following exegetical possibilities offered by OSAS for the three primary
passages dealing with cheiron may be noted:

• Morally apostate believers are worse than unbelievers in the way morally
apostate believers act (1Tim 5:8).
• Theologically apostate believers are temporally and misthologically
worse off than OT believers who suffered a quick, temporal death
(Heb 10:29).
• Morally apostate believers are temporally worse than and therefore
misthologically worse off than they were as immature believers when they
first came to faith (2Pet 2:20).

Conclusion
       Conditionalists want to condition the retention of regeneration on
faith and works in such a way so as to avoid teaching salvation by works.
One method employed by some conditionalists in this endeavor is to pose
that loss of regeneration is conditioned directly on the loss of saving faith,
not on one’s moral performance via one’s works. This attempt naturally
requires explanation from insecurities as to the actual sequence by which
eternal life is lost in their proposal in relation to faith and works. This study
of ordo apostasia has found the conditionalistic argument lacking logical
consistency on multiple fronts.
Page 232                 Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
           Illustration 91. Row 1 becomes Row 4
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                                Page 233
       The row-1 ordo is: no-works → no faith → death. While seemingly natural
enough, it will not withstand exegetical scrutiny. Realistically, Arminianism
requires that this ordo give way to a row-4 ordo: no-works→ death → faith.
Arminian death (i.e., the loss of eternal life) cannot be delayed until faith dies by
the conditionalistic exegesis in such passages. Rather, in this scheme of things,
as soon as a believer’s works die, the believer herself dies, even if the believer
still believes. This Arminian conclusion is necessitated by the ever popular proof
text of Jam 2:14-26 and collaborated by other similar texts. In such passages the
soteriological faith-works interpretation reduces to no-works → death → faith.
A conditionalistic interpretation of such texts must equate faith-works with no-
works → death → faith, in which death is attributable directly to works.
       The order in such passages is not: If you lose your faith, then you will lose
eternal life. (That would be a row-2 ordo.) Rather, a conditionalistic ordo in
which death is preceded by a breakdown in works immediately must proceed to
death before it moves on to a defection from faith. Such a conclusion is not only
necessitated by an exegesis of the passage and by the realization that death
would not await the defection from faith but also by the observation that to
assert otherwise would result in a rudimentary form of carnal security. Since
mainstream Arminianism denies the security of carnal believers, it cannot allow
itself to affirm that believers who succumb to a carnal lifestyle still have saving
faith. Carnal Christians still may have faith, but conditionalists by-and-large will
insist that such faith is no longer saving. Their theology demands as much.
       To use a concrete example, according to Jesus everyone looking on a
woman lustfully is guilty of adultery (Mt 5:28). And Paul warns believers that
adulterers will not inherit the kingdom (1Cor 6:19-20). The Arminian therefore
would conclude that adulterers will not enter the kingdom. Instead, adulterous
believers are thought to have lost eternal life and be bound for hell.
Consequently, in Arminian thought, a Christian addicted to Internet porn is
going to hell even if he still believes in Christ for eternal life.
       Such a perspective clearly conditions the loss of eternal life directly and
exclusively on the believer’s works. The person in question is still a believer,
but his faith will no longer save him. Perhaps, according to such theology, one
reason James might refer to such faith as dead faith is because it does not flow
from a regenerate nature. More importantly, however, the explicit reason this
faith is called dead faith is because it cannot save. Faith alone is insufficient to
sustain regeneration in Arminianism. Perhaps the most important clarification to
be gleaned from this study of ordo apistia is that the faith-works interpretation
of Jam 2:14-26 does not teach that retention of salvation is conditioned on faith
and works. Far to the contrary, the conditionalistic position must reduce the
condition for the retention of regeneration to works alone in this and similar
passages. To be sure, it might be argued that postconversional faith is a logical
precondition for such postconversional works. Nevertheless, postconversional
faith and postconversional works cannot be made co-conditions for regeneration.
Such a claim still would reduce to salvation by works, by making works a co-
condition. Neither logic nor the texts will permit such a soteric claim.
Page 234                        Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       Illustration 92. Row 1 becomes Rudimentary Carnal Security
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                             Page 235
      While this book affirms that carnal security is biblical, it does so from
a theological framework in which such a conclusion is logically consistent.
The rudimentary form of carnal security affirms that a carnal Christian
remains saved as long as he or she remains a believer. Arminianism logically
cannot allow carnal believers even this degree of security, however. Full-
blown carnal security, on the other hand, such as that advocated by the
present author, would acknowledge that believers still are considered
believers and treated as believers, in terms of possessing eternal life, even if
they cease to believe. Their hopes of inheriting eternal life may die, and in
that sense they may die misthologically, but they cannot die ontologically in
terms of losing their regeneration. The gift of eternal life which they
received is eternal. Therefore, while misthologists affirm the full
unconditional soteriological security of the carnal believer, they nonetheless
simultaneously affirm a misthological row-4 understanding of death in
which what is at stake is not the retention of regeneration but the full fruition
of regeneration. The gift of eternal life which has been planted as a seed
within believers is expected to grow up and blossom into a tree of life. But
whether or not it does so is conditioned on their faith-works.
      To speak concretely yet again (but this time from the perspective of
unconditional security), Christians who allow themselves to die as addicts to
pornographic cravings will have killed their chances of inheriting the
kingdom and of eating of the tree of life. Their potential rulership of the
kingdom will have been forfeited. The opportunity for such believers to live
as a king in that kingdom will have died, and in this sense they will have
died misthologically. As tragic as such consequences may be, they cannot be
equated with the loss of the gift of eternal life which qualifies even addicted
believers with the right to enter the kingdom of heaven. Entrance into the
kingdom is conditioned on new birth, not on new births (Jn 3:3-5). Contrary
to the prevalent Arminian contention, believers do not continually regain
regeneration (being born again and again and again) in order to qualify for
final soteric justification. Regeneration is not linear. The singular, punctiliar
experience of regeneration is sufficient to assure believers of entering the
kingdom. Living as a king or queen within that kingdom, however, will
require that they overcome pornographic tendencies.
      In a properly-enunciated faith-works definition, faith and works
mutualistically and misthologically work together to keep a believer’s hopes
of ruling in heaven alive. In a comprehensive faith-works doctrine, faith and
works are both necessary to acquire misthological salvation. A soteriological
affirmation of faith-works, on the other hand, places faith and works in a
symbiotic relationship in which works leech away the saving ability of faith.
Such soteriologically-mangled attempts at faith-works theology strangle
faith to death. MacArthur and Duty exemplify this faith-works strangulation.
A MacArthurian-Duty approach to faith-works leads to moral security and
therefore ultimately to hell.
Page 236                 Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
           Illustration 93. Row 3 becomes Row 2
Appendix 1. Moral and Theological Apostasy                           Page 237
      As noted, according to MacArthur, “God didn’t save us apart from
faith, and He doesn’t keep us apart from faith.”165 Such a statement affirms a
row-2 ordo: If Christians stop believing, they lose eternal life, even though
they still may be going through the motions of being a Christian.166 Perhaps
such MacArthurian and Arminian Christians think they still are saved
because of their actions. Nevertheless, they are fooling only themselves into
thinking that they are saved by basing their assurance on their works.
Mistaken assurance would be the natural consequence of such an approach
whereby the faith-works interpretation conditions the retention of
regeneration on perseverance in faith alone. Works are but a
postconversional precondition for such faith. However, in reality Reformed
thought does not condition this retention on faith alone. Far to the contrary,
Reformed exegesis necessarily conditions soteric retention on works alone in
passages such as Jam 2:14-26. By adopting a soteric faith-works perspective
in Faith Works, MacArthurianism logically and exegetically commits itself
to an interpretation that conditions getting into heaven on works alone in
some passages and on faith alone in other passages. Doing so poses an
insurmountable problem for such soteriology, not only because it denies
salvation by faith alone in its overall approach, but because it obviously pits
faith alone versus works alone in antithetical juxtaposition.
      For the misthologist, on the other hand, it is a harmonious apposition.
In a text such as Jam 2:14-26, postconversional faith is the precondition for
postconversional works, and these works, in turn, are the sole condition for a
salvation from a merciless judgment pertaining to rewards in heaven.
Although these types of passages condition misthological salvation on works
alone, another class of passages conversely conditions mistholic salvation on
faith alone and inversely regards works as the postconversional precondition
for such postconversional faith. The row-2 ordo acknowledges such
passages. Mistholic salvation is conditioned directly on faith in such
passages. But again, to qualify for such salvation, works are necessary as a
postconversional precondition to keep such faith misthologically alive. To
speak jointly, my doctrinal analysis of ordo apostasia requires that both
row-4 and row-2 theologically be affirmed as true. My mistholic faith-works
interpretation acknowledges that some passages exegetically present one
side of that truth while other passages present the other side of that
complementary perspective. A proper faith-works interpretation recognizes
that some passages bring faith to the foreground while other passages bring
works to the foreground.167
        In order for salvation from eternal damnation to be conditioned on
faith alone, the attending loss of such salvation (if such loss is possible)
logically must be conditioned on faith alone. From a logician’s point of
view, the attempt on the part of some insecuritists to condition the believer’s
security directly and strictly on the believer’s theological perseverance in
faith rather than on the believer’s moral perseverance in faithfulness is to be
Page 238                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
appreciated. The acknowledgment on the part of such conditionalists that
salvation and the loss of salvation must be based upon faith alone admittedly
demonstrates a concern for logical consistency and biblical fidelity. Other
logistical considerations, however, doom such noble attempts to failure.
Even if conditionalists were successful in demonstrating the hypothetical
feasibility of such an approach, perseverance in faith must itself still be
considered a work. Therefore, any attempt to condition soteric salvation on
perseverance in faith is an aberration from the biblical affirmation of
salvation by faith apart from works.
        The endeavor on the part of such insecuritists to condition loss of
salvation on faith alone is in itself a confession that salvation must be by
faith alone and consequently a logical admission that such salvation cannot
be conditioned on perseverance in faith, since perseverance in faith is a
work. Consequently, one argument implemented for OSAS in the present
work is to stress that perseverance in faith results in a reward rather than a
gift. Notwithstanding the sufficiency of this argument for OSAS, the present
appendix has further demolished the conditionalistic argument by
demonstrating that conditionalism cannot limit loss of salvation to the loss
of faith alone. Conditionalism leads necessarily to the conclusion that the
salvation which was supposed to be conditioned on faith alone actually is
conditioned on both faith and works since the loss of either faith or works
results in the loss of salvation. NOSAS ultimately must concede that the loss
of regeneration is conditioned directly on faith in some of their proof texts
but directly on works in other of their proof texts. Duty was correct to
concede that conditionalism requires that faith and works be considered co-
conditions for the insecuritist. Lack of either faith or works results in an
Arminian death and therefore in the death of Arminianism.
       OSAS agrees with NOSAS that the believer is in danger of death. The
major difference is that OSAS perceives that death is a multifaceted term.
Securitists acknowledge that believers may die temporally, prematurely,
experientially, and misthologically. Yet securitists find insuperable
exegetical and logistical problems in affirming that a believer may die
ontologically. Whereas insurmountable problems exist for conceiving how it
would be possible for a believer actually to lose the free gift of eternal life,
no difficulty prevents OSAS from admitting that the believer who succumbs
to a substandard performance is susceptible to various forms of death.
Apostasy is possible and certainly not profitable. Soteriological loss of
regeneration, however, is impossible.
                  Appendix 2.
       Preconditions and Postconditions
       Introduction
        KISS—Keep It Simple Saint—is the approach advocated by many
Christian writers and expected by many Christian readers. While dummied
down versions of Christianity certainly have their place, a diet limited to that
type of content is certain to lead to the false impression that Christianity is
only for dummies. Lewis rightly has exhorted us not to be intellectual
slackers. Biblical mandates indicate that Christian maturity is not for the
intellectual lazy. Simplicity is not always the best policy.168 Complexity is a
theological necessity in a religion that embraces such doctrines as the
Trinity. Rather than limit ourselves to KISS, I will investigate some of the
considerations that have been implemented in my distinctions between
preconditions and postconditions. Nevertheless, with illustrations and
summations, KISS will not be utterly abandoned.

       Preconditions
       In logic, a precondition is a prerequisite condition that has to be met
before the main argument can have any value. For example, the argument,
“If you hit the baseball with a bat, the baseball will move,” presumes as a
precondition that the baseball is not stuck in dried cement. Similarly, in
computer programming, a precondition is a condition that must always be
true just prior to the operation of some component of code. If a precondition
is violated, the execution of that section of code may fail to give the
expected result. Similarly, in mathematics, a quotient is defined only for
divisors other than zero. You cannot divide by zero, in other words. So a
program that calculates the quotient of a number being inputted as the
divisor would have as its precondition that the inputted number not be zero.

       Conditions
        In conditional sentences, the protasis (if) states the condition for the
apodosis (then). Hitting the baseball, for example, is the stated condition
under which the baseball will move in the above conditional sentence. The
effect, which is the ball moving, is the apodosis: “If (protasis) you hit the
ball, then (apodosis) the ball will move.” Typically, the protasis is placed
first in a conditional statement but not always. The order can be reversed:
“The ball will move, if (protasis) you hit it.” Regardless of the stated order,
the logical condition and cause for the ball’s movement is your hitting it.
Page 240                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                 Illustration 94. Typical Causation: A ⇒ B*
Cause-Effect relation (A ⇒ B)                                         A⊂B
If (A) protasis, then (B) apodosis.
If (A) you hit the ball, then (B) it will move (hit ⇒ move).
If (A) it is an apple, then (B) it is a fruit (apple ⇒ fruit).
If (A) the protasis is true, then (B) the apodosis must be true also.
Deductive certainty.

       As to my inclusion of apple ⇒ fruit in the cause-effect category, a
word of explanation is in order. Deductive certainty makes an apple being a
fruit more than an inference but less than an equivalence. The non-extensive
deductive nature of this apple ⇒ fruit relation is easily seen:

       1. Any sweet tasting plant produce grown on a tree is a fruit.
       2. An apple is a sweet tasting plant produce grown on a tree.
       3. Therefore, an apple is (i.e., must be) a fruit.

        If apple ⇒ fruit were simply describing a definitional relation, the
protasis would be semantically coextensive with the apodosis. But
obviously, not all fruits are apples. For that matter, fruit is defined
technically and botanically more broadly than simply being a sweet tasting
plant produce grown on a tree. Although all sweet tasting plant produce
grown on trees are fruit, not all fruit is a sweet tasting plant produce grown
on trees. So my statement about the apple is a deduction rather than a mere
definition. Likewise, Jesus is not trying to define what bad fruit is when He
says that a bad tree produces bad fruit (Mt 7:17). He is not suggesting that if
a good tree produced good fruit and if you were to put that fruit in a bowl for
months, then that fruit would never go bad. Jesus is not defining bad fruit as
fruit grown on a bad tree. Instead, He is speaking in terms of causation, not
in terms of definition. The Lord is providing a cause-effect relationship: A
bad tree causes/produces bad fruit. Being produced by a bad tree is the stated
condition under which bad fruit is produced.
        In regards to my analogy from computer programming, the operation
of the code is the condition for generating the quotient. To illustrate,
punching in 1 / 2 on the calculator is a condition by which you can cause the
calculator to give you a calculation of 0.5. You cause the calculator to
generate that result. Similarly, faith is the condition for regeneration. Am I
suggesting, then, that you punch God’s buttons and cause Him to regenerate
you? Not at all!

*
  See “Logic Table and Diagrams” in The Outer Darkness for a much more
thorough explanation.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                             Page 241
       Because Calvinists misconstrue the nature of the situation so as to
imply that non-Calvinists believe some such ridiculous notion, a word needs
to be said about the causal nature of cause-effect conditions. A causal
relation (as I am using the term in my A ⇒ B expression) is not necessarily
causal in the sense that A actually causes B. Rather, if A is true, then it is
because B is true also. If A is true, then B must also logically be true
because A could not be true if B were not true also. If (A) you are a believer,
then (B) you are regenerate. Your faith does not actually cause your
regeneration. Rather, you are regenerate because of your faith. Faith is the
condition for your regeneration.
       In this categorization, I am not necessarily distinguishing between a
cause and a condition. Technically speaking, however, faith is the condition
rather than the cause for regeneration. The fact that God regenerates us
because of our faith does not mean that our faith twists God’s arm behind
His back and makes Him give us eternal life. Our faith is simply the
condition; regeneration is the postconditional result. Faith is the condition
that we must meet. Regeneration is the postconversional result that God has
guaranteed. For example, when you flip on the light switch, your action does
not provide or produce the power/electricity that causes the light to shine.
The power is provided by the power company. Your flipping on the light
switch is merely the condition that you must meet to experience that power
from the power company. In like manner, God’s grace provides the believer
with the power for regeneration. Faith is simply the condition.

       Postconditions
       As to the calculator illustration, the calculation of 0.5 is the
postcondition (i.e., the guaranteed result) of having successfully performed
the operation. In mechanical causation, a postcondition is a posterior
condition that always must be true just after the operation of some
component of code. Failure in the postcondition indicates either a failure in
the precondition or condition. If you do not get an answer of 0.5 when
performing the above operation, then you either inputted the operation
incorrectly, or it is time to buy a new calculator! In summary, the
precondition expresses a presumption that must be satisfied when calling the
component, performing the calculation, or fulfilling the condition. The
condition, on the other hand, is the actual performance or execution of the
calculation. The postcondition states the promises or results of what the
component guarantees to yield.
       Lest this summation seem too far afield or too technical, it can be
brought closer back to home with a more practical illustration in which a
young lady buys a Bible, reads the Gospel of John, believes in Jesus for
eternal life, is born again as a result, then lives for Jesus, and finally dies and
goes to heaven to be with Jesus. Was her buying the Bible a condition for
her receiving eternal life? If so, is eternal life an acquisition rather than a
Page 242                                 Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
gift? Did she buy eternal life by buying the Bible in other words? Or did she
get to go to heaven simply because she received eternal life by believing in
Jesus? Or was her living a postconversional good life for Jesus also part of
the reason God let her into heaven? Is heaven conditioned on faith or on
simply having eternal life? If heaven is co-conditioned on having both faith
and eternal life, then how can faith be the condition for its own co-
condition? Where does perseverance in faith fit into the picture? Does God
condition our retention of eternal life on our perseverance in faith and
thereby condition our getting into heaven on both our perseverance in faith
and our possession of eternal life?
                  Illustration 95. Alpha- and Beta-Preconditions
    (A) alpha-precondition ⇒ (B) beta-precondition ⇒ (C) condition ⇒ (D) postcondition
            A= Buy Bible; B= Believe; C = regeneration; D = moral performance

        Distinctions between preconditions, conditions, and postconditions
are helpful in answering such questions. Living a virtuous life and
persevering in faith after we become believers pertains to our
postconversional performance. The input required from us in order to
experience regeneration is that we simply believe in Jesus for eternal life. In
terms of the calculator illustration and in juxtaposition with good works as a
postcondition, saving faith is the precondition to the condition of
regeneration. Just as punching in the correct calculation into the calculator is
the precondition that causes the calculator to perform the computation
(resulting in getting the correct postconditional calculation on the screen of
the calculator), so placing our faith in Christ is the precondition that causes
Him to give us eternal life so that we will go to heaven as a postconditional
result.* In other words, His giving us eternal life because of our
preconditional faith is the condition for our postconditional entrance into
heaven.
        Viewed from this perspective, His giving us eternal life is the
condition, and faith is technically the precondition. But if we plug works
rather than faith in as the precondition, then our error will be far greater than
that of trying to divide by zero. The term precondition is therefore being
used in contrast to postcondition in Illustration 95. Faith is the precondition
for the condition of regeneration. Faith is a precondition in that it logically
must be experienced before one receives eternal life. In the Bible illustration,
the buying of the Bible is a precondition for the young lady coming to faith.

*
  As explained above, I am not necessarily making a sharp distinction between
causation and condition but using one as a metonymy for the other. Our faith
does not actually cause our regeneration or cause God to regenerate us. Faith is
the condition for regeneration, and only in this limited sense is it the cause for
regeneration.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                                  Page 243
Buying a Bible would be an alpha-precondition. Believing would be the
beta-precondition. Correspondingly, whatever works may be pragmatically
or psychologically necessary to come to faith would be termed alpha-
preconditions in distinction to the beta-precondition (which is faith).169
       Admittedly, preconditions to the final precondition normally are not
designated as alpha-preconditions since it is easier simply to refer to the
works necessary to come to faith as preconditions in distinction to faith as
the condition for salvation. Accommodating this more prevalent perception
is easily done. But if the focal point is changed so as to make faith the
condition rather than the terminal precondition, then regeneration would
become the alpha-postcondition, and postconversional performance would
become the beta-postcondition.
                 Illustration 96. Alpha- and Beta-Postconditions
   (A) precondition ⇒ (B) condition ⇒ (C) alpha-postcondition ⇒ (D) beta-postcondition
           A= Buy Bible; B= Believe; C = regeneration; D = moral performance

        The question, then, becomes whether to make our role in conversion
the focal point by bringing faith to the foreground as the condition (see
Illustration 96) or whether to make God’s role in conversion the focal point
by making regeneration the condition (see Illustration 95). The most
important consideration is to avoid making alpha-preconditions or beta-
postconditions theologically necessary to get to heaven; otherwise, one
correspondingly would frontload or backload the gospel with works-
righteousness. Either error is a deadly distortion of the gospel. Given the
biblical emphasis on faith as the condition for eternal life, this accentuation
(as expressed in Illustration 96) is adopted herein as the focal point. For sake
of simplicity, preconversional good works will be regarded as potential
preconditions for faith, and the preconversional faith will be regarded as the
condition that results in regeneration.

       Preconversion and Postconversion
        Adopting this simplified perspective of preconditions also will allow
shifting the focus of the more detailed distinctions to the point where such
examinations are more sorely needed in the present discussion—
postconversional considerations. Lewis acknowledges that postconversional
faith is a virtue. Edwards tries to import postconversional works back into
saving faith. Duty, Marshall, MacArthur, and Shank condition heaven on
postconversional faith-works. Undoubtedly, this postconversional arena is
the proper focus of the current study.
Page 244                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                Illustration 97. Pre- and Postconversional Life




                       Preconversional Preconditions
        In this model, works are a preconversional precondition for saving
faith. One must at least hear the gospel before one can believe the gospel.
Broadly defining listening to the gospel as work would permit consistency
with my definition of a precondition as a condition that must always be true
just prior to the operation of the condition. Be that as it may, I will not be so
strict in my definition so as to picture us as computer programs. After all,
our Programmer has programmed us with free will. Rather than necessarily
defining hearing as a work, my preference will lean toward taking a broader
definition of preconditions as conditions that may be necessary to fulfill a
condition successfully. Buying a Bible and reading the Gospel of John
would provide a case in point. God does not require that we buy a Bible or
read the Gospel of John in order to come to saving faith, but practical
considerations may make doing so pragmatic necessities for some people.
Buying the Bible could be a potential precondition for the young lady in my
illustration. But this precondition must be distinguished from the condition
itself. The condition for regeneration is simply faith, not buying a Bible. The
distinction is necessary; otherwise, one could misconstrue the nature of
eternal life as being something that is bought rather than something that is
received as a free gift. The singular condition that God requires from us is
that we believe in Jesus for eternal life, not that we necessarily buy a Bible.
The free gift of eternal life is not for sale.
        This clarification allows us to understand Jesus’ warning: “And if
your eye causes you to stumble, pluck it out, and throw it from you. It is
better for you to enter life with one eye, than having two eyes, to be cast into
the fiery hell” (Mt 18:9). Suppose an adulterous addiction to Internet porn is
preventing a young man from believing in Christ for eternal life, and this
young man refuses to believe in Christ until he is at least willing to give up
his pornography. In such a case, his giving up pornography would be a
precondition that he has placed on himself with which he must deal before
he can receive the free gift of eternal life. Jesus’ words, in such an instance,
would mean that the young man must give up (or at least be willing to give
up) pornography if he cannot bring himself to believe in Jesus for eternal life
until this matter is resolved first. Even so, I must stress the word if in Jesus’
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                         Page 245
statement. Both the Lord’s use of the word if in this context and the tentative
nature of the command suggests that this course of action is not universally
necessary. Other NT considerations attest that this warning is certainly
provisional. Namely, we are not saved by works (i.e., by performance), and
plucking out one’s eye is certainly performance oriented! Thus, Jesus’
warning must be pertaining to a precondition rather than a condition, since
the Bible does not condition our reception of the free gift of eternal life on
our performance.
        At this juncture, a distinction between universal and non-universal
preconditions needs to be made. Hearing the gospel is the universally-
necessary precondition to believing the gospel. Jesus has committed His
gospel to His witnesses and prays salvifically for those who believe in Him
“through their word” (Jn 17:20). Saving faith comes from hearing the word
of Christ’s offer (Rom 10:17). We must hear it to believe it. Responding in
saving faith is not a mechanical reaction to hearing the gospel, however.170
        To refrain from dogmatically committing ourselves to needless
specificity, it suffices to conclude that some preconditions are universally
necessary, and some are not. Some
preconditions are works; some are not.
As a case in point, buying a Bible and
giving up porn are alpha-preconditions
that may or may not be necessary for
the person in question to come to
saving faith. For example, some people
may be addicted to porn and yet not find it impossible to believe in Christ
despite their addiction. Because they enjoy porn, they may not even honestly
want to give it up. From their perspective, sin is fun. And the Bible has no
qualms about admitting that sin can be pleasurable for a season. Still, no one
likes the harvest that comes at the conclusion of that season (Gal 6:7-8). The
end result is that sin hurts. It kills. For one thing, it can kill all hope of
obtaining the ultimate personal pleasure of ruling with Christ.
        Yet, the lack of willingness to give up pornography (which porn
addicts may deem as pleasurable) need not necessarily pose an
insurmountable obstacle preventing them from believing in Christ. For some
it will; for some it will not. Although some sinners may require this
willingness of themselves, God does not require it of them. In the course of
this study, some Christians have been found to give themselves over to
“wanton pleasure” (1Tim 5:6). Since giving oneself over to sinful pleasure
does not prevent one from being a Christian, there is little reason to think
that it necessarily poses an insurmountable problem to becoming a Christian.
        The misthological goal in discipleship is not to make the requirements
of discipleship the requirements to become or be a believer. Rather, the
biblical objective is to lead converts to develop the attitude of Moses who
chose to follow God’s will pertaining to moral performance rather than to
Page 246                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
“enjoy the passing pleasures of sin…for he was looking to the reward”
(Heb 11:24-26). Moses gave up the pleasures of sin because he wanted a
heavenly reward. Seeking personal pleasure is biblical when one seeks it in
the form of heavenly treasure. Nonetheless, one cannot insist that converts
give up the pleasures of sin in order to go to heaven without perverting the
gospel by making heaven a reward. The Bible promises personal pleasure in
the form of heavenly treasure for those believers who are willing to pursue
heavenly treasure. What it offers for those who are willing to give up the
pleasures of sin is a reward, not a gift. We are not at liberty to pervert the
gospel in presenting it to sexual perverts. Perverting sex is bad; perverting
the gospel is even worse. To apply Paul’s statement about Christian morality
in 1Tim 5:8 to evangelism, a believer who perverts the gospel by making
heaven a reward for giving up sinful pleasure is worse than an unbeliever
who pursues sinful pleasure. It is immoral for a believer to pervert the gospel
to a gospel that leads to hell by making heaven a reward. Leading people to
hell under the pretense of leading them to Christ is crassly immoral.
       The willingness, then, to change one’s performance is a potential
psychological precondition rather than an essential theological precondition.
Since being willing to give up porn is a performance issue, this particular
precondition deals with work. Hearing the gospel, on the other hand, is a
necessary precondition but is not necessarily a work. Therefore, it stands to
reason that some preconditions are universal, theological non-works (such as
hearing the gospel) and some preconditions may be particular, pragmatic, or
psychological works (such as giving up porn). Such preconditions must be
distinguished from the condition of faith.
        Distinctions between preconditions and conditions are certainly
biblical. Paul uses this type of differentiation to explain the purpose of the
law: “Therefore the Law has become our tutor to lead us to Christ, that we
may be justified by faith” (Gal 3:24). In this example, being convicted by the
law that one is a sinner is a precondition to being justified via the condition
of faith. Mistakes, however, abound at this level. Some evangelists make a
law out of using the law as a precondition.171 However, doing so comes
dangerously close to making the law a theologically-necessary precondition.
Even if one only makes the law a psychological necessity, this perception
frequently is combined with the claim that it is a universal psychological
necessity. The argument goes something like this:
                 Illustration 98. Pseudo Syllogism for Law
       1. You cannot trust Christ to save you from your sin unless
          you are first convicted of your sin (by the law).
       2. If you are convicted of your sin (by the law), you cannot
          believe in Christ to save you from your sin unless you
          are willing to turn from your sin (in obedience to the
          law).
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                         Page 247
       3. Therefore, you cannot trust Christ to save you from your
          sin unless you are willing to turn from your sin (in
          obedience to the law).

       This willingness to turn from one’s sin typically is called repentance.
So those adopting this perspective have come to conclude that a person
cannot believe in Christ unless he or she repents. Bell has done well to sound
a bell of alarm. As he documents, Beza and his Calvinistic cronies fell into
this performance-based ordo salutis. Calvin, as Bell conversely notes,
avoided this particular error by making repentance a postcondition.
Unfortunately for Calvin (and unnoticed by Bell), Calvin made repentance a
necessary postcondition and thereby backloaded the gospel. Regardless, a
few simple observations will help us keep from falling off the back of the
wagon or off the front of the wagon into a pile of works-righteousness.
       Contrary to some of my Free Grace contemporaries, the position of
this book is that complying with psychological preconditions is not always
necessary.172 The classic example in Acts 19:18-19 of people who became
believers without initially giving up their magic strongly suggests that a
willingness to give up sin is not a universal psychological necessity for
coming to saving faith. God has not constitutionally programmed us so as to
make it impossible for us to receive forgiveness apart from repentance. To
be sure, our Programmer has programmed us with an internal moral code
that naturally prompts us to love those who love us, to want to help those
who help us, and not to bite the hand that feeds us. The Moral Law (LHN,
alias Common Decency) prompts us in this manner, telling us that it is
wrong to hate those who love us, to hurt those who help us, or to bite the
hand that feeds us. Yet, who among us has not at one time or another broken
this Moral Law? Have we not all fallen short of this standard? Of course we
have. Children snap back at their parents who lovingly have fed them. A
spouse hurts the feelings of his or her loving mate. Our free will makes it
possible for us to respond wrongly. Responding in such a manner is sinful.
The Moral Law (i.e., our internal programming) prompts us to do the right
thing, but we have not been hardcoded to the point where we will inevitably
do the right thing. In addition to being provided with an internal moral code,
we also have been programmed with a free will that makes it possible for us
to violate this internal sense of right and wrong.
       Doing the right thing (e.g., turning from one’s sin) comes naturally to
those trusting in Christ for the forgiveness of their sins. Yet this natural
inclination does not make repentance inevitable. The Moral Law is not a
dictator. On the contrary, we determine our own response under the
influence, or sometimes despite the influence, of the Moral Law. Some
people would not trust in Christ for forgiveness unless they were first willing
to give up magic; alternately some people biblically have trusted in Christ
without being willing to give up magic. Surely the converts in Acts knew
Page 248                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
that they should give up magic. Their desire to practice magic was simply
stronger than their desire to give up magic, so they just gave in to their
stronger desire even though it was morally unnatural for them to do so. The
natural thing for them to do would be to give up magic when trusting in
Christ for the forgiveness of practicing magic. This natural inclination would
come both from the nature of their internal programming and from the
conviction of the Holy Spirit. Trusting in Christ for the forgiveness of one’s
sins without simultaneously being willing to turn from those sins is
unnatural. Doing so goes against our constitutional programming for moral
decency. Indeed, because doing so is a violation of this God-given law, to
trust in Christ for forgiveness of known sins without being willing to turn
from those sins is sinful. Does this mean we have to turn from our sins in
order to be saved from the soteric penalty of our sins? No! God does not
require that we clean up our hearts or our acts before we come to Him for
the free gift of eternal life—it would not be a free gift otherwise! Nor has
God programmed us so as to make it impossible for us to receive the free
gift of eternal life without first committing our lives to Him. The Lord has
made our morally right response natural but not inevitable, not by a long
shot.
        What loving mother, at some point in her life, has not prepared a meal
for her moody teenager only to have her teenager snap back at her? This
teenager eats the free food even while biting the loving hand doing the
feeding. Is it wrong for a teenager to do so? Of course it is. Does this prevent
the teenager from taking the food? Not necessarily. The natural response by
the teenager to such a loving motherly action should be thanksgiving. Yet,
sometimes teenagers can be unthankful, especially when having to eat a
meal that their mother deems particularly nutritious. And this fault is not
limited to teenagers, as we all know. On one occasion, ten leprous men cried
out to Jesus to have mercy on them, and Jesus healed them, but only one of
the ten returned to tell Him thank You (Lk 17:12-19). People eat food every
day without thanking God for it. Is God offended? Probably. Does this mean
that God is going to withhold the food from them? Not necessarily. Like the
loving mother who at times suffers hurtful remarks from the teenager she
loves and yet feeds him, so Jesus freely offers the bread of life and the water
of life to anyone willing to believe in Him (Jn 6:35; 48; 7:37; Rev 22:17),
even if this potential believer is doing things offensive to Him.
        On the other hand, it is morally natural for a teenager to love his
mother and to want to avoid hurting her feelings. And some teenagers would
apologize for anything hurtful that they might have said to their mothers
before sitting down to eat the supper prepared by their mothers. Such
teenagers would not think of doing otherwise. For them, it would be
practically impossible to do otherwise psychologically. Their psychological
makeup would require that they make up with their mothers first before
eating supper with their mothers. Likewise, some people will refuse to trust
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                          Page 249
in Christ unless they are willing to be reconciled to Christ in terms of their
performance.
       Should evangelists appeal to this psychological makeup or internal
sense of right and wrong by telling people they have to get right with God
before they can receive eternal life from God? Absolutely not! To the lost
who are sensitive to the Moral Law, it might be a psychological necessity
that they get right with God before coming to faith in God. Repentance can
be a psychological precondition in those situations. Still, to tell people that
they have to repent before believing in God for eternal life is to mutate
repentance from being a potential psychological precondition into a
theologically necessity, making repentance something that God absolutely
requires from us via His (OT or Moral) law before He is willing to save us.
Doing so makes eternal life a barter rather than a gift.
       MacArthur uses various strategies to conceal the bartering nature of
his soteriology. Purportedly, since God holds out the free gift of living water
in Is 55:1 and then enjoins those receiving this free gift to turn from their
sins (and turn to Him in order to get forgiveness just a few verses later in
Is 55:7), the free gift of living water is contingent upon repentance but is not
considered a work since it results in a free gift. Indeed, MacArthur uses this
type of argument to suggest that Jesus was indicating that the woman at the
well had to repent in order to drink the free gift of living water which Jesus
was offering her (Jn 4:10).173 MacArthur’s argument may be summarized
syllogistically:
                     Illustration 99. MacArthurian Logic
       1. Living water is free and therefore is not conditioned on works.
       2. Living water is conditioned on repentance.
       3. Therefore, repentance is not a work.

       Superficially, such an argument has an allure of logical consistency—
if one is willing to overlook the blatant inconsistency of conditioning a free
gift on one’s commitment to change one’s moral performance. Aside from
this glaring inconsistency, however, logistical problems with MacArthur’s
minor premise in equating Is 55:1 with 55:7 may be mentioned. The fact that
verse one comes before verse seven could be taken to indicate a natural
sequence. If so, God is inviting us to experience regeneration freely and then
subsequently inviting us to experience fellowship.

                          Free Abundance of Life
      1
       Ho! Every one who thirsts, come to the waters; and you who
      have no money come, buy and eat. Come, buy wine and milk
      without money and without cost. 2Why do you spend money
      for what is not bread, and your wages for what does not satisfy?
      Listen carefully to Me, and eat what is good, and delight
Page 250                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
                                 3
      yourself in abundance. Incline your ear and come to Me.
      Listen, that you may live. (Is 55:1-3)

                       Costly Abundance of Pardon
      6
       Seek the Lord while He may be found; call upon Him while
      He is near. 7Let the wicked forsake his way, and the
      unrighteous man his thoughts; and let him return to the Lord,
      and He will have compassion on him; and to our God, for He
      will abundantly (rabah)* pardon. (Is 55:6-7)

        If this perception is correct, God is inviting us to receive eternal life
freely (independent of our performance) and then inviting us to experience
fellowship with Him (via His pardon as we change our performance). On the
other hand, Constable seems to suggest the opposite sequence and yet
evidently comes to a conclusion harmonious with mine: “Repentance is not
something a person must do before God will accept him or her. It is simply a
description of what seeking the Lord looks like. In other words, forsaking
sin is not a precondition for acceptance by God.”174
        If this is soteric seeking in v. 6 that is requisite to coming to the
saving faith (which is necessary to receive the living water) and if this
seeking is composed of repentance, then, to use my terms to describe what
Constable appears to be saying, the alpha-precondition of repentant seeking
is not the beta-precondition that is necessary for God’s acceptance; saving
faith is the exclusive beta-precondition for God’s soteric acceptance. Or
restated without the alpha and beta, Constable is saying that repentance is a
precondition that can help us come to saving faith, but the actual condition
that God requires for taking the living water is faith alone, not repentance.
After inviting us to take the water freely, God gives us helpful directions via
repentance as to how we might bring ourselves to the point where we are
ready to drink freely. Therefore, the theological requirements expressed in
vv. 6-7 are really just theological directions to help us meet a potential
psychological necessity that would make us thirsty enough to drink the free
water. Constable’s approach is certainly attractive and is in complete
harmony with my thesis. Indeed, there are texts in which the summons to
*
  Some translations unfortunately render rabah as freely rather than abundantly
in Is 55:7. Perhaps mention should be made that rabah can also be used to
magnify the greatness of a reward: “Do not fear, Abram, I am a shield to you;
your reward shall be very great (rabah)” (Gen 15:1). For that matter, the
Holladay Hebrew Lexicon simply defines rabah as meaning to reward in
Gen 15:1. Certainly, rabah does not automatically mean freely! Most
translations correctly render rabah as some form of abundantly rather than
freely in Is 55:7. The congruent magnitude of the forgiveness is being stressed,
not its freeness.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                            Page 251
repentance might be regarded as an evangelistic precondition to
pragmatically help people come to saving faith.
        Consequently, there are two routes by which to maintain my thesis in
regard to this text from Isaiah. The question is simply which one is best in
this context. My exegetical preference is to maintain the natural sequence in
the context. After first telling us how to partake freely of eternal life, God (in
harmony with the reflexive manner in which He has programmed us to
respond positively to those who lovingly help us) invites us to fellowship
with Him. Our natural inclination is to love and trust those who freely help
us. Those of us who have partaken freely of that living water can attest that
repentance is a very natural moral reaction. We find it very natural to “love
Him because He first loved us” (1Jn 4:19). Since God has given us eternal
life as a free gift, it makes sense that we naturally would want to fellowship
with Him as a result and therefore seek familial forgiveness in addition
(1Jn 1:9), now that we already have received regeneration. Accordingly, this
subsequent abundant pardon is not a soteriological pardon, only a familial
pardon: pardon for us now that we are children of God, not pardon for us to
become children of God.
        At the same time, we also can acknowledge that the temptation to
love the world is still present and that just because we have the natural desire
to do the right thing does not necessarily mean that we will do what is
morally right. For example, physical birth does not guarantee that mothers
will love their children. It is the most natural thing in the world for mothers
to love their children. However, the Bible does not take for granted that this
natural response is an inevitable response. Rather, Scripture exhorts mothers
“to love their children” (Tit 2:4). In the same way, new birth does not
guarantee a loving postconversional performance or perspective on our part.
These competing tendencies to selfishly love ourselves and to love worldly
allurements still reside within us. The Bible and experience make it clear
that some Christians fail to do the good things that come naturally as a result
of their new birth; instead, they continue to do the bad things that come
naturally as a result of their old perspective.
        Therefore, three exegetical possibilities exist for this OT text from
Isaiah. Two of these preferences are in theological harmony with Free Grace
theology. The MacArthurian alternative, on the other hand, results in a false
gospel of works-righteousness.
              Illustration 100. Potential Sequences for Is 55:1-7
                  Precondition            Condition              Postcondition
Constable        Is 55:6-7          Is 55:1-5
MacArthur                           Is 55:1-5/ Is 55:6-7
Cauley                              Is 55:1-5                  Is 55:6-7
Page 252                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Translating Constable’s precondition as condition (as used in the present
discussion), in order to avoid the alpha-beta complexity, gives three simple
options. One may be logically and biblically consistent by choosing either
the sequence proposed (1) by Constable or (2) by the present author. Or one
may throw consistency out the window and opt for (3) MacArthur’s
supposedly paradoxical proposal (a) by equating taking something without
cost with paying the price for it, (b) by equalizing regeneration with pardon,
and (c) by ignoring sequences that would not necessitate logical
contradictions.
        To be sure, Paul describes a use of the law in Gal 3:24 that is
potentially evangelistic, but Paul’s overarching point is that we cannot keep
the law. As to Paul’s actual use of the law, one does not need to be a Vulcan
to realize that logic dictates that hearing a message pertaining to one’s sin is
necessary to trust in Christ for justification because justification pertains to
one’s sin. This is not exactly rocket science, simply a pragmatic precondition
for such an occasion. One cannot trust in Christ for justification pertaining to
one’s sins if one does not recognize that one is a sinner. Does this mean that
every evangelistic message must focus on sin? Not necessarily, at least not
logically. A message focusing on God’s provision of eternal life through
faith in Christ might focus on God’s love instead.
        Still, for sake of argument, let us suppose that it could be established
exegetically (from a text such as Jn 16:7 for example) that one must trust in
Christ for justification and that, consequently, we must use the law in our
evangelism. Even granting MacArthur such a premise, does his conclusion
follow? Not at all. What we are trusting Christ to do in Gal 3:24 is to justify
us, not to sanctify us: “Therefore the Law has become our tutor to lead us to
Christ, that we may be justified by faith.” This justification pertains to the
penalty of our sin, not to the practice of our sin. Those trusting in Christ to
save them from the practice of their sin as a means of getting to heaven have
failed to trust in Christ for justification as the means of getting to heaven.
They are trying to get to heaven by trusting Christ to help them fulfill moral
obligations to the law. This path leads to hell. One cannot trust Christ for
sanctification and expect to get justification instead. Trusting in Christ for
moral therapy is not the remedy envisioned by Paul in Gal 3:24. Let us
correct the MacArthurian syllogism accordingly:
                Illustration 101. Biblical Syllogism for Law
       1. You cannot trust Christ to save you from the penalty of
          your sin unless you are first convicted of your sin (by
          the law).
       2. If you are convicted of your sin (by the law), you cannot
          believe in Christ to save you from the penalty of your
          sin unless you trust in Christ for justification.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                           Page 253
       3. Therefore, you cannot trust Christ to save you from the
          penalty of your sin unless you trust in Christ for
          justification.

        Paul is not using the law to teach a Christian form of legalism. Far
from it, Paul is using the law as preparation for the necessity of justification
by faith apart from works! The law shows us to be totally bankrupt. It does
not picture us as people a little down on our luck who need a helping hand to
work our way out of debt. Paul is using a little sanctified common sense.
Matthew expects a little common sense from his readership as well. He is
not going to do all the thinking for his readers. His literary objective in
compiling his gospel is not to write a Christianity 101 for Dummies. To the
contrary, he expects a little deductive ability on our part to discern that he is
talking about preconditions in such a passage as Mt 18:9 when he records
Jesus talking about people potentially needing to pluck out their eyes in
order to escape hell.
        First, Matthew acknowledges that the real soteric issue for immoral
people is what they believe (Mt 21:32). Harmonization with the Gospel of
John is a given. Second, repentance (as expressed metaphorically in
plucking out one’s eye) is a performance issue and thus a work. Third, since
soteric justification is by faith apart from works, repentance cannot be a co-
condition for soteric justification. Fourth, since repentance is a potential
soteric condition in Mt 18:9 and since repentance cannot be a co-condition,
repentance must be a precondition. Fifth, repentance is only a potential
precondition since Jesus uses the word if tentatively to entertain the
possibility of the individual necessity.
                     Postconversional Postconditions
        A thoughtful question can be posed legitimately at this point: “If
matters such as plucking out one’s eye are preconditions, then why does
Jesus address them (at least in part) to those who already are believers?” Part
of the answer would consist in acknowledging that as a precondition this
plucking is not theologically necessary. At most, it is only a potential
psychological necessity. But here is the kicker. If God is going to throw the
lost into hell because they stumble over something that is only potentially
psychologically necessary, then believers have good reason to fear such a
God (cf. Mt 10:28). How can believers hope to escape dire consequences
from such a God if they stumble over those postconditions that God has
made absolutely theologically necessary? If God is not going to excuse
unbelievers from hell because they trifled with nonobligatory preconditions,
then the Lord certainly is not going to excuse believers from the outer
darkness because they trifled with obligatory postconditions. If God deals
out hellish severity when the lost fail to deal with preconditions that they
require of themselves and which He does not require, then He definitely is
not going to deal laxly with postconditions that He Himself requires.
Page 254                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       The outer darkness of Matthew awaits those believers who
postconversionally stumble into it. The outer darkness is not hell, but it is
not a picnic on the beach either. If unbelievers are warned so dramatically to
avoid stumbling (into hell) because of theologically optional preconditions,
then why are preachers not warning believers to avoid stumbling (into the
outer darkness) because of theologically necessary postconditions?

       Alpha-Postcondition
       Without going into detail in the present work, the primary reason I
conclude that the outer darkness is not hell is because I believe in
unconditional security. Once a person has met the singular condition of
punctiliar faith, that person is granted eternal life as a free gift. Retention of
such life is the unconditionally-guaranteed result.




Eternal life cannot be lost once it has been gained in response to a punctiliar
response of faith. Retention of regeneration is not conditioned on
perseverance in faith, much less on perseverance in faithfulness. In terms of
regeneration, possession of eternal life is static.

       Beta-Postconditions
                               FaithWorks
        The primary reason Free Grace opponents in the Arminian and
Reformed camps cannot affirm unconditional security is because they want
to blur alpha and beta postconditions, sometimes even to the point of
treating them as one and the same. But when one reaches beta-preconditions,
the dynamic becomes antithetic and cyclic. The sequential arrows (→) in
Illustration 97. Pre- and Postconversional Life show progression:
Preconditions come first, then the condition of faith, and then the alpha-
postcondition of unconditional security. Sequentially, the order is:
preconditions → condition → alpha-postcondition. However, when one
reaches the transition from alpha-postconditions to beta-postconditions, the
sequential arrow gives way to the cyclical symbol ().
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                         Page 255
                  Illustration 102. Cyclic Beta-Postconditions
    preconditions → condition → alpha-postcondition  beta-postconditions

         Postconversional faith enables and enlivens postconversional works.
These works, in turn, empower and energize postconversional faith in a
mutualistic relationship in which both dynamics are necessary to keep each
other alive. The loss of faith would result in dead works, and conversely the
loss of works would result in dead faith. Such a faith-works relationship
might be better designated as faithworks. Both faith and works are jointly
necessary to keep one’s hopes of misthological life alive. The beta-
postcondition of faithworks is the condition for the realization of the
misthological crown of life.


     Faith-Works is FaithWorks




                  Preservation through Perseverance
        Where Edwards went wrong was to make this beta-postcondition of
faithworks the condition for the alpha-postcondition of regeneration.* One
cannot accomplish that magic trick, even with virtual importation. Alpha
comes before beta, not after it. A beta-postcondition cannot be the condition
for an alpha-postcondition. That sequence would put the cart before the
horse. Lewis, in contrast, does not attempt to invert the sequence in his feed-
it-to-keep-it approach to retaining regeneration, preferring instead to base


*
  This criticism is expressed from the vantage point of my perspective in which
regeneration is not linearly contingent.
Page 256                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
our security crassly on our moral postconversional effort. MacArthur, citing
A. W. Pink, takes much the same perspective as Lewis:

             [God] does not deal with [believers] as unaccountable
      automations, but as moral agents, just as their natural life is
      maintained through their use of means and by their avoidance
      of that which is inimical to their well-being, so it is with the
      maintenance and preservation of their spiritual lives. God
      preserves His people in this world through their
      perseverance.175

       This quotation of Pink by MacArthur is in complete harmony with the
Arminian theology expressed by Lewis.* Perseverance is the means by
which Arminian and MacArthurian believers keep themselves from losing
the free gift of eternal life.† Both MacArthurianism and Arminianism teach
that believers will lose the free gift of eternal life if they do not put forth the
moral effort necessary to keep it. Both systems of thought deny carnal
security; carnal believers go to hell. Carnal believers are not good enough to
go to performatistic heaven. By denying eternal security for the carnal
Christian, MacArthur (like any other conditionalist) shows himself to be an
advocate of moral security instead of carnal security.176
                       Moral MacArthurian Christian
                        Illustration 103. Moral Demands




       MacArthur complains that easy-believism “makes no moral demands
on the lives of sinners.”177 Obviously, he is talking about making no moral
demands for reaching heaven since the easy-believism (as he maligns the
Free Grace camp) stringently makes moral demands pertaining to rewards in

*
 See Lose Eternal Life, 95.
†
 For clear confirmation that this is the MacArthurian perception, see Condition,
180.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                       Page 257
heaven. True enough, we in the Free Grace camp make no soteriological
moral demands on the lives of sinners so as to require that they change their
performance in order to get to heaven. Contrastively, MacArthur’s criticism
must mean that his hard-believism makes moral demands in regards to
entering heaven.
                              Synergism
      To be sure, as with Lewis, MacArthur notes that it is not independent
moral effort that saves us:

      Saving faith.…is inseparable from repentance, surrender, and a
      supernatural longing to obey. None of those responses can be
      classified exclusively as a human work, any more than believing
      itself is solely a human work.178

      MacArthurian salvation is only partially, not exclusively or solely or
merely, a result of our work:

      Faith and works are not incompatible. Jesus even calls the
      act of believing a work (Jn 6:29)—not merely a human work,
      but a gracious work of God in us. He brings us to faith, then
      enables and empowers us to believe unto obedience (cf. Rom.
      16:26).179

       Splendid synergism! MacArthur correctly affirms synergism but
wrongly applies it to saving faith so as to make saving faith a synergistic
work of God and man. So much for salvation by faith apart from works
(Rom 4:6). In MacArthur’s synergism, people are justified by faith and
works, and faith itself is a work. Other options are available to MacArthur;
unfortunately, he chooses to regard saving faith as a joint work of God and
man. Perhaps, in trying to make saving faith compatible with works, he
intends to adopt Calvinistic compatibilism, imagining that sovereign
determinism is compatible with human freedom. Regardless, by making
saving faith compatible with human work, MacArthur has made Jesus
incompatible with Paul.
                            Root versus Fruit
       Would MacArthur admit that he teaches synergistic soteriology?
Surely not! In the midst of his very own discussion, from which the above
quotations are taken, he switches to speaking out of the other side of his
mouth: “Far from being a human work, it [repentance] is the inevitable result
of God’s work in a human heart. And it always represents the end of any
human attempt to earn God’s favor” (emphasis his).180 “No aspect of
salvation is merited by human works, but it is all the work of God.”181 Thus,
on the one hand, MacArthur indicates that faith and repentance are human
Page 258                               Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
works which God sovereignly enables and empowers us to perform. Then,
on the other hand, he denies that faith and repentance are human works at
all, claiming instead that they are performed exclusively by God.
Overpowering rather than empowering would seem to be a more apt
description of MacArthur’s view of grace when he switches to speaking
from this alternative perspective. Having indicated that saving faith and
repentance are partially human works, he frequently counters himself with
denials otherwise:

                Let me say as clearly as possible right now that the
         salvation is by God’s sovereign grace and grace
         alone….Saving faith, repentance, commitment, and
         obedience are all divine works….I have never taught that
         some presalvation works of righteousness are necessary to or
         part of salvation….Salvation thus establishes the root that will
         surely produce the fruit. (Italics his.)182
                       Willingness to Work is Work
        Although MacArthur frequently uses strawman misrepresentations of
the Free Grace position,183 I would deem a similar reciprocation on my part,
in attacking a strawman caricature of MacArthur’s position, to be a waste of
time and miss the heart of the issue. Preferring to aim for the heart of the
issue, I will attempt (as much so as possible given his tendency for
paradoxical oscillation) to accurately summarize some of the main thrusts of
his arguments.
        MacArthurian repentance requires a willingness to change one’s
moral performance. This MacArthurian presalvation condition* supposedly
is not the actual work itself and only part of the root system that produces
the postsalvational† moral performance that composes perseverance. In
MacArthur’s perspective, the beta-preconditional wholehearted willingness
and tremendous desire to work must be distinguished from the actual beta-
postconditional work itself that springs forth from repentance and faith.184 In
other words, the willingness to work which comprises the root cannot be
considered the work which comprises the fruit. To do so would confuse the
root with the fruit. The willingness to work is not a work. Thus, repentance
and faith are not works according to MacArthur, even though they center on
the willingness and commitment to change one’s moral performance.
        Contrary to MacArthur’s repeated claims, even aside from the fact
that he denies that willingness to work is enough (since he makes the actual
performance of work necessary as the fruit, even in making the willingness
and desire to work conditions for salvation), he clearly is teaching salvation
*
    Or beta-precondition to use my term from his perspective.
†
    Or beta-postcondition to use my term from his perspective.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                          Page 259
by works. Since we are to be judged and praised on the basis of the motives
and intentions of our hearts, even our intention and willingness to work is a
work—a performance issue (Gen 6:5; 50:20; Prov 21:27; Is 29:20;
Acts 8:22; 1Cor 4:5; Heb 4:12). To restate this statement in the form of a
rule, if the action arising from the intent to perform the action has
meritorious value, then so does the intent to perform that action. To put it
bluntly, the willingness/intent to work is indeed a work.
                          God-Given Repentance
       MacArthur uses standard Calvinistic proof texts when he appeals to
Acts 11:18 and 2Tim 2:25 to assert: “If God is the One who grants
repentance, it cannot be viewed as a human work.” His argument here is that
repentance “is a sovereignly bestowed gift of God.”185 MacArthur shoots his
own argument in the heart with a fatal wound as he introduces it by saying,
“Nor is repentance merely a human work.”186 Of course repentance is not a
merely a human work. No one would repent on their own initiative, and
Satan certainly is not going to help them! Apart from God granting a person
the opportunity and ability to repent, no one would repent. To obliterate
MacArthur’s entire argument, one need only note that he implicitly allows
that repentance is partially a human work. MacArthur does not make this
implicit concession lightly; he makes it out of necessity. Cooperative human
effort is required to fulfill the terms of repentance. By making this
concession, MacArthur has conceded the argument. Because we are saved
apart from works—not partially by works—MacArthur’s argument will not
work. Second, Paul says that this repentance leads to the knowledge of the
truth in 2Tim 2:25. Even if this knowledge were saving knowledge (i.e.,
saving faith), which it is not in this context, repentance would just be a
precondition, not a condition, for eternal life.
       I will offer an interpretation of Acts 11:18, however, that adopts
several of MacArthur’s premises (contrary to some in my own camp!) and
demonstrate the feasibility of the precondition argument when contextually
prudent. Two decades ago, in his book Absolutely Free, Hodges wrote a
rebuttal to the Lordship theology of the MacArthurian variety. Hodges
emphatically insisted that repentance that leads to life in this verse is not
talking about eternal life.187 To be charitable to the opposing viewpoint of
the LS camp, I will allow the possibility that Hodges is wrong and
