MacArthur is right and entertain the possibility that this verse indeed is
talking about eternal life.* Shortly thereafter, Wilkin wrote an article stating
that in his assessment, contra Hodges, that eternal life is intended in this
verse. At that time Wilkin was still defending the old Free Grace
interpretation (contrary to both Hodges and MacArthur) which stipulates that
*
  Hodges and MacArthur would agree, more or less, that repentance involves an
internal willingness to turn from one’s sin.
Page 260                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
repentance simply means a change of mind (not necessarily a turning from
one’s sinful ways). So Wilkin concluded that Acts 11:18 was referring to
“changing one’s mind about Jesus Christ” and that this change of mind was
“a condition of eternal salvation.”188 Thus, he sided with those who, like
MacArthur, would insist that eternal life is in view. Years later, Wilkin
eventually came to adopt Hodges’ understanding of repentance and
accordingly redefined repentance as “a decision to turn from one’s sins.”189
Thus, two viable interpretations of this verse are found within the history of
interpretation in the modern Free Grace movement.
        Still, to demonstrate the flexibility of the Free Grace interpretation, I
will reject both of these Free Grace interpretations and side with MacArthur
in this verse regarding a combination of two major points: (1) eternal life is
in view in this verse, (2) and, to use Anderson’s definition of the newer GES
view, which is in harmony with the newer view taken by Wilkin,
“repentance is an internal resolve to turn from one’s sins” (emphasis his).190
Does my adoption of this MacArthurian combination prove lethal to the
GES position? Not at all.
        First, in harmony with Hodges (and the current GES view of
repentance), let it be affirmed that Cornelius already had repented before he
heard the gospel message presented by Peter. This deduction is obvious from
the context anyway. Moreover, in harmony with MacArthur, rather than with
Hodges, let it further be granted that the life Cornelius received in
Acts 11:18 was indeed eternal life. This inference is debatable but may be
granted to MacArthur in order to be charitable to his point of view.
Nevertheless, harmonization of this concession to MacArthur with an
interpretation in harmony with Hodgian theology is easy.

      If God therefore gave to them the same gift as He gave to us
      also after believing in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I that I
      could stand in God's way? And when they heard this, they
      quieted down, and glorified God, saying, “Well then, God has
      granted to the Gentiles also the repentance that leads to life”
      (Acts 11:17-18).

       Peter’s audience simply summarized the entire discourse in this one
sentence: “Well then, God has granted to the Gentiles also the repentance
that leads to life.” Wilkin originally had reasoned along the following lines,
and evidently MacArthur still reasons something along these lines as well:

      1. Believe ⇒ Gift
      2. Repent ⇒ Life
      3. (Repent = believe) ⇒ (Gift = Life)
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                            Page 261
        Believe and repent are considered virtually synonymous in this
construction, virtually part of a two-sided condition for the free gift of
eternal life. Where MacArthur and Wilkin disagreed was in how they
defined repentance. For MacArthur repentance was a basically a turning
from sin; for Wilkin it was a simply a change of mind. Hodges advocated the
turn-from-sin point of view but rejected the hypothesis life = eternal life in
this verse. After all, the text does not state that it was eternal life. Perhaps
the gift was eternal life; perhaps it was just life. Hodges did not specify. But
according to Hodges, the life that resulted from repentance was definitely
not eternal life. For simplicity sake, let us suppose that the gift is not eternal
life in this Hodgian reconstruction:

      1. Believe ⇒ Gift
      2. Repent ⇒ Life
      3. (Repent ≠ believe) ⇒ (Gift ≠ Life)

        As a result of repenting and believing (two distinct responses),
Cornelius came into possession of life. In this case, that life included eternal
life, but it was more than the mere possession of eternal life; it also included
harmonious fellowship with God. I propose a third Free Grace interpretation:

      1. Believe ⇒ Gift
      2. Repent ⇒ Life
      3. Repent ⇒ believe ⇒ (Gift ⊆ Life)*

       The order is: repentance, then saving faith, then the reception of the
gift of eternal life. No doubt, Peter had described the events of ch. 10 in
vivid detail for his listeners before giving them the summary recorded in ch.
11. As his listeners already had deduced from Peter’s description of
Cornelius’ preexisting activities (alms-giving, praying, fearing God, doing
what is right, and being well spoken of by the Jews), Cornelius had repented
long before hearing the message by Peter. It did not take a genius to figure
out that God had sent an angel to Cornelius and then sent Peter to him
because of Cornelius’ repentance (which was evidenced in all his
preconversional works). As a result of Cornelius’ repentance-induced-
openness, when Cornelius heard the gospel message from Peter, Cornelius
believed and received the gift of eternal life.
       What about Cornelius’ good works (alms-giving, praying, fearing
God, doing what is right, and being well spoken of by the Jews)? Were these

*
  Alternatively, if one thought that Acts 11:18 were simply dealing with the
reception of eternal life as a gift, the final expression would be: Repent ⇒
believe ⇒ (Gift = Life).
Page 262                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
works just evidences of his repentance—just the external fruit of the
preexisting root? No. Many writers, both inside and outside the Free Grace
camp think so, however. Wilkin, Anderson, and MacArthur (along with
many others) probably would exclude these works as being a part of
Cornelius’ repentance. Nevertheless, it seems very amicable to the context to
include these works as part of Cornelius’ repentance. Would not Peter’s
listeners have included Cornelius’ works in their reference to Cornelius’
repentance? Defining repentance as change of mind (regarding one’s action)
that results in a change of action is a reasonable definition.191 The Greek
dictionary brings the resulting change in action to the forefront of its
definition as to what it means to repent: to change one’s way of life as the
result of a complete change of thought and attitude (L-N).192 God not only
gave Cornelius his change of mind about his life but also his change of
action. These human works were a part of the repentance that God gave to
Cornelius. MacArthur’s supposition is false—just because something is
given by God does not mean that works are excluded. If you give someone a
job to perform (even if you gave him that job as a gift), his performance of
that job would require that he work.
                    Illustration 104. Tree of Repentance
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                           Page 263


        Repentance is a change of mind that results in a corresponding change
in action. That repentance may grow out of various conditions of the heart.
In terms of the illustration, the tree of repentance includes both the root and
the fruit (the change in mind and the change in action), but it does not
include the soil out of which that tree grows. A broken heart over one’s sin
is fertile soil for repentance (but this godly sorrow is not to be made a part of
repentance). Gratitude for what God has done, is doing, or will do is also
fertile soil for repentance.
                         Illustration 105. Road to Life




        While traveling on the road to Damascus, Virginia, with one of my
sisters to do some bike riding with our brother, our niece in the backseat
asked a form of the infamous are-we-there-yet question. (We had just started
the three hour trip!) To put this trip in a perspective our niece would be able
to comprehend, my sister responded: “We are on the road that leads to the
road that leads to the road to Damascus.” In the same way, the Jewish
believers acknowledged that God had put Cornelius on the road (of
repentance) that would eventually lead him to life. What route God used to
get Cornelius on that road is unstated. In the above example, using a
Page 264                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
highway illustration, let us suppose that God convicted Cornelius of his
sinful lifestyle and used this godly sorrow to bring Cornelius to the point
where he was willing to abandon the sinful indulgencies so prevalent in his
society in order to set out and find God. As a result of Cornelius’ turning
from his sins (inwardly and outwardly) in his pursuit of God, the Lord
eventually sent Peter to Cornelius with the message of salvation. Cornelius
believed and came into the possession of the free gift of eternal life and was
well on his way to obtaining the crown of life as a reward—if he would just
keep on trucking, to continue with the travel analogy. Not only had God put
him on the path that leads to eternal life (as a non-forfeitable free gift) but
also on a path which, if persisted upon, ultimately would bring Cornelius
into possession of eternal life as a reward in the form of the crown of life.
Although God put Cornelius on this path and pointed the way, the effort that
Cornelius exerted along the way certainly involved human work.
       MacArthur wants Cornelius’ change to be the result of God’s
sovereign bestowment so that he can attempt to conceal the human effort.
MacArthur is grasping at straws in a desperate attempt to find some way to
conceal works so that it will not be apparent that he is teaching salvation by
works. Because MacArthur needs to exclude human works from repentance,
he attributes these works to God’s irresistible grace rather than merely
affirming that they are produced by means of God’s enabling grace. With his
frequent affirmations of God’s enabling grace and his limited denials of the
human effort that goes into such works, he short-circuits his own argument.
By acknowledging that such works are not merely human works, he fatally
limits his own denials.
       Non-Calvinists rightly remark that if it was a gift, then it was capable
of being rejected. A gift is not forced upon its recipient. If you give someone
a job and then hold a gun to his head to make sure he performs it, then it is
forced labor. MacArthur holds the gun of hell to the believer’s head,
demanding repentance as a necessity to escape hell. Then MacArthur stands
back and pretends that repentance is not labor, much less forced labor.
       Calvinists probably will object that this present book demands that
believers repent in order to escape the outer darkness. So is the outer
darkness not a gun in God’s hands? No. First, some of the Lord’s servants
do not serve Him. They are not rocks or automations but accountable,
freewill agents. Second, rewards are what are at stake, and rewards are based
(in part) on one’s work. Misthologists do not deny that human labor involves
human work. Third, salvation from the outer darkness does not picture
salvation from the loss of the gift of life (Mt 22:7,13). The outer darkness
does not picture a gun but a paycheck. God did not force Cornelius to give
alms. He simply put Cornelius on a path to life in which He could reward
him for doing as God prompted him.
       By making repentance a part of saving faith, the MacArthurian ordo
metanoeo (order of repentance) would place repentance after Cornelius’
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                          Page 265
alms-giving, praying, fearing God, doing what is right, and being well
spoken of by the Jews. That is a very strange placement: placing Cornelius’
change in mind after his change in action. Would not Cornelius change his
mind about his course of action before he changed his course of action?
Additionally, this unusual MacArthurian ordo appears to picture God as
giving Cornelius his saving change in mind because of Cornelius’ alms-
giving, praying, fearing God, doing what is right, and being well spoken of
by the Jews—a conclusion that MacArthur certainly, and rightly, would
reject. One cannot be given a gift because of one’s works. Rejecting this
impression derived from MacArthur’s ordo, however, requires that one
reject his argument altogether.
        The Lord may use various means to bring a person to the point of
repentance.193 Even if repentance is a point where some individual makes a
decisive turn that leads to life, actually traveling down the route one has
chosen necessarily will require works to reach one’s destination. If it still is
insisted that repentance is just the internal decision and not the
corresponding works, this still does not prove that God made Cornelius’
decision for him. This repentance was mediated not immediate. God may
have mediated this repentance to Cornelius through the means of sorrow or
gratitude, for example. God simply used various means to bring Cornelius to
the point of repentance. God did not make up his mind for him.
        Key variables must be arranged in a highly improbable fashion for
MacArthur’s proposal to be possible. (1) God would have had to give just a
change of mind, not a change in action, since bestowment of human action
would entail human effort and would end up basing the reception of eternal
life on human effort. (2) God would have had to bestow the gift through
irresistible grace rather than through enabling grace, since the latter would
enable human effort. Because being granted something from God does not
necessarily mean that human works are excluded, more evidence must be
provided by MacArthur than merely claiming that God-given = gift.
        Paul says that believers were “granted for Christ’s sake, not only to
believe in Him, but also to suffer for His sake” (Phil 1:29). Suffering for
Christ involves human effort. What God grants is the enablement to endure
suffering. God granted/enabled Cornelius to repent. God has given believers
the ability and opportunity to clothe themselves misthologically in good
works (Rev 19:8). The Lord gives rewards for works (Rev 11:18).
MacArthur’s statement that human works are excluded if God is the
bestower is based on something other than logic or Scripture. MacArthur’s
claim that repentance is granted with sovereign irresistibility is likewise
unbiblical. God says: “I gave her time to repent; and she does not want to
repent of her immorality” (Rev 2:21). Just because God gives someone the
ability and opportunity to repent, this does not mean that the person
necessarily will repent.
Page 266                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        Even if all such considerations as these were answerable in favor of
MacArthur (despite the considerable unlikelihood of such a possibility), the
order still wrongly makes Cornelius’ God-given change of heart the result of
his God-fearing actions rather than vice versa. The proper order would be
that God convicted Cornelius of his need to live a life that was pleasing to
Him and then Cornelius set out to do so in response to God’s convicting
grace and by means of God’s enabling grace. This process involved the
cooperation of Cornelius’ human effort and eventually led to saving faith.
        The most natural interpretation of the passage is that through some
resistible means God granted Cornelius a change in mind that led to his
change in action that led to Peter preaching the gospel that led to Cornelius
believing the gospel that led to Cornelius coming into the possession of
eternal life and put him on the path of life that leads to the crown of life.
Through God’s grace, Cornelius had a change of heart that resulted in his
taking the actions (i.e., performing the God-enabled human works) that
eventually resulted in his coming to saving faith. These works were
preconditions, rather than the condition, for eternal life. Whether or not these
works are considered a part of repentance or just the result of repentance,
they certainly had a role to play in the God-given process that eventually
resulted in Cornelius coming to faith. The gift of life is conditioned directly
and solely on saving faith, not on the (meritorious) preconditions that lead to
such faith.
                                 Will = Must
        As to MacArthur’s other repeated appeals to sovereignty, they prove
nothing. First, if a salvation by sovereignly-produced faith is still salvation
by faith, then a salvation by sovereignly-produced works is still salvation by
works. But the Bible insists that salvation is by faith apart from works.
Second, his distinction between root and fruit amounts to nothing, not only
because he frontloads the gospel with work in the form of willingness to
work but also because he backloads the gospel by making good fruits the
necessary postcondition to reach heaven. Lewis does the same thing.* As has
been demonstrated in MacArthur’s Faith Works† and now in his Gospel, not
only does MacArthur believe that genuine believers will turn from their sins
and persevere in a life of good works, he believes that they must do so in
order to reach heaven: Sinners “must turn from sin.” Good works are “the
necessary and inevitable result of true faith….true faith must always result
in good works.”194 The fruit is as obligatory as the root. He has made the
fruit of good works just as necessary as the root of faith for reaching heaven.
        According to conditionalists, perseverance is a necessary
postcondition of conversion. A regenerate believer cannot reach heaven
*
    See Illustration 30. Faith-Works Are Necessary, 100.
†
    See Condition, 180.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                         Page 267
without perseverance. Furthermore, in Arminian conditionalism, and
frequently in Calvinistic conditionalism as well, perseverance is necessary
for retention of regeneration. This perspective is true of MacArthurian
soteriology in particular: Since according to MacArthurianism God will not
keep a believer apart from perseverance in faith, it stands to reason that in
MacArthurianism perseverance in faith is necessary for the believer’s
retention of regeneration. By making perseverance necessary,
MacArthurianism necessarily makes postconditional perseverance a
condition for the retention of regeneration and for reaching heaven.
                    Illustration 106. Necessary Condition




                      Characteristic versus Condition
        Amazingly, despite his making good works necessary to reach
heaven, MacArthur wants to skirt around the conditional nature of his
MacArthurian postconversional performance by asserting that even if a
characteristic is necessary, it is not a condition: “Sanctification is a
characteristic of all who are redeemed, not a condition for their receiving
salvation” (italics his).195 Inquisitively, securitists may respond, “How about
for their keeping salvation?” Is sanctification a MacArthurian condition for
keeping salvation? This is the real question, and MacArthur refuses to deal
with it in this discussion. Naturally, sanctification is not a condition for
redemption since sanctification comes after redemption. That is not the
question. MacArthur is trying to shuffle his chickens with his shell game.*
The true question that needs to be addressed is whether sanctification is a
postcondition necessary to reach heaven in his theology. The question is not
whether or not sanctification is a precondition for regeneration. Of course it
is not. Sanctification is not a condition for the regeneration which preceded
it. But what he fails to demonstrate is that his argument avoids making

*
  See Illustration 60. MacArthur’s Hatchling, 181; Illustration 61.
MacArthurian Apples and Oranges, 182.
Page 268                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
sanctification (which is a postcondition of regeneration) a condition for
reaching heaven. Is glorification conditioned on MacArthurian
postconversional sanctification? His MacArthurian argument would say so,
but his MacArthurian lips say no: “Confession is not merely a human work;
it is prompted and energized by God….Again, confession is a characteristic
of true faith; it is not an additional condition of salvation.”196
        He claims that confession is not a condition of salvation. But how can
that be? Is he merely talking about initial salvation rather than final
salvation, about becoming saved rather than remaining saved? He quotes
Mt 7:21-23 on this matter and again obscures the issue: “Does this mean
confession before others is a condition of becoming a true Christian? No,
but it means that a characteristic of every genuine believer is that he or she
will profess faith in Christ unreservedly” (italics his.)197 Yet his explanation
does not answer the question, “How about for remaining a true Christian?”
Is confession required to remain a MacArthurian Christian? MacArthur has
admitted that he does not believe that God will keep a believer apart from
the believer’s perseverance. His claim that believers are preserved through
perseverance certainly makes it sound like perseverance is a condition for
preservation. According to MacArthur, not only will believers persevere,
they must persevere. The flipside of MacArthur’s sovereign will is a
conditional must.
        Apparently, the reason MacArthur is laboring so intensely to make a
strained distinction between characteristic and condition is because he can
sense that if the salvation he espouses is conditioned on his postconversional
performance, then it is a meritorious salvation. His invocation of Calvinistic
sovereignty will not deflect from such a conclusion. His appeal to the fact
that postconversional works are not merely human works but are grace-
enabled works does nothing to reduce the conditional or meritorious nature
of such works. Lewis tried the same argument, and it does not work.*
Arminians, Calvinists, Catholics, and Misthologists find common ground in
rooting their works in God’s energizing grace. MacArthur does not own this
turf. He will have to do better, indeed much better, than simply appeal to
God’s enablement as a means of proving that works enabled by God are not
works performed by man.
        MacArthur’s propensity to deny his postconditional conditionalism is
well known, as Wikipedia attests: “John Piper moved the argument [between
MacArthur and Hodges] by clarifying why good works are necessary – not
only for faith to be real, as MacArthur argued, but also for final salvation
from Hell.”198 The documentation provided herein and referenced in the
subject index readily shows that final salvation and justification are
conditioned on postconversional performance by Lewis and Edwards, and

*
    See Illustration 28. Lewis Speaks Rightly and Wrongly of Heaven, 98.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                        Page 269
by Arminianism and MacArthurianism. MacArthur just refuses to use the
word condition to own up to the conditionalism embedded in the
postconditional requirements in his own camp and in his own theology.
       Jesus has no problem with conditionalism, and neither do I. Jesus
shoots straight from the hip with Nicodemus, with a point-blank condition:
“You must be born again” (Jn 3:7). MacArthur has no trouble understanding
that Jesus is providing a “condition for Nicodemus’s salvation.”199
According to MacArthur, this must is a condition. Since MacArthur says that
one must produce postconversional good works in order to go to heaven,
how can MacArthur insist that such postconversional works are not a
condition for heaven? Is MacArthur’s must different from Jesus’ must?
       In any event, as to confessional texts (e.g., Mt 7:21-23; Mt 10:32-33;
2Tim 2:12), MacArthur seems shockingly ashamed of Jesus’ confession of
conditionalism. Regardless, the Bible is clear as to the conditional nature of
this confession and endurance. The Bible even places them in parallel
juxtaposition in the latter verse:

           •   If we endure, we shall also reign with Him.
           •   If we deny Him, He also will deny us.

       Rulership with Christ is conditioned on enduring with Christ. Not
being denied by Christ is likewise conditioned on not denying Christ.
Naturally, misthologists understand Jesus as conditioning our rulership with
Him in heaven on our enduring with Him on earth, and correspondingly His
not denying us such rulership in heaven is conditioned on our not denying
Him on earth. The dual use of if stresses the conditionalism. Contrastively,
MacArthur bizarrely comes to the opposite conclusion and conceives of
enduring as being a mark and characteristic of genuine regeneration rather
than a condition for rewards.200 MacArthur routinely overlooks the
significance of the if. On one occasion, he even elliptically omits the part
before the if when citing Col 1:22-23 so as to create a false impression that
genuine believers will persevere because they are reconciled: “He has now
reconciled you…if indeed you continue in the faith” (ellipses his.)201
MacArthur wishes to treat the verse as if the if were not conditional. Most
shockingly, MacArthur has the audacity to quote the passage in its entirety,
to emphasize the conditional aspect (the if and following) with italics, and
then obstinately to criticize Hodges for saying that it is conditional.
Somehow MacArthur does a summersault and asserts that the passage is a
guarantee that genuine faith will persevere to the end.
       It gets worse. In this very footnote, in which MacArthur asserts that
Col 1:22-23 is making a guarantee, MacArthur quotes Hodges as saying,
“There is nothing to support the view that perseverance in the faith is an
inevitable outcome of true salvation.”202 In his strawman caricature of
Hodges, MacArthur does not inform his readers as to what grounds Hodges
Page 270                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
uses for such a statement. Instead, MacArthur turns around and quotes
Col 1:22-23, as if this passage clearly refutes Hodges, seemingly implying
that Hodges had not considered this text. Truth be told however, the
quotation that MacArthur extracts from Hodges is from the same page on
which Hodges himself quotes Col 1:21-23 and in which Hodges
immediately states: “It is clear that ‘condition’ is the only appropriate word
here.”203 What MacArthur has done is to skip over this sentence from
Hodges, extract the next sentence from Hodges, turn around and quote
Col 1:22-23, as if Hodges had not considered the text, and ignored Hodges’
statement that Col 1:22-23 clearly expresses a condition. Some questionable
footwork is going on in this MacArthurian footnote.
       Using the verse breaks found in the KJV or NKJ as a reference point,
one can consult the Leedy Greek diagrams to see that v. 23 (i.e., if you
continue…) is used to modify the presentation of v. 22, not the
reconciliation of v. 21. So that the general reader will not have to shrug his
or her shoulders with a that’s-Greek-to-me attitude, perhaps the following
simplification will not be an oversimplification. Like MacArthur, I will use
the NAS translation, but for ease of reference I will modify my verse
delineation for the present discussion:
                  Illustration 107. Structure of Col 1:21-23




       The verb present in v. 22 is a Greek infinitive denoting purpose and is
well rendered by the NAS as in order to. One reason God has reconciled us
soteriologically is in order to present us before Him holy and blameless and
beyond reproach (i.e., as misthologically blameless). However, to be
presented in this manner, one must continue in the faith firmly established
and steadfast. Contrary to MacArthur’s elliptical statement, Paul is not
saying that God has reconciled us in the past if we continue in the faith in
the present. Rather, this present continuation is the condition for this future
presentation. Continuation is neither the condition nor the guaranteed result
of past reconciliation. This future presentation is mistholic, not soteric.
       To speak in terms of well-known biblical references, God saved us
from hell in hopes that He would be able to commend us with the words:
Well done. Nevertheless, our hearing this parabolic praise is conditioned on
how well we do. To the faithful slave, Jesus says: “Well done, good slave,
because you have been faithful in a very little thing, be in authority over ten
cities” (Lk 19:17). If we hear the words well done, it will be because we
have done well. Reconciliation makes us soteric slaves (i.e., Christians).
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                           Page 271
Thus, being a slave is conditioned on simple faith. Being good slaves,
however, requires that we be good (i.e., good Christians). Or as Jesus
expresses it on another occasion: “Well done, good and faithful slave; you
were faithful with a few things, I will put you in charge of many things”
(Mt 25:23). Bad slaves (i.e., carnal Christians) will be cast into the outer
darkness instead of being put in positions of rulership (Mt 25:30). Jesus does
not say anything bad about the good slaves in these parables. Like Jesus,
what Paul is saying in Col 1:21-23 is that if we want the Lord to speak only
positively about our Christian performance, we must have a good Christian
performance. This blameless presentation is dealing with rewards:
misthological relativity not soteriological perfection.
       Paul is talking to Christians about Christians being judged at the
Judgment Seat of Christ in Col 1:21-23. He is not talking about God judging
lost people at the Great White Throne Judgment. As a dispensationalist,
MacArthur should be sensitive to such an elementary observation, especially
since Hodges practically spelled it out on the very page from which
MacArthur was quoting. Instead, MacArthur makes a strawman argument by
refusing to admit that v. 23 is conditional. His discussion is perforated with
such holes in logic. This perforation makes his arguments easy to tear apart.
One such perforation occurs when, immediately after quoting Rom 10:10, he
claims that confession is a characteristic rather than a condition. To the
contrary, the parallelism within the verse resolutely says otherwise:

    •   With the heart man believes, resulting in righteousness
    •   With the mouth he confesses, resulting in salvation.

        Astoundingly, MacArthur claims that confession in this text is not a
condition for salvation!204 His treatment of the biblical text is appalling. In
this text, confession is most certainly a condition for salvation, just as belief
is a condition for righteousness. Once again, these biblical statements are in
parallel juxtaposition within the same verse. What MacArthur is refusing to
concede is that two different conditional outcomes are envisioned. This
distinction has been spelled out time and again in Free Grace literature.205
For sake of simplicity in the present discussion, summarization will suffice:
Faith results in justification (imputational righteousness); confession results
in sanctification salvation (practical righteousness).
        MacArthur’s theology, however, necessitates that perseverance be a
condition for entering heaven, and yet he tries to hide this conditionality
with rhetoric. Why? Obviously, advocates who take the bear-or-burn
approach regarding fruit bearing do not want to imply that final salvation is
conditioned on fruit bearing, because fruit bearing involves human work,
and they do not wish to be perceived as teaching salvation by works. It is
hard, indeed very hard, even for Reformed writers, to try to conceal the
human cooperation involved in jointly producing good fruit by the power of
Page 272                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
the Spirit, especially when the Bible repeatedly calls these postconversional
fruits good works! So it would be the death knell for MacArthur to admit
that final salvation is conditioned on these postconversional works.
                           Because versus Cause
        I do not wish to give the false impression that MacArthur stands alone
in failing to admit the conditional nature of fruit when he makes fruit a
guaranteed postconditional result. Far to the contrary, he is using an
argument that can be found readily in Arminianism, Calminianism, and
Calvinism. For example, Picirilli, like Forlines, is a very astute Arminian
who wishes to limit the loss of salvation to the loss of faith alone in his ordo
apostasia, in an attempt to avoid teaching that we are kept saved by our
works:

             1. It is extremely important to express our view in such a
      way that faith, and not works, is the sole condition of
      salvation….
             “Saved by faith and kept by works” simply will not
      accord with Biblical teaching….
             2. In whatever ways the positive “works” of a believer
      are involved in perseverance, we must relate them to faith and
      not as conditions of continuing in salvation as such….
             .…it is the faith and not the evidence of it that saves.
             In that sense, we may call them [works] “essential,” just
      as bearing apples is “essential” to an apple tree but manifests
      what the tree is instead of making the tree what it is.206

        As Picirilli realizes, if he cannot avoid making postconversional work
a condition for retaining salvation, then he is teaching a false gospel.
Therefore, he wants to treat postconversional good works as essential non-
conditions that do not make (i.e., do not cause) us to be what we are. But can
the fruit really be reduced to being essential yet non-causational and non-
conditional? Can one really eat the fruit from Picirilli’s hermeneutical tree
and yet not die from being poisoned with works-righteousness?
        In similar fashion, Geisler (a Calminian logician) comments, “Only
the faith that takes ‘root’ and produces ‘fruit’ (Luke 8:13,15) is true saving
faith,” to which he adds the old adage, “we are not saved by works but by
faith that works.” “Good works flow naturally and inevitably from”
justifying faith.207 To the contrary, in making good works inevitable, Geisler
appends these works as soteriological baggage necessary to reach heaven.
Since these misperceptions are so widespread, are found in diverse forms of
conditionalism, and are encountered in advocates with pronounced biblical
and logical insight, attributing such defects to blemishes in the integrity or
intelligence of those adopting this perspective is ill-advised. My intention is
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                            Page 273
not to engage in personal attacks by calling the integrity or intelligence of
conditionalists into question.* Their position, however, is certainly not
unassailable, and it is their position that must be attacked since it logically
leads to works-righteousness.
       Arminianism, Calminianism, and Calvinism find common ground in
seeking to deny the contingent nature of postconversional works lest they be
perceived as teaching salvation by works. Such conditionalists demonstrate
sensitivity to the necessity of disavowing the conditional nature of
postconversional works in order to avoid teaching an accursed soteriology.
Consequently, if unconditional security is successful in demonstrating the
contingent nature of postconversional works, then, by token of the implicit
and explicit admissions on the part of such conditionalists, conditional
security has been refuted. The stakes are high; unconditional security cannot
afford to lose this round.
       As to Picirilli’s analogy, true enough, apples do not make a tree an
apple tree but rather manifest the fact that the tree is an apple tree. The
thought here obviously goes back to Jesus’ words in Mt 7:17-20, where
Jesus uses a similar analogy to teach that those people who produce bad fruit
will burn in hell, and those who bear good fruit will go to heaven. The more
thoughtful conditionalistic rationale is that such people go to hell because
they are bad trees, not because of their bad fruit. The nature of the tree
(representing regeneration or lack thereof) is claimed to be the reason the
saved or lost, respectively, produce the corresponding fruit, and their
destination is determined by their nature rather than by what is produced by
such nature. Their condemnation is claimed to be conditioned exclusively on
their unregenerate nature rather than on the works produced by that nature.
Granted, such an argument does have a logical appeal. Even so, this appeal
is more superficial than real.
       To restate Picirilli’s argument in terms of causation (which is the
manner in which Picirilli frames the analogy with his word making), good
fruit does not cause one to be saved but demonstrates whether or not one is
regenerate. Similarly, our faith does not cause our regeneration; rather, we
are regenerate because of our faith. Such arguments regarding causation are
well taken herein and are in harmony with standard causational perspectives
in not necessarily equating cause with because.† The present book is not

*
  Nevertheless, when a writer such as MacArthur says that a Free Grace position
is shocking or when an Arminian says that Free Grace advocates have not given
careful consideration to the issues, then it is necessary to demonstrate that such
Calvinistic and Arminian posturing is susceptible to the same criticisms.
†
  See Illustration 94. Typical Causation: A ⇒ B, 240. Because may express a
condition rather than a cause, but as a general rule I are not making a sharp
distinction.
Page 274                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
asserting that the bad fruit causes the bad tree to be cast into the fire; rather,
the bad tree is thrown into the fire (at least in part) because of its bad fruit
(cause ≠ because). However, Picirilli is asking us to believe that there is no
causal relationship between being cast into the fire and the bad fruit. His
argument would be tantamount to claiming that a person is cast into hell
because of his or her sin rather than because of his or her sins. Such a
dichotomy is false. The lost are cast into hell because of their sin nature and
because of the sins produced by that nature. Picirilli’s distinction likewise
collapses. The bad tree is cast into hell because of its bad fruit. If bad fruit
refers to works, then salvation from hell is conditioned on works. Picirilli
has failed to avoid teaching salvation by works.
                      Evidence-Inference (Inductive)
        Nonetheless, it would be premature to dispense with Picirilli’s
argument at this point. I wish to engage my opponents’ arguments at full
strength, even if I have to strengthen (or at least clarify) their arguments for
them in order to do so. His argument, in a nutshell, is basically that
postconversional works keep postconversional faith alive, and
postconversional faith, in turn, keeps us alive spiritually. Picirilli is too sharp
of a theologian to wittingly condition soteric death directly on a believer’s
works. Therefore, our being kept alive soteriologically is conditioned by
Picirilli on our perseverance in faith rather than on our perseverance in
works.
        I have already countered this type of argument by showing that a
biblical ordo apostasia demonstrates that postconversional death can come
about as a direct result of a breakdown in a believer’s postconversional
performance. My contention is that since soteriological salvation from
spiritual death cannot biblically be attributed to a believer’s work, this
postconversional death cannot be soteriological. Postconversional death for a
believer must be something other than soteriological death. Misthological
death is the most plausible outcome of moral apostasy. Rather than repeat
this argument, I will allow the possibility for the moment that I have failed
to prove that there is a causal relationship between moral apostasy and
soteriological death in soteriological conditionalism. An alternate way to kill
this conditional dragon is still available.
        In taking direct aim at the heart of Picirilli’s argument, I have pointed
out that he appeals to works as the evidence rather than the cause of our
nature. Laying aside my objections for the moment that the fiery
consequences in Mt 7:17-20 are based on both the bad nature and bad fruit
produced by that nature and that the issue is not what makes the tree bad but
why it was cast into the fire, I will give the conditional dragon a sporting
chance and proceed with the Picirillian appeal to causation based on
evidence. His hypothesis, then, is that apostates are thrown into hell because
of their loss of life which was directly because of their loss of faith.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                           Page 275
Although their works were necessary to keep that faith alive, they are not
thrown into hell because of their breakdown in works. Rather, their works
simply led to a breakdown in their faith. More importantly, for the current
scope of the discussion in picturing the conditional perspective, these works
merely are considered the evidence that these moral failures lost eternal life.
Failure in moral performance did not directly cause these moral apostates to
lose eternal life according to the Picirillian theory.
        Again, I will ignore, for the moment, that this hypothesis is untenable
since many of the people in question (even in Mt 7:17-20) still believe in
Jesus and are thrown in hell despite believing in Him. After all, I would
contend that they are thrown into hell because they believe in Jesus for a
performance-based entrance. Surely Picirilli would concur, but he certainly
would suggest that those thrown into the fire should have believed in Jesus
for an evidence-based entrance instead of a performance-based entrance. I
do not wish to underestimate the potential strength of my opponents’
arguments. Astute conditionalists such as Picirilli and Shank certainly would
agree with me that believers cannot trust in their postconversional works for
entrance into heaven. Accordingly, the questions that need to be considered
are: “Can postconversional performance be restricted to the arena of
evidence? Even if this postconversional performance is limited to playing a
role of evidence, are the lost saved from hell (at least in part) because of this
evidence?” Securitists rightly respond negatively.
        This type of conditionalistic argument (as expressed by Edwards) has
been found defective. Edwards and Logan also try to slip in soteriological
performance by making a distinction between causes and conditions and by
appealing to good works as evidence. Even so, Edwards found such works to
be directly necessary, not indirectly necessary (contra Picirilli), for salvation
from the fires of hell. I can pit the Edwardsean conditionalistic appeal to
good works as necessary evidence against the Picirillian conditionalistic
appeal to good works as necessary evidence to demonstrate that
conditionalists cannot even agree among themselves as to the judicial nature
of this evidence. In Edwardseanism, this evidence is necessary for salvation,
indissolubly connected with it so that salvation from damnation truly and
judicially depends upon this evidence.* But if final salvation judicially
depends upon this fruit, then salvation is conditioned on this fruit. Still, let
us proceed under the assumption that Edwards is wrong and that Picirilli is
somehow right and that this indispensible necessity is auxiliary and not a
condition for final salvation, despite the obviously self-contradictory nature
of such a proposal. Can Picirilli actually manage to pull a Houdini and
escape from the inescapable conclusion that he has made good works a
condition by appealing to works as merely essential evidence? No.

*
    See Arminians, 165; Logan’s Praise, 168.
Page 276                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       One argument that I could advance on Picirilli’s behalf is to appeal to
an evidence-inference form of causation. The wedding band is a popular
example of this form of inference: If (A) she is wearing a wedding band,
then (B) she is (probably) married. For sake of expediency, the Matthean
warning will be reduced to this: If you are a bad tree, then you will produce
bad fruit, and if you produce bad fruit, then you will go to hell. This warning
certainly seems to be a simple chain of causation: A ⇒ B ⇒ C.

                    (A) Bad tree ⇒ (B) Bad fruit ⇒ (C) Hell

        Bad fruit is the immediate cause for being thrown into hell, and being
a bad tree is the ultimate cause for being thrown into hell. Both jointly
constitute the reasons a person is sent to hell (A & B ⇒ C). The lost are not
thrown into hell for simply being sinners but also for sinning. They are
condemned to hell, at least in part, because of the fruits they produce.* The
judicial nature of this evidence is confirmed by Jesus when He responds to
the defendant: “Depart from Me, you who practice lawlessness” (Mt 7:23).
Is it not rather peculiar for Picirilli to suggest that they are not caused to
depart because of their lawless practice? Regardless, let us overlook this
Achilles’ heel in Picirilli’s argument and give him the benefit of doubt to see
if there is any room for any reasonable benefit of a doubt, even when
ignoring this strand of evidence.
        In an evidence-inference form of causation, the evidence comes first
and the cause which supplies the proposed reason for that evidence comes
last. In other words, the protasis and apodosis trade places from what one
would find in a typical cause-effect relationship. Let us see if this will help
the Picirillian hypothesis. The first part of the logical expression now
becomes the inverse: (B) bad fruit ⇒ (A) bad tree. If you produce bad fruit,
then you are a bad tree. Producing bad fruit does not make/cause you to be a
bad tree. Rather, you produce bad fruit because you are a bad tree. Now, let
us put the entire expression back together by combining this evidence-
inference with the effect-cause for the last part of the expression:

                    (B) Bad fruit ⇒ (A) Bad tree ⇒ (C) Hell
                        Evidence       inference       result

       In my reconstruction of the Picirillian position, (B ⇒ A) if you
produce bad fruit, then you are a bad tree. And (A ⇒ C) if you are a bad
tree, you are sent to hell. So you are sent to hell because of your inherent
badness (because of A), not because of your bad performance (i.e., not

*
  See discussion of the asymmetrical relation between damnation and salvation
as illustrated by a digon in Woolly Wolves and Woolless Sheep.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                          Page 277
because of B). Your poor performance is only an infallible indication of your
inherent badness. In my reconstruction of the typical fruit-root argument as
used by such conditionalists, it readily becomes apparent why diverse
conditionalists from Arminianism, Calminianism, and Calvinism find this
interpretation so attractive. It provides them with the means of making good
works a necessary part of the equation without conditioning salvation
directly on such works, or so it would seem. The logical attractiveness of
this approach is very seductive, however.
       Whatever else their shortcomings, at least Edwards and Logan were
not completely seduced by the root-fruit fallacy in that they recognize the
conditional nature of the fruit. If fruit is theologically necessary, it is
logically a condition. Piper admits as much concerning this Matthean
passage:

      So a transformed life is a necessary condition of eternal life, but
      does not earn or merit eternal life.
          Or, as Jesus said, in Matthew 7:16-17, “You will know
      them by their fruits.”208

Granted, Piper does appeal to good works as evidence, but, like Edwards,
Piper provides a judicial flavor to this fruit:

      The appearance of fruit does not make a tree a fruit tree. But it
      shows that it is a fruit tree. So a transformed life does not make
      a person a Christian. But a transformed life shows that a person
      is a Christian.
           In summary then: in the last day there will be a judgment.
      It will settle finally and publicly who enters eternal life and who
      doesn’t….But that verdict will “accord with our deeds”—our
      daily lives will give evidence that we trusted Christ more than
      money.209

       While Piper regards fruit as the necessary result (treating it as
evidence), at the same time (in a manner reminiscent of Edwards), he
indicates that this fruit is judicial evidence upon which one’s eternal fate
legally is conditioned. They will be judged, and the verdict determining their
outcome will be according to their deeds (i.e., their works). More
conditionalists should wake up to the same realization in their own
conditionalism. The appeal to fruit as necessary or infallible evidence
naturally leads to the conclusion that the fruit is judicial and thus
conditional.
       Granted, Piper believes that the free gift of eternal life is unearned,
even though it is conditioned on the believer’s performance, because it is
unfailingly produced as a result of the believer’s union with Christ. The
Page 278                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
counterarguments already supplied herein naturally would apply to his
attempt to make eternal life the unearned result of a believer’s performance.
For example, just because these works are performed through God’s
energizing power, this does not mean that these works are not our works or
that what we receive in response to such works can be considered a gift
rather than a reward. Putting such fallacies in Piper’s logic aside for the
moment, however, he may be credited at least for recognizing that his
conditional theology makes good works a condition. That is more than can
be said for many conditionalists, such as Picirilli and MacArthur, who try to
affirm the necessity of fruition and yet deny that fruition is a condition.
Nevertheless, to give this conditional dragon yet another sporting chance, I
will proceed with the assumption that Edwards, Logan, and Piper are wrong
and that Picirilli, Geisler, and MacArthur are somehow right that this
necessity does not imply conditionality. Can the fallacy of denying
contingency be demonstrated from the premises of those conditionalists who
use this type of argument? Yes, it can.
        First, in order to be sure that I have given my opponents’ argument its
fair due, let it be reiterated that I do not necessarily challenge any and every
conclusion that Mt 7:16 is an example of evidence-inference. Given my
definition for causation-effect as involving deductive certainty and my
definition for evidence-inference as rising no higher than inductive
probability, if one were to interpret Mt 7:16 in terms of probability, then I
would acquiesce that such an interpretation is in harmony with the evidence-
inference approach.* Frequently, for example, even those adopting a
conditionalistic interpretation of this passage will water down their
conclusion so as to doubt rather than to deny the salvation of a professed
believer living in sin. Such conditionalists hesitantly will express their
doubts about whether or not someone who is living a morally defeated life is
saved, but they balk at definitively concluding that such a person is lost. This
tendency, which is frequently found in the conditional camp, creates a
tension with the unequivocal claims by those conditionalists who appeal to
the evidence-inference approach as a means to conclude that living a good
life is absolutely essential. Conditionalistic claims that such fruit is essential
are at odds with other conditionalistic claims that the absence of such fruit
only indicates what is probable. Not only are conditionalists at odds with
themselves as to whether or not the fruit is conditional, but there is also a
division even among those conditionalists who deny that it is conditional as
to just how necessary such fruit really is. Yet even a watered-down

*
  I do not suggest that this passage can be properly understood as exegetically
casting doubt upon a believer’s salvation based on his or her performance. I am
simply making a limited acquiescence based on a pure, but limited, logical
analysis that focuses on this verse without contextual considerations.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                          Page 279
conditional approach will still drown the Picirilli-Geisler-MacArthur
argument to death.
       For example, using an illustration popularized by Wallace, as a
representation of the evidence-inference causation, consider the wedding
band example of evidence-inference into which I interjected the word
probably:*

•   If she is wearing a wedding band, then she is (probably) married.

The reason she is married is not because she is wearing the wedding band.
Rather, the most probable reason that she is wearing the wedding band is
because she is married.210
                  Explanation-Evidence (Abductive)
       Because the probable cause for her wearing the wedding band is
found in the second half of the sentence (i.e., in the apodosis), the order of
the statement may be reversed so that the sentence is expressed in typical
cause-effect sequence:

•   If she is married, then that would probably explain why she is wearing a
    wedding band.

       In this restatement of the relationship, I have used abductive logic to
place the probable cause first, since this is the cause-effect order Jesus uses:
“You will know them [i.e., the cause] by their fruits [i.e., the effect]”
(Mt 7:16). Again, the discussion of this verse is limited to probabilities,
regardless of whether or not one uses the inductive evidence-inference
approach or this reversed abductive explanation-evidence approach. Not all
married women wear wedding bands all the time, so I have to insert the
word probably. Speaking in terms of probability (or at least thinking in
terms of implied probability) comes naturally when speaking inductively or
abductively. However, this means that the Picirilli-Geisler-MacArthur
interpretation is unnatural. If they are thinking exclusively in terms of
induction or abduction (which is apparently the case since the Picirilli-
Geisler-MacArthur perspective takes fruit as evidence rather than as a
condition), then they are pressing the nature of the evidence to an
unwarranted level of certainty in which the evidence is absolutely necessary.
Their position logically would result in restating the illustration as:
•   If she is married, then that would definitely explain why she is wearing a
    wedding band.

*
  Even Wallace notes that the inference is limited to observation that is
inductively suggestive. Therefore, it would only denote probability.
Page 280                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

        Necessarily, has to be, and must be are the types of expressions that
MacArthur uses to describe the logical connection between root and fruit.
Such terms denote certainty and convert the expression from one of
probability to necessity. Yet in a strictly evidence-inference approach or in a
purely explanation-evidence approach, such certainty is impossible. To
restate, the MacArthurian claim is: the fruit is necessary; you have to have
it; you must have it; otherwise, you are not really saved.
        However, in an explanation-evidence approach, such claims are like
saying, “If you are married, then you are necessarily wearing a wedding
band. The ring does not cause you to be married. Nevertheless, if you are not
wearing the ring, then this proves that you are not married. The ring is
necessary; you have to have it; you must have it; otherwise you are not
really married.” Such an argument is clearly illogical. The MacArthurian
insistence on the fruit of good works as necessary evidence is consequently
irrational. Picirilli likewise appeals to the evidence of good works as being
essential. Doing so essentially means that wearing a wedding band is
essential to being married. To say the least, the conditionalistic inductive or
abductive marriage of fruit with root so as to produce a certain result is
highly strained.
        Using their logic, being married would cause you to wear a wedding
band. To be sure, from the vantage point of their logic, the wedding band
does not cause the marriage; nevertheless, it is an infallible indication of the
marriage. Their conclusion thus is false. Or restated in terms of tree and
fruit, being a bad tree causes you to produce bad fruit. Admittedly, the bad
fruit does not cause you to be a bad tree, but it is an infallible indicator of
your being a bad tree. Granted, this latter conclusion is true, but the
corresponding wedding band analogy is false. But why? The reason is to be
found in the context of the tree-fruit discussion. The inference regarding the
relationship between the tree and fruit is based on more than mere evidence-
inference.
        The tremendous strain evidenced in the conditionalistic evidence-
inference approach and in the corresponding explanation-evidence
arguments is because of their placing such terms (as necessarily, has to,
must, essential) in the wrong category. Such terminology is not conducive to
the inductive or abductive models but is well suited to the deductive model.
In deductive cause-effect relationships, if the protasis is true, then the
apodosis must necessarily be true as well.* For example, consider the
statement: If it is an apple, then it has to be a fruit. Being a fruit is essential
to the nature of an apple. This is the language of cause-effect conditionality.


*
    See Illustration 94. Typical Causation: A ⇒ B, 240.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                         Page 281
       Consequently, on the basis of sheer logic, the Picirilli-Geisler-
MacArthur appeal to fruit-root as being an example of necessity but not of
conditionality is illogical. This passage is using deduction, not merely
induction or abduction. The fruit is necessary because, contextually, the
Lord is including a cause-effect relationship, not merely an evidence-
inference. But if the fruit is necessary and if the logical relation in the
passage encompasses a deductive cause-effect condition, then the outcome
of heaven versus hell is contingent on the fruit. And if the outcome is
contingent on the fruit, then by Picirilli’s own admission, he is teaching
salvation by works since he equates fruit with works.
                Illustration 108. Conditionalistic Conclusion
       Inductive effect-cause: necessarily bad fruit ⇒ bad tree
       Deductive cause-effect: necessarily bad tree ⇒ bad fruit
       Conclusion: bad tree ⇔ bad fruit

In summary, Jesus is doing more than drawing an inference. He is giving a
cause-and-effect relation. The Lord is stating a condition, not asking a
question. My previous perception has now proven to be the correct
deduction. The Lord is providing a chain of causation: A ⇒ B ⇒ C .

                     (A) Bad tree ⇒ (B) Bad fruit ⇒ (C) Hell

       Conditionalists who seek to avoid this conclusion wish to invert the
order of the first two terms in an attempt to make hell directly contingent on
the nature of the tree: (B) bad fruit ⇒ (A) bad tree ⇒ (C) hell. Such an
order, however, is adverse to the abduction that the Lord is making: (A) bad
tree ⇒ (B) bad fruit ⇒ (C) hell. Additionally, the conditionalistic inversion
is insensitive to the implications of the deductive nature of the context.
Moreover, the conditionalistic inversion is futile because conditionalism
leads to a relationship in which hell necessarily is conditioned on fruit:
bad tree ⇔ bad fruit (i.e., cause ⇔ effect). Granted, fruit is only the
necessary effect and therefore a condition rather than cause for hell in
conditionalism. Even so, that conclusion is all that is needed to show that
conditionalism conditions hell on works since conditionalists equate fruit
with works (i.e., perseverance).
                        Cause-Effect (Deductive)
       So how might a conditionalist still try to avoid admitting that they are
conditioning salvation on works in such a passage? Could they admit the
cause-effect relationship between the tree and fruit (which logically makes
the fruit necessary) and yet insist that the fruit is not a condition for the
salvation from the burning? Not logically. Jesus expresses a cause-effect
relationship between the tree and fruit when He says that a bad tree produces
Page 282                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
bad fruit (Mt 7:17), so we confidently can say, with deductive certainty, that
(A) bad tree ⇒ (B) bad fruit. Jesus also expresses the other deductive
certainty: (A) good tree ⇒ (B) good fruit.
        The Lord obviously is making the differentiation between the good
and bad categories mutually exclusive. Consequently, I would have no
objection to a conditionalist suggesting a logical contraposition: (B) not
good fruit ⇒ (A) not good tree. It is when they make this contraposition and
then insist that this is the logical order that I question their deduction:
(B) not good fruit ⇒ (A) not good tree ⇒ (C) Hell. Such logistical
gymnastics are interesting but hardly persuasive. The actual relationship
between A and B is A ⇔ B in terms of being coextensive and even more
precisely A ⇒ B in terms of logical sequence. So for a conditionalist to
insist that one has to place B before A is highly suspect. Moreover, the Lord
does not express His statement in a reverse contraposition when He
concludes with the nature of the condition: “Every tree that does not bear
good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire” (Mt 7:19). Common
sense should suffice to make it apparent that Jesus is saying: (A) bad tree ⇒
(B) bad fruit ⇒ (C) Hell. The heart of this passage is unmistakably
deductive. Being thrown into hell is conditioned on the bad fruit. To define
that fruit in terms of works is to condition salvation from hell on works.
        For the sake of those who like Geisler are logicians, for the sake of
those readers who may be more visually oriented, and for the sake of KISS, I
will express these conclusions in terms of Venn diagrams along with some
practical illustrations to demonstrate the inescapable conditional nature of
the heart of this passage. I will begin by condensing the latter part of
Mt 7:19 to a conditional statement and by simultaneously expressing it
beside an appropriate everyday illustration:

      If (B) you do not pay your taxes, then (C) you will go to jail.
      If (B) you do not bear good fruit, then (C) you will go to hell.
                        Illustration 109. Jail and Hell
 (B Versus Not B) and (Not B ⇒ C)        (B Versus Not B) and (Not B ⇒ C)
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                          Page 283


        In logic, one may affirm (via a contraposition) that not B then C is
equivalent to not C then B. Or expressed in terms of symbolic logic (;B ⇒
C) = (;C ⇒ B). Accepting the cause-effect statement as true for the sake of
illustration, if you do not go to jail, then you must have paid your taxes.
Accordingly, if you do not go to hell, then you must have borne good fruit.
Would one not say that paying your taxes is a condition for not going to jail?
Naturally. Would one not also conclude that bearing good fruit is a condition
for not going to hell? Certainly.
        In using Venn diagrams, one may express the relationship between B
and not B by coloring the outside of B as not B. In this case, I am associating
not B with its result C, and I have shaded the area outside of B
accordingly.211 Paying one’s taxes is a necessary condition for not going to
jail. Likewise, bearing good fruit is a necessary condition for not going to
hell. This demonstration suffices to show that conditionalists who use this
passage to teach that fruit represents works as necessary to escape hell are
conditioning salvation on works. Nevertheless, it may be objected that I
have not expressed the relationship of A to B in the above illustrations. If so,
doing so is no problem. For simplicity sake, I will be content with the typical
manner in which deduction is normally expressed.* Surely, there is no
objection to the following summation.
                Illustration 110. (Bad ⇒ Bad) and (Good ⇒ Good)
     (A ) Bad Tree ⇒ (B) Bad Fruit           (A ) Good Tree ⇒ (B) Good Fruit




If the corresponding representations on the right-hand side of the above two
carts are plugged in, the corresponding composite is obtained:

When using Venn diagrams, a typical representation of a contraposition
would shade the outside area of the deduction as showing not B (and
consequently not A). So shaded area = not. If you are a good tree, then you
will produce good fruit and not go to hell as a result. For sake of
completeness, a picture of its polar opposite is also included:
      Illustration 112. Contraposition of (A) Bad Tree ⇒ (B) Bad Fruit




If you are a bad tree, then you will produce bad fruit and not go to heaven as
a result. These Venn diagrams are simply ways of picturing what Jesus
already has made apparent in the text itself. One should not have to play the
role of Sherlock to put these clues together.
