A preference for contrapositions in the above illustrations is prevalent, since
this is the manner in which Jesus expresses the relation in Mt 7:19 with not.
But for those who would be interested in seeing what the relationship would
look like with straight deduction, the following representations are offered.
                        Illustration 114. A ⇒ B ⇒ C
Page 286                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

       To put it mildly, those conditionalists who seek to deny that the
outcome C is conditioned on B are engaging in strained exegesis. For those
who think that this approach is too logical, I contend that there is no
disparity between being logical and biblical in this passage. I labor in The
Outer Darkness to show that such root-fruit arguments exegetically
condition our salvation on our labor. Still, I will not belabor the point any
further here. The conditional nature of the collaborating texts briefly
examined above and my interaction with Forlines regarding ordo apostasia
suffice without reprise. The fruits are necessarily conditional, explicitly so in
the Edwards-Logan-Piper representation and implicitly so in the Picirilli-
Geisler-MacArthur faction. All forms of Protestant conditionalism (whether
found in Arminianism, Calminianism, or Calvinism) condition salvation
from hell on moral performance and, in so doing, teach salvation by works.
                           KISS Interpretation
       When I matter-of-factly gave my wife a Readers Digest version of the
above logical conclusion of the Matthean passage, she could not believe her
ears. How could her husband condition salvation from hell on bad fruit!
Would that not be teaching salvation by works? So rather than completely
drop the matter here and proceed on to a logical examination of the root,
perhaps it would be wise for me to pause and provide my wife with a KISS
interpretation.

Fruit ≠ Practice
       A logical analysis of the passage in Mt 7:15-23 demonstrates that
those who make good fruit a theological necessity cannot stop short of
acknowledging that the salvation entailed is conditioned on that fruit. For
many interpreters, this would mean that their theology reduces to teaching
soteriological salvation by works because they would equate the fruit with
the moral practice found in v. 23, which, in consequence, would be a
salvation conditioned on lawful obedience. So how does the present writer
avoid teaching salvation by works in this context and yet agree with those
conditionalists who condition salvation on the fruit in this passage?
Elementary, my dear Watsonette. I examine the clues left behind by the Lord
and pay attention to the details that He has embedded within the narrative.

                            Singular versus Plural Fruit
             15
              Beware of the false prophets, who come to you in
      sheep’s clothing, but inwardly are ravenous wolves. 16 You
      will know them by their fruits. Grapes are not gathered from
      thorn bushes, nor figs from thistles, are they? 17 Even so, every
      good tree bears good fruits; but the bad tree bears bad fruits. 18
      A good tree cannot produce bad fruits, nor can a bad tree
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                             Page 287
                              19
      produce good fruits. Every tree that does not bear good fruit_
      is cut down and thrown into the fire. 20 So then, you will know
      them by their fruits.*
                             Profession versus Practice
              21
                 Not everyone who says to Me, “Lord, Lord,” will
      enter the kingdom of heaven; but he who does the will of My
      Father who is in heaven. 22 Many will say to Me on that day,
      “Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in Your name, and in Your
      name cast out demons, and in Your name perform many
      miracles?” 23 And then I will declare to them, “I never knew
      you; depart from Me, you who practice lawlessness.” (Mt7:15-
      23)

Know ≠ Guess
       The them of v. 16 (and v. 20) clearly refers to the false prophets in
v. 15. Discernment of false prophets is the subject matter. False teachers can
be correctly detected as such by their false teaching. False teachers teach
false doctrine. (Commentators note that in the OT detecting a false prophet
via their prophecy is a common theme.) Therefore, when the Lord notifies us
that we can know these false teachers by their fruit, He is most readily
understood as saying that we can accurately know (epiginosko) false
teachers by their teaching.212 No guessing is involved. Something more than
mere inductive probability is suggested lexically and is demanded
contextually. The Lord says you will know, not merely that you can know.
This passage employs absolute language: will know, will know, cannot
produce, and never knew. It is safe to conclude that we can know with
absolute certainty that those who teach false doctrine are false teachers.
       Since this passage is dealing with soteriological themes, there can be
no doubt that here the Lord is instructing us as to how to discern which
teachers teach a false gospel. Without a doubt, we can know without any
doubt that those who teach a false gospel are false teachers. In this particular
passage, fruits would not include their actions but would be limited to their
teaching. False teachers frequently fool the gullible into thinking that they
are good teachers because such teachers often live morally good lives. Many
teachers of works-righteousness have a life of works-righteousness to back
up their teaching. Soteriologically, trying to discern them as false teachers
by their works is a foolhardy quest. Logically, those who try to infer whether
or not someone is a false teacher or a good teacher from the evidence they
see in the teacher’s life must reduce the passage to inductive probability.

*
  Although most translations render fruit (karpos) as singular in Mt 7:17-18, it is
plural. The NAS has been modified accordingly in the above rendition. The
singular time that fruit is singular in this passage is in Mt 7:19.
Page 288                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Such an approach runs counter to the tenor of the context. Deductive
certainty is definitely the superior interpretation: (1) Everyone who teaches a
false gospel is a false teacher. So (2) if you encounter someone teaching a
false gospel, then you can know with deductive certainty that he or she is a
false teacher. Such certainty comes from focusing on the teacher’s teaching
rather than being fooled by the teacher’s lifestyle.

Fruit ≠ Fruits
        Both verses that describe how we can discern these false teachers in
this context use the plural form of fruits: “You will know them by their
fruits” (Mt 7:16,20). A holistic interpretation of their message in its entirety
is in view. Just because these teachers say that we are saved by grace apart
from works, this does not qualify them as good teachers—if they turn around
and deny this teaching by implicitly or explicitly conditioning the final
realization of this salvation on faith that works. By making good works
necessary to enter heaven, false teachers unquestionably demonstrate that
they are false teachers. Therefore, it is by their words about soteric faith
which will reveal whether or not they truly espouse saving faith.
        When the Lord provides His chain of causation in the interior part of
this paragraph, according to Matthean Greek text, the Lord continues to use
the plural form of fruit, thereby demonstrating (among other things) a
continuity with the deductive certainty and embedded conditionality in the
passage. However, when the rubber meets the road, or in this case, when it
comes time to put the fruit tree into the fire (7:19), the Lord switches to fruit
singular in Greek to make it clear that salvation versus damnation is
conditioned on singular fruit. This shift, along with the absolute language
and the limitation of the condition to the singular form, strongly suggests a
distinction between plural fruits and singular fruit in this particular context
so that the singular fruit produced individually by the good tree refers to
saving faith as opposed to the non-saving faith produced individually by the
bad tree. For the sake of KISS, this differentiation can be expressed
pictorially.
            Illustration 115. Distinction Between Fruit and Fruits
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                         Page 289
       A proper identification of the fruit allows a logical confirmation of
the chain of causation without teaching salvation by faith-works:

       (A) Bad tree [lost] ⇒ (B) Bad fruit [defective faith] ⇒ (C) Hell
       1. Good tree [saved] ⇒ (B) Good fruit [saving faith] ⇒ (C) Heaven

Fruit = Faith
        This identification of singular fruit as faith explains why the lost
cannot produce good fruit, and why the saved cannot produce bad fruit: “A
good tree cannot produce bad fruit, nor can a bad tree produce good fruit”
(Mt 7:18). It is absolutely impossible for one kind of tree (good or bad) to
produce the fruit associated with the other type of tree. The good tree, for
example, cannot produce the bad fruit because the singular good fruit is the
narrow fruit that shows that one has entered the narrow gate (Mt 7:13-14).
Specifically, the singular good fruit that the good tree produces is saving
faith. The plural fruit produced by a teacher teaching a true soteric gospel of
faith alone in Christ alone is not a different kind of fruit (such as a broad
fruit) but multiple, verbal attestations to the type of fruit and therefore a
picture of the underlying faith possessed by such a teacher.
        This interpretation is in harmony with those securitists and
insecurities who correctly insist that the way we discern false teachers’
teaching is through their teaching. Even Lenski, for example, acknowledges
that the fruits refer exclusively to the false teachers’ words, not to their
works or to a combination of their works and words.213 And although Lenski
is to be commended for taking such a position, a more technically accurate
perspective is possible: Good fruit singular refers to saving faith
exclusively, and good fruit plural refers to saving faith pictorially.
Continuity between a prophet’s teaching and his faith is presumed so that a
prophet’s teaching concerning faith is the means by which we accurately
determine what a prophet believes. Plural fruits from any given teacher (as
rendered by the majority of the English texts in vv. 16, 20) is a metonymy
for his or her faith as discerned by his or her teaching. Yet again, for the
sake of KISS, this metonym may be represented pictorially.
            Illustration 116. Continuity Between Fruit and Fruits
Page 290                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        The words of a prophet/teacher/preacher about soteric faith are the
filter/window/transparency/picture through which the nature of his or her
underlying faith is seen. The faith produced by the lost teacher, for instance,
is the defective faith of works-righteousness espoused by conditional
security. Conditionalists believe in Jesus’ name for kingdom entrance, but
they also believe in their works performed in Jesus’ name for such entrance
and are denied entrance as a result. They profess faith in Christ, but they
were never saved because they never produced good fruit (i.e., saving faith).
They only produced defective faith in Christ. Faith in faith-works will never
save from hell. Heaven versus hell is determined by the singular response of
saving faith—by fruit singular not by the individual’s plural fruits.
Nevertheless, the plural fruits of a preacher’s teaching about faith are the
window by which we inductively discern if he or she has saving faith.
Entrance into heaven is not conditioned on the multiple attestations/fruits of
this singular faith. The multiple attestations/fruits flowing from a teacher’s
mouth are simply the means by which we discern whether or not a teacher is
a good or bad teacher. We do not cast people into hell because of their fruits,
and their fate is not based on our discernment of their fruits.
        Their being cast into hell is conditioned solely on the singular fruit of
faith. In the first paragraph (v. 19), the false teachers are thrown into hell
because of their singular fruit (i.e., because of their defective faith). In the
second paragraph, their dupes are thrown into hell because of their defective
practice. The majority of interpreters have taken the broad gate by equating
fruit with practice. Yet this is precisely why the dupes of the false teachers in
this passage are told by Jesus that they were never saved. They thought that
the fruits that they had to produce in order to get into heaven were faith in
Jesus and attendant good works. And they are condemned to hell on the very
basis of their practice (i.e., their performance). This does not mean that the
good fruit upon which the Lord is conditioning our salvation in this passage
is good works! Far to the contrary, those misconstruing the Lord’s words so
as to make the saving fruit anything other than saving faith have placed
themselves in the precarious position being pictured by Jesus as never
having had saving faith. To reiterate, saving fruit is saving faith. The plural
form of fruits (as it pertains to any single individual) refers to the presence
or absence of saving faith as detected by means of their teaching.
Nonetheless, saving faith itself is the singular good fruit.214
        After having correctly deduced that the fruits of detection refer to the
teacher’s words rather than works, even Lenski blunders when he reaches
7:23 and comments: “Works are decisive as being the open evidence of the
inner relation of the heart.”215 What Lenski is insinuating is the common
evidence-inference approach which makes fruits (in the form of works) the
necessary evidence of whether or not one has saving faith and yet tries to
insist that salvation is conditioned exclusively on the nature of the heart/tree
rather than on the nature of the fruit. However, as has been demonstrated, it
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                            Page 291
is futile to try to drive a wedge between the tree and its fruit so as to insist
that the outcome of the tree is not directly conditioned (at least in part) on
the type of fruit it produces. The Lord leaves no room for doubt that the
outcome of the tree is directly because of the output of the tree when He
says: “Every tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into
the fire” (Mt 7:19).

Fruits ≠ Perseverance in Faith
       Astute conditionalists trying to merge a Forlines-Picirilli type
argument with my perspective undoubtedly will insist that the plural fruits in
the Greek text refer to perseverance in faith and follow Lenski’s lead and
scoff at the significance of the singular form of fruit in 7:19 by regarding it
as a collective singular used in place of the distributive plural.216 In other
words, they will claim that the Lord’s switch from a plural to singular in
v. 19 means nothing and that the use of the present participle in v. 19 surely
proves that this singular fruit must be produced continuously. An
interpretive paraphrase of the passage from this conditionalistic perspective
regarding the linear aspect would be:
      15
        Beware of the false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s
      clothing, but inwardly are ravenous wolves. 16 You will know
      those false prophets by their faith. Grapes are not gathered*
      (£) from thorn bushes, nor figs from thistles, are they? 17 Even
      so, every good tree produces† (£) saving faith; but the bad tree
      produces‡ (£) defective faith. 18 A good tree cannot be
      producing§ (£) defective faith, nor can a bad tree be

The NAS concordance wrongly supplies bear (phero) as the verb in Mt 7:18.
But the verb used throughout the passage is produce (poieo). While this
observation is trivial in the present paragraph (in that the usage is synonymous),
nevertheless it is significant to note that poieo is the verb also featured in the
following verses: The one who enters heaven is the one who does (poieo) the
Father’s will (Mt 7:21); those thrown into hell are those who did (poieo)
miracles (Mt 7:22); the wise builder does (poieo) what Jesus teaches (Mt 7:24);
the foolish builder does (poieo) not do what Jesus teaches (Mt 7:26).
Conditionalists will argue that doing the Father’s will is a linear action in
Mt 7:21. The present writer would argue, in contrast, that the articular present
participle in Mt 7:21 can be understood readily as a substantive that refers back
to one who has performed the punctiliar action of bearing the singular fruit of
Mt 7:19.

      producing* (£) saving faith. 19 Every tree that not producing†

      then, you will know them by their faith. (Mt 7:15-20; TM)

Present Tense ≠ Perseverance in Faith
        The present tense and the predominance of the plural fruit (in the
Greek text) would be considered overbearing evidence by conditionalists so
as to render the present participle in v. 19 as producing, and the singular
nature of the fruit would be swept away and ignored grammatically and
denied theologically. The Scripture, however, is its own best interpreter, and
the Scripture is clear that its implementation of a singular rather than a plural
form of a word can have tremendous theological implications (e.g.
Gal 3:16). Context is king. And in this Matthean context, it is imperative that
present tense be broadened to include the possibility of punctiliarity. No one
would suggest that the present participle for gather in 7:16 means that Jesus
merely is denying that grapes are continuously gathered (£ ) from thorn
bushes. Jesus is not alluding to the possibility of occasionally gathering
grapes from a thorn bush! The singular versus plural forms and the
proverbial nature of the context, along with a little sanctified common sense,
must be our guides in understanding the present tense.
        Abusing the present tense so as to require perseverance in bearing
fruit does an injustice to the Greek aspect and to the Matthean context. The
plural fruits from a singular tree are the means by which we detect whether
or not that tree is a good or bad tree. We can know with deductive certainty
that a person teaching a false gospel is a false teacher. And we can know
with inductive probability that such a teacher is probably lost. Verse 16 is a
transitional verse between the induction pertaining to discerning false

* Present infinitive.
† Present participle.
Although most translations render fruit (karpos) as singular in Mt 7:17-18, the
singular time that fruit singular is used in this passage is in Mt 7:19. Even so,
Lenski renders the verb as producing to denote linear aspect, as if multiple fruits
were being produced in this verse. However, the context (in conjunction with the
singular form) renders the linear aspect highly unlikely for an individual. Thus,
rendering the singular fruit in v. 19 with £ (to denote linear aspect) is highly
contestable. In contrast to Lenski, I find the Lord’s transition from a distributive
plural in vv. 17-18 to a singular in v. 19 to be confirmative that fruit is to be
understood in the singular for the individual. Therefore, I am in agreement with
the rendering of v. 17-18 with the singular form of fruit as found in most
translations. See my online article (Producing Karpos) at my website for other
rudimentary aspectual considerations pertaining to this text. Fuller elaboration
than provided herein concerning those aspectual parallels will have to await
treatment in The Outer Darkness.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                             Page 293
teachers in v. 15 and the deductive conditionality embedded in the heart of
the passage in vv. 17-19. The plurality in the Greek text is not an indication
that perseverance in faith is a soteric necessity. The context specifies that
singular fruit from each tree is the soteriological condition, and the verbal
aspect actually concurs that punctiliar fruit from each tree is all that is
necessary. But demonstration of this statement necessarily will require an
explanation of verbal aspect.

Greek Aspect
       Fanning, a Greek aspectologist,* regards the first part of v. 17 as an
example of a general (i.e., non-specific) reference since it uses a
combination of every (pas) with tree (an anarthrous singular noun).
Accordingly, he says that it “is open-ended or unlimited as to when and how
many times these situations occur” (VANT, 181). This type of construction
refers to any action that can occur “any time” (VANT, 209; emphasis his).
An open circle ({) would seem to be a fitting picture for this open-ended
gnomic (i.e., generic) sense of the present tense. Some might object that a
durative action is still intended and try to put an arrow inside that circle ({
                                                                              ¨ ).

After all, as noted above, Lenski admits that the plural form of fruits (in vv.
17-18) is a distributive plural but wants a linear aspect. Nominally, Lenski
admits individual singularity, but aspectually he wants durative lineality—a
rather schizophrenic dichotomy. Nevertheless, for sake of argument, I will
entertain such a perspective since Fanning says that the gnomic present
“seems to occur more frequently with verbs of durative meaning, and pays
more attention to the extension of time” (VANT, 267).†
       Several reasons for rejecting the durative insertion of an arrow by the
conditionalists are available from Fanning himself, however. First, Fanning
points out that the articular present participle can be used as a “substantive
with the sense ‘the one who (ever) does’” (VANT, 183). This is an
extremely significant acknowledgment on his part. One of the examples
provided by Fanning is Jn 3:36a. The verse accordingly would read: “The
one who ever believes in the Son has eternal life” (TM). A singular response

of faith is sufficient; perseverance in faith is not requisite.* Matthew uses the

Obviously, it would be saving faith.
        Collaboration is available from Fanning’s more explicit explanations.
He explores the grammatical parallel with 1Jn 3:9 (VANT, 217), where the
NAS translates the verse as saying: “No one who is born of God practices
sin.” Conditionalists like to use this verse to assert that if one is born of God,
then one does not practice sin. Contrapositionally, if you practice sin, then
you are not born of God. Unfortunately, for conditionalists, however, the
grammar and context weigh heavily against such a translation. Like
Matthew’s statement about what the tree produces (poieo), John is using
poieo to make an absolute statement: “No one who is born of God produces
[poieo] sin” (TM). Matthew is not saying that good trees do not produce bad
fruit as a practice. He is saying that good trees do not produce bad fruit ever.
Good trees absolutely never produce bad fruit in Mt 7:17-19. Ontologically,
a believer cannot produce even one bad fruit or sin as an expression of his or
her regenerate nature. Fanning pulls the rug out from under conditionalism
when he clarifies:


* Since Jn 3:16 has every (pas) with an articular present participle, it falls into

†
  As an advocate of conditional security, Wallace would object and seek to take
the soteric articular present participle out from under the auspices of the gnomic
articular present participle and make the soteric usage a customary present
(GGBB, 522-523). My countermove is to consider the soteric usage a punctiliar
present—if one is so inclined to remove it from under the gnomic category.
Wallace’s argument is highly strained; a conditionalist would do better to argue
that soteric articular present participles are simply stative. My counter is to
regard it as permanently substantive. These moves and countermoves on the
aspectological battlefield put the conditionalistic argument in checkmate. See
my forthcoming books Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from
the Gospel of John and John in Living Color. My classifications therein are not
mutually exclusive but accumulatively reinforcing: The distributive punctiliar
gnomic () becomes a punctiliar aorist for the singular individual (~) at
the moment of saving faith and results in a permanent, non-contingent
substantive stative (z▬▬ ).

              It should be observed from these examples [e.g., Mt
      7:17, Jn 3:36] that generics are usually multiple in a distributive
      sense: the plurality which is predicated consists of each one of a
      group doing an act a single time, rather than repeatedly. Thus,
      the sense of a generic utterance is usually an absolute statement
      of what each one does once, and not a statement of the
      individual’s customary or habitual activity. (VANT, 216-217;
      italics his.)218

        If this more exacting assessment by Fanning is accepted, then not
only is Matthew not saying that a good tree characteristically or habitually
bears good fruit, but Matthew is indicating instead that each good tree bears
a single good fruit once. This understanding would be in harmony with
Jesus’ conditioning the outcome of each individual tree on the singular fruit
that tree produces (Mt 7:19). Jesus is not giving a mere proverbial rule of
thumb or suggesting that grapes are occasionally, rather than customarily or
habitually, gathered from thorn bushes. Rather, the Lord is making an
absolute statement: Grapes are never gathered from thorn bushes as a thorn
bush produce. Therefore, this distributive property for the gnomic present as
proposed by Fanning certainly seems reasonable.
        Although the basic point being developed herein could be content to
leave the references to plural fruit in vv. 17 and 18 open-ended ({) and
contrast these plural references with the inner punctiliarity of the singular
fruit (~) in v. 19, Fanning’s distributive interpretation is very attractive
grammatically, contextually, and theologically; plus, it has the additional
advantage of providing a way to distinguish the present tense from the
aorist.* Vertically distributing the dots within the open circle to represent
each tree ({  ⋮ ) would be one way to picture this distributive property.† Or
these distributive dots could be placed at a slant to show that they may occur
at any time ({   ⋱ ). Still, such a representation looks too aoristic from the
outside, since the outside is still represented as a circle. A better model

would be to stretch out this distribution over an indefinite period of time

       In deference to KISS, the following interpretive paraphrase suffices
for my conclusion:
      15
        Beware of the false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s
      clothing, but inwardly are ravenous wolves. 16 You will know
      those false prophets by their faith. Grapes are not gathered from
      thorn bushes, nor figs from thistles, are they? 17 Even so, every
      good tree produces () saving faith; but the bad tree
      produces () non-saving faith. 18 A good tree cannot
      produce () unsaving faith, nor can a bad tree produce
      () saving faith. 19 Every tree that does not produce
      () saving faith is cut down and thrown into the fire. 20 So
      then, you will know them by their faith. (Mt 7:15-20; TM)

       The present participle for gather in 7:16 does not mean that Jesus is
merely denying that grapes are continuously gathered (£) from thorn
bushes. Contrary to those who imagine grapes falling and getting stuck on
thorn bushes from which they might be picked, Jesus is not implying that
one occasionally might gather grapes from thorn bushes. A linear sense of
produce is ruled out by common sense. Jesus is not describing a linearly
produced faith. Nevertheless, the plural form of faith in vv. 16 and 20 is a
cause-effect metonymy for the teaching which such faith produces. Our
English translations do well to translate fruit as plural in these two verses.

English Translations
        Are our English translations (such as the NAS and KJV) in error
when they translate the plural form of fruit as a singular in vv. 17-18? No.
Although the Greek text does indeed use a plural from of karpos in these
two verses, our English texts which translate it as singular in these interior
verses are doing us no disservice since the multiplicity of fruit is because of
its distributive nature. Multiple fruits from each tree/teacher are not in view
in these interior verses. However, multiple fruits from each teacher are in
view in the external verses (i.e., vv. 16 and 20) because faith is being viewed
from the perspective of its characteristic teaching.
        On the other hand, in the Lukan account, Luke uses the singular form
of karpos for both the interior and exterior summations (Lk 6:43-44). And
on another occasion from what he recorded in chapter seven but in a
pericope similar to Luke chapter 6, Matthew uses the singular form for the
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                            Page 297
detection: “The tree is known by its fruit” (Mt 12:33). His association of
fruit with speech is clear, since the next verse supplies the explanation: “You
brood of vipers, how can you, being evil, speak what is good? For the mouth
speaks out of that which fills the heart” (Mt 12:34). Henderson rightly
interprets the plural fruit in Mt 7:16 in terms of the singular fruit of
Mt 12:33: “It becomes clear that the ‘fruits’ refer to what comes out of a
person’s mouth (the message) that reveals the heart. Hence, a false prophet
is known to be false by his false message. Look the wolf in the mouth!”
(Emphasis his.)219 Robbins likewise concludes, “Evil fruit is false teaching;
good fruit is true teaching; and we are to judge men by their fruit, that is,
their teaching” (emphasis his).220
        These interpreters interpret the singular fruit of Mt 12:33 cross-
textually with plural fruit in Mt 7:16, and I have no objection with their
doing so. Charging the biblical writers with inconsistency or their
interpreters with lacking sensitivity regarding the singular versus plural is
unnecessary. Rather, fruit can be used interchangeably with fruits if one is
not trying to make a contrast between the two forms.* Nevertheless, most
translations demonstrate proper contextual sensitivity in Mt 7:15-20 when
they make a contrast between the two forms in English. Jesus is, in fact, only
addressing the singular production of fruit from each individual tree in these
interior verses. The plurality is because of distributive singularity. I therefore
will adopt the distinction made in most English translations between plural
fruit in the exterior verses and singular fruit in the interior verses when
interpreting this passage contextually.
        Jesus’ statement that you will know them by their fruits serves as the
chiastic bookends (i.e., an inclusio) to the cause-effect relationship being
expressed in the heart of the paragraph. The evidence-inference induction of
the plural fruits used in the exterior bookends of this Matthean context is
based upon the cause-effect relationship that exists between singular fruit
and the nature associated with that fruit in the interior part of the chiasm. We
can detect a false teacher’s faith by his or her teaching and know with
absolute certainty that a false teacher who has never produced saving faith is
certainly lost.

Literary Analysis
       Hagner notes the basic chiastic structure but fails to consider the
singular versus plural nature of the fruit. Instead, he makes the typical
assumption that the passage is talking about good works as necessitative-

Further elaboration will be provided in The Outer Darkness.
Page 298                                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
manifestative righteousness. Invariably, by making good works necessary to
enter heaven, he has conditioned entrance into heaven on good works.221
Fanning astutely has noted the distributive aspect. A number of writers

fruit of saving faith in 7:19. Accordingly, my distinction between internal

distributive singularity.

As it is the Lord does not use this structure and instead continues with the

inductions based on the fruit we see in a person’s life in v. 18, then it is
exceedingly strange that He did not convey His intent in a manner consistent
with logic and did not implement a chiastic structure that would have been
conducive to that understanding.
                Illustration 118. False Teachers in Mt 7:16-20


   Heaven                                          Heaven costs
   is free .                                       you everthing.




        The way we know whether or not a teacher believes the gospel is by
listening to what he or she teaches about the gospel. The Bible is clear that
we must trust in Christ alone for eternal life in order to receive eternal life.
Those teachers who are teaching that it is not enough to trust in Christ alone
for eternal life have given us an infallible means by which to discern what
they believe about the gospel. They believe a false gospel—a gospel that
leads to hell. MacArthur correctly concludes that false teachers presenting a
false gospel “are more dangerous than a cobra.”222 And yet, by teaching that
multiple fruits (in terms of moral performance) are necessary to reach
heaven, he has identified himself as a poisonous teacher.
        In this Matthean context, false teachers are those teachers who
condition a believer’s entrance into heaven on his or her moral practice.
Some false teachers try to hide this conditionality by appealing to fruit as
mere evidence. Nevertheless, by making it necessary evidence, they make
this moral performance a condition for reaching heaven. Their teaching is
characterized by contradiction as they try to conceal the meritorious nature
of their performance-based condition for salvation. They may even assert
obviously conflicting statements, such as claiming that heaven is free but
costs us everything. MacArthur inadvertently identifies himself as such a
Page 300                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
teacher when he says, “We can pay nothing for salvation, yet coming to
Jesus Christ costs everything we have.”223 This is not a slip of the tongue by
MacArthur but an example of him speaking with a forked tongue, since he
appeals to Lk 14:26-28 to establish his point: “If anyone comes to Me, and
does not hate his own father and mother and wife and children and brothers
and sisters, yes, and even his own life, he cannot be My disciple. Whoever
does not carry his own cross and come after Me cannot be My disciple. For
which one of you, when he wants to build a tower, does not first sit down
and calculate the cost, to see if he has enough to complete it?” MacArthur
fuses coming to Jesus for the free salvation with coming after Jesus in the
costly commitment of discipleship. Not only is following Christ costly, but
even coming to Christ initially is costly in such MacArthurian confusion.
Salvation from start to finish is costly—to you—from MacArthur’s
perspective. Who carries your cross? You do. Who has to count your cost to
see if you are able to pay the full price? You do. MacArthur speaks out of
both sides of his mouth, and in doing so he shows that he does not speak for
God when he portrays the Lord as offering a single benefit in this passage
that is costly-free to you. You have to pay the price to get it freely.224 Utter
nonsense!
        Sure, God will help believers who follow Christ: Help them earn
rewards in heaven, not heaven as a reward! Of course, following Christ in
discipleship in order to obtain rewards is costly for those who have already
come to Christ in order to receive the free gift of eternal life. The order
expressed by the Lord in this passage is come to Him (for the free gift), then
come after Him for the costly reward. The reception of eternal life as a free
gift is taken for granted by the Lord here. The additional benefit that comes
to you as result of discipleship is not taken for granted; it must be earned.
You must give up your possessions to get it (Lk 14:33). Salvation from
being cast out (into the outer darkness) is indeed costly (Lk 14:35). In
contrast, salvation from hell is free.
        Tom Brown, an Arminian, seeks to avoid making such a blatant
contradiction as MacArthur by clarifying: “Salvation is free, but keeping it is
costly.”225 MacArthurianism is in agreement with Arminianism in asserting
that God will not keep us if we do not persevere. Yet Brown’s elucidation is
superior to MacArthur’s articulation since MacArthur wants to make the gift
costly both to receive and to keep. Brown is content simply to make the free
gift costly to keep. Both Shank and MacArthur endeavor to make the free
gift costly both to receive and retain.226 Therefore, Brown’s distinction is
superior to the costly-to-receive-and-retain position jointly advocated by
MacArthur and Shank. Nevertheless, Brown still has failed to avoid teaching
salvation by works. His perspective is tantamount to saying that initial
salvation is free but final salvation is costly. However, if initial salvation
from hell is free, then how can final salvation from hell be costly? Moreover,
Brown is refuted by his fellow Arminians, such as Lewis, who assert that
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                          Page 301
heaven is not a reward. If final salvation is by works and refers to salvation
from hell and to entrance into heaven (as Brown supposes), then Brown has
blown the distinction that some of his fellow Arminians have tried so
diligently (yet futilely) to maintain within Arminianism in asserting that
heaven is not a reward. Picirilli, for example, has refuted Brown’s approach
by admitting that saved by faith and kept by works will not work.*
        More importantly, Brown has shown a lack of critical interaction with
the example which he himself supplies. He likens salvation to a free car that
freely is given to you as a gift that is fully paid for and yet which is costly
for you to keep because you must put gas in it, give it tune-ups, and change
the oil, etc. One glaring weakness with this analogy is that the car is yours to
keep even if you stop putting gas in it, etc.
                    Illustration 119. Composition of Free Gift




      Alternatively, when one considers some of the soteriological
components that come standard with this car (that has been given freely to us
as an irrevocable gift), clearly the mere possession of this car denotes
unconditional security. These features come standard with the free gift:

      •    Righteousness: being given the imputed righteousness of Christ
      •    Justification: being declared righteous
      •    Redemption: soteric forgiveness
      •    Salvation: from penalty of sin and from hell
      •    Adoption: legal status as God’s child
      •    Eternal life: life that cannot die
      •    Seal: sealed with Spirit

*
    See Because versus Cause, 272.
Page 302                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

Since the present book is merely an affirmation rather than a full-fledged
defense of unconditional security, it will suffice for present purposes to
highlight a couple of these standard features. Arminians acknowledge that
Jesus and the Father keep us safe in their hands so that no one can take
(harpazo) us from that safe position (Jn 10:28-30). Yet they assert that we
might take ourselves out of God’s hand. Simultaneously, they assert that
God soteriologically will take the Holy Spirit from us if we are not faithful
(Ps 51:11). The Arminian God could thereby break the seal of the Spirit. But
claiming that God will not soteriologically take us out of His hand but will
soteriologically take His Holy Spirit from us is logically inconsistent.
Rather, God will not soterically take His Spirit from us because He will not
soterically take us out of His hand.

       1. If God were to take His Spirit from us soteriologically, then He
          would be the one taking us out of His hand soteriologically.
       2. God will not take us out of His hand soteriologically.
       3. Therefore, God will not take His Spirit from us soteriologically.

       The above argument for OSAS basically is using a contraposition
which uses statements as its premises that NOSAS would itself acknowledge
as true.* Because the conclusion logically results from the agreed-upon
premises, the NOSAS argument that God will soteriologically take the
sealing of His Spirit away from unfaithful believers is necessarily false.
Stated alternately from a more direct line of reasoning, since the seal of the
Spirit has been given freely to us, the seal of the Spirit cannot be taken from
us. Arminians are abusing these texts when they insist that God can break

hand. Contraposition: (;B) God does not remove us out of His hand, then (;A)
God does not remove His Spirit from us. By conceding the truth of the A ⇒ B
statement and the protasis of the contraposition ;B, conditionalists leave
themselves no wiggle room by which to picture believers as wiggling out of
God’s hand. God cannot let us wiggle out of His hand because in order to do so
He would have to take His Spirit from us, and in order to do this, He would have
to take us out of His hand. But He has promised not to take us out of His hand.
The best logical ordo harpazo that the insecuritist could offer would be:
(1) wiggle out, (2) Spirit removed, (3) taken out. Even if the insecuritist insists
that these actions are simultaneous, these actions still would have to have a
logical sequence. But how can we wiggle out and still have the Spirit? How can
we remove the Spirit without God removing the Spirit? How can we wiggle out
and subsequently be taken out? How can we be taken out when God has
promised not to take us out?

the seal or soteriologically take His Spirit from us or when they suggest that
we can take ourselves soteriologically out of God’s hands.
       To speak pictorially in terms of the above illustration, in which the
seal of the Spirit has been pictured as the front bumper, if the only part of
this car that we knew for sure that we would be able to keep regardless of
our performance was the front bumper, this single assurance would be
enough to assure us of reaching heaven. Yet we get to keep so much more—
for free! The seal of the Spirit was given freely to us and will not be taken
from us. Brown has blown his argument by acknowledging that the
soteriological car is free.
       Similar observations can be made regarding forgiveness. For
example, claiming that the parable of the unmerciful servant (Mt 18:23-35)
depicts a soteriological forgiveness which was granted freely but which may
be revoked subsequently because of postconversional failure in performance
is an incredibly inconsistent argument posed by Arminians. Misthologists
simply may point out that the forgiveness of this servant is not a picture of
the soteric forgiveness necessary to become a servant. The individual in
question incurred his great debt in his service to his lord while he was
already a servant. The forgiveness granted by his lord was not free
soterically but condignly and congruently meritorious. God has obligated
Himself temporally to forgive believers of their enormous accumulation of
sin dept if they simply will confess those sins (1Jn 1:9). But such
forgiveness is not free nor soteric. Nor does this temporal forgiveness
guarantee mistholic forgiveness if this temporal forgiveness is not
accompanied by the forgiving of one’s fellow believers (pictured as fellow
slaves in this parable). The humongous accumulation of postconversional
sins can come rushing back upon believers misthologically at the bema* if
they have been unmerciful toward others, especially toward their fellow
believers.
       Free forgiveness should not be confused with congruent or condign
forgiveness. Free forgiveness is ours to keep regardless of our performance;
otherwise, it would not be free. Similarly, there are dimensions of eternal life
that are free and other dimensions that are not free. The free dimension is
ours to keep. For the sake of Brown’s illustration, let it be expressed this
way: All believers are promised a car (picturing life) in heaven, but not all
believers are promised a Rolls-Royce. If believers want a Rolls-Royce type
of experience in heaven, they not only are going to have to be forgiven

  Bema is a transliteration of the Greek word used in 2Cor 5:10 to refer to the
