the Great White Throne Judgment—the thronos of Rev 20:11.
Page 304                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
(which is free), they also are going to have to be forgiving (which is costly).
The Beetle is free; the Rolls-Royce is not. To make the cost of discipleship
the cost for receiving or keeping the free gift of eternal life is to deny that
the free gift of eternal life is truly free. Those teachers who deny the freeness
of the soteriological benefits with their logical inconsistencies are teaching a
false gospel. They are teaching that you have to earn a Rolls-Royce type of
experience just to make it into heaven as a free gift. Misthologists will
counter, however, that rolling along like royalty is a reward, not a gift.
                               Reformed Root
        Having now demonstrated that the evidence-inference theory that
seeks to make good practice a necessity to enter heaven necessarily
conditions entrance into heaven on our practice and therefore stands self-
condemned by its own practitioners, and having provided a brief KISS
exegesis which is in harmony with the superior causation model wherein it
was demonstrated that salvation is conditioned on the singular fruit (of
saving faith), it is now appropriate to turn our attention from the fruit to the
root since the Reformed fruit springs from a highly questionable root. All
fruit is not created equal. The fruit found in Calvinism is even far more bitter
than that found in the other conditionalistic camps. Unearthing the true root
found within the Reformed perspective will require that we examine their
claims regarding God’s sovereignty in the fruit production process.
Calvinists are not appealing merely to sovereignty in a simple attempt to
mask the conditional nature of the fruit. More is afoot to this Reformed root
than typically meets the eye.
                   Illustration 120. Unconditional Election
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                        Page 305


        What MacArthur is trying to do with his guaranteed-fruit-from-root
argument is find a way to reconcile his theology with his exegesis. Reformed
theology insists that genuine believers (i.e., the elect) will persevere. The
perseverance of the elect is guaranteed sovereignly in Calvinism. Given this
hermeneutical grid, advocates of this outlook sometimes wind up trying to
put a round peg in a square hole—a conditional text in an unconditional
interpretation. A poorly conceived root-fruit rubric does not help. To get to
the root of the matter, we must dig deeper. The roots of the Reformed
argument are grounded in unconditional election and sours the Reformed
fruit even more.
        Given this understanding of the situation, MacArthur’s attempt to turn
Col 1:21-23 into a guarantee is much more comprehensible. He is trying to
do more than get away with teaching works-righteousness by denying the
conditional nature of the fruit and by attributing it to God’s sovereignty.
Because of his commitment to unconditional election, MacArthur is of the
firm persuasion that the elect will reach heaven unconditionally. Therefore,
it is natural for him to try and force this text into that hermeneutical mold.
Along the way he repeatedly appeals to God’s sovereignty and election. In
addition to the typical problem he faces in trying to deny the fruit’s
contingency, logical consistency with the Reformed doctrine leads him to
commit a root fallacy in trying to mitigate his own conclusions and find a
way to make sovereign grace compatible with enabling grace. His fruit is
thoroughly flavored by the sovereign grace coming up from the roots of his
theology.
              Illustration 121. MacArthurian Sovereign Grace
      Unconditional Election + Enabling Grace = Sovereign Grace

        MacArthur’s affirmation that God enables and empowers us while
simultaneously claiming that God does so sovereignly is much more
understandable (although no more compatible) when one factors in
unconditional election. In the Reformed view, God sovereignly determined
that the elect will come to faith and persevere in faith, and He has not
conditioned their coming to faith on their perseverance in faith or on their
free will. The outlines of this Reformed outlook would run something along
the following lines:

    1. God unconditionally determined that the elect will reach heaven.
    2. God conditionally determined that regenerate believers must
       persevere in faithworks in order to reach heaven.
    3. Therefore, God unconditionally determined that elect believers will
       persevere.
Page 306                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        This observation helps explain why MacArthur oscillates so much
between will and must and tries so hard to deny the conditional nature of the
situation. While securitists are looking at perseverance from the conditional
viewpoint of the minor premise (i.e., #2) and pointing out that his argument
conditions the retention of regeneration on perseverance, MacArthur is
looking at the situation from the unconditional vantage point of the major
premise (i.e., #1) and affirming that the regenerate believers unconditionally
will reach heaven because they are the elect. Does this mean that truth is
simply in the eye of the beholder? No. We need not opt for a postmodern
copout. A harmonization is available because truth is noncontradictory.
        If one believed in mechanical causation, one might be content to
define postconditions in terms of computer programming: A postcondition
refers to an item that is a guaranteed result of successfully having met a
stated condition. MacArthur considers perseverance the guaranteed result of
election. Presumably, his theological stance would indicate his endorsement
of either mechanical or compatible causation for perseverance. The present
book, in contrast, advocates freewill persuasional causation instead, at least
regarding alpha-preconditions and beta-postconditions. Regardless, what
MacArthur refuses to admit is that he simultaneously is making
perseverance a condition for reaching heaven. In Reformed theology,
although perseverance is a guaranteed postconditional result of regeneration
(because of election), perseverance is also a condition for final justification.
The conditional nature of the Reformed postconditional result is
demonstrated easily with a corresponding Reformed causation chain.
           Illustration 122. Causation Chain for Final Justification




             A⇒B⇒C
               A                      B                      C
     Initial Justification Perseverance Final Justification
     1. Condition               2. Postcondition
                                3. Condition       4. Postcondition

         Like a cascading waterfall, the postcondition of expression A
becomes the condition for expression C. Specifically, in Reformed theology
(1) initial justification is the condition for perseverance. (2) Perseverance is
therefore the postcondition of initial justification. But perseverance in turn
becomes the (3) condition for final justification. Finally, (4) final
justification becomes the postcondition of perseverance.
        As to the equivocation between will and must in Reformed logic, if
you have experienced initial justification, you will persevere, and you must
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                           Page 307
persevere in order to experience final justification. The postconditional will
is a conditional must. From the Reformed perspective, you will/must
persevere. When perseverance is viewed from the angle of sovereignty, you
will persevere. When perseverance is viewed from the angle of
conditionality, you must persevere. The will cannot be divorced from the
must; neither can the must be separated from its conditional nature.
        MacArthur objects that a postcondition cannot be a condition for its
own condition. For example, perseverance cannot be the condition for
regeneration. True enough, so what? Of course, perseverance cannot be the
condition for initial justification (i.e., B is not the condition for A).
Glaringly, however, what MacArthur is refusing to address is the fact that
his theology makes perseverance the condition for final justification (i.e., B
is the condition for C). MacArthurian theology, as an expression of
Reformed thought, logically must make the postcondition of the preceding
result the condition for the proceeding result.
        He continues this refrain in his Saved Without a Doubt: “You’re
secure only if you endure, but as a true believer you will endure because you
are secure” (emphasis his).227 No mystery there, not even a paradox. In terms
of the logical analysis above, such a statement really amounts to little more
than a truism from the Reformed perspective. As is evident in MacArthur’s
statement, your salvation is conditioned on your endurance and thus earned.
Never fear, MacArthur is here so save the day with the assurance, just a few
pages later, that all is not what it appears: “Endurance does not earn eternal
life, but it is the proof of true faith and love, and that is rewarded by eternal
life.”228 Huh? This is tantamount to saying that you get eternal life as an
unearned reward for enduring. That is more than an oxymoron! It is a flat
contradiction. His theology collapses, as it must, into making heaven a
reward.
        Did he stutter? Was this a slip of the pen? Not at all. He dogmatically
asserts: “The reward for the believer who does not collapse under trials is
eternal life….It is the believer’s ultimate reward” (Jam 1:12). He continues:
“The Lord will reward with eternal life those who demonstrate with
perseverance of a victorious athlete that they were truly saved.”229 Even
Lewis denied that heaven is a reward. Not MacArthur. If you want to go to
MacArthurian heaven, do it the old fashion way—work for it. The true irony
is that we in the Free Grace camp fully agree that there are a number of
passages, such as Jam 1:12, which teach that eternal life is a reward. In
contradistinction, we do not equate the dimension of eternal life which is
earned as a reward with the believer’s free soteriological entrance into
heaven. Rather, the aspect of eternal life that is earned as a reward has
nothing to do with our unearned soteric entrance into heaven but pertains
exclusively to our abundant mistholic entrance into heaven. The form of
eternal life that is earned as a reward deals with rewards in heaven. Free
Grace theology does not make a reward of heaven. By fusing the
Page 308                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
soteriological and misthological dimensions of eternal life into one,
MacArthur is attempting to make heaven an unearned reward that believers
receive as a free gift because they strenuously persevere until death. His
argument is self-refuting. And his attempts to mask the works-righteousness
nature of his soteriology are futile.

Energization
        He uses the standard argument that believers are energized and
enabled by the Holy Spirit to perform these works that result in their being
allowed into heaven. Again, misthologists simply may respond that since
rewards are based on works, rewards are earned. The fact that such works
are energized by the Holy Spirit only makes them synergistic (not
monergistic). The monergistic energization does not detract from the
meritorious nature of such synergistic works in the least. God and the
believer both have a part to play. God’s part is to supply the energy. To his
credit, MacArthur implicitly affirms synergism, acknowledging, “Our part is
to endure.”230 And on occasions he reiterates what would, under any
reasonable circumstances, be considered a logical admission of the
conditional nature of such endurance, admitting that “continued faith is
necessary.”231 “To have a true relationship with God, you have to live a holy
life.”232 What is incumbent upon us to do on our part, what we have to do,
what is necessary for us to do, what we must do to get to MacArthurian
heaven is endure. It is little wonder, therefore, that onlookers from
Wikipedia consider it an advance in the discussion for Reformers to get on
with it and admit that endurance is a condition for reaching heaven in
Reformed thought.
        It is no mystery as to how Reformers can be certain that believers will
persevere. MacArthur takes the standard Reformed party line when he
equates God’s foreknowledge with His foreordination. The reason God
knows that we will persevere is the same reason that He knows that we will
believe in the first place, because “God sovereignly chooses people to
believe in Him.”233 “All true believers will persevere” because (in the words
of the Westminster Confession which MacArthur quotes in support) “this
perseverance of the saints depends, not upon their own free-will, but on the
immutability of the decree of election.”234 By removing free will as a
contingency out of the chain of events, Reformed theology is able to assure
that the elect will persevere. Perhaps MacArthur even intends to take the
Reformed party line that those of us who believe in God out of our own free
will are going to hell as a result.*




*
    See endnote 183.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                        Page 309
Tension
      The tension between Calvinistic monergism and Calvinistic synergism
pertaining to initial versus final justification is well known. Geisler notes
that Calvinists “maintain that the very first moment of conversion
(regeneration) is totally a result of God’s operation, without any cooperation
on man’s part.” Thus, initial justification is tied monergistically to God’s
operative grace. However, “at every point after that, man’s will cooperates
with God’s action” so that final justification is synergistically dependent
upon cooperative grace.235 Dillow likewise observers: “Salvation in this
system is initial belief coupled with a life-long synergism of human and
divine work.”236
      Yet MacArthur acts, at times, as if Calvinism makes perseverance in
faith a monergistic result when this is just a Calvinistic waffle. The
doubletalk that is evidenced in MacArthur’s discussion of cooperation in
relation to election and perseverance comes as no surprise when one
considers the irreconcilable tension between the Reformed U and P in
TULIP. When viewed from the direction of unconditional election (U), the
elect are said to be unconditionally elected to persevere independently of
their cooperation. Yet when viewed from the conditional necessity of
perseverance (P), perseverance obviously is dependent upon their
cooperation.
                   Illustration 123. Cross-Eyed Calvinism




U = Unconditional                                           C = Conditional

       Viewed from the direction of U, perseverance is not contingent upon
the cooperation of the elect. Viewed from the conditional direction of C,
perseverance is contingent upon the cooperation of the elect. These
contradictory viewpoints of perseverance are inherent within TULIP and
result in MacArthur trying to deny the obvious implications of his own
system. As Geisler and Dillow note, after the initial moment experienced at
regeneration, Calvinism switches over from monergism to synergism.
Consequently, cross-eyed Calvinism views the same event (i.e.,
Page 310                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
perseverance) as being both conditional and unconditional in the same
way—soteriologically.

Reprobation
        Unfortunately for Reformed theology, their taking free will out the
equation for election also has the mirror reaction of ultimately taking free
will out of the equation for reprobation. The positive action of election has
an equal and opposite negative reaction in reprobation. At this point, I will
be told to play nice and point out that treating reprobation as the symmetrical
twin of election is an aberration found in hyper-Calvinism and not associated
with the more socially acceptable forms of Calvinism one typically
encounters. A call to such scholarly decorum, however, seems to be a call to
participate in a make-believe perception that logically cannot exist. It would
be much like asking me to not rock the boat by pretending that the fruit is
not really a condition. For obvious reasons, I cannot concur by pretending
that the fruit in conditionalism is unconditional. The Pied Piper has made a
funeral dirge of that tune.237 In the same manner, Free Grace advocates have
no reason to pretend that the unconditional root of Reformed theology is any
better than its conditional fruit.
                 Illustration 124. Unconditional Reprobation
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                                Page 311
       The major point debated among Calvinists is whether or not God
conditionally or unconditionally reprobated the lost. It really is a moot point.
Even if God did decide to condition the damnation of the nonelect on their
lack of faith, He first unconditionally decided to pass over them and make it
impossible for them to come to faith. Calvinists tie themselves in lapsarian
knots by trying to figure out a way to make their theology palatable and not
make God culpable—an impossible task in a system devoid of genuine free
will.
                 Illustration 125. Broken Infralapsarian Mirror

Unconditional election      = unconditional regeneration + conditional justification

? conditional reprobation   = unconditional preterition   + conditional condemnation

       As explained more fully in The Outer Darkness and Woolly Wolves
and Woolless Sheep, the infralapsarian mirror logically is broken because
Calvinistic reprobation is just as unconditional as Calvinistic election.
Regardless of one’s Calvinistic preferences, the bottom line remains the
same. Reprobation must be unconditional since the same corresponding
components and sequence result in an election that is unconditional. Yet to
fully grasp the insidious nature of this underlying Calvinistic rootage, its
secondary shoots comprising temporary faith must be considered also.
When the primary and secondary roots in the Calvinistic tree are examined,
the conclusion that reprobation is unconditional is undeniably strengthened.
       MacArthur is fond of mentioning God’s sovereign enablement as the
basis for the perseverance of the elect. Not surprisingly, however, he does
not discuss the twin brother of this sovereign enablement. Beware of the
dark side of Calvinistic sovereignty. The positive side of Calvinistic
sovereignty, as attractive as it may seem, has an equally dark side buried in
the Calvinistic details. And in this case, the devil is truly in the details. If one
reads the fine print, one finds that the Calvinistic God has a sadistic dark
side.
       No one can believe in Christ for eternal life without God enabling the
person to do so. Many Free Grace writers rightly agree with the Calvinists
on this point. I also fully agree with MacArthur that Judas initially thought
himself to be a genuine believer. In a manner of speaking, Judas believed in
Jesus.238 God enabled Judas to believe. But here is where I part company
with Calvinists in explaining the nature of this God-enabled faith and why it
was defective. Calvinism would have us believe that God sovereignly caused
Judas to believe—Judas could not have done otherwise. For the Calvinist,
saying that God sovereignly enabled someone (elect or nonelect) to believe
is code for saying that God caused that person to believe. The Calvinistic
God put just enough gas in Judas’ tank to get him out on the highway so that
he would crash and burn when he ran out of God’s energization. God had no
intention of giving Judas enough gas to reach a positive destination. Instead,
Page 312                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
God unconditionally had chosen Judas for damnation. It cannot be said that
God just simply passed over Judas. God actively chose Judas to be one of
the apostles. God energized Judas with a faith that was sufficient for Judas to
leave everything and follow Jesus. God gave Judas a faith that was sufficient
for Judas to believe that he was one of the elect. God empowered Judas with
the authority to cast out demons. Yet God also had predetermined to leave
Judas high and dry. And if the Calvinistic God will do that to Judas, how can
you be certain that He will not do so to you also?
        When discussing the parable of the soils, MacArthur correctly
perceives that the “condition of the soil” represents the condition of the
human heart and that this condition of the heart determines what response
and result will be given by the potential convert to the gospel.239 However,
MacArthur’s leaving the matter there deceptively gives the false impression
that culpability is Calvinistically located in the human heart. To the contrary,
if Calvinism is true, then culpability ultimately must be located in God’s
sovereignty. God is the one who determines the condition of the soil and the
condition of the human heart. The reason Judas’ nonelect faith was choked
out by greed and materialistic messianic expectations was because God
sovereignly had predetermined that this is the type of faith that He would
predispose Judas’ non-regenerate heart to produce. Judas had no choice to be
anything other than God’s hangman. God irresistibly determined the heart
disposition that Judas would have, and then the disposition of Judas’ heart
determined that his faith would give out. Ultimately, infralapsarianism
places culpability for Judas’ sin in the heart of God just as surely as does
supralapsarianism. Regardless of the sequence of God’s decrees, as both
Bryson and Vance demonstrate,240 both forms of Calvinism lead to the
conclusion that Calvinistic reprobation is unconditional. In terms of primary
causation, the reason Judas was reprobate was not because of the condition
of his heart but because of the mysterious condition of God’s heart. Just as
the Calvinistic God chose to make a devil out of Judas, this mysterious God
just might chose to make a Judas out of you.
        Without a doubt, Calvinists cannot know that they are saved without a
doubt if they follow the precepts of their theology through to their logical
conclusions. Perhaps the reason MacArthur did to not deal with such
skeletons in the Calvinistic closet when he presented the Reformed doctrine
of assurance in his book Without a Doubt was because he could not be sure
of his salvation logically if he dealt with the full spectrum of sovereign grace
Calvinistically.
        According to Calvinism, election and reprobation are tucked away
mysteriously in God’s hidden will. Calvinists cannot peer down below the
topsoil to see if the roots supporting their personal faith  works are rooted
and grounded in unconditional election. So they have to examine their faith
and works frequently to see if they are really saved. Yet according to
Calvinism, many among the nonelect likewise are energized by God with
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                             Page 313
faith and works so that they will think that they are saved. Judas was. The
only thing Calvinists can do is keep an eye on their tree of faith  works and
keep working to keep it alive with the realization that if they fail, then they
will go to hell because God did not choose to energize them long enough to
make it to heaven. Calvinists may shout in public Tetelestai! (It is finished—
Jn 19:30), but in the dark they must whisper, If we endure.241 The Calvinist
logically cannot look to Jesus’ cross for assurance of his or her election. The
Calvinistic Jesus may not have died for him or her if he or she is not one of
the Calvinistic elect. Even if Jesus did die for the nonelect (which some
Calvinists would allow), the only way to be sure that one Calvinistically is
elected for heaven is to look at one’s own personal cross. In the end, the
Calvinist is left gazing up into his or her own personal tree of faith  works
for personal assurance of salvation rather than to the tree that composed
Jesus’ old rugged cross.
        Contrary to the Reformed argument, securitists contend (1) that
perseverance is not a guaranteed result and (2) that perseverance is not
necessary to reach heaven. Consequently, we can look directly to Jesus’
cross for our entrance into heaven. Reaching heaven is not conditioned on
our perseverance. In contradistinction to MacArthur, I readily affirm free
will and the viable role it plays in both contingent and non-contingent
preconditions and postconditions. Some preconditions guarantee the result,
some do not. Hearing the gospel, for example, does not guarantee that one
will believe the gospel, but believing the gospel does guarantee that one who
believes the gospel comes into possession of eternal life. In like fashion, it
must be observed that some postconditions are guaranteed while others are
not. Freewill responses make contingency a reality both before and after
conversion, but God’s sovereignty cannot be factored out of the equation.
        God has free will and sovereignty. The Lord has the sovereign
freedom to exercise His free will by making both contingent and non-
contingent decisions. Specifically, alpha-postconditions are guaranteed
unconditionally by God.* The Lord unconditionally predetermined that
regenerate believers will unconditionally go to heaven. Once we have met
the condition of punctiliar faith, our possession of eternal life as a free gift is
absolutely guaranteed. Once we have become a believer, there are no further
conditions that we must meet in order to have this life eternally. Possession
of this life is static; possession of this gift does not fluctuate. Unconditional
soteric security is the guaranteed result—even for the carnal believer. The
believer’s security is not conditioned on his or her moral performance.
Soteriological security is completely unconditional.


*
 See Illustration 96. Alpha- and Beta-Postconditions, 243; Illustration 97. Pre-
and Postconversional Life, 244.
Page 314                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       Postconversional faithworks, however, are beta-postconditions and
therefore are fully conditional. They are subsequent postconditions that
come about as a result of (1) having met the condition of saving faith and of
(2) having eternal life as a postconversional consequence. Our dynamic
experience of life in this arena is very much conditional. Eternal life is both
a static and dynamic entity: Quantity of life is static; quality of life is
dynamic. The quality of life we enjoy throughout eternity will be determined
to a very considerable degree by our moral performance we now exemplify
as Christians. This quality of life can be so diminished in the case of carnal
Christians that they can be dead in terms of their fellowship with God. Their
fellowship with God can die. Death of temporal fellowship necessarily
results in death of potential rulership if familial death persists until the point
of death. This misthological death in regards to denied rulership would
involve misthological separation from God in the outer darkness. One cannot
enjoy a life of service with Jesus as a co-ruler if the opportunity to serve as a
ruler has been taken away.

       Conclusion
        Having surveyed some of the complexities dealing with preconditions
and postconditions, a KISS application is now in order. In evangelism there
are certain prerequisites to which we must be sensitive when presenting the
gospel, and some of these prerequisites may vary depending upon the
individual to whom we are speaking. Consequently, evangelism should not
be limited to a set of mechanical formulas. We are speaking to persons with
personalities, not trying to program robots. Getting the desired response is
not a simple matter of learning to push the right buttons. The individual has
a very decisive role to play in coming to saving faith and in the
postconversional results that will be generated.
        Unfortunately, some have thought that they could improve on the
gospel according to Jesus, in which He scattered seed on a wide variety of
soils with a wide variety of results. Pseudo evangelists have imagined that
they have improved on Jesus’ sowing technique by demanding that everyone
be good soil (i.e., be good Christians) in order to reach heaven. These
pseudo Lordship Salvationists will consign bad Christians to hell and then
criticize misthologists as being antinomians just because misthologists
consign bad Christians to the outer darkness. Something is not quite right
when opponents of misthology malign misthologists as making a hell out of
heaven when it is Arminians and Calvinists, not misthologists, who claim
that carnal Christians go to hell. Contrary to such Lordship Salvationists,
misthologists will continue to affirm carnal security (i.e., the security of
carnal believers) by not conditioning salvation from hell on postconversional
moral performance. Soteriological security is guaranteed unconditionally.
Misthological security is another matter altogether. Postconditional
performance is certainly a condition for rulership in heaven.
Appendix 2. Preconditions and Postconditions                           Page 315
        As to licentiousness antinomian opponents on the other side of the
spectrum (who are mutually antagonistic to both genuine and pseudo
Lordship Salvation alike), they will turn Free Grace doctrine into
licentiousness. Biblically, this is to be expected (Jude 1:4), but this does not
give anyone license to preach legalism. Licentious antinomians simply
should be warned of their impending destruction. They can either expect the
black darkness of Jude or the outer darkness of Jesus. One need not play
God and try to discern if they are lost or saved based on their behavior. It is
enough that these two bleak options are presented to those wallowing in the
mire of licentiousness without trying to force everyone—good and bad
alike—to question their salvation on the basis of their behavior. As
advocates of unconditional security, we can have absolute assurance of our
relationship with God, know that it is permanent, get on with our lives, and
focus on our fellowship with God because we know that giving our lives for
Christ results in fellowship with Christ. Union with Christ already has been
guaranteed. The prize for which we run is communion.
        A young man with whom I was acquainted gave up Internet access
after he became a Christian. He had a self-admitted addiction to Internet
porn. So the way he dealt with this addiction was to cut off his access to the
Internet—a very wise decision. Some people suffering from such an
addiction may need to be willing to cut off their Internet access before they
will be willing to come to Christ. The words of Jesus are very appropriate in
such a case: “If your right hand makes you stumble, cut it off, and throw it
from you; for it is better for you that one of the parts of your body perish,
than for your whole body to go into hell” (Mt 5:30). If your mouse-hand is
keeping you from coming to Christ because you are unwilling to come to
Christ unless you are first willing to deal with your pornography addiction,
then do what is necessary to cut off that addiction. Do not let an addiction
keep you from salvation. Christ does not condition your salvation on your
cutting off your Internet access, but if you do, then cut it off.
        On the other hand, some pornographically-addicted people may be
willing to come to Christ without being willing to give up their addiction.
The free invitation to eternal life applies in such a case: “The Spirit and the
bride say, ‘Come.’ And let the one who hears say, ‘Come.’ And let the one
who is thirsty come; let the one who wishes take the water of life without
cost” (Rev 22:17). The water of life is free. Come, just as you are. You are
not required to overcome your addictions in order to come to Christ in
saving faith. But beware, although the water of life is without cost, the tree
of life is not. Those who have overcome the world by saving faith (1Jn 5:4)
must overcome the allurements of the word by faith  works in order to
partake of the tree of life (Rev 2:5). If you do not do what is necessary to
overcome your postconversional addiction through the grace of God, you
very well may find yourself cut off from the tree of life in heaven, although
not from heaven itself. Heaven is free; the tree of life is not. The tree of life
Page 316                                                          Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
is conditioned on the postconditional tree of faithworks. Still,
misthologists will not poison the water of life with human merit, as pseudo
Lordship Salvationists are prone to do. Throwing the tree of faith  works
into the water of life would make the water of life deathly bitter.
       Salvation is Conditioned on the Interior Singular Fruit!
                          Appendix 3.
                        Moral Repentance
         Introduction
        As has been noted already, Marshall appeals to Jeremias in support of
what would appear to be a preposterous proposition: that salvation by
Christian works is not salvation by works.* To be fair, it must be admitted
that Jeremias’ argumentation is more extensive than what Marshall is able to
provide in his simple one-page summary. Nevertheless, even Jeremias’ more
extensive argument is insufficient to provide a suitable defense for such an
obviously false statement and is inadequate to answer the penetrating
questions that may be launched against it.
        Does Jesus actually intend for us ethically to attain entrance into the
kingdom through God’s enabling grace as Marshall suggests? Is our
entrance into heaven actually a free gift conditioned on an ethic of grace in
which grace enables us to persevere so that we finally reach heaven as a
result of our grace-enabled perseverance?
        Negative answers to such questions logically would result in a
negation of Marshall’s assertion that our entrance into heaven is conditioned
on our ethical performance. Nevertheless, demonstration of this negation
will be profitable, so I will entertain the argument as advanced by Jeremias.

         Ethical Morality
         Jeremias correctly deduces that Jesus’ gospel proclamation

        was apparently the dissolution of all ethics; it seemed as if
        moral conduct meant nothing in God’s eyes. The world around
        Jesus based man’s relationship with God on his moral conduct.
        Because the gospel did not do that, it shook religion to its
        foundations.242

       If one could take Jeremias’ statement at face value, then it would
refute Marshall’s citation. Jeremias could not be teaching that entrance into
heaven is conditioned on one’s moral performance if he really believed that
the gospel does not base a believer’s relationship with God on the believer’s
moral conduct. Yet it would be premature to jump to the conclusion that
Marshall has misunderstood Jeremias. The problem is not that Marshall has
misstated Jeremias position; rather, it is that Jeremias is misleading the naïve

*
    See Second Sense, 111.
Page 318                          Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
reader into thinking that what he has said is what he really believes. Since
Marshall is no naïve reader, he can see that Jeremias does indeed condition
our entrance into heaven on our ethical performance.
 Illustration 126. Jeremias Speaks with Doubletalk on Ethical Performance




       Jeremias does not really mean what he says, or at least does not say
what he means, in that he does, in fact, condition entrance into heaven on
one’s ethical performance through the vehicle of repentance. Jeremias
basically thinks that Jesus made repentance possible to those for whom
starting off with a clean slate was impossible and that Jesus also ruled out
casuistic merit as a means for entering heaven so that the Jews could no
longer think that they could get to heaven by having their good deeds
outweigh their bad deeds.243 While such evaluations are true enough, they do
not go nearly far enough. Jeremias swings the door wide open to congruent
merit via repentance as the means to enter heaven. Therefore, although
Marshall was right to conclude that Jeremias does, indeed, condition
entrance into heaven on grace-enabled ethical performance, Marshall was
wrong to think that doing so would free him from the charge of teaching
works-righteousness. Citing Jeremias will not help Marshall’s attempt to get
into heaven by nonmeritorious works since such works congruently contain
merit.

      Reward of Grace
       The contention by Marshall (and Lewis for that matter) that entrance
into heaven is obtained by works performed through God’s enabling grace
has been refuted easily herein by the observation that rewards are based on
grace-enabled works. Indeed, works that result in heavenly rewards are
expected to be performed through God’s enabling grace. In short, grace-
based works result in rewards. Thus, to base heaven on such grace-enabled
works still would be to make heaven a reward. While such an observation is
adequate for the present purposes in refuting the watered down version of
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                         Page 319
Jeremias’ argument as presented by Marshall, it would be inadequate for
rebutting a more robust representation of Jeremias’ argumentation.
Reformed opponents objecting to this position would claim that there is no
merit in such Christian works. Heaven, they would argue, would be a reward
of grace—a reward supposedly devoid of merit within Reformed theology.*

       Merit versus Gratitude
       Jeremias could be used to support the meritless reward-of-grace
mentality. After all, Jeremias clearly asserts that in the NT concept of
reward “the idea of merit” is replaced by “gratitude for God’s grace.”244 My
contention, however, is that Jeremias’ proposal is ludicrous and sets up a
false dichotomy between merit and gratitude. In reality, Jeremias’ rejection
of merit only refutes the notion of strict merit. To be sure, strict merit and
gratitude are antithetical. However, Jeremias’ rebuttal of strict merit is
wholly inadequate to refute the possibility of condign merit, much less the
probability of congruent merit. In fact, Jeremias sounds as if he is
conceptually, albeit unwittingly, advocating congruent merit as a condition
for entering heaven in his treatment of repentance, despite his best efforts to
do otherwise.

       Merit of Repentance
      According to Jeremias, the portion of the parable of the wedding
supper dealing with the wedding garments is not genuine:

              The Church was continually confronted by the danger
       that the gospel of the free grace of God might be interpreted
       as freeing the baptized from their moral responsibilities.…In
       order to remove any ground for such a misunderstanding, the
       parable of the Wedding Garment was inserted [by the Church]
       into the parable of the Great Supper, introducing the principle
       of merit, and emphasizing the necessity for repentance as the
       condition of acquittal at the Last Judgment.”245

      Jeremias admits that the parable of the wedding garment (Mt 22:11-
13) teaches merit: garment = repentance = merit. He just refuses to

*
 See soteriological equations 4-6 in Illustration 69. Perspectives on Merit (p.
199) for three soteric forms of the reward-of-grace view:
                                 grace-grace
                                       merit -reward
                                              grace
                                 grace- grace -greward
                                       works
                                                  race
                                 grace- g£faith - reward
                                          race grace
Page 320                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
acknowledge that the part of the supper parable dealing with the wedding
garment is authentic to Jesus. Instead, Jeremias invents a literary critical
assumption which attributes the part of the parable dealing with the wedding
garment to the church through the hand of Matthew. Supposedly, the church
invented this teaching to picture repentance so that free grace could not be
freed from moral responsibility as a soteriological necessity. Yet in doing so,
the church purportedly introduced a foreign element of merit into Jesus’
parable.
           Illustration 127. Jeremias Speaks Wrongly of Authenticity




       This literary assumption by Jeremias involves some truth and some
error. Truly, a message of free grace would free believers from moral
obedience as a necessary means for reaching heaven. Jeremias correctly
perceives such to be the case. Moreover, he correctly deduces that
repentance necessarily entails merit. Therefore, his reasoning is simple:

      1. Jesus taught free grace which was antithetical to merit and moral
         necessity as soteriological conditions. (True)
      2. The wedding garments denote merit. (True)
      3. Therefore, Jesus could not have taught both. (False)

       The problem with Jeremias’ deduction is that his conclusion does not
logically flow from his premises. If the wedding garments are not dealing
with free grace, then Jeremias’ whole argument against their authenticity
falls apart. My argument is that the wedding garments are dealing with
rewards and therefore properly picture merit. The believer lacking these
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                          Page 321
wedding garments is thrown into the outer darkness in Mt 22:13. Being
thrown into the outer darkness is not a picture of free grace; rather, it is a
picture of negative rewards. After all, rewards can be punitive. Also,
believers are exhorted to keep their garments (Rev 16:15). Doing so is their
responsibility. The danger is not that they may soteriologically lose their
salvation, but that they may misthological lose their reward. Rewards are not
free. Keeping one’s garments white is an indication of personal worthiness
in overcoming the moral obstacles in one’s path (Rev 3:4-5). Jesus exhorts
believers to buy these white garments (Rev 3:18). If believers want these
white garments, they will have to pay the price. These garments are not a
picture of free grace.
        For present purposes, it suffices to note that Jeremias’ literary
criticism is open to criticism. More pointedly, for Jeremias to turn around
subsequently* and try to condition entrance into heaven on repentance is, by
his own admission, to condition entrance into heaven on merit. His entire
argument self-destructs, as does Marshall’s appeal to Jeremias. Marshall has
no legitimate basis for disassociating merit from Christian works. Jesus
teaches merit, and rewards are based on that merit. For Marshall to teach that
we are saved from hell by ethical obedience to Jesus’ teaching is to teach a
salvation contingent on our fulfilling our moral responsibilities. Marshall
therefore is teaching a gospel that is opposed to free grace. He has rejected
the gospel according to Jesus. In a nutshell, Jesus’ gospel is: Heaven is free;
rewards in heaven are not free. Marshall has in effect tried to combine the
two thoughts so as to make heaven a reward.

         Laborers in the Vineyard
        Before continuing, however, with our interaction with Jeremias on his
exclusion of the garments, it will be prudent to examine the premise upon
which his exclusion is based, namely a bias against the possibility that Jesus
affirms the possibility of merit. Although I have deductively and biblically
demonstrated Jeremias’ error above, one often needs do little more than cite
Jeremias to refute Jeremias. He trips over his own statements in his attempt
to deny clear examples of merit in the NT. Regarding the parable of the
laborers in the vineyard (Mt 20:1-16), for example, he correctly notes that
the generally accepted interpretation of the parable, which assumes that
everyone will be rewarded equally in the kingdom, misses the point of the
parable. Even more insightfully, he further admits: “Some would add that it
is intended to teach that reward is wholly of grace, but this is erroneous, they
first received their pay, as Paul would say, kata. ovfei,lhma [of debt], and not
kata. ca,rin [of grace] (Rom. 4.4).”


*
    See Wedding Garment, 326.
Page 322                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        If the example of the laborers receiving their payment is not wholly of
grace, then it is partially of merit. And as been demonstrated already, to be
partially of grace and partially of merit is an apt description of congruent
merit.246 Or one might argue for condign merit. Or one might argue that
some of the laborers represent condign merit while others represent
congruent merit. This is my preference. Regardless, the most natural
deduction would be that the parable of the laborers in the vineyard is
picturing some type of merit.
           Illustration 128. Jeremias Speaks Rightly of Implicit Merit




       Quite frankly, the workers in the parable put the owner of the
vineyard in their debt by providing him a day’s worth of labor. Since their
payment is based on debt and is not wholly of grace (as Jeremias admits), the
only reasonable conclusion is that some form of merit is being represented.
Those laborers who bargained for a day’s wage for a day’s worth of work
are rewarded on the basis of condign merit; whereas, the other workers who
only worked part of the day (and yet are given a full day’s wage) are
rewarded on the basis of congruent merit. The parable smacks of merit.
Jeremias himself practically admits as much.
       Also, to his credit, Jeremias also discredits the popular notion that the
parable of the laborers is dealing with rejecting the free gift of salvation. He
disapproves the popular notion that the laborers who work the entire day and
then murmur and

       boast of their deserts…reject God’s free gift (a favorite
       interpretation), cut themselves off from salvation….But this
       interpretation, too, misses the point of the parable. What the
       first receives is not condemnation, but the agreed wage.247
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                        Page 323
       His deduction is obvious enough. Since the benefit bestowed on the
workers is based on their works, and thus represents some form of merit, the
benefit cannot represent God’s free gift. Moreover, the laborers who
complain about the amount of their condign paycheck, thinking they have a
right to a congruent payment like the other workers, are still given their
condign paycheck. They get the same payment as the other workers. This
payment cannot be condemnation in hell because those who receive the
congruent payment receive the same payment. This parable is not dealing
with rejecting the gospel of free grace, because the benefit in question is
received and earned, not free or rejected.
   Illustration 129. Jeremias Speaks Rightly and Wrongly of the Laborers




       Nevertheless, Jeremias fumbles the ball before he gets to the end of
his discussion by suggesting that the parable is addressing soteriological
rejecters of the kingdom after all: “The parable is clearly addressed to those
who resembled the murmurers, those who criticized and opposed the good
news, Pharisees for example.…men to whom the gospel is an offence.”248
He thereby implies that the parable is concerned with the soteriological
rejection of the kingdom, a common weakness in Jeremias’ treatment of the
parables. Despite the fact that the parable is (1) talking about working for a
payment, (2) affirms that all the workers get the same benefit, and (3) does
not condemn the complainers to execution, Jeremias does an about-face and
thinks that it pictures rejection of the message of free grace. Jeremias’ own
analysis suffices to show the weakness in his own position in that he
practically has acknowledged the merit inherent in the parable.
       Those workers receiving this benefit are being paid this benefit.
Obviously, they are not working to earn a soteriological free gift. The proper
deduction, therefore, is that their recompense is based on their work, which
puts the payer of the wage in their debt on the basis of their merit. These
hired laborers (i.e., wage laborers, misthoo; Mt 20:1,7) work all day to earn
their agreed-upon wage (misthos, Mt 20:8). Genius is not necessary to figure
Page 324                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
out that this parable is dealing with misthological themes, especially when
Jesus uses the Greek words from which misthology is derived three times in
the same parable! The parable is talking about rewards based on works and
thus on merit. Even so, such an observation strangely eludes Jeremias, who
imagines that the parable is a contrast between merit and undeserved grace
so that Jesus is thought to be seeking to exclude merit—despite Jeremias’
earlier concession that the benefit is one of debt!249 Jeremias exhibits a
considerable amount of inconsistency in his ingenuity.
                       Reward versus Recompense
       By means of artificial differentiation, Jeremias asserts that Jesus does
not mean to use misthos (the Greek word for reward/recompense) to
acknowledge our “claim to reward” but only to affirm “the reality of divine
recompense.” Well, if that is the case, then Jesus certainly has a funny way
of showing it when He responds to the complainers: “Take what is yours”
(Mt 20:14). Obviously, they take payment because it is theirs. Their claim to
the payment is valid. Jeremias’ attempt to evade this conclusion shows that
there is something peculiar about Jeremias’ interpretation rather than about
Jesus’ illustration.
      Illustration 130. Jeremias Speaks Doubly Wrongly About Rewards




        One would do well to question Jeremias as to his averred distinction
between reward and recompense. Allegedly, according to Jeremias, “there
can be no question of merit here. Merit has an eye to human achievement;
recompense looks to God’s faithfulness. That God is trustworthy and offers
recompense stands assured.”250 Even the conjectural ground that Jeremias
hopes to gain with his superficial distinction between recompense and
reward is lost when one considers the fact that Jeremias only has ruled out
strict merit with this implicit acknowledgment of congruent merit. What God
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                              Page 325
in His faithfulness is offering to us, according to Jeremias, is a positive
recompense based on our positive response to God. Specifically, according
to Jeremias, this recompense is based on “the good deeds” that we have
forgotten that we have done.251 I object strongly. A salvation based on the
good deeds (which we have forgotten but which God nevertheless
remembers) is still a salvation by good works! In all reality, Jeremias is
advocating making heaven a recompense based on our good works and, in
doing so, is rejecting Pauline soteriology in the process. Logically, Jeremias’
soteriology leads to salvation by works and to a combination of condign and
congruent merit. He just refuses to acknowledge the obvious merit in his
own proposal. This is not unusual for Protestants, however.
                       Catholics versus Protestants
       Catholic apologist, Robert Sungenis, takes the Protestant, Michael
Horton, to task for confusing the strict merit with condign merit, in Horton’s
failed attempt to refute all merit by refuting strict merit. Sungenis quotes
from Aquinas to clarify the issue: “Merit in strict justice implies an absolute
equality without any grace given to the person who merits. But merit de
condigno involves an equality which arises from grace which has been
given to the one meriting.”252 Sungenis is seeking to get Protestants who
teach faith-works as the means of entering heaven to own up to the merit
inherent in their own theology. In doing so, Sungenis simply is being more
forthright about the logical implications of the faith-works position which he
shares with Protestants.
       With my simplistic mistholic equation grace-grace       merit -reward, I have
                                                                       grace
basically granted (to a considerable degree) in brief what Sungenis is
arguing for in length: Rewards entail merit and are based on works
performed through God’s enabling grace. Where I would strongly disagree
with Sungenis is in his basing our entrance into heaven on this merit and
                                              merit -reward as a soteric equation.*
thus regarding this representation in grace-grace     grace
For example, I reject his conditioning our immortality upon our morality.
Sungenis seeks to justify his position by conditioning a believer’s
soteriological security on works of grace (i.e., works performed through
God’s enabling grace flowing from faith and entailing condign merit) as
opposed to works of debt (i.e., works attributed to one’s self and limited to
strict merit). For Sungenis, entrance into heaven is conditioned on faith-
works, not on works alone (for works alone would be works of debt in his
opinion) and not on faith alone (for the notion of salvation by faith alone is
considered unbiblical in Catholicism). Instead, one’s eternal security is
conditioned on works springing from faith and thus on faith-works. As one
can readily discern, Catholicism and Protestantism are in substantial
agreement in affirming conditional security based on faith-works. Therefore,

*
    See row 4 in Illustration 69. Perspectives on Merit, 199.
Page 326                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
conditionalists, whatever their theological background, are trying to merit
their way to heaven—whether or not they admit it.
       As pointed out in The Outer Darkness, Horton rejects unconditional
security. The debate between Sungenis and Horton, therefore, boils down, in
essence, to a squabble between two competing forms of conditional security.
On the one hand, Arminians and Catholics condition entrance into heaven on
faith-works and believe that such works are works of grace performed
through God’s enabling grace. This particular subgrouping of conditional
securitists bicker among themselves as to whether or not such works contain
some type of merit: Arminians tend to think such works do not entail some
form of merit; whereas, Catholics are inclined to think otherwise. The
Catholics are right on this particular issue: works entail merit. The other
branch of conditional security, composed of Calvinists, similarly is disposed
to conditioning entrance into heaven on faith-works, but Calvinists tend to
believe that such works are works of grace performed through God’s
sovereign grace and contain no type of merit.
       Edwards is an exception to this Calvinistic rule of thumb in that he
affirms sovereign grace but nevertheless imports derivative merit. Logan
joins him in this venture. Instead of importing this merit virtually, Jeremias
does so conceptually, evidently in the guise of congruent merit. Since Lewis
believes that saving faith entails moral virtue, he implicitly makes heaven a
reward (surely as a reward of grace even though he does not use the term).
Yet Lewis shoots his own argument for conditional security in the foot by
denying that heaven is a reward (in any sense). Jeremias might be regarded
as an inverted exception to the rule that Protestants tend to deny merit in that
while Jeremias does in fact deny merit, he nevertheless affirms
recompense—a complete oxymoron.

       Wedding Garment
       If Jeremias had been straightforward with the parable of the laborers,
which he treats as authentic (although he mistakenly thinks that it is talking
about the Pharisees rejecting the offer of free grace because they will not
repent),* then he would have no basis for rejecting the insertion of merit in

parable of the laborers is interpreted properly, Jesus’ teaching on merit
proves to be a stumbling stone to Jeremias’ liberal literary criticism.
    Illustration 131. Jeremias Speaks Rightly and Wrongly of Authenticity




        My critical assessment of Jeremias’ literary criticism shows his
criticism to be lacking in logical consistency. The parable of laborers teaches
the payment of debt; therefore, Jeremias has no authentic reason to conclude
that Jesus does not teach parabolic merit. The Matthean text stands as it is
written, as being an authentic representation of Jesus’ conditioning rewards
on merit. To restate, since Jeremias admits that the notion of the benefit
received by the laborers as being wholly of grace is erroneous, he implicitly
has conceded that the payment is partially meritorious. Therefore, he
nullifies his own basis for rejecting the authenticity of the wedding garment
on the grounds of it being meritorious. If the authentic payment is
meritorious, then the wedding garment cannot be rejected as being
inauthentic simply because it is meritorious.
        Since Jeremias rejects merit, he considers this section pertaining to
the wedding garment to be an erroneous interjection by the church in which
the church tried to read “its own actual situation” into the parable of the
supper.253 Nevertheless, rejection of his theory of interjection is prudent
because he himself practically concedes that Jesus Himself teaches merit in
the parable of the laborers. Since the benefit is not wholly of grace, it is
partially of merit. Jeremias’ literary objection crumbles with this
observation. Jeremias has no authentic reason to conclude that the parable of

                   Historical Versus Literary Background
         Jeremias also acknowledges that there is no historical foundation for
believing that the custom of the time was for the host to provide the wedding
garment to those who attended the wedding. And he rejects the popular
literary basis offered from 2Kings 10:22 as a result:

       Its conclusion (22.11-13) has long troubled the expositors as
       they found themselves confronted by the puzzling question
       why a man called in from the streets should be expected to
       have a wedding-garment. The favourite [sic] explanation that it
       was customary to provide invited guests with a festal garment
       (cf. II Kings 10.22) breaks down here, since there is no
       example of the existence of such a custom in the time of
       Jesus.254
    Illustration 132. Jeremias Speaks Doubly Wrongly About Authenticity




       After attributing this part of the parable to the church as an attempt to
require repentance (and thus introducing merit into the parable), Jeremias
subsequently turns around and considers this meritorious repentance a
rabbinic interpretation and opts to attribute the wedding garment to Jesus
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                          Page 329
after all. Purportedly, Jeremias does so on a literary basis by claiming that
the garment refers to God giving/awarding imputed righteousness (obviously
as a free gift) and on the basis of a verity of texts: 1En 62:15, Pistis Sophia
8; Is 61:10; Lk 15:22; Rev 3:4-5,18; 19:8.255 However, by his own
admission, the historical evidence is suggestive otherwise, nullifying the
conjectural literary basis for believing that the garments were provided.
Moreover, the literary evidence he cites is counterproductive to the notion
that these white garments were given freely.
        Jeremias comes across as a confused scholar with this oscillation: first
saying that the parable is inauthentic because of his literary criticism, then
acknowledging it is authentic on the basis of literary parallels; first
acknowledging that it indicates merit, then trying to deny the merit
represented by it; first pointing out that historical evidence is against
regarding it as representing garments provided by the host, then trying to
find proof texts to assert otherwise.
        At one point at least, Jeremias correctly concludes that the parable is
authentic, yet he completely misses the literary basis by which its
authenticity may be affirmed. Speaking strictly from the standpoint of
literary criticism, I confirm the parabolic authenticity because the parable is
in harmony with the historical climate of Jesus’ day, in which the garments
were not provided, and because my harmonization is confirmed by rabbinic
and literary parallels. Furthermore, my meritorious interpretation is in
harmony with Jesus’ other parabolic introductions of misthological themes.
Thus, my literary criticism affirms the authenticity of the parable and is in
harmony with rabbinic parallels. Jeremias poses a false dichotomy between
the rabbinic ascription of merit and the biblical description of merit. Both
sources teach merit.
        As to the proof texts that Jeremias advances above as literary
parallels, reputedly demonstrating that the wedding garments were provided
freely, I contend that the exact opposite is true.* Briefly, in addition to the
texts already mentioned,† Is 61:10 contextually is indicative of practical
righteousness, not imputational righteousness. This practical righteousness
results in misthological righteousness. Thus, the wedding garment denotes a
combination of practical and misthological righteousness. This righteousness
is impartational, not imputational. This text from Isaiah very well may
provide the backdrop for the texts in Revelation. If so, these NT texts clearly
confirm the mistholic perspective regarding Isaiah’s text, since being clothed
in white garments is a reward based on personal worthiness and practical
overcoming in Revelation. In fact, the righteous garments explicitly are
