identified as the righteous works of the saints in the final text (Rev 19:8)!
One could not ask for a clearer literary allusion than that provided in this
Johannine finale to prove that such garments depict a misthological
righteousness which is granted as a result of practical righteousness!
                                 Prodigal Son
        As to the parable of the prodigal son, in which the father clothes his
repentant son with a robe (Lk 15:22), the son’s being clothed with this robe
is a consequence of the son’s repentance. If repentance denotes merit (as
Jeremias correctly admitted in his earlier assessment and even subsequently
in his rabbinic alternative), then the garment is given because of (congruent)
merit. The meaning of the parable would be that immature Christians who
wander away from fellowship with God are invited to repent and come back
into fellowship with God so that they can be rewarded with at least some
congruent rewards for doing so.
                               Unworthy Slaves
        Jeremias stakes a lot on his understanding of the parable regarding the
unworthy slaves (Lk 17:10) to conclude that it means: “We have done
nothing to merit God’s approbation, and all our good works give us no claim
upon him”256 so that this parable “puts an end to the idea of merit. There are
no merits at all before God” (emphasis his).257 Lest anyone is tempted to
jump to the same conclusion as Jeremias in thinking that this parable (like
the parable regarding the prodigal son) proves that believers are unworthy
(Lk 15:19,21) of the garment, let it be noted that Jesus only rules out strict
merit in these parables, not other forms of merit. Unthinkingly parroting
Jeremias’ take on the parables is unwise since Jesus elsewhere teaches that
rewards are based on the personal worthiness of His followers (Mt 10:37-38;
22:8; Lk 20:35). For that matter, one of the passages cited by Jeremias
conditions the garment on personal worthiness (Rev 3:4). Harmonization
within the biblical record is attained easily by denying strict merit
(worthiness) while simultaneously affirming condign and congruent merit
(worthiness). Lack of harmony within Jeremias’ discussion, on the other
hand, is demonstrated just as easily.
        Jeremias is correct to conclude that Jesus makes it impossible to merit
heaven since even a “covetous look” brings one into judgment (Mt 5:28).258
But what Jeremias fails to admit in his attempt to circumvent the graduation
of sin and matching judgment taught by Jesus in Mt 5:22 is that although
any sin can send one to hell, this does not mean that there cannot be a
graduation of punishment in hell (or in heaven for that matter). Additionally,
by noting that the Pharisees could not be saved because of their trust in their
merit, Jeremias has condemned himself, falling into the same trap as the
Pharisees by trusting in the merit of his repentance. He is trapped by the
logic of his own argument:
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                        Page 331
                      Illustration 133. Garment = Merit
     1. The wedding garment represents repentance.
     2. Repentance represents merit.
     3. Therefore, the wedding garment represents merit.259

                          What is Repentance
       By trusting in his repentance to clothe himself with soteriological
righteousness, Jeremias inadvertently is clothing himself in works-
righteousness. Judaizers and contemporary pseudo Lordship Salvationists
will, of course, rejoice with Jeremias’ view of repentance since he says
repentance is:

       • “Being sorry” for sin.
       • “Turning away from sin.”
       • Not “half-hearted.”
       • “A complete surrender to a new master.”
       • Becoming a child again who learns to say “Abba.”
       • “Simply trusting in the grace of God.”
       • “Being overwhelmed by the grace of God.”
       • “Putting on the wedding garment.”260

      The section of Jeremias’ discussion from which this list is obtained
comes after his section denying the possibility of any merit before God.261
Correspondingly, one more item needs to be added (albeit with obvious
inconsistency in his argument) to make this list a complete representation of
Jeremias’ perspective:

       • Repentance is nonmeritorious.

       Jeremias is oblivious to the inherent merit he imports into repentance
in the preceding list. Such a list is subject to the inherent weaknesses still
found today in the turn-or-burn soteriology of fake Lordship Salvation. For
one thing, subjectivity is a problem. How sorry do you have to be in order to
be forgiven of your sins and go to heaven? If full-hearted (as opposed to
half-hearted) sorrow and surrender are necessary to reach heaven, how can
you be certain that you are not only 99.9% sorrowful and surrendered?
Could it be that you fall short of the complete 100% sorrow and surrender
that Jeremias deems necessary?
       A semantic issue with Jeremias’ approach is evident: If repentance is
simply trusting in the grace of God, as he claims, then what is faith? How is
repentance different from faith? If repentance is believing, why does the
Bible urge people to “repent and believe” (Mk 1:15)?
Page 332                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        A logistic problem with his order is apparent: Where does repentance
fit into his ordo salutis? Does God become a believer’s Father before or after
repentance? Does repentance occur before or after saving faith? Such
questions are not merely exercises in academic speculation. They are vitally
important.*
        Consistency concerning his order is certainly a problem: According to
Jeremias, “Jesus offers salvation to sinners before they repent, as is
particularly clear from Luke 19.1-10” (emphasis his).262 Do we hear
Jeremias hearkening back to Calvin’s ordo salutis here?† If so, fine and well.
But in view of Jeremias’ list above, it makes no sense for him to place
repentance after salvation. Repentance cannot be the requirement for
imputational garments and yet come after the imputation of such
imputational garments!
        The soteric curse is also the problem for Jeremias: Since Paul places a
curse on those trying to get to heaven by faith-works (Gal 1:8-9), then why
does Jeremias’ performance-based soteriology not fall under this curse on
works-righteousness? How can repentance simply be trusting in God’s grace
apart from your merit, as Jeremias asserts, when you have to jump through
performance hoops to get to heaven in his theology?
        The mistholic alternative is more attractive: If repentance is joy over
the grace of God, then why can it not be misthological joy over being
graciously rewarded by God in the form of congruent merit? Why must our
joy or God’s grace be limited to gifts? Why can we not rejoice if God
stupendously rewards our feeble efforts?
        Jeremias’ consistency concerning grace is a notable problem: What
distinguishes the message of Jesus is the “unconditional character of grace”
(emphasis his).263 A simple glance at Jeremias’ list will prove that the grace
given in response to repentance is not unconditional. This repentance-
derived grace is conditioned on whole-hearted surrender to the Lordship of
Christ. Such an assessment is no problem for those who see repentance as a
matter dealing with rewards given in response to congruent merit, but it
spells doom for Jeremias’ attempt to twist repentance into a nonmeritorious
condition resulting in a gift.
        As to the extrabiblical texts Jeremias cites in reference to the alleged
imputational nature of the wedding garment, what Jeremias fails to
acknowledge in 1En 62:15 is that those clothed with this garment are those
who have demonstrated practical righteousness. The garment is not given on
the basis of imputational righteousness but on the basis of practical
righteousness!‡ Attributing any value to the later gnostic Pistis Sophia is

*
  See Epilogue, 345.
†
  See Illustration 98. Pseudo Syllogism for , 246.
‡
  See The Outer Darkness for more details regarding Enochian soteriology.
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                        Page 333
questionable, but Jeremias’ failure to tell his reader that it is Jesus who is
being clothed with the garment in this context because He is worthy is
inexcusable (Pistis Sophia 10). Even if it were a worthiness attributed
exclusively to rank, it still would entail personal worthiness. Even so, where
is the evidence that this personal worthiness does not also embody practical
worthiness? To put it mildly, historical and literary evidence cited by
Jeremias suggest most strongly that being able to stay at the feast because of
the garments one is wearing represents a meritorious reward based on
personal and practical worthiness.
              Illustration 134. Provided or Produced Garments




        Scholarship is widely divided over whether or not the garments were
provided. Commentators run the full spectrum from claiming that the
evidence that the garments were provided is quite sufficient to asserting that
it is completely lacking and then concluding that the garments merely were
washed.264 As a rule of thumb, those claiming that the garments were
provided have a reasonable recourse by which to claim that the garments
refer to imputed righteousness. Then again, even if the garments are
provided, they still could be referring to imparted righteousness. If, on the
other hand, the garments merely are washed, then the most natural
conclusion is that they refer to imparted righteousness. Regardless, as to
where one finds oneself in one’s assessment of the swing of the pendulum
Page 334                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
regarding the probability that the garments were provided, the most probable
interpretation is that the garments necessary to attend the feast refer to the
personal holiness produced by believers through the means God has
provided for them in living a holy life. Correspondingly, to misconstrue
participation in this feast as entrance into heaven not only overlooks the fact
that the man in question already had entered the feast but even more
precariously ends up, more often than not, on conditioning entrance into
heaven on one’s meritorious performance. In any case, it certainly will not
do to equate these garments with repentance and then equate participation in
the feast with entrance into heaven. Doing so would condition entrance into
heaven on our meritorious performance.

       Conclusion
        Marshall’s faith in Jeremias’ defense of an ethically-based entrance
into heaven has been misplaced. Not only does Jeremias fail to establish his
point, he practically demolishes his own argument with logical and literary
inconsistencies and biblical inaccuracies. Repentance entails merit. To base
one’s entrance into heaven on one’s repentance is to try futilely to merit
heaven. Parables that portray Jesus as teaching merit are authentic to Jesus
and pose no problem for harmonization with His message of free grace once
it is realized that heaven is free but rewards in heaven are earned. Jeremias’
earlier deduction, in which he perceived that the wedding garment represents
a meritorious repentance, is correct. Believers in the church repeatedly are
called upon to repent in Rev 2-3 so that they may not lose their heavenly
rewards.
        If harmony between Jesus’ proclamation in the gospels and in
Revelation may be assumed, and no legitimate reason for not harmonizing
these accounts has been found, then the most natural conclusion is that the
man who shows up at the wedding improperly dressed represents a carnal
believer who shows up in heaven improperly clothed because he did not
repent of his carnality while living on earth. As a result, this carnal believer
is thrown into the outer darkness. Again, assuming a continuity between the
message of Jesus in the first book of the NT and His message in the last
book of the NT, the only proper deduction would be that the casting of
carnal believers into the outer darkness represents their loss of rewards in
heaven, not their exclusion from heaven itself.
        Naturally, conditionalists frequently attempt to deny the very
existence of carnal Christians since even the mere existence of this type of
Christian is a complete embarrassment to their conditional theology.
Passages such as Mat 7:20-23 and Jam 2:14-26 are taken by conditionalists
as demonstrating that professing believers who have substandard moral
performance are either not saved to begin with or lose their salvation
somewhere along the way. Such interpretations lead to a performance-based
view of salvation. Nonetheless, as seen in this brief survey and demonstrated
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                         Page 335
in the much fuller treatment in The Outer Darkness, harmonization of these
passages with the carnal Christian theory is demonstrated easily. The
Matthean passage in Mat 7:20-23 does, in fact, consign professing believers
with substandard performance to hell, but it does not do so because they are
carnal believers. Rather, it does so because those making this profession of
faith in Jesus are performance-based conditionalists whose moral
performance falls short of the moral perfection demanded by the Lord Jesus
Christ Himself—which is Himself. The conditionalists in this passage appeal
to their own righteousness rather than Jesus’ imputed righteousness as the
reason they should be allowed into heaven. They flunk the Kennedy
question. The text reads as if these people are standing before the Lord and
have just been asked by Him as to why He should let them into heaven, but
He is dissatisfied with their response and pronounces that they will go to hell
instead of being allowed into heaven. Their objection amounts to the claim
that they have lived a good Christian life. Unfortunately for them, it was not
good enough.
       Jesus already had anticipated this type of answer and destroyed any
hope of reaching heaven through this means when He asserted earlier in this
very sermon: “For I say to you, that unless your righteousness surpasses that
of the scribes and Pharisees, you shall not enter the kingdom of heaven”
(Mt 5:20). Our moral perfection must surpass that of the moral
perfectionists. In short, it must be perfect. Jesus indicates as much when a
few moments later He warns: “Everyone who looks on a woman to lust for
her has committed adultery with her already in his heart” (Mt 5:28). Seeking
to enter heaven by trusting in God and by trying to keep His moral
commandments will send one to hell. Not breaking the Ten Commands (in
this case, “Thou shall not commit adultery”) is shown to be an impossible
task. The moral standard is Christ, not fallen humanity. He is the vertical
moral ruler against which we must be able to measure ourselves and be
found to measure up. If one is to answer the Kennedy question on the basis
of goodness, there is only one good answer as to why God should let us into
heaven. We must be able to respond convincingly that the reason God
should let us into heaven is because we are as good as Jesus Christ. If we
truthfully cannot provide that answer, then there is no hope of our entering
heaven. We cannot trust in our own goodness as our basis or means for
entering heaven.
       Unconditional securitists can, of course, honestly answer that they are
as good as Christ because their trust is not in their own righteousness but
exclusively in the imputed righteousness of Christ. Since Christ has given
them His righteousness as a gift, they can appeal to His moral perfection as
the reason God should let them into heaven. Their hope is built on nothing
less than Jesus’ blood and His righteousness. They dare not trust in their
righteousness, but wholly lean on His righteousness.
Page 336                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
               Illustration 135. Correct Chicken-Egg Sequence




         As to Jam 2:14-26, the context is dealing with the judgment of
believers (Jam 2:13; 3:1). Therefore, the Jacobean text is concerned with the
judgment of carnal believers who have not put their faith into action. Carnal
Christians already have imputed righteousness and will be saved from hell as
a result. However, they must have practical righteousness to be saved from a
merciless judgment in terms of rewards in heaven. Like the carnal believer at
the wedding feast (who is improperly clothed), these carnal believers in the
Epistle of James will find themselves in the inexcusable position of not
having lived out their Christian life in a morally-victorious manner.
         Edwards does well to note that James is talking about a secondary
justification that is conditioned meritoriously on our postconversional works.
By the sheer nature of the case, one would anticipate that such justification
would be misthological. This anticipation of misthological justification is
met with contextual justification (Jam 2:13; 3:1). The issue in question is not
whether or not believers will be saved from hell but whether or not they will
escape a merciless judgment. If they are judged mercilessly, they will lose
the potential crown which James already had mentioned (Jam 1:12). Carnal
Christians will lose out on winning such crowns. Misthologically, judgment
for such a believer will be unmerciful. James’ point, then, is that believers
need faith and works to obtain a final misthological justification.
         Matthew and John concur that a Christian who fails to repent of his
moral lethargy will be cast/spit out (Mt 22:14; Rev 3:16). Such a Christian
will be in heaven but be a heavenly outcast. Just as in our society an outcast
is still a member of that society, so such a Christian still will be found to be
a member of the heavenly society but subject to a social stigma that is
altogether undesirable. The resulting state of carnal believers will be
something over which they naturally are upset. The outer darkness will be
Appendix 3. Moral Repentance                                              Page 337
found to amount to much more than theological spilt milk, as indicated by
their weeping over their predicament. All three times the Bible refers to the
outer darkness, it notes that those carnal believers consigned there weep as a
result (Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30). The misthologically outcast will be
emotionally downcast. No doubt, they will be able to console themselves
eventually and considerably with the joy that comes from being in heaven.
Nevertheless, there is no reason to conclude that they will be able to comfort
themselves completely. To the contrary, there is every reason to believe that
the Lord’s promise to wipe away tears in heaven (Rev 21:4) is limited to
those believers who repent of their carnality during their lives on earth.*
Repentant believers will merit the misthological handkerchief.
       Misthologists are not left shooting in the dark, hoping that they have
hit upon the correct solution in this proposition. A rather remarkable
confirmation comes from the hand of Paul:

               And I, brethren, could not speak to you as to spiritual
         people but as to carnal, as to babes in Christ. 2I fed you with
         milk and not with solid food; for until now you were not able
         to receive it, and even now you are still not able; 3for you are
         still carnal. For where there are envy, strife, and divisions
         among you, are you not carnal and behaving like mere men?
         (1Cor 3:1-3; NKJ)

       Thrice Paul repeats that these Christian brethren are carnal. Those
conditionalists who claim that there is no such thing as a carnal Christian
have quite an enigma on their hands. And as if this text were not clear
enough, the Holy Spirit has Paul proceed to demonstrate a few verses later
that such temporal carnality may be found to result in misthological
calamity:
         11
            For no man can lay a foundation other than the one which is
         laid, which is Jesus Christ. 12 Now if any man builds upon the
         foundation with gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, straw,
         13
            each man’s work will become evident; for the day will show
         it, because it is to be revealed with fire; and the fire itself will
         test the quality of each man's work. 14 If any man’s work which
         he has built upon it remains, he shall receive a reward. 15 If any
         man’s work is burned up, he shall suffer loss; but he himself
         shall be saved, yet so as through fire. (1Cor 3:11-15)




*
    See The Outer Darkness.
Page 338                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
        A carnal Christian is a believer who has been found, either temporally
or misthologically, not to be victorious over fleshly lusts or deceits. The
parabolic material from Matthew, the symbolic envisioning from John, the
didactic imagery from Paul, and the historic application from James coalesce
into a beautiful misthological harmonization. So what is one to make of the
fact that many expositors fail to appreciate this harmony and imagine a
disharmony instead? Or what about those writers who think that they, at
least, hear a tension in this quartet? Have these biblical writers strained their
expositional vocal cords? Is there a tension to their voices that has escaped
detection? No. The tension and lack of harmony that is perceived by some to
exist amongst the biblical writers is explained much more readily as a
tension between the biblical writers and their listeners, not as a tension
between the individual members of this biblical quartet. Those listening to
these biblical writers and perceiving anything less than sweet harmony
should have their spiritual reception checked. The problem is in the receiver,
not the transmitter.
        More pointedly, since Paul places a curse on those misconstruing the
basic nature of the gospel so as to turn it into a performance-based rat’s race,
and since James teaches that teachers of the gospel are under a stricter
judgment, and since John teaches that anyone who takes away or adds to his
message will suffer severe misthological consequences, it is reasonable to
infer that those teachers who deny the existence of carnal believers have
done so because they have misconstrued the underlying nature of the gospel
and consequently have placed themselves in the outer darkness of Matthew
or perhaps, even worse, demonstrated by the fruit of their teaching that they
do not believe the gospel and thereby have sentenced themselves to
Matthew’s hell. The doctrine of carnality is not a triviality. Many of those
who bar carnal believers from heaven because of their carnal behavior will
be found to have barred themselves from heaven because of their defective
theology.
                         Appendix 4.
                        Gospel Stratum
      Introduction
        Those in the Lordship Salvation camp have asserted that it is
necessary to include a call to repentance in the proclamation of the gospel in
order to be true to the gospel of Jesus and thus to proclaim a saving message.
Certainly, the gospel according to Jesus contains a call to repentance. The
problem is that Lordship Salvationists act as if this admission provides
justification for their inclusion of repentance as a necessary component
within evangelism.265
        The Free Grace camp rejects this Lordship Salvation conclusion since
the Lordship Salvation inclusion of repentance as an evangelistic necessity
inevitably conditions salvation from hell on performance. Moreover,
contrary to the Lordship Salvationist intent, the Lordship Salvationist claim
excludes the Gospel of John from being considered the gospel according to
Jesus. When those in the Free Grace camp deny that repentance is a
necessary component of the gospel, they are looking at the word gospel in its
restricted meaning (i.e., as referring to the saving message that must be
believed so that one experiences saving faith). Repentance is not part of this
restricted meaning of gospel.

      Saving Message
        Including repentance in the gospel proclamation is not a false gospel
when the word gospel is broadly defined with its full NT range of meaning
so that repentance is made a condition for fellowship with God or for reward
from God. Repentance is properly included in this manner within that broad
NT semantic range (cf. Mk 1:15). However, as Wilkin has pointed out, when
the word gospel is used in the popular sense to describe what a person must
believe to be saved from hell, repentance should not be included in that
restricted definition of the word gospel. Wilkin suggests that the restricted
use of the word gospel at the popular level be replaced by the expression
saving message in order to avoid confusion and to be biblically accurate. As
Wilkin correctly notes, the saving message is “what one must believe to be
born again.”266

      Contextual Restriction
       Wilkin’s proposal is one possible course of action. Pragmatically,
however, the popular use of the word gospel is too ingrained to be changed.
If nothing else, technical accuracy will have to make room for popular
sentimentality. Even if, for the sake of argument, it is granted that the word
Page 340                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
gospel is never used in a restricted sense in the NT, its semantic range
ironically has been expanded, within in the public sector, to include a
restricted meaning as referring to the content of saving faith. Wilkin’s
substitution will surely be lost in the court of public appeal. The public is not
about to start calling gospel tracts saving message tracts. Nor will the title
Gospel of John be supplanted by the title: Saving Message of John. Even
though I believe John purposely avoids using the term gospel, I find the title
Gospel of John helpful. I am not going to try to dislodge the gospel title
from John’s presentation even though one rightly might argue that the title is
technically inaccurate and potentially runs cross-grain to John’s purposeful
omission of the word gospel. Even though I am sympathetic with Wilkin’s
attempt to clarify by using saving message as a substitution for the popular
usage of the term gospel, I will not use this substation but rather implement
contextual restriction.

       Synoptic Usage
       Nevertheless, technical accuracy should not be brushed aside even if
the popular usage of the term is retained. Naturally, the usage of the word
gospel by the gospel writers should be given paramount consideration as to
the meaning they wish to convey by the word. Mark commences his
presentation with this declaration: “The beginning of the gospel of Jesus
Christ, the Son of God” (Mk 1:1). Mark will then use the noun gospel
(euaggelion) an additional seven times within his gospel account. The gospel
is referred to as the gospel of the kingdom: “And after John [the Baptist]
had been taken into custody, Jesus came into Galilee, preaching the gospel
of the kingdom of God and saying, ‘The time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of
God is at hand; repent and believe in the gospel.’” (Mk 1:14-15; MT; TM;
cp. Mt 4:23; Lk 4:43).
       Matthew also uses the noun gospel. In three out of four of these
nominal occurrences, Matthew specifies that he is talking about the gospel
of the kingdom (Mt 4:23; 9:35; 24:14). This gospel conditions (mistholic)
salvation on perseverance (Mt 24:13-14). The gospel of the kingdom
includes a call to repentance and a promise of reward. Rulership of the
kingdom is at stake.
       Unlike Mark and Matthew, Luke does not use the nominal form of
the word for gospel. However, Luke does implement the verbal form of
preaching the gospel (euaggelizo) ten times, in comparison to Matthew’s
singular use of the verbal form (Mt 11:15). In harmony with the other two
synoptic writers, Luke specifies repeatedly that he is referring to the gospel
of the kingdom. He records Jesus as saying, “I must preach the gospel of the
kingdom of God to the other cities also, for I was sent for this purpose”
(Lk 4:43; TM). Also, Jesus “began going around from one city and village to
another, proclaiming and preaching the gospel of the kingdom of God”
(Lk 8:1; TM). Moreover, “the Law and the Prophets were proclaimed until
Appendix 4. Gospel Stratum                                           Page 341
John [the Baptist]; since then the gospel of the kingdom of God is preached”
(Lk 16:16). The gospel that was preached since the commencement of the
ministry of John the Baptist (and thus throughout Jesus’ ministry) is the
gospel of the kingdom. By means of explicit identification and in terms of
frequency of usage, the Synoptic Gospels are correctly identified as Gospels.
Specifically, they focus on the gospel of the kingdom.

       Johannine Absence
        The proclamation by John, in strong contrast, omits any reference to
gospel. Apparently, John is demonstrating technical, historical accuracy by
purposefully omitting the word gospel from what has come to be called The
Gospel of John. A reasonable conjecture is that his Gospel, as it has come to
be called, omits any reference to the gospel or to repentance because John is
not calling for repentance and therefore is not issuing a gospel call (at least
as the term gospel was understood in “in the gospel of Jesus” as related by
the Synoptic Gospels) because such a call would include repentance.
Whereas the synoptic writers are presenting the gospel of the kingdom, John
restricts his focus to a narrower subcomponent: the message of grace. Thus,
he does not use the word gospel because using this word would have
suggested a broader focus: the gospel of the kingdom (with its inclusion of
repentance—which John purposefully has omitted).267

       Gospel of Grace
       Nonetheless, perhaps with some insensitivity to John’s historical
technical precision, the popular designation Gospel of John has been added
from antiquity to John’s presentation of Jesus’ message. Although John did
not supply this title, the title is here to stay because of this subsequent
popular entitling. Whereas the Synoptic Gospels focus on the gospel of
Jesus, John adopts a narrower focus in concentrating on the saving message
of Jesus. If, at least in deference to the popular designation, this narrower
focus is labeled the gospel of grace (cp. Acts 20:24), then John has narrowed
his scope of the Jesus’ message to the gospel of grace. John’s masterful
presentation might, therefore, be dubbed appropriately: Gospel of Grace.
       Speaking then in these terms, to port the broader concepts associated
with the gospel of the kingdom (with its emphasis on earning rewards) into
the theologically narrower gospel of grace would result in a false gospel in
which entrance into heaven is made a reward. This importation is foreign to
the NT usage. To interject repentance from the gospel of the kingdom into
the narrower gospel of grace would falsify the gospel (in both its broad and
narrow forms) because the gospel of the kingdom includes the gospel of
grace which excludes the call to repentance as a soteric condition.
       So what are we to do in the current theological climate? Will we
equate the gospel with the inclusion of repentance and thereby deny that the
Page 342                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Gospel of John is a gospel according to Jesus because the Gospel of John
purposely omits both the words gospel and repentance? Not likely.268
        The better recourse is to acknowledge that all words have a semantic
range and that the word gospel is no exception. Accordingly, the Gospel of
John can be called a gospel when it is acknowledged that it properly leaves
out the words gospel and repentance because the Gospel of John is not
writing a gospel in the broad sense of the word (which would have included
a call to repentance and would have conditioned salvation on perseverance).
Instead, John is focusing on the evangelistic invitation to take the water of
life freely. He is, thereby, writing, in theological terms, a gospel of grace.
Consequently, his presentation can be called a gospel because the gospel can
be narrowed theologically in scope to what is necessary to be believed for
the possession of eternal life as a free gift (resulting in unconditional
security).

      Gospel Inclusion and Exclusion
                     Illustration 136. What is the gospel?




       The gospel of Jesus (GJ) includes many things (snake handling and
drinking poison to name but a few). The gospel of the kingdom (GK)
includes requirements for rewards, such as repentance and perseverance.
Conversely, this smaller subset form of the gospel (GK) excludes snake
handling and drinking poison from the larger set (GJ) as requirements for
kingdom rulership. Snake handling and drinking poison are extraneous
details found in the outer circle, not in the inner circle (much less in the
innermost circle). The reward of kingdom rulership presupposes kingdom
entrance by faith, however. Therefore, what is in the innermost circle is
presupposed in the middle circle. That is, the gospel of the kingdom
(regarding rewards in heaven) presupposes the gospel of grace (concerning
Appendix 4. Gospel Stratum                                              Page 343
entrance into heaven). Although this presupposition regarding entrance by
faith is touched upon by the Synoptic Gospels (e.g., Mt 21:31-32), the
requirement for entrance is the focus of John’s exposition. John’s gospel of
grace (GG) concentrates on the one thing that one must do to be born again
and thereby qualify for kingdom entrance—believe (Jn 3:3-5).*
                       Illustration 137. Snaky Preaching




       Will those in the Lordship camp assert that it is necessary to include
snake handling and drinking poison in the evangelistic proclamation of the
gospel in order to be true to the gospel of Jesus? I doubt it! Although the
gospel of Jesus includes such details, these details are not included in what
one must do in order to go to heaven. They are part of the gospel broadly
defined but not part of the gospel narrowly defined. Given my affirmation of
the integrity of the biblical record, I would affirm that the gospel
introduction in Mk 1:1 includes the gospel commission in Mk 16:18 (with its
promises regarding snakes and poison). Nevertheless, I am not going to tell
people that they have to handle snakes or drink deadly poison in order to be
saved. Just because some Christian missionaries have been bitten by
poisonous snakes (cp. Acts 28:3) or unknowingly have drunk deadly poison
without ill effects in fulfillment of this promise does not mean that doing so
is prescriptive.†
*
  GG ⊂ GK ⊂ GJ.
Naturally, each subset excludes some elements found in the larger set:
     • Snakes & poison ⊄ GK. One is not required to handle snakes or
         drink poison in order to inherit the kingdom.
     • Repentance & perseverance ⊄ GG. One is not required to repent or
         persevere in order to enter the kingdom. The heart of the gospel, the
         gospel of grace, excludes repentance and perseverance as
         requirements for kingdom entrance.
†
  One missionary relates that when he and his fellow missionaries entered a
village to share the gospel, the natives poisoned them. It was only after the
natives saw that the missionaries suffered no ill effect that the natives told the
missionaries what they had done and were willing to listen to them.
Page 344                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
       The Lordship prescription, on the other hand, if actually followed,
would lead to another Jamestown massacre. I counter that not everything in
the broad form of the gospel is intended for public consumption as a
necessary means of reaching heaven. Failing to distinguish between the
broad forms and narrow forms of the gospel can be quite deadly, not only
physically but soteriologically. A poisonous perversion of the gospel is far
more deadly than a poisonous snake. Therefore, a poisonous gospel should
be no less odious than a poisoned communion cup.

       Conclusion
       Lordship Salvationists claim that anyone who omits a call to
repentance is not preaching the gospel according to Jesus. Will they also
claim that omission of Jesus’ commission regarding handling poisonous
snakes and drinking deadly poison indicates a failure to preach the gospel
according to Jesus? No way! Yet Mark would take issue with their inclusion
of repentance while making an exclusion of snakes and poison. Mark
includes both. He is not ashamed of the gospel of Jesus, even if it includes
some hard-to-believe promises, such as handling snakes and drinking
poison. I am not ashamed of that gospel either.
       Excluding the message of repentance from the gospel of grace has
nothing to do with being ashamed of the gospel of grace because repentance
is not a part of the gospel of grace. Likewise, excluding the promise of
miraculous signs about picking up snakes and drinking poison from the
gospel of the kingdom has nothing to do with being ashamed of the gospel
of the kingdom because snakes and poison are not a part of the gospel of the
kingdom. On the other hand, I suspect that some (even from antiquity) have
left out the promise regarding snakes and poison from the gospel of Jesus
because they were embarrassed by this component of the gospel of Jesus.
Their failure to include this promise regarding snakes and poison does not,
however, necessarily bring their regeneration into question.
       Repentance is a part of the gospel of Jesus except when that gospel is
limited in scope to the message of evangelism. When the gospel of Jesus is
focused on the purpose of evangelism, then the message of repentance is
properly omitted, as attested by the gospel of John. Indeed, when the
intention is to limit the consideration to what is required to have eternal life
as a free gift, then the inclusion of the message of repentance as a condition
is an improper aberration.
                                Epilogue
       Fight the Good Fight
       If C. S. Lewis were alive today, I would love to go to the movies with
him to watch Narnia and Prince Caspian and discuss the theological
implications of these movies which his books have inspired. Or if Jonathan
Edwards were alive, I’m sure I would enjoy discussing his virtual importing
as compared to my virtual embedding. Surely a discussion with Jeremias
regarding the impact of misthology on literary criticism would be
interesting. The focus of my fight is not with the person but with his
position. There is no reason to question the overall intelligence or allegiance
of these opposing authors. But there is every justification for refuting their
theology when it departs from biblical soteriology. My own allegiance to the
Lord would be open to serious question if I did not fight the good fight of
faith and contend earnestly for the faith (1Tim 6:12; Jude 1:3). And my love
for my Lord, for my children, and for others certainly would be suspect if I
just sat quietly on the sidelines while well-meaning wolves in sheep’s
clothing are trying to lead my children and others away from the faith. If the
Bible demands that I consider those teaching a performance-based gospel
accursed wolves, then who am I to turn a deaf ear to their howls?

       Years Later
        When I was at the age that my sons are now, I was an advocate of the
turn-or-burn gospel which they are now hearing. That was the message I
shared with my friends. I had never heard a consistent faith-alone gospel. I
was one theologically messed up kid. Like so many others, I was trying to
tell others that they had to turn from their sins in order to get the free gift of
eternal life, yet at the same time I told them that salvation is by faith alone. I
knew something did not sound quite right about having to change your
performance to get a free gift, but that was the only gospel I knew. Now,
many years later, I can look back on those years of struggle between a faith-
alone gospel and a faith-plus gospel and praise God for a deliverance that
allows me logically and biblically to embrace free grace with theological
consistency. In a day and age such as ours, and in a community such as ours,
there is no way I can spare my children the experience of having to struggle
with such matters and from having to think through these same issues for
themselves. They too will have to learn to fight the good fight of faith. I
cannot spare them the fight, but I can show them how to win it. Praise God, I
did.

      1
         Geisler enjoined S with P by claiming that God determinately knows
who will persevere. Geisler’s determinate election results in a conditional
security in which the result is positively guaranteed. Therefore, in terms of
results, Geisler’s Calminianism looks more like PEARP. This might be the
best acronym by which to describe Calminianism. Since the perseverance is
guaranteed in TULIP, the security of the elect is also. They will not lose
their regeneration since they will persevere. Therefore, this security is both
guaranteed and conditional. Geisler’s approach results in the same outcome
and therefore is best considered a modification in which the S in PEARS has
been replaced with a synthetic form of P in TULIP to yield PEARP.
        Alternatively, since the acronyms for Calvinism and Arminianism
both teach that perseverance is necessary to reach heaven, the Calminian
mediating position forged by affirming the soteriological necessity of
perseverance from the S of PEARS and the P of TULIP might be better
described by a combination of S + P. Because Geisler affirmed this core
doctrine of perseverance from a TULIP perspective but rejected the rest of
TULIP in preference for an approach more in harmony with PEARS, his
Calminian position may be described appropriately as somewhat analogous
to a PEARS+P since he affirms the TULIP form of P. Conversely, some
Calvinists frankly acknowledge that Calvinistic retention of regeneration is
conditioned on perseverance. This stress might be regarded by some
Calvinists to be TULIP+S, at least in terms of stress. The Arminian S+P and
the Calvinistic P+S forms of Calminianism might be represented by the
acronyms PEARPS and TULIPS respectively. From the view point of
predestination, perseverance is guaranteed in both forms of Calminianism.
Since the majority of Calminians seem to affirm the body of the PEARS, the
best recourse is to either describe them in terms of PEARP, PEARPS, or just
stress the tail end agreement with PS.

Whether or not Luther is correct in regarding Jonah 3:5 as an example of
saving faith, his concern is valid. Placing repentance as a soteriological
necessity before saving faith is a sequence that nullifies salvation by faith
alone. Granted, Luther did think that repentance would “follow inevitably”

inescapable nature of this conclusion. In contrast to Luther, however, the

believing does not mean that everyone will.

        Mark Cahill, One Heartbeat Away: Your Journey Into Eternity

completely misrepresented the nature of the case by making heaven
conditioned on the way we live in previous pages.

        A Lordship preacher at the church where my family and I are
attending as I write this book presented a sermon in defense of the Lordship
perspective of repentance. The bulk of this sermon was dedicated to proving
(from his perspective) that in order to go to heaven, you must repent.
Remarkably, he then turned around to stipulate that if you are repenting in
order to go to heaven, you will go to hell because repenting in order to
heaven is legalistic repentance. To an extent, I agree with him. Thinking that
one must repent in order to reach heaven is definitely a legalistic
perspective. In reality, this preacher unwittingly refuted the first part of his
sermon as being a legalistic perspective.
Endnotes                                                              Page 349
                    Illustration 138. Legalistic Repentance




      As if the doubletalk was not bad enough, this preacher sought to
illustrate what he believed to be to the proper motivation for repentance with
a question along this line: “If God were to tell you that heaven were already
full, would you still live a repentant life?” According to this preacher, if you
would not still repent even though you had no hope of going to heaven, you
had a legalistic mindset.
      Those familiar with atheistic motivation will recognize the Kantian
philosophy lying beneath this preacher’s assessment. According to such
atheists, you should do the right thing because it is the right thing to do, not
for the personal gain that might come to oneself—such as going to heaven.
This preacher had drunk from the atheistic fountain and mistaken it for
living water. When I challenged this preacher via email to defend his
sermon, he declined. And this point was not even one of the weaknesses I
bothered to mention in that email!
      In that preacher’s assessment, godly repentance is not self-seeking.
God, on the other hand, has a completely different assessment. The Lord
promotes seeking one’s own good and that of one’s loved ones by fearing
Him: “I will give them one heart and one way, that they may fear Me
always, for their own good, and for the good of their children after them”
(Jer 32:39). Fearing God for one’s own good is good. God wants us to repent
of our sins and believe in Him for own good. When the Bible exhorts us not
to seek our own good (1Cor 10:24; 13:5), it is not saying that we are not to
seek our own good in any sense. That would make no sense. Rather, we are
to seek our own eternal good by putting the temporal needs of others before
our own temporal needs. We seek our own good by seeking the good of
others (1Cor 13:3).
      7
        Under its section “Salvation,” the Baptist Faith & Message (June,
2000) states that salvation “is offered freely to all who accept Jesus Christ as
Lord and Savior” (p. 11). These theological catchwords mean that a person
must make Jesus Lord of one’s life in terms of one’s behavior in order to
Page 350                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
receive the purportedly free gift of salvation. By making Jesus Lord of your
performance, you supposedly are entitled to salvation as a free gift. Of
course, salvation is not really a free gift if it is conditioned on your
performance. This Baptistic confession is flawed in its logistic expression of
biblically saving faith. In this same section, it compounds its error by
combining repentance with faith as a co-condition for salvation and
redefines faith as a performance-based commitment: “Repentance is a
genuine turning from sin [changing one’s negative performance] toward
God. Faith is the acceptance of Jesus Christ and commitment of the entire
personality to Him [regarding one’s positive performance] as Lord and
Savior” (p. 11). Acceptance of Jesus as Lord is defined salvifically in terms
of changing one’s positive and negative behavior.
      For sake of theological accuracy, I must point out that the Baptist Faith
& Message subtly makes repentance and faith the conditions for salvation
but not for regeneration. Instead, repentance and faith are made the results of
regeneration:

           Regeneration, or the new birth, is a work of God’s grace
      whereby believers become new creatures in Christ Jesus. It is a
      change of heart wrought by the Holy Spirit through conviction
      of sin, to which the sinner responds in repentance toward God
      and faith in the Lord Jesus” (p. 11).

      As clearly seen in the ordo salutis presented by the Baptist Faith &
Message, regeneration comes first, then repentance and faith. The Baptist
Faith & Message explicitly confirms this order by making repentance and
faith the responses of this regenerative change of heart. Repentance and faith
are made results of this regenerative new birth. Perhaps my fellow Southern
Baptists in the pew would be surprised to learn that the Baptist Faith &
Message makes regeneration the condition for saving faith and thereby
denies that saving faith is a condition for regeneration. In effect, it is placing
the chart before the horse by saying that you have to be born again in order
to believe. It is denying that you have to believe in order to be born again. It
affirms the Calvinistic ordo salutis and denies the biblical order which
makes faith the condition for regeneration. The typical Baptist in the pew
probably would be more inclined to adopt the biblical order than that of the
Baptist Faith & Message. Yet the Baptist Faith & Message is supposed to
represent what Southern Baptist believe, not what a minority of Southern
Baptist representatives want them to believe.
      The majority of Southern Baptist laity would not be alone in rejecting
the order articulated in the Baptist Faith & Message. In his book on the
subject, which was also published by Southern Baptists, Hobbs turns the
order presented in the Baptist Faith & Message on its head: “Regeneration is
the result of conviction of sin, repentance from sin, faith in Jesus Christ, and
Endnotes                                                              Page 351
the confession of that faith….This is true repentance necessary for
regeneration” (p. 60). In this restatement of the Baptist Faith & Message,
regeneration is made the result of repentance and faith. But the Baptist Faith
& Message states the opposite!
      Perhaps we can just pretend the Baptist Faith & Message is just poorly
or ambiguously worded. Be that as it may, regardless as to which seemingly
conflicting Baptistic ordo is adopted, both confessions harmonize in
conditioning salvation on changing one’s performance. Hobbs decries
“salvation by works” out of one side of his mouth, yet on the next page he
salvifically demands “repentance from sin,” and on the page after that he
redefines saving faith as committing to God’s “will and way” on the page
after that (pp. 59-61). See Herschel H. Hobbs, The Baptist Faith and
Message (Nashville: Convention Press, 1971). In summation, the Baptistic
message is: If you stop performing negatively and start performing
positively, then you can be saved freely from hell. This salvation from hell is
not really offered freely in either Baptistic confession.
      When (in the Sunday School class discussion of the Baptist Faith &
Message) our pastor remarked that he did not see how one could have Jesus
as Lord in one sense without having Him as Lord in every sense, he simply
was providing the rationale made popular in the Lordship camp that Christ
must be Lord of all or He is not Lord at all. If He is not Lord of your
behavior, then He is not your Savior. Such rhetoric has been demolished in
the Free Grace (FG) camp and shown to be logically and biblically
fallacious. For present purposes, however, it suffices to point out that a
person is saved by believing in the Lord Jesus as one’s Savior. Neither your
subjective recognition of His Lordship nor your subjective submission to His
objective Lordship is theologically necessary, but His objective Lordship is
theologically necessary. In other words, He must be Lord in order to be your
Savior, but He does not have to be Lord of your behavior in order to save
you from the penalty of sin. You can believe in Jesus for salvation, knowing
that He has the power and authority to save you from hell, without having to
trust in your performance performed on His behalf in order to save yourself.
The only way Jesus’ atoning death could have the power to save you is if He
is Lord God. And He is. But He has not conditioned your salvation from hell
on your making Him Lord of your behavior.
      While our pastor was preaching through the book of Galatians, I was
pleased with his insistence that salvation is by grace alone through faith
alone in Christ alone. In fact, on the day in which I am adding this note, after
our Sunday morning service, he made it through the entire sermon and
invitation without saying anything contrary to his affirmation that salvation
is by grace alone through faith alone in Christ alone. Disappointingly,
however, during the sermon, he did explicitly place regeneration before
faith. To be sure, he slipped it in with one, single, brief statement. The rest
of the sermon was spent urging people to flee to Christ in faith for salvation.
Page 352                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Probably, no one else in the congregation picked up on the fact that by that
statement in which he placed regeneration before faith he had nullified the
remainder of his sermon. So he slipped that statement in successfully
without arousing congregational suspicion. The laity in the pew would have
been kept in the dark by the remainder of his sermon as to the implications
of his statement.
      Despite his sermonic stress urging people to come to Christ in saving
faith, by placing regeneration before faith, he logically had denied that those
listening to his sermon had the ability to do otherwise than flee to Christ in
saving faith—if God decided to save them. Conversely, if God did not
decide to regenerate them, then they could not come to Christ. His sermon
falsely gave the impression that whether or not a person comes to saving
faith is up to the individual in Reformed theology, as if the individual
listening to his sermon could do otherwise. If logical consistency is
employed, then his presenting the invitation as if the listener could do
otherwise was a shell game, at least from the perspective of his theological
premise that regeneration precedes faith.
      With his appeals, he gave the misleading impression that whether or
not his listeners’ would be saved was up to them—as if they could do
otherwise in Reformed theology. Actually, in Reformed theology, if God
regenerates you, then you will desire to flee to Christ in saving faith, and this
desire irresistibly will cause you to flee to Christ in saving faith. You cannot
do otherwise. More fully, if God regenerates you, it will be contrary to your
pre-existing desires (since you are dead in sin and cannot desire to respond
positively to God). After God regenerates you, you cannot help but flee to
Christ in saving faith.
      While on the one hand I appreciate the fact that the bulk of our pastor’s
sermon and all his invitation were superior to his Reformed theology (this
morning at least), on the other hand I am cognizant that such an appeal could
be designed to make Reformed theology appear more palatable than it
actually is to an unsuspecting congregation. In other words, a pastor could
use such an inconsistency in order to lead his congregation into falsely
thinking that Reformed theology is logically consistent with the type of
evangelistic appeal that he is giving (in which it is implied that those
listening have a real choice and could respond to the contrary) when, in fact,
the pastor does not really believe that those listening to his sermon have a
choice to respond to the contrary. Rather than bluntly tell his congregation
that (1) if God regenerates you, then you will flee to Christ and cannot do
otherwise and (2) if God does not desire to regenerate you, then there is
nothing you can do about it, a Reformed pastor might opt instead to give the
false impression that people actually have a choice to the contrary when
listening to his message in order to lead his congregation unwittingly to
embrace his Reformed theology.
Endnotes                                                               Page 353
     Presuming that a Reformed pastor has sufficient integrity so that he
would not implement such a strategy wittingly, perhaps it might be
conjectured that he does so by embracing his irrational dialectic, thinking
that it is true mysteriously even if it cannot be true logically. As to the
dialectic nature of his appeal, it amounts to this type of Reformed invitation:

  •    If you are regenerate, you will flee to Christ and be saved.
  •    So flee to Christ and be saved.

     All the stress falls on the second part of the dialectic. The false
impression conveyed by this type of invitation is that it is up to you as to
whether or not you will be saved—as if you could do otherwise. But in
presenting this type of invitation, our pastor was leaving out the full, logical
implications of Reformed thought:

      1. If you are regenerate, you will have an irresistible desire to flee to
         Christ in saving faith.
      2. If you will have an irresistible desire to flee to Christ in saving
         faith, you will flee to Christ in saving faith and cannot do
         otherwise.
      3. Therefore, if you are regenerate, you will flee to Christ in saving
         faith and cannot do otherwise.

      Whether you will flee to Christ in saving faith is really not up to you. It
is up to God. If you are one of the elect, you cannot do otherwise than flee to
Christ in saving faith. The impression that those listening to the sermon
could do otherwise was nothing more than smoke and mirrors, an illusion, a
rocking back and forth on the Reformed rocking horse. At least it was a
break from the dialectic I typically have to endure on Sunday mornings: You
cannot get to heaven by virtue of your performance, so change your
performance so that you can go to heaven.
      As a postscript, the following Sunday while driving home from the
service, Jonathan asked me what I thought of the sermon from the first half
of Gal 5 that morning. Aside from the pastor slipping and saying that one
could lose one‘s salvation (see Gal 1:8-9; cp. Gal 5:4) and then correcting
himself midsentence with an ambiguous errant statement to the effect that
the passage meant that they (the Galatian believers evidently) would be
soteriologically without salvation, I pointed out that the stress of the sermon
was properly on the fact that salvation from soteriological damnation is a
gift apart from works, that such salvation by works never works. Yet the
pastor had nullified his own sermon, as expected, by inserting a
soteriological necessitation of good works. One way he did this was by
briefly reading Is 55:7: “Let the wicked forsake his way [change his
performance] and the evil man his thoughts. Let him turn to the Lord, and he
Page 354                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
will have mercy on him, and to our God, for he will freely pardon” (NIV).
The sermonic dialectic, then, was: If you change your performance, you will
be given free soteric pardon that is not conditioned on your changing your
performance. The irrational nature of the sermon was easy for Jonathan to
see once I summarized it for him. Unfortunately, I do not expect that others
in the congregation would be aware of the subliminal association the pastor
was trying to make with such a brief insertion followed by stress on the
freeness of the offer.
      Although the allegation of subliminal advertising of popcorn in movie
theaters may be based more on myth than fact, this is the illustration that
readily came to mind by which to explain the sermonic effect to Jonathan.
By making a quick, smooth insertion that passed far below the threshold of
consciousness for most listener’s perceptibility to the effect that free pardon
is gained by changing one’s performance and then stressing from Galatians
that it was free, free, free, the unwary listeners would be lulled into thinking
that the pastor really believes that soteric pardon is free, when the fact is that
he demonstrated that he does not logically believe that it is free since he
conditioned it on changing one’s performance. Surely, no one knew that this
is what he was doing. In fact, I myself quite possibly would not have even
noticed his performance-based interpretation if someone had not emailed me
the week before and asked me about that very verse and translation of
Is 55:7.
      Maybe the pastor was not even consciously aware of the contradiction
he was making. Still, I pointed it out to my sons. They need to be aware of
what he is doing: preaching a false gospel that leads to hell because it
logically conditions not only the reception but the retention of soteric
salvation on one’s performance. Satan knows what he is doing when he
blinds the eyes of pastors and listeners into thinking that they are responding
to a free invitation that is not truly free.
      As to the passage in Is 55:7, it is dealt with elsewhere herein. As to the
Galatian passages, Christians can commit apostasy and be subject to
misthological repercussions. Loss of salvation from eternal soteric
damnation was not the danger for the Galatian believers. The pastor was
mistaken in both his original statement (that fallen from grace ≠ lose
salvation) and in his correction (that fallen from grace ≠ to be without
salvation). See my book Fallen From Grace But Not From Perfection.
      When our pastor reached Gal 5:16-21, as expected his sermonic stress
took a nosedive into pure pseudo Lordship Salvation. This passage
concludes: “I warn you, as I did before, that those who live like this will not
inherit the kingdom of God” (NIV). The basic thrust of the pastor’s sermon
was that the way you live determines whether you will be saved from hell.
According to his sermon, the whole issue is who is in charge of your life,
who is doing do the driving. So you must commit your life to Christ to get
eternal life. Having God in charge of your life is the way you get to heaven.
Endnotes                                                             Page 355
Nothing was said about eternal life being free in this sermon. Yet in a
closing comment, he claimed that he was not teaching salvation by works
since lack of good fruit would indicate lack of regeneration. The good fruit
is reputedly present because you are saved; salvation is supposedly not a
result of salvation. The congregation bought it: hook, line, and sinker. Satan
will have little trouble reeling them into hell, unless, of course, a copy of a
book such as this one (or some other spiritual scissors) should find its way
into their hands and be allowed to cut the line.
         On the Sunday in which our pastor finished his series on Galatians, I
send this email note to my sons after service (since Jeremy comes to the later
morning service): “I think this was obvious to you. The sermon this morning
was: You are not saved by your circumcision (performance); you are saved
by your repentance (performance). [Contrary to our pastor.] This is not the
theme of Galatians. Repent/repentance is not even found in the book of

Galatians is Paul’s defense of his gospel against those who were trying to
subvert the gospel with legalism. Our pastor demonstrated his complete
failure to grasp the central message of Galatians with his closing sermon on
Galatians in which he equated the gospel with repentance. As many have
noted, but our pastor failed to notice (or at least failed to perceive the
significance of), repentance is conspicuous by its absent from Paul’s defense
of the gospel in Galatians.

      13
         Instead of acknowledging his error regarding the lack of repentance
in the Gospel of John, MacArthur seeks to justify his insistence by making
repentance implicitly requisite by appealing to characteristics that he gleans
as being necessarily descriptive of genuine believers from the Gospel of
John.

            To say that John called for a faith that excluded repentance
      is to grossly misconstrue the apostle's concept of what it means
      to be a believer. Although John never uses repent as a verb, the
      verbs he does employ are even stronger. He teaches that all true
      believers love the light (3:19), come to the light (3:20-21), obey
      the Son (3:36), practice the truth (3:21), worship in spirit and
      truth (4:23-24), honor God (5:22-24), do good deeds (5:29), eat
Page 356                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
      Jesus’ flesh and drink His blood (6:48-66), love God (8:42, cf.
      1 John 2:15), follow Jesus (10:26-28), and keep Jesus’
      commandments (14:15). Those ideas hardly concur with no-
      lordship salvation! All of them presuppose repentance,
      commitment, and a desire to obey. (Emphasis his.)

      First, note that MacArthur is less than honest when he refers to the
opposing school of thought as “no-lordship salvation.” Actually, as already
explained, Free Grace theology maintains the biblical affirmation of Christ’s
Lordship, both objectively and subjectively, and thereby affirms genuine
Lordship Salvation, not the pseudo imitation. As affirmed in Free Grace
theology, a person must submit to the Lordship of Christ to the extent of
believing in the Lord Jesus for eternal life in order to be saved from hell.
Second, by making such good performance necessarily true of the believer,
MacArthur makes it requisite for entrance into heaven. He is, in fact,
conditioning entrance into heaven on the believer’s performance and thereby
contradicting the Pauline emphasis that soteric salvation is by faith apart
from works. Third, this is a very selective list that MacArthur provides, and
it fails to consider the Johannine examples in the Gospel of John of carnal
believers who possess eternal life. Fourth, a metaphorical analysis of
synonyms for believe in the Gospel of John actually supports unconditional
security rather than MacArthur’s performance-based conditional security.
See my book Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the
Gospel of John.
      In similar vein, MacArthur seeks to appeal to a conceptual
implementation of repentance by noting that grace is incorporated
conceptually although not mentioned explicitly:

      It is true that John does not use the word repentance, but as we
      have observed elsewhere, our Lord also did not use the word
      grace. One suspects no-lordship theologians would recoil from
      any suggestion that the doctrine of grace was missing from
      Jesus' teaching. (Emphasis his.)

See John MacArthur, “Repentance in the Gospel of John.” Available at
http://www.gty.org/Resources/Articles/A238. Accessed on October, 22,
2009.
      In making such a response, MacArthur fails to provide his readership
with some very significant pertinent data. First, the Gospel of John does, in
fact, acknowledge that Jesus was characterized by grace (Jn 1:14,16-17).
Second, Jesus explicitly did include the word grace (charis) in His teaching
(Lk 6:32-34). Yet this context is referring to grace as a reward. Jesus is
referring to misthological grace. MacArthur has failed to provide any quotes
from Jesus’ lips that John could have quoted in support of soteric grace. Had
Endnotes                                                             Page 357
Jesus stressed or at least used the word charis soteriologically in the manner
being indicated by MacArthur, then perhaps one might reasonably wonder
why John did not include some such quote from Jesus in light of John’s
assessment about grace being realized in the person and ministry of Jesus.
However, if Jesus did not use the word charis in the Pauline soteric capacity
being described by MacArthur, then one can hardly fault John for not
quoting Jesus in that capacity!
      Of course, the doctrine of grace is not missing from Jesus’ teaching. So
what? A much more germane question must be considered: “Is the word
grace—used in a soteric capacity—missing from Jesus’ teaching?” To be
sure, Jesus spoke gracious words (Lk 4:22). But where are the quotes that
MacArthur expects John to have supplied (in harmony with the synoptic
gospel) that Jesus actually used the word grace in stressing the free offer of
eternal life?
      On the other hand, the Free Grace camp can demonstrate easily and
repeatedly that Jesus used the noun repentance and the verb repent in the
Synoptic Gospels. If it were John’s intention to stress a doctrine of soteric
repentance (as MacArthur imagines), then why (comparatively speaking)
does John clam up when it comes to using the words repent and
repentance—so much so as to convey the impression that he purposefully is
avoiding using the word?
      To be fair to MacArthur and not to deceive the readership by omitting
relevant data, let it be noted that Jesus does use the verbal form of grace
soterically in Lk 7:42-43, where He speaks of graciously (charizomai)
forgiving a sinful woman. Surely, MacArthur would say that even this
isolated instance (with perhaps Lk 7:21) proves that John could have quoted
this account in His gospel to undergird his statement about Jesus being a
preacher of grace. Yet such a claim would overlook that the stress in John’s
gospel is not pertaining to forgiveness but concerning the reception of
eternal life. A MacArthurian might then respond that the reason John does
not use repent/repentance is because he is dealing with reception of eternal
life rather than forgiveness. Such a response, however, would play very
nicely into the hands of those in the Free Grace community, such as Hodges,
who say that the possession of eternal life is the sole remaining issue for
entrance into heaven.
      Aside from such speculative arguments and rejoinders, MacArthurian
and Hodgian soteriology are both agreed that the doctrine of grace is
soteriologically present in the Gospel of John. Presuming agreement with
Pauline soteriology (which both camps would also claim), this concord
means that both camps are agreed that the Gospel of John is prohibitive to
making the reception of eternal life contingent upon performance.
Furthermore, both camps are agreed that repentance necessarily entails a
change in performance. The most natural conclusion, therefore, would be
that the free gift of eternal life could not be contingent upon repentance. The
Page 358                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Hodgian conclusion is in accord with this conclusion; the MacArthurian
conclusion is not.
      Any attempt to make performance exclusively the fruit of repentance
will fail for multiple reasons, not the least of which, in regard to the present
discussion at least, is that Johannine synonyms for believe (to which
MacArthur would assign repentant value) are prescriptive rather than
descriptive in relation to having eternal life and yet denote performance if
interpreted in the manner suggested by MacArthur above. Performance
becomes a MacArthurian preconversional requirement in that case.
Conversely, if MacArthur were to port repentance exclusively into
postconversional descriptions, he would be placing repentance after
conversion and thereby nullify his own premise that repentance is required
for the reception of eternal life.
      A far more satisfying thesis is that despite the wealth of synoptic
material supporting performance related repentance, John avoids using this
explicit material because he is advocating a doctrine of grace in which the
soteric possession of eternal life is not contingent—either prescriptively or
descriptively—on repentance. If his material regarding carnal believers is
also considered, then it is apparent that even implicit soteric repentance is
also implicitly refuted by Johannine soteriology.

         In the context of Mt 10:32-33, Jesus is addressing His followers as to
the importance of publicly persevering in the faith. He is speaking
specifically to “His twelve disciples” (Mt 10:1; cp. 10:5), providing them
instruction about what they are to preach about the “kingdom of heaven”
(Mt 10:7). Jesus is sending these preachers out “as sheep in the midst of
wolves” (Mt 10:16). His warnings about the reception they will encounter
reaches out prophetically to the time period of the tribulation and the need
for believers to endure to the end of the tribulation in order to be saved
misthologically (Mt 10:22) when the Son of Man returns at the conclusion of
the tribulation (Mt 10:23).
      The everyone (pas) and whoever (hostis) of Mt 10:32-33 apply
exclusively to the sheep, that is, to the regenerate preachers of the kingdom
message and to their converts, not to the wolves. Wolves in sheep’s skin,
like Judas, have no hope of entering the kingdom even though they confess
Jesus in their public preaching about Jesus. Obviously, Mt 10:32-33 should
not be misconstrued so as to be applied to Mt 7:15,22 with the resulting
conclusion that the wolves in sheep’s skin and their false converts are
promised kingdom entrance because they publicly confess Jesus as Lord.
      Despite their confessing Christ before men, these lost confessors of
Christ still will be excluded from heaven. Therefore, Jesus’ promise to
confess the confessors must be limited to believers: “Everyone (= every
believer) therefore who shall confess Me before men, I will also confess him
before My Father who is in heaven.” Likewise, His denial of the deniers
would be applicable to believers: “But whoever (= any believer who) shall
Endnotes                                                             Page 359
deny Me before men, I will also deny him before My Father who is in
heaven.”
      Everyone and whoever equals all believers in Mt 10:32-33. A relative
all (meaning all sheep) is being implemented. Believers (i.e., sheep) living
in the present time period will appear before the Lord at the Judgment Seat
of Christ in heaven. Thus, they will be judged in heaven. Believers living
through the tribulation will be judged at the commencement of the millennial
kingdom. These believing sheep will be in the kingdom of heaven also.
      The context concludes with a stress on rewards (Mt 10:41-42). Being
confessed as worthy of (ruling with) the Lord or being denied as worthy of
(ruling with) the Lord is a reward (Mt 10:37-38), not a gift. For an evangelist
to make public confession a requirement for kingdom entrance is to make
heaven a reward. It is to be a Judas to the gospel message.
      15
         It should not be assumed that if Jesus were referring to believers
standing before their Father, He would have said your Father rather than My
Father. Granted, possessive pronouns are important to Jesus: “Say to them,
“I ascend to My Father and your Father, and My God and your God’”
(Jn 20:17). Still, when Jesus is speaking of the Father dispensing rewards to
believers, He is not reticent to use My Father (Mt 20:23; 25:34) or even the
Father (Jn 12:26). Jesus does not necessarily use the term your Father or
their Father; although, it is evident that He is referring to those for whom
such designations would be applicable. Thus, the designation My Father
leaves the question open as to whether or not those being addressed have a
personal relationship with the Father. In Mt 7:21, Jesus uses My Father, not
their Father. He does not say that the lost were sent to hell because they
failed to do the will of their Father. God was never their Father (Mt 7:23).
Jesus does not use the affirmation of God’s Fatherhood lightly or universally
(Jn 8:42,44). Therefore, when the Lord says, “Love your enemies…in order
that you may be sons of your Father who is heaven” (Mt 5:44-45), He is not
telling us how to come into a saving relationship with the Father. God is
already our Father. God is already the Father of those being addressed by
this exhortation. In other words, Jesus is not saying, “Love your
enemies…in order that you may become sons of the Father.” He is not
telling us how to make God our Father. Rather, He is telling us how to be
sons of the Father we already have, how to demonstrate the relationship we
already have with our Father. In terms of relationship, the thought conveyed
by the pronoun your is that you are to be sons because you are sons, not be
sons so that you may become sons. Nevertheless, in terms of experience,
ginomai is used to state that this loving obedience is the way we become
sons. To combine the dynamic thought of the verb with the static preexisting
relationship expressed by the pronoun your, we are to love our enemies so
that we experientially may become sons of God who has already become our
Father relationally. In terms of logical and conditional combination, one
could use this expression: your Father → love ⇒ sons.
Page 360                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
         Perhaps another illustration will help. Jesus instructs us to forgive
with this warning: “If you do not forgive men, then your Father will not
forgive your transgressions” (Mt 6:15): your Father → forgive ⇒ forgiven.
The facts that (1) God is already our Father and that (2) we are already
forgiven of our sins in terms of our going to heaven are already assumed
before the question as to whether or not we forgive is broached. In fact, one
reason we are expected to forgive is because we already have been forgiven
(cp. Mt 18:21-35). We are expected to be forgiving because God is our
Father, and He is forgiving. We do not forgive in order for God to become
our Father, but we do forgive in order that we may become sons of our
Father (in terms of our behavior). This is not a contradiction because I am
using the word become in two different senses. God already has become our
Father in terms of relationship (denoted by the pronoun our in this example).
Even so, if we are to exhibit that relationship, we must imitate His behavior,
if we are to become His children in terms of our behavior. As discussed in
Drawing and Appointment, commentators refer to this Semitic idiom as
paternity by example.
