         As to Gracely’s Calminianism, he explains it in a footnote:

           God in His foreknowledge understands when a person’s
      faith in the work of Christ is of such degree that it shall
      persevere to the end. And because God has this knowledge, He
      can declare that such a person is eternally saved upon the
      instant that person truly trusts Christ. (Incidentally, this fact
      refutes the notion that we would disbelieve and lose our
      salvation in the future. God knows whose faith among men is of
      a persevering kind (i.e., belief) and consequently gives His
      Spirit only unto those who truly (irretractably) believe. Thus
      God’s bestowal of the Spirit is a seal of their salvation.)
      (Emphasis his, 131,143, n. 32. See http://www.xcalvinist.com
      /category/chapter-10/.)
Page 362                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
      This example provides an excellent contrast between Calminianism and
Marrowism. Salvation in the latter is not conditioned on the degree or
continuation of one’s faith. God foreknows who will believe and declares
that such a person is eternally saved in response to that person’s punctiliar
faith the very moment that person comes to faith in Christ. The reason God
declares such a person eternally saved in that very instant is because
soteriological salvation is conditioned only on an instance of faith! God’s
unconditional declaration is not contingent upon the person’s future
perseverance. Even so I heartily recommend Gracely’s book. Certainly, I
would recommend Norman Geisler’s Calminian writings as well.
      Lloyd Olson, another Calminian, arguing for eternal security,
regrettably thinks that MacArthur “cogently” summarizing the OSAS view:
“God did not save Christian’s apart from faith. He does not keep them
apart from faith” (p. 227). Yet Olson refutes himself when he says,
“Believers have been eternally saved (justified by faith)—period! Salvation
is always secure. Even if they don’t persevere in the faith, their salvation is
secure” (p. 101). Talk about doubletalk!
      My rebuttal of MacArthur’s suffices for a rebuttal of Olson as well.
Olson quotes from an article by MacArthur. I have provided a similar quote
from MacArthur’s book. For my quotation and interaction, see Condition,
180. For his, see Lloyd A. Olson, Eternal Security: Once Saved Always
Saved. (Mustang, OK: Tate Publishing & Enterprises, 2007).
      Despite a number of weaknesses in Olson’s book (regarding
perseverance, and equating regeneration with justification, and making
sanctification a necessary outcome of justification), I still would recommend
his book to those already well acquainted with Free Grace (FG) literature.
That is more than I can say for MacArthur’s soteriological works; although,
I do find some of his other books (such as his commentaries) useful.
      I heartily would recommend a number of writers who flirt with making
perseverance a necessity/inevitability: Willard Aldrich, Gary Derickson,
Erwin Lutzer, Gordon Olson, Richard Seymour, J.F. Strombeck, and Steven
Waterhouse. I will be eternally gratefully for contributions by Richard
Seymour. His books were the first Free Grace books I ever read, so many
years ago. Strombeck is a classic Free Grace writer.
      For a more technical interaction with such writers, see my discussion of
RFG2 and RFG3 in The Outer Darkness. For present purposes, let this
summation suffice. Calminians make perseverance necessary to reach
heaven. Marrowists do not. Between these two positions, some FG writers,
with various degrees of success (or really lack thereof) try to make
perseverance assured but not necessary. Some of the writers I heartily
recommended above might be considered FG Calminians.
      •    Calminian: believers will necessarily persevere.
      •    FG Calminian: believers will persevere.
      •    Marrowists: believers will not necessarily persevere.
Endnotes                                                            Page 363


All three groups affirm OSAS. I will concur with my fellow Marrowists
(Dillow, Hodges, Kendall [earlier writings at least], Wilkin, and JOTGES)
that apostasy is possible and that believers who commit apostasy do not lose
regeneration. In passing, apart from the exegetical problems encountered by
FG Calminians, I will mention a problem they have regarding assurance. If
you cannot be certain that you will persevere, can you be certain that you are
a genuine believer according to FG Calminianism? Logically, no.

    1. Genuine believers will persevere (so FG Calminianism).
    2. You might not persevere (so NT warnings).
    3. Therefore, you might not be a genuine believer.

     Little wonder, then, that some FG Calminians divorce faith from
assurance! The logical outcome of their system is that you would have to
believe without knowing that you are a believer! Marrowists, on the other
hand, insist that assurance is the essence of saving faith. You can know for
certain that you have eternal live without knowing for certain that you will
persevere. Marrowism should not be confused with Calminianism.

             Christians with the gift of proclamation may frequently

      (i.e., included here would presumably be things that at first

      perception), so that their warnings have a greater sense of
      urgency.…This is because the proclaimer senses an immediacy
      about some divine warning to the church and understands that
      God is warning the Body against some disastrous course or
      doctrinal disease.…Most prophets would be lousy pastors
      because their often blunt and serious approach can leave people
      feeling they are impatient and unsympathetic. (Emphasis his.)

pastor. In some ways, the pragmatic effects of the gift of prophecy might
even be regarded as the curse of prophecy. God’s people have a history of
killing the prophets sent to them (Mt 23:37). Today, the church just
marginalizes the prophets sent to her as the preferred means (although not
only means) of silencing them. Gracely, 126-134. See “The Church: Equal

      45
          Technically, Jesus could lose eternal life to a certain extent.
Certainly, He could not lose eternal life in the sense of losing an attribute
that is essential to His existence as God. Nor could He lose His relationship
with His Father and cease to be the Son of God. On the other hand, He could
experience a break in fellowship with the Father that was so painful He cried
out: “My God, My God, why hast Thou forsaken Me?” (Mt 27:46) As I
explain elsewhere in more detail, Jesus lost eternal life qualitatively in that
experience on the cross. Even so, His loss of eternal life could not drop
below the qualitative threshold (and neither can ours). Since spiritual death
Endnotes                                                             Page 365
is defined as separation from God, one might even say that Jesus
experienced spiritual death on the cross. Nonetheless, not even in that
experience could He experience the complete death of eternal life. His static
possession of eternal life remained intact. He could give up His dynamic
personal exercise of that attribute but not His static possession of such an
attribute.

         Like Lewis, MacArthur also uses the same appeal to grace-enabled
works as being necessary to reach heaven. Arminians and Calvinistic’s join
hands in basing their entrance into heaven on graced-enabled works.
MacArthur claims that since these works are grace-enabled they are not
meritorious. MacArthur, Gospel, 232. The MacArthurian version of this
Arminian argument is susceptible to the same weakness: Heavenly rewards
are based on grace-enabled-works; therefore, grace-enabled works are still
meritorious works.
      47
         MacArthur correctly identifies the broad gate as human performance:
“The only choice is between the plethora of religions based on human
achievement and the one religion of divine accomplishment” (Gospel, 204).
“These are religious people who have chosen the road of human
achievement” (p. 212). The religious people in view in this context are
professing Christians (Mt 7:22). Therefore, the religious people being
described are professing Christians, and the broad gate is that of Christian
performance. By advocating Christian works (i.e., divinely-enabled works)
as the means of entering heaven, MacArthur has chosen the broad gate that
leads to destruction. Contrary to MacArthur, the broad gate is not (in all
aspects) the “easy way” (p. 205). The broad gate is the hard gate of human
performance. Correspondingly, it takes little effort to enter the broad gate
but a lot of effort to travel the broad path because it is performance based.
Conversely, it takes tremendous effort to find the narrow gate and no effort
to travel the narrow way that results in eternal life because it takes a lot of
effort on the part of those who have a performance-based mentality to come
to the correct conclusion that the narrow way that results in the free gift of
eternal life is not performance based.
      48
          Another argument used by those attempting to make works a
requirement to reach heaven is to claim that we are not saved by works of
the law but by works of faith (so Duty, 31). Balderdash! Such fiddle-faddle
fails to recognize, among other things, that when Paul is refuting the Jewish
means of merit in Romans and Galatians, it is understandable that Paul
would specify that a person cannot be saved by works of the law since these
were the type of works through which those under Jewish influence were
seeking justification. But when talking to Gentiles, without focusing on
Judaizers (where there is no need for that specification), Paul rejects works
in total from consideration. Granted, although the expression works of the
law may be limited to Romans and Galatians in the Pauline corpus, the
concept is not entirely absent elsewhere in his writings. For example, false
Page 366                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
circumcision in Phil 3:2 and righteousness derived from the law in Phil 3:9
likewise refer to the same type of legalistic moral performance. Still, in
excluding works as the means to justification, Paul does not limit such works
conceptually to works of the law. The rejection of works is used more
comprehensively in several passages: Eph 2:8-9; 2Tim 1:9, and Tit 3:5.
Moral performance of any kind is rejected soteriologically, not just legal
obedience performed in obedience to the law.
     Moreover, even in the epistle of Romans, Paul bases condemnation on
more than just the Jewish works of the law written on paper. Like Lewis,
Paul also bases our condemnation on our failure to keep the internal law
written in our hearts (Rom 2:15). Paul concludes “that both Jews and Greeks
are all under sin” (Rom 3:9). So when Paul goes on to say a few verses later
that we are justified by faith apart from works of the Law (Rom 3:28), he is
to be understood as denouncing justification by Jewish or Gentile works
stemming from either external or internal law keeping. All works are
denounced as a means of justification (in a justification that is by faith apart
from works). Additionally, the principle exemplified by Abraham in
Rom 4:5-6 (which excludes soteriological justification by works) temporally
predates the giving of the external law. And the affirmation of no longer in
Rom 11:6 logically postdates the giving of the Christian law. In conclusion,
we are not justified from eternal damnation by Jewish, Gentile, or Christian
works.
     49
        In synergism, God provides the energization via spiritual stimulation
by which believers are encouraged to do God’s will. Through God’s
enabling grace, God works synergistically in cooperation with the free will
of believers in making it possible for believers to perform goods works, such
as persevering in faith. While it is true that God, likewise, cooperatively
works together with the free will of the lost in enabling them to come to
saving faith, it must be remembered that saving faith is not a work. The
synergistic activities through which a person comes to saving faith are only
synergistic preconditions to saving faith. Since saving faith is the singular
condition for regeneration and since saving faith is not a work, regeneration
is exclusively the work of God and is not based on human work.
Regeneration is produced monergistically by God independently of any
cooperative work performed by man. Saving faith is only a condition (not
cause) for regeneration. God’s working in cooperation with a believer’s free
response of faith to save the believer at the point of regeneration is not a
synergistic activity since the believer is not contributing any work at the
point of regeneration but is only responding with a passive punctiliar
persuasion. Regeneration is not a result of synergism. Although synergism
presupposes libertarian freedom (in that God performs regeneration in
cooperation with the believer’s free response of saving faith), synergism
should not be confused with libertarianism so as to consider regeneration a
synergistic result because saving faith is not a work.
Endnotes                                                               Page 367
      Olson provides this definition: “Synergism is any theological belief in
free human participation in salvation” (p. 17). See Roger E. Olson,
Arminian Theology: Myths and Realities (Downers Grove: InterVarsity
Press, 2006). This simplistic definition might be abused by those who do not
read his full discussion. As Olson defines synergism, one might think that
Arminians believe that regeneration is a synergistic result because it is
conditioned on free human participation. Not so! Such an assessment would
do an injustice to his discussion, in particular, and to Arminians, in general.
Libertarianism cannot be equated with synergism. Synergism requires
libertarianism, but synergism is more than free human participation. My
tautological definition supplies the necessary clarification: Synergism means
to work together cooperatively with someone else to produce something that
is a result of mutual work. Naturally, to work together cooperatively with
someone else to produce something means that what is produced is a result
of mutual work. I should not have to spell out the logical implication in the
second half of the definition, but doing so is necessary because some
Calvinistic critics falsely equate libertarianism with synergism so as to give
the misleading impression that libertarianism teaches that regeneration is
produced by synergistic works.
      To set the record straight, Arminians acknowledge that regeneration
necessitates a free human participation in the form of saving faith but insist
that this free human participation does not produce a synergy. Forlines
competently refers to the Arminian viewpoint as conditional monergism (p.
235). Justification and regeneration, the immediate benefits of saving faith,
are produced monergistically by God on the condition of saving faith—
which is a cooperative passive response made possible through divine
enablement (p. 160). Such a view of saving faith realistically is shared by
Calvinism so that saving faith is a synergistic result within Calvinism as well
(pp. 259-260).
      Similarly, in Free Grace theology, saving faith is the punctiliar passive
persuasion that one has eternal life in Christ as a result of believing in Christ
for unconditional security. This punctiliar passive persuasion is not a work;
although, it may come as a result of work (in the form of libertarian
synergism by prevenient grace). Therefore, the saving faith that passively is
contributed by the free human participation at the point of regeneration is
not a work. Regeneration cannot possibly be a synergistic result.

  •   Synergistic result: God’s work + cooperative human work.
  •   Regenerative result: cooperative human non-work + God’s work.

     Since regeneration is conditioned on faith apart from works,
regeneration cannot be a synergistic result. Libertarians are being falsely
accused of teaching salvation by works just because they condition salvation
on libertarian faith. Saving faith is not a work! Arminians are being unjustly
Page 368                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
accused by Calvinists as teaching salvation by works just because Arminians
believe that faith is a synergistic result. Calvinist need to be more honest
about the Libertarian sequence:

  •   Synergistic Preparation → Faith → Monergistic Regeneration
  •   Synergistic Precondition → Condition → Monergistic Result

      To repeat, although faith make come as a result of preconditional
works, faith itself is not a work. Regeneration is conditioned on faith alone,
not on the works that may have gone into producing that faith. Regeneration
is not a result of works.
      Arminians would point out that they also implement further safeguards
to prevent regeneration from being considered the result of work since many
of them consider saving faith (1) to be a gift (2) that is passively produced
by the convert (who merely does not resist God’s prevenient grace) and
(3) proceeded by the initial stage of regeneration. One may consult Olson’s
discussion.
      These additional safeguards are unnecessary, however. As to the first
precaution, the actual reception of the gift of life need not be a gift in order
for the gift to be a gift. Receiving a gift is not a work. Therefore, saving faith
need not be considered a gift in order for the gift received by faith to be
considered a gift. An immaculate reception is no more necessary than an
immaculate conception. The reception of a gift does not need to be called a
gift in order to prevent the gift from being tainted as a work. Second,
although God is actively at work in producing our saving faith, we do not
have to be pictured as passively summiting at the preconditional stage so
that He is doing all the active work. Actively listening to the gospel or
actively reading a gospel tract does not mean that the passive result of saving
faith is not actively produced by the convert in cooperation with God’s
activity. Third, Forlines (p. 235) and Picirilli (pp. 159-160) are to be
commended for not placing regeneration before faith. Olson and the
Arminians he documents unnecessarily treat “prevenient grace as
regenerative” (pp. 158-178), thus placing a prevenient form of regeneration
before faith. I object. Universal atonement need not mean universal
regeneration.
      Many Arminians correctly limit prevenient grace to the gospel call.
Even so, including the initial stage of regeneration in prevenient grace would
have horrific results unless this first phase of Arminian regeneration was
carefully distinguished from the first phase of Calvinistic regeneration. As it
is, without this carefully delineation, Arminianism gives the impression that
prevenient regeneration results in a still birth rather than new birth for all
those who reject the gospel—a miscarriage of prevenient grace. If one had to
choose between Calvinistic irresistible grace and Arminian abortion, then
one would have to adopt the Calvinistic option as the lesser of two evils.
Endnotes                                                            Page 369
      Fortunately, Forlines and Picirilli already have been provided the exits
from this conclusion. An alternative readily exists: Adopt the classical
definition of prevenient grace but do not mislabel it as regeneration. On the
other hand, some will object that adopting the Arminian definition of
prevenient grace but not embracing the label of regeneration (applied to it by
some Arminians) does not insulate one from the libel of playing a semantic
word game. As demonstrated in Ordo Salutis, the label of prevenient
regeneration may be adopted (from a combined libertarian-trichotomous
perspective) without doing violence to regeneration.
      Defending a correctly enunciated Arminian libertarianism as not
resulting in synergistic regeneration is not equatable with acquitting
Arminianism of teaching synergistic regeneration, however. Arminianism
still defects from salvation by grace through faith alone in that it makes
repentance (regarding one’s intended performance) a condition for initial
justification and perseverance (regarding one’s actual performance) a
condition for final justification. The logical result is that in the Arminian
scheme regeneration is gained by one’s intention to perform better and kept
by one’s follow-through of that performance In both Arminianism and
Calvinism, entrance into heaven ends up being conditioned on synergistic
performance. That both systems teach that repentance and perseverance are
made possible by God’s enabling grace does not detract from the fact that in
both systems, regeneration is kept by human performance. Rewards earned
through God’s enabling grace are still earned rewards. The logical outcome
of both systems is that heaven is made an earned reward since entering
heaven is conditioned on persevering through God’s enabling assistance.
         Lordship Salvation, whether it is of the Arminian or Calvinistic
persuasion, necessarily teaches synergistic salvation since it makes salvation
conditioned on the intent to work initially and on the production of works
subsequently. Even the intent to work is work (Heb 4:12). To make salvation
contingent upon one’s willingness to change one’s performance is to make
salvation contingent upon one’s performance. Pseudo Lordship Salvationists
only add insult to injury when they make synergistic follow through
soteriologically necessary. Only Free Grace theology is free from the curse
of soteriological works-righteousness. In Free Grace theology, regeneration
is not synergistically produced by the intent to work or synergistically
preserved through perseverance in work. Only Free Grace theology teaches a
truly monergistic regeneration.
      50
          Some would make an artificial distinction between help and helper
so as to suggest that God helps us but cannot rightly be called our Helper.
The Scripture, however, while frequently describing God as helping us, does
not object to describing God as our Helper: “Thou hast been the helper of
the orphan” (Ps 10:14). “O Lord, be my helper” (Ps 30:10). “God is my
helper” (Ps 54:4). “The Lord is my helper” (Heb 13:6). Jesus calls the Holy
Spirit “another Helper” like Himself (Jn 14:16) and repeatedly refers to the
Page 370                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Spirit as our Helper (Jn 14:26; 15:26; 16:27). We are not passive puppets
being moved by God’s sovereign strings. Benjamin Franklin was correct to
conclude in his Poor Richard’s Almanac that in many aspects: “God helps
those who help themselves.”
     Sometimes it is true that God also helps the helpless (Is 25:4) who
cannot help themselves. Salvation from eternal damnation falls into this
category. God does all the work. In many cases, however, God helps us by
enabling us to help ourselves. For example, if we want God to help us find a
job, we cannot expect Him to fill out the job application for us. We are
expected to put feet to our prayers and a hand to the pen, not to expect Him
to do everything for us. Perseverance falls into this category. By confusing
these categories and by making perseverance a necessity for final salvation
from eternal damnation, Calvinists unthinkingly wind up teaching: “God
saves those who save themselves.”
     The Psalmist says of God, “You are my helper and my deliverer!”
(Ps 40:17; NET). Deliverer is also translatable as Defender and Savior.
Sometimes Christians are enjoined to be “ready to make a defense”
(1Pet 3:15). Developing one’s skills in Christian apologetics requires work.
Not working at being ready to make a defense and expecting God to do all
our work for us would be wrong. Likewise, sometimes the Bible enjoins
God’s people to save themselves (Jer 48:6; 51:45). Temporal and
misthological salvation indeed can involve our effort. The problem is that by
importing perseverance into what is necessary for salvation from hell,
conditionalists are making this type of salvation a God-saves-those-who-
save-themselves salvation. Logically, in conditionalism, God is no longer
pictured as saving a drowning man but a swimming man. If you swim to
God’s boat, He will pull you in and save you. But you have to swim
(persevere) until you reach that boat.
     A better picture of what is entailed in soteric salvation is provided by
the occasion when Peter, beginning to sink in the sea, “cried out, saying,
‘Lord, save me!’ And immediately Jesus stretched out His hand and took
hold of him, and said to him, ‘O you of little faith, why did you doubt?’
And when they got into the boat, the wind stopped’” (Mt 14:30-32). Peter
was not saved by swimming to the boat or by his grip on his faith or by his
grip on Jesus but by Jesus’ grip on him. That grip took Peter all the way to
the boat. This physical grip is reminiscent of Jesus’ soteriological grip: “I
give eternal life to them, and they shall never perish; and no one shall snatch
them out of My hand” (Jn 10:28). When it comes to getting into the boat that
takes us to heaven, Jesus does not save those who save themselves but those
who call upon Him to save them because they realize that they are helpless
to save themselves.

         Nevertheless, Lewis does express positive remarks concerning
rewards in some of his other writings.
Endnotes                                                                Page 371
     52
        MacArthur quotes and commends this song as well. John MacArthur,
Hard to Believe: The High Cost and Infinite Value of Following Jesus
(Nashville: Nelson Books, 2003), 86. As is apparent from his discussion,
however, MacArthur does not come to the cross empty handed. His
understanding of Lk 9:23 is that in order to “come after Jesus into the
kingdom of God—anyone who wants to be a Christian—has to face three
commands: 1) deny himself, 2) take up his cross daily, and 3) follow him”
(p. 6). Clearly, despite his denials elsewhere, MacArthur is conditioning
entrance into heaven on one’s daily performance: If anyone wants to enter
into heaven, he has to meet these performance requirements on a daily basis.
MacArthur does not believe anyone can reach heaven empty handed apart
from grasping his or her own cross. In his Gospel, MacArthur continues this
theme, affirming Macaulay’s statement: “Entering the kingdom of heaven is
costly business….it costs to enter the kingdom” (p. 145, n. 4). “What Jesus
meant when He spoke of taking up one’s cross….is…that we count the cost
carefully. He was calling for an exchange of all that we are for all that He is”
(p. 149).
               Illustration 139. MacArthurian Cross Exchange




       MacArthur objects that those of us who think that he is importing
performance (via his views on repentance) as an intrusion into salvation by
grace alone “fail to comprehend the doctrine of substitution and
imputation….that we contribute nothing to our salvation but lay hold of
eternal life by faith in that substitute” (Hard, 188). Actually, we comprehend
the doctrine of substitution and imputation well enough to realize that we in
the Free Grace camp are the ones who actually believe that we contribute
nothing to our salvation but lay hold of eternal life by faith in that substitute.
Also, we can see the matter well enough to recognize that MacArthur does
not believe his own affirmation since he believes that he must contribute his
own cross-bearing and have works in addition to faith in order to avail
himself of the saving sufficiency of that substitution.
       MacArthur correctly notes that the righteousness necessary to “enter
the kingdom of heaven….is the genuine, perfect righteousness of Christ that
is imputed to each believer” in Mt 5:20 but mistakenly claims, on the basis
of Mt 7:21, that “if you do not live a genuinely righteous life” you will not
“enter the kingdom” (Hard, 95, 122-123). Within the space of a single
sermon, MacArthur pictures Jesus as preaching that entrance is based on
Page 372                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
imputed righteousness (which would be independent of human performance)
and that this entrance necessitates a righteous life (which would be
dependent on human performance). By making practical righteousness a
necessity to enter heaven, MacArthur has made it logically impossible to
enter heaven without contributing to that entrance by the way one lives.
MacArthur has nullified faith in the substitutional atonement as a sufficient
means of entering heaven. In doing so, he brings an indictment against
himself since he acknowledges that the purpose of Jesus’ sermon is to bring
an “indictment against the self-righteous legalism and works salvation
system of the Pharisees” who, as noted in Lk 18:9, “trusted in themselves
that they were righteous” (Hard, 74-75,78).
       MacArthur correctly notes that Protestants “and all people who
believe they can earn salvation” are “all going to eternal hell” (Hard, 33),
but he fails to provide a logical rationale as to why he should not be included
in that number. Perhaps he intends to acquit himself of the charge of trying
to earn heaven by only discrediting the meritorious nature of independent
human effort and by allowing that Christian works done though the power of
the Holy Spirit do not disqualify one as trusting in works. This seems to be
the backbone of this defense since he claims that his method of salvation “is
not salvation by good works but the very opposite: salvation by rejecting all
hope of pleasing God on our own” (Hard, 10). Apparently, he intends to
insinuate that pleasing God with God’s help would be soteriologically
permissible. After all, he insists, “someone might say this sounds like the
religion of human achievement. Not so….His power becomes your
resource” (Hard, 85). Thus, availing ourselves of God’s power as a resource
to perform good works appears to be MacArthur's means of pleasing God
soteriologically.
       This proposal will not suffice, however, because MacArthur correctly
acknowledges that the “lie of human achievement” says, “We have some
sort of hand in saving ourselves.” This lie of human achievement proposes
that we can “just let God give us a little religious environment to aid our
natural goodness, dispense a little power to us, or infuse a little strength
into us” (Hard, 78-79). Accepting God’s external or internal aid as a means
to please God is still a vain attempt to please God by human achievement
according to MacArthur. So even a Protestant environment (in which one
draws upon the power of the Holy Spirit to live a righteous life) still would
not provide a suitable means for trying to add works as a soteriological
necessity. By MacArthur’s own admission, such recourse would still amount
to the lie of salvation by human achievement. MacArthur cannot appeal to
Protestant works enabled by the Spirit as a means of entering the kingdom
without condemning himself as a Protestant Pharisee.
       Overall, it is a fair assessment of MacArthurian soteriology to accept
his own understanding of Mt 13:44-46 as descriptive of what he really
believes about salvation. You must “buy it. The complete surrender of all
Endnotes                                                             Page 373
possession is the essence of salvation” (Hard, 16). So much for salvation
from hell being a free gift! “Salvation for sinners cost God His own Son; it
cost God’s Son His life, and it’ll cost you the same thing” (Hard, 93). “You
pay the price”; otherwise, if you forsake Christ, you will receive eternal
damnation because of your apostasy (Hard, 136). If you want salvation from
hell, buy it. If you want to enter heaven, then buy that entrance.
       According to MacArthur, the treasure that you are trying to buy in
these parables, by selling all you have, is entrance into heaven. What is hard
to believe, but nevertheless true, is that MacArthur has pictured Jesus as
practically selling tickets to enter heaven—such is the gospel according to
MacArthur.
                  Illustration 140. MacArthurian Turnstile




       Undoubtedly, realizing that he will be charged with selling tickets to
the turnstile of the narrow gate that leads to heaven, MacArthur switches
over to speaking out of the other side of his mouth, acknowledging that
salvation is a free gift that cannot be bought since it already has been bought
by the Lord (p. 148). He tries to pass off his contradiction as a paradox:
“There is nothing left to pay, no possibility that our works can be
meritorious. But that does not mean there is no cost in terms of salvation’s
impact on the sinner’s life. Do not throw away this paradox just because it is
difficult. Salvation is both free and costly” (p. 149). For the moment, we can
ignore the inconsistency this poses with his statements elsewhere (e.g. in his
treatment of Lk 14:26-28 and in his definition of saving faith) when he says
that saving faith and salvation are initially costly. Coming to Christ and
coming after Christ are jointly costly in his book. See Illustration 118. False
Page 374                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
Teachers in Mt 7:16-20 (p. 299) and endnote 224. Regardless of his
contradictory statements concerning the freeness of the reception of the gift
in other places, when discussing the narrow gate, he states: “Entering that
door to God’s kingdom takes conscious, purposeful, and intense effort”
(Matthew, 455). Whose effort? Yours. He continues: “It is for those who
want the kingdom at any cost, and who sell all they have to buy that great
treasure [reward] and that great pearl (Matt. 13:44-46).” Who pays the cost?
You do. Who eventually winds up buying their way into this MacArthurian
heaven? You do. Something is left for you to pay; your works to enter this
heaven consequently are meritorious. MacArthur has left no possibility of
logical consistency in his argument. Even if the MacArthurian gift were free
initially (which it is not), it is not free subsequently.
      53
          I. Howard Marshall, Kept by the Power of God: A Study of
Perseverance and Falling Away, digital edition (Paternoster Digital Library,
2005), 61. In support, Marshall (229, n. 42) uses op. cit. to reference pp. 24-
34 from Joachim Jeremias. Presuming Marshall’s citation refers back to his
previous reference to Jeremias (which was 227, n. 20), Marshall would be
deferring to Joachim Jeremias, New Testament Theology, vol. 1, The
Proclamation of Jesus, trans. John Bowden (London: SCM Press, 1971). But
if this is the case, then the page range Marshall provides has nothing to
commend his assertion, which is that salvation by Christian works is not
salvation by works—as nonsensical as that would be. Still, if one were to
consult Jeremias’ discussion on pp. 119, 147-151, 156-157, 215-218, one
would, indeed, find arguments by Jeremias on these pages which could,
indeed, be used to support Marshall’s contention that the NT ethic of grace
is considered a nonmeritorious “response to the grace of the kingdom”
(Marshall, 61). But even though Jeremias’ arguments are more involved than
Marshall’s summary statement would indicate, they still fall woefully short
of proving that Jesus intends for us to attain ethical entrance into the
kingdom through God’s enabling grace.
      Perhaps Marshall means to defer to Jeremias’ The Parables of Jesus
(see Marshall, 227, n. 15). If so, the page range he suggests is still ill
advised. Granted, Marshal is referring to the 1963 edition of Jeremias’
treatment; whereas, the present author is consulting the 1972 edition, so
perhaps this might explain the discrepancy. See Joachim Jeremias, The
Parables of Jesus, Revised Third Edition (London: SCM Press, 1972). But
even so, Jeremias’ expanded 1972 edition fails to be persuasive for those
who accept the biblical evidence at face value as provided by the NT writers
rather than try to deface it with a literary criticism that picks and chooses
what parts of the NT writings to accept at face value. Marshall will have to
do better than cite a liberal scholar who makes inconsistent arguments in
order to substantiate his claim that salvation by Christian works is not an
accursed gospel of works-righteousness.
Endnotes                                                             Page 375
     This criticism notwithstanding, if one digs long enough, one will
eventually hit gold. No doubt, Marshall means to refer to Joachim Jeremias,
The Sermon on the Mount, Biblical Series — 2, gen. ed. John Reumann,
trans. Norman Perrin (Fortress Press, 1963). Here, Marshall’s page range
finds a perfect match. More importantly, the positive aspects of his
summation find splendid demonstration. Marshall’s summation (p. 69) is:

             Nothing in what has just been said should be taken to
        imply that fulfillment of the ethic of Jesus is to be taken as
        a condition for entry into the kingdom in the sense that
        men must show themselves worthy of the kingdom or work
        for a place in it….We owe to J. Jeremias the extremely
        important insight that the ethic is preceded by the Gospel. It
        is an ethic of grace and consequently can be fulfilled only
        by disciples who have responded to the gracious offer of
        Jesus.

      Splendid! If Marshall had just stopped there, all would have been fine
and well. Unfortunately, however, by the time one reaches the end of
Marshall’s next paragraph, one finds him coming to the opposite conclusion:
“Perseverance in this life is the way of entry into the future kingdom” (p.
69). To be sure, an astute theologian like Marshall would retort that he has
not contradicted himself since, in his first reference to entry into the
kingdom, he left out the word future. Present entry into the kingdom, it could
be claimed, is by faith apart from works, but future entry is by grace-enabled
works. I take issue with any such attempt to justify a works-righteousness
approach to future entry into the kingdom. On the other hand, it might be
objected by some that Marshall has misrepresented Jeremias in that Jeremias
does not proceed to this works-based entrance in The Sermon on the Mount.
I conversely would take issue with those trying to discredit Marshall’s
summation of Jeremias’ theology. My above citations from Jeremias’ other
works were not a wild goose chase but confirm that Marshall faithfully has
represented Jeremias’ soteriology with this works-based mentality.
      Nevertheless, despite their mutually mistaken works-righteousness
perspective, one truly does strike theological pay dirt if one stops with the
first part of Marshall’s assessment, which is the outcome to which Jeremias
also limits himself in The Sermon on the Mount. Moreover, by adopting a
more conservative form-critical-perspective, I am able to frame Marshall’s
summation of Jeremias’ positive contribution in a manner that is
representative of Free Grace theology with the following proposition: The
Synoptic Gospels were written primarily for the purpose of discipleship. As
such, the presumption within those gospel accounts leans strongly toward
the disposition that the readers of those gospels already knew the gospel of
grace. The Sermon on the Mount, for example, is not chiefly concerned with
Page 376                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
evangelism. It presupposes that those listening to the message already have
responded to the soteric message of the gospel and now need mistholic
instruction. In other words, Matthew’s rendition of the Sermon on the Mount
takes for granted that those reading it already have received the free gift of
eternal life (as described by the Gospel of John) and have been assured of
kingdom entrance. What they need is instruction pertaining to kingdom
rewards.
      As Jeremias notes, Jesus exhorts in this sermon: “You are light.…Let
your light shine” (Mt 5:14-16). Obviously, Jesus is not talking to
unbelievers. He is not telling unbelievers how to become light. Rather, the
Lord is instructing those who have already become light—through believing
in Him (cp. Jn 12:36)—regarding how they can radiate that life. When the
Lord exhorts us to forgive in order to be forgiven filially (Mt 6:14-15), He
presumes that we already have been forgiven judicially, as evidenced by the
fact that God is now addressed properly as our Father. When Jesus exhorts
us to enter by the narrow gate, Matthew does not go into detail within this
abbreviated from of Jesus’ sermon as to how one enters the narrow gate. Nor
should Matthew be expected to do so. Oral familiarity on his readers’ part
with the narrow gate soteriology, as recorded in Jn 10:9 and 14:6, may be
presumed. The sermonic concern in Mt 7:13-23 is not focused so much on
clarifying how one enters the gate or even with identifying the narrow gate
but with indentifying the wolves in sheep’s clothing and warning those of us
who already have entered by the narrow gate as to the soteric fate of the
wolves and the disastrous mistholic impact (Mt 7:24-27) their ravenous
teaching will have on our lives if we believers allow these false teachers to
detract us from building our lives on Christ.

         I am using congruency as denoting consistency as opposed to
equivalency. My example of congruent merit is more closely related to
Endnotes                                                           Page 377
typical illustrations of pactum merit in which a father makes a pact with his
son that if his son aces the SAT or makes all A’s in high school, he will buy
his son a new car. However, I would rather modify the term congruent merit
than implement the term pactum merit because the latter may be rejected as
an oxymoronic non-meritorious merit. Christ did make a pact with His sheep
in Mt 24:13-14), but this pact does not exclude genuine meritorious
performance on the part of his sheep. Although the car dealer may not regard
the father’s son as having done anything to merit the car by doing so well in
his studies, the father may very well regard the matter differently. Hence
when the father tells his son, “Well done,” and gives his son the promised
reward, neither he nor his son may regard the car as a gift. The reward is
consistent with the promise but disproportional to the amount of work that
went into earning it.

          Defending bridal misthology is beyond the scope of the present
work. The Outer Darkness may be consulted for such a defense. I will
present only a most rudimentary argument and harmonization herein for the
sake of the astute reader who may have noted that it seems to fly in the face
of my bank-account analogy. First, a basic defense would be:

     1. Only faithfully believers will co-rule with Christ.
     2. Christ’s Bride will co-rule with Christ.
     3. Therefore, only faithful believers compose the Bride of Christ.

      As to a harmonization, note that in the Cinderella story, she is not an
ugly witch. She is perceived as a beautiful, chaste, virtuous, hardworking,
Page 378                              Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

virtues that she becomes his wife and monarchal consort. (Some have even

Christian teaching that virtue reaps rewards in heaven. Christians who want
a fairytale ending cannot afford to be any less morally virtuous.) I simply

imputation of Christ’s righteousness. If one wants an analogy that
corresponds more closely to the point Edwards’ is trying to make without
transgressing into bridal misthology, then the example of Annie may be
consulted.

          Both initial faith and perseverance in faith are acts of obedience.
More is necessary to determining if something is virtuous than simply
determining if it is an act of obedience. If I were to say that we are saved by
virtue of our faith, what I mean by that statement would be determined by
the type of salvation to which I was referring. If it is soteriological, then I
would simply mean because of our faith, not by any virtue in our faith. Our
faith, in this case, merely taps into the alien virtue of Christ. Alternatively, if
I am talking about misthological salvation, then being saved by virtue of our
faith means being saved by the derivative inherent virtue in our faith.

          Edwards seems to struggle with regarding faith as an instrument in
the hand of the Calvinistic God by which God justifies the believer versus an
instrument in the hand of the Arminian sinner by which the believer receives
Christ and consequently receives justification. Apparently, Edwards leans
toward the former in seeing faith as an instrument in God’s hand by which
God apprehends the sinner: “God justifies a believer…because he sees
something in this qualification that…renders it a fit thing…whether it be
because faith is the instrument, or as it were the hand, by which he that has
purchased justification is apprehended and accepted” Edwards, Meaning:
How Is It by Faith Alone? Still, even if it were the latter and the sinner’s
hand is perceived to be the instrument, it would make little difference since,
according to Logan’s assessment of Edwards’ compatibilism, God
irresistibly causes the sinner to stretch out his own hand.

      118
           Ibid., 47. Bell and Kendall are in agreement that the antinomian
controversy was basically over the doctrine of assurance. Antinomians,
historically speaking, are those who base their assurance on God’s word
rather than their works. Viewed from this perspective, according to both Bell
and Kendall, Calvin was an antinomian. Even though Bell and Kendall are
in substantial agreement with their overall analysis, they do manifest a
difference of opinion regarding the role of emotions. According to Kendall,
“Calvin warns against looking to one’s feelings in any case. Indeed, the one
thing above all else which Calvin emphasizes is that we must never look to
ourselves for assurance” (p. 24). Bell, on the other hand, insists that saving
faith for Calvin necessarily includes an emotional affection for Christ so that
we feel saved (pp. 20-22). M. Charles Bell, Calvin and Scottish Theology:
The Doctrine of Assurance (Edinburgh: The Handsel Press, 1985). Kendall,
169.
      Regardless of Calvin’s feelings about the role of feelings, Kendall is
correct to base assurance exclusively on the word independent of our
feelings. For that matter, Bell finds John Campbell to be Calvin’s true
successor since Campbell “refuses to ground the knowledge and certainty of
faith in anything other than the revelation of God” (p. 188). Yet if the
assessment of Campbell that Bell has provided is correct, then Bell’s opinion
regarding Calvin is called into question since Bell’s assessment of Campbell
seems to preclude assigning any saving role to a believer’s emotions. If
Calvin did interject the believer’s emotions into the composition of saving
faith, then Campbell has not only proven himself to be Calvin’s successor
but also Calvin’s superior since Campbell, as acknowledged by Bell’s own
summation, believes that assurance comes from “contemplating the mind
and feelings of God toward us as revealed fully in the mind and feelings of
Christ” (p. 191). Our salvation is based on how God feels about us, not on
how we feel about God or ourselves. God’s feelings, not ours, are the sole
soteriological concern. The Lord’s feelings about us are expressed in
Jn 3:16. He loved us enough to die for us. Our assurance is anchored on the
bedrock of God’s love for us, not on our fickle love for God.
Endnotes                                                              Page 381
      According to Bell, Campbell was Calvin’s superior regarding election:
“Campbell succeeded here where Calvin has failed, for Calvin created
problems for his doctrine of God, and for assurance, by insisting upon a
hidden, secret will in God. Campbell, on the other hand, insisted that God’s
will for us is fully revealed to everyone in Jesus Christ” (p. 203, n. 3). God
loves everyone, even the nonelect, but God only justifies the elect. The way
you can know you are one of the elect is to believe in Christ. If you believe
in Christ, then you are justified in Christ and hence may know that you are
elected in Christ. Such simplicity is superior to Calvin’s complexity. It
would appear that Campbell is superior to Calvin regarding both election
and emotions.

          Anderson provides the theological context in which the Protestant

         Ibid., 30. Hodges is criticized falsely by MacArthur as advocating
fleshly merit. Still, to MacArthur’s credit, he at least realizes that Hodges is
advocating misthological merit. Yes, merit. The present author has
encountered those who, like MacArthur, are opposed to the idea of merit and
yet who do the exact opposite of MacArthur and twist Hodges’ words to
purport that Hodges does not believe in misthological merit! One poster at
the GES chat site, who was trying to reject the present author’s defense of
misthological merit, cited Hodges in support of the poster’s claim that
Page 382                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
rewards are not based on merit. The poster used this quote from Hodges and
inserted these ellipses in order to do so:

            We share John Calvin’s view of Galatians 6:8 as dealing
       with the subject of rewards...” “The fact that God so honours
       the works which He grants us freely as to promise them an
       undeserved reward is itself of grace…I deny that in us there
       are any good works which God rewards except those which we
       have from His grace…” Calvin, Comm. Galatians 6:8…”
       “Clearly, Calvin’s comments are evangelical to the core.”
       (Bold by poster, italics by Hodges.)

        This quote by the poster is from Hodges’ classic: The Gospel Under
Siege: A Study on Faith and Works, 2nd ed. (Redención Viva, 1992), 170,
endnote 2. The poster is trying to give the impression that Hodges is
opposed to inclusion of merit in rewards. Had the poster, however, paid
more attention to the text to which Hodge’s endnote pertains, perhaps the
poster would not have been so careless. In discussing Gal 6:8, Hodges
plainly affirms: “A man gets what he deserves to get.” As if that were not
plain enough, Hodges explicitly affirms: “There is nothing here about
justification by faith or the concept of a free gift. Nothing is plainer than that
the ‘everlasting life’ of which Paul speaks is not free, but based on the
moral merits of those who reap it” (p. 86). Yes, our rewards are based on
our moral merits. The present writer concurs completely with Hodges that
eternal life, when spoken of as a future reward, is based on what we deserve
to get and thus on our moral merit.
        The point Hodges is attempting to make in this endnote was
elliptically deleted by the poster. Hodges’ intent is clearly indicated: “We
share John Calvin’s view of Galatians 6:8 as dealing with the subject of
rewards, and does not treat this verse as any kind of ‘test’ of salvation!”
Yes, Calvin is correct to note that Gal 6:8 is dealing with rewards and is not
to be used as a soteric test. Moreover, in this endnote Hodges clarifies that
this is the aspect of Calvin’s discussion to which he is giving his sweeping
approval: “Clearly, Calvin’s comments are evangelical to the core. We find
nothing here of the Reformed doctrine that works test the geniuses of faith.
Indeed, Calvin was insistent that assurance should not be sought in our
postconversion works” (italics his). Hodges is not to be understood in this
unguarded endorsement as supporting Calvin’s view of rewards as being
undeserved since Hodges clearly affirms in the body of his text that a man
deserves what he gets. It is a splendid endnote—when read in context. Like
the present author, Hodges simply is expressing his agreement with Calvin
that assurance of our salvation is not to be found in our works.

           For sake of simplicity, in the present discussion the faith being
referred to in 2Pet 1:5 will be assumed to be saving faith that results in the
regeneration which Peter has just described in the previous verse (2Pet 1:4).
On the other hand, even if the faith being referred to in 2Pet 1:5 is the initial
stage of sanctifying faith mentioned in 2Pet 1:1, the overall point being
made within the body of the present discussion is still valid. Saving faith
results in regeneration; saving faith does not necessarily, inevitably, or
automatically result in good works. Peter instructs us to add virtue (moral
excellence) to our faith (2Pet 1:5). Whether or not Peter is talking about
adding virtue to our initial saving faith or to our subsequent incipient
sanctifying faith, his point is that believers need to add works to their initial
faith in order to obtain the desired misthological result in this context. Does
this mean that virtue is to be distinguished from our faith? Yes and no. Our
virtue has no part in our original soteric faith, but virtue is to be an add-on to
our subsequent mistholic faith.
      142
          Some in the Reformed camp admit that God obligates Himself to
reward us, but they then insist that this obligation is exclusively to Himself
and to His own faithfulness—not at all to us or to our merit. Admittedly, the
Reformed argument is correct to note that God obligates Himself to give us
eternal life as a free gift without becoming indebted to us. God does not owe
us this free gift as a reward despite the fact that God has promised it to us.
Therefore, God’s obligation, at least in this case, is not based on our merit;
otherwise, God would be in our debt and owe us this gift.
      Still, is it not strange to say that God obligates Himself to reward us but
then turn around and insist that God does not obligate Himself to us? There
are some missing links in the Reformed logic. First, God can owe us in the
sense of being morally obligated to us. Does a father not owe it to his son to
love his son? Does this necessarily mean that his son has merited his father’s
love? Of course not! A father is morally obligated, not meritoriously
obligated, to love his son. Not all obligations are based on merit. While it
might be argued that all obligations are based on what is morally right, it
should not be inversely assumed that everything that is morally right is
Page 384                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
based on meritorious obligation. It is morally right for a person to keep his
word and fulfill his promises. If what he has promised is a gift, then the
promised benefit is unearned. If what he has promised is a reward, then the
promised benefit is earned. This is not exactly rocket science. God has
morally obligated Himself, most definitely to us, by making a promise to us
that He would give us eternal life. The Reformed notion is brazier to suggest
that God’s obligation is only to Himself.
      Meritorious obligation is but a subset of moral obligation. Hence,
meritorious obligation is necessarily a moral obligation, not vice versa. If a
father promised his son a new basketball if his son would mow the yard,
would the father not have morally obligated himself to reward his son with a
basketball if his son mows the lawn? Certainly. And would not his son have
the right to conclude that he earned the basketball even though his father
provided him with the mower by which to cut the grass? Naturally.
Unquestionably, merit is indeed involved. Just as a father can graciously
give his son the opportunity to put him meritoriously in debt to his son, so
God likewise has obligated Himself morally to us with rewards based on our
merit. Some obligations are meritorious.
        143
            If one were to explore this cup-of-milk analogy a little more
closely (before adding the chocolate to it), one might further suggest that
since saving faith comes before regeneration (and therefore does not flow
from a regenerate nature), such faith cannot have any derivative or inherent
merit in it. Only after regeneration, can true chocolate (i.e., inherent merit)
be added to this milk. It takes pure milk to enter the kingdom, but it takes
chocolate milk to inherit the kingdom. What I fear is that so many, in
following the example of Lewis and Edwards, may fail to distinguish the
difference and end up with poisoned milk.
        In this particular example, you must put the milk in the cup before
you add the chocolate. Otherwise, you face having a terminal allergic
reaction to the pseudo chocolate. You must not put the chocolate in the cup
before you pour the milk. You must not put the chocolate in the cup as you
pour the milk. Otherwise, you are getting your chocolate from the wrong
container—a container in which the merit is being derived from a nature that
has not yet experienced regeneration. You must wait and put the chocolate in
after you pour the milk so that you may add true chocolate springing from a
regenerate nature. And the only way you can do this theologically or with
logical consistency is by realizing that the milk results in one clearly defined
benefit but the chocolate results in a completely different but equally defined
benefit. Granted, both benefits may be defined as eternal life or justification.
But if one mistakenly equates the gift of eternal life with the crown of
eternal life or soteriological justification with misthological justification,
then one runs the grave risk of choking to death on that cup of chocolate
milk.

         The Judean apostates experienced a moral defection from the faith
(Jude 1:4). The Galatian apostates experienced a theological defection from
the faith (Gal 5:4). Theological defection need not be preceded by moral
defection. A believer can become entangled in a web of theological lies
without first becoming entangled in a web of moral lies. For this reason,
rather than making the natural ordo apostasia an absolute rule, I made it a
rule of thumb. The Galatian ordo in 5:4 would be represented by row 2 and
the Judean apostasy by row 4 in Illustration 89. Possibilities for Arminian
Ordo Apostasia, 227.
     150
         Rudimentary carnal security only affirms the security of the carnal
believer who continues to believe. Naturally, conditionalists are appalled at
the even more shocking robust affirmation of unmediated carnal security.
The argument of this book is that carnal believers are secure soteriologically
even if they cease to believe. Satan may cut through the insulating protection
of their works and faith, but when his saw hits their regeneration, the teeth of
his saw gnaw in vain. He cannot cut through their regeneration because
regeneration consists of eternal life, and eternal life is eternal. Such life
cannot be destroyed because it is eternal; nor can it even scratched because it
is unconditional.

          Solomon is a classic OT example of moral apostasy (1Kgs 11:1-41).

      155
           Shank makes a tactical error when he admits: “It is abundantly
evident from the Scriptures that the believer is secure. But only the believer.
Many who have debated the ‘security of the believer’ have missed the issue.
The question is not, Is the believer secure? but rather, What is a believer?”
(Life, 55, n. 3; emphasis his). According to Paul, the moral apostate in
1Tim 5:8 is a believer. By Shank’s own admission, one would deduce that
the moral apostate is secure since he is still regarded as a believer by Paul.
Therefore, the living death of the moral apostate in 1Tim 5:6 would not
Endnotes                                                                Page 387
impinge soteric security and thus would have to be something other than
spiritual death.
       Shank would respond, of course, that the moral apostate is no longer a
true believer because a true believer is someone who has saving faith, and
saving faith is faith-works. Still, to make such an argument is to concede the
argument that Arminians cannot condition salvation on faith alone. In
reality, Shank already has conceded that point in essence when he consents
to “Melanchthon’s dictum, ‘It is faith, alone, which saves; but the faith that
saves is not alone.’ Not all ‘faith’ is saving faith….faith without works is
dead also (Jas. 2:26). Such ‘faith’ cannot save” (p. 197). Yet Shank tries to
maintain that salvation is by grace rather than by works (p. 196) by asserting
the latter: “These important obligations are only the expression of faith.
They must never become the objects of our faith. All our faith must rest in
Christ alone” (p. 265; emphasis his). Obviously, according to Shank, these
obligations are conditions which a believer must meet in order to keep his
faith alive and thus keep himself saved. Sanctification is thus the means for
retention of regeneration. According to Shank’s analysis, if one loses his
sanctification, he will then lose his regeneration.
       Forlines claims just the opposite, or so it would seem, “Sanctification is
always the accompaniment of justification, but it is not a condition or ground
of justification. It is simply that the salvation ‘package’ includes both….We
can no more have justification without sanctification than we can
sanctification without justification” (Truth, 218; emphasis his). He then
criticizes “cheap easy-believism which promises justification without
sanctification” since easy-believism concluded that “sanctification was
optional” but “without thinking the matter through” (pp. 218-219).
       Actually, Free Grace writers are left to wonder if their critics, such as
Forlines, really have thought through the matter. Both Shank and Forlines
are making final salvation conditioned on faith-works. Yet Forlines shrinks
back from acknowledging that works are a condition, and Shank attempts to
hide the conditional nature of works by calling them obligations and an
expression of saving faith. Even so, if works are a necessary expressions
(i.e., obligatory expressions), then they are a condition for final justification.
Shank admits as much when he conditions “final salvation” on “living faith”
(p. 280). According to Shank, reception of the eternal life is a free gift, but
retention of eternal life is a reward (p. 281). The final realization of eternal
life in terms of entering heaven is a reward according to Shank.
       Have opponents to unconditional security clearly thought through their
ordo apostasia (order of apostasy)? Which comes first: dead works or dead
faith? The best ordo apostasia that they can give is: (1) moral apostasy
(from good works), then (2) theological apostasy (from faith), followed by
(3) loss of regeneration. In this way, they can condition the loss of
regeneration directly (and exclusively in their opinion) on faith. The
deductive logic of this approach is commendable, but the logical consistency
Page 388                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
by which it is derived and maintained is questionable. Paul throws quite a
few monkey wrenches into the gears of the machinery used to generate this
Arminian ordo. First, Paul suggests a different ordo apostasia in 1Tim 5:6,8:
                   Illustration 142. Pauline Ordo Apostasia
           1. Moral defection
           2. Retention of faith
           3. Death

        Even if this death were soteriological, then Forlines would still have
to account for the fact that subjective apostasy did not occur on this
occasion. The apostate in question did not abandon his faith. For that matter,
his denial of the faith was only moral, not theological. Forlines must retreat
from conditioning salvation on faith alone to conditioning it on faith-works,
which is the conclusion to which his theology logically leads. He should
have recognized this deduction if he only had thought his theology through.
Forlines must join ranks with Shank to conclude that (form the
conditionalistic perspective) it is possible for a believer’s faith to rest in
Christ alone and still not be saving faith because it does not produce the
good works necessary to qualify as saving faith. Salvation by faith alone is
only a myth in such an approach, only given lip service by the Arminian.
Shank regards ongoing “obedience as an essential aspect of saving faith.
There is no saving faith apart from obedience” (p. 197). Quoting a stanza
from Cecil Alexander, Sank says “It is essential that we ‘try His works to
do’” (p. 264). Essentially, Shank is teaching salvation by works-
righteousness rather than by grace-righteousness. Yet Shank seeks to
disavow himself of such a charge by insisting that “to presume to
supplement grace through human endeavor…is to become severed from
Christ and the saving grace of God” (p. 265).
        What a tightrope act! If a believer fails (for a moment?) and tries to
do God’s works through human effort, the believer loses his salvation
morally, and if the believer fails (for a moment?) and trusts in his works
performed through God’s enabling grace as the “ground” or “object” of his
faith, then he loses his salvation doctrinally (p. 264). And just when you
wonder how long (if at all) the Arminian gymnast might be able to walk
such a tightrope, you can look at the other end of the Arminian tightrope and
see Paul furiously sawing away at it with statements which insist that soteric
righteousness is conditioned on faith apart from works and which clearly
assert that the free gift of eternal life will not be granted as a result of works
(e.g. Rom 3:28; 4:6; Eph 2:8-9). Not only are works excluded by Paul from
being the grounds of justification, they also are excluded from being the
instrumental means for justification. Our salvation-by-grace-through-faith-
apart-from-works will not be granted as the result of works. Our works are
disallowed as either the grounds or instrumental means. This means that
Endnotes                                                                  Page 389
even if Shank and Forlines were successful in not trusting in their works as
the grounds of their salvation (a difficult enough task as it is given their
theology), they would still be disqualified by Paul on the grounds of their
having made works the instrumental means of their salvation and therefore
having made salvation the result of their works. Arminianism will not work!
        Protestants adopting a soteric faith-work perspective make works the
instrumental means of soteric salvation: grace-works grace -g r a c e . The works are
                                                            reward

said not to count as works since they are performed through God’s enabling
grace (so Arminianism) or through God’s sovereign grace (so Calvinism).
Marrowism, in contrast, refuses to base its soteriology on works, making
grace the grounds and punctiliar faith the sole instrumental means for such a

      168
           Simplicity and Occam’s razor certainly have their place, but
simplistic interpretations that fail to deal adequately with the essential data
fail to meet the criteria of even that razor. Moreover, God did not shave
away all difficulties for us with that razor. He expects us to use that razor, as
well as other means, in seeking Him and to do our own shaving. He remains
a God that desires to be sought and who rewards those who seek Him. Many
arguments both for NOSAS and for OSAS amount to little more than proof
texting. Still, God has buried treasure in the details for those willing to mine
for it. Even so, when all is said and done, amidst whatever difficulties
encountered, OSAS will win because of that razor—because only OSAS is
in harmony with the fundamental observation that the free gift of eternal life
is free and eternal.

            Meritorious alpha-preconditions to the singular, final,
nonmeritorious beta-precondition of faith are not factored in by the
benefactor as part of the reason the gift of life is bestowed upon the
beneficiary. Faith is the singular instrumental means by which regeneration
is received. The works necessary to come to faith are not considered part of
the efficient or instrumental means for regeneration. The precondition of
faith is the singular condition for regeneration.
      170
          Preconditions do not necessarily guarantee the result, unless perhaps
one were to acknowledge that some guaranteed results may be contingent.
After all, some postconditions are contingent on our freewill response. And
even though effectively hearing the gospel universally grants the opportunity
and ability to believe the gospel, whether or not an individual responds in
saving faith is for the most part left up to the individual.
