      172
          Pseudo Lordship Salvationists make repentance both a theological
and psychological co-condition with faith. Free Grace writers sometimes
write as if they hold the same point of view. According to Dillow,
Endnotes                                                             Page 391
              It is impossible to become a Christian and at the same
        time harbor ideas that one is going to “continue in sin.”
        Becoming a Christian involves repentance.…it is biblically,
        psychologically, and spiritually impossible to…cherish ideas
        of intending to persist in some known sin.…The presence of a
        purpose to continue in sin is incompatible with saving faith,
        but the absence of a lordship commitment is not’” (p. 151)

     Dillow has a better grasp of the nature of faith than he does of the role
of repentance. At least, in contrast to pseudo Lordship Salvation, Dillow
does not redefine faith as commitment. Martuneac apparently limits his
adaptation of the Lordship perspective to psychological necessity. But even
so, he makes repentance a co-condition with faith, as shown by his
implementation of the two-sided coin illustration (p. 119-122,224). On the
positive side, like Dillow, Martuneac correctly denies that the Lordship
commitment is a component of saving faith: “Demanding the high price of
discipleship in exchange for salvation is creating a precondition to merit the
free gift of God and this is wrong” (p. 234, cp. 64). Martuneac realizes that
demanding a commitment to do the right thing would be a meritorious
precondition but fails to perceive that demanding a commitment not to do
the wrong thing also would be a meritorious precondition. Just as strangely,
Martuneac rightly and approvingly provides an extended quote from Bing:

          Thus, the account of the rich young ruler does not teach that
     to be saved the ruler must meet the demands of discipleship,
     surrender to Christ’s lordship…or repent of particular sins….The
     forsaking of one’s possessions, or the willingness to do so is
     never made a condition of salvation. (p. 160)

      According to Bing, a person does not have to repent of particular sins.
And even in this quote, Bing seems to imply that a willingness to repent of
sins is not necessary. Such an impression certainly is strengthened when one
reads Bing’s splendid chapter “Repentance and Salvation” (pp. 60-92). Bing
commences that chapter by noting, “MacArthur demonstrates his difference
with the Free Grace view when he gives this three-fold significance
[involving intellectual, emotional, and volitional components] to repentance”
(p. 61). Bing justifiably rejects the three-element view of salvific repentance
as being a Lordship teaching that is incompatible with Free Grace teaching.
Yet this is a Lordship definition of repentance that is adopted by Martuneac
(p. 114-119)! Martuneac’s frontloading the gospel with Lordship repentance
and his backloading it with good works as the necessary Lordship evidence
of conversion (pp. 248,276) give the strong impression that Martuneac may
be nothing more than a Lordship wolf in Free Grace clothing.
Page 392                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
     On multiple fronts Moyer is a decidedly better representative of Free
Grace theology than Dillow and Martuneac concerning the willingness to
turn from sins. Moyer clearly rejects theological necessity of such a view
and only admits the very high probability of psychological necessity.
Furthermore, he also relegates such necessity to the arena of precondition
rather than condition.

           The question that invariably rises on the practical level is,
      Can a person trust Christ if he or she is not willing to give up a
      particular sin? Theologically, the answer is yes….But what a
      person is not prevented from doing theologically, he or she will
      find difficult to do psychologically. To trust the One who dies
      on a cross for one’s sin while having decided that one is not,
      under any circumstances, going to give up a particular sin, is
      most difficult, if not impossible, for a person to do....it becomes
      virtually impossible.…The problem is not a scriptural or
      theological one; it is an internal psychological one. (pp. 103-
      104).

     Why? Because that is the way God designed us. But does this mean
that God has designed us in such a way as to make it virtually impossible, if
not impossible, for us to receive forgiveness without being willing to turn
from our sins? If so, then the problem is a theological one after all. God is
not really offering us a free gift with no strings attached if that is the case.
God simply replaced the strings with wires and so wired us in such a way
that we cannot take forgiveness under the terms which He offers it. Because
of such considerations and because of biblical confirmations, Robert
Wilkin’s qualification to Moyer’s explanation is superior:

           People with sinful addictions often cannot see that need
     unless they hit bottom and give up the addiction. Turning from
     sins is not a condition of salvation. However, for some it may be
     a practical necessity—not to clean up their lives, but to be able to
     see their need and come to faith in Christ.

     For some people this psychological precondition may be necessary; for
others it may not be. Therefore, the position adopted herein is that the
willingness to turn from one’s sins is neither an overt nor a covert
theological precondition but only a potential psychological precondition.
     See Charles C. Bing, Lordship Salvation: A Biblical Evaluation and
Response. Grace Life Edition (Burleson: GraceLife Ministries, 1992). Lou
Martuneac, In Defense of the Gospel: Biblical Answers to Lordship
Salvation (Xulon Press, 2006). Larry R. Moyer, Free and Clear:
Understanding and Communicating God’s Offer of Eternal Life (Grand
Endnotes                                                             Page 393
Rapids: Kregel, 1997). Robert N. Wilkin, “Self-Sacrifice and Kingdom
Entrance: Part 2 of 2: Matthew 5:29-30,” GIF (September 1989).
      Other indications of Martuneac’s leanings toward Lordship Salvation
are found in his criticism of the Free Grace position as an extremist position
advocating “Easy-Believism” (pp. v,vi,120). This is the same criticism
leveled against Free Grace theology by Lordship Salvationists. Martuneac
tries to distance himself from Lordship Salvation by criticizing it as
demanding “full surrender” (p. 64). Martuneac’s solution is to seek to
balance the Free Grace position with Lordship Salvation by demanding only
a partial surrender in which there must be no areas of sin in the potential
convert’s life that “he would be unwilling to give it over to God….that he
would refuse to submit to Christ’s lordship” (p. 64). Martuneac wants to soft
pedal Lordship Salvation on the frontend in an attempt to make it more
palatable to the Free Grace community. Still, unwillingness to turn from
one’s sinful performance would disqualify one from heaven according to his
mediating attempt. Hopefully, the Free Grace community will be more
discerning than to adopt such performance-based modifications on the
frontend. Martuneac also says that “the fruit of repentance [change in action]
must follow the root [change of mind about sin]” (pp. 111-112). He makes
the follow-through in changing one’s performance a soteriological necessity
on the backend.
      Granted, Martuneac rejects the strong Lordship position when he
denies that a person could be “born again based on any sincere intention to
serve God” (p. 114). Yet, at the same time, he obviously seeks to espouse a
soft Lordship position when he conditions a person being born again on a
sincere intention to turn from sins. Of course, this presents a logical dilemma
for Martuneac. How does turning from sin not entail turning to God in
service? Not serving God is a sin—correct? If one must turn from sin to be
saved (as Martuneac proposes), would that not mean that one must serve
God to be saved? Are not sins of omission still sins? Why does Martuneac
think that a person cannot be saved if he is unwilling to turn from sins of
commission but contend that such a person can be saved if he is unwilling to
turn from sins of omission? Regardless, it is still performance-based
salvation.
      Like the typical Lordship Salvationist, Martuneac makes faith and
repentance “two-sides of the same coin” (p. 119). Admittedly, it is possible
to adopt such a perspective in Free Grace theology if one simply defines
repentance as a change of mind about sin, Jesus, and oneself so that one no
longer believes in oneself or in one’s performance for salvation and instead
believes in Jesus as the Savior from the penalty of one’s sins. Martuneac,
however, clearly goes beyond this potential Free Grace position into
Lordship Salvation territory when he demands that a potential convert must
make “a definite, on-purpose decision to confess that sin, and turn from the
old ways to Jesus Christ” (p. 121). Martuneac is conditioning salvation on
Page 394                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
one’s intention to change one’s performance by turning from one’s sins. To
be sure, he says that “man is not saved by promising good works” (p. 94).
Still, Martuneac is criticizing Free Grace theology because it does not
condition salvation from hell on the promise to do better in terms of turning
from old sins. In effect, Martuneac criticizes Free Grace for teaching that
salvation is free. He would prefer to condition salvation on the promise to
stop committing certain sins. In the end, he conditions salvation on
promising to change one’s performance on the frontend and on the necessity
to actually change one’s performance on the backend. He is an inconsistent
Lordship Salvationist trying to conceal his conditional security under the
cloak of a modified Free Grace theology.

         MacArthur’s most prevalent distortion of the Free Grace position in
his Gospel is seen in his failure to admit that many in the Free Grace camp
teach a very strong doctrine of rewards, a doctrine of rewards that is much
stronger than his, in fact. Therefore, to charge the Free Grace position with
being antinomian because it does not make soteric demands on a believer’s
behavior is only a half-truth. Had the whole truth been admitted, MacArthur
would have acknowledged that the Free Grace camp tends to make very
strong moral demands. As it is, MacArthur, like Lewis, finds it easier to
implement false dichotomies. In this case, MacArthur’s false dichotomy is
that one must either choose between Lordship Salvation’s emphasis on
moral necessity or a supposedly Free Grace emphasis on complete lack of
moral necessity. The option of opting for a Free Grace position that insists
on the misthological necessity of Christian morality was not even
considered.
Endnotes                                                           Page 395
     Another half-truth, at best, is seen in MacArthur’s statement that those
of us in the Free Grace camp do not rely upon the power of the Holy Spirit
to meet that misthological moral necessity:

              Those who argue against lordship salvation often base
      their theology on the faulty assumption that the work of God in
      salvation stops with justification. The rest, many believe, is
      purely the believer’s own effort. (p. 200)

No citations are provided by MacArthur of those writing representatively of
the Free Grace theology who hold such a position. Is it a fictitious position
that MacArthur has made up and attributed to the Free Grace camp? Do any
of the Free Grace writers whom MacArthur has cited hold to such a
position? Where is the documentation? It readily will be seen that the
present Free Grace writer does not hold this (fictitious?) position. Even
MacArthur’s own qualifiers would suggest (to the thinking reader) that
many in the Free Grace camp do, in fact, base sanctification on God’s
enabling power. For that matter, many in the Free Grace camp (such as the
present writer) would agree with MacArthur that the only way a person can
come to saving faith is through God’s enablement.
      For that matter, MacArthur misrepresents the matter when he pretends
that his Reformed theology has a believer coming to saving faith as a mere
result of divine enabling. MacArthur writes like an Arminian in his
discussion of divine enablement! Is dressing up his Reformed doctrine in
Arminian garb the only way that MacArthur can make his Reformed
doctrine palatable? He says, “God draws the sinner to Christ and gives the
ability to believe” (p. 189). Of course God does. Many of us in Free Grace
would agree with that statement. Granted, MacArthur claims that faith is a
gift, and the present writer does not hold that point of view. Nevertheless,
there are those in the Free Grace camp who reject Lordship Salvation and
who yet believe that faith is a gift when viewed exclusively in terms of
divine enablement (Dillow, 280, 288). Moreover, Picirilli, an Arminian,
endorses a similar view and even states: “Arminius freely represented faith
as the gift of God” (p. 167). Arminians and Marrowians concur with
MacArthur that divine enablement is definitely needed in order for a person
to come to saving faith. But MacArthur is trying to insinuate more when he
claims: “We cannot even believe without God’s sovereign enablement (John
6:44, 65); we cannot conjure up faith out of the human free will” (p. 194).
      MacArthur evidently intends to suggest that divine enablement is not
enough, that God must do more than simply enable us to believe, that God
must sovereignly (i.e., irresistibly) cause us to believe. If this is what he
believes, then the inquisitive reader of the MacArthurian material may well
wonder if MacArthur is advocating mechanical causation or compatibilistic
causation or is he merely content with freewill persuasional causation? The
Page 396                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
second part of his statement seems to deny that free will can play a role in
our coming to saving faith. If so, it would not be surprising since Wikipedia
notes: “The Reformed tradition has typically advanced the belief that faith
stemming from one’s free will cannot save.” If this is the case, does
MacArthur mean to imply that those of us who believe (or at least think we
believe) in God as a result of divine enablement are lost? Apparently,
MacArthur would say that we are lost semi-Pelagians because we believe
that free will has a role to play in our coming to saving faith (p. 254-255). Or
could it be that he would say that we are simply mistaken in thinking that we
believe in God as a result of mere enablement and that we will be told when
we reach heaven that we actually believed because of God’s sovereign
enablement? Is perseverance the only way to tell if one really has a
sovereignly produced saving faith, given a Reformed premise, or must one
also persevere and believe that one’s perseverance is a result of sovereign
grace rather than merely a result of God’s enabling grace? MacArthur leaves
quite a few questions unanswered.
      Yet MacArthur criticizes Hodges for not explaining how inheriting the
kingdom could be a reward when MacArthur thinks that Rev 21:7-8 proves
that all believers will inherit the kingdom: “I am aware of Zane Hodges’
view that to ‘inherit the kingdom’ is somehow different from entering the
kingdom. But Revelation 21:7-8 makes the meaning of these words [in
1Cor 6:9-11] indisputable” (p. 247). No, it does not. Hodgian apprentices
will not find a MacArthurian proof text taken out of context indisputable.
But I will continue that dispute in The Outer Darkness. This present work is
just the warm-up round. For now, I simply point out that Hodges did not fail
to explain how inheriting is somehow different from entering the kingdom in
that he regarded performance-based inheritance a reward and a freely
granted entrance a gift. As to indisputable texts, I think that Col 3:23-24 is
such: “Whatever you do, do your work heartily, as for the Lord rather than
for men; knowing that from the Lord you will receive the reward of the
inheritance.” But what treatment does this passage receive from MacArthur
in his Gospel According to Jesus? None. It might be objected that it would
be too much to expect a treatment of an epistolary text in a book dealing
with the gospels. I point out that the text to which MacArthur makes his
appeal in Rev 21:7-8 is not found in the gospels. Moreover, when one
consults MacArthur’s Gospel According to the Apostles, one finds that
Col 3:23-24 is passed over in silence there also. Why does MacArthur not
deal with strong points advanced by his opponents? An argument deprived
of its collaborating argumentation is nothing but a strawman imitation. This
is only the tip of the iceberg. MacArthur’s strawman is stuffed full of
misrepresentations, misleading insinuations, and glossed over
considerations.

          I am defining repent (metanoeo) more comprehensively than just to
turn from one’s sin because in the OT it is God who may or may not (repent)
metanoeo (LXX: 1Sam 15:29; Joel 2:13-14; Jonah 3:9-10; 4:2; Zech 8:14;
Jer 4:28; 18:8,10). Obviously, God does not sin or need to turn from sin, but
God may change His mind about a course of action. For this reason, I am not
inclined to agree with those of my fellow Free Grace writers who insist that
metamelomai is never used synonymously with metanoeo. The evidence
suggests otherwise if one broadens one’s discussion to include the OT:

     • God will not change His mind (metamelomai, Ps 109: 4; Heb 7:21).
     • God will not change His mind (metanoeo, 1Sam 15:29).

      Furthermore, both verbs can function interchangeably as preconditions
for saving faith in certain contexts:

     You did not repent and believe (metamelomai, Mt 21:32).
     Repent and believe in the gospel (metanoeo, Mk 1:15).

      Admittedly, since 2Cor 7:8-10 uses the two terms differently, the
semantic overlap is by no means complete. The usage in Mt 27:3 regarding
Judas is debatable. If metamelomai refers to feeling sorrow for one’s sin in
this verse, it does not lead to Judas having saving faith. On the other hand, if
ESV is correct to render metamelomai in terms of metanoeo (he changed his
mind)—and performed a corresponding action in bringing back the money—
then it still may be concluded that metamelomai does not lead to saving
faith. Consequently, the godly sorrow/change of mind associated with
metamelomai may be a helpful precondition in coming to a repentance that
leads to life, but it does not lead necessarily to this outcome. It may lead to
death instead! Judas killed himself as a result of his metamelomai.
Page 398                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
      What is the root of repentance? Godly sorrow (lupe) produces
repentance unto salvation (2Cor 7:10). God’s kindness (chrestos) leads to
repentance (Rom 4:2). When metamelomai is translated as sorrow or regret,
it can be used in the same capacity, that is, as leading to repentance
(Mt 21:29,32). Many things can lead to repentance, but they do not
irresistibly lead to a godly outcome. Worldly sorrow (lupe; lupeo) leads to
death. Perhaps the sorrow (metamelomai) which Judas had in Mt 27:3 was
worldly sorrow rather than godly sorrow. Even so, metamelomai (like lupe)
can lead to either a saving or damning outcome.
      Some of my Free Grace compatriots may wish to appeal to Anderson’s
proof texts in Acts 3:19 and 11:21 to challenge my assessment that
repentance may include the external manifestation of the internal change of
mind that produced it. In anticipation of that objection, I acknowledge that
the syntax in Acts 3:19 roughly parallels that of Acts 11:21.

     • repent (metanoeo) and return (epistrepho)
     • believed (pisteuo) turned (epistrepho) to the Lord.

      Accordingly, repenting is not equatable with returning anymore than
believing is equatable with turning. In both cases, those who visibly turn are
doing more than just inwardly turning. However, this admission does not
prove that repenting must be exclusively internal. The summons in Acts 3:19
might be an abbreviation for: inwardly and outwardly turn from your sins
(metanoeo) and visibly turn to the Lord (epistrepho). Likewise in
Acts 26:20, “They should repent [from sin; metanoeo] and turn to God
[epistrepho].” Metanoeo refers to their past conduct in regard to their sin;
epistrepho looks to their future conduct in regard to the Lord God. As to the
prodigal son, metanoeo refers to making up one’s mind to leave the far
country (and actually leaving it); epistrepho refers to returning to the home
country. Metanoeo refers to turning away; epistrepho refers to returning
back or turning to. Anderson’s proof texts are insufficient to prove that
metanoeo (repentance) must be exclusively internal.
      Surely, the joy in heaven over the return of the sinner who repents is
not over the sinner’s mere internal willingness to turn from his sin apart
from his actual external turning from his sin (Lk 15:7,10). Was Jesus merely
calling for an inward change in Lk 13:5? Surely in calling for the inward
change, Jesus was likewise demanding its corresponding outward
manifestation in order to avoid perishing in temporal calamity. In the same
fashion, the sinning brother is expected to give outward, verbal confirmation
that he has repented, “Saying, I repent” (Lk 17:4). Saying this outwardly
with his lips, not just inwardly with his heart, was required.
      Calling for deeds appropriate to one’s turn from sin is certainly
appropriate (Acts 26:20). To be sure, outwardly turning from sin is the fruit
of repentance. So what? An apple is the fruit of an apple tree. Does this
Endnotes                                                               Page 399
mean that the apple is not part of the apple tree? Of course not. The fruit of
repentance is part of the tree of repentance. There is no need to treat the fruit
of repentance as if it were not a part of repentance. Stated more fully,
repentance is a change of mind (regarding one’s action) which may
inclusively result in a change of action. Or stated otherwise, repentance is a
change of mind which includes a corresponding change of action.
      Sorrow may or may not precede repentance. Repentance, in turn, may
or may not come before saving faith. Sometimes God uses godly sorrow to
lead a person to godly repentance (and ultimately to saving faith). On the
other hand, sometimes the Lord uses kindness (and resulting gratitude)
instead to lead people to repentance (Rom 2:4). Sometimes the Lord uses
biblically imparted wisdom, rather than repentance, to lead a person to
salvation through faith in Christ (2Tim 3:15). Regardless of the intermediate
means God uses to lead people to saving faith, it is presumptuous for pseudo
Lordship Salvationists to demand that God do it their way.
      192
          As to the lexical picture of a tree presenting repentance, the fruit is
not within the root. The fruit (change of action) is not contained in the root
(change of mind). The tree is made up of the composite.
      The definition adopted within this book intuitively places the root
before the fruit: Repentance is a change of mind which includes a
corresponding change of action. Conversely, one might expresses the fruit
first as Lopez does: “Metanoia means change of direction that obviously
includes a change of mind.” (René A. Lopez, Romans, GNTC, 631.) This
Free Grace definition is very close to the one by L-N cited within the body
of the present book: to change one’s way of life as the result of a complete
change of thought and attitude. Hunt combines the change of mind with
change of action by stating that metanoia and metanoeo “refer to a change of
mind concerning sins, that is, turning from one’s sins.” (Dwight L. Hunt,
Second Corinthians, GNTC, 795.) Vacendak simply defines repentance in
terms of its fruit by positing that in the book of Revelation repentance
“always refers to turning from sins.” (Robert Vacendak, Revelation, GNTC,
1260.) Regardless, as is readily seen, lexically including the external change
in action as part of repentance certainly falls within the parameters of Free
Grace theology. (Also see GNTC 574, 1003.)

           See Lordship Salvation. Available at http://en.wikipedia.org
/wiki/Lordship_salvation. Accessed on December 20, 2008. Granted, some
would criticize using citations from Wikipedia for illustrations of prevalent
perceptions (and one certainly cannot adopt something said on Wikipedia at
Page 400                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
face value without critical analysis), but let it be noted that this summation
by Wikipedia (that the Reformed position makes good works necessary for
final salvation) does far more justice to the debate than statement made by
Theopedia:

          The word necessary is contested with particular bitterness
     [among Free Grace and Lordship Salvationists]. For instance, the
     (Reformed) claim “repentance is a necessary condition of
     salvation” is simply stating that “everyone who is being saved
     repents”. The misunderstanding could arise in that “repentance is
     a necessary condition of salvation” could be thought to mean
     “repentance causes someone to be saved”. The necessariness of
     repentance arises in that it always follows regeneration, and
     always accompanies salvation. (Emphasis original.)

Available at http://www.theopedia.com/Non-lordship_salvation. Accessed
on June 14, 2009. Theopedia tries to hide the conditional nature of
repentance by making it, in effect, a mere state following regeneration. To
illustrate in terms of a well-known feature of Greek grammar, “the perfect
tense expresses the state or condition of the subject of the verb” (NSVNT,
49). Describing the situation in these terms, from the Theopedian
perspective, makes repentance only a condition of regeneration rather than a
condition for regeneration. Repentance is a necessary result of regeneration.
Contrary to Theopedia, the problem is not a misunderstanding on the part of
those in the Free Grace movement but a masquerading on the part of those in
the Lordship camp. Many of those in the Lordship camp, such as
MacArthur, refuse to own up to the fact that their condition of repentance (in
terms of state) is a condition for the retention of regeneration (in terms of if-
then becausal propositions).
      Contra Theopedia, MacArthur himself acknowledges that within his
theology the necessity of repentance is a condition for salvation! (See
endnote 199 herein.) MacArthur is being thoroughly inconsistent when he
pretends that the necessity of performance is not a condition for final
salvation. Nevertheless, MacArthur’s equating necessity of repentance with
condition for salvation is enough to demonstrate the error of the Theopedian
explanation.
      Intellectual honesty would require that MacArthurian and Theopedian
interpreters acknowledge they are conditioning the final outcome of
salvation on perseverance since they teach that God preserves those who
persevere. In Reformed thought, if you persevere, then God will keep you.
Your persevering is a condition for God to keep you. Perseverance is not
merely a condition of (i.e., result of) God keeping you. The Reformed
condition of repentance (resulting from initial regeneration) becomes a
Endnotes                                                              Page 401
condition for retention of regeneration when extrapolated to its final
outcome in Reformed thought.
      For example, Piper asks, “If we are justified once for all by grace
through faith apart from works at the point of true conversion, then how can
our final salvation be conditional upon a transformed life of holiness?” He
correctly identifies a crucial question: “Why does practical holiness (i.e.
love) inevitably accompany justifying faith?” His answer is that “works are
evidence of true faith, and are not the means of our salvation the way faith
is. They are the evidence that faith is real and thus are necessary for final
salvation.” Works are a necessary condition for reaching heaven according
to Piper because they are necessary evidence of faith. Works are a means of
Piperean salvation (just not a condition in the same way faith is). Quoting
Watson, Piper further confirms, “Repentance [practical change in the way
you live] is a condition, not a cause [for final salvation].” See “Future Grace
/ Battling Unbelief, Session 01.” Available at http://www.desiringgod.org
/ResourceLibrary/Seminars/1587_Future_Grace__Battling_Unbelief_Sessio
n_01/. Accessed on January 16, 2008.
      Piper is quite frank about his affirmation of conditional security and the
conditional nature of faithfulness: “The Bible does not guarantee security at
the expense of faithfulness to Jesus.” Concerning 1Pet 1:5, he surmises:
“God’s power protects us for salvation by sustaining our faith. The only
thing that can keep us from heaven is forsaking our faith in Christ, and
turning to other hopes, other treasures.” “There is no safety belt. There is
one way to heaven: the way of persevering faith.” “Our security is not in
making heaven unconditional. Our security is in God’s infallible
commitment to fulfill the conditions of heaven.” Our protection is
conditioned on our perseverance: “He caused us to be born again by creating
our faith; and he protects us on the way to heaven by preserving our faith.”
See “The Elect Are Kept by the Power of God.” Available at
http://www.desiringgod.org/ResourceLibrary/TopicIndex/14_Perseverance_
of_the_Saints/851_The_Elect_Are_Kept_by_the_Power_of_God/. Accessed
on January 16, 2008.
      According to Piper our security is not unconditional. To the contrary, it
is conditional: “Final salvation from future judgment [in terms of hell] is
conditional. It will not happen apart from our persevering faith.” Piper lists
many conditions making up the conditional nature of this soteric security:

      These are just some of the conditions that the New Testament
      says we must meet in order to inherit final salvation. We must
      believe on Jesus and receive him and turn from our sin and
      obey him and humble ourselves like little children and love him
      more than we love our family, our possessions or our own life.
      This is what it means to be converted to Christ. This alone is
      the way of life everlasting.” See “Conversion: The Creation of a
Page 402                           Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
      Christian Hedonist. (Available at http://www.desiringgod.org
      /dg/id36_cf.htm. Accessed on January 16, 2008.)

      Everlasting life is conditioned on an ever expanding list of
requirements according to Piper’s dogma. For a partial expansion, one may
consult the list that Piper supplies elsewhere, entitled: “Texts That Point to
the Necessity of Yielding to Christ as Lord in Order to Inherit Eternal Life.”
He then commences his list: The Necessity of Doing Good, The Necessity of
Obedience, The Necessity of Holiness, The Necessity to Forgive Others, The
Necessity Not to Live According to the Flesh, The Necessity of Being Free
From the Love of Money, The Necessity of Love to Christ and God, The
Necessity to Love Others, The Necessity to Love the Truth, The Necessity of
Being Childlike, The Necessity to Bridle the Tongue, The Necessity of
Perseverance, The Necessity of Walking in the Light, The Necessity of
Repentance, The Necessity of Warfare Vigilance. Anyone with half an
inclination to do so could greatly expand the partial list Piper has provided.
Piper has confused the things necessary to inherit the kingdom with things
necessary to enter the kingdom. By treating the things that are necessary to
inherit the kingdom as if they were the things that are necessary to enter the
kingdom, Piper has conditioned entrance into heaven on one’s performance.
In short, he is teaching salvation by works. See “Letter to a Friend
Concerning the So-Called ‘Lordship Salvation.’” Available at http://www
.desiringgod.org/ResourceLibrary/Articles/ByDate/1990/1496_Letter_to_a_
Friend_Concerning_the_SoCalled_Lordship_Salvation. Accessed on May
23, 2010.
      As expected Piper makes God-enabled works a condition for salvation
from damnation: “Obedience [in terms of works a and a life of faith] is such
a necessary extension of saving faith that in both covenants obedience to
God is a condition of final salvation. Not legalistic ‘works of law,’ but
Spirit-empowered ‘obedience of faith.’” See “The Law Does Not Annul the
Promise.” Available at http://www.desiringgod.org/ResourceLibrary
/Sermons/ByDate/1983/388_The_Law_Does_Not_Annul_the_Promise/.
Accessed on January 16, 2008.
      In Piper’s estimation, obedience, in terms of the way one lives, is
necessary for salvation from damnation:

            Jesus saw some measure of real, lived-out obedience to the
      will of God as necessary for final salvation….
      ….But though our lived-out perfection only comes in heaven,
      Jesus really does transform us now, and this transformation is
      really necessary for final salvation. But the way our new
      behavior is necessary is different from the way trusting Jesus
      for our perfection is necessary. Trusting Jesus connects us with
      him….Therefore, trusting Jesus is necessary in order to be
Endnotes                                                             Page 403
      connected to Jesus who is the foundation of our justification.
      But new, transformed behavior is necessary as the fruit and
      evidence of this connection with Jesus. (pp. 160-161; italics
      his.)

Contrary to Theopedia, as demonstrated in the quotes above form Piper, the
Reformed condition of final salvation…is really necessary for final
salvation. Piper has additional ways of demonstrating that Reformed
theology necessarily makes works necessary for final salvation. He
immediately launches into a discussion of nature of fruit in Mt 7:17-19 and
concludes:

         The fruit does not make the tree good. The tree makes the fruit
      good. Good deeds do not attach us to Jesus. They are not the ground
      of our being declared righteous…. The reason Jesus can say, “Every
      tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire”
      (Matt. 7:19) is not because the fruit is the basis of our acceptance with
      God—the tax collector had no fruit to offer—but because the absence
      of fruit shows we are not connected to Jesus. (p. 161)

      In the end you are justified (declared righteous) at the final judgment
and thrown either into the fire or not thrown into the fire because of your
fruit. The fruit did not make you a righteous person, but your fruit (i.e., the
way you live) is proof as to whether or not you are a righteous person. Is it
necessary fruit? Yes, according to Piper. Why? Because final justification or
condemnation will be based on your fruit. The logical outcome of Piper’s
statement is that you are saved from hell at the point of judgment because of
your performance, as Piper himself explains in his footnote to his statement
above:

        Though it may cause confusion, it is possible to use the word
      “justify” to describe how the fruit of good behavior works in
      the day of judgment. The fruits can “justify” us in the sense
      of proving that we are believers and belong to Jesus and have
      a right standing with God in him. That is how I understand
      Matthew 12:37, “By your words you will be justified, and by
      your words you will be condemned.” It is as though the Judge
      said, “The evidence is compelling: Your words warrant the
      judgment that you are a true believer in my Son and have rested
      your case with him and banked on his righteousness for
      acceptance in this court.” Or: “Your words justify [warrant,
      validate] the conclusion of this court that you have trusted in
      the righteousness of Jesus Christ for your justification in this
      court.” (p. 161, n. 1)
Page 404                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity

      In Piper’s soteriology, you will be justified, in terms of heaven versus
hell, at the final judgment by your works and words (i.e., because of your
performance). These works are necessary evidence, and God’s verdict and
your final justification is conditioned on your good behavior. The Piperean
fruit has been picked from the Edwardsean tree. See What Jesus Demands
from the World (Wheaton: Crossway Books, 2006).
      Piperean theology is obviously conditional: “The saints will and must
persevere in the obedience which comes from faith. Election is
unconditional, but glorification is not.” The Edwardsean virtual importation
is used in defense: “God justifies us on the first genuine act of saving
faith, but in doing so he has a view to all subsequent acts of faith
contained, as it were, like a seed in that first act” (Piper’s emphasis).
Final Piperean salvation is conditioned upon subsequent post-conversion
performance: “Final salvation is made contingent upon the subsequent
obedience which comes from faith….we are justified through our first act of
faith because God sees in it (like he can see the tree in an acorn) the embryo
of a life of faith” (which follows). According to this statement, Piperean
salvation was given to us initially because God saw that we will persevere
subsequently. Logically, initial justification is given to us on credit (i.e., on
lay-away), by Piper’s God, because of the subsequent works we will
perform. According to Piper, Abraham was justified by God not only
because of his initial faith (in Rom 4:3) but because of his subsequent faith
“which gave rise to acts of obedience later in his life” (Rom 4:19-22). See
“What We Believe About the Five Points of Calvinism.” Available at
http://www.desiringgod.org/ResourceLibrary/Articles/ByDate/1985/1487_
What_We_Believe_About_the_Five_Points_of_Calvinism/#Perseverance.
Accessed on January 16, 2008.
      Piperean salvation from hell is conditioned on a life of holiness. This
life of holiness (as surmised under the banner of repentance) is a necessary
condition rather than a cause. For interaction herein with the Edwardsean
counterpart, see Causation, 163. Piper seeks to avoid works-righteousness
by grounding such works in Christ. For interaction herein with the
Edwardsean counterpart, see Hunsinger’s Criticism, 125; Digging Oneself
into a Hole, 126. For interaction herein with the Edwardsean counterpart to
Piper’s courtroom analogy, see Arminians, 165. Piper’s seed-tree argument
is that of Edward’s virtual importation in a nutshell. Appealing to Abraham
to justify this seed-tree analogy is a rehash of Edward’s argument. For
notation herein regarding the Edwardsean counterpart, see Abraham’s
Justification, 154. For interaction, see David’s Justification, 146.
      If faith is the root and works are the fruit, then Edwards and Piper have
placed the fruit within the root. In their soteriological agriculture, God
justifies believers initially because of the works that believers will perform
subsequently. Even initial justification (which is biblically apart from works)
Endnotes                                                                  Page 405
becomes justification by works by the time this disastrous duo is through
with it.
      Piper rightly regards perseverance in faith (i.e., linear faith £) to be a
condition for final salvation in 1Pet 1:5. His mistake lies in regarding this
final salvation as soteric rather than mistholic. Perseverance in faith is
required for salvation as a reward, not as a gift. Alternatively, some
unconditional securitists believe that punctiliar (z) faith rather than
perseverance in faith is the subject matter in 1Pet 1:5. As exegetically
doubtful as this alternative may be, it is soteriologically superior to Piper’s
insistence that salvation from hell is conditioned on linear (£) faith.
Incidentally, Piper speaks inconsistently when he acts as though Piperean
salvation from hell is conditioned on faith alone in his discussion of
1Pet 1:5. His further discussions cited herein prove that he also conditions
final salvation on postconversional works. Piper conditions entrance into
heaven on perseverance in both faith and faithfulness.
      This is not to say that Piper is always candid about his conditionalism.
For example, he acknowledges that in his view Rom 8:13 applies to heaven
versus hell and has application to the professing believer. However, he twists
the verse to mean that if you have been justified initially, then you will put
to death the deeds of the Spirit subsequently. In this article, he fails to own
up to the fact that he is making final justification conditioned on the way the
professing believer lives. See “How to Kill Sin Part 1.” Available at
http://www.desiringgod.org/ResourceLibrary/Sermons/ByDate/2002/83_Ho
w_to_Kill_Sin_Part_1. Accessed on January 24, 2010.
      In this article at least, I believe Piper is susceptible to his own criticism:

            Some use language to conceal where they stand rather than
      to make clear where they stand. One reason this happens is that
      clear and open statements usually result in more criticism than
      ambiguous statements do. Vagueness will win more approval in
      a hostile atmosphere than forthrightness will.
            But we want nothing to do with that attitude. Jesus refused
      to converse with religious leaders who crafted their answers so
      as to conceal what they thought (Mark 11:33).

See The Future of Justification: A Response to N. T. Wright (Wheaton,
Crossway Books, 2007), 32.
     Still, to his credit, Piper practically does admit the conditionalism in his
interpretation concerning Rom 8:13 in other places: “Eternal life [in terms of
heaven versus hell] is at stake in the battle against sin” (p. 140). As to eternal
security and lust, “if you don’t fight this sin with the kind of seriousness that
is willing to gouge out your eye, you will go to hell and suffer there
forever.” “If we don’t fight lust we lose our soul” (p. 136). In Piperean
terms, this means you would lose your salvation and go to hell if you lose
Page 406                             Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
the battle against lust. For those willing to take time to put the Piperean
jigsaw puzzle together, the conditionalism is plain to see, even regarding this
verse. See Battling Unbelief (Colorado Springs, Multnomah Books, 2007).
      As to his book, The Future of Justification, although he does not
candidly describe the necessity of good performance as a condition, he
certainly treats it as such: “I believe in the necessity of a transformed life of
obedience to Jesus by the power of the Spirit through faith as a public
evidence and confirmation of faith at the Last Day for all who will finally be
saved” (Justification, 110; emphasis his). So perhaps one can only fault
Piper’s readers rather than Piper himself if the readers of Piper’s book do not
pick up on the fact that Piper makes the evidence a condition for final
justification. After all, a few pages later he even cites Rom 8:13 in support
of his contention that the biblical writers “make moral transformation
(especially the fruit of love) necessary for final salvation” (pp. 114-115;
emphasis his). If one has read widely enough in Piper’s writings, one should
realize that in making good performance necessary evidence of initial
justification, he has admitted time and again that he is necessarily making
good performance a condition for final justification.
      Naturally, as explained herein, I reject his assessment that our entrance
into heaven is conditioned on our performance. Even so, I appreciate that in
The Future of Justification Piper endeavors to show that God-enabled soft
legalism is still Pharisaical legalism that should be rejected (see especially
pp. 149, 152, 154, 158-159). On this matter, we heartily agree. Where we
disagree is that I am convinced that Piper himself is a soft legalist. His
appeal to good works as a condition (in the sense of necessary evidence)
rather than as grounds or basis for final soteric justification is simply too
weak to deflect this critical assessment.
      Of course, as Piper points out, good works are not the grounds for final
justification. So what? Good works are not even the grounds for rewards.
Yet rewards are dispensed according to works, and in that sense based on
works. (See “Judgment is Always Based on Works” in my book, Breaking
the Rocking Horse.) Final justification in terms of entrance into heaven is
not a reward and therefore is not according to works, contrary to Piper.

Nicodemus’s salvation: he must acknowledge this sinfulness and repent.”
Even MacArthur equates necessity of with condition for. Yet if repentance is
a condition because it is a necessity, then so is performance.

           I are not equating not paying taxes with going to jail since there are
other reasons that one could go to jail. Simply, not paying one’s taxes is a
sufficient cause (rather than necessary cause) for going to jail. Conversely,
paying one’s taxes is a necessary condition for not going to jail.

       In the same fashion, not bearing good fruit is a sufficient cause for
going to hell; bearing good fruit is a necessary condition for not going to
hell. As is apparent, it is not necessary for my argument that I make bearing
good fruit a necessary and sufficient cause (⇔) for going to hell. It suffices
for the pertinent part of my deductive argument merely to point out that
bearing good fruit (or not bearing bad fruit) is at least a sufficient cause.

      214
          Condemnation in the first pericope is based on fruit/faith, while it is
based on practice/works in the second paragraph. This does not mean the
fruit is practice. To the contrary, in this context, fruit is not practice, and
faith is not works. Rather, those who have faith in their works are rightly
condemned for such erroneous faith and works. The dual basis for
condemnation is quite understandable: defective faith and defective works.
Justification, on the other hand, is based on faith apart from works. God’s
singular will (as it pertains to our soteric justification) is that we produce the
singular response of saving faith, not that we also produce saving works.
Those who misconstrue this passage so as to teach that the way we do God’s
will (as it pertains to entering heaven) is to produce morally good fruits are
producing soteriologically poisonous fruits instead.

      223
          Ibid., 456. Likewise in his Gospel, MacArthur says, “Salvation is a
gift, yet it costs everything” (p. 47). He mistakenly thinks that he can justify
Page 410                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
such a statement by claiming that salvation “is defined by what it produces,
not by what one does to get it” (p. 48). Not so! Salvation is a gift. Paul
defines a gift as a benefit that is not a result of works (Eph 2:8-9). If the
benefit is the result of the recipient’s works, even if those works are divinely
enabled, then the benefit is not a gift. Since MacArthur missed this point,
perhaps it would be wise to spell it out:

     1. Salvation is a gift.
     2. A gift is not a result of works.
     3. Salvation as a gift is not a result of works.

Contrary to MacArthur, since salvation is a gift, it is defined most
emphatically not just by what it produces but additionally by what one does
to get it.
      224
           By his own definition of saving faith, MacArthur makes eternal life
costly from its conception: “Saving faith is an exchange of all that we have
for all that Christ is” (Gospel, 151). Coming to Christ in saving faith will
cost you everything in MacArthurian soteriology—a fact he conveniently
seems to forget when it gets in his way. In fact, he even denies the obvious
implication of his own statement on this very page: “This does not mean that
we barter for eternal life. We do not buy salvation by surrendering our
lives.”
      To the contrary, if one must exchange one’s life for eternal life, then it
is a barter. The primary passage to which MacArthur appeals to back up his
argument on this page is that of the labors in the vineyard (Mt 20:1-16). This
parable shows a combination of condign and congruent merit. (See Laborers
in the Vineyard, 321 herein.) MacArthur acts as if this parable is devoid of
merit, despite the fact that their recompense/payment is based on their
works! MacArthur thinks that the denarius that they are paid as a result of
their work represents eternal life associated with entrance into the kingdom
of heaven (p. 153). According to this perspective, what they were working to
get was eternal life in heaven. If they did not work, they would not be
allowed into this MacArthurian heaven. Yet somehow in this MacArthurian
reconstruction, entrance into heaven is supposedly not granted on the basis
of works! MacArthur insists elsewhere, with typical MacArthurian
inconsistency, that we must buy our entrance into heaven. (See endnote 52
herein.) In reality, he has done no better in his present discussion.
      MacArthur completely misconstrues the parable into teaching an
unmerited entrance into heaven based on an “equality of eternal life” for
kingdom workers (p. 155). Far to the contrary, there is a basic equality of
kingdom reward for faithful kingdom workers. Quite possibly, what some
workers lack in terms of greater misthological works may be made up for by
greater misthological faith. Even amidst the basic misthological equality,
Endnotes                                                               Page 411
there is a hint of potential misthological inequality: “The last shall be first,
and the first last” (Mt 20:16).

      226
          I have already quoted Shank and shown that he regards the reception
and retention of the free gift of eternal life to be costly and a reward (see his
p. 281). For defense of his premise, Shank refers his readers back to his
second chapter: “The High Cost of a Free Gift.” That chapter is simply a
defense of the type of Lordship Salvation popularly espoused by MacArthur.
In that chapter, Shank claims: “Salvation costs men nothing . . . and
everything” (ellipsis his; p. 17). The gift of salvation is costly….It costs
everyone who receives it the total submission of self” (p. 18). That pseudo
Lordship Salvationists like Shank believe that the gift is costly to the
recipient is easy to see. How they can simultaneously demonstrate, with
logical consistency, that is also free is impossible to perceive.
      Although Brown’s statement and illustration that the reception of the
free gift is indeed free have been well received herein, one cannot help but
wonder if his attempt to make the reception of salvation free is anything
more than an artificial attempt to try and reconcile the irreconcilable tension
between the alleged freeness of the gift and its costliness in Arminianism
and Calvinism. Would Brown really denounce Shank as teaching a false
gospel because Shank makes the reception of the gift costly? Would Brown
be willing to affirm that submission to Christ’s mastery in regard to one’s
performance is not a requirement for the reception of eternal life? Or has
Brown merely affirmed the fact that the free gift is free to receive in order to
try to squelch his critics with a gloss? Because one can only wonder, if God
gives eternal life as a free gift independent of initial performance, why
would God turn around and take it away because of subsequent
performance? If repentance in terms of performance is not required to
receive the gift, then why is it required to keep the gift? Brown’s brand of
Arminianism appears to be just as logically inconsistent, if not more so, than
that offered by Shank.

         Piper rather candidly admits that, from his perspective, what Jesus
did for us on the cross was crucially “necessary but not enough.” “Future
grace” (in terms of the God-enabled performance) is necessary to keep Piper
and his wife soterically “in Christ.” “The backward look [to what Jesus did
for us on the cross] is not enough” (Battling, 113-114). The Piperean view of
Jesus would have believers look back on Jesus’ cross and cry out, “It is not
enough!” rather than, “It is finished!”
Endnotes                                                           Page 413
                       Illustration 146. Is it finished?




      Lest one respond that according to Piper the ground/basis is finished,
let me clarify why according to the implications of Piper’s theology the
necessary work performed by Jesus is not finished. Piper’s theology requires
that Jesus infuse us, on a day-by-day basis, with His energizing power and
that we respond by performing good works through this power in order to
stay saved. What Jesus does through us in terms of daily performance is an
additional necessity over and beyond what Jesus did for us on the cross in
order for us to reach Piperean heaven. Getting to heaven is not just a matter
of our performing good works; it is a matter of Jesus performing these good
works through us. Whereas our performance may be the condition; Jesus’
ongoing post-conversional performance is made the basis for our final
justification in Piperean soteriology. Jesus still has a lot of unfinished,
necessary work to do in getting believers to Piperean heaven.

      264
          Pertaining to the wedding garments in Mt 22:12, additional literary
and historical evidence is cited by commentators both for and against the
theory that the wedding garments were provided by the host. In Lenski’s
opinion, the evidence that the garments were provided “is quite sufficient”
(Matthew, 857). Blomberg only acknowledges that it “is quite possible” that
the garments were provided (Matthew, 329). Carson is skeptical and says
that the evidence that the garments were provided “is inadequate” (Matthew,
457). Turner is even more skeptical and states that it “is weak” (Matthew,
524). Morris goes so far as to state that the “evidence that this sort of thing
was done in ancient times is lacking” (Mathew, 552). Nolland swings the
pendulum completely away from the provided-theory by citing an
extrabiblical parable in which fools were excluded because of their soiled
attire. He concludes that “at whatever level was within their reach, people
dressed up for special occasions. Freshly washed garments and lower
hemlines probably provided a minimal differentiation” (Matthew, 890).
Although he mistakenly equates the righteous here with that of Mt 5:20 and
wrongly thinks that Mt 5:20 is referring to the “practice of righteousness” (p.
225), at least Nolland correctly associates the personal washing motif with
personal righteousness. Turner states that “most scholars tend to think of it
in terms of personal righteousness” (p. 525, n. 6). Morris notes that viewing
these garments as “meritorious works” is one of the basic options among
commentators (Mathew, 552). Thinking in terms of similar options between
imputed versus practical righteousness, Michael Wilkins tries to avoid the
conclusion that the latter would entail merit: “Others suggest that this refers
to clean garments as opposed to dirty ones, not symbolizing works meriting
salvation but evidential works of righteousness for those already having
obtained salvation” (Matthew, 717). Numerous weaknesses have been
shown in the present book in appealing to works as mere evidence of
Endnotes                                                             Page 415
salvation. Suffice it to say that Wilkins has not been completely
straightforward about the evidence.
      First, Wilkins misleads his readers into thinking that commentators do
not regard the works as meritorious. Morris, in contrast, states that they do
regard them as meritorious. Second, scholarly opinion aside for the moment,
the most natural interpretation of the parable is that the wedding garments
are conditional, not merely evidential. Third, returning to scholarly opinion,
Mounce (citing Fenton) sees the garments as “a new life of good works”
(Matthew, 206). Even if Mounce is thinking in terms of necessary evidence
so that these works demonstrate whether or not one is elect, he, like
Edwards, obviously regards these works as judicial evidence: “The verses
warn believers without a changed life that they will be rejected at the Last
Judgment” (p. 206). The believers’ outcome is conditioned on the garments
they wear. The Judge will pronounce His verdict in harmony with the
evidence. Appealing to the works as evidential fails to make them less than
works—meritorious works at that—upon which one’s fate is conditioned.
France says that there is “no relevant evidence” that the garment was
provided. Like Mounce and Fenton, he believes that it refers to the good life
a believer must produce. “Without it, there can be no guarantee of security”
(Matthew, 313). Frankly, for conditional securitists, it does not matter if the
garments are imputed or imparted. Insecuritists still will find works
necessary for security.
      In this brief survey, the pendulum of scholarly opinion swings from
viewing the garments as provided clothing to merely washed clothing.
Although some commentators are less than candid about the conditional
nature of the garments, the conditionality is readily apparent. Whether the
garments refer to imputed or imparted righteousness, this righteousness is
required to attend the feast. Consequently, the believer’s outcome is
conditioned on the clothing the believer is wearing. If the garments were
provided, then the prevalent opinion is that they refer to imputed (alien)
righteousness. However, the garments still could refer to imparted
righteousness even if they are provided. The parallel in Rev 19:8 is highly
suggestive of this possibility. The bride is to produce her own white
garments consisting of personal righteousness through the means provided.
Most likely, the garments refer to imparted righteousness even if the
garments are provided. And the garments almost definitely refer to imparted
(personal) righteousness if they are not provided. Therefore, regardless of
the historical backdrop, understanding the garments as referring to practical
righteousness is most advisable. In harmony with Rev 22:14, a misthological
understanding of the garments as being washed garments is to be preferred.
If believers wish to be allowed to attend the feast, then they must produce
clean garments. The Lord provides the water and soap. Believers though
provide the labor to produce the personal holiness necessary to attend the
feast.
Page 416                            Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity
      Carson practically trips over the significance of the garments without
realizing it: “It is difficult to believe that the wedding clothes symbolize
righteousness, unless we construe it as a righteousness essential not to enter
but to remain there” (Matthew, 457). Indeed! The man in the parable had
righteousness sufficient to enter the feast but not enough to stay. The most
reasonable deduction is that imputed righteousness allowed him to enter, but
lack of practical righteousness prevented him from remaining. Salvation
from the outer darkness into which he was cast in the next verse (Mt 22:13)
was conditioned on his personal works of righteousness. Wash up or be
kicked out! The significance of his being allowed into the feast but not being
allowed to stay is explained in The Outer Darkness and strongly supports
several conclusions: (1) the outer darkness is not hell, (2) the garments refer
to imparted righteousness, (3) soteriological security is unconditionally
guaranteed, and (4) misthological security is not unconditionally guaranteed.
        265
            Lordship Salvationists confuse the broad and narrow meanings of
the gospel so as to lead the unsuspecting public into thinking that the Free
Grace exclusion of repentance from the heart of the gospel necessarily
amounts to a Free Grace exclusion of repentance from the gospel altogether.
By appealing to the popular sentiment that the gospel is equatable with the
saving message that must be believed to be born again and then inserting the
requirement for repentance into that meaning, Lordship Salvationists have
corrupted the gospel. Contrary to their claims, the gospel does not condition
salvation from hell on repentance. Biblically, the gospel, in both its broad
and narrow forms, never conditions the free gift of eternal life on
repentance.

           Perhaps not so incidentally, John does use the word gospel in
Revelation where there are numerous calls to repentance and omits the word

Lordship interpreters give him credit.
      268
          Renaming the Gospel of John technically satisfies the Lordship
Salvationist demand and arguably might be accurate biblically, but it will
certainly fail to satisfy public consensus or even Lordship Salvationists.
Lordship Salvationists are not pursuing technical accuracy when they insist
that the gospel of Jesus includes repentance; instead, they are trying to sway
public sentimentality (so as to make repentance a soteric necessity—contrary
to John).
